0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23325/homepage_large.9d47b66c.jpg|Fantasma|832.0|Cornelius|['Electronic']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Lefse']|2016-06-11|1997|2016-06-11 15:46:03.478334|"

 By the mid-‘90s
column2: Japanese pop culture had peaked in global coolness. Anime and video games enthralled kids all over the globe
column3: and author Haruki Murakami was starting to gain traction in the English-language world. And although it might not have been  quite as universal as Pokemon
column4: Shibuya-kei music was winning praise from Western listeners. The genre’s mish-mash of sonic references and samples spanning the entire 20th century caught the ears of non-Japanese labels
column5: leading to the ‘60s-swooning of Pizzicato Five and lounge-tronica of Fantastic Plastic Machine seeing widespread release. Nothing captured as much critical attention
column6: however
column7: as Keigo Oyamada’s Cornelius project
column8: whose 1997 album Fantasma came out Stateside one year later via Matador Records. Soon after
column9: the Shibuya-kei movement became oversaturated and its biggest names drifted to new sounds.

column1: Fantasma marked the high point for the movement
column2: and has since been celebrated as the style’s ultimate triumph. The Japanese music media isn’t big on “all-time” lists
column3: but when the mood strikes
column4: Cornelius’ third proper album always winds up in the top ten. All this canonization has the side effect of making Fantasma feel like an artifact
column5: a musical museum devoted to a scene that could never exist outside of ‘90s Tokyo. Portland-based imprint Lefse’s new vinyl reissue—featuring four enjoyable bonus tracks
column6: albeit songs that aren’t on the album for a reason —reminds that what makes this set of songs special hasn’t aged. Like Endtroducing… or Discovery
column7: Fantasma took the (often literal) sounds of the past to create something new and exciting
column8: while also ending up a celebration of the process of finding
column9: listening and creating music.

column1: It’s fitting Shibuya-kei’s finest statement came courtesy of one of the people most central to its emergence. Coming of age during Japan’s economically booming Bubble years
column2: Oyamada had time to play in bands and spend hours exploring Tokyo’s well-stocked record stores. Alongside Kenji Ozawa in the group Flipper’s Guitar
column3: he crafted songs drawing inspiration from all sorts of eclectic sources—the Scottish post-punk of Orange Juice
column4: Madchester
column5: bossa nova
column6: the Monkees’ movie debut Head. Despite a tendency to swipe melodies wholesale
column7: they pushed a slew of new sounds into the Japanese music conscience.

column1: Alongside Pizzicato Five and a few other groups introducing unfamiliar styles
column2: Flipper’s Guitar’s CDs sold extremely well at Shibuya music stores—well enough that they snuck into the nation’s album charts. The media
column3: smelling a trend
column4: called it Shibuya-kei (literally
column5: Shibuya style). From there
column6: new artists emerged
column7: not united by a specific sound but rather an ethos that writer W. David Marx pins as “pastiche and bricolage
column8: ” offering an alternative to mainstream J-pop. Oyamada launched a label
column9: Trattoria
column10: sharing music from names such as Kahimi Karie and Hideki Kaji
column11: and started his solo career as Cornelius
column12: releasing two albums that found him caught between singer-songwriter and musical curator. He also starred in a Shibuya-kei-tinged hair mousse ad.

column1: Fantasma
column2: though
column3: promised something different and more daring. Whereas previous Cornelius albums launched right into sunny horn fanfare
column4: “Mic Check” begins with a faint click and a lot of space. Someone puffs a cigarette
column5: a can cracks open
column6: and somebody whistles a portion of Beethoven’s 5th. Early copies of Fantasma came packaged with earphones
column7: and “Mic Check” quickly establishes why—it’s a producer’s album
column8: one where every sound is labored over and plays a role in the greater journey. Oyamada wants the listener to be adequately ready for this—“can you hear me?” he asks in Japanese—so that they don’t miss any detail
column9: before letting a semi-song bloom around them.

column1: From there
column2: Oyamada treats listener to a smörgåsbord of musical thrills. His songs here frequently jump between headphone channels—the dizzying Speak & Spell rock of “Count Five or Six” being a great example of this technique—while going one step further by playing around with the idea of recording music. Side two of the record starts with “Chapter 8 (Seashore and Horizon)
column3: ” which opens with Robert Schneider and Hilarie Sidney of the Apples in Stereo performing a very Apples-in-Stereo-sounding song. But before a minute can pass
column4: someone hits the stop button on a cassette player
column5: and Oyamada jumps in with his own interpretation of sweetly sung indie-pop
column6: the sort of number that could easily slide into the Elephant 6 catalog. Then the player clicks again
column7: the tape rewinds
column8: and the Apples come back in frame.

column1: “Fantasma is a kind of album that only has one entrance and one exit. That is
column2: you can’t listen to if from the middle
column3: ” Oyamada told a magazine around the album’s release. As the defining Shibuya-kei full-length
column4: it’s loaded up with references to obscure older music spliced with styles that were
column6: fresh—drum ‘n’ bass drills through tropicália on album centerpiece “Star Fruits Surf Rider
column7: ” while “Monkey” jams samples sourced from R&B and an old record starring Mr. Magoo to create a playful romp that’s the most stereotypically Shibuya-kei-sounding thing here—but Oyamada wasn’t simply flexing his deep record collection. Sounds reappear frequently across Fantasma
column8: songs referencing one another in subtle ways—early English-language reviews tended to knock Cornelius for having too much going on
column9: but Oyamada knew exactly what he was doing with the rush of noises. Everything ends up in its right place
column10: making for a more cohesive and intimate listen.

column1: And that’s fitting
column2: as Fantasma celebrates the process of discovery and falling in love with music. Shibuya-kei was built on crate-digging discoveries
column3: but oftentimes could come off as simplistic (or
column4: at worst
column5: trying to be too cool with nothing but some obscure records). But only Fantasma peers into the actual act of listening. Half of the songs here feature no coherent lyrics
column6: but when words do come through
column7: they capture the feeling of being at a concert (“Clash”) or shutting out the world via headphones (“New Music Machine”). Sudden shifts in style even make sense within Fantasma’s walls—the twinkling
column8: childhood collage of “The Micro Disneycal World Tour” gives way to the feedback-soaked
column9: adolescent thrash of “New Music Machine.”

column1: Nearly every song title on Fantasma references an existing musical group
column2: obscure or world famous
column3: but it feels like an act of grateful tribute rather than a hip name-check. With Flipper’s Guitar
column4: Oyamada straight-up sampled chunks of the Beach Boys “God Only Knows
column5: ” but on his own “God Only Knows” he spends the track’s seven-minute-plus run time weaving an intricate pop production inspired by (but never directly taking from) Brian Wilson (and quoting another Oyamada favorite
column6: the Jesus And Mary Chain). He reveals his intention with the penultimate number
column7: “Thank You For the Music
column8: ” which acknowledges all of his musical heroes
column9: along with the listeners who came along for the Fantasma ride
column10: all over a folksy backing track that makes way for a rapid-fire collage of sounds heard over the course of the album...a reminder of the last 50-some minutes.

column1: A lot of Shibuya-kei in 2016 sounds extremely dated
column2: and it’s not totally the fault of the music for this. A big draw of the style was how the artist themselves served as a curator for the audience
column3: funneling the forgotten sounds of yesteryear to a new audience. But the internet has completely changed the concept of curation—anyone can become an expert on niche styles with some focused Wikipedia digging
column4: while the idea of finding a new perspective to old sounds has been replaced with “make me a playlist that sounds best while I’m in the bath.” Not to say there aren’t perks to a digital reality—I downloaded Fantasma off Soulseek in 2005
column5: and it’s easier to find Shibuya-kei deep cuts on YouTube now rather than go to the actual Shibuya neighborhood.

column1: But Fantasma distills the spirit and process of Shibuya-kei down to its purest essence and still sound warm and celebratory today. He imagined musical utopia
column2: where genre lines fade easily and where geographic borders can vanish (in 2016
column3: Japanese artists construct their own imagined versions of albums because of streaming exclusivity). In the ‘90s
column4: Cornelius caught attention for a cool sound that earned him comparisons to Beck
column5:
but it’s the sense of sheer joy and excitement running through Fantasma that still makes it an exhilarating listen today.

On his third proper solo album
column4: Alexis Taylor puts aside all semblance of pop affectations in favor of something totally sparse and infinitely more vulnerable: a record composed entirely of piano and voice. Recorded at Hackney Road Studios
column5: the aptly-named Piano is not only the most straightforward thing the usually cheeky Hot Chip frontman has ever released
column6: it’s also the most surprisingly personal. Taylor has always had a knack for embedding wistfulness and bittersweet melancholia into pristinely rendered pop songs. With Piano Taylor peels back any kind of artifice
column7: offering a collection of songs that examine mortality
column8: religion
column9: and the creative impulse itself.

column1: The album opens with “I’m Ready”—a song that correlates the creative process with a kind of expansive emotional openness. “Don’t you know I’m ready?” sings Taylor. “Don’t you know I’m healthy? Nowhere else I’d rather be/Nothing to protect me/No one to defend me.” The song
column2: which is carried aloft by Taylor’s lovely but unfussy piano playing
column3: speaks to vulnerability at the core of the record. The idea of emotional nakedness as reflected by this sort of stripped back
column4: bare-bones performance style is certainly nothing new
column5: but it’s a conceit that works nicely here
column6: showcasing just how genuinely sweet Taylor’s voice actually is. This is particularly true on the record’s two standout covers—a take on Artie Glenn’s “Crying in the Chapel” (a song made famous by Elvis in 1965) and
column7: even more odd and sublime
column8: a gorgeous version of Crystal Gayle’s 1977 hit
column9: “Don’t It Make My Brown Eyes Blue.” Stripped of its more obvious gospel tropes
column10: the former plays like a love song to serenity
column11: a paean for the peace that comes with surrendering to a higher power or some great love. With his quietly non-ironic dissection of the latter
column12: Taylor gets to the sticky emotional core of Gayle’s song—i.e. the pain of being tossed aside for someone else—and delivers it with devastating ease: “Tell me you love me and don’t let me cry/Say anything but don’t say goodbye.”

column1: Of the original songs on Piano
column2: the most interesting of the lot are oblique examinations of spirituality
column3: all rendered from the stance of the unbeliever. “In the Light of the Room” and “I Never Lock That Door” each unspool with the rhythms of an old country song or a hymn
column4: the divinity at their centers less about any specific god but rather sourced from a sense of love
column5: goodness
column6: and wholeness that exists only in the abstract. (“There’s one place that’s always open/And you’ll find me if you’re hoping/to be mine for all of time/I never lock that door.”) In the liner notes for Piano Taylor admits that many of these songs are meant to “celebrate lives of friends now passed
column7: as well as love for those closest to us
column8: and music itself.” On the elegiac “So Much Further to Go” Taylor balances the urge to bring something new into the world against the crushing brevity of human experience
column9: describing life itself as “a miracle that's hard to bear
column10: ” while on album-closing “Don’t Worry” he intones
column11: “If I’m gone away
column12: don’t worry/It is only forever” as if to remind us that life is short
column13: but also sometimes unbearably and stupidly long.

column1: It would be easy to dismiss Piano as a slight addition to Taylor’s discography
column2: but that would be wrong. The quiet humanity in these songs is disarmingly simple at first
column3: but these sentiments creep up on you
column4: giving credence to the notion that it’s in these private moments of contemplation where the narratives of our lives are ultimately assembled. “In the light of the room/Through a window dappled/I was dreaming of you/And of all that’s happened
column5: ” Taylor sings on “In the Light of the Room.” It’s the kind of simple moment of observation that Piano is full of. Taylor is no stranger to wearing his heart on his sleeve
column6: Piano takes that notion one step further— it’s as if Taylor is taking his heart out for everyone to see
column7:
then discreetly leaving it on your coffee table.

Ladyhawke’s 2012 album
column3: Anxiety was as much a “difficult sophomore album” as one’s likely to hear this decade: On it
column4: New Zealand-born Philippa “Pip” Brown killed the ‘80s buzz of her debut with prickly pop-punk exploring some of the loneliest and least-fun emotions the human brain concocts. For that
column5: it’s underrated. But it’s understandable that Brown would want to retreat from it
column6: as much for its tepid reception as for her  reported state of mind while making it. “I’d never done a sober show in my life until last December
column7: ” Brown said; years of chasing social anxiety with alcohol gave way to detox and therapy and the pilgrimage to L.A. all early-to-mid-career musicians take eventually; from it emerged a happier person and
column8: consequentially
column9: a happier album. Who can fault that?

column1: Wild Things announces its shinier
column2: almost-perfectly-happy intentions immediately with “A Love Song
column3: ” another entry in the long and usually-pretty-great tradition of unabashed pop songs whose self-referential brightness conceals something dark and whose every line—“you’ve opened my eyes to the oldest tale of time
column4: ” “you pull me up and tell me how this could end”—works equally well as love or tragedy. Brown repeats the title to the point of insistence
column5: or even defensiveness
column6: like she’s distracting herself from something dark and unspoken.  The ambiguity is crucial; so is the exuberant pop rush.

column1: In abandoning the spikier sound of Anxiety for more straightforward synth-pop
column2: though
column3: Ladyhawke returns to one of the most overcrowded genres going
column4: where thousands vie for maybe a few months of syncs and a lifetime of anonymity. Too much of Wild Things is aimed little higher than that – most audibly on “Golden Girl
column5: ” on its polite throb to the Lumineers “hey!”s to the synths that suggest pre-ubiquity La Roux to the distressingly ukulele-like line you can almost smell the lemon Pledge on. It raises two questions: A) whether it’s already in an ad
column6: or just sounds like it’s already in one
column7: via Pavlovian association
column8: and B) whether it’s mistagged and actually by Catey “Brooklyn Girls” Shaw.

column1: “Wild Things” suffers the same; its graceful sweep and confessions so plainspoken (“when you’re almost always lonely
column2: you forget to take it slowly”) mean little when they’re in the service of a Where the Wild Things Are allusion that was dead long before its corpse was fireside-tromped over in the past decade by Spike Jonze and Alessia Cara. It sounds well enough like 2016 and its trends
column3: but it barely sounds like Ladyhawke. (Ladyhawke was ahead of these trends
column4: too—synthpop most obviously
column5: but also “Paris Is Burning
column6: ” which if it were released today would fit right into the crowd of disco licks and vaguely house-ish beats.) For every inspired touch—the backing-vocal frisson and ABBA-esque sweep to the melody of “Chills”—there’s an underwritten chorus
column7: or a thin arrangement
column8: or a lyrical complication avoided.

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: Wild Things’ thorniness
column3: however intermittent
column4: is its best strength. “Let It Roll” has a clattery
column5: deliberately crowded arrangement
column6: guitar tremors off a LoneLady track and Brown’s best vocal mode: tensed-throat stress and tamped-down shyness so fully expressed that they come off as rock-star swagger. Likewise
column7: the disco chorus and New Order synth latticework on “Dangerous” aren’t new
column8: but they at least live up to their title
column9: and to Brown’s older material. But there’s not nearly enough of it. There could have been; before Wild Things
column10: Brown scrapped an entire album that
column11: from press indications
column12: probably sounded a lot like Anxiety; neither she nor the people she said heard it was happy with the results
column13: but one wonders if it was really that bad
column14:
or just not commercial and crowd-pleasing enough. Wild Things collapses over the strain to be both.

Well
column2: nobody will be calling Fear of Men twee anymore. On the Brighton band’s debut album Loom
column3: Jessica Weiss voiced some seriously dark
column4: at times even-morbid sentiments
column5: but they were undercut by disarming jangle-pop guitars and sprightly rhythms that made it difficult to take her at her word. Thirty years of conditioning have taught us to associate these sounds with levity—after all

column9: though
column10: the band eliminates the disconnect between Weiss’ bleak prose and their delivery system. Any element with even the slightest whiff of Camera Obscura has been replaced by extraterrestrial synths
column11: ominously bowed bass
column12: and guitars distorted beyond recognition. It’s fitting the trio recorded it in a repurposed slaughterhouse
column13:
because Fall Forever is the work of a band gutting its sound and watching it bleed out.

“Vesta” introduces the album with a jolt of warped
column14: digitally manipulated noise
column15: a throat clearing of sorts meant to announce the new direction. Like many of the album’s highlights

column25:
a detour from which it never returns.

Even the album’s most straightforward dream-pop tunes are battered by sharp
column26: militaristic snares. They create a sense of flagellation that’s driven home by Weiss’ relentless lyrical focus on how much pain and punishment she can withstand
column27: and her repeated assertions that she doesn’t need the intimacy that’s withheld from her. “I’m like an island
column29: “I don’t need to feel your arms around me.” Nonetheless
column30: she internalizes the rejection. It manifests itself in a resentment of her own “vile body
column31: ” which she describes variously as made of wax and stone

column34:
it’s the album’s poppiest number.  

Weiss fills Fall Forever with lyrics like that
column37: leaving the physical world behind and transcending morality. That tight thematic focus means that the songs sometimes bleed together—many feel like minor rewrites of the one that came directly before it—yet the repetition feels deliberate
column38: like part of a calculated do-over. “Without a body

so it’s as if she’s vowed to repeat herself until the words sink in. This time they do.

Garbage would sooner risk obsolescence than fake a smile. The industry learned this the hard way in 2001 when they tried to steer the band back to the mainstream following the commercial failure of their third record Beautiful Garbage
column2: released three weeks after 9/11. Hoping for a smooth transition onto the pop-and-rap-glutted charts
column3: label executives approached frontwoman Shirley Manson and producers-slash-bandmates Duke Erikson
column4: Steve Marker
column5: and Butch Vig demanding rapped guest verses and pop hooks. They got the same old Garbage instead: seething
column6: surging
column7: brutal–Billboard potential be damned.

column1: Fifteen years later
column2: Garbage have outlasted the naysayers and jilted ex-lovers. 2012’s Not Your Kind of People couldn’t match the sonic cohesion and thrills of 1995's self-titled debut and Version 2.0
column3: but as the band’s first effort in seven years
column4: it also provided an oasis for all those jaded by EDM's brainless
column5: bro-y #posivibes. With their post-return jitters under control
column6: the band have solidified that return with Strange Little Birds
column7: their darkest
column8: most intimate LP and the band’s strongest effort in 15 years.

column1: Manson's been happily married for six years (her husband
column2: Billy Bush
column3: co-produced this album and its predecessor)
column4: but she’ll never get over misery
column5: her lifelong muse; like all Garbage albums
column6: Strange Little Birds obsesses over
column7: romanticizes
column8: and even celebrates sorrow. On the lead single “Empty
column9: ” she towers over her bandmates’ roaring void with arms akimbo
column10: underscoring her woe by way of dramatic
column11: elongated syllables; “I’m sooooo empty
column12: ” she moans
column13: quaking atop Vig and Erikson's steeled groove. “Night Drive Loneliness
column14: ” a ballad inspired by a piece of fan-mail thrust into Manson's hand following a Garbage gig in Russia
column15: develops its titular subject as a sensual ritual. Considered in tandem with the track’s slinky lounge arrangement and boudoir imagery (“I got my high heels/and my lipstick/My blue velvet dress in my closet”)
column16: Manson's sighing refrain–“My night drive loneliness comes again and again”–hints at a more hopeful subtext: perhaps depression's just another nameless paramour occupying the passenger seat
column17: another car whizzing by in the night.

column1: Of course
column2: the same could be said for love. Every glimpse of romantic bliss on Strange Little Birds–the galvanizing lust on “Magnetized
column3: ” the stolen glances of “We Never Tell”–ultimately dissolves under Manson’s fatalist approach to matters of the heart. Although she’s come a long way from the paranoid interrogations of the Bleed Like Me era (“I think you’re sleeping with a friend of mine/I have no proof
column4: but I think that I’m right""; “Why Do You Love Me?”) the front-woman still regards love as a rigged game–one she’s happy to play
column5: because she’s got nothing else to lose. Midway through the album
column6: on the funereal choruses of “Even Though Our Love Is Doomed
column7: ” Manson soberly proclaims the song’s titular sentiment to deliver a message of hope
column8: not fear: “Even though our stars are crossed/You’re the only thing worth fighting for/You’re the only thing worth dying for.” Elsewhere
column9: “Sometimes” and “Amends”–Strange Little Birds’ respective opener and closer– fashion Manson's philosophy into an olive branch extended to her already-“doomed” loves: “There is nothing you could say/To cause more hurt
column10: or cause me shame/Than all the things that I have thought about myself
column11: ” she admits.

column1: Strange Little Birds lands less than a year after Garbage’s 20th-anniversary reissue of 1995’s landmark self-titled debut
column2: and while the new album’s sessions predate Garbage’s commemoration festivities
column3: their temporal and stylistic overlap sets it apart from the similarly-styled but unevenly executed band have released over the past fifteen years. Indeed

column5: and far from subtle: “Empty” and “Supervixen” share the same glam-industrial DNA
column6: and the dreary “Blackout” employs the same skittering trip-hop showcased in “A Stroke of Luck.” Despite these superficial similarities
column7: repeat spins of Strange Little Birds ultimately belie an older
column8: wiser reincarnation of that youthful rage
column9: not just a cheap retrospective. Twenty years on
column10: Garbage are still grappling with their demons
column11: but they’re disarmingly zen–even ecstatic– about the battle. With material like this
column12:
they’ve got a right to be.

Speedy Ortiz have done great things with the extended play format. 2012’s excellent Sports foreshadowed the big statement that their full-length debut

column1: The Open Mike Eagle remix is built upon the “So I’m the god of the liars” line
column2: with the occasional whisper of “Poseying in prose again.” The remix could work well as a meditation soundtrack
column3: allowing the listeners’ minds to melt away while they consider what being the god of the liars truly means. It’s an underwhelming way to end an EP
column4: but also allows the two original tracks to truly shine.

column1: The title of opener “Death Note” is an allusion to a Japanese manga series about a notebook that kills anyone whose name is written within its pages. Speedy Ortiz leave the supernatural references at the start; the notebooks mentioned in “Death Note” are tools to work through melancholy. There’s an undeniable heaviness to the track
column2: especially when Dupuis seems to corner the unknown subject and pleads
column3: “How often can I say it until you believe?/They were all love letters/These are all love letters to me.” “A death note can be [a] kind of love letter to yourself
column4: “ Dupuis has explained. This paradoxical logic nails
column5: lyrically
column6: what makes Speedy Ortiz so special: their ability to flit between worlds of darkness and light.

column1: “Emma O” continues Foiled Again’s transition into the dark side
column2: especially once one considers that Emm-O is the Japanese judge of the dead. It’s a slow tale of forced time spent with a lover and the ambivalent feelings that follow. There’s a wallowing bit of distortion near the middle of the song like a gray cloud over a cartoon character
column3: just a perceptible reminder that the song is dark. Shortly after comes the line “Your 27
column4: Emma-O you read the masters but you still don’t know about love” which manages to be heartbreaking while also eerily resembling a Belle and Sebastian lyric. Like “Death Note
column5: ” which ends with the reassurance that “These are all love letters to me
column6: ” “Emma O” ends with the aphorism “I never wanna come for you again/I only want your comfort.” Speedy Ortiz are careful about which lyrics they choose to turn into mantras
column7: and the brief punch offered by those in “Death Note” and “Emma O” are more enriching than “Puffer.”

column1: Foiled Again is a mixed bag. On one hand
column2: there are two great tracks that
column3: for whatever reason
column4: didn’t make it onto Foil Deer and are now seeing the light of day. Then there are the two remixes
column5: one of which is considerably stronger than the other. Combining these four songs results in a strange listen; the two new songs could stand on their own as singles
column6: same with the remixes. Nonetheless
column7: Foiled Again confirms that Speedy Ortiz are exploring new territory
column8:
and it will be exciting to see how they break their own molds next.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23341/homepage_large.35984cc6.jpg|Victorious |33773.0|Floorplan|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['M-Plant']|2016-06-10 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:04.569572|"

If you’ve read an interview with Robert Hood in the last few years
column2: you'll see that the Detroit techno pioneer obsessed with one question: What is the difference between an energetic Sunday morning at church and the rapturous hours of dawn spent at the club? To him
column3: they both aspire to the same physical and experiential ends. Be it dark room or wooden pew
column4: you should find yourself swaying
column5: head to the floor
column6: singing praises to something beyond yourself. They both function
column7: at some deeper level
column8: in the realm of the sublime and the ecstatic. For the last decade he’s lived in rural Alabama and has been working as a practicing minister when he’s not on tour. While the lifestyles might suggest a radical disjuncture
column9: he thinks that they have to inform each other.  And the music he’s released under Floorplan has been his primary vehicle for exploring the more spiritual ends of his musical identity.

column1: He’s appeared as Floorplan on and off since 1996
column2: but a full album of work didn’t materialize until 2013’s Paradise
column3: a kind of career retrospective for the moniker. Overall
column4: Floorplan is a departure from his epochal minimal techno work
column5: orbiting instead around disco
column6: gospel
column7: and house. He’s also released some of his most iconic tracks as Floorplan
column8: including “Never Grow Old
column9: ” which is a template for what you can expect structurally and thematically: exuberantly looped chants and a professorial level of attention to detail
column10: both in production and song craft. And now he’s invited his teenage daughter
column11: Lyric Hood
column12: to co-produce the second full-length Floorplan album
column13: Victorious
column14: a 75 minute long test of Hood’s spiritual dance music.

column1: His daughter first joined him behind the decks as a sixteen-year-old
column2: and after a spat of touring that included a rather heartfelt closing set at Dekmantel last year
column3: she’s helped co-produce much of Victorious. You can sense the youthful energy she imparts all over Victorious
column4: which benefits from hanging a tad looser than Paradise. It’s eleven tracks are more open
column5: more anthemic
column6: and brighter than much of what Hood has done in the past.

column1: It opens with the six-minute “Spin
column2: ” a clinic on structuring a house-music single
column3: fashioned from effortlessly timed cues
column4: jump cuts
column5: and studied progressions. There’s a moment in “Spin” when the beat becomes vaporous and then solidifies
column6: giving you a sense of how physical Hood can make electronic music feel. This physicality is made even more clear in the particularly religious-minded tracks like “The Heavens & The Earth” where a hypnotic reading of the opening lines of Genesis is placed on top of a warm pulsating synth. The line between club and church is forcefully collapsed
column7: and it’s well-argued case study for the spiritual goals for this kind of music.

column1: For all the seamless transitions within tracks
column2: Victorious can feel a little incoherent as a whole. The tracks often end abruptly
column3: closing their loops before they can pleasantly spill into the next moment. There is repetitiveness to the song structures that can feel predictable at a certain point. While you can sense something clunky about how these songs work as as a full unit
column4: individually the tracks overcome the album’s shortcomings by not feeling overcrowded or overproduced. There is something delightfully dispassionate about the way they can reframe and reign in uncontrollable funk in “Tell You No Lie” or slyly weave a sermon in between the thumps of “He Can Save You.” But then other instances like “Ha Ya” can feel phoned in
column5: and somehow the differences between each track can start still feel superficial on repeated listens.

column1: Perhaps the biggest limitation to it all is that Victorious is in no way a headphone listen. It is constrained by site specificity. If there is a possible maximum-pleasure listening experience it will come from luxuriating in this music very loudly and perfectly articulated over multiple sets of speakers. Perhaps this is true of all dance music
column2: but the thesis of Floorplan is especially grounded in a communal experience. In order to really have that ecstatic event Hood aims for
column3: you simply cannot be behind a pair of headphones. Victorious is filled with moments that give you glimpses of the club in heaven
column4: but like the afterlife itself
column5: it’s always out of reach
column6:
distinct only in brief flashes and in feverish moments.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23344/homepage_large.fb5bf27d.jpg|Emotions and Math|33782.0|Margaret Glaspy|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2016-06-10 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:04.670851|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".250roi0pla8.1.6:0.1.0.$21999/=1$21999.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div class=""adn ads"">

Margaret Glaspy grew up playing fiddle and trombone and listening to early-’00’s Top 40 pop. She hung around in the Boston folk scene after briefly attending Berklee College of Music and eventually settled amongst New York’s singer-songwriter community. Along the way
column2: Glaspy released a pair of EPs
column3: beginning with Homeschool
column4: a solo-acoustic offering that highlighted her compelling
column5: nasally warble.

column1: Several years later
column2: Glaspy has arrived with her full-length debut Emotions and Math
column3: a collection of compact grunge-rock and breezy torch songs that mark a decisive departure from the quiet
column4: spare softness of her past recordings. After starting off singing meandering
column5: exploratory folk (see the modernist recitation of “Know My Name/To Be Heard and Be Had”) on her debut Glaspy has developed a newfound knack for pop hooks and easy melodies.

column1: If the songs on Emotions and Math
column2: which follow conventional structures and hover in the two-three minute range
column3: have polished over some of Glaspy’s intriguing eccentricities as a vocalist
column4: they also show off her refined focus as a songwriter. On the ’90s-Liz Phair-indebted title track
column5: Glaspy establishes herself as an uncanny chronicler of everyday neuroses
column6: outsourcing her anxieties about a long distance relationship to the numbing tasks of calendar keeping and number crunching “the days ‘till you’re back.”

column1: Two tracks later
column2: she channels her anger inwards on the swaggering rocker “You and I
column3: ” blaming herself for letting a lackluster love linger too long: “Tonight I’m a little too turned on to talk about us
column4: ” she sings in front of a punchy guitar line. “Tomorrow I’ll be too turned off and won’t give a fuck.” Glaspy asserts her indifference with so much confidence that what might be a moment of despair instead scans as comforting
column5: if not downright celebratory. It’s one of many instances on Emotions and Math in which Glaspy reserves her deepest empathy for her characters during their lowest moments
column6: when their flaws are getting the best of them and their only sense of reassurance might be knowing that their peers are
column7: more likely than not
column8: fucking up just as mightily.

column1: At their best
column2: these songs share the self-scrutinizing intimacy of Elliott Smith and the imaginative melodic intonations of Joni Mitchell
column3: two of Glaspy's most obvious influences.  Whether she’s writing from the point of view of a parent giving advice to their lonely child (“Parental Guidance”) or acting out imaginary conversations about her deepest insecurities (“You Don’t Want Me”)
column4: Glaspy is a lyricist who can toggle between distanced storytelling and open-hearted self-examination with equal ease.

column1: Compiled from years worth of accumulated material
column2: Emotions and Math suspends time and chronology as the 27-year-old songwriter navigates the dead ends
column3: cheap promises and false starts of young adulthood. One minute
column4: she’s stomping on the fading embers of a failed fling; the next
column5: she’s pining for those very memories she just so happily surrendered. Glaspy toys with these emotional contradictions
column6: juxtaposing nostalgia and angst against one another from song to song. As she puts it: “Why remember all the times I took forever to forget?”

column1: That line is from “Memory Street
column2: ” the album’s centerpiece which finds Glaspy tiptoeing her way through remembrances of a failed relationship she’s worked hard to get over set to a slow-burning Neil Young & Crazy Horse groove. “When I get hungry for the mess we made
column3: ” she sings
column4: indulging the cruel thrill and fulfillment in revisiting painful memories and past traumas
column5: “I start walking down memory lane.” Whereas many songwriters might revel in the youthful abandon of such recklessness
column6: Emotions and Math instead treats bad decisions and destructive impulses with compassionate clarity and heartfelt empathy. When Margaret Glaspy sings that she’s “a woman actin’ like a kid
column7: ” she presents the line not as critique but as consolation: it happens to the best of us.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23343/homepage_large.d646c320.jpg|There’s Alot Going On |32308.0|Vic Mensa|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Roc Nation']|2016-06-09 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:04.798442|"

Vic Mensa went very quickly from playing in a band with his friends to crawling on national television with Kanye West to signing to Jay Z’s label. Until now
column2: he hasn’t had much time to take it all into account. On There’s Alot Going On–remarkably
column3: just the Chicago rapper’s third solo release–he finally catches up. The results brim with pain
column4: anger
column5: and confusion
column6: but there’s also plenty of confidence and ambition. Throughout the EP
column7: which is the best and boldest thing he’s made so far
column8: he airs out his mistakes and fears
column9: adding depth to well-produced
column10: invigorating music.

column1: Mensa has consistently been the second-highest-profile member of SaveMoney–the Chicago collective that boasts Donnie Trumpet
column2: Joey Purp
column3: Towkio
column4: and most prominently
column5: Chance the Rapper. At first
column6: he followed closely in Chance’s footsteps
column7: with his 2013 mixtape INNANETAPE often sounding like a knockoff Acid Rap. But he spent 2014 exploring the intersection of house music and hip-hop
column8: resulting in the excellent “Down on My Luck” and plenty of SoundCloud gems. By 2015
column9: he had taken a sharp left-turn toward post-Yeezus aggro-rap. He was definitely not Chance Lite anymore
column10: but his music lacked personality
column11: with high profile collabs (“U Mad” with Kanye and “No Chill” with Skrillex) and aesthetic taking precedence over substance. He seemed like a second-in-command in search of a role to embody: Was he an ODB or a Beanie Sigel or an A$AP Ferg?

column1: With There’s Alot Going On
column2: you can hear him settling into himself
column3: and he opens up like never before. The first track “Dynasty” pairs boasts with a beautiful grandiose instrumental
column4: before the affair gets immediately darker. “16 Shots” is dedicated to Laquan McDonald
column5: the 17-year-old Chicagoan who was shot to death by a city police officer on a highway in 2014. It’s an appropriately angry song with distressing imagery
column6: like a little girl–young enough to have braces–being forcefully shoved to the street by cops. No matter how many listens
column7: the song’s ending will always be sickening and unbearable
column8: as one of the McDonald family’s lawyers
column9: Jeffrey Neslund
column10: describes the murder in plain detail
column11: with just the hum of a bass making it even more ominous. “16 Shots” is not the EP’s best song
column12: but it is its clearest
column13: setting the mood for the entire record.

column1: “Danger” and “New Bae” showcase Mensa as a gifted pop artist. The songs are thunderous yet reserved
column2: allowing his vocals to hold as much weight as the beats. Standout “Liquor Locker
column3: ” with a surprising but welcome uncredited Ty Dolla $ign feature
column4: is a cry for help disguised as a smooth acoustic come-on. Mensa doesn’t just want D’USSÉ (a Jay Z favorite)
column5: he needs it to free himself from pain
column6: and just wants a partner in his escape. Ty$
column7: meanwhile
column8: is similarly desperate: He promises the best sex ever
column9: but seems to be unable to stand.

column1: The closing title track is a stark admission of depression
column2: addiction
column3: physical abuse
column4: and entitlement. Mensa sings a very pretty hook (“Know I never die/We live forever in my mind/And I sanctify/We live forever
column5: still that life”)
column6: but it’s more of a diary entry than functional rap song: For the most part
column7: he ditches any discernible rhyme scheme and punning. But again
column8: it’s a necessary moment for Mensa
column9: as a person and an artist
column10: and has a captivating narrative arc. “There’s Alot Going On” is the most vital song on the EP. It leaves no stone unturned
column11: no minute unrecalled. Vic Mensa likely will no longer ignore his past
column12:
as he had on many faceless songs in the past couple of years; he can finally grow toward a promising future.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23323/homepage_large.1be34700.jpg|Stranger to Stranger|4158.0|Paul Simon|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Concord']|2016-06-09 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:05.038877|"

Of all the baby-boomer heroes to make it past 70
column2: none have been old longer than Paul Simon. Raised in Queens to first-generation Hungarian-Jewish immigrants
column3: he copyrighted his first song
column4: “The Girl for Me
column5: ” with Art Garfunkel when he was 14
column6: an indication both of his preternatural ambition and a belief that art is as much a business as it is a means of self-expression. He never rebelled
column7: never played to fashion
column8: never seemed as interested in the dangerous divinations of rock‘n’roll as in the quiet diligence of songwriters from the 1930s and ’40s
column9: who kept short hair and bankers’ hours. He has claimed that he tried to be ironic a few times
column10: but it didn’t work. His first crime is mildness; his second is thinking. He might be your parents’ favorite musician
column11: but your grandparents probably thought he was a pretty decent guy too.

column1: The same qualities that made Simon seem square as a younger artist made him durable into—and beyond—middle age. His second solo album
column2: Paul Simon
column3: invented the literate
column4: introverted style we now call indie-folk
column5: and beat Oscar the Grouch by two years in suggesting that melancholy isn’t a weakness
column6: but a form of insulation against even worse emotional weather. In the ’80s
column7: when Bob Dylan was making kabuki disco albums and Simon’s other ’60s peers—the Rolling Stones
column8: for example—were getting lost in the open ocean of too much encouragement
column9: Simon recorded Graceland
column10: an album whose South African sound was both middlebrow and radical
column11: universally likable and yet alien to Simon's typical audience. (For further listening on this subject
column12: visit the compilation The Indestructible Beat of Soweto
column13: released just around the time Graceland came out. It endures.)

column1: Simon’s lyrics
column2: which had always been less about people being free than people getting by
column3: were maturing: He was more aloof now
column4: but funnier
column5: too. Take this
column6: the first verse of a song called “Gumboots”:

column1: ""I was having this discussion in a taxi heading downtown/Rearranging my position on this friend of mine who had a little bit of a breakdown/I said
column2: ‘Hey
column3: you know
column4: breakdowns come and breakdowns go/ So what are you going to do about it? That’s what I’d like to know.’”

column1: Twenty years earlier
column2: he would’ve zeroed in on the breakdown and thrown an orchestra at it; now it was relegated to a couple lines on an album with a host of other problems to compartmentalize. Here was someone stepping into the tempered disappointments of being 40 like they were shoes bought just a little too soon. This
column3: he recently told a class at Yale
column4: is when Simon says he was finally comfortable admitting he was an artist.

column1: Simon’s post-Graceland career has had its embarrassments
column2: but as with a lot of older
column3: canonized artists
column4: critics seem to take an unusual kind of glee in magnifying them
column5: when
column6: near as I can tell
column7: he bothers the public far less than the rest of his graduating class. There was The Capeman
column8: a musical about the Puerto Rican gang member Salvador Agron
column9: which is one of those sub-middling projects nobody would’ve heard about if it wasn’t coming to us from Paul Simon
column10: but since it was coming to us from Paul Simon
column11: people heard about it a lot more than they needed to. (Several writers—myself included
column12: I admit—have noted how unconvincing Simon is when using the word “fuck
column13: ” which he attempts several times on the soundtrack.) There was 2006’s Surprise
column14: which found him working with Brian Eno
column15: an artist of related but incompatible genius whose deference to atmosphere tended to wash out the quiet precision of Simon’s songs.

column1: So Beautiful or So What from 2011 was a lot better
column2: and
column3: for an artist of Simon’s stature
column4: surprisingly weird—the sound of an elder statesman settling into his own idiosyncrasies
column5: seemingly unconcerned with legacy or relevance. More than anything
column6: Simon in the ’00s reminds me of the Brazilian singer Caetano Veloso
column7: himself a national treasure whose albums have only gotten leaner and more enigmatic as he keeps making them.

column1: Which brings us to Stranger to Stranger
column2: a compact
column3: often jittery album populated by schizophrenics
column4: disenfranchised teenagers
column5: musicians locked out of their own gigs
column6: and some kind of avenging werewolf coming to kill the rich. I’ve always attributed part of Simon’s enormous popularity to how good he is at teasing out life’s silver linings
column7: at softening disappointment with bittersweetness
column8: regret with nostalgia. Even his saddest songs contain the implicit bromide that life goes on.

column1: Here
column2: things feel less reassuring
column3: more open-ended. Several of the album’s songs—“Street Angel
column4: ” “In a Parade
column5: ” “The Werewolf”—are bemused and overstuffed
column6: rickshaw rides down busy
column7: unfamiliar streets with people you can’t quite get a read on. Even the album’s friendliest moment
column8: a light
column9: West African-style folksong called “Cool Papa Bell
column10: ” is shadowed by lines about “the thrill you feel when evil dreams come true.” (It also contains Simon’s most convincing use of the word “fuck” yet.) Here
column11: Simon’s voice—always boyish
column12: always a little bit distracted—takes on the ominous warmth of Albert Brooks in Drive
column13: who isn’t slitting your wrist until he is.

column1: The shift here is from wisdom to prophecy
column2: from certainty to contingency. Musically
column3: it’s his most adventurous album since Graceland
column4: filed with strange rhythmic kinks and a junkyard’s worth of barely identifiable sounds. Simon’s appropriation of new styles has often had the unfortunate effect of making it seem like he’s domesticating them
column5: making them palatable for the king’s court. (This was
column6: of course
column7: a big debate around Graceland.) Here
column8: he gets as close as he’s ever been to the romantic ideal of kids gathered on a corner banging on what they found in the alley
column9: or of the weird old guy bumping down the road in a wooden cart filled with treasures unknown
column10: from the chimes of “The Clock” and the accidental ambience of “In the Garden of Edie” to the vocal sample on “Street Angel
column11: ” flipped and processed to make it sound like a clogged drain. (The sample comes from the Golden Gate Quartet
column12: a proto-gospel group who Simon also sampled on So Beautiful or So What
column13: and who invented what in my estimation is the safest anti-depressant on the market.)

column1: Simon has claimed inspiration in part from the American composer Harry Partch
column2: who envisioned a scale that broke up the customary 12 tones into 43
column3: creating slippages and interstices and little gradations of sound that might seem like dissonance to Western ears but that have an oblique
column4: mysterious beauty. Simon borrows a couple of Partch’s homemade instruments here—the zoomoozophone
column5: the chromelodeon—but also borrows a little of his spirit
column6: of a transient life
column7: of quick fixes and no clear plan. My favorite lyrics sound thrillingly unwritten
column8: raw footage of wit in action. Consider it a corrective to a career of smoothing things over: Stranger to Stranger is unpasteurized
column9: mongrel music.

column1: Simon has always been subject to criticism for a certain kind of exceptionalism. Two of his biggest songs
column2: “I Am a Rock” and “Sounds of Silence
column3: ” deal with characters who wear their alienation like badges
column4: dark lords of their own personal libraries left with no choice but to turn their faces heroically away from the sheeple who surround them. This was a guy who responded to the news of his partner going to work on a movie in Mexico by writing a song called “The Only Living Boy in New York
column5: ” never mind the other 6 million people living there.

column1: As his career wore on
column2: the alienation mellowed into casual arrogance. By 1983’s Hearts and Bones
column3: which Simon himself has acknowledged as an artistic dead-end
column4: he had become the kind of guy who shows up at the party but never has a good time
column5: bored by life but willing to smirk at it
column6: who thinks he’s better than you but is too polite to say so.

column1: We see some of that guy on Stranger
column2: just as we see him on every Paul Simon album—that’s part of what makes it a Paul Simon album. The musician on “Wristband
column3: ” for example
column4: who draws an analogy between his own frustrations getting back into the VIP area and what poor people must feel on the brink of a riot. Personally
column5: I see it as satire
column6: the portrait of someone who has mostly lost touch with reality but still has to answer to it eventually. My guess is many will see it as condescension.

column1: Then again
column2: pop has always been nicer to artists who portray struggle than relative ease
column3: more welcoming of emotional engagement than emotional detachment
column4: and increasingly hostile both to intelligence and ambiguity. Simon is all these supposedly bad things and worse. For every one of him
column5: there are 10 guys waiting to stuff him into a locker—that’s how it is
column6: and probably how it’ll always be. “It turns out to be a great thing for me
column7: I don’t worry/I don’t think
column8:
” he sings at the beginning of “Cool Papa Bell.” “Because it’s not my job to worry or to think. Not me. I’m more like—every day I’m here I’m grateful.” Anyone familiar with Simon's music knows he must be talking about someone else; his genius is being able to sell the line anyway.

An indie band’s commercial breakthrough
column3: when and if it comes
column4: is a tricky landmark to pass unscathed. If the follow-up doesn’t catch
column5: the band tends to go one of three ways: They can call it quits
column6: accepting their commercial decrepitude; wind things down over a couple of albums
column7: continuing to tour the hits as a glorified karaoke act; or
column8: as a last resort
column9: enlist some decorated pop producers who will
column10: in theory
column11: affix makeshift wings and propel them into the stratosphere. So it is with Peter Bjorn and John
column12: a Swedish trio inseparably wed to a pretty whistling melody from 2006
column13: whose songwriting smarts always promised an elusive second wind.

column1: Breakin’ Point
column2: their sixth album and first in five years
column3: attempts to reclaim unpaid dues: written as the trio studied ABBA’s greatest hits
column4: recorded in that band’s old studio
column5: and completed with Paul Epworth
column6: Greg Kurstin
column7: Emile Haynie
column8: and other major producers with considerable résumés. (The band's Björn Yttling
column9: a notable producer in his own right
column10: worked alongside Kurstin on Lykke Li's recent albums.) They return a new band: edges planed
column11: eccentricities jettisoned
column12: with a strict emphasis on the effortless hooks that made Writer's Block click. Song to song
column13: they apply the formula with some success. But three albums on from that breakout LP
column14: Breakin’ Point seems an optimistic title—in 2016
column15: the record arrives almost a decade too late.

column1: That’d be by-the-by if the songs served a purpose beyond mainstream expansion
column2: which they sometimes do. Highlight “Hard Sleep” is convincingly euphoric
column3: full of jubilant falsetto and carnival bombast. Its winning formula—lyrics of waning romance
column4: choruses determined to bounce and soar regardless—is capably reproduced throughout the record. But the song stands out as a rare home-run on an album too blandly ambitious to stick in the memory.

column1: Interestingly
column2: PB&J have history folding their musical ennui into the songs themselves: Gimme Some’s “Second Chance” scans as a commentary on the struggle to replicate “Young Folks”’ success
column3: while “It Don’t Move Me
column4: ” from Living Thing

 In 1968
column2: Aretha Franklin reportedly said: “There are only three things happening in England: The Rolling Stones
column3: The Beatles and Terry Reid.” And the deeper you delve into Reid's music
column4: the more astonishing it becomes that he has lived out the past half-century in relative obscurity
column5: while so many of his contemporaries have been enshrined as rock music royalty for decades. Due to his uncanny ability to channel raw emotion through his bombastic voice
column6: Reid picked up the nickname Superlungs at the beginning of his career
column7: turned down the opportunity to front Led Zeppelin and Deep Purple
column8: and set out for a uncompromising solo career. In 1973
column9: at the age of 24
column10: he released River
column11: a near-flawless album of roots
column12: blues
column13: rock 'n' roll
column14: folk and jazz that quickly became a collector's item as it revolved in and out of print for years. The Other Side of the River is a new collection of 11 tracks from River's session
column15: six of which are previously unheard
column16: and the stunning part is
column17: had they been released with the original LP
column18: it would probably be even more coveted than it is today.

column1: Take
column2: for example
column3: “Avenue (F# Boogie)
column4: ” a rambling and rollicking number that lazily directs you into the heart of the album. The newly unearthed version has a lived-in
column5: worn-out feel: you can easily picture a gang of long-haired dudes with mutton chop sideburns lounging around a studio
column6: cracking off riff after riff. Ike and Tina Turner's Ikettes are featured on backing vocals on the track
column7: and their infusion of lush R&B warmth ties the chorus together with spine-tingling effect. It's gorgeous
column8: and in a way improves on the already-fantastic
column9: tighter studio version.

column1: Clearly
column2: having ready access to the talents of the Ikettes never hurt anyone
column3: but the main star in virtually everything Terry Reid ever released is his otherworldly voice. On every song
column4: it bursts forth with equal parts gravel and honey; his soulful belting is effortless and at the same time
column5: sounds almost painful. On “Let's Go Down
column6: ” his vocals ride crescendoing blasts of brass up and down the chorus
column7: alternating from a surly talk-sing to chest-bursting wails. The song is a perfect introduction to Reid as Superlungs – even setting aside his virtuoso guitar playing
column8: he's an artist defined by an incredible natural instrument.

column1: The sound on The Other Side of the River is impeccable
column2: but the tracks themselves are obvious rescues from a very deep vault (“Let's Go Down” finishes with Reid cutting the track short
column3: quipping: “Do you want to have another go
column4: or shall we end it here?”)
column5: which makes the fact that it sounds like a well-rounded and complete record all the more impressive. Title track “River” is probably the closest to its original
column6: Reid's jazzy phrasings mimicking the languid semi-tones of Nina Simone
column7: skipping atop plucked guitars and minimal bossa nova percussion. It's a quiet moment that demands your attention
column8: and an admirable palette cleanser from the album's more raucous moments.

column1: The record's only major fault is that a few of the tracks are truly just studio noodling – “Celtic Melody
column2: ” while still an interesting listen due to Reid's inherent charm
column3: peters out before it really starts
column4: and “Late Night Idea” is basically just that. But given that the bulk of the album manages to rival its original incarnation
column5: these transgressions are excusable
column6: and even the few mostly improvisational outtakes
column7: like the sweet and lilting “Anyway
column8: ” prove to be well worth salvaging from the cutting room floor. Light years from a mere slap-dash rarities compilation
column9:
The Other Side of the River takes some of a seminal rock musician's most interesting sketchworks and reimagines them as his magnum opus.

column7: ” they coo on the album's lead single

There's a straightforward emotional maturity in the moment that has always distinguished their best work.  The minimal instrumentation serves double duty as both stark moment of contemplation and mid-album comedown.

One of the most famous Dylanisms arose from a conversation with director Sam Peckinpah on the set of the 1973 movie Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid. “Just be yourself
column2: ” Peckinpah suggested to a 32-year-old Bob Dylan who
column3: by this point
column4: had already been everything from folk messiah to rock Judas
column5: who had received glowing reviews and miserable ones
column6: who once stood as a pillar of New York authenticity and was now struggling to play the role of a mysterious stranger in a Western movie filmed in Durango
column7: Mexico. Fittingly
column8: Dylan snapped back to Peckinpah: “Which one?”

column1: If Dylan’s 1966 double album Blonde on Blonde is generally viewed among his most iconic
column2: it’s because it was his first album to show all the different Dylans in their best light
column3: with appearances from the freewheeling folk singer from the early ‘60s all the way up to the weirdo bluesman he would later become. It’s not Dylan’s only album that plays genre and mood the way other artists use backup guitars
column4: but it’s the one that made them all feel the most coherent
column5: attractive
column6: and maniacally unstoppable.

column1: For the album’s fiftieth birthday
column2: an impressive array of acts have gathered to pay homage to its thin
column3: wild
column4: multiple personality disorder. Blonde on Blonde Revisited is a worthy tribute
column5: maintaining the album's original track order and flow while also showcasing the wide-ranging talents of the artists collected. Unfortunately

Malcolm Middleton’s monotonous Matrix-soundtrack-meets-hotel-lobby remake of “Rainy Day Woman #12 & 35” at once drains all the brainless fun out of the original while making it sound even more brainless in the process (maybe not everybody must get stoned). Better is Thomas Cohen’s subtle
column7: Britpop remake of “Most Likely You Go Your Way And I’ll Go Mine
column8: ” refitting Dylan's bluesy kiss-off with a jazzy
column9: laid-back groove. As evidenced by last year’s fascinating Bootleg Series
column10: however
column11: most of the songs from this era had already been reinvented and torn apart multiple times before being released: the arrangements that Dylan landed on feel definitive for a reason. For the most part
column12: despite the daring
column13: experimental nature of the album proper
column14: the songs that fare best here are also the ones that take the fewest obvious risks.

column1: Steve Gunn’s thoughtful vocal performance in “Visions of Johanna” and Michael Chapman’s intricate guitar work in “Leopard-Skin Pill-Box Hat” are highlights: examples of artists paying homage to Dylan’s songs not through reinvention but through total reverence. Similarly
column2: after contributing some of the most surprising performances on last month’s Day of the Dead
column3: Phosphorescent shows up with a refreshingly stripped back take on “I Want You
column4: ” recalling the early Oldham-isms of Pride more than the underwater country of Muchacho. Elsewhere
column5: Marissa Nadler’s austere (even for her) take on “Absolutely Sweet Marie” and Ryley Walker’s stunning “4th Time Around” both make strong cases for each artist’s particular style
column6: illustrating how influential Dylan’s music was for a generation of folk artists hellbent on sounding more like themselves. Like the best of Dylan’s work
column7: these performance sound like timeless standards and unanswerable riddles.

column1: The real revelation here
column2: though
column3: is the closing number. As was the case on the original Blonde on Blonde
column4: Jim O’Rourke’s “Sad Eyed Lady of the Lowlands” takes up the entirety of Side D (and even outlasts Dylan’s by two minutes). O’Rourke refines Dylan’s epic waltz into a gorgeous acoustic ballad– his hushed
column5: emotive vocal recalling The Wild
column6: The Innocent-era Springsteen in its quiet intensity. Calling back to the initial recording of the song
column7: when Dylan’s band treated every chorus like a climax
column8: assured that this must be the last one
column9: O’Rourke inserts a series of found recordings of city streets
column10: ringing phones
column11: and passing cars between the verses. The opposite effect to the original’s eleven-minute runner’s high
column12: these passages find the artist pausing to look out the window
column13: overwhelmed by the task at hand and threatening to quit before coming back with more to say. It’s a fitting tribute to Dylan at a point in his career when he couldn’t even stand still for the duration of a photo shoot
column14: when “being yourself” wasn’t an instruction to follow but an intuitive instinct. Blonde on Blonde Revisited
column15: then
column16: serves an album-length response to Dylan’s comeback. Why just be yourself when you can be all of yourselves
column17:
all at once?

column8: and a straining chorus vocal that cannot possibly have been delivered by someone who’s smoked as many cigarettes as Casablancas. (There’s also a remix from the band’s Fab Moretti
column9: which is totally listenable.) “What side are you standing on?” Casablancas sings
column10: which sounds like a challenge to anyone who might pretend the band hasn’t earned its right to screw around.

column1: The benefits of screwing around
column2: of course
column3: could be challenged. “Drag Queen” is the so-called “future”—a more self-consciously “mature” song that opens with a ominous
column4: decayed smear of guitars and continues with the high-concept of Casablancas singing to himself in dueling voices
column5: sort of sounding like a hungover Phantom of the Opera. Halfway through
column6: a Strokes-sian guitar refrain is copy-and-pasted into the flow. It’s a mess
column7: but it’s an interesting mess. “Threat of Joy
column8: ” meanwhile
column9: stretches all the way to their pre-fame days
column10: when they sounded just bored and arrogant enough to be sexy. It’s an alternative universe take on what “The Modern Age” might have sounded like if they’d taken a record executive’s advice to slow it down
column11: get a better studio
column12: and play it straight. It’s not as good
column13: of course
column14: but it’s still charming
column15: and has Casablancas’ most charismatic vocal performance.

column1: At the very least
column2: all three songs will fit seamlessly into their live show. In 2015
column3: I saw the Strokes play a headlining set at Primavera Sound for a rabid crowd who ate up every song
column4: even “Machu Picchu.” The band was just as well-dressed than they’d been in the early ’00s (except for Casablancas
column5: who was cosplaying as a Planeteer
column6: but hey
column7: it’s a look)
column8: and they didn’t miss a note
column9: even as I don’t think a single member came within ten feet of another during the entire set. They didn’t play “12:51” at 12:51 a.m.
column10: because fuck coincidences. A credible source told me their fee for the 90-minute set was more than the cost of your dad’s mortgage.

column1: If their solo dalliances in the last half-decade have given weight to the idea that the Strokes are more of a business than a living
column2: breathing band
column3: it's still been fascinating to watch them shed their skin and become whatever it is they'll be for the rest of their career. And with the pivot of Casablancas’ Cult Records to functioning as a gatekeeper for the living
column4: breathing culture that helped birth the band
column5: they seem like a band that’s very aware of their legacy… as well as how easy it would be for that to stop mattering
column6: should the context no longer exist. Maybe they didn’t mean to become iconic
column7: but it happened
column8:
and there are still people who want to see what happens next.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23303/homepage_large.ea557c50.jpg|Ash & Ice|2288.0|The Kills|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2016-06-07 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:07.337862|"

When the Kills first emerged
column3: Alison Mosshart and Jamie Hince had a fire-and-water dynamic. Pitting her howls against his dead-cool guitar damage
column4: the duo were like elemental forces locked in a symbiotic relationship of mutually assured destruction. Now
column5: 15 years and five albums later
column6: they’ve become Ash & Ice—refined byproducts of their original state
column7: sapped of their frisson. When water hits fire
column8: there’s sizzle and struggle and wreckage. When ash hits ice… well
column9: you just wind up with a somewhat dirty piece of ice. And so it goes with this monolithic record
column10: whose surface soot can’t disguise the fact it’s a little too chilled for its own good.

column1: Since their delightfully deviant debut Keep on Your Mean Side
column2: The Kills have managed to squeeze a lot of juice from their bare-bones blues roots. Sophomore album No Wow delivered a pop punch
column3: Midnight Boom saw them go electro
column4: Blood Pressures dabbled in dub and pastoral balladry. Ash & Ice is The Kills’ first album in five years—a delay partly attributed to chronic tendon problems Hince experienced after breaking a finger. And
column5: as if making up for lost time
column6: they’ve returned with an ambitious record that encompasses everything they’ve done before and further embellishes their boombox beats with Brazilian and Afro-pop influences. Clocking in at 50 minutes
column7: it is by far the longest Kills album to date. But while Ash & Ice has the girth of a big statement record
column8: it lacks the focus and purposeful sequencing of one.

column1: The issue with Ash & Ice isn’t that The Kills are slowing down or going soft—the quietest tracks here actually resonate the most soundly. “Hum for Your Buzz” is a stripped-down gospelized serenade complete with organ drones and a steeple-shaking lead vocal from Mosshart—that’s destined to become a crowd-pleasing encore standard in the band’s setlist. By contrast
column2: “That Love” is an affectingly unvarnished piano confessional that evokes the raw simplicity and bald lyricism of Plastic Ono Band-era John Lennon
column3: while “Echo Home” is a gorgeously sullen duet whose slow-percolating dream-pop atmospherics and tick-tock beat mirror the doomed
column4: dissolving romance playing out in the lyrics. For a band that once carefully cultivated its mystique through mugshot-style photos
column5: mysterious aliases and sunglassed aloofness
column6: The Kills have become remarkably adept at telegraphing intimacy and vulnerability. And with Hince's finger injury forcing him to rethink his slash-and-scrape guitar technique
column7: his playing on these downcast songs displays a heretofore-untapped delicacy and sensitivity.

column1: However
column2: Ash & Ice is an album of quality comedown tracks surrounded by run-of-the-mill rockers that plateau instead of peak. It’s curious
column3: since that the album actually boasts some of the band’s most candid and crushing lyrics to date—from the leash-fastening commitment pledge of “Heart of a Dog” (“I want strings attached/unnatural as that feels/I’m loyal!”) to the tawdry teases on “Siberian Nights” (“I could make you cum in threes/I’m halfway to my knees”) that are soon revealed to be the desperate entreaties of someone scared of enduring another night alone. (And according to Hince
column4: that someone could very well be Vladimir Putin.) But the music rarely matches the feverish energy of those words
column5: with the opening mid-tempo march of “Doing It to Death” setting a sluggish pace for the record that’s only compounded by the serviceable Stonesy struts (“Bitter Fruit
column6: ” “Black Tar”)
column7: drum-machined dirges (“Days of Why and How”)
column8: and deconstructed
column9: broken-beat pop (“Let It Drop”). And the precious few shots of momentum—like the gritty glam of “Impossible Tracks” and the Primal Scream-like motorik throb of “Whirling Eye”—slam on the brakes just as they’re about achieve lift-off
column10: or rein in Hince’s ray-gunned guitar blasts right when he’s on the verge of entering berserker mode (“Hard Habit to Break”).

column1: The Kills enjoy a rarefied status in 2016. As one of the few active acts from the early-'00s garage-rock explosion
column2: they’ve transcended their early standing as an MTV2-friendly version of Royal Trux to become icons in their own right for a new generation of transgressive rockers. But Ash & Ice betrays the challenge of sustaining fresh inspiration deep into your second decade. The blues may have brought Mosshart and Hince together
column3:
but Ash & Ice too readily embodies one of the genre’s favored tropes—the struggle to keep on keepin’ on.

column2: we probably have enough albums dedicated to rave nostalgia. And the British producer Matt Cutler should feel OK about that
column3: because as Lone
column4: he's responsible for quite a few of them. His new one
column5: Levitate doesn't really break any new ground; it reprises ideas (and in some cases
column6: specific synthesizer patches) that he has been using since 2010's Emerald Fantasy Tracks. Yet
column7: to its credit
column8: it doesn't feel redundant. At its best
column9: this short
column10: punchy album feels like a distillation of everything that has made Lone's work great so far.

column1: Historically
column2: Lone's music has tended to toggle between two modes. On the one hand
column3: there's drowsy
column4: lysergic downbeat in the tradition of Boards of Canada and Dilla; on the other
column5: a kind of exaggerated rave revivalism
column6: which takes tropes from early-'90s UK dance music and blows them up to gargantuan proportions. Lemurian and Ecstasy & Friends
column7: his first two albums
column8: kept to hip-hop tempos
column9: woozy moods
column10: but the Red Bull kicked in with 2010's Emerald Fantasy Tracks
column11: and he threw himself into house tempos with gusto. The intensity built on 2012's vertiginous Galaxy Garden
column12: and then
column13: since everything that comes up must come down—an adage many ravers know all too well—2014's Reality Testing slunk back under the covers
column14: balancing hip-hop beats with slow
column15: starry-eyed house and boogie in the vein of Floating Points' early singles.

column1: From a title like Levitate
column2: you can guess where Cutler's taking us this time: right back up to the top. It might be Lone's most intense album to date—dancing like a downed electrical wire
column3: with its hooks as immediate as anything he's ever done. Album opener “Alpha Wheel” brings us hurtling up to speed with fat
column4: loud
column5: practically diamond-encrusted breakbeats and a chord progression that sets off tiny serotonin bombs with every syncopated stab. “Backtail Was Heavy” inhabits similar terrain
column6: balancing rough-cut breaks and detuned horn stabs with a sparkly
column7: Aphex-indebted synth melody. In a curious case of double déjà vu
column8: it's a hardcore throwback through-and-through
column9: and it also uses an uncannily similar synth sound from Emerald Fantasy Tracks’ “Moon Beam Harp.”

column1: The shuddering “Triple Helix” and the smooth drum'n'bass roller “Sea of Tranquility” keep the energy levels soaring; even the Boards of Canada pastiche “Sleepwalkers” musters a kind of rhythmic force that the Scottish duo themselves have rarely achieved. Levitate is the shortest album Lone has ever made—just 33 minutes in all
column2: and two of its nine songs are sketch-like ambient interludes. Functionally
column3: it's more like an EP than an album
column4: but that extreme sense of focus works in its favor: There's no wasted effort
column5: and his craft has never sounded better—his beats are Jaws-of-Life strong
column6: his melodies buffed to a blinding sheen. His ingenious way of flipping
column7: chopping and reversing breakbeats recalls Squarepusher’s first two albums
column8: made when the drill'n'bass producer's goofy grin hadn't yet hardened into a smirk. And Cutler manages to find subtle ways to surprise. Both “Alpha Wheel” and “Sleepwalkers” build to their climax and then just drop away.

column1: It all comes together in “Triple Helix”: the sound design
column2: the energy
column3: the optimism. It's wild
column4: disorienting
column5: sugary
column6: hyper-sensory stuff
column7: and it's no wonder that my 11-month-old daughter loves it. Rave has always had an infantilizing aspect
column8: from songs like Smart E's “Sesame's Treet” to accoutrements like pacifiers and Mickey Mouse gloves. Levitate leverages rave nostalgia to get to a deeper truth: Free your inner child
column9:
and your ass and mind will follow.
