“Shut up
column2: Beavis
column3: you’re ruining it.” That’s Butt-Head telling Beavis to stop interrupting White Zombie’s “Thunder Kiss ‘65” video. The cartoon duo treated Rob Zombie and Sean Yseult’s band with deep reverence
column4: and ironically enough
column5: the clip is widely credited as the reason for White Zombie’s initial leap to multi-platinum success. It’s easy to see why the band captured the imaginations of millions of Butt-Heads: Their aesthetic was fully realized—horror and grindhouse-nodding videos and lyrics
column6: Zombie’s booming voice skulking at the front (not to mention his dreads and goggles). It was metal that rode grooves and featured tons of samples. The mid-'90s run of White Zombie that produced their final two albums—their final single
column7: appropriately enough
column8: being their Beavis & Butt-Head Do America soundtrack contribution—was easily the most popular.

column1: But by the time they were playing arenas and getting frequent airplay on TV
column2: they’d been making music for a decade
column3: and their earliest work arguably holds up better than the stuff that made them famous. Yes
column4: it's a total surprise that Numero Group are giving an extremely successful rock band fronted by Rob Zombie the box set treatment—an honor usually reserved for forgotten funk and soul gems. But it also makes total sense. It Came From N.Y.C. unearths records both unreleased and out-of-print while exhaustively telling the band's lesser-known origin story. The box comes with rare photos
column5: archival flyers
column6: a complete archive of their shirts
column7: reproductions of Rob Zombie’s illustrated liner notes
column8: and a detailed account of the band’s history from (full disclosure!) Pitchfork contributor Grayson Haver Currin. Interviews with the band
column9: logged in a beautiful hardcover tome
column10: offer crucial context for this music.

column1: In the beginning
column2: they were a band of art school kids living amid New York City crime and filth. Sean Yseult and Rob Cummings were both attending Parsons in 1984. Yseult switched from ballet to photography after she broke her foot
column3: discovering hardcore and picking up instruments in the process. Cummings moved to New York from small town Massachusetts where he’d been dreaming of the city described by the Ramones and Velvet Underground. The two met in a cafeteria. She had blue-black hair; he wore a Misfits motorcycle jacket. They became a couple and were inseparable for years. They kicked around the idea of starting a band together and ultimately named themselves after a 1932 Bela Lugosi-starring horror film.

column1: What’s quickly apparent from the almost three hours of music on It Came From N.Y.C. is that Cummings and Yseult were the creative and aesthetic anchors behind White Zombie. Guitarists never stuck around long in the band’s early incarnations
column2: which means every one of their first records had an entirely different vibe. Ena Kostabi’s solos on their debut 1985 EP Gods on Voodoo Moon
column3: for example
column4: are a little more flashy than seems sonically appropriate for the band’s ominous
column5: minimal
column6: and occasionally trippy noise-punk underpinnings.

column1: There are great moments on that first 7”—the uneasy melodic sway of “Tales From the Scare Crow Man” and point-perfect opening chug of “Gentleman Junkie”—but the songs themselves show more potential than prowess. Cummings’ growling
column2: raspy screams are perfectly suited to his early horror-aping lyrics
column3: but the frontman billing himself as “Rob Straker” hadn’t found his eventual authoritative Rob Zombie howl. Still
column4: the essentials that would remain throughout the band’s tenure are present on their first recordings: hooks led by Yseult’s bass while Straker shouts nihilistic lyrics about holy mountains
column5: demon clowns
column6: Nazis
column7: butchers
column8: and scarecrows.

column1: The band’s sound was pushed forward on their 1986 “Pig Heaven” single—presented in the box as an EP with four more unearthed tracks from the same session. Their new drummer Ivan de Prume
column2: who would stay with White Zombie throughout the 1980s
column3: emboldened their rhythm section tenfold. They sounded stronger and tighter than ever
column4: and Straker’s psychedelic horror lyrics were becoming narratively connected stories. In their new attempts to make songs trippy or disorienting
column5: they didn’t rely on thin effects pedals—they shoved more details into the margins. (Later in their discography
column6: they proved to be adept with a “more is more” approach.)

column1: The record is bookended by the tinny recording of a ragtime piano—a simple device that both emphasizes their power and shows their interest in painting a more elaborate picture beyond just screams and spilled blood. But while new guitarist Tim Jeffs was an excellent player
column2: his blues-heavy riffs felt out of place in White Zombie. The nearly eight-minute blues groove of “Rain Insane” is one of the most significant departures in the band’s discography
column3: and while it’s definitely an impressive Straker-fronted blues rock jam
column4: White Zombie were much better when they veered toward chaos.

column1: It’s important to note that while White Zombie were making records and playing shows
column2: they were operating in the same New York underground as Swans and Sonic Youth. After they dumped Jeffs
column3: they looked for a guitarist with more specific influences—their ad asked for someone who was into the Butthole Surfers
column4: X
column5: and the Birthday Party. They found Tom Guay
column6: who ran in the same circles as Pussy Galore and was clearly more ready to convey dissonance than prowess. On 1987’s Psycho-Head Blowout EP
column7: Straker was becoming a more confident frontman
column8: Yseult’s low-end was becoming beefier and more authoritative
column9: and on songs like “Gun Crazy
column10: ” de Prume would bring rapidfire discord. They were becoming more abrasive and unpredictable
column11: Yseult unafraid to dive headlong into sludge while Guay tried on a variety of anxious
column12: frenetic grooves.

column1: Their next record was written
column2: recorded
column3: and released soon after Psycho-Head Blowout. It was hammered out in a practice space that shared walls with people who screamed in the hallways
column4: jumped out windows
column5: and kept pet raccoons. “It was a fucking nuthouse to say the least
column6: ” remembers Straker. Those were the conditions behind their debut album—their most bleak and noise-centric outing yet. With no-wave producer Wharton Tiers (Sonic Youth
column7: Glenn Branca)
column8: they made their debut album Soul-Crusher
column9: one of the best of their career.

column1: Early on in White Zombie’s recordings
column2: they tried for intimidation
column3: but could never rise above pastiche. With Soul-Crusher
column4: they create a sound that’s fully unsettling
column5: Straker’s multi-tracked voice becoming a one-man cackling
column6: shrieking chorus. There are several moments throughout where saliva seems to be palpably sticking to his lips
column7: making his uncomfortable lyrics borderline unbearable. Guay
column8: again
column9: is essential. Any impressive on-point solos are buried in the mix beneath Yseult’s massive
column10: overpowering sludge. When he’s prominently featured
column11: he’s playing in the wrong key or doing some incredible work with feedback. Several times
column12: de Prume full-on switches time signatures while the band slip in and out of key. The album features spoken-word samples from old horror movies
column13: but by this point the band was its own B-movie soundtrack.

column1: Despite hitting their target squarely
column2: Straker decided to move on. Guay was fired from the band; Straker started crediting himself as Rob Zombie and became enamored with Metallica’s Ride the Lightning. As a result
column3: White Zombie made the abrupt
column4: full transition to metal on Make Them Die Slowly. Everything about the album is more crisp: The lyrics in the liner notes were no longer hand-scrawled with illustrations littering the margins. Guitarist John Ricci
column5: who could rip through galloping riffs and nail precise high-speed solos
column6: was practically the stylistic opposite of Guay. Producer Bill Laswell placed a huge emphasis on Ricci’s guitar and Zombie’s voice while neutering the rhythm section. Yseult’s bass wasn’t the overpowering beast it was on the previous two records
column7: which means White Zombie were deprived of one of their most crucial ingredients. The drums sounded smaller
column8: thin and hollow. The overall effect is especially draining when taken in the box set’s chronological order: the noise dominance of Soul-Crusher followed by the sluggish
column9: monotonous Make Them Die Slowly.

column1: Once again
column2: White Zombie would ditch their guitarist and move on to the next one. Jay Yuenger is the one that stuck—he stayed with the band until they eventually called it quits. Their final record before signing to the majors and moving out to L.A. was 1989’s God of Thunder. On the cover
column3: Zombie holds the severed head of Gene Simmons. The record opens with their cover of the Destroyer classic “God of Thunder
column4: ” and White Zombie introduce their version by jacking Kiss' legendary introduction: “You wanted the best? You got the best! Introducing the hottest band in the world!” Their sense of humor and a slam-dunk performance of a Kiss classic bring some much-needed levity to their aesthetic.

column1: In their final stop before “Thunder Kiss ‘65
column2: ” God of Thunder shows the band utilizing samples more successfully than ever. (The best one: Between Zombie verses
column3: a blasé voice chimes in to say
column4: “Listen
column5: you fuckers.”) Yuenger’s style in his White Zombie debut offers the midpoint between Ricci’s and Guay’s—he’s impressive
column6: but not overpowering; heavy
column7: but precise. By God of Thunder
column8: they found footing after some thrilling moments in the underground and a couple of creative missteps. But the missteps come with experimentation
column9: and experimentation is mandatory if you want to escape the 1990s as maximalist weirdo rock stars.

column1: Listening back to White Zombie
column2: it's interesting to consider how their music holds up in 2016. Obviously
column3: they're a crucial part of Rob Zombie's horror legacy
column4: introducing the nihilistic hellscape language he would follow in his solo albums and literal horror films. In an era where Michael Gira is making some of the best records of his life while early works by Sonic Youth and Lydia Lunch are getting reappraised
column5: White Zombie's early presence as a New York underground institution is
column6: on their first 7""
column7: intriguing
column8: and on Soul-Crusher
column9: enthralling. Even their later hits
column10: entrenched in 1990s culture as they were (again
column11: thanks in large part to ""Beavis & Butt-Head"")
column12: stands the test of time thanks to riffs like the slide guitar of “More Human Than Human.” This music pummels
column13: and better still
column14: it escapes the trap of self-seriousness that so many metal and noise bands seem to fall into. They had a sense of humor
column15: which came through in their use of samples and in Zombie's deranged carnival barker performances. But even more engaging than the music's heft
column16: humor
column17: or chaos is the narrative that forms across It Came From N.Y.C.—one of a band that played by their own rules
column18:
bucking genre conventions and cutting ties with bandmates in an effort to continuously move forward.

“Shut up
column2: Beavis
column3: you’re ruining it.” That’s Butt-Head telling Beavis to stop interrupting White Zombie’s “Thunder Kiss ‘65” video. The cartoon duo treated Rob Zombie and Sean Yseult’s band with deep reverence
column4: and ironically enough
column5: the clip is widely credited as the reason for White Zombie’s initial leap to multi-platinum success. It’s easy to see why the band captured the imaginations of millions of Butt-Heads: Their aesthetic was fully realized—horror and grindhouse-nodding videos and lyrics
column6: Zombie’s booming voice skulking at the front (not to mention his dreads and goggles). It was metal that rode grooves and featured tons of samples. The mid-'90s run of White Zombie that produced their final two albums—their final single
column7: appropriately enough
column8: being their Beavis & Butt-Head Do America soundtrack contribution—was easily the most popular.

column1: But by the time they were playing arenas and getting frequent airplay on TV
column2: they’d been making music for a decade
column3: and their earliest work arguably holds up better than the stuff that made them famous. Yes
column4: it's a total surprise that Numero Group are giving an extremely successful rock band fronted by Rob Zombie the box set treatment—an honor usually reserved for forgotten funk and soul gems. But it also makes total sense. It Came From N.Y.C. unearths records both unreleased and out-of-print while exhaustively telling the band's lesser-known origin story. The box comes with rare photos
column5: archival flyers
column6: a complete archive of their shirts
column7: reproductions of Rob Zombie’s illustrated liner notes
column8: and a detailed account of the band’s history from (full disclosure!) Pitchfork contributor Grayson Haver Currin. Interviews with the band
column9: logged in a beautiful hardcover tome
column10: offer crucial context for this music.

column1: In the beginning
column2: they were a band of art school kids living amid New York City crime and filth. Sean Yseult and Rob Cummings were both attending Parsons in 1984. Yseult switched from ballet to photography after she broke her foot
column3: discovering hardcore and picking up instruments in the process. Cummings moved to New York from small town Massachusetts where he’d been dreaming of the city described by the Ramones and Velvet Underground. The two met in a cafeteria. She had blue-black hair; he wore a Misfits motorcycle jacket. They became a couple and were inseparable for years. They kicked around the idea of starting a band together and ultimately named themselves after a 1932 Bela Lugosi-starring horror film.

column1: What’s quickly apparent from the almost three hours of music on It Came From N.Y.C. is that Cummings and Yseult were the creative and aesthetic anchors behind White Zombie. Guitarists never stuck around long in the band’s early incarnations
column2: which means every one of their first records had an entirely different vibe. Ena Kostabi’s solos on their debut 1985 EP Gods on Voodoo Moon
column3: for example
column4: are a little more flashy than seems sonically appropriate for the band’s ominous
column5: minimal
column6: and occasionally trippy noise-punk underpinnings.

column1: There are great moments on that first 7”—the uneasy melodic sway of “Tales From the Scare Crow Man” and point-perfect opening chug of “Gentleman Junkie”—but the songs themselves show more potential than prowess. Cummings’ growling
column2: raspy screams are perfectly suited to his early horror-aping lyrics
column3: but the frontman billing himself as “Rob Straker” hadn’t found his eventual authoritative Rob Zombie howl. Still
column4: the essentials that would remain throughout the band’s tenure are present on their first recordings: hooks led by Yseult’s bass while Straker shouts nihilistic lyrics about holy mountains
column5: demon clowns
column6: Nazis
column7: butchers
column8: and scarecrows.

column1: The band’s sound was pushed forward on their 1986 “Pig Heaven” single—presented in the box as an EP with four more unearthed tracks from the same session. Their new drummer Ivan de Prume
column2: who would stay with White Zombie throughout the 1980s
column3: emboldened their rhythm section tenfold. They sounded stronger and tighter than ever
column4: and Straker’s psychedelic horror lyrics were becoming narratively connected stories. In their new attempts to make songs trippy or disorienting
column5: they didn’t rely on thin effects pedals—they shoved more details into the margins. (Later in their discography
column6: they proved to be adept with a “more is more” approach.)

column1: The record is bookended by the tinny recording of a ragtime piano—a simple device that both emphasizes their power and shows their interest in painting a more elaborate picture beyond just screams and spilled blood. But while new guitarist Tim Jeffs was an excellent player
column2: his blues-heavy riffs felt out of place in White Zombie. The nearly eight-minute blues groove of “Rain Insane” is one of the most significant departures in the band’s discography
column3: and while it’s definitely an impressive Straker-fronted blues rock jam
column4: White Zombie were much better when they veered toward chaos.

4|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22975/homepage_large.c818dddc.jpg|Soul-Crusher|33541.0|White Zombie|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Numero Group']|2016-06-07 00:00:00|1987|2016-06-11 15:46:08.359765|"

“Shut up
column2: Beavis
column3: you’re ruining it.” That’s Butt-Head telling Beavis to stop interrupting White Zombie’s “Thunder Kiss ‘65” video. The cartoon duo treated Rob Zombie and Sean Yseult’s band with deep reverence
column4: and ironically enough
column5: the clip is widely credited as the reason for White Zombie’s initial leap to multi-platinum success. It’s easy to see why the band captured the imaginations of millions of Butt-Heads: Their aesthetic was fully realized—horror and grindhouse-nodding videos and lyrics
column6: Zombie’s booming voice skulking at the front (not to mention his dreads and goggles). It was metal that rode grooves and featured tons of samples. The mid-'90s run of White Zombie that produced their final two albums—their final single
column7: appropriately enough
column8: being their Beavis & Butt-Head Do America soundtrack contribution—was easily the most popular.

column1: But by the time they were playing arenas and getting frequent airplay on TV
column2: they’d been making music for a decade
column3: and their earliest work arguably holds up better than the stuff that made them famous. Yes
column4: it's a total surprise that Numero Group are giving an extremely successful rock band fronted by Rob Zombie the box set treatment—an honor usually reserved for forgotten funk and soul gems. But it also makes total sense. It Came From N.Y.C. unearths records both unreleased and out-of-print while exhaustively telling the band's lesser-known origin story. The box comes with rare photos
column5: archival flyers
column6: a complete archive of their shirts
column7: reproductions of Rob Zombie’s illustrated liner notes
column8: and a detailed account of the band’s history from (full disclosure!) Pitchfork contributor Grayson Haver Currin. Interviews with the band
column9: logged in a beautiful hardcover tome
column10: offer crucial context for this music.

column1: In the beginning
column2: they were a band of art school kids living amid New York City crime and filth. Sean Yseult and Rob Cummings were both attending Parsons in 1984. Yseult switched from ballet to photography after she broke her foot
column3: discovering hardcore and picking up instruments in the process. Cummings moved to New York from small town Massachusetts where he’d been dreaming of the city described by the Ramones and Velvet Underground. The two met in a cafeteria. She had blue-black hair; he wore a Misfits motorcycle jacket. They became a couple and were inseparable for years. They kicked around the idea of starting a band together and ultimately named themselves after a 1932 Bela Lugosi-starring horror film.

column1: What’s quickly apparent from the almost three hours of music on It Came From N.Y.C. is that Cummings and Yseult were the creative and aesthetic anchors behind White Zombie. Guitarists never stuck around long in the band’s early incarnations
column2: which means every one of their first records had an entirely different vibe. Ena Kostabi’s solos on their debut 1985 EP Gods on Voodoo Moon
column3: for example
column4: are a little more flashy than seems sonically appropriate for the band’s ominous
column5: minimal
column6: and occasionally trippy noise-punk underpinnings.

column1: There are great moments on that first 7”—the uneasy melodic sway of “Tales From the Scare Crow Man” and point-perfect opening chug of “Gentleman Junkie”—but the songs themselves show more potential than prowess. Cummings’ growling
column2: raspy screams are perfectly suited to his early horror-aping lyrics
column3: but the frontman billing himself as “Rob Straker” hadn’t found his eventual authoritative Rob Zombie howl. Still
column4: the essentials that would remain throughout the band’s tenure are present on their first recordings: hooks led by Yseult’s bass while Straker shouts nihilistic lyrics about holy mountains
column5: demon clowns
column6: Nazis
column7: butchers
column8: and scarecrows.

column1: The band’s sound was pushed forward on their 1986 “Pig Heaven” single—presented in the box as an EP with four more unearthed tracks from the same session. Their new drummer Ivan de Prume
column2: who would stay with White Zombie throughout the 1980s
column3: emboldened their rhythm section tenfold. They sounded stronger and tighter than ever
column4: and Straker’s psychedelic horror lyrics were becoming narratively connected stories. In their new attempts to make songs trippy or disorienting
column5: they didn’t rely on thin effects pedals—they shoved more details into the margins. (Later in their discography
column6: they proved to be adept with a “more is more” approach.)

column1: The record is bookended by the tinny recording of a ragtime piano—a simple device that both emphasizes their power and shows their interest in painting a more elaborate picture beyond just screams and spilled blood. But while new guitarist Tim Jeffs was an excellent player
column2: his blues-heavy riffs felt out of place in White Zombie. The nearly eight-minute blues groove of “Rain Insane” is one of the most significant departures in the band’s discography
column3: and while it’s definitely an impressive Straker-fronted blues rock jam
column4: White Zombie were much better when they veered toward chaos.

column1: It’s important to note that while White Zombie were making records and playing shows
column2: they were operating in the same New York underground as Swans and Sonic Youth. After they dumped Jeffs
column3: they looked for a guitarist with more specific influences—their ad asked for someone who was into the Butthole Surfers
column4: X
column5: and the Birthday Party. They found Tom Guay
column6: who ran in the same circles as Pussy Galore and was clearly more ready to convey dissonance than prowess. On 1987’s Psycho-Head Blowout EP
column7: Straker was becoming a more confident frontman
column8: Yseult’s low-end was becoming beefier and more authoritative
column9: and on songs like “Gun Crazy
column10: ” de Prume would bring rapidfire discord. They were becoming more abrasive and unpredictable
column11: Yseult unafraid to dive headlong into sludge while Guay tried on a variety of anxious
column12: frenetic grooves.

column1: Their next record was written
column2: recorded
column3: and released soon after Psycho-Head Blowout. It was hammered out in a practice space that shared walls with people who screamed in the hallways
column4: jumped out windows
column5: and kept pet raccoons. “It was a fucking nuthouse to say the least
column6: ” remembers Straker. Those were the conditions behind their debut album—their most bleak and noise-centric outing yet. With no-wave producer Wharton Tiers (Sonic Youth
column7: Glenn Branca)
column8: they made their debut album Soul-Crusher
column9: one of the best of their career.

column1: Early on in White Zombie’s recordings
column2: they tried for intimidation
column3: but could never rise above pastiche. With Soul-Crusher
column4: they create a sound that’s fully unsettling
column5: Straker’s multi-tracked voice becoming a one-man cackling
column6: shrieking chorus. There are several moments throughout where saliva seems to be palpably sticking to his lips
column7: making his uncomfortable lyrics borderline unbearable. Guay
column8: again
column9: is essential. Any impressive on-point solos are buried in the mix beneath Yseult’s massive
column10: overpowering sludge. When he’s prominently featured
column11: he’s playing in the wrong key or doing some incredible work with feedback. Several times
column12: de Prume full-on switches time signatures while the band slip in and out of key. The album features spoken-word samples from old horror movies
column13: but by this point the band was its own B-movie soundtrack.

column1: Despite hitting their target squarely
column2: Straker decided to move on. Guay was fired from the band; Straker started crediting himself as Rob Zombie and became enamored with Metallica’s Ride the Lightning. As a result
column3: White Zombie made the abrupt
column4: full transition to metal on Make Them Die Slowly. Everything about the album is more crisp: The lyrics in the liner notes were no longer hand-scrawled with illustrations littering the margins. Guitarist John Ricci
column5: who could rip through galloping riffs and nail precise high-speed solos
column6: was practically the stylistic opposite of Guay. Producer Bill Laswell placed a huge emphasis on Ricci’s guitar and Zombie’s voice while neutering the rhythm section. Yseult’s bass wasn’t the overpowering beast it was on the previous two records
column7: which means White Zombie were deprived of one of their most crucial ingredients. The drums sounded smaller
column8: thin and hollow. The overall effect is especially draining when taken in the box set’s chronological order: the noise dominance of Soul-Crusher followed by the sluggish
column9: monotonous Make Them Die Slowly.

column1: Once again
column2: White Zombie would ditch their guitarist and move on to the next one. Jay Yuenger is the one that stuck—he stayed with the band until they eventually called it quits. Their final record before signing to the majors and moving out to L.A. was 1989’s God of Thunder. On the cover
column3: Zombie holds the severed head of Gene Simmons. The record opens with their cover of the Destroyer classic “God of Thunder
column4: ” and White Zombie introduce their version by jacking Kiss' legendary introduction: “You wanted the best? You got the best! Introducing the hottest band in the world!” Their sense of humor and a slam-dunk performance of a Kiss classic bring some much-needed levity to their aesthetic.

column1: In their final stop before “Thunder Kiss ‘65
column2: ” God of Thunder shows the band utilizing samples more successfully than ever. (The best one: Between Zombie verses
column3: a blasé voice chimes in to say
column4: “Listen
column5: you fuckers.”) Yuenger’s style in his White Zombie debut offers the midpoint between Ricci’s and Guay’s—he’s impressive
column6: but not overpowering; heavy
column7: but precise. By God of Thunder
column8: they found footing after some thrilling moments in the underground and a couple of creative missteps. But the missteps come with experimentation
column9: and experimentation is mandatory if you want to escape the 1990s as maximalist weirdo rock stars.

column1: Listening back to White Zombie
column2: it's interesting to consider how their music holds up in 2016. Obviously
column3: they're a crucial part of Rob Zombie's horror legacy
column4: introducing the nihilistic hellscape language he would follow in his solo albums and literal horror films. In an era where Michael Gira is making some of the best records of his life while early works by Sonic Youth and Lydia Lunch are getting reappraised
column5: White Zombie's early presence as a New York underground institution is
column6: on their first 7""
column7: intriguing
column8: and on Soul-Crusher
column9: enthralling. Even their later hits
column10: entrenched in 1990s culture as they were (again
column11: thanks in large part to ""Beavis & Butt-Head"")
column12: stands the test of time thanks to riffs like the slide guitar of “More Human Than Human.” This music pummels
column13: and better still
column14: it escapes the trap of self-seriousness that so many metal and noise bands seem to fall into. They had a sense of humor
column15: which came through in their use of samples and in Zombie's deranged carnival barker performances. But even more engaging than the music's heft
column16: humor
column17: or chaos is the narrative that forms across It Came From N.Y.C.—one of a band that played by their own rules
column18:
bucking genre conventions and cutting ties with bandmates in an effort to continuously move forward.

column3: and released soon after Psycho-Head Blowout. It was hammered out in a practice space that shared walls with people who screamed in the hallways
column4: jumped out windows
column5: and kept pet raccoons. “It was a fucking nuthouse to say the least
column6: ” remembers Straker. Those were the conditions behind their debut album—their most bleak and noise-centric outing yet. With no-wave producer Wharton Tiers (Sonic Youth
column7: Glenn Branca)
column8: they made their debut album Soul-Crusher
column9: one of the best of their career.

column1: Early on in White Zombie’s recordings
column2: they tried for intimidation
column3: but could never rise above pastiche. With Soul-Crusher
column4: they create a sound that’s fully unsettling
column5: Straker’s multi-tracked voice becoming a one-man cackling
column6: shrieking chorus. There are several moments throughout where saliva seems to be palpably sticking to his lips
column7: making his uncomfortable lyrics borderline unbearable. Guay
column8: again
column9: is essential. Any impressive on-point solos are buried in the mix beneath Yseult’s massive
column10: overpowering sludge. When he’s prominently featured
column11: he’s playing in the wrong key or doing some incredible work with feedback. Several times
column12: de Prume full-on switches time signatures while the band slip in and out of key. The album features spoken-word samples from old horror movies
column13: but by this point the band was its own B-movie soundtrack.

column1: Despite hitting their target squarely
column2: Straker decided to move on. Guay was fired from the band; Straker started crediting himself as Rob Zombie and became enamored with Metallica’s Ride the Lightning. As a result
column3: White Zombie made the abrupt
column4: full transition to metal on Make Them Die Slowly. Everything about the album is more crisp: The lyrics in the liner notes were no longer hand-scrawled with illustrations littering the margins. Guitarist John Ricci
column5: who could rip through galloping riffs and nail precise high-speed solos
column6: was practically the stylistic opposite of Guay. Producer Bill Laswell placed a huge emphasis on Ricci’s guitar and Zombie’s voice while neutering the rhythm section. Yseult’s bass wasn’t the overpowering beast it was on the previous two records
column7: which means White Zombie were deprived of one of their most crucial ingredients. The drums sounded smaller
column8: thin and hollow. The overall effect is especially draining when taken in the box set’s chronological order: the noise dominance of Soul-Crusher followed by the sluggish
column9: monotonous Make Them Die Slowly.

column1: Once again
column2: White Zombie would ditch their guitarist and move on to the next one. Jay Yuenger is the one that stuck—he stayed with the band until they eventually called it quits. Their final record before signing to the majors and moving out to L.A. was 1989’s God of Thunder. On the cover
column3: Zombie holds the severed head of Gene Simmons. The record opens with their cover of the Destroyer classic “God of Thunder
column4: ” and White Zombie introduce their version by jacking Kiss' legendary introduction: “You wanted the best? You got the best! Introducing the hottest band in the world!” Their sense of humor and a slam-dunk performance of a Kiss classic bring some much-needed levity to their aesthetic.

column1: In their final stop before “Thunder Kiss ‘65
column2: ” God of Thunder shows the band utilizing samples more successfully than ever. (The best one: Between Zombie verses
column3: a blasé voice chimes in to say
column4: “Listen
column5: you fuckers.”) Yuenger’s style in his White Zombie debut offers the midpoint between Ricci’s and Guay’s—he’s impressive
column6: but not overpowering; heavy
column7: but precise. By God of Thunder
column8: they found footing after some thrilling moments in the underground and a couple of creative missteps. But the missteps come with experimentation
column9: and experimentation is mandatory if you want to escape the 1990s as maximalist weirdo rock stars.

column1: Listening back to White Zombie
column2: it's interesting to consider how their music holds up in 2016. Obviously
column3: they're a crucial part of Rob Zombie's horror legacy
column4: introducing the nihilistic hellscape language he would follow in his solo albums and literal horror films. In an era where Michael Gira is making some of the best records of his life while early works by Sonic Youth and Lydia Lunch are getting reappraised
column5: White Zombie's early presence as a New York underground institution is
column6: on their first 7""
column7: intriguing
column8: and on Soul-Crusher
column9: enthralling. Even their later hits
column10: entrenched in 1990s culture as they were (again
column11: thanks in large part to ""Beavis & Butt-Head"")
column12: stands the test of time thanks to riffs like the slide guitar of “More Human Than Human.” This music pummels
column13: and better still
column14: it escapes the trap of self-seriousness that so many metal and noise bands seem to fall into. They had a sense of humor
column15: which came through in their use of samples and in Zombie's deranged carnival barker performances. But even more engaging than the music's heft
column16: humor
column17: or chaos is the narrative that forms across It Came From N.Y.C.—one of a band that played by their own rules
column18:
bucking genre conventions and cutting ties with bandmates in an effort to continuously move forward.

Can a duo be a supergroup? Maybe that’s a tongue-in-cheek designation for Whitney
column2: the band composed of former Smith Westerns guitarist Max Kakacek and former Unknown Mortal Orchestra drummer Julien Ehrlich. Both were standout members of their former bands; Kakacek never got his due in Smith Westerns
column3: as singer Cullen Omori’s presence soaked up much of the adulation. Ehlrich
column4: who looked about 11 years old behind the kit with UMO
column5: was a long-limbed beast. Whatever reasons for their previous acts’ dissolution and split
column6: the two have found each other and put together something simple but always invaluable: a great warm weather rock’n’roll record.

column1: It’s hard to talk about Whitney without first talking about Girls
column2: another sweet-and-sour rock duo that both UMO and Smith Westerns spent time on tour opening for. Girls breathed life into earnest folk-rock by writing simple
column3: powerful songs about being in love with life and learning to enjoy the basic things. But they broke up after two albums
column4: and their absence left an empty space that has never been filled. Whitney come closer than any band since.

column1: Light Upon the Lake
column2: their debut LP
column3: is a short collection of short songs; half of them are made up of easygoing guitar flourishes
column4: the other half feature woozy strings and slurred brass. This is the Corona of rock records
column5: as Whitney consistently walk that fine line between identifiable and platitudinal. Take the chorus from most recent single “No Matter Where You Go”: “I can take you out/I wanna drive all around with you with the windows down/And we can run all right.” It’s so generically wistful that it could provoke an eyeroll
column6: but it’s delivered with such gentle earnestness that it’s improbably touching. Light Upon the Lake operates in a universe of endlessly repeatable joy
column7: with a touch of melancholy to keep it interesting. The songs could be about romantic love
column8: but they’re open-ended enough to be whatever you want them to be.

column1: The vocals are a harder sell. Ehrlich
column2: assuming vocal duties here
column3: is on the whinier
column4: Muppet-ier side of things. The overall muffled effect of the recording doesn’t help to crystallize anything
column5: either. It’s like someone’s stopped at a stoplight singing their heart out in their car with the windows up and you hear it from the sidewalk. It works great in terms of expressing earnestness but possibly not in terms of pleasantness. I like it because it feels very true. That said
column6: I wouldn’t hold it against you if you weren’t turned off
column7: at least initially.

column1: Make it past that
column2: though
column3: and you’ll find most songs to be near flawless on a small scale
column4: working the way a great short story does. The crisp edges of these songs betray people who really know how to play their instruments
column5: but instead of flashing that fact
column6: they back up
column7: writing only in vivid
column8: broad
column9: easygoing pop-rock strokes. “Golden Days
column10: ” has all the elements of showiness—a guitar solo
column11: extraneous brass
column12: a singalong—but the song stays small and hummable. Low-key perfectionism is perhaps a humbler virtue than seeking the big
column13: dynamic splash. But it has a way of sneaking in past our defenses and lingering longer—before we know
column14: we’ve been singing that song under our breath for the better part of a year.  Whitney might not reinvent anything
column15: but they sound perfect right now
column16:
and it’s hard to argue with being in the right place at the right time.

Putting aside Mumford and Sons’ attempts to taint the term “folk rock
column2: ” there’s no shortage of strong singer-songwriters putting their own spin on the genre these days
column3: from Angel Olsen to Father John Misty to Sharon Van Etten to Kevin Morby. As familiar as it is
column4: music like this can be deceptively tricky to do right; it requires close attention to storytelling and lyrical economy as well as the ability to not completely overpower these words in pursuit of the occasional rock-out. On their debut Masterpiece
column5: Brooklyn’s Big Thief hits the balance with ease and aplomb.

column1: Singer-songwriter Adrianne Lenker’s pens evocative scenes of people and places
column2: while the band shifts nimbly between lo-fi acoustic and throwback rock hooks
column3: keeping everything noisy and tuneful. They do not reinvent the form and they probably won't be the band to break it
column4: but Lenker has a striking voice and a way with turns of phrase—she is a clear star. She's released albums before—one solo and two proto-Big Thief collections with her main collaborator
column5: guitarist Buck Meek
column6: under the moniker Buck and Anne—but on <i>Masterpiece
column7: the songs sound cherry-picked over a lifetime of writing
column8: the stories carefully compiled.

column1: Masterpiece is a scrapbook of sorts
column2: so it makes sense that the name songs—“Paul
column3: ” “Lorraine
column4: ” “Randy”—tend to be the strongest. ""Paul"" twinkles gorgeously through a wistful
column5: dreamy ache of guitars as Lenker recounts a love that could have been if she hadn't been so practical
column6: but ""Lorraine"" is the kind of scene worth replaying in your mind every night just before dozing off. Atop a lightly strummed acoustic melody
column7: Lenker describes an encounter that under another's less tender eye would seem dirty. But Lenker—seemingly harmonizing with herself—captures the magic of spontaneous attraction
column8: the way some lovers can draw you in through just about anything.

column1: Compared to her stripped-down
column2: pre-Big Thief work—where she sounds quieter
column3: sweeter
column4: slightly twangier at times—Lenker sings with more heft here
column5: prodded by the big sound the band makes when it kicks in behind her. But even when the music veers towards feedback and solos
column6: when it seamlessly shifts tempos and directions on a dime
column7: Lenker’s voice remains the guiding force. On standout ""Real Love
column8: ” the band alternates between sparse riffs and bright flourishes of guitar reverb as Lenker likens love to all the awful things—a heart attack
column9: domestic abuse
column10: blackened lungs. She connects it to childhood—how your parents' example of love can screw you up—and it’s a heavy realization that manifests into Masterpiece’s rawest bit of feedback.

column1: What doesn’t work as much are the attempts to make Masterpiece feel overly homemade. The brief opening song
column2: “Little Arrow
column3: ” is in a decidedly lower fidelity than the rest of the album
column4: which can be charming but in this case detracts from how vivid the full band sounds. At the end of “Interstate
column5: there’s a field recording of a baby repeating the same phrase about liking trucks. These touches to the scrapbook feel like tacked-on reminders of an earlier sound. Listening to Lenker’s early work
column6: where she is definitely more of a folk singer
column7:
I’m reminded of a line from Masterpiece’s title track: “There's only so much letting go you can ask someone to do.”

It's hard to think of a band that's gotten more artistic mileage out of a consistent sound than the Melvins. Since their debut Gluey Porch Treatments almost three decades ago
column3: the Melvins have barely wavered from the lumbering adamantine groove that made them so hugely influential on countless grunge
column4: sludge
column5: and alt-metal acts. At the same time
column6: the group's nucleus
column7: frontman Buzz Osborne and drummer Dale Crover
column8: have jumped at opportunities to experiment for the better part of their history. Most notably
column9: over the last ten years Osborne and Crover have shaken things up dramatically
column10: leading an ever-shifting array of Melvins lineups as if the band encompasses multiple identities at once.

column1: In some ways
column2: Basses Loaded is the logical culmination of this ongoing musical-chairs policy. Crover and Osborne's preference for lineup fluidity is rooted in the 2005 departure of longtime bassist Kevin Rutmanis (Cows
column3: Tomahawk). So it follows that Basses Loaded features six different people on bass
column4: most of whom have participated in some form of album cycle with the band. (Crover himself plays bass on four tunes
column5: leaving the drum duties on those songs to original Melvins skinsman Mike Dillard
column6: who returned to record and tour behind the 2013 album Tres Cabrones.) But Basses Loaded also signals trouble
column7: with several indications that the band could now benefit from stability as much as it has benefited from freedom in the past.

column1: Perhaps for the first time ever
column2: the Melvins sound unfocused and—worse—like their music is beginning to lack energy. Where you can point to just about any tune in the Melvins catalog and marvel at how Crover
column3: Osborne
column4: and their cohorts convey passion resorting again and again to the band's trademark Sherman-tank rhythms and de-tuned guitars
column5: Basses Loaded mostly just plods. Sure
column6: it's gutsy to start an album off with “The Decay of Lying
column7: ” a downtempo skeleton of an arrangement that stretches out to six-plus minutes. But the song is devoid of the textural elements the Melvins normally excel at. It also lacks a climax
column8: which leads you to question whether there's a payoff for the patience it takes to sit through it.

column1: There are lively moments: second track “Choco Plumbing
column2: ” for example
column3: with its soaring
column4: '76-era KISS-inspired chorus over an odd-shaped riff. But if anything the song only highlights that we haven't heard enough lately from the Jared Warren/Coady Willis/Big Business incarnation of the band that's been phasing in and out of activity since 2006—especially in contrast to the hodgepodge of contents that makes up the rest of the album.

column1: To say that the cover of the Beatles classic “I Want to Tell You” doesn't shed any new light on the original is an understatement. It's as if the band were vying to give us all the textbook definition of “throwaway cover tune.” Osborne has publicly professed his love of the Beatles
column2: while their influence on guest bassist Steve McDonald's main band Redd Kross is obvious
column3: so clearly they don't mean to be irreverent. But Osborne's snarling vocal can't help but give the song a sophomoric demeanor. Likewise
column4: Osborne and Crover are fairly avid real-life baseball fans
column5: but their rendition of “Take Me Out to the Ball Game” is so snide you would never guess it. Here
column6: it functions as little more than a novelty item
column7: and barely functions in that capacity.

column1: The real kicker here is that “Take Me Out to the Ball Game” is preceded earlier on the record by “Shaving Cream
column2: ” another old-time novelty song with a similar cadence. The song eventually switches into something resembling an electronic loop
column3: but then devolves into outright half-assery when Osborne just shouts “I'm all fucked up / I'm all fucked up” over and over. “Planet Destructor” features the otherwise extraordinarily inventive Trevor Dunn (Mr. Bungle
column4: Fantômas
column5: Trio-Convulsant)
column6: who just absentmindedly plays a mismatched walking bassline over the verse as if he'd been playing along with the wrong tune the whole time. The gag is revealed when the whole band shifts into full-on jazz halfway through the song. By then
column7: it's too late.

column1: Such moves might elicit lukewarm chuckles if they were coming from a band of teenagers for an audience of teenagers
column2: but from seasoned veterans with a dedicated following they reek of being low on ideas. Only the warped psychedelia of “Maybe I Am Amused
column3: ” which features Nirvana's Krist Novoselic
column4: legitimately goes down avenues the band hasn't explored before. Novoselic's accordion injects shades of Eastern gypsy folk music and singer/songwriter folk into the Melvins sound
column5: reminding us that the Melvins have remarkable range given how doggedly they've stuck to their guns.

column1: With its variations in mood
column2: tone
column3: and personnel
column4: Basses Loaded plays more like compilation of B-sides culled from multiple recording sessions spanning several years. That's not actually the case
column5: but the album's lack of flow—and in some cases
column6: lack of point—suggests that for this group with its vitality still well intact after 30-plus years
column7:
a re-focusing is probably in order after a very fruitful run of creative detours.

After releasing two consecutive records of quiet
column2: lonely piano-only music (2013’s Julia with Blue Jeans On and the 2014 City Wrecker EP)
column3: the Spencer Krug of guitars
column4: of bleepy synthesizers and occasionally pounding rhythms is back. Earlier this year
column5: his first famous act Wolf Parade announced that the band was reuniting
column6: first with a secret show and then by dropping their first recording of new music in five years. And now he’s followed that development with the release of his latest effort under the Moonface name
column7: the fully electrified My Best Human Face.

column1: Considering that his last two records relied entirely on piano
column2: Krug’s lyrics and his wearied moan—a nicely distinctive voice to be sure
column3: but one with limited range and an ability to grate on overexposure—they turned out to be surprisingly strong
column4: particularly the full-length Julia. Despite the limited instrumentation
column5: on each he made great use of both depth-adding vocal overdubs and ruminative
column6: carefully considered piano accompaniments showing not a rock musician playing songs but a trained pianist uncovering notes.

column1: With My Best Human Face
column2: however
column3: Krug has returned to traditional keyboard-driven rock
column4: and in offering a new electric version of the previous EP’s title-track ode to Montreal “City Wrecker
column5: ” he implicitly asks his listeners to assess the results. The original “City Wrecker” was emotional centerpiece of that release; looking back on Krug’s time spent in Montreal and his somewhat anguished decision to leave
column6: it worked quite well in the cold and stark context of piano and voice. However
column7: with Krug’s decision to repeat the track here he does himself a bit of a disservice
column8: as his chosen ornamentation for it in a Twin Shadow-y imaginary-'80s slow burn removes some of the heft of the song and makes you speculate on the seriousness of its sentimentality in the first place.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: the rock contrivances work better. Lead single “Risto’s Riff” charges out of the gate with a pounding four-on-the-floor rhythm and sinewy guitar that carry Arcade Fire-style urgency. It's so immediate that you are compelled to shout along with the chorus even as you realize it hinges on the half-hilarious
column3: half-ridiculous rallying cry “At least I'm not a photographer!” On “Ugly Flower Pretty Vase
column4: ” he marries a tight drum-and-bass rhythm to snappy
column5: minimal Britt Daniel guitar. And “Them Call Themselves Old Punks” nails the cresting payoff that “City Wrecker” strived for.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the brief seven-song album neither starts nor ends well
column3: bookended by two dirges. Opener “The Nightclub Artiste” feels like a textbook example of when Krug takes too much time on a slow song going nowhere
column4: putting too much emphasis on a voice that just isn’t dynamic enough. Plodding closer “The Queen of Both Darkness and Light” is even worse
column5: sounding like exit music that plays over credits while an audience exits a theatre. The fact that it clocks in at a baffling seven minutes—the longest song on the record—makes it seem like Krug must be hearing something the rest of us are not.

column1: Then there are Krug's way with lyrics
column2: which can be as divisive as his voice. There’s no question he puts painstaking effort into telling stories rather than singing songs
column3: but there are times when is choices are so off-putting it's hard not to do a double-take.  Take the aforementioned “At least I'm not a photographer” in “Risto’s Riff
column4: ” or the equally awkward “There’s nothing punk about that” refrain in “Them Call Themselves Old Punks.”  Both moments don't feel witty or unorthodox as they do just awkward
column5: like chunky square pegs jammed into the round holes of standard rock songwriting.

column1: When Krug sticks to his strengths—off-the-beaten-path keyboard-driven rock n’ roll
column2: with taut
column3: wiry tunes that match his voice and wry wit—he generally succeeds. But his tendency to slow it down and draw it out leads him to take risks that often don’t pay off. He hit a decent payday on Julia with Blue Jeans On
column4: but already that formula delivered diminished returns on its successor City Wrecker EP. And here now on his electric return
column5:
even less so.

If Detroit underground hero Payroll Giovanni and Minnesota-born
column2: Texas-based producer Cardo Got Wings swerved any further West on Big Bossin’ Vol 1
column3: they’d splash down into the Pacific. The pair’s panoramic portrait of a mid-level hustler leans so heavily on classic LA gangster rap
column4: Bay Area hyphy and hood movie mythology
column5: it’s impossible to picture these narratives taking place anywhere else but California. Call it Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas music—a nostalgic throwback to a time when pop culture was loaded with images of palm-treed pavements
column6: side-held pistols and fingers curled into a ‘W’ that comfortably files alongside Kendrick Lamar and DJ Mustard’s modernized takes. Chance the Rapper’s gospel-swathed Coloring Book has been called the sound of the summer
column7: but it’s Big Bossin’ Vol 1 that’ll fill the Lowriders with octane.

column1: Payroll’s a member of Doughboyz Cashout
column2: whose contract with Jeezy’s CTE World imprint has more or less come to nothing
column3: but the group has countered the stasis with concrete-tough mixtapes that bite like the Michigan winter. On Big Bossin’ Vol 1
column4: Cardo brings in the sun. Behind the boards on all 18 tracks
column5: his beats are built to feel like westside classics
column6: with melodic synthesizers
column7: silky vocoders
column8: sour whistles
column9: James Worthy-sized handclaps and female background vocals.

column1: The emcee proves the perfect foil for Cardo’s grooves. His relaxed flow is slowed a couple of knots as he sinks into the beats
column2: evoking the swagger of Too $hort and the smoothness of the late Mac Dre–if the two West Coast legends had been compelled to rap about selling drugs on every song. Pitching himself as a rags-to-riches neighborhood baron
column3: Payroll chronicles a life of drug deals
column4: bright jewels and warm pistols. But Big Bossin’ Vol 1 is more self-aware pastiche than hard-boiled realism. There’s no creeping menace
column5: ten crack commandments
column6: or cutting moral center.

column1: The outline might be familiar
column2: but Payroll brings his own literary deftness. His fluid rapping is matched with a close eye for detail and sharp turn of phrase. “Sell Something” sees him lay out an origin story as he recalls finding an eighth-ounce of cocaine at age 15: “It was like the crack gods were like
column3: ‘Here young dog’
column4: ” he spits wryly. On “Day in the Life
column5: ” he recycles the concept of Ice Cube’s “It Was a Good Day
column6: ” replacing the basketball games and Goodyear Blimp with police sightings and handguns. Moving from the mundanity of his morning routine
column7: to the tension of almost gunning down two innocents
column8: Payroll’s storytelling paints pictures in clear technicolor.

column1: “Successful” is the clearest iteration of Payroll and Cardo’s collaborative sparkle. The beatmaker recycles the opulent keys and fat bassline previously gifted to Nef the Pharaoh on pop number “Betta Run.” In Payroll’s hands
column2: it’s reimagined as a brash hustler’s anthem. The rapper plays the grinning Don
column3: laying out by his pool in the Cali sun
column4: counting the fruits of the come-up. It’s a sound as timeless as a Bukowski novel; as iconic as the Hollywood sign. Together
column5: the duo have coaxed out their respective strengths on Big Bossin’ Vol 1. At a time when the West is enjoying a creative surge
column6:
a couple of young outsiders are helping to carry the weight.

Slum Village is a rap nerd's dream—cult figures with a drama- and death-filled story that's tied into the genesis of a nigh-mythical figure
column2: a man who was still redirecting the path of the genre while he lay on his deathbed. The group's lineup was constantly churning

column4: they've become peculiar cult figures: frequently referenced
column5: yet largely unknown. The group now consists of sole original surviving member T3 and longtime SV producer Young RJ
column6: but it has variously boasted the presence of Detroit wordsmith Elzhi and J Dilla's younger brother
column7: Illa J and gone through name changes (weeks after their official debut was released in 2000
column8: they released quasi-album Best Kept Secret as J-88). But there is one combination—the OG trio of T3
column9: Baatin
column10: and Jay Dee (as Dilla was primarily known then)—that stands as the Supremes with Diana Ross
column11: Harold Melvin and the Bluenotes featuring Teddy Pendergrass. And with the Fan-Tas-Tic: A Jay-Dee Production box set

column1: The Fan-Tas-Tic box set is sourced mostly from the the group's two most widely lauded efforts—Fan-Tas-Tic
column2: Vol. 1 and Fantastic
column3: Vol. 2. Both achieved holy-grail status in part due to their scarcity
column4: in the days when music was passed hand-to-hand and dubs of dubs were of ever-decreasing quality. The majority of people who heard the first two Slum Village records in the early days were hearing corrupted versions full of hiss and distortion that actually aided Dilla's warm grooves and the rappers' frayed and imperfect vocal performances. All of the songs were recorded in Dilla's basement on a DAT machine
column5: which meant that the group had to do their songs in one take. They only had two mics—even ad-libs and hooks were done in real time. Furthermore
column6: the entire debut album was made over the course of a week
column7: sandwiched in between Dilla's growing responsibilities and rising renown as a producer for acts like the Pharcyde and A Tribe Called Quest. This imbued their early recording with a genuine garage-band quality—and even after they signed to A&M Records for their second project
column8: they still recorded from the same location
column9: bringing acts from the both coasts to in Dilla's Conant Gardens basement.

column1: In hindsight
column2: Dilla was the star of Slum Village
column3: but that message was never broadcast through the releases—and it's great to hear Dilla's music outside of the idol worship that has sprung up around him following his 2006 death. Hearing full swaths of Dilla productions where his music is foundational but not central is almost unthinkable today. Even though this set is subtitled A Jay-Dee Production
column4: it skips the heavy-handed approach of 2012's Rebirth of Detroit tribute or of his many reissued  digital artifacts
column5: which tend to get weighed down by their own sense of of historical importance. On Fan-Tas-Tic
column6: the stars are aligned equally—Baatin's squiggly esoteric weirdness
column7: T3's rhyming with a chip on his shoulder
column8: the celestial backdrops of Dilla's expansive
column9: smooth-yet-rugged palette of soul samples. Everyone was locked in for these records
column10: and the focus is on no single part
column11: but the sum of Slum Village.

column1: There's a beauty in how local these records are—not in terms of landmarks or civic pride (though that is palpable too)
column2: but in the sound of young artists trying to break away from a crowded pack of competition. T3 and Baatin experiment with bar formation
column3: wordplay and vocal inflection—most notably on Fan-Tas-Tic
column4: Vol. 1
column5: which is more or less a collection of semi-polished demos chronicling their real-time progression from collaborators to actual group. On this debut
column6: the rappers stutter as if trying figure out how to navigate over Dilla's low-end theories—the producer's tracks were incredibly articulate
column7: full of intelligent bass grooves
column8: cushioned and hidden drum patterns that spoke to a shyness
column9: and an offbeat smattering of snaps
column10: snares
column11: ticks and claps that felt like nervous tension or socially awkward conversations full of pauses and repeated non-sequiturs. It's all there on Fan-Tas-Tic
column12: Vol. 1's opening number
column13: “Fantastic” which features a nearly-eerie but wholly-soothing track hosting laughable sex advice: “All you gotta do is grip your meat/ Laugh at her
column14: massage her/ Take a bath with her/ Devour her.”

column1: Foreshadowing his final evolution with Donuts
column2: some of Dilla's tracks were lyrical enough to not require much rapping
column3: and the group was smart enough to let some of his music breath
column4: playing loose with their presence. For “Look of Love (Remix)” they laid back and mimicked Slick Rick; on “Hoc N Pucky” they free-styled over-the-top grunts and growls and sound effects; and on numbers like “Fantastic 2
column5: ” “Fantastic 3
column6: ” and “Fantastic 4
column7: ” they retreated to simply chanting hooks
column8: treating alternate takes as half-song interludes.

column1: If the song titles (and history) get confusing
column2: it's understandable. Slum Village wasn't necessarily focused on being easily accessible or readily formatted.  Songs
column3: themes and concepts were constantly treated as serials
column4: reduxed
column5: remixed
column6: and reprised; the average song length on the debut is about two-and-half minutes
column7: with almost half of them clocking out before the 90-second mark. Amazingly
column8: they all come off as complete ideas. There's never the impression that the crew ran out of ideas
column9: or had too many to share—rather
column10: it feels as if they said what they had to say and when they had no more to say
column11: they stopped.

column1: By the time Fantastic
column2: Vol. 2 was released in 2000
column3: Dilla had worked closely with A Tribe Called Quest
column4: Busta Rhymes
column5: Common
column6: The Pharcyde and others—all of whom found new rhyme pockets in his work. T3 and Baatin obviously cribbed from these greats
column7: but it wasn't just the rappers who felt emboldened by Jay's advancement.  One boon of his prodigious career is that—despite its brevity—Dilla's work had mini-phases and periods
column8: like truncated versions of Picasso's Blue Period or Miles Davis' forays into fusion or funk. On Vol. 2 he's no longer condensed
column9: adding a sense of comfort and ease to all his prior antics. Despite all of the (deserved) accolades given to Donuts
column10: Vol. 2—with warm shimmers like “Get Dis Money
column11: ” “Fall In Love” and “Climax (Girl Shit);” throbbing excursions like “Eyes Up” and “Go Ladies”; and pulsing moments like “Conant Gardens” and “Raise It Up” —makes one of the strongest cases for Dilla's greatness.

column1: The album featured Busta Rhymes
column2: Kurupt
column3: D'Angelo
column4: Pete Rock
column5: and—perhaps most notably—Q-Tip affirming the end of A Tribe Called Quest and anointing SV and flame keepers on “Hold Tight”: “Hold tight
column6: this is the last time you hear me/ I'm out now
column7: this is the last time to cheer me
column8: he rapped. “I'ma leave it in the hands of the Slum now.” Q-Tip's declaration didn't help the album's fortunes much; Vol. 2 was shelved and left in purgatory for two years before being shipped off to another label. And by the end of that year
column9: the Slum Village of Jay Dee
column10: T3
column11: and Baatin (who passed away in 2009) was no more.

column1: Fan-Tas-Tic: A Jay-Dee Production also comes through with a comprehensive history of Slum Village (the A Fan-Tas-Tic story booklet)

column5: Vol. 1 and Fantastic

column7: but mainly kept intact and made to sound crisper without losing their original basement charm. The five included pieces of 7” vinyl seem gratuitous (their content is duplicated on the discs)

column10: discs
column11: and booklet are just in a box with too much space for them; they just sit and shift and will likely be damaged under less than the most careful handling. But the draw here should always be the music.  And Dilla comes through on both of these projects

column13: ” both a reworking of the Vol. 1's “Beej N Dem”) Baatin raps: “You say looking for them niggas

column15: we be them/This shit remind me of some old EPM/ D shit

column18: and his rhyme partner
column19: but never Dilla. It may be sacrilege to many
column20:
but hearing Dilla without hearing rappers talk about Dilla is the best way to hear Dilla.

“It's not the destination
column2: it’s the journey” is an old cliché
column3: but one that sounds refreshed and alive on folk-rocker Steve Gunn's Eyes on the Lines. It’s an album about travel and transition
column4: about exploring
column5: wandering
column6: and letting yourself get lost. Every song happens on the way to something else
column7: in the patches between starting out and ending up. Often it's unclear exactly where Gunn’s characters are headed
column8: or why
column9: but the flux in his words and music is vivid. To get caught up in these tunes is to eschew standing still.

column1: Despite all the forward motion
column2: Eyes on the Lines is also richly contemplative. As Gunn extolls the virtues of ambling
column3: he gives himself lots of time to observe and ruminate. That reflectiveness is matched by the music
column4: which is rarely static—there's always a shuffling beat or winding hook to keep the motor running—yet never rushed. Gunn’s band sounds confident without being complacent
column5: and breezy in the best sense. The effects can be subtle as a whisper
column6: but these songs continually move the air.

column1: Gunn continually refers to roads
column2: paths
column3: and changes in direction. In “The Drop
column4: ” he sings
column5: “I think I missed my flight/Looks like I’ll spend the night
column6: ” and sounds pretty happy about it. By closer “Ark
column7: ” his blissful aimlessness takes on a Zen-like quality: “Here is where we’ll get nowhere/And everywhere is there now.” It might seem indulgent to pair such beatific sentiments with jammy guitar rock
column8: but Eyes on the Lines is actually quite focused.

column1: Though Gunn’s songs develop gradually
column2: the tensions mount and momentum builds. Often that comes from increasing jolts of energy
column3: as in the stair-climbing hooks of “Ancient Jules
column4: ” which celebrates losing control in a rush of layered guitars. On “Conditions Wild
column5: ” Gunn again espouses letting go—“Feel the path and move along/The traces where you’ll go”—but the tune’s ratcheting swing makes that idea exciting rather than passive.

column1: Nine players are credited on Eyes on the Lines
column2: and you can feel their presence throughout
column3: as each song weaves contributions into a tapestry. It’s been thrilling to see Gunn settle so well into collaboration. From his initial forays as a solo artist
column4: to his excellent duo albums with drummer John Truscisnki
column5: to 2014’s lush full-band album Way Out Weather
column6: he’s continually stepped up without slipping. Eyes on the Lines continues that ascent
column7: as does Gunn’s sense of the world as a grand vista to traverse. By embracing the expanse
column8: his music has gotten bigger
column9:
and more universal.

Legendary records are legendary for different reasons—some for the music and some for the musicians. In terms of The Wailing Wailers
column2: it would be tough to locate folks who don’t know the song “One Love” or the name of the fellow singing this song. Bob Marley is enough of a worldwide superstar that his face and his later lyrics are as familiar to American college students as they are to Ethiopian teenagers.

column1: The Wailing Wailers is not
column2: by strict definition
column3: an album—it wasn't recorded or sequenced as a whole. The Jamaican music industry has traditionally been shaped by singles
column4: so this is effectively a singles bundle that was gathered up and released in late 1965. Not only does this highlight the first major recordings of Bob Marley (and it should be noted that most of the songs have Marley writing credits)
column5: but the happy
column6: bouncy
column7: optimistic sound of The Wailing Wailers is also the sound of post-independence Jamaica. It is the sound of a music that would soon reach out beyond the island and internationally through the remarkable voices of Bunny Wailer
column8: Peter Tosh
column9: and
column10: most of all
column11: Bob Marley.

column1: In addition
column2: The Wailing Wailers emerged from Clement “Coxsone” Dodd’s Studio One
column3: one of the foundational
column4: pioneering recording studios where Jamaican music is concerned. Operative from the 1950s through to the early 1980s
column5: Studio One released ska
column6: rocksteady
column7: reggae
column8: and dancehall over the years. The history of Studio One is key to the history of music in Jamaica and the rise of both reggae and Bob Marley.

column1: Revisiting it now
column2: you can also clearly hear the ways that popular music circulates and crosses borders. The influence of American R&B and pop is evident—there’s a version of “What’s New Pussycat?” here—but also a specificity that places the record smack in the middle of the ska and rocksteady period
column3: a precursor to the reggae that propelled Marley into the stratosphere of fame he found himself in the 1970s. Patwa
column4: the Jamaican language
column5: is a Creole that brings together various linguistic elements and structures stemming from West African languages
column6: such as Twi and Yoruba
column7: English
column8: Spanish
column9: Dutch
column10: and Native American sources. A Creole language brings together all of these elements. Similarly
column11: the musical genres of Jamaica are creolized forms. As case in point
column12: The Wailing Wailers brings together multiple influences
column13: at times sounding like 1960s croony R&B as on “I Need You
column14: ” skank-ready ska on “One Love” and “Simmer Down
column15: ” and then Patwa-inflected proto-reggae on the slightly slower “Rude Boy.”

column1: This past year novelist Marlon James became the first Jamaican to win the Man Booker prize for his novel A Brief History of Seven Killings. The book takes the attempted assassination of Bob Marley as its starting point and zooms out from there
column2: taking in the scope of '70s Jamaica
column3: extending forward to the 1990s. The panoramic scope of James’ book is a demonstration of Jamaica’s international reach and influence. The Wailing Wailers is another key piece of the artistic and creative juggernaut that is Jamaica
column4: helping to demonstrate the narrative of reggae and of Bob Marley. With Jamaican creativity in the spotlight
column5: it’s a perfect time to provide access to Studio One again.

column1: The Wailing Wailers is the first reissue from Yep Roc Music Group
column2: who have access to the Studio One catalogue
column3: thanks to an agreement with Coxsone’s daughter Carol Dodd
column4: and they are starting as they plan to continue—with reissues of foundational albums (some quite rare) provided in the form of their original release. The Wailing Wailers is one that has been available since its original 1966 release
column5: specifically by New England’s Heartbeat Records. Heartbeat lovingly reissued a good number of Studio One releases from 1983 through to the mid-'00s
column6: but changes in the music industry meant that Heartbeat petered out. Yep Roc appears to be ably picking up the trail and providing high-quality LP
column7: CD and digital access as well as involving Jamaican native Chris Wilson
column8: the former A&R manager for Heartbeat. The care that has been put into this reissue is obvious. It’s meant to provide a historical touchpoint by utilizing all original album art and providing the same track listing as the first time around
column9:
and now a legendary album will be consistently available to whole new audiences.

Despite the torpid

“I done been on both sides of the burner/I done witnessed both sides of the murder/I done seen a nigga killed/And seen a nigga kill a nigga.” This is how Joey Purp opens up his new mixtape
column2: iiiDrops—announcing himself as a street-savvy
column3: thug-fluent
column4: criminal-adjacent observer of society's darker corners. He's more on the sidelines than in the fields
column5: but he's not an outsider looking in
column6: either. An accessory by necessity
column7: he's smart enough to not snitch and careful enough to make his death threats subliminal
column8: yet still aware enough to speak as the conscience from within the belly of the beast

column11: ” he raps.

column1: It's tempting to simplify when talking about artists
column2: to shave off their multitudes
column3: flatten
column4: and categorize them. Because he is part of Chicago's Savemoney crew—the loose collective of artists that includes Chance the Rapper
column5: Vic Mensa
column6: and others—Joey comes with a certain set of preconceptions
column7: namely that he be a technically proficient stylist with a progressive artistic bent. He fits that bill
column8: sometimes

column10: socially aware and defiantly filthy

column12: which is more well-rounded and definitive than his woozy The Purple Tape or his word-centric experimentalism as part of Leather Corduroys.

column1: Where Chance spent Coloring Book showcasing the audacity of his hope for a better tomorrow
column2: Joey is a panoramic and holistic realist when he looks around at the forces and people that support the cycle of violence in his hometown. On “Cornerstore” he rides a horn-powered groove from Thelonious Martin and Donnie Trumpet
column3: dropping off pinpoint observations along the way: He recalls speaking to his brother who may never come home from behind bars
column4: confesses of marijuana dreams of drug kingpin success
column5: notes that “White kids deal with problems that we never knew to bother/Arguing with they dads
column6: we pray we ever knew our fathers
column7: ” and watches gentrification from ground zero: “Now up in the corners where killers used to inhabit/They built a row of new condos where they tore down project buildings.” He's joined by Saba (another Savemoney satellite)
column8: who matches him observation for observation: “My best friend from when I was 11
column9: posted with the weapon/Actin' like he do not see me step into they section/We used to hoop daily and treat it like a profession/And now I'm walking by him like I'm some type of pedestrian.”

column1: Joey’s songs make no distinction between the personal and political
column2: and see systemic failures through the lenses of individuals without ever quite pointing fingers or succumbing to victimization. “We grow up being neglected by our elected officials
column3: ” he raps on “Money & Bitches.” “My nigga
column4: cry me a river
column5: I’ll buy you a tissue/ I don’t wanna hear your complainin’
column6: you pressin’ my issue/All I know is money and bitches.” There’s also little difference between good thoughts and worthy wordplay—every rhyme and idea flows into a next; almost every moment is quotable and represents a greater whole. It’s an astounding feat for someone who tried to lean and swag his way through his first solo project.

column1: In a year that's been dominated by headline releases from marquee artists
column2: iiiDrops has the making of a sleeper hit. The POV is measured and insightful
column3: the rhyming is assured by both technical and narrative metrics
column4: and the music is quietly confident and sharply novel—Knox Fortune and GARREN's funky broken soul on “Photobooth
column5: ” OddCouple's triumphant swing on “Morning Sex
column6: ” the stripped Neptunes-ish drumplay of “Girls@” and “Say You Do
column7: ” updated blaxploitation psychedelia on “Godbody
column8: ” a semi-paranoid summer evening pulse to “When I'm Gone.” Some of the numbers sound like they belong of a producer’s showcase
column9: more than a rapper’s coming out party
column10: but Joey rides every beat with an easy intensity that makes his worldview the unifying factor here. He never allows the tracks to become the sole point of focus

column5: ” he raps

If “The X Factor” has done one good thing in its many years of manufactured drama and purposeful audition mockery
column2: it’s near-singlehandedly keeping alive the decades-old tradition of the pop girl group in the West. While they never disappeared worldwide—girl groups and their alumnae dominate J- and K-pop
column3: for instance—the only two Western girl groups with consistent pop clout are the UK’s Little Mix and the States’ Fifth Harmony

column1: There are some downsides to this. Most groups that get far on “The X Factor” are assembled from failed solo auditions
