column8: now with discernibly individual personae: Ally on lead and Dinah on backup
column9: Normani with the near-rap
column10: Lauren’s cool alto balancing Camila’s Ring Pop of a voice. (Rumors of the latter being groomed for a solo career
column11: at least as of this album
column12: are exaggerated; 7/27 is as vocally egalitarian as any girl-group album of the past decade or so
column13: and better for it.) It’s easily the best potential single the group’s ever released.

column1: It also sounds exactly like 2003—specifically
column2: like a cut off Christina Aguilera’s Back to Basics or Mya’s Moodring. An even eerier flashback comes with “Not That Kinda Girl
column3: ” which rehashes the look-don’t-touch theme that was everywhere in pop in ‘03 and adds Missy Elliott
column4: who as usual lately is operating at maybe 50% of peak but is welcome nevertheless because 50% of peak Missy is still pretty damn good. The echoes of early-'00s R&B radio  seem to say more about the length of the pop nostalgia cycle than anything about Fifth Harmony in particular
column5: which points to a larger issue: For all the group’s done to establish each singer vocally
column6: they’ve yet to pin down a sonic identity
column7: nor a lyrical identity beyond vague empowerment
column8: and 7/27 dutifully triangulates every trend and radio format of the past couple years. There’s stuttery
column9: pitch-shifted EDM with “The Life.” There’s the fake r&bass track “Work From Home
column10: ” wherein Dr. Luke protégé Ammo imitates rap producers imitating DJ Mustard. There’s even diluted reggae and Fetty Wap collaboration
column11: both on “All in My Head (Flex)
column12: ” which samples Mad Cobra’s “Flex.” About half the tracks have tropical-house synths stuck in like cocktail umbrellas.

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: the trendier the track
column3: the worse Fifth Harmony showcase it proves. Several of the songs also suffer from brutally protracted lyrical metaphors that function as near-parodies of pop song form. It’s not entirely Fifth Harmony’s fault
column4: for instance
column5: that r&bass ceased to be a thing well before “Work from Home
column6: ” or that everyone missed Jordin Sparks’ near-identical 2015 single called “Work From Home
column7: ” or even that everyone (somehow) missed a certain megastar’s No. 1 single about work-work-work-work-work-work. It’s definitely their fault that this single involves a lot of metaphorically sexing up the freelance life
column8: which is perhaps the least sexy labor arrangement in world history. (More accurate first verse: “worried about basically everything
column9: wearing ripped pajamas”). Or that only Ty Dolla $ign—whose verse is one big leadup to a T-Pain-esque “put in overtime on your booooddddyyyyyyyy!”—takes the material as seriously as he should
column10: which is to say not at all.

column1: Like most girl groups
column2: Fifth Harmony trades in the kind of pop-cultural press-quote feminism where the group can say they are out squash gender roles and “gender-institutionalized thinking” while recording a fantasy of a stay-at-home sexter reassuring the household breadwinner that he’s the boss at home. And like girl groups historically
column3: they grapple with how to reconcile that independence with love. The original girl groups were as liable to record love songs as wistful
column4: even macabre cautionary tales. Modern groups Little Mix and Spice sing love songs
column5: but they couldn’t be more obvious that their heart belongs to their besties. Destiny’s Child
column6: with few exceptions
column7: repudiated love entirely: “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9f_YTbQzlik"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">if you ain’t in love
column8: I congratulate you.”

column2: though
column3: approaches the subject with full abandon. “I Lied” thoroughly rescues its conceit from Michael Bolton hell and turns it into a sighing
column4: feverish surge reminiscent of “Countdown.” Bonus track “Dope” is even more crushed-out
column5: with a track that sounds like jittering through the whole runtime of a slow jam and lines delivered like so many words to stumble over en route to the big confession: “I don’t know what else to say
column6: but you’re pretty fucking dope.” It strikes that rarest of balances for crush songs—confident but skittish
column7: sure of one’s exact feelings but clueless about what to do next
column8: independent but nevertheless absolutely swooningly done for—and also feels like a first. Mediocre girl-group material is a cartoon simulation of women’s lives. Good girl-group material reflects them. Great girl-group material recasts them in 3D with all the color cranked up. Finally
column9: albeit in flashes
column10:
there are hints that Fifth Harmony may reach that peak.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23281/homepage_large.25353efb.jpg|DJ-Kicks|28083.0|Dâm-Funk|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['!K7']|2016-06-03 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:11.812075|"

The best DJ sets always involve some sort of telepathy. Usually it’s when a DJ constructs a set that steers you towards euphoria so effectively that it feels like they’re inside your brain at a panel of controls
column2: à la Voltron—a state of ecstatic dissociation so magical that it's the third most popular subject for pop songs after love and smoking weed. But rare and particularly talented DJs can pull off an even more magical feat
column3: dragging you out of your head and into their minds
column4: letting you hear the world through their ears for a moment.

column1: I used to think Dâm-Funk was the more typical kind of DJ
column2: mostly because I’ve only seen him at festivals and big events
column3: and never at Funkmosphere
column4: the residency he’s held at an L.A. bar for the past 10 years. In that more intimate environment
column5: he can stretch out and offer a fully immersive sound experience. And after hearing his contribution to the DJ-Kicks franchise
column6: which is designed to replicate the Funkmosphere vibe
column7: it’s clear that he’s actually the second kind of DJ
column8: and maybe one of the best at that specific kind of mind meld.

column1: Heard through Dâm-Funk’s ears
column2: the world is
column3: as you might expect
column4: a very funky place. It’s also very dreamy. Dâm may be best known for reigniting L.A.’s passion for hard-edged
column5: car-shaking synth funk
column6: but at 44
column7: he seems more interested in creating a shared hypnagogic utopian mindspace than simply rocking a party.

column1: The mix’s tempo tops out at a fairly restrained 126 BPM
column2: and most of the tracks chill a few notches below. The mood is overwhelmingly easy-going
column3: from contemporary synth auteur Moon B’s study in warm
column4: reverb-drenched minimalism that opens the mix
column5: to the closing shimmer of Philly-inspired soul group Crystal Winds’ 1982 track “Funk Ain’t Easy.” Some of the selections
column6: like the airbrushed erotic fantasia “Love Jam” by the cultishly strange duo Randell & Schippers (who have a screencap of a complimentary MySpace comment from Dâm on the homepage of their website
column7: beneath a backstage photo at a Blue Man Group show)
column8: border on New Age. Others
column9: like Gaussian Curve’s synth pad daydream “Broken Clouds
column10: ” cross fully over.

column1: Taken as a whole
column2: the mix paints a soothing watercolor portrait of a funk-based American counterpart to Balearic house—a style that Ibiza ravers were starting to greet the dawn with around the same time as the bulk of Dâm’s DJ-Kicks picks were being recorded–that never actually existed. Piecing together obscure old cuts from regional labels that probably wouldn’t ever have crossed paths back in the day (like Verticle Lines’ proto-vaporwave 1982 breeze-funk rarity “Theme From Beach Boy” and Gemini’s airy 1997 take on Chicago house
column3: “Log In”) Dâm’s crafted an entire genre in retrospect.

column1: It’s a sound with a promising future
column2: if this mix is any indication. Dâm’s picks lean heavily on vintage grooves that are extremely rare even by crate-digger standards
column3: but some of the strongest material is new. There’s Moon B’s “Oof
column4: ” and Kansas City funk auteur Reggie B’s purplishly psychedelic “Poison Candy
column5: ” and Dutch producer Henning’s “Arrival / Departure
column6: ” which drops a throbbing G-funk beat into a crystalline garden of blissful synth flutes.

column1: Despite Dâm’s preference for playing tracks pretty much all the way through—which suggests an infectious
column2: wide-eyed passion for the music that fits into his mind-control powers—the mix is properly appreciated as a whole. You can let it wash away whatever cares you have in warm
column3: funky waves. There are a few songs that deserve to be listened to on their own
column4: though
column5: and one of the best comes from a collaboration between Dâm and fellow L.A. dreamchaser Nite Jewel. “Can U Read Me?” takes the peak-Janet weightless perfection of “All for You” and turns its touch even lighter
column6: transforming it into something that captures the joy of seeing the sun rise in the corner of your eye and knowing the party isn’t even close to being over. Funk may not be easy
column7:
but with Dâm at the controls it can sure feel that way.

"|21942.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21942-dj-kicks/|7.7|Miles Raymer

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23275/homepage_large.8e0c8d75.jpg|Collapse|31927.0|Seiho|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Leaving']|2016-06-03 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:12.395220|"

Field-recorded sounds have been part of popular music almost as long as portable recording devices have existed. Our desire to capture the world as we hear it with the purpose of sharing with others is intrinsic to humankind
column2: as are our desires to tinker and to put forward a best face; in experimental electronic music
column3: we often see all three of these desires play out at once. A great example of this is Collapse
column4: the latest album by Japanese artist Seiho
column5: a genre-fluid record which follows in the footsteps of its forebears in the hopes of creating something new and distinct out of fresh ideas
column6: beat culture and curated found sounds.

column1: Collapse is a strange and beautiful record that refuses categorization
column2: traipsing through the fields of house
column3: free jazz and musique concrète on the way to something inscrutably Other. Despite being ostensibly an “electronic” record
column4: Seiho proudly boasts that “very few samples were used in the making of the LP
column5: ” instead utilizing live instrumentation and sounds captured in personal recordings of animals
column6: machines and nature
column7: which he sculpted into many of the beats
column8: rhythms and chirps put on display.

column1: The idea of turning found sounds into electronic music is nothing new
column2: of course. Matthew Herbert and Matmos have been releasing records with beats made from hand-crafted sound recordings for years
column3: with two of the most famous examples coming in 2001 with the former’s Bodily Functions and the latter’s A Chance to Cut Is a Chance to Cure. Both of those records derived their power in part from their slavish devotion to specific themes (sounds from bodies and medical procedures
column4: respectively). One spin of Collapse
column5: however
column6: and you can tell that Seiho is going for something else
column7: something freer and less constricted by subject matter; rather than focusing on a world bodies or industrial machines
column8: Seiho wants you to hear the wandering world that passes in front of him. And wander it does—over the course of only thirty-three minutes
column9: Collapse darts and dashes from sound to idea to sound like the speed-shifting brain of a manic teenager. Not one track of the ten lingers on a single musical idea for long. Even the track (possibly ironically) titled “Deep House” doesn't have a single deep house or even house-inspired idea coursing through it.

column1: For this reason
column2: it’s easier to see Collapse as a single work with repeating index points rather than a collection of “songs.” There’s jazz-concrète (“The Vase”)
column3: actual deep house (“Exhibition
column4: ” “Plastic”)
column5: and whimsical IDM (“Peach and Pomegranate
column6: ” “DO NOT LEAVE WET”); many songs
column7: such as “Edible Chrysanthemum
column8: ” touch multiple indexes. In many ways
column9: this record is a kindred spirit to last month’s Brainfeeder release Fool by Dutch artist Jameszoo. But while that record felt messy and basement-made
column10: Collapse is neat and pristine
column11: as if every careening moment has been carefully crafted and controlled so that no matter how wild it gets
column12: it will never fall apart.

column1: There’s no question that Collapse is a fascinating
column2: inspired record. But the obvious challenge in making music this inherently fidgety is that it can be tough for a listener to stay engaged for long stretches of time
column3: let alone the duration. As a result
column4: some of the tracks get boring (“Deep House
column5: ” “Rubber”) and others start or end interestingly but can’t sustain the momentum throughout.

column1: “Edible Chrysanthemum” and “DO NOT LEAVE WET” manage to hold on to their ideas just long enough to sink in deeper than the rest.  The first begins with pleasant mechanical hums and aviary trills
column2: then picks up a mock-gamelan beat (maybe samples of sticks on glass) before giving way to a mournful near-jazz of horn
column3: piano and percussive clacks. Album closer “DO NOT LEAVE WET” is easily the warmest and poppiest track: Beautiful
column4: rich and full
column5: and featuring a wider range of instrumentation of '80s funk and R&B
column6: it invites jamming in summer mornings en route to the beach
column7: or maybe afternoon mojitos. The song plays almost like your reward for staying put
column8: and underlines that with a bit more focus and clarity
column9:
Seiho might evolve into an important voice in the new guard of experimental electronicists.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23259/homepage_large.17cc3eca.jpg|Skin|30917.0|Flume|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mom & Pop'
column2: 'Transgressive'
column3:
'Future Classic']|2016-06-02 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:12.661595|"

The universe opened quickly for Flume
column4: the 24-year-old Australian DJ/producer born Harley Edward Streten: his debut album topped the ARIA charts
column5: Lorde and Disclosure enlisted him for remixes
column6: and mud-caked crowds have strained to glimpse him at Coachella and Lollapalooza. And with that rise
column7: he’s become something of a dance music Rorschach test: either he’s posited as mainstream electropop’s next great hope
column8: or he deepens the frowns of those fatigued by rave culture ubiquity and personifies all that is frivolous about it. (The Guardian recently brushed him aside with
column9: “Oh
column10: great! Just what the world has been waiting for
column11: ” a pessimism that leans toward the Woody Allen school of astronomy.) It’s no wonder
column12: on his second album
column13: Flume says he aimed to write a track that sounds “like the fabric of the universe tearing ”—all that weight was cramping his shoulders.

column1: Skin
column2: the record in question
column3: aims for that level of grandiosity throughout. It’s a stadium-sized upsell of Flume’s prior atmospheric formula—skittish beats that cleave easily to gruff rappers and R&B sopranos alike
column4: rattling future-bass warp
column5: undulating synths—that swells with energy but spills over edges. Here
column6: Flume recruits an array of famous guests (Beck
column7: Little Dragon
column8: Vince Staples
column9: Raekwon
column10: AlunaGeorge)
column11: padding their radio-friendly cuts with the persistent crescendos of his self-titled debut
column12: then ballasting them with loose instrumental interludes. The sum suggests that he’s an earnest collaborator
column13: flashier but still casting around for a distinct identity.

column1: Flume has a fondness for female voices singing in their upper register. On his first album
column2: that role was played by Jezzabell Doran on the album’s best cut (“Sleepless”). Here
column3: it’s handled twofold by Aluna Francis of AlunaGeorge (the groggy
column4: glitchy “Innocence”) and also Kučka
column5: a young Aussie singer who distinctly echoes Francis in slinky R&B phrasing and tinny topnotes. The halting
column6: futurist beat of Kučka’s solo track (“Numb & Getting Colder”) nods to Flying Lotus and Four Tet; that core is closely repeated on her second turn
column7: “Smoke & Retribution
column8: ” which jolts awake in agile verses by rapper Vince Staples. The lead single
column9: “Never Be Like You
column10: ” is already a Disclosure-remixed pop hit (and a winking psychotropic video); it saunters on Flume’s languid trap drops and a plummy R&B hook from the Canadian singer Kai
column11: a former Jack Ü collaborator who trills a mundane mea culpa with a gleam of defiance. (“I’m only human can’t you see/I made
column12: I made a mistake/Please just look me in my face/Tell me everything’s OK”). There’s a mathematical quality to how he deploys singers in these productions
column13: where the heavier his low-end distortion throbs
column14: the more featherweight smoke curls follow.

column1: Snuck in at the close
column2: “Tiny Cities
column3: ” featuring Beck
column4: is comparatively minimalist
column5: a welcome smattering of downtempo new wave synths. Here
column6: the production is as nimble as the vocalist; Beck opens in staccato leaps
column7: chipper despite the Sea Change-like refrain of despondency (“it was never perfect
column8: never meant to last”)
column9: and Flume loops him in a slow
column10: roiling momentum until the sentiment blooms into a battle-scarred catharsis worthy of a John Hughes soundtrack. There’s one betrayal of Flume’s busy hand in the song
column11: in a dubstep-lite drop halfway
column12: but it’s energizing. The delicate ebb that follows it—complete with falsetto from Beck
column13: naturally—is the most vulnerable moment of the album. Skin’s other cameos don’t approach that humanity: Little Dragon’s “Take a Chance” buckles under an erratic beat that feels determined to remix itself twice over
column14: and Tove Lo’s lilt sounds harried on “Say It
column15: ” though her chorus does generously provide your next Tinder icebreaker (“let me fuck you right back”).

column1: Against this
column2: the instrumentals can be hesitant
column3: as if waiting patiently for a vocalist to drop by—“Pika” stretches out a fragment of a SBTRKT-like soul murmur
column4: and “Free” pushes the repetitive yet determined synth runs of a keytar gained sentience. But there is one glimpse of intriguing extroversion in Flume’s standalones: “Wall Fuck
column5: ” the musician’s aforementioned attempt to rip the universe a new one
column6: which delivers a hell of a rubbery
column7: electrohouse-inflected bass and snarls a sliver of ghostly female coos into a strange
column8: invigorating banger. It’s short and snappy
column9:
gone too fast in an album that could’ve been streamlined to let moments like it shine. But maybe it’s the sound of floodgates opening.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23254/homepage_large.8e780eab.jpg|Modern Country|29384.0|William Tyler|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2016-06-02 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:12.838329|"

William Tyler is not a traditional storyteller. Having played guitar alongside some of Nashville’s most distinctive songwriters (Lambchop’s Kurt Wagner and Silver Jews’ David Berman)
column2: he has clearly learned a good deal from them about establishing his voice
column3: structuring narratives
column4: and building tension. But Tyler—whose solo albums are purely instrumental—works in a field all his own
column5: composing increasingly intricate and immersive narratives with just his playing. Tyler referred to his 2013 Merge Records debut Impossible Truth as being a “’70s singer-songwriter record without vocals
column6: ” and he develops that vision even more fully on its follow-up
column7: Modern Country. Backed by an all-star band that notably includes Wilco’s Glenn Kotche and Megafaun’s Phil Cook
column8: Tyler is able to summon a wide range of moods
column9: from plaintive pastoral folk to a particular kind of kosmische American music that fuses Brad Cook’s spacey synths and Luke Schneider’s gorgeous pedal steel like a slow
column10: steady breeze on a hot summer day.

column1: Even with all the talent in the room
column2: Tyler’s guitar remains front and center. In “Kingdom of Jones
column3: ” his close-mic’d fingerpicking is breathtaking. The clear
column4: constant sound of his strings rattling and his hand sliding across the neck highlight just how intimately produced and carefully performed these songs are. While quieter moments like these feel like a natural progression from Tyler’s early solo guitar work
column5: other songs demonstrate how complex his signature style has become. Of course
column6: there are enough sprightly
column7: rubbery guitar licks to remind you that this is a guy whose official website also functions as a carefully curated Grateful Dead video blog. Still
column8: Tyler puts an emphasis on both words in the album title. The compressed
column9: layered solos in the first half of “The Great Unwind” recall prime-era Mark McGuire
column10: while its triumphant
column11: chugging second half actually brings to mind prime-era Mark Knopfler. First single “Gone Clear
column12: ” meanwhile
column13: is Tyler’s most dazzling composition yet: a six-minute stunner that plays like Jim O’Rourke’s The Visitor reimagined to soundtrack a ballet.

column1: Tyler’s thematic inspirations are equally far-reaching. “Kingdom of Jones” is dedicated to the Mississippi county whose anti-slavery stance during the Civil War put them at odds with the rest of the Confederacy. The lilting
column2: starry-eyed “Albion Moonlight” is named for the title character of Kenneth Patchen’s American classic The Journals of Albion Moonlight (a character who coincidently posits that “Man has been corrupted by his symbols” and that “Language has killed his animal”—arguments put into practice by the band's quiet
column3: evocative performances). Like his holographic figure on the album cover
column4: Tyler lets himself become a part of his surroundings throughout Modern Country
column5: encouraging his listeners to explore for themselves.

column1: “The cultural geography of this vanishing America is what I sense as a slow fade
column2: ” spoke Tyler’s disembodied voice in a trailer announcing the album’s release: the kind of grandiose mission statement that might seem over-the-top were it not coming from an artist whose music is so radiantly full of ideas. He continued
column3: “Modern Country is a love letter to what we are losing in America– to what we’ve already lost.” The beauty of the album lies in the fact that Tyler is able to pay homage to these foundations not with bitterness or cynicism but with awe
column4: appreciation
column5:
and even hope.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23321/homepage_large.a7f53053.jpg|Suck on This|28602.0|Die Antwoord|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ZEF']|2016-06-02 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:13.006397|"

Suck on This is presented to us as a stopgap for Die Antwoord’s fourth studio album
column2: We Have Candy. MC Ninja teases the record in an interlude where he mimics geek king Napoleon Dynamite
column3: a cultural reference so dated and worn-out that 12 years have passed and it still feels too soon to revive it. It's a neat stand-in for the South African rap trio and troll merchants Die Antwoord themselves: They may have started this act with the intention of discomfiting us  and making us think
column4: but in 2016
column5: they are merely wearisome.

column1: Even though it’s hard to erase the shock rap-rave South African group’s rat-infested
column2: toilet-sitting
column3: loogie-hocking videos from your memory (we’ve tried)
column4: it has been two years since they released their last album
column5: Donker Mag
column6: so here’s a refresher: Ninja and Yolandi Vi$$er embrace “zef
column7: ” a philosophy that encourages intentional vulgarity. In doing so
column8: they’ve created a body of work that at times can be engaging. Even now
column9: it’s hard not to be riveted by 2010’s “Zef Side”—there’s that slow-mo of Ninja’s knock-kneed thrusts that send his flaccid penis flopping around in his Dark Side of the Moon shorts; there’s Yolandi’s severe mullet
column10: her awkward dancing and alien-like visage. In the ensuing years
column11: however
column12: we’ve become inured to Twitter trolls and ALL CAP$ personalities. More often than not these days
column13: Die Antwoord comes off as tired and trying way too hard.

column1: In a 2012 interview about their sophomore album Ten$ion
column2: Die Antwoord said their issues with Interscope stemmed from the label urging them to “be more generic.”  This is an ironic claim
column3: for it's precisely what plagues Suck on This
column4: their first mixtape since being liberated from their contract. While the tape includes new material along with remixes of old songs
column5: the whole thing sounds like a retread. Nothing here is as bad as Ninja’s nasally chorus on Ten$ion’s opening track “Never Le Nkemise 1” or the unlistenable Uncle Jimmy skit
column6: but maybe “boring” is a worse criticism than “bad.”

column1: Sure
column2: there are moments here that you can imagine playing well to festival crowds: If you close your eyes during the drops on “Gucci Coochie
column3: ” you can practically see the rows of shirtless bros and underbutt-showing girls in the Sahara tent at Coachella losing their minds. The best production is on the slinky
column4: simmering “Bum Bum
column5: ” but Ninja’s line
column6: “Bed wet
column7: legs spread
column8: big mess everywhere” is such a profoundly gross visual that you will be lunging for the skip button.

column1: When it’s all said and done
column2: the remixes are the most interesting tracks on Suck on This and God (fka DJ Hi-Tek) especially squeezes some life out of Die Antwoord’s most popular songs. He pumps “I Fink You Freaky” full of steroids
column3: bumping up Letterman’s favorite song to a vein-popping
column4: eyes-bulging
column5: steam-spouting cartoon. The last 45 seconds reach such berserk Road Runner-levels
column6: you wonder if he’s making fun of electro trap. If so
column7: he’s beating Ninja and Yolandi at their own game. At this point
column8: it all—even the letter that accompanied Suck on This claiming they didn’t know what a mixtape was—feels too contrived to be enjoyable. Maybe We Have Candy will surprise us and swerve far left
column9: but if not
column10:
Die Antwoord’s getting muted.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23253/homepage_large.8a968c3e.jpg|Awkward Pop Songs|33727.0|Jank|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Creep']|2016-06-02 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:13.331440|"

Humor has a tenuous place in music
column2: and actual “jokes” have almost none at all. It's understandable: Most songwriting places a premium on some sort of basic honesty
column3: and asking someone “are you joking?” is usually a way to determine if they are shitting you. Honest
column4: earnest attempts to be funny
column5: meanwhile
column6: usually end up with the opposite result. So this is what Awkward Pop Songs knowingly puts itself up against—its cover art and album title immediately establish its prank-punk bonafides and “JANK” itself is probably even sillier than the ""Futurama"" reference frontperson Matt Diamond used for previous band Panucci’s Pizza. But in the few months since its initial release and its physical reissue
column7: Awkward Pop Songs has lived out a lyric from another trio whose superficial goofiness was a Trojan horse for one of the most inventive
column8: original and flat-out fun records in its realm: “Saw the cover of the tape
column9: figured it’s pretty wack/later on eventually admitted that it’s pretty crack.”

column1: As was the case with Das Racist
column2: local heroes Ween
column3: and even the Golden State Warriors
column4: JANK’s irreverence feels like an unlocked superpower rather than a defense mechanism or compensatory measure—that they’re having this much fun with their technically astonishing chops makes their subversion of realness seem all the more amazing. Even more improbable is the number of styles in which they can operate: though the title Awkward Pop Songs is the least-clever aspect of the LP
column5: it’s an accurate descriptor for an overview of nearly every offshoot of “revival” emo that has coalesced into the new shape of alternative rock.

column1: There’s plenty of the arpeggiated
column2: hammer-and-pull guitar of the dubious
column3: American Football-fathered “twinkle” subgenre
column4: as well as the two-handed tapping that marks its mathier offshoots. JANK can also veer towards hefty
column5: Will Yip-approved emo-gaze and sometimes it all happens within the same song (“Caitlyn”). Diamond’s voice can elicit the instantaneous thrills of raw-throated
column6: Midwestern emo and caffeinated pop-punk without the requisite adenoidal whine. In fact
column7: the songs that most immediately sound like they're crushing hard on someone turn into surrealistic stoner talk: “Caitlyn” proposes a playdate of “Katamari Damacy” and late-night TV with an imaginary dog. “Wut I Liek Abt U” cops the irrepressible
column8: house party giddiness of Nothing Feels Good and its whimsical
column9: quotable non-sequiturs—“And you could use a new toothbrush!;” “Tell me your favorite kind of dinosaur?”

column1: At its peaks
column2: Awkward Pop Songs draws a fat highlighter on the connection between emo’s fourth wave and the unconventional
column3: genre-spanning pop of the Dismemberment Plan or the Unicorns
column4: bands whose manic
column5: effusive
column6: anti-cool styles soon were subsumed by more earnest
column7: bombastic forms of indie rock. This aspect of JANK can make Awkward Pop Songs sound damn-near necessary in 2016—if peers like Foxing
column8: The World is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die
column9: and the Hotelier are stewards of the communally composed
column10: broadly ambitious sound of mid-decade indie rock
column11: they also have its tendency towards somber intensity.

column1: But JANK kid because they love: the most impressive part of Awkward Pop Songs is that it’s incredibly funny without sounding like it’s ever making fun of anyone specific. Diamond's pop culture reference points are still cartoonish and broad—“Ouran Highschool Toast Club” tweaks the title of a popular parody of otaku culture
column2: while “Race Car Bed” nods at an overlooked joke on the otherwise overexposed “Can I Borrow A Feeling?” episode of “The Simpsons.”

column1: But the best laughs are musical in-jokes and some have nothing at all to do with JANK’s style of music. “Race Car Bed” also nominally “features” the presumable #sadboy parody Yung Goth Boi and “Loading Screen” might be a subtext-free goof on the retro-futurist fetishizing of James Ferraro or PC Music. “The Hat Store” strives to be this decade’s “Combination Pizza Hut & Taco Bell;” “Spilt to Bill” shouts out the similarly untamed Island of Misfit Toys and announces
column2: “if you don’t like Built to Spill
column3: then I don’t fuck with you or anyone you know” while sounding like a There’s Nothing Wrong With Love cut played at 78 rpm.

column1: The climactic moment of Awkward Pop Songs occurs when the happy hardcore of “J A N K!” crumples into a heap for no discernible reason. And then
column2: the most legit LOL a punk record has given me in ages: a group chant of “THIS IS...A RIPOFF...OF A...TITLE...FIGHT SONG
column3: ” knicking the melody of their emo-gaze turning point “Head in the Ceiling Fan.” It doesn’t come off like a joke at the expense of punk rock’s most stoic bands
column4: or really even the countless pop-punk acts who’ve aped it to establish a more “mature” sound. It's more of a simple “if if feel good
column5: do it” moment. Or
column6: an acknowledgment that even if it's only four years old
column7: that's a watershed classic
column8: and thus
column9: public domain. It’s the same kind of open-ended communication and crowd participation that constantly pops up in hip-hop and pop music. Rather than shy away from people claiming their fans are “meme loving Tumblr kids
column10: ” JANK say
column11:
“we are too.” Is it any wonder that JANK can basically be their own backing band at shows these days?

Cover songs have long been a crucial part of Mark Kozelek’s work. In the days of Red House Painters
column2: Kozelek recorded devastating interpretations of songs by Kiss
column3: Paul McCartney
column4: and even Francis Scott Key to prove just how widely applicable his brand of melancholy was. His selection of covers—often picked straight from the classic-rock songbook—drew a clear line from his sepia-toned shoegaze to golden-era '70s radio
column5: culminating in his curation of a John Denver tribute album at the turn of the millennium and his ensuing move toward more straight-ahead singer-songwriter material under the Sun Kil Moon moniker. In the first decade of the '00s
column6: as Kozelek’s music found him less focussed on emotional extremes and more on the gray areas in between
column7: he recorded subtle
column8: gorgeous versions of songs by contemporaries like Low
column9: Will Oldham
column10: and Casiotone for the Painfully Alone. Up until his recent turn toward diaristic
column11: autobiographical songwriting
column12: these covers were some of his most revealing work: songs that felt as much a part of his legacy as any he had written.

column1: In that sense
column2: Kozelek’s latest collection of covers
column3: Mark Kozelek Sings Favorites is his most classically Kozelekian release since 2010’s Admiral Fell Promises
column4: the solo guitar mood piece that served as the finale for one season of his career
column5: before 2012’s Among the Leaves ushered in a prolific era of controversies and absurdly big lyric sheets. Like Admiral Fell Promises
column6: Mark Kozelek Sings Favorites features some material that will be familiar to longtime followers. Tracks like Bob Seger’s “Mainstreet” and the traditional folk song “Get Along Home Cindy” have appeared in his live sets for years. Meanwhile
column7: a superior rendition of “Send in the Clowns” first showed up on his 2008 odds-and-ends collection The Finally LP
column8: and “Float On” marks the twelfth Modest Mouse cover Kozelek has put to tape. As such
column9: the title of this collection feels as much a means of drawing a tenuous thematic link between the material as it is a way of admitting
column10: “These are just some songs that Mark Kozelek already knew the words to.” As with the previous release in this series (Sings Christmas Carols)
column11: you will probably know whether or not you want to hear it based on the title alone.

column1: Still
column2: it’s 2016 and it wouldn’t be a new Kozelek release without a few surprises. The most obvious change here is the fact that the sole accompaniment on the album is piano
column3: an instrument used sparingly but effectively throughout his work. And while these performances are a far cry from
column4: say
column5: “Shadows”—the stirring piano ballad highlight from 1995’s Ocean Beach—Favorites has a few fine moments. “Float On
column6: ” a song whose tragic afterlife has found it Kidz Bopped and even worse
column7: finally gets a rendition it deserves. Stripped of its iconic guitar hook
column8: Kozelek’s rendition places the focus on the complex vocal climax at the end
column9: made even more powerful by the understated piano part. Elsewhere
column10: in a loving rendition of David Bowie’s “Win
column11: ” Chris Connolly's piano is the perfect accompaniment
column12: alternating between jazzy
column13: downtempo verses and bold choruses.

column1: Other songs lack these dynamics
column2: like the pleasant but unimaginative redos of “Somewhere Over the Rainbow
column3: ” Roy Harper's “Another Day
column4: ” and the aforementioned Seger cover. Although the latter’s lyrics are a perfect fit for Kozelek’s recent turn toward rambling recollection
column5: the performance feels characterless. While the best of Kozelek’s cover songs found him refitting the songs to suit his particular guitar tunings and vocal style
column6: the arrangements here are mostly identical to their originals. Who would have listened to his AC/DC covers album if he had just strummed power chords and hummed along? On Favorites
column7: it’s as if Kozelek just wandered into a piano bar
column8: handed over a stack of sheet music
column9: and hit record.

column1: At its best
column2: the casual atmosphere makes for one of Kozelek’s loosest
column3: lightest collections to date: something to throw on when you don’t have the emotional capacity for his more distinctive albums. And while Kozelek’s weary
column4: grumbly voice has helped to give a sense of depraved intensity to his last few releases
column5: it sounds prettier here than it has in a while
column6: thanks in part to the inherent melodicism of the songs he picked for the project. Still
column7: for an artist whose cover songs used to reveal multitudes about the performer
column8: Favorites mostly feels self-serving. Maybe that’s why he chose to start the set off with “Send in the Clowns
column9: ” a wry song of wasted love and regret. Coming from a 49-year-old guy who
column10: with every new release
column11: seems increasingly uninterested in pleasing anyone but himself
column12: it also plays as a sort of non-apology. “My fault
column13: I fear
column14: ” Kozelek sings
column15:
“I thought that you wanted what I wanted—sorry my dear.” What follows is a collection of songs that is unlikely to become anybody’s favorite: just more proof that Mark Kozelek Sings Whatever the Hell He Wants.

The best instrumental acts make it easy for you to imagine what their frontperson might be like

column3: heart-clutching romantic—it’s not surprising they’re as much of an influence on emo’s 4th wave as American Football. Russian Circles would present as a burly
column4: stoic
column5: type and even without Tyondai Braxton
column6: Battles maintained the impish
column7: playful charm of his vocals from Mirrored. Holy Fuck are tougher to get a read on: They were arguably electro-punk subversives at the outset; they’ve toured with M.I.A.
column8: and appeared on the Billboard Dance chart

column11: Alvvays

column1: While Latin was crisp and kinetic

column1: Above all else

column4: i.e.
column5: a dance-punk band in a literal sense
column6: trying to approximate electronic music with live instrumentation (and some non-instruments)
column7: to be as pummeling as they are danceable. Congrats is a record that rarely lets up
column8: but there’s a sense of humor creeping in somewhere

column10: ” they imagine themselves as a musclebound chillwave act and the synth-bass of “Caught Up” is a sincere homage to early-'00s DFA.

column1: Holy Fuck never sound out of their element on Congrats—the most surprising addition is an acoustic guitar on the “Shimmering” interlude. But even at less than a minute
column2: “Shimmering” somehow exposes the ultimate issue with Congrats and perhaps Holy Fuck as an enterprise. It’s not so much that “Shimmering” is the first time Congrats repeats itself—as a reprise of the earlier “Shivering
column3: ” that’s completely intentional. But as one of the final tracks

column5: that it has some kind of sonic narrative. Congrats isn’t incoherent in its diversity
column6: it just never seems to build on itself—the record lacks a definitive peak
column7: and most of the individual tracks tend to just state their main idea fairly early on.  Mostly
column8: it’s tough to specify what exactly makes Holy Fuck special or innovative at this late stage in their career
column9: or what they're trying to do with this project besides keep things moving. Of course
column10: that’s a high calling by itself
column11: and maybe Holy Fuck is just the lifesaver who shows up to the party with ice and cups: though it’s functional
column12: Congrats is still fun.

column1: Correction: Due to a tracklisting change
column2:
an earlier version of this review misidentified the song “Caught Up” as “Crapture.” It has been amended.

If Travis Stewart and Praveen Sharma are indeed more concerned with refining their sound than developing it
column2: Folding Time is Sepalcure polished to a textureless patina of reference points. Nearly five years after their self-titled debut album marked the peak convergence of late-2000s bass music and its myriad influences—dubstep
column3: R&B
column4: footwork
column5: house
column6: ambient
column7: hardcore—the duo's second full-length returns to that once vital style to find it rendered prosaic. “Inside me
column8: inside of you/I've been going backwards
column9: ” sings Body Language's Angelica Bess amidst the swaying UK funky-lite of “Devil Inside.” It's surely all too perfect that she wraps up Folding Time's complications so succinctly
column10: and yet the music's dearth of adventure can only be traced to an unflinching myopia.

column1: Maybe it's unfair to fault a rose for having thorns: Sepalcure offered such a gorgeous example of pancultural electronica in 2011 that they have every reason to reclaim their past successes. Besides
column2: “Pencil Pimp” and “The One” aren't being rinsed for nostalgia just yet
column3: so why not transpose their clubby effervescence and disembodied soul to another colorful
column4: balanced stretch of tunes? These guys certainly have the fans for it
column5: and the kind of dubwise dynamism in “Hearts in Danger
column6: ” “Loosen Up
column7: ” and “Brother Forest” is a textbook execution of hybrid sensibilities made seamless. But when those ideas sound underexplored (“Dub Of”)
column8: detached (“Hurts So Bad”)
column9: or superfluous (“Ask Me”)
column10: it's as if Sepalcure see their self-imposed genre as exemplary in electronic music's constantly changing ecosystem.

column1: Stewart and Sharma have said that Folding Time's writing process was like “connecting the present with the past…digging through old memories.” How listeners interface with the refurbished music hinges on their value of that past and the currency it holds. The vocal samples in these tracks offer a reliable barometer in that regard (nothing says 2010 UK bass like an Aaliyah stand-in tossed over some kick-and-stick). Both Sepalcure and their solo projects
column2: Machinedrum and Braille
column3: have always fixated on vocals—sampling the likes of Whitney Houston
column4: Jocelyn Brown
column5: Monica
column6: and KC & JoJo
column7: among others—so their heavy presence is no surprise here. Unlike the Burials and Four Tets and James Blakes out there
column8: however
column9: Sepalcure have never been much for abstraction
column10: lifting lyrics and their sentiments wholesale (maybe pitched down a couple steps) instead of flipping them into a unique translation. “Not Gonna Make It” grabs the opening line of Gladys Knight's “Neither One of Us”; “Been So True” samples liberally from “Heard It All Before” by Sunshine Anderson; hooky and animated as they are
column11: neither song manages to speak new meaning from the vibrant source material. Such handling of samples can relegate empowering and soul-searching music to props for a stunt.

column1: Folding Time's original vocals meet that issue head on. Canadian singer Rochelle Jordan and Brooklynite Angelica Bess each give a nuanced
column2: personalized performance that nudges the music into a pop context. Whiffs of SBTRKT and Bonobo linger in the lush
column3: chilled-out motifs of “Fight for Us” and “Devil Inside
column4: ” but their dubby atmospheres and injured melodicism are Sepalcure hallmarks writ sync-friendly. The verse-chorus structures and downtempo arrangements don't offer a way forward for Stewart and Sharma so much as point towards an alternate space for their music to inhabit
column5: well-adjusted and respectably commercial. Likewise
column6: Folding Time serves as a stopgap for an aging sound without a firm grasp on its bearings. Should Sepalcure continue writing from their fixed point
column7:
they'll have to project further and further from its origin.

Angry Angles captured Jay Reatard at a pivotal point in his career—which
column2: up to that point
column3: hadn’t resembled a career at all. On paper
column4: the short-lived band was just the latest in an erratic string of projects that the Memphis-based garage-punk wild man had been tearing through since the late ’90s
column5: chief among them the Reatards and the Lost Sounds. During that time
column6: he always kept a handful of side projects on the back burner
column7: but Angry Angles seemed different. When formed in 2005
column8: immediately after the breakup of the Lost Sounds
column9: Angry Angles seemed poised to become Reatard’s new big thing
column10: the group that might propel him to the next level of cult infamy. Instead
column11: the band imploded in 2006
column12: leaving a trail of singles in its wake.

column1: Angry Angles collects those singles
column2: along with previously unreleased bonus material
column3: and as such it comprises the entire studio output of Angry Angles. Seventeen songs nailed to the wall in a little over a year is nothing to sneeze at—and neither are the songs themselves

column7: but rendered in a more vivid
column8: visceral Reatards-esque spew
column9: Angry Angles tracks like “Crowds” and “Apparent-Transparent” are lobotomized post-punk
column10: whiplash anthems for 21st-century dehumanization.

column2: a voice-processed call-and-response with Reatard that pays unabashed homage to Devo. There’s an actual Devo cover on Angry Angles as well

column5: the Urinals (“Black Hole”)
column6: and Reatard’s mentor Greg Oblivian (“Memphis Creep” by the Oblivians). Churned together

column9: or “Can’t Do It Anymore

column2: but they’re anything but redundant. On the original single version
column3: distortion is smeared across Reatard’s manic chants and punch-drunk guitar; on the abridged alternate version
column4: that noise is whittled to a finer point. “Things are moving around me all the time
column5: ” Reatard howls on both. It sums up exactly where he was circa-Angry Angles. His romantic relationship with Brown ended the same time the band did
column6: leaving him to pour his scattershot energy into his burgeoning solo career. Brown moved on to Golden Triangle
column7: then a DJ career; Rousseau moved back to his home state of Arizona to revive the formidable Destruction Unit (an outfit Reatard was originally a part of). And Reatard funneled his turmoil into his 2006 breakthrough solo album
column8: Blood Visions
column9: an album that sounds more and more like a masterpiece as time goes by. Angry Angles is a blurry
column10: inconsistent snapshot of his liminal state between dude-in-a-million-bands and burgeoning solo icon—ragged here
column11: refined there
column12:
and brimming with vitality.

Baton Rouge rapper Kevin Gates is relentless
column2: both in style and in work ethic. He’s released his latest mixtape
column3: Murder For Hire 2
column4: only four months after his exceptional major label debut
column5: Islah
column6: which is quietly one of the best-selling rap albums of the year thus far
column7: and clearly among the best-made ones. Gates took a sideways route to commercial success
column8: amassing a devoted cult following through his plainspoken and unflinchingly honest raps and a prickly online presence that’s just as confounding. “You know I got a lot of record labels tryin' to sign me / They say if I'm a risk
column9: it's detrimental to the profit
column10: ” he rapped on Murder For Hire closer “Khaza.” But his antics haven’t even moderately budged the bottom line
column11: and this sequel is further evidence of a winning formula: stay true to yourself and deliver a reliable product.

column1: Murder For Hire 2 serves as both a true followup to its predecessor and an Islah epilogue. There are lots of similar flourishes to the latter—haunting piano keys
column2: dips into gravelly singsong
column3: and some dynamic cadences—but it models the former’s loose structure

column5: it’s quite a formidable collection of records with some of the rapper’s most forceful and vital flows. Over time

His acute eye for detail is as effective reliving addiction (“Great Example”) as it is recounting old gun fights.

column1: “Off Da Meter” finds Gates at his most complex
column2: measuring his rising fame against the sadness set upon him by a grief-stricken life (In the hook
column3: he sings
column4: “Getting 50 Gs a feature
column5: my show price is going up / Hard to deal with this depression lately I've been throwing up” before later delivering the equally complicated appraisal: “God love his children
column6: he's awesome / He sent me an angel who's flawless / Got shot in my mouth in '05 / Knocked out my teeth
column7: it was awful”). Kevin Gates is often best playing the fragile thug
column8: letting his shortcomings manifest as bite-sized ugly truths in passing
column9: and on MFH2 he plays up this dichotomy. “The Prayer
column10: ” aptly produced by the Villains
column11: revisits facing 25-to-life as a 25-year-old hustler
column12: chastising the futility of “internet beef” in the process. On “Lil Nigga
column13: ” a song devoted to camaraderie
column14: he professes his affection for those in his inner circle
column15: then
column16: within seconds
column17: he tracks down and nabs the man that shot him
column18: dispensing his own brand of street justice. He tightropes the divide between hardcore goon and thoughtful companion better than any of his peers
column19: even making the gap indistinguishable at times. ""Believe in Me"" is vintage Kevin Gates: raw to the point of being tender and exposed.

column1: The hooks aren't quite as catchy or well-written on Murder For Hire 2 as they have been in recent months
column2: and he phones it in on ""Fuck It
column3: which repurposes OT Genasis' ""Cut It"" into a rather bland and affectless replica
column4: but overall the tape is a welcome addition to the Gates canon. It works well as a snack-sized accompaniment to the bigger prize. Just because Gates is only a few months removed from the biggest success of his career doesn’t mean there’s even the slightest chance that he plans on slowing down. “Moving on
column5: better thoughts
column6: cleaner weed
column7: cleaner living / Kitchen bags at the cleaners
column8: even made a cleaner killing
column9: ” he raps on “Showin' Up
column10: ” continuing to push onward and upward
column11: carrying his momentum forward. He’s an unstoppable force with an indomitable will
column12:
and he’s on the verge of becoming rap’s brightest sleeper star.

Beth Orton has been considered a singer-songwriter folkie for so long that it can be hard to remember that her career began quite differently. She got her start singing on William Orbit's chillout project Strange Cargo
column2: and she lent her voice to two songs on the Chemical Brothers' Exit Planet Dust
column3: placing her smack in the middle of British pop's volatile post-rave milieu. When her 1996 breakout album
column4: Trailer Park
column5: appeared
column6: it balanced plaintive acoustic guitars and barroom piano with trip-hop beats and atmospheric electronic detailing. That unusual fusion had a lot to do with producer Andrew Weatherall
column7: whom Orton hired after he wedded acid house to bluesy psych rock on Primal Scream's Screamadelica. But Trailer Park ended up being an outlier in Orton's catalog. On subsequent albums she progressively dialed back the electronics

column11: homespun mantle of folksingers like Nick Drake and Sandy Denny.

column4: psychedelic synth-mashers Fuck Buttons

column7: meanwhile

column10: constructing a virtual mood board of favorite songs as they sketched out Kidsticks' idiosyncratic sound. That might how the dubstep-inspired bass throb of “Petals” snuck through
column11: not to mention the peppy new wave pastiche of ""1973."" Fortunately
column12: most of these songs are far more than the sum of their influences: “Petals” may start out sounding like Massive Attack
column13: but by its guitar-and-drum-duel finale
column14: it burns like a church on fire.

column1: It helps that Orton and Hung have enlisted a crack group of musicians
column2: including bassist Bram Inscore
column3: jazz drummer Guillermo E. Brown
column4: percussionist Lucky Paul
column5: and George Lewis
column6: Jr. of Twin Shadow on guitar; Grizzly Bear bassist Chris Taylor also turns up on a couple of songs
column7: and the soundtrack composer Dustin O'Halloran contributes string arrangements to a few more. Their contributions are subtle but key. The rolling “Wave” crests atop a deceptively potent rhythm section and surging wah-wah guitar; “Flesh and Blood” gives her pastoral tendencies a loose
column8: jammy makeover and adds lilting
column9: one-finger synth lines. The scope of her collaborators' resumes—Inscore has played with Beck and Charlotte Gainsbourg
column10: and Brown has a long history with David S. Ware and Matthew Shipp's groups
column11: while Paul can be found sitting in with Chilly Gonzales and Mocky—says something about Orton and Hung's approach here: Kidsticks is less a roadmap to a given destination than a net for catching vibes.

column1: As for Orton
column2: loosening up suits her well. You can tell how much she's enjoying herself by all the ways she experiments with her voice. She takes on three or four different styles in “Snow
column3: ” alternately cooing and yelping
column4: playing head voice off chest voice. On “Wave
column5: ” her delivery frays around the edges
column6: inseparable from the throat that produced it; every crack
column7: every quaver feels like a proud badge of her years on the planet. She's just as physical on “Flesh and Blood
column8: ” but here
column9: in contrast
column10: she sounds absolutely luxurious
column11: with a texture like crushed velvet.

column1: Lyrically
column2: the big themes hold sway. She fixates on celestial bodies and planetary forces: suns
column3: moons
column4: stars
column5: seas
column6: smoke
column7: snow
column8: waves
column9: weather. She swims through a liquid sky on ""1973""; lilacs turn to teardrops in ""Petals."" But she also has an ear for small
column10: lovely details
column11: like ""corduroy legs running up the stairs
column12: the image that gives shape to “Corduroy Legs
column13: ” a delightful
column14: boundless expression of parental love. And if her lyrics sometimes read like the work of someone who's coming off a lost weekend of tarot cards and John Donne
column15: she also knows when to strip back: In “Falling
column16: ” she sings
column17: with devastating simplicity
column18: “Now my phone book / Is filling up with dead friends / And I wonder / Who would answer if I called them.”

column1: Throughout it all
column2: a picture emerges of Orton that's anxious
column3: playful (“You got a certain way
column4: I swear
column5: of sticking it in
column6: ” she leers on “1973”)
column7: and even supremely relatable. There are love songs here
column8: and falling-out-of-love songs
column9: and sometimes it takes a while to tell which is which. The twist in a song called “Falling” is that she's “falling backwards from your arms”; in “Dawnstar
column10: ” she sings
column11: “Our love is gaining speed
column12: ” but she also admits
column13: “I am thankful that what I have is enough.” Escape velocity is for the young
column14: I think she's saying; once you reach a certain stage in life
column15: you're happy just to keep going. And if this all sounds like a case of lowered expectations
column16: the strikingly beautiful “Flesh and Blood
column17: ” the album's peak
column18: turns simple acceptance—of “whatever this is
column19: ” as she sings
column20: over and over—into something approaching ecstasy.

column1: Looking back on Trailer Park
column2: Orton told The Quietus in 2009
column3: “I thought
column4: well
column5: if I really am a singer… I must create my own thing and do it
column6: only then will I prove it. But even today I'm still proving it to myself.” But on Kidsticks
column7: she no longer sounds like she has anything left to prove
column8: which is precisely what's allowed her to make the riskiest album of her career. And she sounds like she's had the time of her life making it
column9:
too.

"|21917.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21917-kidsticks/|7.6|Philip Sherburne

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23282/homepage_large.dc5a021f.jpg|Minor Victories|33080.0|Minor Victories|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Possum']|2016-05-31 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:16.837755|"

Minor Victories have wisely shied away from billing themselves as a supergroup
column2: a term that implies a degree of star power they can’t quite deliver. They prefer the much more neutral descriptor “band.” Still
column3: it’s impossible to separate the group from their other projects. Any band featuring Slowdive’s Rachel Goswell
column4: Mogwai’s Stuart Braithwaite
column5: and Editors guitarist Justin Lockey (along with his brother James) is going to carry certain expectations
column6:
and on their self-titled debut they live up to each and every one of them.

The album’s creation involved a lot of emailing back and forth between members before some of them had even met
column7: sort of a Postal Service situation only with a lot more CC’s. “We didn’t record in the same room
column8: or at the same time
column9: ” they write in the album’s liner notes
column10: “to be honest we probably didn’t start off with the same vision.” Shared visions are irrelevant
column11: though
column12: when you have a lineup of players with such defined lanes. The album’s sound feels preordained: Slowdive’s sighing shoegaze
column13: Mogwai’s cinematic wanderlust
column14: and Editors’ gloomy riffage are all represented
column15:
and in more or less equal measure.

If there’s one thing all three of those bands have in common
column16: it’s that you if you’re reading this site you probably know what they all sound like
column17: but you probably can’t hum any of their songs off the top of your head. That’s not a knock; like a lot of acts from their respective scenes
column18: those groups prioritized aesthetic statements over strong songwriting voices. That sonics-first mindset inevitably carries through Minor Victories
column19: too. On opener “Give Up the Ghost
column20: ” Goswell sings broodingly about black roses and the blood surging through her veins
column21: but it’s mostly an excuse for the song’s gothy ambiance
column22: buzzsaw guitars
column23: and moody orchestral accents. “A Hundred Ropes” and “Folk Arp” are even more sweeping
column24: with even more dramatic string arrangements. Everybody in the group clearly knows their way around a studio
column25:
and the album rarely sounds less than superb.

What’s missing
column27: is the central promise of a supergroup: the thrill of hearing established musicians in a truly different context. Minor Victories’ lineup may stem from different circles
column28: but their approaches are so complementary that there’s rarely any tension or surprise. Unsurprisingly
column30: the album’s most memorable tracks each introduce an X factor. Twilight Sad’s James Graham gamely duets with Goswell on “Scattered Ashes (Song for Richard)
column31: ” a pop number with handclap drums and a blissfully fuzzy riff that imagines a Jesus and Mary Chain cover of “Dancing in the Dark.” Then
column33: Mark Kozelek joins her for what’s essentially a stowaway Sun Kil Moon song
column34:
“For You Always.”

It’s at once completely out of place
column36: and completely welcome. Kozelek goes into full Benji overshare mode
column37: rattling off a flood of dates and locations with almost obsessive
column38: journalistic detail. “We met once in Los Angeles just around the time of the Columbine murders and Mojave 3 were playing on Sunset Boulevard at Tower Records…” he sings (well
column40: recounting his 20-year friendship with Goswell and its periodic romantic undertones. For her verses
column42: and though she can match neither the grace nor the clumsiness of his prose
column43: it’s exciting to finally hear her outside her element. Like everything Kozelek has a hand in
column44:
it’ll drive some listeners absolutely nuts. But in one song he does what Minor Victories manages only intermittently: He makes a lasting impression.

"|21943.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21943-minor-victories/|6.0|Evan Rytlewski

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23248/homepage_large.d5156793.jpg|Rock the Fuck on Forever|33724.0|Angel Du$t|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Pop Wig']|2016-05-31 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:17.358974|"

It’s hard to say whether form or function came first in hardcore
column2: but it’s one hell of an equal partnership—music that effectively conveys the feeling of being extremely intense about something
column3: for about as long as one can feel comfortable being that extremely intense. And yet
column4: its brevity also makes it an interesting filter for pop.  With only two minutes to spare at most
column5: the verses have to be cut out or ignored
column6: the chorus just gets yelled a few times and then you move onto the next one. Isn’t that how most people choose to remember pop songs anyway? Angel Du$t isn’t the first band to come up with this idea
column7: but whereas most bands of this sort come off like hardcore acts dabbling in pop
column8: Rock the Fuck on Forever is the exact opposite.

column1: Hell
column2: this isn’t the first time they tried either
column3: though 2014’s A.D. seems like an obvious dry run in retrospect. At the time
column4: Angel Du$t were a relatively melodic hardcore band
column5: but they didn’t sound ready to embrace it as their definitive aspect. Fortunately
column6: they were emboldened by its positive underground reception. In an interview from last year
column7: the incredibly well-named Justice Tripp said
column8: “I think in 2015
column9: you can do whatever you want and most hardcore kids will at least try it out.” His native Baltimore is having a bit of a moment right due to a couple of hardcore bands that go far outside of the genre’s strictures. In addition to Angel Du$t
column10: Praise skews emo in a way similar to Title Fight
column11: and the rapidly ascendant Turnstile could pass for an aggro 311 or unwoke Rage Against the Machine at times. Angel Du$t itself contains members of Turnstile and fist-swinging traditionalists Trapped Under Ice.

column1: Angel Du$t still love themselves some hardcore bluster—“Rectify” sounds awful cheerful about the ass-kicking you've got coming your way
column2: Tripp’s pretty sure everyone’s kinda full of shit (“Somebody Else”) and life is kinda pointless (“Headstone”). It’s kind of a posture
column3: though: Tripp sings with a chest-puffing huff and enunciates so every lyric is completely understandable. It’s musclebound and also lovably cartoonish
column4: like being menaced by Zangief from Street Fighter or something.

column1: The power of Rock the Fuck on Forever actually lies in its love songs. The band describes themselves as a cross between the Lemonheads and Bad Brains
column2: essentially meaning they play goofy pop songs about how much they like girls and/or how much they wish a girl would like them back at extremely fast tempos. Will Yip’s production tends to be divisive in punk circles
column3: but there’s no denying his ability to make bands in this realm sound like they could’ve snuck into a 1995 alt-rock station if things broke right; the stuttering vocals from  “Ready 2 Receive U” and “Upside Down” imagine if Cloud Nothings followed their pop-punk muse and worked with Rob Cavallo rather than Steve Albini. In other words
column4: they’re about halfway between Pinkerton and Smash.

column1: It’s Angel Du$t’s best trick
column2: but it’s not their only one—there’s nods at surf-rock (“Bad Thing”)
column3: rap-metal non-sequitur (“Toxic Boombox”)
column4: and classic hardcore hxc call-and-response (“Hurt You Bad”). There’s even an instrumental! Rock the Fuck on Forever sees itself as a real-deal album
column5: lending a degree of seriousness to Angel Du$t that would otherwise be absent. Whether it’s necessary is a different issue—even at 20 minutes or so
column6: they've stretched as much as they need to and it’d almost certainly be stronger if it were three minutes shorter rather than three minutes longer.

column1: As much as Rock the Fuck on Forever has the sound of a crossover
column2: there’s never the sense that the band is playing the angles and hoping to score a ticket out of punk rock. You can’t say a band called Angel Du$t making a record called Rock the Fuck on Forever isn’t self aware
column3: but t<span style=""font-weight: 400;"">o get a sense of their work ethic
column4: they’ll be playing nine straight nights while traversing Tijuana to Seattle and back to Los Angeles for the purist Sound and Fury Festival. It’s loud
column5: it’s fast and it kicks ass: despite the jokes and mash notes
column6:
this is hardcore.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23297/homepage_large.97206ee0.jpg|Mosey|33751.0|Daniel Romano|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New West']|2016-05-31 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:17.950987|"

Canada’s Daniel Romano is neither an outlaw nor a good ol’ boy
column2: a bro nor a balladeer. He's made power pop and indie rock
column3: but since going solo in 2010 he's been making his twist on classic country. He might not be tearing up the Stateside country charts
column4: but his new Mosey still makes for a solid entry in the new-school canon of hybrid country. Rather
column5: Romano’s fifth full-length under his own name finds him relying on classic flourishes to build simple songs that look to the great beyond.

column1: For the duration of its dozen songs
column2: Mosey is married to the aesthetics of a forgotten B-movie about the wild West. Romano’s voice sounds weary
column3: the guitars are all a little fried
column4: and mariachi-style brass seals the deal. Psychedelia seeps in
column5: too
column6: for a hazy fever-dream finish. The resulting LP sounds like a dusty
column7: abandoned postcard
column8: a yellowed “wish you were here!” that curls at the corners.

column1: “Valerie Leon” gets the record off to a scorching start
column2: in which Romano races through a near-breathless yarn about a forbidden love that becomes a different sort of disaster—getting what you want doesn’t always yield the best results
column3: it seems. But the bright chorus enlivens the song and makes it sound like a wry joke of sorts. Romano offers an intense triple stack of loneliness toward the middle of the record: “One Hundred Regrets Avenue” sounds hopeless
column4: thanks in part to Romano’s off-kilter piano lines
column5: while “I’m Alone Now” and “Sorrow (For Leonard and William)” trade in melancholy malaise even as they swing and shuffle.

column1: Mosey isn’t all gloom
column2: though it boasts plenty of excellent bummer songs. “Toulouse” is a cheeky
column3: slinky number that finds Rachel McAdams adding wobbly hound-dog “woo”s and breathy lines in French
column4: and “Hunger Is a Dream You Die In” is beguiling in its measured patter. There
column5: Romano sounds barely patient as he contemplates growth and solitude: “Somethin’ in you’s not the same
column6: when there’s no one to share your pain.” Mosey speaks to restless
column7: if uncertain
column8: ambition: you know you need to go
column9:
but you’re not sure where or how to get there.
