column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23229/homepage_large.2971f0dc.jpg|X-Communicate|33564.0|Kristin Kontrol|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2016-05-30 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:18.142760|"

Up until now
column2: Kristin Welchez was most commonly known as Dee Dee Penny
column3: the alter-ego she adopted to front garage band Dum Dum Girls
column4: who formed in 2008 amidst an ongoing revival of '60s-inspired
column5: wall-of-sound rock groups. While embodying Dee Dee
column6: Welchez's cool was effortless
column7: as all cool should be; she could have been born with crimson lipstick and a glossy pair of Ray-Bans sitting perfectly parallel to her incredible black bangs. Now
column8: she has re-reinvented herself as Kristin Kontrol
column9: and her first solo record X-Communicate is a total 180 from her work with DDG
column10: eschewing guitar music for the sleekest synthpop imaginable.

column1: Saying that X-Communicate only takes its strongest moments from '80s pop would be pigeonholing
column2: but it's undeniable that shades of that decade permeate the record from start to finish. The chorus to “Skin Shed” could almost be a lost Kylie Minogue classic
column3: even down to Welchez's vocal delivery
column4: and the backing harmonies on tracks like “Drive the Night” are straight out of Go-Go's/Bangles/Bananarama territory. If Kristin Kontrol ever does truly hit the mainstream
column5: it could be with “What Is Love
column6: ” a song that makes use of the trickiest and most show-stopping of '80s songwriting staples—the power ballad—to tremendous effect. Every single moment is accounted for and brought to completion
column7: from the simple piano melodies of the song's beginning to the stadium-anthem finish.

column1: Luckily
column2: X-Communicate avoids superficiality and mimicry by also adding liberal doses of '70s rock and '90s indie and alt-rock
column3: like on “Face 2 Face
column4: ” a mid-tempo number that would have easily fit into 120 Minutes rotation circa '96. There are even tinges of contemporary pop where necessary (the saxophones on the impeccable “White Street” could conceivably be described as “Jepsen-esque”). Other than Welchez
column5: there are two notable creative forces behind X-Communicate: producers Kurt Feldman (who fronts synth band Ice Choir and used to be a member of both the Depreciation Guild and The Pains of Being Pure at Heart) and Andrew Miller
column6: who was the Dum Dum Girls' final guitarist. The pair's extensive knowledge of pop production is an instrument in itself
column7: and one that
column8: along with Welchez's well-honed songwriting
column9: lifts X-Communicate far beyond mere revivalism.

column1: The album's title track is the culmination of all these elements
column2: a polished four minutes full of bleating keyboards and driving drum machines that conjure a midnight drive through L.A. It does what pop songs do best: Take a moment and blow it up to its largest possible size for all to enjoy. In any genre
column3: it’s a difficult task to make music for an informed audience that is both referential without being derivative
column4: exciting without cloyness. Yes
column5: X-Communicate could be a better record: It could reach further beyond the sound that defines it; it could work harder to analyze and skewer some of the tropes that end up supporting it. However
column6: sticking the landing on a musical pivot this total is an impressive feat
column7: and ultimately
column8: the album’s minor shortcomings become admissible next to its higher moments. The clear ambition of X-Communicate is to leave Welchez’s old persona behind and emerge
column9: fresh and new
column10: as something completely different
column11: and by and large
column12:
that objective is achieved.

"|21891.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21891-x-communicate/|7.5|Cameron Cook

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23319/homepage_large.dcfd2d8e.jpg|The Dream is Over|33490.0|PUP|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['SideOneDummy'
column2:
'Royal Mountain']|2016-05-30 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:18.265750|"

On a surface level
column3: PUP’s second album is this year’s Celebration Rock or The Things We Do to Find People Who Feel Like Us: a half hour of capital-R Rock music
column4: nothing but glorious redlining guitars and pile-on group chants that should be banned in cars for safety purposes. It’s deeply unfashionable and equally vital-sounding
column5: the everyman/Superman appeal of all three enhanced by the setbacks in their origin story. Every review of The Dream is Over is obligated to mention the inspiration behind the album title—after literally shredding his vocal cords
column6: Stefan Babcock was told by a doctor
column7: “the dream is over.” The irony is that Babcock would’ve told you the same thing at any point in the past two years if he never set foot in the office. While Beach Slang and Japandroids use rock music to promise salvation for drunk and aimless weirdos
column8: after playing upwards of 400 shows behind their 2014 self-titled
column9: PUP can only write what they know—which is why the first song is “If This Tour Doesn’t Kill You
column10: I Will”. Ask Beach Slang if they relate.

column1: Babcock’s homicidal thoughts are countered by panicked
column2: massed vocals that double as restraining orders—“WHY CAN’T WE JUST GET ALONG?” “WHY CAN’T EVERYBODY JUST CHILL?!??” Notice that there’s never any threat to turn the damn van around or just break up. Judging by their insane touring regimen and adrenalized music
column3: this a band that believes it can power through anything by sheer force of will. But even if being in PUP sounds like a living nightmare for Babcock
column4: it’s all he’s got. Gig or no gig
column5: he’s waking up most mornings on the floor with more apologies than dollars in the bank
column6: coming to the same conclusion over and over again: that voice in my head telling me I’m a loser was right all along.

column1: But
column2: as Patrick Stickles once sang
column3: that’s OK. “Now that you’ve finally figured me out/I can go home and rest easier now
column4: ” Babcock brays on “Doubts
column5: ” one of the many songs on The Dream is Over which retells an involuntary romantic/vocational break up. “What am I supposed to do now?” he asks and it’s not a rhetorical question; The Dream is Over is weirdly pragmatic about hitting bottom. It’s heartening to see PUP’s realm become more mature
column6: mindful and socially conscious
column7: but being constantly broke
column8: hungover and miserable fucking sucks and there’s no way around it.  There’s a “don’t fight it
column9: feel it
column10: ” philosophy to PUP’s music
column11: validating these emotions with an unapologetically nasty record that lets you work out all of your angst in a safe place.

column1: Babcock yells
column2: “I’ve been blessed with this shit luck
column3: ” a sentiment that typically traces back to the Replacements
column4: the patron saints of lovable loser punk. But Babcock’s misery has nothing to do with luck and everything to do with decisions (“And I’m sick and tired of blacking out on my carpet/And waking up all on my own/So I brought you home"") and PUP’s music is more based in hyper-aggressive post-hardcore and skate-punk. Babcock’s vocals are clean
column5: yelpy and sing-song melodic
column6: justifying PUP's brief spell on the Warped Tour
column7: but the music takes after the precise assault of Drive Like Jehu in the gymnastic chorus of “Doubts
column8: ” Pixies at their most manic (“Sleep in the Heat”)
column9: and the hectoring bass assaults of Mclusky (“Old Wounds”). There’s enough self-deprecation to ensure that The Dream is Over never sounds hateful
column10: but the physical violence of the “Reservoir” and “If This Tour Doesn’t Kill You
column11: I Will” videos isn’t entirely played for laughs. Someone is going to get hurt here.

column1: It’s all very effective because the ultimate message is “misery loves company.” Though a far more accomplished and tuneful record than their debut
column2: The Dream Is Over feels just as much a preview for PUP’s live show. Whereas most music of this sort never tries to sound like more than a couple guys in a room
column3: PUP’s approach is so over-the-top that it can sound as CGI’d as any chart-pop; you have to see it in person just to find out if they can really pull this off. Can they really nail the heart-stopping segue between “If This Tour Doesn’t Kill You” and “DVP”?  How can anyone play as melodically and as fast as they do on “DVP”? On every single chorus
column4: the four members of PUP sound like 4000
column5: is that really how it comes off in a room or is it because they rightfully expect everyone in the crowd to shout along? Frankly
column6: the energy and intensity that’s channeled into the first half of The Dream is Over feels utterly impossible
column7: especially given the subject matter.

column1: But even at 31 minutes
column2: Babcock’s relentless self-loathing can go from intoxicating to simply toxic; it’s fitting that “My Life is Over and I Couldn’t Be Happier” and “Can’t Win” are immediately followed by a song called “Familiar Patterns.” Babcock finally steps out of himself on the closing “Pine Point.” Inspired by the 2011 interactive web documentaryWelcome to Pine Point
column3: Babcock looks back and remembers his brother dying in a drunken car crash
column4: walks around the abandoned Northwest Territories mining town and sees Pine Point as a fate far worse than death or even his current situation (""Imagine if your hometown never changed"" goes the tagline). As a sort of pop-punk Greek chorus
column5: the band repeats “I hope you know what you’re doing” over anxious minor chords
column6: cautionary advice that had about as much impact on them as “the dream is over.” They’ve tried so hard and got so far only to find out in the end
column7: it doesn’t even matter.  So the only thing to do is keep moving—if that tour didn’t kill PUP
column8:
nothing will.

"|21718.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21718-the-dream-is-over/|7.8|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23260/homepage_large.079485d3.jpg|Tempo|32141.0|Olga Bell|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['One Little Indian']|2016-05-30 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:18.906358|"

Where Olga Bell's last album
column2: Край (Krai)
column3: offered an imaginary tour of her native Russia's hinterlands
column4: Tempo represents a very different sort of ethnographical expedition: into contemporary club culture and '90s dance pop. In preparing for the album
column5: the conservatory-educated musician made a habit of frequenting events like François Kevorkian's Sunday-night Deep Space parties at New York's Cielo club
column6: where she would dance
column7: Shazam
column8: and
column9: above all
column10: listen closely to the inner workings of what she heard. (She made these research trips alone
column11: she says
column12: in order to avoid the distractions that would have accompanied going with friends.) Back in her studio
column13: she browsed producers' forums to find out which VSTs young EDM producers currently favor—""I wanted to use sounds that I thought of as really commercial and almost kind of gross
column14: she says—and she wrote out measure-by-measure transcriptions of vintage songs like Snap!'s classic ""Rhythm Is a Dancer"" and 2 Bad Mice's ""Like It Deep
column15: the better to understand their structural underpinnings.

column1: But if this all sounds very academic
column2: the project was motivated by a far simpler impulse: The desire to make joyful
column3: body-moving music. She was especially inspired by the way that different tempos evoke different physical responses
column4: so she began most songs by deciding which tempo matched her mood that day—hence the album's title—and then letting the music come to her as the metronome tick-tocked steadily away. The process yielded an array of rhythms across the spectrum
column5: from woozy trip-hop to peak-time house to 160-BPM footwork.

column1: The results resemble dance music as glimpsed through a funhouse mirror: strangely distorted
column2: sometimes goofy
column3: and deeply pleasing on a simple
column4: almost childlike level. Pitch-shifted voices zoom across the stereo field like unknotted balloons
column5: and bursts of tuned 808 toms and rimshots chatter like wind-up teeth. Common dance music tropes get magnified to exaggerated proportions: Trap finger-snaps echo through hangar-sized reverb in ""ATA
column6: and in the giddy ""Randomness
column7: trance stabs and synthesizer leads congeal into an ungainly heap
column8: like a Jell-O mold filled with Eurodance. The bridge of ""Power User"" turns hip-hop's call to throw your hands up into a sing-song jump-rope rhyme. Stylistically
column9: the music has little in common with Край; last year's Incitation EP anticipates Tempo's electronic palette but not its spunky sense of play. But what unites the three records is Bell's evident delight in the plasticity and malleability of sound. She's particularly fond of portamento
column10: the effect that connects a run of notes in a long
column11: sweeping motion
column12: which she applies liberally to synths and voice alike
column13: giving her melodies a springy
column14: elastic sense of movement.

column1: Bell may have trained as a pianist
column2: but she proves to be a formidable singer: expressive
column3: playful
column4: inventive
column5: and acrobatic without being showy. Just listen to the finely calibrated timing and the carefully cracked pitch of the way she sings
column6: ""You sulk
column7: sit alone in a bar / Looking a little like a punchline
column8: buddy"" (from ""Power User
column9: which is decidedly not a toast for the douchebags). She can go from operatic finesse to a conspiratorial whisper in a single phrase
column10: and she's never too polished to make time for hiccups
column11: chuckles
column12: and vocal fry. In fact it's often her voice that carries the day: Subtract the synths and beats from the gooey R&B jam ""Zone
column13: and the tune would hold up just fine as an a cappella
column14: her multi-tracked harmonies stretched across the frame like a web of chewing gum.

column1: Fortunately
column2: despite Tempo's unusual backstory
column3: nothing here scans as ironic. And in a few cases
column4: Bell's outsider-looking-in setup has little bearing on the music itself. ""Ritual
column5: a full-blooded house anthem featuring the singer Sara Lucas (sounding a lot like Roísín Murphy in late-night-diva mode)
column6: wouldn't sound at all out of place on a crowded dancefloor at three in the morning. And the closing song
column7: ""America
column8: makes for an uneasy comedown from all the carefree hijinks that have preceded it. Over a minor-key dirge
column9: she gives her adopted homeland a stern talking-to—""Is that what you fear? That you're not forever?""—while tremulous organs and gleaming sawtooths explode like a halftime show. In the song's refrain
column10: she jams an extra pause into the world and accents the final syllable—""Ameri-ca""—to make it suddenly sound foreign and strange. If the message of the song is that we can't dance away the end of empire
column11:
there's a subtler truth being made here: that we can wear our otherness like a badge of pride.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23121/homepage_large.41eee1c0.jpg|Mondo Alterado|33630.0|Rebolledo|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hippie Dance']|2016-05-30 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:19.071079|"

The Mexican techno producer Mauricio Rebolledo has compared his own aesthetic to a drive through a long tunnel. You can hear that in his music: the whine of the engine and the wheels against the road; isolated notes bobbing in empty space like taillights streaking through the darkness; the steady pulse reminiscent of the rhythm of fluorescent lights passing overhead
column2: all lines converging dimly on a distant vanishing point.

column1: There were glimmers of it on his debut album
column2: 2011's Super Vato
column3: which spun bare-bones synth and drum tracks into rowdy
column4: psychedelic club cuts that conveyed the manic rush of hallucinating at the wheel. But it really came together on his 2014 mix CD Momento Drive
column5: particularly on a remarkably strange song he created for the mix
column6: <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NAuqWyW32NQ"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“Windsurf
column7: Sunburn & Dollar
column8: ” in which he hollered the titular phrase in a throaty caveman howl—something more like “Windsor
column9: sumble 'n' doar!”—over a beat that sounded like an electric guitar going up in flames
column10: strings popping their coils as the whammy bar turned molten.

column1: The same aesthetic defines Mondo Alterado
column2: a new album of original material that has more in common with that mix CD than it does with his debut album. A DJ who is partial to psychedelic sets of mind-numbing duration—he and Superpitcher played a 25-hour back-to-back set (as Pachanga Boys) in Mexico City a few years ago—Rebolledo has said that he only began producing in order to create the kind of material he was seeking for his sets but couldn't find elsewhere. In that sense
column3: Mondo Alterado is a testament to the clarity of his vision. It unrolls like an impeccably thought-through DJ set
column4: right down to the way tracks flow seamlessly from one to the next
column5: with held notes or drumbeats acting as the glue that holds the pieces together.

column1: Rebolledo's music has always been sparse
column2: but on Mondo Alterado
column3: it's more hypnotically hollowed-out than ever. “Spacer Rainbow Woman” is typical of his approach
column4: as two spindly guitar notes and a gently swaying drumbeat are strung like a rope bridge across the void. A wordless sigh offers a suggestion of melody
column5: and in the song's long plateau—you can't really speak of “peaks” in Rebolledo's work—a rubbery bass arpeggio creates rhythmic and harmonic tension. “Discótico Sinético” and “Discótico Estático” are similar: one-finger synth melodies
column6: distant whoops and howls
column7: lunkheaded rhythms heavy on cowbell and tom. “A Numb Gas to the Future” is even more minimal—a coldwave sketch and seven-minute palate-cleanser
column8: connecting two of the album's highlights
column9: “Fears Come True” and “Pow Pow.” (The latter is especially great
column10: coming closest to the unhinged ecstasy of “Windsurf
column11: Sunburn & Dollar.”)

column1: Nothing happens in a hurry here
column2: and Rebolledo himself pokes fun at his music's humid languor in the title of the album's opening track
column3: “Here Comes the Warrior (Super Short Album Version).” Its swirl of droning synths
column4: tribal drums
column5: and ululations goes on for nearly a quarter of an hour
column6: and begs the question: What on earth must the long version be like? Which brings us to one of Mondo Alterado's best qualities: its absurdist sense of humor. In “Life Is Strange
column7: Life Is Hard
column8: Life Is Great
column9: ” Rebolledo fills in the music's emptiness with a rambling monologue full of platitudes and positive affirmations
column10: sounding like a self-help speaker that the denizens of Black Rock City have mistaken for an actual shaman as he builds to a tongue-in-cheek climax: “Never lose the faith
column11: 'cause life is really great/Dance again/Dance again.”

column1: Despite the lyrics' campy qualities
column2: there's something off about them
column3: something almost sinister
column4: and that disturbing undercurrent carries into “Fears Come Through
column5: ” a dead-eyed protestation of unrequited love delivered over canned tambourines and Novocaine-drip synths. With a chorus that goes
column6: “I don't want to be afraid to say I love you
column7: ” it's the creepiest anthem you're likely to hear on a dance floor all year.

column1: Throughout this long
column2: sidewinding album
column3: you may  find yourself asking
column4: Is this guy for real?—and that's precisely what makes Rebolledo's whole shtick so compelling. The music is enervating and exhilarating in equal measure
column5: and it sounds unlike almost anything else in techno right now
column6: save for similarly left-field primitivists like Barnt. Mondo Alterado isn't for everyone. But for those who like their techno with a healthy dose of deadpan
column7:
Rebolledo's unique strain of gonzo trance is all the fuel they need for a long trip to the far side of nowhere.

"|21786.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21786-mondo-alterado/|7.4|Philip Sherburne

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23289/homepage_large.576c7e78.jpg|elseq 1|168.0|Autechre|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2016-05-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:19.293973|"

Arriving in a month thick with surprise album releases from A-listers like Beyonce
column2: Drake
column3: James Blake
column4: and Radiohead
column5: Autechre’s Elseq might not surpass its peers in terms of buzz or anticipation. But it has definitely got them beat in sheer volume. The five-part series—which was posted to the UK-based electronic duo’s webstore last week—adds up to more than four hours of music
column6: out-clocking its peers by a significant margin. Taken at once
column7: Elseq 1-5 is a mammoth hunk of listening
column8: the IDM equivalent of a Netflix series binge. It is twice the length of Autechre’s last—and previously
column9: lengthiest—album

column1: Musically
column2: the collection seems to advance the argument for Autechre as a sort of post-human jam band
column3: with members Rob Brown and Sean Booth improvising at length within an opaque world of custom-designed music software. Free from the limitations of a physical format (there is currently no CD or vinyl release planned for Elseq)
column4: Autechre are free to sprawl and wander. And wander they do. Elseq 1-5 are as heady and frustrating as anything the duo have ever released. In some stretches
column5: the music is glacial and serene (“eastre”). In others
column6: the Brown and Booth’s violent squelches suggest machine-on-machine violence in the spirit of Survival Research Laboratories (“c7b2”). Absorbing the whole thing requires a bit of commitment. Or maybe it just takes a giant bag of weed and a lot of free time. Thankfully
column7: Elseq is also available to purchase in installments.

column1: Active since the late ’80s
column2: Autechre’s early full-lengths—Amber
column3: Tri Repetae—could be more clearly understood in the context of dance music
column4: as the duo relied on similar hardware
column5: like drum machines and analog synthesizers. Even still
column6: their output has always embraced and amplified electronic music’s eerie otherness. “We had heard these Latin Rascals edits with these fast bits with drums that sounded weirdly robotic
column7: taking electro into this other zone
column8: ” Booth told Thump last fall. “Half of the tracks that we do as Autechre are about recreating the actual sensations I used to get from those things—just getting post-human and next level.” As the years have passed
column9: the duo’s music has become ever more idiosyncratic and abstract. The DNA of techno and electro are in there somewhere
column10: but Booth and Brown have largely abandoned traditional melody and harmony in favor of raw sound design.

column1: Elseq 1-5 is not Autechre’s first foray into download-only releases. 2008’s Quarstice was followed by a series of digital EPs that offered expanded and alternate mixes
column2: which were often superior to that album’s edited material. Last year
column3: the duo posted a series of nine recent live recordings of new material for sale online. An important part of Autechre’s identity has been the duo’s willingness to mess with its audience’s perceptions. A track might register as repetitive
column4: yet never actually repeat itself. Another might repeat the same phrase for 20 minutes at a stretch. Other works have been so chaotic that it is nearly impossible to retain them in your memory.

column1: The set’s second installment is the most extreme
column2: with Booth and Brown delving into crunchy
column3: headache-generating digressions in 10-minute chunks that will feel either exhausting or exhilarating. “eastre” kicks off the third grouping with nearly a quarter-hour of droning
column4: unearthly string tones. Not all of it is engaging
column5: but if you ever wondered what it would really mean for Autechre to take an uninhibited plunge into the weirdo void
column6: now you have your answer.

column1: Elseq feels like an advancement of the duo’s recent live sets
column2: offering a similar ratio of rhythm to noise and order to chaos
column3: but a richer palette of sounds. There aren’t a lot of melodies to be heard
column4: but there are a number of distinctive tones and tricks—percussive thumps that sound like collapsing cardboard boxes
column5: gritty woofer-busting bass tones. At the start of “pendulu hv moda” a reverb effect seems to move rapidly between wet and dry
column6: spacious and tight
column7: creating the dizzying sensation that space is expanding and contracting in time with the music. The best tracks land perfectly in the DMZ between the mechanical and musical. On “foldfree casual
column8: ” shimmering chords at first register as sentimental
column9: but become more repetitive and emotionally vacant as they are pushed into the wings by jittery and alien rhythms.

column1: As a live act
column2: Autechre is pretty much without parallel. In concert
column3: the duo’s music feels un-gridded and spontaneous in a way that few computer or drum machine-backed performers can manage. In its best stretches
column4: Elseq seems like a document of this aspect of Booth and Brown’s process – the part that’s just two dudes taking pleasure in real-time collaborative music making. Which
column5: in a way
column6: might serve to deflate the futuristic vibe a little. All talk of robots and post-humanity aside
column7:
it’s hard to think of anything quite as earthly as a jam session.

4|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23318/homepage_large.917cb1a0.jpg|elseq 5|168.0|Autechre|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2016-05-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:19.293973|"

Arriving in a month thick with surprise album releases from A-listers like Beyonce
column2: Drake
column3: James Blake
column4: and Radiohead
column5: Autechre’s Elseq might not surpass its peers in terms of buzz or anticipation. But it has definitely got them beat in sheer volume. The five-part series—which was posted to the UK-based electronic duo’s webstore last week—adds up to more than four hours of music
column6: out-clocking its peers by a significant margin. Taken at once
column7: Elseq 1-5 is a mammoth hunk of listening
column8: the IDM equivalent of a Netflix series binge. It is twice the length of Autechre’s last—and previously
column9: lengthiest—album

column1: Musically
column2: the collection seems to advance the argument for Autechre as a sort of post-human jam band
column3: with members Rob Brown and Sean Booth improvising at length within an opaque world of custom-designed music software. Free from the limitations of a physical format (there is currently no CD or vinyl release planned for Elseq)
column4: Autechre are free to sprawl and wander. And wander they do. Elseq 1-5 are as heady and frustrating as anything the duo have ever released. In some stretches
column5: the music is glacial and serene (“eastre”). In others
column6: the Brown and Booth’s violent squelches suggest machine-on-machine violence in the spirit of Survival Research Laboratories (“c7b2”). Absorbing the whole thing requires a bit of commitment. Or maybe it just takes a giant bag of weed and a lot of free time. Thankfully
column7: Elseq is also available to purchase in installments.

column1: Active since the late ’80s
column2: Autechre’s early full-lengths—Amber
column3: Tri Repetae—could be more clearly understood in the context of dance music
column4: as the duo relied on similar hardware
column5: like drum machines and analog synthesizers. Even still
column6: their output has always embraced and amplified electronic music’s eerie otherness. “We had heard these Latin Rascals edits with these fast bits with drums that sounded weirdly robotic
column7: taking electro into this other zone
column8: ” Booth told Thump last fall. “Half of the tracks that we do as Autechre are about recreating the actual sensations I used to get from those things—just getting post-human and next level.” As the years have passed
column9: the duo’s music has become ever more idiosyncratic and abstract. The DNA of techno and electro are in there somewhere
column10: but Booth and Brown have largely abandoned traditional melody and harmony in favor of raw sound design.

column1: Elseq 1-5 is not Autechre’s first foray into download-only releases. 2008’s Quarstice was followed by a series of digital EPs that offered expanded and alternate mixes
column2: which were often superior to that album’s edited material. Last year
column3: the duo posted a series of nine recent live recordings of new material for sale online. An important part of Autechre’s identity has been the duo’s willingness to mess with its audience’s perceptions. A track might register as repetitive
column4: yet never actually repeat itself. Another might repeat the same phrase for 20 minutes at a stretch. Other works have been so chaotic that it is nearly impossible to retain them in your memory.

column1: The set’s second installment is the most extreme
column2: with Booth and Brown delving into crunchy
column3: headache-generating digressions in 10-minute chunks that will feel either exhausting or exhilarating. “eastre” kicks off the third grouping with nearly a quarter-hour of droning
column4: unearthly string tones. Not all of it is engaging
column5: but if you ever wondered what it would really mean for Autechre to take an uninhibited plunge into the weirdo void
column6: now you have your answer.

column1: Elseq feels like an advancement of the duo’s recent live sets
column2: offering a similar ratio of rhythm to noise and order to chaos
column3: but a richer palette of sounds. There aren’t a lot of melodies to be heard
column4: but there are a number of distinctive tones and tricks—percussive thumps that sound like collapsing cardboard boxes
column5: gritty woofer-busting bass tones. At the start of “pendulu hv moda” a reverb effect seems to move rapidly between wet and dry
column6: spacious and tight
column7: creating the dizzying sensation that space is expanding and contracting in time with the music. The best tracks land perfectly in the DMZ between the mechanical and musical. On “foldfree casual
column8: ” shimmering chords at first register as sentimental
column9: but become more repetitive and emotionally vacant as they are pushed into the wings by jittery and alien rhythms.

column1: As a live act
column2: Autechre is pretty much without parallel. In concert
column3: the duo’s music feels un-gridded and spontaneous in a way that few computer or drum machine-backed performers can manage. In its best stretches
column4: Elseq seems like a document of this aspect of Booth and Brown’s process – the part that’s just two dudes taking pleasure in real-time collaborative music making. Which
column5: in a way
column6: might serve to deflate the futuristic vibe a little. All talk of robots and post-humanity aside
column7:
it’s hard to think of anything quite as earthly as a jam session.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23159/homepage_large.6a1ae385.jpg|Everything's Beautiful|33664.0|Robert Glasper|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Legacy'
column2: 'Columbia'
column4: biopics are notorious for being underwhelming. Nitpicking can come from multiple directions—with one camp deriding a central lack of tension in the telling of an icon’s familiar story
column5: and another wailing over any dramatic liberty taken with the historical record. Director and actor Don Cheadle’s new film about Miles Davis plunges consciously and energetically into this fraught zone
column6: not least because it dares to call itself Miles Ahead (aka the title of one of Davis’ great big band LPs). That titling move amounts to an open invitation to jazz whiners and/or experts everywhere.

column1: As an actor
column2: Cheadle looks and sounds the part. His styling is immaculate
column3: and his voice channels Davis’ famous rasp. But at a level of sound
column4: the two recordings that spring from Cheadle’s project face an even steeper challenge—simply because any re-appropriation of Davis’ music is a more precarious enterprise than acting out the life story. In this light
column5: reporting that the original sounds created for (or inspired by) Cheadle’s film do not immediately register as embarrassments is a form of high praise.

column1: The bulk of this film’s single-disc “original motion picture soundtrack” is built from brief dialogue snippets from the film (which are fine)
column2: select Davis cuts presented in full (“So What
column3: ” from Kind of Blue
column4: naturally) and a few edits of classic Davis recordings (which should be avoided on general principle). Shaving down clips of Miles is a necessity of cinematic sound-design convention
column5: and isn’t a mark against the film itself. But once you’re listening to a recording
column6: outside the theater
column7: I doubt even the filmmakers behind Miles Ahead would argue that it isn’t more important to seek out a complete
column8: originally issued take. The soundtrack’s most interesting custom songs come toward the end of the album
column9: where the film’s musical supervisor
column10: keyboardist Robert Glasper
column11: has the chance to offer four original pieces inspired by Davis’ protean example. And he makes each opportunity count.

column1: “Junior’s Jam” has a spare funk indebted to Miles’ Jack Johnson sessions (and fortunately the playing of Glasper
column2: saxophonist Marcus Strickland
column3: and trumpeter Keyon Harrold doesn’t sound overly imitative). The chill of “Francessence” sounds equally inspired by In a Silent Way as well as latter-day film score work by the likes of Terence Blanchard. There’s a group rave-up meant to connote an active club feel (“What’s Wrong With That?”)
column4: and it includes some fiery soprano saxophone playing from onetime Davis band member Wayne Shorter. And album-closer “Gone 2015” features joyously triumphant rhyming from the too-often overlooked Pharoahe Monch.

column1: Working on the film seems to have given Glasper more ideas than could be included on the original soundtrack. So
column2: with the permission of the Davis estate
column3: he’s also created another full-length release that frequently uses the trumpeter’s recorded legacy as point of departure. More than a “remix” album
column4: Everything’s Beautiful shows off Glasper’s skills with sampling
column5: and his talent for creating original work. The pinnacle of the set comes on “Maiysha (So Long)
column6: ” when Erykah Badu delivers original lyrics over Glasper’s playing and a sample of a Davis performance found on the album Get Up With It. And the keyboardist’s cover of “Milestones” proves that he doesn’t need access to the trumpeter’s tape-vault in order to create valid interpretations.

column1: Glasper’s supporting cast draws from the range of talents he’s also employed on his reliably enjoyable Black Radio series of jazz-meets-R&B fusion recordings. So in addition to Badu’s star turn
column2: we get Phonte rapping over a 9th Wonder production (during “Violets”)
column3: as well as the presence of vocalists like Bilal—whose phrasing and register-leaps animate the strut of “Ghetto Walkin’” (built from a groove Davis cut in 1969). The melisma and occasional grit of Ledisi’s voice drives “I’m Leaving You
column4: ” a song which also puts the spotlight on the guitar work of latter-day Davis collaborator John Scofield.

column1: A trio of cuts toward the middle of Everything’s Beautiful suffers from feeling less robustly reimagined than the rest of the set—placing a slight drag on momentum. But there’s an easy fix: To experience the full range of the pianist’s Davis-derived thinking
column2: just add Glasper’s contributions from the Miles Ahead soundtrack to Everything’s Beautiful. By being respectful of the artist’s legacy while also making some smart
column3: contemporary production choices
column4: Glasper’s best work proves an an ideal vehicle for paying tribute to an artist who had a firm feel for tradition
column5:
but who never stayed fixed in one place for very long.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23286/homepage_large.b330a450.jpg|Faraway Reach|31080.0|Classixx|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Innovative Leisure']|2016-05-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:20.561499|"

When Classixx released their debut album Hanging Gardens in 2013
column2: it turned out that the Los Angeles duo Tyler Blake and Michael David
column3: previously known for their production
column4: were equally talented as songwriters. Among the album's many highlights were the songs in which the duo brought in outside voices
column5: such as the glorious Nancy Whang-assisted kiss-off ""All You're Waiting For"" and the pre-sunrise melancholy of “Borderline
column6: ” which featured an affecting performance from Kisses vocalist Jesse Kivel. These fleeting glimpses of the pop album Classixx might one day make were tantalized
column7: and on their sophomore effort Faraway Reach
column8: they plant their flag even firmer in straight-ahead pop.

column1: Their songwriting remains a strong point
column2: and Classixx continue to show a knack for choosing kindred-spirit collaborators. This time around
column3: names that would appear in larger fonts on festival posters show up: Michael Angelakos of Passion Pit—whose has worked with dance producers before
column4: appearing on last year's Adventure
column5: the underrated debut from France's Madeon—drops by on “Safe Inside
column6: ” and his wide-eyed sincerity neatly aligns with Classixx's buoyant worldview.“I Feel Numb” is full-on disco
column7: featuring a heart-on-his-sleeve vocal from Holy Ghost! frontman Alex Frankel.

column1: “I am the one who makes you feel OK
column2: ” Frankel assures a concerned significant other as he warns them that he might be slipping into another depressive spell. It's an example of the world-weariness that suffuses the record—Frankel makes this person feel not good
column3: not great
column4: but just OK. And
column5: as any adult will attest
column6: sometimes OK is good enough. An album that recasts the dancefloor as a space to explore—and
column7: crucially
column8: attempt to combat—the malaise of adulthood
column9: Faraway Reach concerns itself with less-than-glamorous topics ranging from depression (the aforementioned “I Feel Numb”)
column10: to mundane and banal activities like fighting with one's partner in line at the grocery store (“In These Fine Times”) and allowing of the pain of the past to inform but not define you (“Just Let Go
column11: ” which absorbs the anthemic qualities of big-tent EDM and features How to Dress Well aka Tom Krell in full-on diva mode to great effect).

column1: Classixx redeems the bleakness of these topics with their natural sense of warmth—their music often feels like a familiar hand on your shoulder urging you to keep going. In hindsight
column2: the sun-bleached vibes of Hanging Gardens played a role in the rise of tropical house
column3: and the same laid-back tempos and vague hints of sea breeze  are found on Faraway Reach. But there's an inclusivity to Classixx
column4: a sense of arms-outstretched welcoming that makes it impossible for anyone to turn their nose up at their music.

column1: “I can do whatever I want
column2: ” warbles T-Pain on standout “Whatever I Want.” This confidence applies equally to his collaborators—in a nod to Michael David's birthplace of South Africa
column3: Classixx effortlessly bring in Nonku
column4: daughter of famed South African artist Ray Phiri
column5: on “Ndivile.” And the album's wordless moments
column6: of which there are only three
column7: including tranquil opener ""Grecian Summer"" and the title track
column8: demonstrate that Classixx haven't lost the ability to craft propulsive dance grooves
column9: even if they're treated more as scene-setters and transitional tools. At various points
column10: Faraway Reach is: a shrug; a call-to-arms; a balm. At its best
column11:
it's all these things at once.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23272/homepage_large.a410eb8e.jpg|K.M.T.|33737.0|Africans With Mainframes|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Soul Jazz']|2016-05-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:21.270199|"

Recently DJ and producer Jamal Moss appeared on a panel on Afrofuturism at Moogfest alongside Reggie Watts
column2: Janelle Monáe
column3: and hip-hop production duo Christian Rich. It was good company for him to be in
column4: but even in that eclectic crowd he is an outlier. Whether as the Sun God
column5: I.B.M.
column6: IAMTHATIAM
column7: or most often as Hieroglyphic Being
column8: Moss' abundant discography is filled with so many u-turns that it begins to resemble a Spirograph. For every CD-R of synth squalls there is another full of manic drum machine polyrhythms. And then there was We Are Not the First
column9: last year's meeting with an ensemble of free jazz’s finest
column10: suggesting an imaginary space where the AACM gigged at Ron Hardy's Music Box.

column1: Working with fellow producer Noleian Reusse as Africans With Mainframes
column2: now Moss swings from Windy City jazz to Chicago acid at its most caustic. While the duo have released a slew of 12”s dating back to 2001
column3: K.M.T. is their first full-length. Kemetic Modulating Textures is eight tracks of Moss and Reusse at their most unrelenting and there’s a coarseness to every texture that at times might make you mistakenly think it was just slapped together. Yet the frequent references to Egyptology (Googling each track title reveals a profound knowledge of prehistoric culture) suggest a greater thought at work
column4: and if you manage to survive the bruising BPMs of the album's first half
column5: it becomes mesmerizing.

column1: Opener “Anachronistic” sets the table for what lies ahead: everything in the red
column2: a snare fill stumbling and slipping across the grid
column3: the 808’s edges increasingly fuzzy with distortion. And then just when it verges on pure noise
column4: that telltale acid squiggle worms through and the snare coheres into a visceral thrill. What might scan as sloppy and unfocused suddenly snaps into sharp relief and it’s effective throughout K.M.T.
column5: album highlight “Negroid Spinx” being a fine example. It too features overdriven snares that concuss to the point of delirium and then at the 3:30 mark
column6: Moss and Reusse drop out the beat and give us a brief respite
column7: a glimpse of an oasis in the midst of a haboob.

column1: On the back half of the album
column2: AWM relent and allow in more space. The epic “Qustal Artifacts” builds carefully
column3: the track forgoing heavy beats for a heady array of arpeggios
column4: the results not unlike Cluster
column5: had they been Afrocentric rather than Germanic. “Naqada” and the title track sound like some tribal Folkways field recording rendered on machine rather than anything currently extant in electronic music.

column1: Last year
column2: Moss explained his first encounter with Sun Ra’s music as a shock to the system: “His music wasn’t about making sense: it was just about receiving these transmissions
column3: this knowledge.” It’s a lesson that Moss carries forward with K.M.T.
column4: suggesting that while some of his tracks might scan as scrambled transmissions
column5:
continued exposure reveals a profound signal beneath the noise. 

"|21934.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21934-kmt/|7.5|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22998/homepage_large.8c1e33f7.jpg|Goodness|31939.0|The Hotelier|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tiny Engines']|2016-05-27 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:21.494138|"

Christian Holden is fighting like hell to stand in the sun. The Hotelier singer is coming off a dramatized retelling of a tragedy-ridden early adulthood
column2: in the form of the fourth-wave emo classic <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18963-the-hotelier-home-like-noplace-is-there/""><i>Home
column3: Like NoPlace Is There
column4: and now it’s time to really start rebuilding. That’s a lot to expect of a record
column5: but it’s not like the Hotelier can’t handle the pressure. The Massachusetts trio are angling for that rare genre-rock to general-rock crossover space
column6: and Goodness is their most concerted bid yet. Home
column7: Like NoPlace Is There—the Hotelier’s second album
column8: released in 2014—suggested their appeal to listeners outside of emo revival’s grasp (alongside the likes of the World Is a Beautiful Place & I Am Not Afraid to Die and Modern Baseball)
column9: and it’s hype that’s only reaffirmed by Goodness. At this point
column10: however
column11: it might not even be accurate to call them emo
column12: so let’s just have it out now: The Hotelier is a great rock band
column13: however you classify them.

column1: This is not to say Goodness doesn't have its share of histrionics
column2: though to be fair they are more like affirmations. The album flirts with transcendentalism
column3: the 19th-century philosophical movement favored by Emerson and Thoreau
column4: which recognized the inherent goodness of humanity and the natural world while also placing a high value on fierce individuality. And so Goodness finds itself out in the fields of New England
column5: stripping back to the essentials—trying to love and trust again
column6: and finally moving the fuck on. Anyone who has attempted these things understands that they can rank among the most difficult emotional tasks
column7: depending on how bad other humans have messed you up. <i>Home
column8: Like NoPlace Is There took often-excruciating stock of that damage: It opened with a suicide
column9: lingered uncomfortably on a funeral scene
column10: and reckoned with the psychological ravages of a lifetime of abuse. At times Goodness pushes towards positivity with this same level of intensity
column11: but it’s fraught with its own kind of tension: You can really hear the trying.

column1: Sometimes it’s grating
column2: how hard Goodness tries to find the light. The album is broken up with campfire-y interludes of peaceful chants atop acoustic guitar
column3: which were “sung under a total lunar eclipse in Plymouth
column4: Vermont” according to official credits. We are also treated to a recitation of the lullaby “I See the Moon
column5: ” Holden’s spoken-word introduction to the album
column6: and “a sound collage recorded of morning birds in Charlton
column7: Massachusetts.”

column1: Other times
column2: it’s the trying that draws you in. The percussion is so relentless
column3: the guitars so urgent
column4: the voice so direct
column5: that songs like “Goodness Pt. 2” and “Piano Player” feel like something that could get you out of bed in the morning. For much of the latter
column6: Holden can be heard—in either the foreground or in the background amid utter sonic chaos—screaming what may be the most realistic mantra ever chanted: the word “sustain.” That said
column7: this same sort of trick is not as profound the second time Holden pulls it
column8: spending a fair chunk of “Sun” simply repeating its title. At least that underwhelming passage results in Holden’s most indelible punk vocal on the entire album
column9: and it's a throaty blow that stands in stark contrast to the calmer
column10: Stipe-like tone Holden employs here more than ever.

column1: For as riotous as it can sound
column2: Goodness is remarkably precise in how it plays with dynamics and layers. This manifests in myriad ways: the music cutting out to emphasize Holden’s poetic pleas to feel alive
column3: the disregard for traditional song structures
column4: the way the two guitars have a near-constant interplay that adds dimensions (and hooks)
column5: and the slow and tense introduction of more instruments over the course of a song
column6: like on the mortality-obsessed standout “Opening Mail for My Grandmother.”

column1: Simply put
column2: the playing is more ambitious and varied on Goodness than on Home
column3: Like NoPlace Is There
column4: an album where the narrative drama manifests into some of the rawest anthems of unhinged youth and crippling self-loathing recorded this decade. But Goodness’ judicious sense editing clips the band’s wings just a little
column5: keeping the music from feeling as boundless as Holden’s emotions. Still
column6: it’s admirable
column7: all this searching for the good and appreciating the simple. At the end of Home highlight “The Scope of All This Rebuilding
column8: ” the singer had found himself defeated
column9: admitting
column10: “I can’t find my way around this.” Goodness is proof that somehow
column11:
Christian Holden did.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23279/homepage_large.f1d226ed.jpg|It Happened in Flatbush|31049.0|The Underachievers|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2016-05-27 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:22.200249|"

On the first verse of It Happened in Flatbush
column2: the latest mixtape from Brooklyn-based rap group the Underachievers
column3: Issa Gold comes for blood. “Niggas really just average
column4: can’t sell a fucking thing/Niggas’ numbers is trash
column5: Troy Ave would never win” he seethes
column6: referring to an ongoing beef between Underachievers and their Pro Era associates with Troy Ave. Over cascading keys and a rattling beat that fits perfectly for a rap group co-signed by Brainfeeder
column7: Gold and AK
column8: the group's dual MCs
column9: trade verses with a light-hearted yet fierce temerity
column10: shouting out the deceased Capital Steeze of Pro Era (whom Troy Ave recently dissed) and declaring their Beast Coast collective will finish Troy off permanently.

column1: It's an early peak. Unfortunately
column2: it's also the most potent moment on the entire interminable run of It Happened in Flatbush
column3: the Underachievers' first release since their 2015 album Evermore: the Art of Duality. Originally turning heads in 2013
column4: the group seemed novel in a post-TDE/A$AP scene: A New York duo who weren't cheesy enough to insist on taking NY hip-hop back to some idealized ‘90s golden age
column5: or desperate enough to hop the coattails of rap's latest trend. Though initially tethered to their vague mystical allusions (calling to mind ‘90s groups like Leaders of the New School) and a heady “conscious” vibe
column6: they quickly settled into a comfortable role that didn't play up their Brainfeeder connections
column7: or lyrically deviate all that differently from A$AP's “party and bullshit” ethos and Pro Era's nostalgia trips.

column1: This continues on It Happened in Flatbush
column2: which is a flat album in every way
column3: no pun intended. None of the beats really knock
column4: instead dutifully bopping along as the two MCs stick to forgettable
column5: uninspired tropes about weed
column6: women
column7: and New York chest-thumping. For all the multi-syllabic bars about how much they're winning
column8: It Happened in Flatbush can be dismissed with one word: joyless. There’s no spirit in any of these songs
column9: just repetitive verses and boasts poorly anchored by weightless
column10: mealy-mouthed hooks. One example is the penultimate track “John Lennon
column11: ” which initially matches the intensity offered by opening track “Never Win
column12: ” but ends up lumbering along instead of taking off
column13: offering a cumbersome bridge and no thematic resolution.

column1: Intentionally or not
column2: too much of the tape sounds unimaginatively inspired by TDE. Issa Gold frequently lapses to a hard syllable
column3: ratatat flow that's pure Schoolboy Q
column4: while AK's gruff bark brings Jay Rock to mind
column5: but you wish either could match Ab-Soul's pathos. There are nearly no memorable lines (although “I’m like LeBron/I’m like Mussolini
column6: Genghis Khan/a leader of the town” got stuck in my mind for all the wrong reasons) or impressionable beats. Even on “Gangland
column7: ” where Issa Gold raps
column8: “I blow weed til I collapse
column9: every night I say I quit/but every morning I relapse
column10: ” the line doesn’t land because there’s no emotional context to place it into
column11: no weighty dynamic that redeems all the flat “smokin’ Cali shit” talk with something that grapples with morality a little more meaningfully outside this one passive moment.

column1: Contrast all this with the Technicolor fun of a group like the Bay Area’s Heartbreak Gang
column2: New York's genuinely weird Doppelgangaz
column3: or Tacoma's obscure but rewarding ILLFIGHTYOU
column4: whose debut 2013 mixtape picked up similar buzz. It Happened in Flatbush lacks a compelling reason to listen
column5: especially if their vaguely intriguing mystical conscious brand is what got you into them in the first place. It's a concentrated dose of rappity-rap New York stuff—fine if your patience for it runs high
column6: but if not
column7:
likely to make you tune out.

Apart from a few stray months in the ‘60s
column2: it's hard to imagine any period in which Allen Ginsberg's First Blues might have found commercial success
column3: the present one included. But in a somewhat more liberated world
column4: Omnivore's Last Word on First Blues box set makes more sense now than any time since the double LP's 1983 release on John Hammond's eponymous indie label. A radical in Ronald Reagan's ‘80s as much in Dwight Eisenhower's ‘50s
column5: Allen Ginsberg's open
column6: gleeful
column7: and articulate queerness bursts through here as clear as ever
column8: a poet dancing with all the legal freedoms earned when a California State Superior Judge declared that Ginsberg's groundbreaking 1956 poem “Howl” was of “redeeming social importance
column9: ” and therefore not obscene—freedoms Ginsberg had declared himself to possess long before. While the poet's wobbling voice remains a hard sell in the 21st century (ditto
column10: to some listeners
column11: his sexploits)
column12: producer Pat Thomas' loving Last Word on First Blues reissue reveals Ginsberg as a missing link in the East Village's musical pathways
column13:
a secret alt-folk hero hidden in relatively plain view.

Recorded over three sessions in 1971
column15: and 1981
column16: the new First Blues comes with a third disc of supplementary material
column17: including appearances by Bob Dylan on bass and jazz hero Don Cherry on kazoo. It opens with the Dylan-abetted sing-alongs “Going to San Diego” and “Vomit Express
column18: ” both sounding as if Ginsberg had visited Big Pink for a session in the Basement. Amid the surreal-hootenanny atmosphere
column19: in which Dylan jams alongside Arthur Russell
column20: Ginsberg's voice finds a comfort zone. But
column21: just as much as Dylan
column22: First Blues carries forward the sloppy and joyous folk-rock of Ginsberg's East Village neighbors in the Holy Modal Rounders and the over-the-top poetry of his friends in The Fugs
column23: whose co-founder Ed Sanders appears in Last Word session photos from 1971. At the heart of the later recordings
column27: who fixes the poet's anarchic spirit and wandering melodic tendencies amid a solid folk-rock sparkle—and who would go on to join the The Fugs when that band reunited in 1984.

column1: Though released as one album
column2: First Blues also represents three separate slices of Ginsberg's musical career: sex-positive folk romps like “Jimmy Berman (Gay Lib Rag)
column3: ” word-crammed investigative poetry anthems like “CIA Dope Calypso
column4: ” and less classifiable specimens of wise cosmic folk. The lines are blurry
column5: but it is the latter category that is perhaps the most refreshing. Though Ginsberg isn't a singer by most traditional measures
column6: he is a surprising and capable songwriter
column7: finding charming melodies he can only get across in the broadest way
column8: as on “Vomit Express” (from 1971)
column9: aided by big gang vocals on the chorus
column10:
and the Rounders-like “Old Pond” (from ten years later).

For all his legendary lack of inhibition
column11: Ginsberg's singing is sometimes a bit (ahem) stiff
column12: more a crooning poet than a singer-songwriter. The 1976 band is the most supportive
column13: featuring David Mansfield on elegant pedal steel and Arthur Russell on cello
column14: achieving an easy
column15: swaying grace on “Gospel Novel Truths” and a cool existential swing on “Broken Bone Blues.” These songs and others seem primed for covering by a new generation of free weirdos
column16: including the rambunctious “Guru Blues” (“I can't find anyone to fuck me in the ass”)
column17: the solemn “Father Death Blues.” It is on the demos disc
column18: too
column19: that the bed bugs and speed freaks of “NY Blues” provide a through-line to the hyper-local topicality of contemporary East Side songwriter Jeffrey Lewis
column20:
fitting in comfortably next to “Scowling Crackhead Ian” and other characters of Lewis' recent Manhattan.

Perhaps a more natural and capable freak-folker is Ginsberg's hubby
column21: the poet Peter Orlovsky
column22: who punctuates his ode “You Are My Dildo” with a game jug-band falsetto
column23: and (on the bonus disc) delivers his fellatio-lovin’ “Penny's Farm” rewrite “Feeding Them Raspberries To Grow” in a convincingly olde-tyme warble. At their best
column24: the players in the three different session bands featured here make a spot for Ginsberg and his voice to become one with the music
column25: as on the 1976 outtake “Slack Key Guitar
column26:
” an anti-colonial nu-exotica lullaby that recalls a more chilled-out Van Dyke Parks.

For its numerous charms
column27: Ginsberg's sexual openness continues to make First Blues an eyebrow-raising experience three-and-a-half decades after its recording. Nor is it without its complications. “Everybody's just a little bit homosexual whether they like it or not
column28: ” Ginsberg sings on the first line of the provocative and Fug-ly “Everybody Sing
column29: ” but “everybody” in the song's cosmology doesn't seem to include females. (Orlovsky is a bit more equal-opportunity.) As in his visionary poetry
column30: all of Allen Ginsberg is on display during the the two-and-a-half hours of recordings
column32: but always (and still) vital. As responsible for pop music's turn to poetry as anyone
column33:
Allen Ginsberg had more than a few songs of his own.

The struggle to pronounce some of the more difficult Amharic consonants and constructions—difficult for English speakers—will often meet with an encouraging exclamation of “gobez”! Translations for the word range from smart to brave to courageous to talented to witty. Debo Band’s saxophonist
column2: leader and ethnomusicologist Danny Mekonnen translates the phrase “Ere gobez” as a “call of the lionhearted—it's a term used to inspire.” It’s certainly an apt label and message for the Ethiopian 11-piece band’s second album
column3: a record the reaches and then surpasses the heights of their excellent 2012 self-titled debut.

column1: Because not only do the varying definitions of gobez fit the range of music on this record
column2: but the music of Debo Band is that of a big
column3: brave roar
column4: song after song. This is a powerful
column5: and
column6: perhaps
column7: inspirational record: it certainly inspires dancing
column8: filling spaces and capturing a dynamic live sensibility. It’s no surprise that this is a band that takes up a great deal of room. With so many members
column9: some in Boston
column10: some as far away as Addis Ababa (violinist Kaethe Hostetter established a String Center in the Ethiopian capital)
column11: Debo is true to its name
column12: which means “communal labor.” The community of Debo Band includes a bold
column13: shimmery horn section
column14: complete with sousaphone
column15: but also slick guitar
column16: a tight rhythm section
column17: orchestral strings
column18: an accordion and
column19: on occasion
column20: a masinquo—a one-stringed Ethiopian fiddle. There’s a quaver in lead vocalist Bruck Tesfaye’s voice that is in keeping with Amharic-language singing style
column21: but it is a powerfully pure energy that sits on top of each song
column22: rising  along with all the other instruments.

column1: If you know anything about Ethiopian music and musical traditions
column2: it’s most likely that you have a good relationship with the over two-dozen edition strong Éthiopiques series
column3: lovingly curated by France’s Francis Falceto. The series focuses on the 1960s and ‘70s
column4: and Debo Band certainly draws from this era
column5: but they also pull from more recent times as well as from funk
column6: rock and pop. Debo’s material is reinterpreted and reconsidered
column7: pushed through a creative process that remains true to source as well as their own specific sound (7 of the 11 tracks on the album draw from previously existing works
column8: which are well cited in the liner notes).

column1: There is an adaptation of Somali Dur-Dur band song “Rafaad iyo Raaxo” (originally performed in the mid-'80s) on “Kehulum Abliche” and Debo Band dips into Okinawa
column2: Japan in “Hiyamikachi Bushi” (a song composed almost 60 years ago). Ere Gobez provides numerous examples how Debo Band seems to taking part in conversations that are happening in multiple spaces and places at different times. Heck
column3: “Yalanchi” sounds almost like a smooth groove that might
column4: just might
column5: be in good company with some Yacht Rock luminaries.

column1: For those unfamiliar
column2: it’s valuable to note that the specific rhythms of songs such as “Oromo” and “Ele” draw upon the musical cultures of the Oromo and Gurage. The infectious spring of these two tracks is undeniable. It’s near impossible not to dance to
column3: even if you aren’t familiar with the exact dance styles necessary
column4: though it’s certainly fun to take a little YouTube trip to find out the level of skill and control involved in Oromo as well as Gurage dancing. By doing so
column5: one can understand just how important the big sound and speed of the songs function for dancing. And it’s hard to imagine any of the band members standing still during the recording of this record. Or anyone who will listen to Ere Gobez or see Debo Band live either. Each track seems to bounce around the room
column6:
pulling the listener along with it.

In a literal sense
column2: Apologies to the Queen Mary has become 2005’s most essential record; shorthand for a set of qualities that defined a year considered to be indie rock’s artistic and cultural zenith. If you’ve been nostalgic for those times—and it seems like plenty are—it’s easier than ever to empathize with an already wearied Dan Boeckner when he slurs his first words on Wolf Parade’s debut LP: “I’m not in love with the modern world.” And yet
column3: the hyperspeed production
column4: distribution
column5: consumption and coverage of music allows Wolf Parade to make a comprehensive “triumphant comeback” despite only taking six years off. Hell
column6: even the release strategy of EP 4 is similar to the one used by the stars: the short-lead
column7: quick drop of highly-anticipated material.

column1: EP 4 is no “appointment listening""
column2: though. Its 12 minutes of new material almost immediately got overshadowed by Chance the Rapper
column3: Brand New
column4: new Ariana Grande singles and whatever Kanye got himself into last week. This likely worked in favor of Wolf Parade
column5: since EP 4 feels ancillary to their return rather than the focus. This isn’t the sound of Wolf Parade asserting themselves. It’s Wolf Parade reintroducing themselves to each other after Spencer Krug and Dan Boeckner built massive catalogs that now makes their original band a supergroup in reverse.

column1: Wolf Parade had originally promised something with a “heavy glam vibe
column2: ” suggested Krug was taking the spiritual lead here—in all aspects
column3: vocally
column4: sartorially
column5: lyrically
column6: he’s the theatre kid in Wolf Parade and
column7: moreover
column8: his songs are the ones that work best with crowd participation. Turns out those reference points were simply meant to signify a leaner
column9: more trebly and immediate version of Wolf Parade
column10: scaling back on the thick
column11: proggy arrangements that defined the lesser-loved At Mount Zoomer and Expo 86.

column1: It’s much easier for Krug to find his “Wolf Parade mode”: he simply has to be more reined in than Sunset Rubdown
column2: Moonface or Swan Lake
column3: which means writing songs that are about three minutes instead of six—“Mr. Startup” and “C’est La Vie Way” are satisfying
column4: jittery New Wave that could’ve just as easily been attributed to Boeckner. The streamlined
column5: aerodynamic sound of EP 4 has much more in common with Boeckner' work in Operators
column6: Handsome Furs
column7: and Divine Fits.

column1: Enjoyable as it is
column2: EP 4 does seem like smart risk management
column3: a test run that confirms that whatever the group comes up with won’t be a Pixies-style disaster.  As such
column4: the rewards are modest: “Floating World” pleasantly hovers
column5: never aspiring to the moon launch of “Yulia.” The frenzied midsection of “C’est La Vie Way” recalls “Fancy Claps”
column6: but only briefly before pulling back. The most instantly lovable parts are the “2005!” sonic easter eggs: the second verse of “Mr. Startup” works the hi-hat on the 2 and 4
column7: which defined the sound of mid-2k indie rock almost as much as the word “angular.”

column1: But EP 4 is missing the friction between Krug and Boeckner that allowed Apologies to the Queen Mary to instantly combust within Isaac Brock’s compressed production: the cadences
column2: mannerisms and subject matter between the two frontmen are almost indistinguishable here. More likely
column3: it’s the general sense of yearning that has yet to be rediscovered
column4: the ambition to transcend something that defined not only Apologies to the Queen Mary but many of its celebrated peers in the Class of 2005. Maybe that will come in time: even if Wolf Parade aren’t in love with the modern world
column5:
they’re learning to live in it.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23295/homepage_large.1050fb90.jpg|Should I Remain Here at Sea?|2148.0|Islands|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Manqué']|2016-05-26 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:24.476011|"

Nick Thorburn’s music has been downloaded more than 80 million times in the past two years
column2: but a majority of those people will likely always associate his work with a girl who can’t pronounce the phrase “MailChimp.” In a perfect world
column3: the two albums his band Islands have simultaneously released would change that.

column1: Taste and Should I Remain Here at Sea?  are Islands’ first releases since 2013. In the intervening years
column2: Thorburn busied himself by composing for the podcast
column3: Serial
column4: including the tinny minor-chord piano theme that starts each episode. That his band has released these somewhat-different albums on the same day should come as no surprise to those familiar with Thorburn’s output. After coming to prominence as a leading force in the Unicorns
column5: a band that arguably helped lift indie rock out of a self-serious rut in 2003
column6: he formed Islands
column7: as well as several other projects that blur the line between serious and silly
column8: including Mister Heavenly
column9: Th’ Corn Gangg
column10: Reefer
column11: and Human Highway. To say nothing of his solo work that he releases as Nick Diamonds. Basically
column12: he is a compulsive music maker
column13: and his foray into soundtracking the most popular podcast ever made him antsy to get back to Islands.

column1: It also seems to have focused him. Taste is a largely electronic affair
column2: while Should I Remain Here at Sea?  is more guitar-based. But it’s not their instrumentation that gives these albums their distinct personalities. The recording notes show that the band switched between working on Taste and Should I Remain... for bursts
column3: completing both within a few months of each other. The resulting two albums seem to offer two ways of dealing with personal devastation: for the first few days you try to make sense of it all while talking to those who are close to you. The wounds are still fresh and you can only speak of it with an air of gravitas. A few days later and you’re able to gain some perspective on the event and perhaps even make light of it. Taste is the bitter sharp-witted album immediately dealing with the fallout. Should I Remain… is lighter
column4: looser and more concise
column5: in the same way that you refine your story once you’ve tried telling it a few times.

column1: There’s a heavy theme of a fracturing relationship on both albums
column2: as well as unlikely recurrences of fierce gripes about American cops and benign complaints about California weather. These releases are also united in their robust choruses
column3: which could get stadiums to sing along if Thorburn dumbed it down and wrote more formulaically. But that’s not in his nature: He’s not aggressively courting those millions of Serial listeners. Thorburn’s greatest skill is creating subliminal hooks that will stay with you even if you didn’t notice them at first. A lyrical line will swim around in your head until it offers an unexpected truth
column4: like the advice he offers about dealing with personal tragedies soberly: “Turn to face it
column5: resist the narcotic embrace
column6: ” he sings in Taste’s lead single
column7: “Charm Offensive.” It’s the type of line that will come floating to the front of consciousness when you’re thinking about throwing up your hands and giving into your worst impulses.

column1: While Islands have gotten progressively more serious with each release
column2: the band do still know how to keep proceedings from getting too staid. A tap dance solo highlights “Stop Me Now” on Should I Remain…
column3: the whistle line from “The Good
column4: The Bad and The Ugly” finds its way into “The Joke
column5: ” and one of the most exquisite songs in the collection is given the irreverent title of “Outspoken Dirtbiker.” As far as absurd titles go
column6: it’s no “Don’t Call Me Whitney
column7: Bobby
column8: ” but it does showcase Thorburn’s ability to keep his sense of humor when dealing with weighty issues.

column1: The band is in top form here. On both albums
column2: Thorburn shares producer credit with bassist Evan Gordon
column3: who is also responsible for the programming. The uneasy beats on Taste are part of what give that album its kick. Guitarist Geordie Gordon and drummer Adam Halferty also make both albums richer by providing dense textures and strong background vocals. Should I Remain Here at Sea? has the feel of friends blowing off steam the only way they know how
column4: after working so hard on something outside of their comfort zone. The process of the band working through Taste together has united them in this shared experience
column5: and they rock out accordingly on “Back Into It
column6: ” the track that opens Should I Remain…

column1: This relationship between records makes Islands’ induction to the Two-Separate-Releases-at-the-Same-Time Club a different proposition than more famous double offerings from Guns N’ Roses
column2: Bruce Springsteen
column3: Paul Westerberg
column4: and Bright Eyes. Of course
column5: when all of those acts did it
column6: we weren’t living in the streaming society we are now
column7: and I’d be writing this review to tell you which one of these is more worth your money. For the most part
column8: it’s now just a matter of which one is worth your time
column9: and they both are. These albums may be decidedly separate
column10:
but they’re only complete when experienced together.

"|21955.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21955-tasteshould-i-remain-here-at-sea/|7.4|Pat Healy

When the African vinyl-digging trend peaked five or six years ago
column2: there was a rush
column3: mostly among American and European collectors

column1: Much of Vol. 2 expresses a desire for freedom and a resistance to the social and political dis-ease of post-war Nigeria. On “Life in Cannan
column2: ” Ceejebs lament the state of what could have been their promised land. Over nimble jazz keys and thick bass
column3: lead vocalist Eyo “Crosbee” Hogan gathers his listeners around him
column4: intoning
column5: “Come around
column6: people of this world/let’s get together and pray/Evil things are happening every day/Many rich are getting poor/The poor ones are dying away.” Echoing that sense of despair is The Identicals’ nearly-apocalyptic “Who Made the World
column7: ” on which they demand answers to questions they know they’ll never get
column8: howling
column9: “Who made the world? Who made the land? Who made the moon?” Even the love songs here ride on a sort of desperation bordering on futility: on opening number “Come Back
column10: ” band leader Theodore Nemy’s voice cracks time and time again as he begs for his “baby” to “come back.” An organ drones beneath him
column11: sympathetic (figuratively and musically) to Nemy’s grievances.

column1: Perhaps most clearly exemplifying the intersection of Afrorock and the politics of the time on Vol. 2 is the band Action 13
column2: who appear on Vol. 1 as their later iteration
column3: Aktion. On Vol. 2
column4: their song “Set Me Free” could easily be interpreted as a protest against the band’s prison-like relationship to their then-patrons
column5: the Nigerian military’s 13th Brigade. Many brigades of the time used bands to entertain their soldiers
column6: boost morale
column7: and reassure citizens
column8: via music
column9: that all was well. Initially
column10: their patronage was helpful in providing a number of Eastern musicians with a living. But Action 13
column11: like many other bands with brigade numbers affixed to their names
column12: eventually grew frustrated
column13: and many tried to break free to make a name for themselves independent of the military. These outside pressures
column14: as well as labels’ jostling to sign artists with varying degrees of success
column15: often augmented bands’ internal instabilities as well. There was a ton of back-and-forth between bands. For instance
column16: on Vol. 2
column17: we see Tony Grey
column18: (former?) keyboardist of the Magnificent Zenians (Vol. 1) leading his own band
column19: The Black 7; certain members of Afrorock pioneer Joni Haastrup’s Monomono appear here backing one Shadow Abraham; juju icon King Sunny Ade makes a surprise appearance producing The Believers’ “Life Will Move.” Trying to make sense of the bands’ relationships to each other
column20: to regional trends
column21: to labels
column22: and to military involvement is like trying to make sense of a messy maze of crossed paths

column1: But in that sense
column2: Wake Up You!: The Rise and Fall of Nigerian Rock
column3: 1972-1977 does a thorough job of conveying the angst and mutability of Nigeria’s protean post-war period. This was music that helped people
column4: young people especially
column5: to sort through their own identities in the wake of war
column6: even if it was to define what they weren't. On Vol. 1
column7: in the chorus of their track “Scram Out
column8: ” from their 1977 album Be Nice To The People
column9: young schoolboy rockers Question Mark sing
column10: ""I want to feel free
column11: I want to feel happy!"" Which at the end of the day
column12: through all its ups and downs
column13:
was what the movement was about.
