column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23274/homepage_large.b8d1b9e4.jpg|Earrings Off!|32361.0|Adult Jazz|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tri Angle']|2016-05-26 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:25.874570|"

 The British experimental rock group Adult Jazz has no problem cramming their music with ideas and lofty goals. In interviews describing their 2014 debut Gist Is
column2: they name dropped Hermann Hesse
column3: criticized religious institutions
column4: and said that the album tackled everything from morality to empathy and the efficacy of communication itself. NPR even followed suit when reviewing the record
column5: saying it was concerned with “the search for meaning in life.” Two years later they’ve released their sophomore follow-up
column6: Earrings Off! a record that equally embraces the same theory-laden attitude. Earrings Off! is meant to analyze the complexities of gender and the body’s changing place in society. In descriptions of the album
column7: the band has stressed the record’s interest in “the possibility of authenticity” in a society that rewards normative behavior.

column1: It’s all very interesting to read about what an album is supposed to do
column2: and there is precedent for the political thrust of a piece of music to affect the conversation it’s entering
column3: but these intentions can so often backfire. (PJ Harvey’s The Hope Six Demolition Project being a case study for this fine line). The cleverness and unique playfulness of Adult Jazz's debut Gist Is helped steer it away from the cliff of self-indulgence and pretension. Earrings Off! edges much closer to that drop-off than its predecessor
column4: burdened by often-silly lyrics and a sound that is a bit more derivative than their last record would suggest.

column1: What still remains uniquely rewarding about Adult Jazz’s music is the construction of their sound. They use a trombone
column2: cello
column3: processed vocals
column4: and a menagerie of sample to tread the line between acidic minimalism and bubbly exuberance in confoundingly expert ways. Of this album’s seven songs
column5: three of them (“(Cry for Time Off
column6: )” “(Cry for Coherence)
column7: ” and “(Cry for Home)”) are short sonic sketches
column8: serving as the most interesting moments in the otherwise slow pace of Earrings Off!’s 24 minutes. These three songs mostly focus on single sounds—a helium-cracked vocal cry
column9: dissonant string loops
column10: and the bated breath of a brass instrument. These pared-down constructions generate more and more detail on repeated listens. The album’s four other songs attempt to mimic this but come off as overwrought and heavy handed at best.

column1: The difficult six minutes of “Pumped From Above” exploits corrosive horn sounds and maddeningly uneven drumming for all their worth. It could almost sound like a facsimile of a Peter Brötzman composition
column2: but the arrangement of the chaotic noises can be curiously predictable. The singing is usually so swaddled by the noises that Harry Burgess’ words are obscured
column3: but when you look at what he’s saying on paper it can make the experience even more cringe-inducing. Take this passage: “God cannot be softening/He beats strong with iron wings/Kneeling sporty chest pumping/Before the Alpha-lord.” You can open up any book of poems by Hart Crane or Dylan Thomas and find a similar impenetrability. But these words and images have the feeling of being selected at random; their difficulty doesn't have a sense of clarity or deeper meaning and incomprehensibility isn't the same as seriousness.

column1: This is a running thread through the album that detracts from where Earrings Off! improves upon their debut. They’ve learned how to create hooks without sacrificing from their outre sounds. This is best accomplished in the title track (which pleasantly confirms any of the Dirty Projectors comparisons) and “Eggshell.” But even the pleasure of craft can melt away when you figure out amidst the textures these words are ringing out: “And if he's 1940's/He whistles through a meadow.” It makes it impossible for the album to actually engage with the conversation it proposes
column2: and often made me wish I could ignore the words and allow the singing to be another instrument. Earrings Off! is filled with these sorts of growing pains
column3:
ones that hopefully point to brighter pastures sometime soon for this promising band.  

"|21936.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21936-earrings-off/|6.0|Kevin Lozano

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23230/homepage_large.10eb5d56.jpg|Dangerous Woman|31708.0|Ariana Grande|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Republic']|2016-05-25 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:26.018294|"

“You need a bad girl to blow your mind
column2: ” Ariana Grande taunted us in 2014 on “Bang Bang
column3: ” her smash-hit collaboration with Jessie J and Nicki Minaj. In that crowd
column4: Grande didn't really seem like the bad girl; maybe she knew one she could fix you up with? As she told Complex the year before
column5: “I don’t see myself as sexy and I’m not comfortable being sexy and dressing sexy. I don’t see myself ever becoming a sex symbol.” But she seems to have taken the “Bang Bang” lyric as a mood-board inspiration for her third album <i>Dangerous Woman
column6: which finds the 22-year-old trading in the mini-skirts
column7: go-go boots
column8: and cat ears for a Sasha Fierce-like alter ego. As a result
column9: Grande spends most of Dangerous Woman coyly flirting with desire
column10: “bad decisions
column11: ” and independence. “Something about you makes me feel like a dangerous woman
column12: ” she sings on the chorus to the slow-burning title track
column13: which is a few qualifications away from actual danger. There's something about the whole album that feels a bit like Sandy in her skintight leather outfit at the end of Grease
column14: only in Ari’s case
column15: it’s a latex bunny mask.

column1: At this point
column2: there’s no question that Grande is a powerhouse vocalist
column3: having earned her comparisons to Celine Dion
column4: Mariah Carey
column5: and Christina Aguilera circa Back to Basics. (Among her spot-on impersonations of those singers
column6: Grande does an absolutely insane Aguilera impression
column7: solidifying her spot as the diva’s millennial incarnation.) Grande’s four-octave range
column8: impeccable control
column9: and penchant for belting assures that no matter the lyrics or production
column10: her music will always be strong in that regard. And as in her previous album My Everything
column11: which was chock-full of bangers like the Zedd-produced “Break Free
column12: ” the production on her new Dangerous Woman is enormous
column13: full of flirty pop eruptions and slinky dancefloor seductions. ""Into You
column14: produced and co-written by Max Martin and Alexander Kronlund
column15: who helped pen some of Robyn’s best songs
column16: might be Grande's best single since “Love Me Harder.”

column1: So then where does Dangerous Woman struggle? In a rather forthcoming interview with Billboard
column2: Grande described the album as “a 22-year-old girl comes into her own trying to balance growing up
column3: love
column4: and a lot of other bullshit along the way.” However
column5: the listener comes away from Dangerous Woman feeling like they still don’t know much about the ponytailed lady peeping out from behind the mask. Grande has never touted herself as a Swiftian friend to all fans
column6: but her slight reserve means that Dangerous Woman
column7: paradoxically
column8: feels safe
column9: which acts in contradiction to the at least 19 times she sings a variation of “danger” or “dangerous” on the record.

column1: Dangerous Woman opens with “Moonlight
column2: ” which was originally the title of the record and thusly should perhaps be viewed as a prologue. “Moonlight” offers the album’s closest thing to a ballad
column3: all celestial romance and melismas. But it’s serenity is quickly steamrolled over by “Dangerous Woman
column4: ” the real introduction to the record. “Dangerous Woman” is a slinky
column5: empowered
column6: Bond theme of a belter; you can practically picture her sauntering down a grand staircase in a floor-length gown and fur on the way to seduce and destroy a lover. After the quake of “Dangerous Woman
column7: ” “Be Alright” and “Into You” are appropriately both cool
column8: snappy little thumpers.

column1: In the middle of this 15-track record
column2: Dangerous Woman’s guest features feel underused and lackluster. Nicki Minaj’s verse on “Side to Side” is a far cry from the duo’s Pinkprint collaboration “Get on Your Knees” which found both women returning to the personalities of “Bang Bang
column3: ” Ariana as a doe-eyed vixen
column4: Nicki as the tough-as-nails Queen. That chemistry is absent here and instead Minaj’s bored
column5: reggae-tinged verse compliments neither women. Although Minaj once again relies on the sexual wordplay her last name provides
column6: the verse feels rather PG. Lil Wayne’s appearance on “Let Me Love You” was one of Dangerous Woman’s more surprising features
column7: yet perhaps predictably
column8: Weezy seems sleepy. He manages to throw out the cringe-worthy line “She grinding on this Grande
column9: oh lord
column10: ” and not even the obligatory “moolah baby!” saves him from sounding half-hearted.

column1: Perhaps the most unsatisfying collaborator is Future. A majority of his contribution is repeating the song’s title
column2: “Everyday
column3: ” making him Dangerous Woman’s more minimalist version of Big Sean on “Problem.” If Future’s sexual-devotion-filled verse was taken away
column4: it would be immediately obvious that “Everyday” is constructed atop a pile of hot fluff. The only exception to this is Macy Gray’s “Leave Me Lonely
column5: ” which sets Gray’s raspy pipes against Grande’s flawless vocals
column6: adding a welcome change of consistency. Smack in the middle of all these features is “Greedy
column7: ” a romp that announces that Grande truly shines when she is given center stage.

column1: The second half of the record lacks the energy of the first. She continues to sing of growth and maturity from a former self (“I used to let some people tell me how to live and what to be but if I can’t be me then fucks the point?”) with the point being that she is now free in thought and action. As Minaj says on “Side to Side
column2: ” “young Ariana run pop.” This is indeed evident on Dangerous Woman
column3: even if the results are uneven at times. Grande does not need to force any sort of spirit
column4:
she is full of it already. She just needs to find the Dangerous Woman within herself and let her break free. 

"|21892.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21892-dangerous-woman/|7.6|Quinn Moreland

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23214/homepage_large.1dd45677.jpg|Good Luck and Do Your Best|28121.0|Gold Panda|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['City Slang']|2016-05-25 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:26.557845|"

Two years ago Gold Panda made a series of trips across Japan with the photographer Laura Lewis to gather visuals and field recordings for what was supposed to be “a sight and sound documentary
column2: ” perhaps not unlike Chris Marker’s quiet and thoughtful film essays. So far the documentary hasn’t been made
column3: but the impressions of the trips during the fall and spring of 2014 led to his first album in three years
column4: Good Luck and Do Your Best. Apparently the moment of inspiration and the album’s title came from a chance interaction with a taxi driver who wished them luck
column5: saying those very words as they exited the cab. He wrote the album in Chelmsford
column6: using Laura's photos
column7: their colors and experiences
column8: as catalysts for the album’s 11 tracks.

column1: It is decidedly brighter
column2: more low-key
column3: and less dance-oriented than his previous outing Half of Where You Live. Instead this newest album seems to fit more into the structure and mood of his debut Lucky Shiner. The same spirit of nostalgia
column4: pleasantly handmade feel (which comes from his expert use of MPCs)
column5: and wistful joy pervades Good Luck and Do Your Best. It sounds quite unlike any of the electronic music being made in 2016
column6: and is refreshingly unfashionable in that way.

column1: The best tracks capture the short-lived exuberance of the photographer's golden hour. When the sun is on the cusp of setting
column2: if you’re lucky
column3: streetscapes will be awash in an exceedingly warm golden light. It makes whatever you photograph seem more buoyant
column4: colorful
column5: and evanescent. The bright drum-pad meditation of “In My Car” and the understated string arrangements in “Time Eater” all speak to this kind of feeling. Gold Panda is at his best making lush and ambulatory compositions
column6: and the relaxed itinerancy of a vacation is most evident in his more minimal sound studies
column7: like “Unthank” and “I Am Real Punk” which rely on just a few elements
column8: like the repetition of plucked strings or a single synth looped.

column1: Those songs in particular reminded me of the producer Suzanne Craft
column2: or the compositions by the Japanese vibraphonist Masayoshi Fujita. They have same ability to create a grand feeling atmosphere out of minimal ingredients. This album only doesn’t work when it gestures towards faster paces. “Song for a Dead Friend” stands out as a one of the album’s true missteps
column3: a seemingly juke-inspired track that twists an ankle and falls flat.

column1: In terms of samples used
column2: the Japanese inspiration seemed to come mostly from the use of string instruments
column3: but otherwise it’s more muted than the story suggests. Two music videos were released in advance of the album (for “Pink & Green” and “Time Eater”) and the videos try to give an idea of what the documentary might have been. In “Pink & Green” in particular we find Gold Panda and Laura in the midst of the vacation. They walk the streets
column4: gaze at the sights
column5: eat at McDonalds. They take the train and laugh at dinner and sing karaoke
column6: as tourists must feel compelled to do in Japan. There’s a kernel in the visual aesthetic and silent narrative that might not mean to point to Lost in Translation
column7: but it’s hard to avoid. How can you appreciate a vacation in a foreign place
column8: thoughtfully and gracefully? Missteps seem inevitable.

column1: Listening to this album
column2: I wondered if Gold Panda set out to explore some of these thoughts from the pads of an MPC. Does archiving a vacation in sounds or pictures
column3: making art of it
column4: do justice to the essential passing of things? Is nostalgia destructive or generative? At the end of it all
column5:
the music escapes the expectations its creators imbue it with. As its title suggests Good Luck and Do Your Best is a modest and heartfelt attempt to celebrate a memory and place that you continue to love even at a distance.

"|21874.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21874-good-luck-and-do-your-best/|7.4|Kevin Lozano

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22893/homepage_large.e7b4680c.jpg|Four Organs / Phase Patterns|3554.0|Steve Reich|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Superior Viaduct']|2016-05-25 00:00:00|1971|2016-06-11 15:46:27.339189|"
Unlike some other famous works by the minimalist pioneer Steve Reich
column2: Four Organs is not the least bit soothing. It doesn’t murmur or churn; it squawks
column3: sort of
column4: digging into your nerves like a hangnail: “Stop
column5: stop
column6: I confess
column7: ” someone reportedly wailed at the work’s premiere. A concertgoer rapped her shoe on the stage at the same performance
column8: like Khrushchev at the 1960 United Nations General Assembly. Reich described the scene years later with evident pleasure as a “riot.”

column1: <div>As a result
column2: it acquired a reputation in Steve Reich’s canon. It is unloved
column3: the black-sheep son that will never reap the adulation of Music for 18 Musicians or Different Trains. But the thing is
column4: Reich designed it for discomfort. The whole piece consists of four Farfisa organs
column5: hardly peaceful instruments
column6: leaning on one long dominant eleventh chord. This chord
column7: the dominant eleventh
column8: is a “home” chord with bits and notes of other places lingering in it. It is inherently uneasy
column9: rooted to the spot with one eye over its shoulder. Even if you’ve never looked at a page of written music in your life
column10: you can just feel the tendons pulling in its harmonic makeup. Listening to this piece in headphones
column11: with multiple Farfisas pulling at this one chord like dogs fighting over a sock
column12: I sometimes had to remind myself to unclench my jaw.

column1: <div>This record
column2: reissued by the San Francisco-based label Superior Viaduct
column3: was originally released in 1970 by Shandar
column4: a small French label that made an outsized impact on American musical modernism: in its decade-long existence
column5: the imprint managed to release works by Albert Ayler
column6: La Monte Young
column7: Cecil Taylor
column8: Sun Ra
column9: and many others. Like any good champions of the musical avant-garde
column10: they were eventually punished by fate: in 1979
column11: a flood destroyed most of their original vinyl stock
column12: effectively ending the enterprise.

column1: <div>But for a while
column2: places like Shandar were safe harbor for then-misfits like Reich. The two pieces here
column3: Four Organs and Phase Patterns
column4: come from an era of Reich’s work when he was still in an obsessively scientific mode
column5: boring down on a single capital-I Idea to extract from it whatever secrets might be unlocked from it. The idea here was his first big one
column6: and the one that he remains most associated with: If you took two tones
column7: set them apart from each other
column8: and then moved them in and out of frequency incrementally
column9: you could push open a gate of perception. The idea began with tape loops
column10: but Reich soon moved it into live instrumentation
column11: and then pushed its way into larger forces
column12: where that original idea could be heard more as a whisper more than a shriek. Here
column13: it is the work of four monomaniacally focused musicians: The Farfisas are played by Steve Reich and Philip Glass
column14: joined by Arthur “Art” Bixler Murphy and Steve Chambers
column15: while Jon Gibson supplies the steady maraca shakes.

column1: <div>
<div>These early works have a fierceness
column2: a pointed urgency to them
column3: the way that early works in new styles tend to: They are not only establishing a new language but also arguing for their very right to exist in the same breath. “Phase Patterns
column4: ” the second composition on this recording
column5: has a similar feel: To layman ears
column6: it might sound like the beginning of a long Ray Manzarek organ solo that caught a snag in a tree branch mid-ascent. It also might sound
column7: to digital-age music fans
column8: like an intentionally corrupted recording
column9: something that had been spliced on a laptop. But that’s where the dizzy energy of these recordings come from: Behind these odd
column10: irregular shapes are four musicians counting measures and beats as if their lives depended on it.

column1: <div>All of this makes the piece sound like torture
column2: which of course it is not — it is a sensory challenge
column3: the same way a deep massage can be. When the masseuse leans their elbow into the soft tissue under your shoulder blade
column4: you groan but you don’t yelp; you trust that when they are done you will feel the benefits of the discomfort. So it is with your ears and mind and Four Organs. It is good to have your patience stretched
column5: your senses tugged. Minimalism was often thought of as smooth churn
column6: something to help regulate your breathing and help you zone out. But that’s only one function it serves; it can also tunnel deep into areas of your nervous system that other music doesn’t even think to aim for. "|21584.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21584-four-organs-phase-patterns/|7.6|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23219/homepage_large.23088737.jpg|Put the Kid on the Sleepy Horse|33703.0|Mock Orange|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Topshelf']|2016-05-25 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:28.067694|"

The most recent spate of “Best Emo Albums of All Time” lists makes an admirable attempt to legitimize a style of punk rock that has spent the past two decades derided as something you’re supposed to grow out of. But the inclusions unintentionally serve as the best counterargument: Dear You might be the only time you see a band’s fourth album in there. Nearly of all the classic emo bands either spectacularly implode in their early stages
column2: devolve into sustainable mediocrity or are Fall Out Boy. But after launching some of the leading figures of emo’s 4th wave
column3: Topshelf Records has served as a continuing ed lab for elder statesmen: in 2014
column4: Braid sounded as contemporary and vital as ever on their Will Yip-produced No Coast and also shed some light on the oft-overlooked Jazz June when they released After the Earthquake months later. With their ninth release and first in five years
column5: Mock Orange is in the same place the Velvet Teen were on their 2015 Topshelf comeback All is Illusory: previously unclassifiable to their detriment
column6: they’re now given a new
column7: flattering context in which to be understood.

column1: Looking at it now
column2: Mock Orange’s convoluted trajectory could actually serve as the basis for a tragicomic mockumentary of late-'90s emo. Their first two LPs were produced by Mark Trombino and J. Robbins and released on a label that was destroyed by George Lucas in a copyright infringement suit. After the turn of the century
column3: they evolved into a kind of floral
column4: orchestrated indie rock that the Get Up Kids
column5: the Promise Ring and Saves the Day used to effectively end their commercial peaks. 2004’s sync-friendly Mind is Not Brain somehow found them within reach of MTV2 airplay and major cable shows and fittingly
column6: they toured with Rogue Wave
column7: that era’s definitive “shit luck” band. On their next two albums
column8: they dabbled in literate
column9: NPR-indie and more or less went alt-country. And now
column10: here’s Put the Kid on the Sleepy Horse
column11: which was put in jeopardy after a nearly fatal hard drive failure. Seriously
column12: always back things up
column13: kids.

column1: After all that
column2: it’s natural that Mock Orange would spend Put the Kid trying to assess whether the bullshit has been worth it. Single “High Octane Punk Mode” probably would’ve been sarcastic even in their early days
column3: but the lightly chiding tone fits within what is otherwise midtempo
column4: “The O.C.” indie mode. Ryan Grisham relates how his desire to expand his social circle and listening habits even the slightest bit are still seen as betrayals in his community
column5: reflecting on the blinkered view within hardcore that only becomes apparent once you step outside of it: “the safety pin floats way out
column6: but never really goes away.”

column1: As with No Coast
column2: Put the Kid on the Sleepy Horse finds itself in an existential and geographic liminal space
column3: between adult responsibility and spiritual upkeep
column4: between major media centers. And yet
column5: while Braid felt marooned even in Chicago
column6: Mock Orange is based out of Evansville
column7: Indiana
column8: a corridor between the Midwest and the South—bordering Kentucky
column9: equidistant from Chicago and Tupelo
column10: Mississippi. Twenty years in
column11: they’ve finally reconciled the strident
column12: universal yearning of their earlier
column13: midwestern emo phase with the twang of 2011's Disguised as Ghosts. Surprisingly
column14: they’ve dropped any vague sense of alt-country for straight-up southern boogie: the blown-out riffs on “Window” and “Too Good Your Dreams Don’t Come True” sound like they are one Dan Auberbach cosign away from KROQ airplay.

column1: And yet
column2: while this is undoubtedly the greatest eighth album from any band ever tagged as emo
column3: Put the Kid on the Sleepy Horse itself lacks the true standout moments that would explain what earned Mock Orange their cult status to begin with. The most intriguing hook occurs on “Nine Times
column4: ” where brash slide guitars and shifty rhythms pivot into a stately march on the chorus. Elsewhere the choruses cruise rather than soar
column5: and Grisham’s lyrics cut your skin but never draw blood. Brief insight into scene politics aside
column6: most of his judgment is directed at himself for his artistic intransigence. Of course
column7: there’s a cheat code for dealing with this
column8: which is to write about writer’s block:  “There was a time when all my lines kept pouring out
column9: now they’ve gone missing
column10: ” he sings
column11: lamenting the “dead end verses on my back.” After the self-deprecating “Too Good Your Dreams Don’t Come True
column12: ” the final song is titled “Tell Us Your Story” and it's final line is “I fear I’ve stayed too long.” But the song itself is the first time  on the album Mock Orange sound triumphant
column13: so while that might have been his fear
column14:
it was worth the past five years to push through it.

It's easy enough to think there's no need for a reissue of Changesonebowie
column2: the original David Bowie hits compilation
column3: in 2016. In the 40 years years following its initial 1976 release
column4: it has effectively been written out of Bowie's active discography
column5: banished from the catalog after a rush-released 1984 CD. Changesbowie
column6: a 1990 revision designed for compact disc
column7: swapped out the original hit version of  “Fame” for a remix but otherwise presented a thorough overview of Bowie's hit-making peak
column8: setting the stage for a flood of digital-era compilations that reworked the same territory. The most recent of these was the shape-shifting 2014 set Nothing Has Changed but 2002's double-disc Best of Bowie is something of a standard bearer
column9: offering 39 hits
column10: including all 11 songs from Changesonebowie. All these compilations have had the effect of making the original greatest hits feel antiquated: it would seem an album made redundant by history.

column1: And
column2: yet
column3: Changesonebowie is an important record in the arc of David Bowie's career—maybe not on the level of The Rise & Fall of Ziggy Stardust & the Spiders From Mars or Low
column4: but it isn't a stretch to say that the album is partially responsible for cementing Bowie's stardom. When Changesonebowie first appeared in May of 1976
column5: Bowie was four years removed from his Ziggy Stardust-fueled UK breakthrough
column6: but he had only recently cracked the U.S. market
column7: with “Fame” hitting number one in 1975. He'd remain in the Billboard Top 10 with Young Americans and Station to Station and
column8: this
column9: the compilation that closed the curtain on the first act of his career.

column1: Bowie would soon decamp to Berlin to reinvent himself as an electronic art-rocker
column2: but Changesonebowie isn't especially interested in his progressive side. Some freakiness lies on its margins—the interstellar folk of “Space Oddity
column3: ” the coy sexuality of the non-LP single “John
column4: I'm Only Dancing”—but the anchors here are the heavy rockers: “Ziggy Stardust” and “Suffragette City
column5: ” “The Jean Genie
column6: ” “Diamond Dogs” and “Rebel Rebel.” Riffs rule all
column7: so loud and hooky they obscure whatever faint hint of camp there may lay underneath Mick Ronson's guitars. Those suggestions of a stranger world—all the allusions to aliens
column8: tramps and zombies—are faint transmissions from the depths of the individual albums
column9: but what's here is Bowie at his simplest. This is quite deliberate. He chose the tracks for Changesonebowie
column10: bypassing actual British hits while elevating “Ziggy Stardust” and “Suffragette City” into the canon by their mere inclusion.

column1: That's because Changesonebowie turned into a major hit upon its release. It is one of the handful of David Bowie albums to be certified as Platinum in the U.S.—it earned that distinction in 1981
column2: five years after it went gold upon its initial release—an honor Hunky Dory
column3: Ziggy Stardust
column4: Station to Station
column5: Low
column6: and “Heroes” all missed. Odds are Changesonebowie would be the one Bowie album that you'd find in a record collection in the '70s and early '80s
column7: and it was designed to be that way. It was meant to be cool
column8: stylish and accessible—as glamorous as the Tom Kelley portrait on the cover—which means Changesonebowie deliberately bypasses stranger elements. Absences are abundant
column9: some of them puzzling from the vantage of 2016. “Starman
column10: ” his 1972 breakthrough
column11: is absent
column12: as are “Drive-In Saturday
column13: ” “Life On Mars?” and “Sorrow
column14: ” all singles that peaked at three on the British charts; the Top 10 “Knock On Wood” from 1974's David Live is MIA
column15: too. Nothing from Pin Ups is here
column16: nor is there anything from The Man Who Sold The World
column17: not even the title track which is a modern-day standard thanks to Nirvana's MTV Unplugged In New York rendition in 1994.

column1: Yet
column2: as this economical compilation plays
column3: none of these tunes are missed. There's an elegance to the structure of Changesonebowie
column4: with its near chronological sequencing lending the album a narrative: it is the story of Bowie's metamorphosis from a quizzical folkie to a conquering colossus. As Changesonebowie progresses
column5: the music expands: the brawny glam turns ornate on the second side and then slides into soul
column6: with the funky rhythms supplying an artful ascendance. “Golden Years” ends the compilation on a note of triumph: it plays as a celebration of the self-reinvention showcased on Changesonebowie.

column1: This moment of triumph didn't last long. He traded celebrity for art in 1977
column2: throwing himself off the populist path Changesonebowie carves. But the record itself endured
column3: as records do. Audiences who never found much patience of the cubist synths and uneasy aural pools of the Berlin years would find solace with the songs on Changesonebowie
column4: whether they were heard on this old LP
column5: a new hits collection or
column6: most likely
column7: on the classic rock radio that embraced these songs for the very reason they were included on the comp in the first place: these are the tracks that present Bowie at his hardest and straightest. Collected
column8: they provide a summation of his peak as a rock star and
column9: in some ways
column10: remain an excellent introduction to his work: it doesn't tell you everything you need to know
column11:
but it captures Bowie's essence and repackages it as a roaring good time. That's reason enough for Changesonebowie to be back in circulation.

In the middle of her new song “Paint it Blue
column2: ” Dawn Richard sings to the high heavens
column3: “Even if I wanted too/I could not be with you/How did you paint it blue?” The loaded lyrics define the mood of her newest release
column4: a collaborative 4-track EP with Fade to Mind’s Kingdom (aka Ezra Rubin) titled Infrared. She told us earlier this year that her artistic career was entering the red era

column8: the production
column9: and lyrics of this beautifully gauzy and experimental R&B journey

column11: points to a brief flirtation with a sort of “blue” period as well.

column1: The collaborations between Kingdom and Richard were teased last year in both a Rinse FM mix and at an event called “WAVES: Nexus Re-Morph” for the Pérez Art Museum in Miami. At “WAVES
column2: ” Kingdom
column3: Richard

column2: dissolving down all the best parts of his tropes (very heavy bass
column3: knife-sharp synths
column4: and echoing percussion) into an ideal backdrop for Richard’s velvet voice. He works low key magic all over “How I Get It” where he plays with expectation and hesitance in spectacularly novel ways. As Richard sings “Bitch I don’t lose
column5: ” Kingdom lets loose a gentle waterfall of synth notes
column6: elevating her war cry with victorious energy.  The two move seamlessly from the swagger of “How I Get It” to the plaintive doubt of “Paint it Blue” and “Baptize.” She sung “Baptize
column7: ” the album’s closer

column12: encompassing everything from death defying adoration and righteous anger to
column13: best of all
column14:
forgiveness.

The So So Glos have always tied their identity to their native Brooklyn in a way few of their neighbors have. The band filled their 2013 breakout album Blowout with sketches of their borough’s streets
column2: subways
column3: skylines
column4: and bodegas
column5: guarding each reference with an insistence that in order to truly appreciate these things you had to have grown up there (as singer Alex Levine sees it
column6: the city’s way of life is under constant threat from outsiders). More tangibly
column7: the group’s members also co-founded two of Brooklyn’s big all-ages venues
column8:
Market Hotel and Shea Stadium. That’s the kind of legacy contribution to their music scene than few acts can claim.

Yet in the scheme of the city as a whole
column9: the So So Glos are just a tiny blip. It’s one thing to nurture a music scene
column10: but when condos and dog bakeries are pricing the people you grew up with out of your neighborhood
column11: there’s not much you can do—one punk band alone can’t turn the tide of gentrification. On the group’s latest album
column12: Kamikaze
column13:
they’re feeling the weight of that reality.

“The new New York that we’re living in now is almost unrecognizable to the gritty grime and crime-ridden streets that we grew up on as kids
column14: ” Levine lamented to Billboard. “It seems like we’re moving in a direction where the movements and art which sprung out of 1960s through 1990s NYC are being celebrated
column15: but there’s very little respect for the environment that harbored the culture. It’s harder than ever to be a working artist in the city and the disparity between rich and poor is becoming greater and greater. People want to see graffiti in an art gallery but not in the streets; they want to see the CBGB toilet behind glass at the Met
column16:
rather than sit on it at an actual dive.”

On Kamikaze
column17: Levine often comes across like The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’s Lillian Kaushtupper
column18: a protector of the neighborhood’s endangered Biggie murals and policer of newcomers who look like potential Arcade Fire members. It’s a horrible thing
column19: feeling like a member of a dying breed while you’re still in your 20s
column20: and these songs convey a creeping sense that the band is waging a losing battle—not only against gentrification
column21: but also against technology
column22: the passage of time
column23:
and possibly even the shelf life on their own ideals.

Recorded with Rocket From the Crypt’s John Reis and mixed by Saddle Creek mainstay Mike Mogis
column26: as well as some unobtrusive strings on a couple of tracks
column29: and fist-pumping enthusiasm remain. The tension between the band’s perennially youthful sound and their ever-more-jaded worldview that drives the record. Even when Levine rails against technology on “A.D.D. Life
column31: Undertones-styled anthem that John Peel would have loved
column32: he does so with the keen awareness that he’s far from the first punk singer to touch on this stuff. “I’m a too-much-information-generation cliché
column33:
” he sneers.

That’s not the only time he makes himself a target. A Titus Andronicus-styled mini-epic set to an elbow-jabbing Op Ivy tempo
column34: “Kings Country II: Ballad of a So So Glo” tells of the downfall of two selfie-snapping
column35: phone-addled narcissists. In a final twist
column37: Levine stops admonishing the strawmen he’s created and fesses up to his own hypocrisy. “I’m standing in some parking lot staring into my phone
column38:
” he huffs. “I guess I am a lot more like those two than I’d like to admit.” It’s easy to write a song condemning technology; it’s a lot harder to lead by example.

Kamikaze is filled with moments like these
column39: tiny cracks in the seams of the band’s value system. The album’s title conveys not only a willingness to die for the cause
column40: yet also a sense of predetermined defeat. So is it worth falling on the sword for something that no longer exists? And aren’t some changes for the better? Blowout opened with memories of rooting for the truly terrible New York Mets of Levine’s youth. The team has since rebounded—they’re defending National League champions now—yet to hear Levine tell it
column41: he preferred them as underdogs. “I never cared too much for winning
column43: ” Levine sings defiantly on “Going Out Swingin’.” If he’s wrong
column44:
so be it. He’s chosen his hill.

To best understand the impetus that drives artists ranging from the Neanderthals to an outsider artist like Judith Scott to a small town fellow like Terry Allen
column2: consider this line: “Everyman he got to leave his mark/So I got my pencil and I got my chalk/and there ain’t a rock made I can’t make talk.” It’s a verse from the piano-pounded “Writing on Rocks Across the USA” from Allen’s 1975 debut album
column3: and in the next verse he scales a cliff in the midst of a Galveston hurricane with a pencil in hand
column4: boasting: “I scribbled down some of the mysteries and I stopped that howling wind.” Is there a more succinct image of artistic futility than graphite put to granite amid gale winds?

column1: That artistic impulse must have felt like an alien transmission for someone like Terry Allen
column2: who was raised in a small Texas town. Like fellow Lubbockians Buddy Holly and Waylon Jennings
column3: Allen had to get the hell out to realize his vision
column4: though even when he was at art school in LA
column5: he was haunted by a cast of characters that he soon set to a song cycle and series of lithographs titled Juarez (and subsequently as a screenplay and sculptural and video installation).

column1: Pressed up in minuscule quantities the same year that another Texan
column2: Willie Nelson recorded his own spare song cycle
column3: Redheaded Stranger
column4: Juarez was an outlier even on the “outlaw country” scene: a hand-darned film noir that alludes to the fall of the Aztec Empire
column5: Jesus
column6: motel sex
column7: and the purgatory that is the Rio Grande border. It's now regarded as a touchstone in alt-country but even still
column8: it has more in common with Cormac McCarthy’s Border Trilogy
column9: Mexican folk art
column10: and Terrence Malick’s Badlands than anything in the country genre. And while Juarez has been reissued a few times over the decades
column11: only with Paradise of Bachelors’ deluxe new reissue are Allen’s peculiar visuals again wedded with the music.

column1: Now Allen is more prominently known as a sculptor
column2: painter
column3: and conceptual artist who has been awarded NEA grants and a Guggenheim Fellowship
column4: to where his songwriting takes a backseat to these other practices. But Juarez retains its kick 40 years on. Centered around Allen’s by-turns barrelhouse and contemplative piano playing and his Texas twang (with glints of mandolin
column5: pedal steel
column6: maracas)
column7: Allen tells the story of two couples—one a sailor on shore leave with a Tijuana prostitute
column8: the other a pachuco with his girlfriend—and how their encounter ends in bloodshed.

column1: His way with the ivory and his coyote howl of a voice can best be appreciated on the six-minute “Cortez Sail
column2: ” seguing from seemingly unconnected scenes in a manner that approaches fine cinema: a rainy highway out of Los Angeles; the landing of Cortez in Mexico; an APB for an outlaw on the run in Colorado
column3: a gun in his lap. Allen is impressionistic and cinematic in his details
column4: such as the image of lightning that tears clouds and then closes that tear in that same instant.

column1: His sparse yet driving music and the trenchant visual work accompanying are noteworthy elements of Allen’s four decades as an artist
column2: but what stands out in revisiting Juarez now is the stunning poetry of the lines themselves. Allen’s words are a piquant kick throughout: raunchy
column3: pithy
column4: and richly redolent. Of course there are quirky lines like “Today’s rainbow is tomorrow’s tamale” at the end of “Radio…And Real Life” that brings a chuckle every time
column5: as does a fantasy about a tryst in the desert
column6: which includes “anal with whipped cream” as jackalopes look on.

column1: But other lines quiver with a raw vision rarely heard in folk or country. On the rollicking “Border Palace
column2: ” Allen yowls how “my skinny body slip[s] like a knife into her perfume
column3: ” while the sweet “Honeymoon in Cortez” features the image of the TV’s glow glimpsed between toes. And on “There Oughta Be a Law Against Southern California
column4: ” Allen threatens with a real ripsnorter: “I’m gonna turn your asphalt back into brimstone.” Whether it’s the side of a cliff or on those tiny black rocks
column5:
Allen and his pencil leave quite the mark.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23277/homepage_large.c9d748c3.jpg|Fallen Angels|1177.0|Bob Dylan|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2016-05-23 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:31.059106|"

You can go all the way back to the beginning of “What the fuck is Bob Dylan doing now?” and find jazz. “Peggy Day” from Nashville Skyline—his first detour into melodic crooning—is snappy Western swing; following that was Self Portrait’s notorious take on Rodgers and Hart’s “Blue Moon
column2: ” and New Morning’s hepcat pastiche
column3: “If Dogs Run Free.” Dylan’s earliest Frank Sinatra tribute dates back five decades and only found its first official release in 2014: the addled Basement Tapes-era riff on the Johnny Mercer classic “One for My Baby (One More for the Road).”

column1: None of this
column2: however
column3: made the advent of his Standards Period last year any less of a surprise. Some of the initial shock was the result of the growing stigma around the aging-rocker-does-the-American-songbook format
column4: not the fact that Dylan would offer his own version. As he himself acknowledged in his labyrinthine Musicares acceptance speech last year
column5: this sort of record has become a convention—a profitable one. At this point
column6: any new release in this vein scans as something more sordid than a stocking-stuffer: an empty money grab.

column1: Dylan’s particular
column2: oddball point in bringing up the trend was to illustrate the absurd degree to which he was still viewed as a man apart. Why did people pore over Shadows in the Night any more than Rod Stewart’s latest compilation? “In their reviews no one says anything
column3: ” Dylan demurred. “In my reviews
column4: they’ve got to look under every stone and report about it.”

column1: But his point doesn’t quite land. After all
column2: Shadows
column3: and Dylan’s second standards set
column4: Fallen Angels
column5: don’t bear much resemblance to the market standard. The latter’s arrangements recall a time and place that never existed—a mythical dive halfway between a resurrected smoky East Village club and
column6: when drooping pedal steel figures dominate the action
column7: a Texas barroom. When creaky cellos and horn soloists crop up
column8: Tom Waits’ more muted '00s output comes to mind. But this atmosphere sounds like a byproduct of who could make it to the session
column9: how much rehearsal they had time for between tour dates
column10: what Dylan ate yesterday; it doesn’t come over as carefully cultivated.

column1: Dylan doesn’t put a clear twist on this music; it twists him. Devotees judge performers of early–20th-century standards on their ability to interpret—whether they can shape and communicate a song’s meaning with some degree of musical cleverness. But Dylan simply delivers them. In the process
column2: he tends to draw out the strangeness inherent in the compositions rather than making them sound effusive and natural. On opener “Young at Heart
column3: ” the close rhyme schemes and overstuffed lines (“Look at all you’ll derive out of being alive…”) draw attention to themselves. On the ubiquitous “Come Rain or Come Shine
column4: ” there’s so much precedent for logical ways to approach this song that one can't help but feel like Dylan is deliberately trying to muck it up. “We’re in or we’re out of the money” is faxed out mechanically
column5: the contrast inherent in the line absent.

column1: The languid pacing—often
column2: as down-tempo you could reasonably take these songs—often improves matters. So while Dylan’s breezy take on Hoagy Carmichael’s greatest triumph “Skylark” is a dead-eyed
column3: aberrant disaster
column4: his pliable
column5: conversational intro to the Casablanca/When Harry Met Sally…-famous “It Had to Be You” feels inviting. But some shifts in pacing work. Blonde on Blonde’s amphetamines are a things of decades past
column6: but perhaps some young engineer handed Dylan his first 5-hour Energy to carry off “That Old Black Magic
column7: Angels’ closest thing to a barnburner. Here
column8: words spring off Dylan’s lips
column9: rather than becoming saltwater in his throat; his ever-odder
column10: geographically indeterminate accent stays out of the way. He chuckles a bit on the final triumphant release
column11: as if he’s stunned even himself.

column1: The axioms in the songs on Fallen Angels were written to speak to various familiar moments of the human experience. With Dylan
column2: though
column3: the universal “truth” in these compositions—that word is littered throughout his Musicares tirade—doesn’t reflect easily
column4: or even deliberately uneasily
column5: back on him. In his muse Sinatra’s case
column6: of course
column7: such truth came easy: The singer was at the bar until last call in both the tabloids and on his albums
column8: probably bemoaning Ava Gardner’s latest tryst. But there’s no clear through-line to Fallen Angels’ subject matter
column9: no point of view.

column1: The final product
column2: then
column3: feels adrift: just off the coast of delivering a discrete emotional impact
column4: offering a sporadic
column5: self-reflexive charm for fans who smile at Dylan’s every left turn
column6: whether in spite of themselves or on principle. In other words
column7: it’s a new Dylan album: the product of a life ritual no one can fathom
column8:
but which is doubtless way more typical than one might think; perennially modest; worth a faithful fan’s money.

"|21939.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21939-fallen-angels/|6.4|Winston Cook-Wilson

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23264/homepage_large.43d615e3.jpg|The Triad|5293.0|Pantha du Prince|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2016-05-23 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:31.677467|"

Techno is often dismissed as clinical music
column2: engineered for precision impact. But an irony of the genre—and one that Hendrik Weber
column3: who records as Pantha du Prince
column4: understands deeply—is that
column5: though technical by definition
column6: techno is most satisfying when you can feel the human inside the machine. This is the case with The Field’s analog loops and Ricardo Villalobos’ live samples; it’s what makes Holly Herndon’s cerebral experiments compelling and breathes life into Jon Hopkin’s chilliest compositions. Like those artists
column7: the tension between organic and synthetic is at the core of Pantha du Prince’s work
column8: from his minimal techno classics
column9: Diamond Daze and This Bliss
column10: to Black Noise
column11: which saw Weber celebrating nature through field recordings and a collaboration with Panda Bear. You can hear it when Weber abandoned the trappings of the genre to experiment with a three-ton bell carillon
column12: usually found in European cathedral towers
column13: on Elements of Light
column14: and it’s what makes The Triad
column15: Pantha du Prince’s first solo record in six years
column16: his most maximalist and emotional release to date.

column1: Since the early '00s
column2: Weber has evolved from monastic bedroom producer to an artist who prefers the company of friends
column3: from Noah Lennox to The Bell Laboratory to Stephan Abry
column4: with whom he created the duo Ursprung. In many ways
column5: The Triad plays like the sum total of Pantha du Prince’s career thus far
column6: uniting Weber's early minimalism with grandiose instrumentation and collaborative songwriting. Though The Triad is billed as a Pantha du Prince release
column7: Weber has lots of help. Joining him are The Bell Laboratory's Bendik Kjeldsberg and Scott Mou
column8: who performs as Queens. Together
column9: the three musicians (and a handful of guests) act as the titular Triad
column10: melding electronic compositions with all manner of analog synths (Synthi 100
column11: ARP
column13: vocals
column14: and live instrumentation.

column1: As a result
column2: The Triad sounds more like the work of a full band than one guy with a laptop
column3: and it's better for it. Compositions unfurl slowly
column4: starting as sketches before layers of instrumentation blanket one another in unpredictable ways. Weber makes expert use of the human voice throughout
column5: treating his own and others' as additional sonic bricolage rather than the centerpiece of any given composition. Album opener “The Winter Hymn
column6: ” for example
column7: begins with a beat
column8: bells
column9: and chimes
column10: before vocals come to the forefront
column11: thawing the track like morning sun on snow. On “Chasing Vapour Trails
column12: ” monotone vocals offer a playful counterpunch to the clamor of bells before the track's bouncy rhythm is joined by ragged guitar squalls for an effect reminiscent of Matthew Dear.

column1: Speaking of bells and chimes
column2: few producers have a better grasp of how to use them than Pantha du Prince. Even before his work using the bell carillon
column3: Weber's palette relied heavily on metallic tones and percussive elements. On The Triad
column4: these sounds blend fully into the DNA of the tracks—it's not a gimmick or a distraction
column5: but the heart of the sound. The effect is simultaneously cooling (bells have a way of adding a chill to the production) and wholly organic. There's a tactile resonance to their sound that's inarguably physical
column6: even when the sound is brittle or delicate
column7: and when a track really goes for the dance floor (see: “You What? Euphoria!”) it hits all the harder.

column1: Listening to a Pantha du Prince record is also a distinctly visual experience. His tracks have a way of enveloping the listener
column2: invoking images of Arctic taigas
column3: snow-capped mountains
column4: rolling hills. Even Weber's track titles—“Islands in the Sky
column5: ” “In an Open Space”—ask to be taken as specifically visual experiences. Song titles even directly recall films: “Lions Love” is named after an Agnès Varda film
column6: while “<a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/18271-pantha-du-prince-frau-im-mond-sterne-laufen/"">Frau im Mond
column7: Sterne laufen” references a Fritz Lang dystopia. It's hard to say whether individual listeners will see the same things while listening to these tracks
column8: but there is a distinctly synesthetic element to the music. The result is an album that creates its own world
column9:
one it feels like you could reach out and brush with your fingers.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23066/homepage_large.4f7b129f.jpg|Pythagorean Dream|730.0|Rhys Chatham|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Foom']|2016-05-23 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:32.632025|"

Rhys Chatham was a flute player until he heard the Ramones and switched to guitar. That's an oversimplification of the pioneering musician and composer's history
column2: but it still says a lot about his unique methods. Throughout his 45-year career
column3: Chatham has translated styles associated with instruments like the flute—classical
column4: formal
column5: studied—into the primal power of rock-based electric guitar. This mix of the high-minded and the lizard-brained holds when Chatham plays other instruments
column6: even when he conducts 400 of them.

column1: Chatham revisits his formative flute/guitar dichotomy on Pythagorean Dream
column2: an album he made by himself—a rarity in his heavily collaborative discography. One side focuses on repetitive
column3: ringing guitar
column4: while the other offers a fluid
column5: morphing flute drone. But the approach for both— devout minimalism seeking transcendence via preset forms—is clearly unified
column6: to the point where the two 19-minute pieces rhyme with each other. Both sides loop and build
column7: mimicking the hypnotic repetitions of nature.

column1: Chatham uses tape delay to create overlapping lines
column2: in the tradition of Terry Riley’s tape loops. This allows Chatham to accompany himself
column3: slowly reflecting sounds back and forth in a hall of sonic mirrors. On side one
column4: he also employs Pythagorean tuning. I’m not technically versed enough to hear what difference that makes (nor are most listeners)
column5: but I do know there’s a precision to each note and chord that gives Chatham’s guitar a patient reverence
column6: like we’re witnessing wordless prayer.

column1: Side two feels even more intimate. As Chatham’s flute tones progress
column2: they get smaller and closer. At points
column3: it sounds as if they’re being whispered in your ear. Throughout
column4: both pieces tremble with giddy energy
column5: but also exude a calm atmosphere in their chiming overtones. In the end
column6: flute and guitar fully unite: The former folds into the latter in a triumphant refrain that soars so high it sounds light-headed
column7: as if Chatham is dizzied by his own playing.

column1: Lightness might be seen as a drawback by some of Chatham’s contemporaries
column2: but it’s always been welcome in his multi-toned music. His sunny
column3: humorous personality shines through in everything he does
column4: whether he’s playing with different musicians every night or simply directing an army of players from behind a conductor’s stand. But there's something more naturally personal about Pythagorean Dream
column5: in the way its multitude of vibrations emanate from Chatham alone. He’s using a language that he created—a language that's not hard for other musicians to learn or interpret
column6:
but one that only Chatham speaks fluently.

"|21893.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21893-pythagorean-dream/|7.6|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23208/homepage_large.ed04769a.jpg|Ullages|30983.0|Eagulls|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Partisan']|2016-05-23 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:33.239963|"

“Hollow Visions.” “Yellow Eyes.” “Tough Luck.” The song titles on Eagulls’ 2014 self-titled practically form a Friday Night Lights locker-room mantra for the sort of outcasts who spent their high-school years getting stuffed into lockers. And yet their hard-charging goth-punk anthems channeled disillusionment into a full-contact sport
column2: with vocalist George Mitchell screaming himself hoarse as if leading a team downfield to annihilate an opponent. Now
column3: after tearing up the turf on their debut
column4: the Leeds band spend their second album trying to build mountains.

column1: As its anagrammed title suggests
column2: on Ullages
column3: everything has been rearranged
column4: but nothing has changed. The band’s marauding gusto and shoegaze overdrive has been replaced by patient builds
column5: soft-focus interstitials and a dream-pop shimmer. (It’s an evolution highly reminiscent of another band of Brits who traded in goth gloom for Big Rock ambition—The Horrors.) But despite the dramatic scenery change
column6: Mitchell remains committed to ripping out his heart and giving us a close-up of the bruises. The crystalline sound simply allows for an unobstructed view of his anguish and anxiety.

column1: It also lets Mitchell get as close to embodying Robert Smith as you possibly can without the jet-black palm-tree hairdo and badly applied lipstick. With the throat-shredding barks of old tempered into a yelp
column2: Mitchell wields more control over his voice. Slow-dissolve anthems like “Euphoria” and “Velvet” feel like the biggest breakthroughs here—their stewing sense of despair doesn’t so much erupt as gradually bubble over
column3: as Mitchell invests their verses with the gravitas of choruses through each increasingly impassioned pass. Ullages also betrays Mitchell’s gift for painting his greyscale world with colorful details and knowing
column4: self-deprecating humor: on the sashaying “Psalms
column5: ” an inquiry to a palm reader opens with the comically dreary line
column6: “Is our future grey as the slabs on our drives?” And when he sings
column7: “When all the fruits from all my labor plummets over me” on the Bunnymen-esque “Lemontrees
column8: ” you realize he’s only writing about this tropical citrus source because it yields the heaviest foodstuff to drop on his head.

column1: But with its predecessor’s white-knuckled intensity in much more limited supply here
column2: Ullages can sag under the weight of its misery
column3: and struggle to rise above pure Cure karaoke. It doesn’t help that mid-tempo churns like the soggy-ember torch song “My Life In Rewind” and the “Fascination Street”-grooved “Skipping” respectively use cassette-replay and broken-record metaphors to comment on the often cruel cycle of life
column4: while coming off like repetitive slogs themselves. And the sense of inertia is compounded by an album-closing pair of ballads—“Aisles” and “White Lie Lullabies”—that follow the same route from quietude to climax
column5: both gradually obliterating Mitchell’s presence in a cathedral-toppling avalanche of noise. Eagulls’ debut made its catharsis feel communal—a shout-along salvo like “Possessed” was effectively a group exorcism performed in a sweaty
column6: overcrowded basement punk dive. Ullages opens up a greater sense of space for Eagulls to soar
column7:
but can feel more distant and isolating as a result.

"|21868.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21868-ullages/|6.6|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23258/homepage_large.5ac5bdde.jpg|Wave|33736.0|Christian Naujoks|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dial']|2016-05-23 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:33.814250|"

A maker of pensive
column2: idiosyncratic music that blurs the boundaries between indie
column3: electronic
column4: and classical
column5: the German musician Christian Naujoks would be an outlier in most contexts
column6: and he certainly is on Hamburg's Dial label
column7: which is nevertheless his longtime home. Founded in 2000
column8: Dial is primarily a hub for the kind of moody minimal techno and crisp deep house espoused by co-founders Lawrence
column9: Carsten Jost
column10: and Turner
column11: along with a roster that includes Pantha du Prince
column12: Efdemin
column13: and Roman Flügel. You'd be hard-pressed to find anything resembling a dance beat in Naujoks' catalog
column14: however. His untitled 2009 debut
column15: recorded on piano
column16: marimba
column17: strings
column18: and flute
column19: betrays the influence of composers like Steve Reich and Wim Mertens
column20: while his 2012 album True Life / In Flames
column21: for piano and marimba alone and recorded in Hamburg's storied Laeiszhalle
column22: comes even closer to modern chamber music
column23: right down to a reworking of John Cage's ""Experiences No. 2.""

column1: What Naujoks shares with his label mates is a propensity for melancholy—his debut album features an acoustic version of New Order's ""Leave Me Alone
column2: retitled as ""Off the Rose
column3: that drives home the impression of Naujoks as a moody romantic with his hands stuffed in a tattered wool coat
column4: staring out at the rainclouds over the harbor—and his third album
column5: Wave
column6: is the most exquisitely melancholy thing he's done yet. It's also the most expertly crafted
column7: demonstrating a significant step up as both a songwriter and an instrumentalist. Shifting and narrowing his focus
column8: this time he concentrates on the electric guitar
column9: which is accompanied on a few tracks by his typically spare
column10: searching piano arrangements. This time
column11: there are no vocals at all—a not unwise move
column12: given that Naujok's slightly quavering voice has never been his strong suit.

column1: He avoids distortion for the most part
column2: save some occasional
column3: subtle overdrive
column4: and though he occasionally multi-tracks his guitar parts
column5: you wouldn't necessarily know it without listening closely. There's little in the way of artifice or obfuscation
column6: just ringing delay and reverb that suggest an expanse as wide as the horizon. This is music that presents itself as the sound of things as they really are: metal strings
column7: ivory keys
column8: tape hiss
column9: tube amps. The occasional squeaking of fingers against guitar strings
column10: or the muted clunk of a piano pedal being lifted and lowered
column11: lends to the music's grounded sense of physicality.

column1: Both rhythmically and tonally
column2: these are fairly simple songs
column3: gently tugged between consonance and dissonance
column4: and lullingly repetitive. The moments that stand out against this placid backdrop are often nothing more than small
column5: brief riffs—a trill that pulls against the root note like white foam peeling off the crest of a wave. Lyrical
column6: meditative
column7: and faintly bittersweet
column8: Wave traffics in affect: It is good music for hiking in the high sierra
column9: for late-night drives through rural Maine
column10: for sunsets on the Pacific
column11: for rainstorms anywhere. Favoring major thirds and fifths and major sevenths
column12: it leaves plenty of open space for the listener to project her own emotions into
column13: and it is never cluttered: In the patient ""Playback Room
column14: a sedate call and response between piano and guitar
column15: the guitar is only touched some 20 times in the song's nearly four-minute run.

column1: Wave frequently brings to mind the work of Factory Records' Durutti Column. Naujoks' wistful melodies and rounded
column2: jewel-toned chords are often strikingly similar to those of Vini Reilly
column3: that group's mastermind and eventual sole member
column4: and so are his atmospheric choices of guitar tone and effects
column5: like the rippling delay of ""Little Dume"" and the burled flanger of ""96 Frames Per Second."" But that's hardly a drawback. The Durutti Column catalog itself often feels a bit like a set of variations on a single theme; that someone new should pick up the torch is a welcome development. And Naujoks' homage breaks new ground on songs like ""Playback Room"" and the title track
column6: in which ruminative piano and guitar figures are spun into gauzy abstraction. The album's only real limitation is that the majority of its songs are all in the same key; given the uniformity of its palette
column7: the songs begin to blend together by the record's end. But if we consider them as a set of variations themselves
column8: that's hardly a grave flaw. It's not surprising that Naujoks is also a visual artist
column9: because ultimately Wave feels like a one-room exhibition: a small gallery full of line drawings or watercolors all in a given style
column10: matted in white and framed in blond wood—tasteful to a fault but still genuinely
column11: even surprisingly
column12:
moving.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23204/homepage_large.ae473f1e.jpg|Strangers|3108.0|Marissa Nadler|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2016-05-21 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:34.041368|"

Marissa Nadler doesn't seem like she's from here. She seems like a transitional spirit from another era—some dark and medieval place
column2: a real-life Melisandre with an angelic tenor. Her music
column3: a regal gothic folk
column4: is equally soothing and haunting
column5: and like singer-songwriters Angel Olsen and Laura Gibson
column6: Nadler doesn’t need much behind her sonically to make an impact.

column1: In years past
column2: it was simply her and and guitar
column3: singing of loss and regret. She occasionally seemed shy or reserved
column4: but she’s opened up more with each album
column5: and on Strangers
column6: Nadler offers traces of her life—discussing personal friends on “Janie in Love” and “Katie I Know
column7: ” and
column8: on “All the Colors of the Dark
column9: ” walking us through the house of an old flame. “Divers of the Dust
column10: ” the album’s panoramic opener
column11: wrestles with heartbreak
column12: yet as always with Nadler
column13: she leaves the words open for broad interpretation: “Lying here
column14: on the rocks
column15: with the cliffs disintegrating/Last I heard
column16: in the end
column17: the waves were scraping city streets.”

column1: Compared with Nadler’s 2014 LP
column2: July
column3: Strangers moves away from folk into more accessible terrain. Produced by Randall Dunn
column4: who’s worked with Sunn O)))
column5: Earth
column6: and the Cave Singers
column7: these sounds are edgier
column8: supplementing Nadler’s bleak aesthetic with layered strings
column9: percussion and guitar
column10: resulting in a rock-oriented sound that lends itself to a wider group of listeners. Even the more pastoral songs like “Skyscraper
column11: ” “Waking
column12: ” and “Dissolve
column13: ” feel heavier
column14: not as gentle as her previous work. Nadler’s music is an acquired taste
column15: but Strangers is probably her most expansive release to date.

column1: As with any Nadler recording
column2: this isn’t a stark turn from her usual vibe. The strength of this album lies in its subtle shifts
column3: the way it casually unfolds without getting stuck. Dunn produces heavy metal
column4: which fits neatly within Nadler's grey-skies approach; even the acoustic songs have a fierceness to them. She's been isolated on her records before
column5: but here the music feels spacious and robust like the workings of a full ensemble in which ideas are allowed to flow. There’s an overwhelming connectivity to her music: As Nadler exorcises her own demons
column6: she brings you along with her
column7: making you feel a little less anxious about your own despair. She sees poetry in the mundane
column8:
elegance in the gloom.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23231/homepage_large.a0fd5705.jpg|These People|145.0|Richard Ashcroft|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cooking Vinyl']|2016-05-21 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:34.568052|"

It’s been a busy month for ’90s Brit-rock icons on the comeback trail—Radiohead
column2: Super Furry Animals
column3: and even the Stone Roses have all recently resurfaced after prolonged periods of inactivity. But of them all
column4: Richard Ashcroft arguably has the longest climb back up the mountain
column5: even when you take the Roses’ DOA “All for One” single into account—after soaring to the top of the pops in 1997 with the Verve’s platinum-plated opus Urban Hymns
column6: his stock has tumbled down unceremoniously through a series of increasingly soppy solo albums released over the course of the '00s.

column1: Like many rock ‘n’ rollers saddled with wild-child reputations
column2: Ashcroft has been accused of going soft in his middle age. The truth is
column3: Ashcroft was flashing his sensitive side way back when the Verve was doing pretty acoustic versions of “Make It Till Monday” on the promo circuit for their 1993 debut
column4: A Storm in Heaven. However
column5: his solo work has too often highlighted the big difference tenderness and mush
column6: blowing out the resolution of simplistic songs like someone trying to project an iPhone home movie onto an IMAX screen.

column1: In a way
column2: the appearance of the first Richard Ashcroft album in six years is more unlikely than the Roses’ return after 21. After all
column3: in this current gig economy
column4: it’s expected that our favorite groups will reunite for the plum festival guarantees
column5: no matter how acrimonious the initial split. And
column6: having already played the Verve comeback card in 2008
column7: followed by an aborted attempt at rebranding
column8: it seemed like Mad Richard was content to just carry on as Dad Richard. But if the emergence of These People is something of a surprise
column9: its contents are anything but. (Well
column10: other than the fact it took a preaching populist like Ashcroft this long to title a song “Hold On”). The extended layoff has only further entrenched Richard Ashcroft’s desire to make Richard Ashcroft albums
column11: with all the ostentatious orchestration
column12: resurrection rhetoric
column13: bumper-sticker mantras
column14: clunky metaphors
column15: and cursory electro-dabbling those entail.

column1: In hindsight
column2: the early Verve were essentially the missing link between Spiritualized and Oasis
column3: but with Urban Hymns
column4: they anticipated the post-Britpop soft-rock that Coldplay would use to fill stadiums. And though Ashcroft is loathe to own that legacy
column5: he and Chris Martin ultimately share similar goals—namely
column6: to retrofit classic
column7: Glastonbury-sized balladry to contemporary Top 40 standards
column8: and sell it to the masses with life-affirming
column9: one-size-fits all-lyrics. Ashcroft still possesses one of rock’s great voices
column10: his singular balance of grit and gravitas undisturbed by the passage of time. But unlike Martin
column11: there’s an inherent weariness to Ashcroft’s singing that meshes awkwardly with his forays into upbeat dance-pop.

column1: The most thrilling moments in Ashcroft’s discography have come when it sounds like he’s getting lost inside his own music
column2: with the surging sonics and multi-tracked vocals pushing him toward rapture. But here
column3: he’s merely singing about going “Out of My Body” over pro-forma disco-house presets rather than actually doing it. That fish-out-of-water feeling only amplifies his lazier lyrics
column4: whether he’s dropping musty Watergate metaphors on that track
column5: or deploying tired heroine-as-heroin cliches about a woman who goes “straight for my veins” on the arms-aloft anthem “This Is How It Feels.”

column1: These People supposedly addresses socio-political hot topics like Syria’s refugee crisis and government surveillance
column2: but those inspirations yield precious little insight—as per his solo m.o.
column3: Ashcroft transforms real-life tumult into nondescript
column4: placeholder lyrics. And while “Everybody Needs Somebody to Hurt” and “Hold On” respectively recycle the “life’s a bitch” sentiments of “Bitter Sweet Symphony” atop neon-flickered electro-pop and sunrise-rave sonics
column5: their pat advice (e.g.
column6: “So hold on
column7: hold on
column8: hold on
column9: hold on/You know there ain’t a lot time
column10: but I know that we can make it!”) doesn’t exactly instill you with the fuck-it-all swagger that prompts one to plow into grannies on your morning stroll.

column1: Ashcroft always fares best when he sounds like he’s addressing another person in an intimate exchange rather than megaphoning the entire human race
column2: and there are moments on These People where he reconnects with the steely-eyed conviction and restlessness that fueled his best songs. His reunion with the Verve’s go-to string arranger Wil Malone pays immediate dividends on “They Don’t Own Me
column3: ” which plays like a sequel to “Lucky Man
column4: ” albeit with the sense of fire-wielding wonderment replaced by hardened resilience. Even better is the atmospheric
column5: dead-of-night rumination “Picture of You
column6: ” which mines a haunted melancholy that Ashcroft hasn’t really tapped since “Sonnet” and “The Drugs Don’t Work
column7: ” while “Black Lines” yields his most rousing performance in ages. Sure
column8: it doesn’t tell you anything we haven’t heard before: “It’s real life/Sometimes it gets so hard.” But more than just remind us once again about the inevitability of debt and death
column9: the song’s ascendant
column10:
string-swept chorus shows Ashcroft still has the ability to make us momentarily forget about it.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23273/homepage_large.7067182d.jpg|Beyond the Bloodhounds|33697.0|Adia Victoria|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Canvasback / Atlantic']|2016-05-21 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:35.138647|"

As any woman will readily tell you
column2: our emotions are constantly subjected to public scrutiny. We’re told to “Smile
column3: baby!” We’re reprimanded for being crazy if we seem too angry or too excited. We talk about “ugly crying
column4: ” as if we must apologize for our grief not being romantic or beautiful enough. If we talk about our frustrations or feelings too much
column5: we’re dismissed as fretful
column6: overemotional
column7: or just plain bitchy. But on her debut LP Beyond the Bloodhounds
column8: Nashville’s Adia Victoria (full name Adia Victoria Paul) makes it pretty immediately clear she doesn't give much of a shit about any of this.

column1: Paul’s music has been described as ""creepy
column2: a notion that barely scratches the surface of what she accomplishes. The album is often unsettling
column3: yes
column4: but that feeling is more a byproduct of the feelings Paul explores on her gnarled songs than an end in itself. Even the record’s “prettiest” song
column5: the wavy and fuzzy “Mortimer’s Blues
column6: ” revolves around Paul’s inescapable loneliness. She approaches love-song territory with “Horrible Weather
column7: ” but there
column8: she sings about finding that person whose dark clouds and troubles match yours. Paul powers her songs with muscular
column9: chugging guitars and plodding percussion. Her riffs crackle
column10: snarl
column11: and sneer with subtle country and blues signifiers
column12: and keys alternately thrum and prick on “Dead Eyes” and “Howlin’ Shame.”

column1: Paul has a knack for crafting drifting lyrical lines that inch under your skin and stay there. Sometimes
column2: they sneak up on you
column3: as in the spoken section that concludes “Invisible Hands.” The track begins with Paul speculating what her fears look like
column4: but when she arrives at “The choir sings Hallelujah from the ovens
column5: ” the song becomes outright chilling. Beyond the Bloodhounds isn’t a blues record per se
column6: but in the grand tradition of the blues
column7: it creates space to look your demons in the eye and acknowledge their foul existence without necessarily doing much about them.

column1: On “Stuck in the South
column2: ” Paul reckons with feeling trapped on her home turf. She sings that she’s “dreamin’ of swingin’ from that old palmetto tree
column3: ” and notes that her skin color “give ‘em cause to take and take.” She promises to leave
column4: but can’t—she’s stuck. Paul’s ache is familiar for many native Southerners: The political and social dynamics of the South are complex and often ugly
column5: as it’s been forever
column6: but for some reason
column7: you stay. Paul’s recognition of her Southern identity goes beyond cloying “hey y’all” affectations. Instead
column8: she weaves together her disgust
column9: frustration
column10: and uncertainty
column11: building a frank look at how she feels about home. From there
column12: Paul closes the record with “Mexico Blues
column13: ” lilting as she sings
column14: “You go your way
column15: and I’ll go mine.” It sounds as though she’s still making up her mind about what her own way is
column16: exactly. But with Beyond the Bloodhounds
column17:
she’s made a satisfying plunge into decadent darkness.
