column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23025/homepage_large.3039df55.jpg|Andando el Tiempo|33561.0|Carla Bley|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ECM']|2016-05-21 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:35.824585|"

Bandleader
column2: pianist
column3: and composer Carla Bley’s prowess isn’t difficult to identify or appreciate. From the outset of her long career
column4: she has created memorable tunes like “Ida Lupino”—a song that appeared on an early album by her onetime husband Paul Bley (and which also appeared on avant-guitarist Mary Halvorson’s recent set of covers). Though when it comes to her full-album statements
column5: she's more difficult to pin down. Her humor can move between the slapstick and the wry. She may stage a straightforwardly goofy album cover
column6: or else use musical quotations in performance in a manner that feels both knowing and politically sincere—as with her work in the late Charlie Haden’s Liberation Music Orchestra.

column1: That mixture of immediacy and mystery quickly earned Bley a following in the worlds of jazz and new composition
column2: one that has remained ardent over the decades. On 2013’s Trios
column3: Bley took the step of letting in an outside producer—Manfred Eicher
column4: the head of ECM Records (which has distributed Bley’s independent label offerings). That album looked back at some of Bley’s past compositional work with a trio that included her longtime bassist and partner Steve Swallow
column5: as well as saxophonist Andy Sheppard.

column1: The same players and producer come together again for Andando el Tiempo
column2: this time to tackle an all-new program of music by Bley
column3: with most of the set devoted to the three-movement composition that gives the album its title. The pianist’s liner notes tell us that sections of this work each “represent stages of recovery from addiction.” Opening track “Sin Fin” finds Bley’s piano spiraling through abstracted tango riffs
column4: her harmonic interplay with the other instruments occupying a frustrated-sounding middle ground
column5: never sounding either totally ebullient or fully despondent. Keening
column6: sorrowful phrases set the tone for a slower middle section
column7: “Potación de Guaya.”

column1: The third movement launches with a striking bit of contrast: a joyous sweep of the piano’s keys
column2: suggesting a strutting exit from the world of addiction. (Bley writes that this bit represents a return to “a healthy and sustainable life”). But all is not automatically set to rights by virtue of the narrative arc; staggered bits of phrases
column3: repeated with a stubbornness
column4: suggest the effort that goes into Bley’s happy ending.

column1: Not everything on the album is this weighty. When titling “Saints Alive!
column2: ” Bley says she was inspired by the “expression used by old ladies sitting on the porch in the cool of the evening when they exchanged especially juicy gossip.” The gently swaying piece doesn’t seem particularly scandalized—instead sounding warmly conversational (especially in the communion between Bley’s chords and Swallow’s tender
column3: high-register bass playing). It seems like a song that might be destined to reach “jazz standard” status
column4: alongside “Ida Lupino
column5: ” a few decades down the road. Even when she’s not throttling into avant-garde theatrics (as on her early-career highlight Escalator Over the Hill) or writing music for Pink Floyd drummer Nick Mason
column6: the casual strangeness of Bley’s aesthetic has been a constant. At 80 years of age
column7: she remains an individual—and still composes like a born melodist
column8:
too.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22996/homepage_large.2365f6ed.jpg|Teens of Denial|32785.0|Car Seat Headrest|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2016-05-20 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:36.165908|"

Sometimes
column2: drugs are no fun. The rad night you imagined
column3: watching 2001: A Space Odyssey and brushing against the outer boundaries of your consciousness
column4: becomes a six-hour hell of wondering Did I leave the oven on? or Did I look weird when I said that thing to that one person or Do I just think I looked weird but was I probably not that weird despite the person obviously thinking I was? and so on. But I’ve never heard someone sum it up as succinctly as Will Toledo does: “Last Friday
column5: I took acid and mushrooms/I did not transcend
column6: I felt like a walking piece of shit/in a stupid-looking jacket.”

column1: That’s from an eminently quotable song called “(Joe Gets Kicked Out of School For Using) Drugs With Friends (But Says This Isn't a Problem)” on Car Seat Headrest’s new record
column2: Teens of Denial
column3: wherein Toledo feels both boundless and deeply
column4: deeply lame as he tries to sort out his life and shake off the chemicals. He doesn’t transcend
column5: but he sees Jesus. He coins a perfect phrase for emotionally distraught
column6: image-conscious young hedonists—“teens of style”—and becomes sort of disgusted by them
column7: even though he knows he and them are all one and the same. He says “Mmmhmm” a lot
column8: which is all you can do during a gnarly trip. Built around some delicate chord changes
column9: Toledo’s pensive singing voice
column10: and a backing band that slowly comes in as the trip gets worse
column11: it actually sounds like a guy walking around town while sifting beautiful thoughts from the bad ones—a perfect pairing of form and content.

column1: It’s the best song about being a confused
column2: chemically dependent 20-something I’ve heard in years. Its appearance on Teens of Denial
column3: Toledo’s first properly recorded album of new material for Matador
column4: is the moment you realize he’s running ahead of the pack as an incredibly imaginative
column5: insightful singer-songwriter who’s also capable of crafting a dynamic rock song. Teens of Denial follows last year’s Teens of Style
column6: a collection of re-recorded tracks taken from his prolific Bandcamp output. Teens of Style presented Toledo as a promising young voice
column7: but maybe anyone would sound promising if given the chance to curate and improve upon their best moments over the last five years. Teens of Style was already great
column8: but Teens of Denial is such a leap forward that it still manages to surprise. Recorded in a studio with a real band
column9: it’s a continuation of Toledo's every-Matador-band-in-a-blender sound: Yo La Tengo’s soft-loud dynamics
column10: Guided By Voices’ jagged pop iridescence
column11: late-period Malkmus’ guitar theatrics
column12: all bundled with emotive
column13: immersive lyrics detailing a frazzled state of mind.

column1: Thanks to Andrew Katz’s propulsive drumming
column2: some cleaner production
column3: and Toledo’s increasing ambition
column4: it sounds more expansive—a firm declaration of talent
column5: rather than a tease. He packs more ideas into “Vincent”'s paranoia
column6: “Unforgiving Girl (She's Not An)”'s romantic euphoria
column7: and the allusive
column8: epic “The Ballad of the Costa Concordia” than some bands put into entire albums. On “Concordia
column9: ” an almost 12-minute track about navigating one’s inadequacies after a life of substance abuse that slowly builds to a towering release
column10: Toledo seamlessly drops a whole Dido verse in the middle. It comes out from nowhere
column11: but it works. (An earlier version of the album included an excellent song “Just What I Wanted/Not Just What I Needed
column12: ” which daringly interpolated the Cars’ “Just What I Needed
column13: ” but a copyright snafu led to its cutting. The revised version
column14: “Not What I Needed
column15: ” sounds fine
column16: though the censored mp3s making their way around the internet must be heard.)

column1: Even with the bigger budget and brighter environs
column2: Toledo's underriding DIY sensibility comes through. You can hear it in the margin-scrawl messiness of his lyrics
column3: which forego neat-and-tidy narratives for  abstractions
column4: like he's snatching flitting images that run through his brain. More important than this deft lyrical touch
column5: though
column6: is his ability to display it within a musically engaging song. Unlike some indie-rock songwriters
column7: Toledo's lyrics don't just sit on the page. The choruses don't arrive at the expected moments or follow traditional shapes
column8: but they hit hard nonetheless: The high harmonies on “Joe Gets Kicked Out” and “Drunk Divers/Killer Whales” are destined for festival singalongs
column9: while “Fill in the Blank” is a burly
column10: driving rock song that might even drive Car Seat’s sensitive listeners to mosh a little.

column1: Teens of Denial is guitar-driven music filled with booksmart lyrics concerned largely with depression
column2: which naturally means that Toledo has been championed in some circles as an “indie rock savior
column3: ” whatever that means. It comes at the same time as a widespread feeling that the idea of “indie rock” itself on the wane. These arguments are often folded into an increased irritation at what might be called “white male ennui
column4: ” the root cause of so much stylishly produced music over the last however many years. But depression is colorblind
column5: and Toledo treats sadness not as a stopping point
column6: but as transformative. (At any rate
column7: he’s also multiracial.) There’s an honest reckoning with what his wallowing has led to
column8: and rapturous exhortation when logic alone cannot solve a problem. “I’ve got a right to be depressed
column9: ” he yells on “Fill in the Blank
column10: ” moments after calling himself out as a little whiner. It’s an emotional conclusion that comes at the beginning of the album
column11: a neat reminder that even after a moment of clarity
column12:
there’s always farther to go.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23266/homepage_large.452b0b8a.jpg|August 26th|33674.0|Post Malone|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2016-05-20 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:36.771733|"

In a post-Rick Ross rap universe
column2: the repercussions for being outed as phony are lower than they’ve ever been. For artists on the come up
column3: social media can be a digital journal of embarrassing missteps—think web sleuths unearthing Travis Scott’s disparaging tweets about his label boss T.I.—but in a time where catfishing can get you on a TV show
column4: these mostly make for momentary hiccups
column5: not career destroyers. These are ideal conditions for someone like metal-and-folk enthusiast-turned-singsong-rapper Austin Post
column6: now known as Post Malone
column7: to flourish. He is a rap charlatan for the digital age
column8: and his debut mixtape August 26th is like falling down an acoustic rap cover k-hole.

column1: It's worth a quick glance back at the twisty road that led to Post Malone's career. He found ubiquity on Soundcloud last fall with the novelty single “White Iverson
column2: ” an homage to the iconic NBA guard. A year and some change earlier
column3: though
column4: he was Leon Dechino
column5: an over-the-top character with a “Tim & Eric”-style surrealist comedy music video called “Why Don’t You Love Me.” The song was created with help from his friends at TeamCrafted
column6: a collective of gamers dedicated to playing and making tutorials for the sandbox game Minecraft. (In one of their videos
column7: Post seems to denounce the song
column8: saying “That’s it. That’s the one song. I’m done making music.”) Before that
column9: he was playing Bob Dylan covers as Austin Richard. As a teen
column10: he was in a hardcore band
column11: a move spurred on by his love of the game Guitar Hero. It isn’t impossible for him to be all of these things at once—hardcore punk
column12: satirist musician
column13: folk singer
column14: diehard gamer
column15: and flex rapper—but there’s something a little disingenuous about going from prodigal son of the Dallas Cowboys corporate infrastructure to a cornrow-wearing
column16: grill-bearing poster boy for appropriation. When asked about his place in the rap world in an interview with The Fader
column17: he all but admitted this
column18: saying
column19: “At 40 years old
column20: I'm gonna be a country singer. That's down the line.”

column1: Even if you were to overlook his questionable origins entirely
column2: it's difficult to excuse his shortcomings as a songwriter. Every song is a rap-cliche house of cards
column3: built on some some basic variation on ""balling"": how he's doing it
column4: who he's doing it like
column5: how you aren't doing it. <span style=""font-weight: 400;"">On “Monte
column6: ” the spiritual sequel to “White Iverson
column7: ” named for Indiana Pacers guard Monta Ellis
column8: he gets outrapped by Lil Yachty
column9: of all people.  He has no legible personality outside the confines of ""marginally famous person excited to trade fame for sex"": On “Get Wit U
column10: ” he raps
column11: “Wanna Fuck? I’m almost famous”; on “Never Understand
column12: ” he raps
column13: “Said they see me at the show
column14: they was in the front row/ They wanna fuck
column15: I told them bitches come and jump on my bus.”

column1: The moments where Post Malone finds the most success on August 26th are when he highlights his schizoid background instead of trying to hide it. His cover of Fleetwood Mac’s “Dreams” takes liberties with the melodies and structure before melting down into a backbone for the haunting thumper “Come Down.” The closer
column2: “Oh God
column3: ” sounds like it could soundtrack a modern spaghetti western with chords that crunch under his distorted croons. Additionally
column4: the 2 Chainz-featuring “Money Made Me Do It” is a nice tribute to slain Atlanta rapper Bankroll Fresh with floating harmonies that settle just below the surface of steel drum synths. Malone's redeeming trick is his way with melody
column5: and some of them are enchanting
column6: particularly on the Jeremih duet “Fuck
column7: ” which vague alludes to the Chicago singer’s “Fuck U All The Time.”

column1: The bulk of the production comes from the Atlanta duo FKi
column2: the team behind songs like Travis Porter’s “Make It Rain
column3: ” Travis Scott’s “Sloppy Toppy
column4: ” the Rich Homie Quan and Young Thug duet “Get TF Out My Face
column5: ” and more recently 2 Chainz’s “Watch Out.” A lot of the beats do fun things with hollowed-out synths and dribbling hi-hat patterns
column6: but there isn’t nearly enough firepower to overcome Post’s verses
column7: which are a series of dead-end signs. <span style=""font-weight: 400;"">It's hard to know what Malone should be doing to strengthen his work; he doesn't really have an identity or a true north in his music
column8: a more interesting direction to point towards. This is ultimately his biggest problem:  Complete reinvention can be a fine and sometimes even necessary thing
column9: but if you’re going to be someone else
column10:
at least be creative about it.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23234/homepage_large.706bd21d.jpg|A New Wave of Violence|33527.0|Head Wound City|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vice']|2016-05-20 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:37.460370|"

Conservative regimes have always provided a boon for punk rock. The Reagan and Thatcher years famously birthed hardcore as we know it; more recently
column2: George W. Bush’s two terms spurred on a generation of bands that expanded the boundaries of post-hardcore
column3: screamo and grindcore. With right-wing demagoguery making headlines and xenophobia on the rise around the globe
column4: another musical backlash could be just around the corner. That might be the idea behind the reunion of Head Wound City
column5: a supergroup whose lineup includes some of the Bush era's most forward-thinking punk musicians: Jordan Blilie and Cody Votolato of the Blood Brothers
column6: Justin Pearson and Gabe Serbian of the Locust and the Yeah Yeah Yeah’s Nick Zinner. Up until now
column7: the band’s only formal output was a 10-minute EP written and recorded in the span of a week in 2005. Following some reunion shows in 2014
column8: Head Wound City have now produced A New Wave of Violence
column9: their fittingly-titled full-length debut.

column1: More so than in the past
column2: Blilie and Votolato seem to take the lead on A New Wave of Violence--these songs all bear a close resemblance to the Blood Brothers’ work circa Burn Piano Island
column3: Burn. Of course
column4: Johnny Whitney’s high-pitched squeal and glam affectations are dearly missed
column5: but many of that band’s other signature elements are here: Blilie's dark humor and throat-shredding screams
column6: the pummeling rhythms
column7: songs that barrel forward with a punishing intensity. Votolato
column8: as always
column9: manages to make an impressive racket
column10: with guitars that alternately crash down in waves of fuzz
column11: roar like a jet engine and buzz like a cloud of hornets.

column1: As with Piano Island
column2: Ross Robinson returns to the boards
column3: lending his skilled hand to the proceedings--few producers can capture the live energy of hardcore bands with the sort of fidelity that Robinson does. The upgrade is immediately apparent; where the Head Wound City EP’s sound was defined by DIY muddiness
column4: A New Wave of Violence brings each element in the mix into sharp focus
column5: even as the overall effect is one of crushing heaviness. These songs are felt as much as they’re heard
column6: with every riff
column7: scream and drum hit practically leaping out of the speakers.

column1: Opener “Old Age Takes Too Long” provides a representative sample: a steady march of floor toms
column2: chugging
column3: palm-muted guitars that give way to thunderous choruses and an almost Misfits-like sing-along refrain of “Whoaaa-ohhhh.” “Born to Burn” and “Palace of Love and Hate” are scorched earth campaigns that sprint through multiple verses and choruses in under two minutes (only three of the ten songs here extend beyond the three-minute mark). Longer tracks like “I Cast a Shadow for You
column4: ”“Avalanche in Heaven” and “Love is Best” recall some of the Blood Brothers’ best-loved songs–multi-part miniature epics like “Cecilia and the Silhouette Saloon” and “Camouflage
column5: Camouflage”—but in keeping with Head Wound City’s proclivity for brevity
column6: are much more tightly scripted.

column1: If you’re looking for a hardcore record that fires on all cylinders

You’ll find few of the Locust’s loopy synth lines or breakneck tempos; Zinner seems content to let his guitar follow rather than lead and in the absence of Whitney

one that manages to balance chaotic intensity with a workmanlike precision that few punk bands can muster.

Tim Heidecker has built a thriving career in comedy
column3: delighting a wide swath of teens
column4: stoners
column5: and other assorted weirdos with sketches that lean heavily on surreal absurdity. The comedian has dabbled in music already with his Tim & Eric co-conspirators Eric Wareheim and Davin Wood
column6: but the new In Glendale is only his second under his own name (the other is 2011’s Cainthology: Songs in the Key of Cain
column7: ten songs about former presidential candidate Herman Cain).

column1: The ten-track LP arrives via Rado Records
column2: a new Jagjaguwar imprint from Foxygen’s Jonathan Rado. In Glendale doesn’t quite have such a concrete unifying concept
column3: but it does focus on “normcore” in all its glory—or
column4: more accurately
column5: its lack thereof. Heidecker declares his love for the suburb over anywhere else in America on the opening title track
column6: and without knowing his résumé
column7: it would be easy to mistake “In Glendale” for a painfully earnest tune written by a dad who still desperately wants to be cool. Late in the record
column8: “I Saw Nicolas Cage” feels like a familiar version of the kind of thrilling celebrity non-encounter that one of your relatives recounts at every family gathering.

column1: “Work From Home
column2: ” though
column3: is a magnificent tribute to the days when you’re too sick (let’s be real: hungover) to function at work
column4: so you promise to “work from home
column5: ” but you’re equally useless there. In Glendale isn’t a riff on the sort of rock that glorifies the difficult common-man endeavors of the American working class. Rather
column6: it’s about the extremely boring real-life shit that most of us deal with every day—to which Heidecker offers a literal nod with “Cleaning Up The Dog Shit.”

column1: But while all the songs are fun
column2: there’s an occasional dark streak that elicits nervous laughter as much as anything else. Heidecker begins “Ghost in My Bed” with “I put your head in a plastic bag and I buried it under the Hollywood sign
column3: ” before detailing the thoughts of a killer who was probably just a regular guy having a good time before the whole murder situation happened. Likewise
column4: “I Dare You To Watch Me Sleep” reads like a creepy letter from a stranger. They’re so at odds with their otherwise unassuming instrumentation
column5: and fit in so neatly among their counterparts
column6: that you can miss them on a casual first pass.

column1: All jokes aside
column2: In Glendale actually is a pretty slick rock record. From any other outfit
column3: it would be a solid effort
column4: with horns and keys providing muscle to every song. Even the piano-led coda of “Ocean’s Too Cold” sounds like it could’ve been lifted from any other polished indie rock record. Heidecker manages to sneak humor into the liner notes
column5: too: every player is noted parenthetically as “other featured artist
column6: ” while Heidecker is noted as a “contracted featured artist.” Like the rest of his comedy oeuvre
column7: Heidecker pulls no punches. In Glendale arrives as a fully formed beast
column8: equal parts parody and confession of our universal lameness. Heidecker is definitely laughing at himself and most of us
column9:
too—whether you drop your self-importance is up to you.

column2: MTV sent a bewildered VJ crew to report live from the long-rolling party taking place outside of Grateful Dead shows

column6: too

column9: interpretations
column10: and reinventions. Already containing universes

column14: singers and instrumentalists

column2: musique concrète

column6: the core of the project is made from the softer colors and textures that have defined indie rock in recent years. At the center is a National-anchored house band that come off as conservative literalists compared to the Dead themselves—pleasant
column7: but not usually taking the music anywhere especially new. Instead
column8: they treat the songs as new standards (which they are)
column9: pairing them with vocalists. Just as the Dead’s hardcore '60s experimentation dissolved to messy stadium-sized calypso thunder

column1: More than nearly any other act that might be considered for a massive multi-disc tribute

column4: ” played by the Dead in 1978 and dropped

column2: speaking for Lee and maybe those around him. Lee surrounds himself with people as equally curious
column3: lovestruck

column2: Lee’s POV is wholly embedded in Mutual Benefit’s music

column1: After Love’s Crushing Diamond

But the enduring sadness in Love’s Crushing Diamond was drawn from Lee witnessing the destructive force of escapism in others. So if the newfound pragmatism and stability of Skip a Sinking Stone seems inevitable for Lee after Mutual Benefit’s success

an inveterate dreamer can’t help but make it sound transitional.

In the last year
column2: in and around Hamilton
column3: Ontario
column4: billboards have been posted around roads warning residents about the danger of the carcinogenic element radon in their homes. The billboard showed a hellish crack in the ground oozing a toxic green light. Jessy Lanza started seeing these advertisements right around the time she moved into her co-producer Jeremy Greenspan’s (of Junior Boys) home to write her sophomore album Oh No. She was also convinced right around the same time
column5: that the air quality in their shared home was poisonous. In order to fight the incoming entropy
column6: she surrounded herself with tropical plants to clean the air
column7: and she completed an album that recycled the bad voodoo into something remarkably generative and self-assured.

column1: She told the FADER that in general  she’s “always thinking of ways to alleviate waking up every day and feeling a deep sense of dread.” Oh No in its own way is about harnessing anxiety and estrangement—imagining how all of her bundles of pent-up nervous energy could be harnessed into a productive flow. The music here is what happens when you turn that faucet on and let all the power just stream out. Oh No is a gorgeous and deadly pop music manifesto that proves yet again the sad girls are not vulnerable and silent subjects. Or as Lindsay Zoladz once wrote
column2: music in this mode is not exactly “sadness” but an expression of  a “particular kind of strength—one that allows the contradictions
column3: complexity
column4: and emotional range of a lived experience.”

column1: In the last three years since her debut
column2: Pull My Hair Back
column3: it's obvious by just listening to this album that both her singing and production efforts have matured exponentially. The songs are freewheeling collages of  '90s R&B
column4: Chicago footwork
column5: acid house
column6: disco
column7: and wonky minimalist pop
column8: using simple instrumentation to span multiple moods and BPMs. Meanwhile
column9: Lanza’s singing works overtime
column10: lifting boulders and throwing them across city blocks. Her lyrics are blunt and straightforward
column11: but her singing allows her to imbue even the most casual and static of statements with a sense of devastating irony. For example in “Going Somewhere” she treats pandering and all its silent erosion with subtle shifts in phrasing
column12: hiccuping in the middle of lines like “Say you love me” and “Baby I just want to impress you"" as if she was almost giggling at the thought.

column1: The exhortations of hurt in Lanza’s songs are not coming from the perspective of someone sulking over their wounds
column2: but a place of triumphant reclamation. The production and her singing on this album reach full symmetry in the album’s centerpiece
column3: “It Means I Love You.” It’s a frenetic blend of footwork surrounding a supine ballad of loss. It tastefully samples a tabla beat from a South African song
column4: and swaddles this percussion in slashing synths. Her voice carries along with the instrumentation in a deathly shadow dance
column5: mimicking its jerky changes in tempo and pitch effortlessly. It all stops just for a moment when she tells the listener
column6: and the beloved
column7: to look into her eyes
column8: because that's when you it means she loves you. In that pocket of seconds
column9:
it feels like you’ve been turned into stone.

On the surface

column1: That is

column3: boredom
column4: anxiety
column5: decomposition
column6: infection
column7: and disease. Life's seen as a nightmare with humans “made of blood and semen/piss and shit.” Elsewhere
column8: people are empty
column9: “useless

column13: “Everyone Is Happy” is not about being happy. (Weirdly

column1: There are some love songs
column2: too
column3: and they don’t end well. On the fuzzed-out
column4: hypnotic “ACD (Abcessive Compulsive Disorder)

column9: corrosive confection/Decay
column10: rotting in your wound/I can

column1: But those are just words

column3: words are useless. The guitars
column4: though

column6: humming
column7: and pure. “Curse of the Sun” sounds like My Bloody Valentine and the Smashing Pumpkins collaborating. Nothing recorded Tired with Will Yip (Title Fight
column8: Braid

column1: In the gorgeously warped
column2: drifting “Nineteen Ninety Heaven
column3: ” Palermo intones
column4: hazily
column5: that “life’s a nightmare.” But while these sounds can often feel like outtakes from Siamese Dream with a more depressed and inward vocalist
column6: you’d be wrong to take the bait and call the record a ""Siamese Nightmare""—as dark as the lyrics are

 Some of the best hard rock songs give little glimpses of a soft
column2: damaged heart beating beneath all the rage. Think about that little bit of major chord respite offered by the ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o1tj2zJ2Wvg&feature=youtu.be&t=2m23s"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">when you're high
column3: you never ever wanna come down"" part of ""Welcome to the Jungle"" or the ""I've been to the edge
column4: and there I stood and looked down"" monologue of ""Ain't Talkin' 'Bout Love."" These gentle flashes invite you into dangerous orbits
column5: despite their narrators' warnings
column6: with an illusion of safety that makes you overlook the whole ""and you're gonna diiiiiiie"" part. On Pile
column7: which is A Giant Dog's third official full-length
column8: the Austin band mix moments of sweetness with a whole lot of ""and you're gonna diiiiiiie.""

column1: The first refrain we hear from singers Sabrina Ellis and Andrew Cashen says it all: ""But I love you
column2: honey/Stay away from me/Tenderness is not for me/I could watch you die and not feel a thing."" Every track is a similar mix of certain danger and uncertain asylum. Five of the album's 15 tracks deal explicitly with death
column3: mostly with a nonchalance that has been a hallmark of rock ‘n’ roll since Bo Diddley bragged that he was just 22 and didn’t mind dying. In the catchy chorus of the first single
column4: ""Sex & Drugs
column5: Ellis and Cashen sing
column6: ""I’m too old to die young
column7: their voices stuck together in honeyed harmony against distorted guitars
column8: a swinging rhythm section
column9: and plinking ""Crocodile Rock"" piano boogie. Later in that song
column10: they rattle off a list of the self-imposed harm they have survived
column11: including ""all the people we fucked
column12: and all the hippies who sucked
column13: and all the hearts that we broke
column14: and all the liquor and coke.""

column1: That the songs dwell so much on mortality feels like a way of acknowledging grief rather than ignoring it
column2: even if they're dealing with it in a depraved way
column3: using juvenile humor to process fear. (At one point in ""Too Much Makeup
column4: they suggest that you ""get reborn as a tampon when you die."") Many of the songs on Pile might feel more offensive if the hooks weren't so strong
column5: and if Ellis didn't have amazing pipes. But the combination of pretty melodies and the ugliest of realities is what drives Pile: it feels like the playlist for a rock-bottom party
column6: made by people who are in a bad place
column7: taking the opportunity to celebrate it before rising above it. They sing and play with the enthusiasm of a last hurrah. It's a rare cocktail that mixes sloppy punk passion with precision
column8: but A Giant Dog have both working for them.

column1: Mike McCarthy
column2: who has produced albums for Spoon
column3: in addition to A Giant Dog's less adventurous 2013 LP
column4: Bone
column5: helps make the morbid mood festive
column6: capturing the band's blend of punk rock and glam
column7: and bringing out a performance from the two singers whose energy betrays the jaundiced lyrics. Yes
column8: it's often nasty
column9: but it's also funny. When Ellis sings about a friend who’s an undertaker
column10: who comes home smelling of ""formaldehy-eeee-iiiiide
column11: it's clear that she's having fun. Ellis and Cashen also play together in a poppier band called Sweet Spirit
column12: which is also true to its name
column13: and not as dangerous or dirty as A Giant Dog. It’s like with A Giant Dog they've found an outlet to unload all of their basest instincts
column14: so Sweet Spirit can stay sweet.

column2: the band are joined by fellow Austin musician and unlikely bedfellow Britt Daniel. Aside from his past collaborations with producer McCarthy
column3: Daniel is also responsible for bringing A Giant Dog to the attention of Merge Records: the label that released much of Spoon’s most celebrated work. His croaky hangover baritone meshes well with Ellis and Cashen

column6: swaggering rhythms
column7: and stunning harmonies. These qualities are perhaps strongest on Pile's final track
column8: ""Failing in Love
column9: where Ramones guitars buzz and lock in with the drum stops and an improbable sax. The words
column10: which seem to detail a divorce
column11: are perhaps the clearest reason for the obsession with death
column12: danger
column13: and keeping affection at bay. ""I've tried and grown tired of failing in love
column14: sing Ellis and Cashen
column15: and it’s so simple and honest that you just want to get close to them
column16:
despite the band's countless cautions against doing so.

This past weekend was Electric Daisy Carnival
column3: a yearly festival for neon-clad EDM ravers that takes place in NYC
column4: among other cities. While perusing the throngs of revelers from the safe distance of EDC's sponsored Snapchat feed
column5: I was struck by the gigantic array of DJs spinning to vast seas of people
column6: each act with their own specific
column7: trademark gimmick. Swedish duo Dada Life throw huge inflatable bananas into the crowd. There's an artist named Marshmello who wears a giant white light-up square over his face. It seemed like elaborate costuming and props were almost a prerequisite
column8: and while hordes of teens dance their worries away
column9: watching them made me long for the old-school showmanship of rave and acid house—no less gimmicky
column10: surely
column11: but grittier
column12: more sardonic
column13: weirder. The last time I saw Irish house and techno producer Marcus Lambkin
column14: aka Shit Robot
column15: perform
column16: he too plugged in a crazy-looking LED helmet when he hit the stage
column17: but it felt like a throwback to house's underground days
column18: and not a ploy for more Instagram likes. He also proceeded to spin his homegrown brand of techno well into the night
column19: striving to create that perfect
column20: lost-in-abandon dancefloor moment—which he achieved
column21: several times.

column1: Shit Robot's third album
column2: What Follows
column3: also tries to recreate that experience
column4: and while it's not always on the mark
column5: it manages to deliver an enjoyable hour-long headtrip.  As on his previous LPs
column6: Shit Robot makes impeccable use of his label mates: Alexis Taylor of Hot Chip
column7: Nancy Whang of LCD
column8: Museum of Love
column9: and the Juan Maclean all lend their talents
column10: and their camaraderie with Lambkin is evident. On opener “In Love
column11: ” Taylor's lilting vocals come in and out of the mix
column12: soaked in piercing 808 synths and stuttering bass sequencers
column13: while Lambkin's production sets the tone for the record: one
column14: big giant swell from start to finish.

column1: The lead single on What Follows is “Lose Control”
column2: cowritten with Nancy Whang and Juan Maclean
column3: where Whang speak-sings a icy directive: “I can't fight this feeling/Lose control.” The song makes good use of Shit Robot's dash of humor
column4: the place where his appreciation of '80s and '90s rave culture comes through the most. It's a theme further explored in “Is There No End
column5: ” a rambling five minutes of shuffling techno where a spoken-word vocal describes a man's stream-of-consciousness journey to the club
column6: only to get kicked out at the party's peak. It's like an exact counter to the surly doorman in Kick Like A Mule's 1992 acid house classic “The Bouncer
column7: ” but recast as the druggy clubber trying his best to follow the music to its peak.

column1: That peak
column2: the climax forever chased by ravers everywhere
column3: never really comes to fruition on What Follows
column4: with a majority of the album blending into one never-ending rise that doesn't quite launch itself over the edge. It's certainly purposeful
column5: but nonetheless it lacks for something meatier
column6: for the sonic equivalent of a huge green robot face lighting up the sweaty night. With DFA intricately woven into his DNA and a near lifetime of ironclad production skills
column7: Shit Robot will no doubt continue honing his sound
column8: inching ever closer to that perfect
column9:
life-changing beat.

When Chicagoan Chance the Rapper delivered his verse on ""Ultralight Beam
column2: the opening song from Kanye West's The Life of Pablo
column3: there was a lot going on—sly homage was being paid to West; rappers were being put on notice (""This is my part/Nobody else speak""); and
column4: most importantly
column5: Chance was encapsulating his past
column6: asserting his present
column7: and telegraphing his future. He was finally positioning himself as a rapper to be reckoned with from a mainstream podium
column8: but he was also delving deep into Christian ideology
column9: with allusions to Noah's Ark and Lot's wife
column10: with his ""foot on the Devil's neck 'til it drifted Pangaea.""

column1: That verse rolled out the red carpet for Kanye's long-awaited album
column2: but it doubled as an announcement of Chance's new Coloring Book (then given the working title Chance 3)
column3: which may very well be the most eagerly-anticipated hip-hop project this year that doesn't come attached to an actual record label. West billed his album as ""a gospel album with a whole lot of cursing on it
column4: but The Life of Pablo wasn't that; it was a rap album with some gospel overtures. Coloring Book
column5: however
column6: fits the billing
column7: packing in so much gospel verve that it sounds like Hezekiah Walker & the Love Fellowship Crusade Choir are going to drop into half the tracks and recite 1 Timothy 4:12 in chorale. Instead
column8: we get Kirk Franklin promising to lead us into the Promised Land
column9: alongside appearances by demonstrated materialistic heathens like 2 Chainz
column10: Lil Wayne
column11: Young Thug
column12: and Future—and the result is an uplifting mix that even an atheist can catch the Spirit to.

column1: Thematically
column2: Coloring Book is a far cry from Chance's previous efforts. His debut mixtape
column3: 10 Day
column4: was a small
column5: heavy-lidded odyssey of being suspended from high school ""for chiefin' a hundred blunts;"" his breakthrough
column6: 2013's dilated Acid Rap
column7: contained songs about being a ""Chain Smoker"" and confessions of ""cigarettes on cigarettes/My momma think I stank/I got burn-holes in my hoodies."" But here
column8: on Coloring Book
column9: Chancelor Bennett observes that ""we don't do the same drugs no more"" over acoustic piano and choristers backing his sentiments. He says the song is not about drugs
column10: but it still comes off as a sobering admission from a rapper who once dedicated a small travelogue to taking acid south of the U.S. border.

column1: ""Music is all we got
column2: Chance professes on ""All We Got
column3: the inaugural number featuring the Chicago Children's Choir and West returning the ""Ultralight Beam"" favor—but it's clear from the outset that this is Chance's show. His vocals—elastic and taut
column4: all jerky grace
column5: full of word-sound collages that hearken back to his spoken-word genealogy— are now almost fully dedicated to God and being high on life. ""I get my Word from the sermon/I do not talk to the serpent/That's a holistic discernment
column6: he raps before threatening to ""give Satan a swirly."" Although his puerility remains intact
column7: his fervor is amplified as never before.

column1: On ""Blessings
column2: poet-activist-singer-songwriter Jamila Woods comes through with the hook: ""I'm gon' praise Him/Praise Him 'til I'm gone
column3: while Chance drops sanctified tweetables: ""I don't make songs for free
column4: I make 'em for freedom/Don't believe in kings
column5: believe in the Kingdom"" and ""Jesus' black life ain't matter/I know
column6: I talk to his daddy."" He also manages to mix in heavenly faith
column7: the joy of fatherhood
column8: and redemption in a couplet and a half: ""I know the difference in blessings and worldly possessions/Like my ex-girl getting pregnant and her becoming my everything/I'm at war with my wrongs."" It's a heavy message delivered lightly
column9: with tongue aflame.

column1: Coloring Book is not all about transcendence
column2: however. Despite asking ""when did you start to forget how to fly?
column3: Chance still has his feet firmly planted as one of the biggest independent rappers of the moment. On ""No Problem"" he raps
column4: ""If one more label try to stop me/It's gon' be some dread-head n-ggas in your lobby."" (In a sublime stroke
column5: the song features Lil Wayne
column6: stretching and compacting his flow to approximate Chance's delivery while speaking on his own ongoing contractual issues with Cash Money Records.) ""Mixtape"" features Young Thug and Lil Yachty—two rappers who have found growing success by upending traditional music industry norms like Chance—to speak on their outsider stances. Thug doesn't get specific enough to make the song as heavy as it might have been
column7: but Yachty's verse is strong (""Time and time again they told me no/They told me I wouldn't go…/Fuck them reviews that they put in the paper/Did what I wanted
column8: didn't care about a hater/Delivered my tape to the world as a caterer"") and helps the hook shine through: ""Am I the only one who still cares about mixtapes?"" (It's worth noting that Chance
column9: who has never released a project for sale before
column10: also released a real-time mixtape last year with fellow outlier Lil B.)

column1: The bars here are so hard that it ain't one gosh-darned part you can't tweet
column2: but the tracks carry their weight like their brother's keeper. ""Summer Friends"" hisses with soft humidity;  ""Juke Jam"" is the soundtrack to a candle-lit bedroom; ""All Night"" moves its feet to Chicago house
column3: courtesy of a roller-rink jam from Kaytranada. But the bulk of this record is handled by musical ensemble the Social Experiment. They're Chance's trusted collaborators—together they released last year's Surf
column4: spearheaded by Donnie Trumpet—and they've been refining a sound of expansive but intimate live jazz-indebted soul for the past few years. Here
column5: they take listeners to church with organs on ""How Great
column6: steel drums on ""Angels
column7: and choirs
column8: choirs everywhere. On the ""Blessings"" reprise that closes out the album
column9: there's an uncredited ""All of the Lights""-esque group harmony courtesy of Ty Dolla $ign
column10: Raury
column11: Anderson .PAAK
column12: BJ the Chicago Kid
column13: and others.

column1: Coloring Book is one of the strongest rap albums released this year
column2: and is destined to be on year-end lists aplenty. It's a more rewarding listen than Drake's recently released VIEWS; it's nearly as adventurous as The Life of Pablo. In execution and focus
column3: it comes as a joyful
column4: praise-dancing rejoinder to Kendrick Lamar's To Pimp a Butterfly. It feels a bit silly to compare Coloring Book to Butterfly
column5: but it feels even sillier not to. When music comes like this—personal and panoramic
column6: full of conversations with God
column7: defying hip-hop norms while respecting them
column8: proving that the genre can still dig deeper into its roots—it needs to be contextualized as what it is. This is an ultralight beam; it's a God dream.

column1:
Correction: The original version of this review stated Chance was suspended from college. He was suspended from high school.

For their third album
column2: Portland's Summer Cannibals signed to the legendary local label Kill Rock Stars. KRS president Portia Sabin has said that the band “take us back to our roots
column3: ” and in songwriter/guitarist Jessica Boudreaux
column4: the four-piece have an insurrectionist frontwoman worthy of the label's well-populated hall of fame. But on Full of It
column5: Summer Cannibals toughen up their assault and hark back to the heavy scene that the Pacific Northwest punks killed off in the late 1980s. Their wailing riff-o-rama
column6: double-tracked guitars
column7: and sharp arpeggios soundtrack Boudreaux's frustrations with a dead-end relationship
column8: wielding (and subverting) machismo rock tropes against a domineering
column9: unavailable guy.

column1: On paper
column2: a lot of Boudreaux's lyrics can seem strangely submissive
column3: pleading for validation and putting her faith in a union that she knows is doomed. “You turn a blind eye to my every appeal
column4: ” she sings on “I Wanna Believe.” “You make me feel like nothing matters but I still see your face/It makes me weak.” Her sneering delivery
column5: though
column6: is a self-aware send-up of this piteous-yet-sometimes-inevitable state
column7: and the frustration that can accompany succumbing to such basic romance woes. She puts her anguish into wider context on the lumbering
column8: cathartic closer “Simple Life
column9: ” questioning whether it's enough to want a “simple love and a simple home.” It's reminiscent of White Lung
column10: whose recent fourth album Paradise sounds like a hairier sibling to Full of It
column11: and also finds Mish Way reconciling her punk background with her conventional desires.

column1: The 11 songs on Full of It barely break the three-minute mark
column2: and wed incendiary fretwork to bottom-end that rolls like a boulder down a marble run. They can do stadium ragers (“Go Home”)
column3: suspenseful Sonic Youth-indebted menace (“Just a Little Bit”)
column4: sludgy girl-groupisms (“Say My Name”)
column5: euphoria (“The Lover”)
column6: and on “Not Enough
column7: ” the brittle conversation between Boudreaux and Marc Swart's guitars evokes early Sleater-Kinney. Summer Cannibals balance the abjection of their lyrics by playing like they're auditioning to ride the flame-belching rig in Mad Max: Fury Road.

column1: Despite the ambiguity of some of her lyrics
column2: Boudreaux's ire is rarely in dispute across these songs thanks to her bile-drenched delivery
column3: though the moments where she makes it explicit are particularly good. “Talk Over Me” is full of coolly insolent
column4: stinging riffs that accompany Boudreaux telling some paternalistic ass where to get off: “I'm not gonna let you talk over me one more time
column5: and I'm not gonna wait for someone else to say that I'm right.” That self-assurance is why Full of It works: Boudreaux can sing from a position of weakness thanks to Summer Cannibals' palpable confidence. On the title track
column6: which kicks back at the music press
column7: she makes perfectly clear that her sense of self doesn't hinge on anyone else's approval: “Tell me my worth
column8: I'll tell you my pitch
column9: ” Boudreaux drawls
column10: before scoffing: “Another lie
column11: yeah
column12: another unreachable itch.” Full of It may not sound like classic Kill Rock Stars fare
column13:
but in these complex negotiations of power—both emotional and musical—they both fit right in and offer a smart update to their history.

In experimental music

column6: aka Mitchel Van Dinther
column7: calls his debut album Fool a collection of “naive
column8: computer jazz

column1: Fool is the latest release by Brainfeeder

column4: Brainfeeder has been home to a great number of warm
column5: wonderful and weird records
column6: some of which has been awesome and inspiring and others which were not. It’s clear from first listen that Fool too is without doubt an “out there” disc
column7: both in the most literal and clichéd ideas of the term. Not only does the record burst at the seams with ideas
column8: but nearly each song does so
column9: with each of the free-flowing tracks careening internally from moments of austere beauty to jazzy breakdowns
column10: to burbling bleeps and blaps and even Pierre Boulez-style musique concrete. It’s a lot of ideas and sounds to cram into a 43 minute record in general
column11: made only a little bit easier to digest by the fact that there are hardly discernible pauses between most of the eleven tracks.

column1: Despite the clutter
column2: there are a number of moments on Fool where everything clicks
column3: in particular the album’s bookends. Opener “Flake” begins with traditional IDM electronic/synth tones that belie the rest of the record’s feel
column4: before falling away to a startling hybrid of G-Funk and chiptune. The beautiful noise here hearkens back to some of the more effervescent and fun experimental electronic music of the late '90s and early 2000 (Plone and early Jamie Lidell in particular come to mind). Closer “Teeth” starts slowly from a lovely interplay of reverbed organ and bass underneath some creaking metal sounds and a soaring violin
column5: before building to a sort of tiny toy orgasm
column6: similar to (but shorter and humbler than) the climax of Daft Punk’s “Contact” from Random Access Memories—and all in two-and-a-half minutes. It's the most focused track on the record
column7: and perhaps not coincidentally the shortest.

column1: There are other great moments on Fool as well
column2: though Van Dinther’s haphazard compositional style  means the record seesaws frequently from the sublime to the mundane
column3: and vice versa. “Lose” follows the killer “Flake” intro but loses its momentum with what sounds like a synthetic orchestra tuning up. However after two-and-a-half minutes of dithering
column4: the noise suddenly builds and breaks way to a gorgeous and alluring melody. The synths continue bleating but the melodic underpinnings take what were tedious sounds and turn it all into something worth remembering. Penultimate number “Toots” is structured similarly
column5: with a warm church organ penetrating 3 minutes in
column6: turning unfocused chirps into something powerful and direct.

column1: Two other tracks of note on Fool feature noteworthy albeit obscure guests: “The Zoo
column2: ” featuring undersung '70s jazzbo Steve Kuhn and “Flu” featuring Brazilian bossa nova player Arthur Verocai. The former is a bit of a Take 2 on Kuhn’s original “Pearlie’s Swine” from his 1971 self-titled record
column3: featuring a similar musical approach and with Kuhn repeating some of the spoke-sung lyrics from that song. Despite a nice and very Arthur Russell-esque electric cello intro
column4: “The Zoo” is one of Fool’s most straight-forward jazz tracks
column5: with some lovely vibraphones and mellifluous bass from Brainfeeder staple artist Thundercat. But for this reason it’s also less experimental
column6: and comes off as a lesser version of the jazz which it apes. And unlike “Zoo
column7: ” which channels Kuhn directly
column8: “Flu” seems like another Jameszoo fusion except two brief and pretty 20 second bursts of Verocai’s samba guitar in the middle of the song. But after each of the 20 second parts
column9: the guitar disappears and the fusion returns
column10: making Verocai’s contributions seem to be swallowed up by the earth.

column1: Jameszoo's work is strongest when he tones down the overt jazz and instead parses the genre for specific sounds and ideas to embellish his electronic experimentations. It’s easy to imagine how a creative
column2: introspective artist like Van Dinther might be able to harness his ample curiosity and ability in the future
column3: but for now
column4:
a lack of focus keeps him grounded. Hopefully next time he gets there.

"|21911.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21911-fool/|6.9|Benjamin Scheim

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23209/homepage_large.3d55090b.jpg|Happy Songs for Happy Zombies|33435.0|Pinkshinyultrablast|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Club AC30']|2016-05-17 00:00:00|2009|2016-06-11 15:46:45.515049|"

Pinkshinyultrablast have been together nearly a decade
column2: but they’re still chasing the clock. The Russian outfit has been living on borrowed time since 2007
column3: when four lifelong music nerds from Saint Petersburg decided to start a band
column4: knowing full well that they’d have to part ways in a few months’ time to attend university. Determined to defy those temporal restraints
column5: the quartet worked in fits and bursts
column6: using every pocket of free time as a chance to commit their memories to wax.

column1: Somehow
column2: they've found ways to develop as a band even with this scattershot work schedule. Just this February
column3: Pinkshinyultrablast released Grandfeathered
column4: an underrated collection of sophisticated—and thunderous—pop songs. Several months after the band's most intricate release to date
column5: London’s Club AC30 is taking a look back on their hurried early period with a reissue of <i>Happy Songs for Happy Zombies
column6: their debut EP. Frequently pointed to as an underrated gem by the modern shoegaze faithful
column7: the four-track
column8: 15-minute collection provides an enjoyable (if brief) introduction to the band’s rapturous take on rock.

column1: Much like the Astrobrite album that inspired Pinkshinyultrablast's name
column2: Happy Songs for Happy Zombies plays it maximalist. The aptly titled opening salvo “Blaster” spills forth in a rush of massive
column3: fanning guitar riffs
column4: whirring feedback
column5: and bass throb. Guitarist Roman Parinov may not sing lead—that job belongs to frontwoman Lyubov Soloveva—but his screechy axe is the track’s strongest voice
column6: easily engulfing her fragile melodies. Soloveva can’t be contained
column7: however—just as Parinov seems to have her buried on “Blaster” or “Ode to Godzilla
column8: ” she phases through him
column9: gently guiding the roar beneath her and preventing the music from dissolving into chaos.

column1: Soloveva
column2: Parinov
column3: and company certainly take cues from amp-stackers like My Bloody Valentine and Swervedriver
column4: but their biggest inspiration on Happy Songs for Happy Zombies arguably isn’t shoegaze
column5: or even musical. In a 2015 interview with Indie is Not A Genre
column6: Soloveva revealed the group’s fascination with the Russian custom of dacha: an annual exodus from city apartment to country cabin for a few months of hard-earned rest and reflection. The burbling “Honeybee
column7: ” certainly feels like the type of song inspired by a day of cloud-gazing; it sees Parinov loosening up and letting the notes unspool steadily atop a fluttering backbeat. Between the lurching
column8: grunge-y verses on “Deerland” and “Blaster”’s aforementioned wind-tunnel arrangement
column9: calling Happy Songs for Happy Zombies a relaxed effort is certainly a stretch
column10: but the EP's dacha mentality endures: freedom
column11: playfulness
column12: childlike wonder—and most importantly
column13: an appreciation of those rare moments where you’re not chasing time or fretting over its passage
column14: but enjoying the time you do have with the people who matter. Fifteen minutes is no eternity
column15: after all
column16:
but it’s ample time for an enjoyable escape—just like Happy Songs for Happy Zombies.

"|21869.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21869-happy-songs-for-happy-zombies/|6.9|Zoe Camp

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23256/homepage_large.857736b4.jpg|The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection|1023.0|Miles Davis|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Prestige']|2016-05-16 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:46.122873|"

When you talk about Miles Davis
column2: you’re really talking about something like eight musicians: a sideman to Bird during the bebop revolution; catalyst of cool jazz; hard bop and modal pioneer; enabler of John Coltrane and leader of the “first great quintet”; nurturer of the younger “second great quintet” in the mid-'60s; collaborator in large ensembles with his musical soul mate
column3: Gil Evans; initiator of an uncompromising jazz-rock-funk fusion; and elder statesmen of a more polished
column4: though still-distinct
column5: fusion in the 1980s.

column1: Even within those periods there are fascinating mini-chapters
column2: like his work from the early 1950s. Now
column3: on the occasion of what would’ve been Miles Davis’ 90<sup>th</sup> birthday this month
column4: comes The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection
column5: a sometimes-disorienting
column6: ultimately sumptuous set of eleven vinyl records from 1951–54
column7: nine of which feature Miles as the sole leader.

column1: The bulk of Miles Davis’ canonical output is on Columbia Records
column2: which he left in 1986 for Warner Brothers in his final years. His pre-Columbia work from 1951–56 was
column3: for the most part
column4: on Prestige Records
column5: a small
column6: fledgling indie label in Hell’s Kitchen launched by Bob Weinstock in 1949. This set is not a comprehensive examination of his stay at Prestige—that is available on the 8-CD <i>Miles Davis Chronicle: The Complete Prestige Recordings
column7: 1951–1956—nor is there any new material here
column8: but the recordings are in the exact format of their release
column9: the forgotten 10-inch vinyl record
column10: something new at the time that could accommodate more minutes than 78 rpm discs
column11: which were the common format for popular recordings. “I was excited about the freedom this new technology would give me
column12: ” Miles wrote in his autobiography. “I had gotten tired of that three-minute lockstep that the 78s had put musicians in.”

column1: If you’re not familiar with the 10-inch format
column2: you’ll have to stay on your toes
column3: as sides rarely go beyond 12 or 13 minutes (and sometimes run for as little as 8 minutes.) The set is in chronological order
column4: more or less
column5: to show how his work progressed
column6: and features the original cover art
column7: complete with typographical errors. (A 7–by–10 replica of one of Miles Davis’ paintings is also included.)

column1: The music
column2: too
column3: will keep you on your toes
column4: and enthralled. In many ways
column5: this is one of his most rollicking periods. It’s post-Bird
column6: post-birth-of-cool (released by Capitol Records)
column7: yet pre-great quintet with John Coltrane
column8: which coalesced at Prestige in 1955 (not included in this set) and progressed into super-stardom at Columbia. Miles is still very much trying to find himself
column9: musically and personally. A few of the musicians he organized for what several years later was called Birth of The Cool—white musicians
column10: it should be said— took it to the West Coast and ran with it. Meanwhile
column11: he was battling heroin addiction. “Heroin
column12: ” he wrote in his autobiography
column13: “was my girlfriend.”

column1: The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection is a document then of a search
column2: an exhilarating one: a search for self
column3: a search for a sound
column4: a search for an aesthetic
column5: a search for like minds. His various band mates on these dates include: Sonny Rollins
column6: Art Blakey
column7: Jackie McLean
column8: Charles Mingus
column9: John Lewis
column10: Max Roach
column11: Lucky Thompson
column12: Roy Haynes
column13: Horace Silver
column14: Milt Jackson
column15: Thelonious Monk
column16: and Zoot Sims
column17: whom
column18: according to Miles’ autobiography
column19: he did heroin with right before they recorded Miles Davis Plays the Compositions of Al Cohn in January 1953
column20: on LP 4. It is—maybe because of the drugs
column21: maybe because it wasn’t Miles’ idea to play Cohn’s music—one of the rare uninspired records here. So is the first
column22: <i>Modern Jazz Trumpets
column23: of which Miles is only one of four leaders
column26: and the forever under-appreciated Kenny Dorham

column1: The rest—before H and after H—is nearly always stirring. Of that first recording
column2: even Miles admitted he wasn’t up to par: “I didn’t play well
column3: ” Davis wrote of that January 1951 session
column4: “but I think everyone else played well—especially Sonny [Rollins].” Indeed
column5: Miles and Sonny had something special
column6: and they have three dates together on this set across four of the LPs. As exceptional as some of the talent Miles assembled is
column7: it didn’t always produce memorable partnerships. Charles Mingus
column8: who plays piano on one tune—and he was a good piano player
column9: just listen to Mingus Plays Piano—was never a going to be good fit with Miles. They both had huge personalities. And although he and Thelonious Monk did mesh well together
column10: and played beautifully on four of these LPs
column11: they clashed personally.

column1: By around 1954
column2: Miles wrote that he’d hoped to form a steady touring band with Rollins
column3: Horace Silver on piano
column4: Kenny Clarke on drums
column5: and Percy Heath on bass. It wasn’t meant to be: Rollins had to deal with his own drug issues; Silver joined Art Blakey’s Jazz Messengers; and Clarke went to the Modern Jazz Quartet. That great-quartet-that-never-was did have one session
column6: on the LP Miles Davis with Sonny Rollins from June 29
column7: 1954. The results hover around perfection as they play the Rollins originals “Oleo
column8: ” “Airegin
column9: ” “Doxy
column10: ” and the Gershwin standard “But Not for Me.”

column1: Miles kicked his heroin habit by 1954 and had a great year
column2: all of which is included in this set
column3: and almost all of his sessions were now recorded at Rudy Van Gelder’s across the river in New Jersey (though in his Hackensack living room
column4: before he built his fabled studio in Englewood Cliffs). The following year
column5: he did settle on a band
column6: but with another tenor
column7: John Coltrane
column8: a 20-year-old bassist named Paul Chambers
column9: Red Garland on piano
column10: and Philly Joe Jones on drums. Not so bad. That quintet would go on to have recording dates for Prestige in 1955 and '56
column11: which became the four albums Cookin’
column12: Steamin’
column13: Relaxin’
column14: and <i>Workin’
column15: though now on 12-inch vinyl as the industry transitioned yet again by the mid-'50s.

column1: The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection can
column2: however
column3: be a little puzzling. If you have a collection of Miles Davis records and want to know if you already own some of this material
column4: it might not be immediately clear. Many fans might own a previous version of
column5: say
column6: <i>Walkin’
column7: which on the cover says “Miles Davis All Stars.” But here
column8: “Walkin’ ” appears not as an LP but merely as a tune—a phenomenal 13-minute version with the superlative tenorist Lucky Thompson—from the April 29
column9: 1954 LP Miles Davis All Star Sextet. Nor is it spelled out that Walkin’ (the 12-inch version
column10: released by Prestige in 1957) is a compilation of two of the 10-inch LPs—Miles Davis Quintet in addition to Miles Davis All Star Sextet—plus one song not on this set. It all gets a little eye-crossing. You can figure most of this out
column11: eventually
column12: flipping back-and-forth from the 12-inch or CD you own (if you do) and the enclosed booklet. It is either maddening or a little fun
column13: depending on your disposition—the fan as archivist.

column1: The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection even rewards when you least expect it
column2: like in 1951’s Lee Konitz Featuring Miles Davis
column3: one of the few times
column4: besides with Bird
column5: where Miles was a sideman. (Cannonball Adderley’s 1958 Blue Note album Somethin’ Else was another
column6: a record so luminous Uniqlo made a T-shirt out of it.) They were colleagues from <i>Birth of the Cool
column7: and Miles liked his playing
column8: even defended him when he was criticized by other black musicians for hiring a white saxophonist. Konitz
column9: the proto avant-gardist who was the first musician to record for Prestige in '49
column10: worked hard—like Miles—to never sound like anyone else
column11: and the two are almost otherworldly here
column12: drifting inquisitively around each other
column13: then as one
column14: as if it were the birth of the free-cool. The daring hints at what would come
column15: for Konitz (still underrated and still playing challenging music at age 88)
column16: and for Miles
column17: always prepared to risk
column18: always willing to move beyond his comfort zone. To hear Miles Davis develop—as a person
column19: as a musician
column20: and as a bandleader
column21: in the midst of technological changes—makes this series of recordings on Prestige specialized
column22: yes
column23:
but also quite special. 

"|21918.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21918-the-complete-prestige-10-inch-lp-collection/|8.4|Michael J. Agovino

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23000/homepage_large.feb7ff4f.jpg|Holy Ghost|31933.0|Modern Baseball|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Run for Cover']|2016-05-16 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:46.980723|"

Modern Baseball became a popular band writing songs about Facebook and Instagram and emulating the selective communication of those social media platforms: revealing personal minutiae without ever having to be vulnerable. Throughout 2012’s Sports and 2014's You’re Gonna Miss It All
column2: Jake Ewald and Brendan Lukens sang mostly about girls
column3: social insecurity
column4: and punk rock hypocrisy—nothing that the average person in their audience hadn’t experienced themselves.

column1: Since then
column2: Modern Baseball have unexpectedly evolved into an important band. After canceling an Australian tour last fall
column3: Lukens went to rehab and was diagnosed with manic depression
column4: alcoholism
column5: marijuana addiction
column6: and cutting behavior
column7: all of which was unsparingly detailed in their Tripping in the Dark mini-doc. Every Modern Baseball interview in the time since has doubled as advocacy for destigmatizing mental illness and encouraging the seeking of medical treatment. They’re not alone: Along with Sorority Noise
column8: the Word Is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die
column9: the Hotelier and basically any leader of emo’s 4th-wave
column10: Modern Baseball demonstrate an undeniable sonic ambition and social conscience in a genre still reduced to a “Sad as Fuck” T-shirt. Their extracurricular candor is a necessary complement to Holy Ghost
column11: which asks for difficult things out of its audience—space
column12: patience and acceptance.

column1: In the past
column2: MoBo’s appeal often lied in how they looked like guys who came to their shows straight from a Drexel lecture hall
column3: singing about things that happened to them just that day. On Holy Ghost
column4: Ewald and Lukens admit that even a wholly unpretentious
column5: image-free band like Modern Baseball might have to put on an act sometimes just to make it to the next gig. “The glare from our stupid
column6: spineless words just whining
column7: every fucking day/what do I really want to say?
column8: ” Ewald spews on “Note to Self
column9: ” one of the many road-weary tracks here.  Throughout Holy Ghost
column10: Lukens and Ewald mostly want to say “I miss you
column11: ” “I love you
column12: ” or
column13: “I’m sorry.” But with their friends
column14: family and Philly often hundreds of miles away
column15: Modern Baseball either internalize or end up directing their anxieties at each other.

column1: There was a point where it was unclear whether Modern Baseball would make it to Holy Ghost
column2: and the tension is audaciously presented in a Speakerboxxx/The Love Below-style split condensed into less than a half hour. Ewald is given the first six tracks
column3: while the remaining five are Lukens’. Even up to last year’s excellent MOBO Presents: The Perfect Cast EP featuring Modern Baseball
column4: new listeners could be forgiven thinking the band only had one singer. At this point
column5: Ewald and Lukens seem like total inverses of each other.

column1: Holy Ghost will inevitably take on a new life as its lyrics become status updates. All the zingers will be Ewald’s
column2: but since his hooks are as densely worded and occasionally unwieldy as his verses
column3: the shoutalongs come from Lukens. Ewald’s side builds towards “Everyday” and “Hiding
column4: ” the most compositionally complex and ornately arranged Modern Baseball songs to date. Lukens
column5: meanwhile
column6: claims he wrote all of his lyrics in the last three days of recording. His songs are urgent
column7: frenzied and compact
column8: with titles that read like inside jokes used as placeholders (“Breathing in Stereo
column9: ” “Coding These To Lukens
column10: “Apple Cider
column11: I Don’t Mind”).

column1: The format serves each writer as an individual. While the shift towards tempered indie rock often robs Holy Ghost of the instant gratification of early MoBo
column2: there isn’t a single clunker lyric that was wedged in for the sake of cleverness. Taken together
column3: Holy Ghost feels inevitably unbalanced. Modern Baseball probably didn’t have much of a choice; shuffled in any way
column4: it just becomes nonsensically disjointed.

column1: The sequencing makes more sense upon hearing the closing “Just Another Face
column2: ” whose chorus alone more than makes up for any denied catharsis. Based on The Perfect Cast and their live Killers covers
column3: an album full of this kind of bombastic arena-emo would be certainly welcome. It consolidates every improvement over You’re Gonna Miss It All: Ewald’s compositional ambition and patience
column4: Lukens’ newly theatrical high range and for both
column5: a desire to recognize the bittersweet way in which the relationship between them and their audience has changed.

column1: The self-pity of the verses are simply and petulantly worded to recall MoBo’s earlier phase and Lukens’ real rock bottom (“I’m a waste of time and space
column2: ” “entering a well-known phase
column3: I scream ‘get lost
column4: I hate everything’”). A number of people might be the voice talking to Lukens during the unabashedly uplifting chorus. Perhaps it’s his family
column5: or Cam Boucher
column6: the Sorority Noise frontman Lukens credits with pushing him to seek help. Maybe it’s a girlfriend
column7: as the title references a lyric from the first song Lukens ever wrote (""How Do I Tell a Girl I Want to Kiss Her
column8: naturally). It could be the other members of Modern Baseball
column9: who Lukens claims “saved my life.” Earlier on ""Note to Self
column10: Ewald hoped to build “something that cannot leave the ground/unless we lift it up together
column11: ” and Holy Ghost makes good on that desire: Every performance of ""Just Another Face"" will end with Modern Baseball and their audience yelling at each other
column12:
“I’ll be with you the whole way.” 

"|21677.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21677-holy-ghost/|7.7|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23156/homepage_large.9f1d759b.jpg|Nattesferd|31130.0|Kvelertak|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Roadrunner']|2016-05-16 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:47.596023|"

Before Metallica basically turned metal into a speed-racing contest
column2: older acts like Accept
column3: Raven
column4: and Metal Church had already embraced fast tempos while keeping one foot planted in what we once called metal but now look back on as traditional hard rock. Sonically speaking
column5: these bands formed a kind of connective tissue between the poofy-haired stuff and the more aggressive styles that arose in part to purge the genre of its focus on backstage hedonism. If they referenced the rock'n' roll lifestyle
column6: though
column7: they tended to do so with a tough-guy attitude
column8: as if partying
column9: sex
column10: and cars weren't the ultimate endgame but the reward for sticking to one's guns and making METAL an all-caps priority for life.

column1: When you hear the modern-day Norwegian sextet Kvelertak (""stranglehold"")
column2: it's obvious that they're aiming for the same middle lane as their proto-thrash predecessors. But Kvelertak also embrace the let-the-good-times-roll side of metal as well. (For the record
column3: the band describes itself first and foremost as ""rock and roll."") And even though frontman Erlend Hjelvik sings entirely in Norwegian
column4: Kvelertak's third album Nattesferd is so thoroughly crammed with fist-pumping hooks it's easy to get the impression that he's singing about heading out to the highway the whole time. He isn't
column5: but on the first song alone the band manages to marry blast beats to the anthemic power of Van Halen
column6: Dokken
column7: and Judas Priest.

column1: Nattesferd actually covers a lot more ground than Kvelertak's '80s ancestors did
column2: but elements that might otherwise oppose one another blend into the experience seamlessly. Kvelertak's fellow revivalists (the Hellacopters
column3: Bonded By Blood
column4: The Sword
column5: and pretty much any Sabbath-mimicking fuzz-rock band) can be so adamant about faithful replication that listening to them can feel suffocating. By contrast
column6: the overwhelming feeling that comes across with Nattesferd is one of freedom to explore. ""Svartmesse
column7: for example
column8: begins with a reverbed
column9: single-string choka-choka-choka guitar line that's initially reminiscent of the Lick It Up-era KISS tune ""Exciter"" until the song veers into a quintessential New Wave Of British Heavy Metal-style verse. It's hard to imagine such a move in anyone else's hands not falling into either complete camp or embarrassing over-earnestness. In this case
column10: it's fun without making you laugh at—or even with—the band.

column1: The same is true of the production. Both Kvelertak's 2010 self-titled debut and 2013's sophomore album Meir benefited from the touch of Converge guitarist/producer Kurt Ballou
column2: who
column3: no surprise
column4: captured the scratchy edges of the band's sound. This time
column5: Kvelertak chose to produce themselves along with engineer Nick Terry (The Libertines
column6: Turbonegro
column7: Robyn Hitchcock). By contrast
column8: Nattesferd hearkens back to a more vintage rock feel. Still
column9: Terry and the band opt for a crisp
column10: vibrant ambience rather than the boxed-in reverbs that were typical of the early '80s.

column1: The CD booklet includes lyrics
column2: which of course won't be of much use for non-Norwegian speakers. But the text for each song is preceded by a cryptic thumbnail summary. Listeners shouldn't expect to get a feel for what the songs are actually about with introductions like ""Odin hangs himself from Yggdrasil for nine days so he can uncover the secrets of the world
column3: ""A future of despair awaits us. Resistance is futile
column4: and ""A traveler ventures into the strange black night with hopes of finding himself a new home."" (The album title means ""night traveler."") Alas
column5: Google Translate won't help you determine that either
column6: but with Nattesferd Kvelertak exploit an opportunity to create a sense of mystery. More importantly
column7: they back it up with a group of songs that's virtually filler-free and loses little steam towards the end. Even if Kvelertak didn't mean to re-cast the Norse deity Odin as a Camaro-driving rebel burning rubber down the road
column8:
Nattesferd makes it exceedingly easy—and enjoyable—to picture him as one.

"|21818.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21818-nattesferd/|8.0|Saby Reyes-Kulkarni

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23119/homepage_large.9416bb53.jpg|I Hear You|33629.0|Arbor Labor Union|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2016-05-16 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:46:48.286788|"

Arbor Labor Union likes to sing about singing. The Georgia post-punk band’s debut album
column2: released in 2015 under the name Pinecones
column3: was titled Sings for You Now
column4: and it contained numerous lyrical references to the titular act; in essence
column5: the album was an account of the band’s own creation
column6: propelled by muscular hymns and steeped in a mystical if not downright metaphysical aura. If Sings for You Now was an origin story
column7: I Hear You is a mission statement. Following a name change to Arbor Labor Union
column8: the group has refined and expounded upon its throbbing
column9: rootsy drone. They’ve also doubled down on singing about singing—if not always in the most convincing way.

column1: Veterans of various punk and hardcore bands
column2: the guys in Arbor Labor Union drew inspiration from Henry David Thoreau’s transcendentalist philosophy for Sings for You Now
column3: and these two areas of inspiration still hold heavy sway over I Hear You. On the pounding “Radiant Mountain Road
column4: ” an uplifting command to “Ascend to the Mount of Joy” is fueled by nervy guitar interplay. Rather than trading or entwining leads
column5: though
