Hooded Fang emerged in 2008 like many Canadian bands of the era
column2: crowding the stage with seven players and offering upbeat artisanal indie-pop with the then-requisite glockenspiels and trombones. But in Daniel Lee’s sly
column3: sonorous vocals
column4: you sensed an eccentric streak lurking
column5: and he and bassist April Aliermo weren’t afraid to unleash it through other projects. Outside Hooded Fang
column6: the two have betrayed a fondness for heaving hardcore (as Tonkapuma) and day-glo electro-pop (Phédre)
column7: while Lee has flexed some Krautrockin’ funk in his solo Lee Paradise project. Meanwhile
column8: Hooded Fang shed its keyboardists and brass section
column9: and as its line-up got leaner
column10: its sound has become progressively meaner.

column1: Hooded Fang’s fourth album
column2: Venus on Edge
column3: represents the next step in an evolutionary process. The transformation began in earnest with 2011’s Tosta Mista
column4: which scuffed up the band’s formative indie-pop sensibility with a Modern Lovers scrappiness. That aesthetic was pushed deeper into the red with the grotty garage rock of 2013’s Gravez. But Venus on Edge is even more weird and wired
column5: marking the moment where Hooded Fang’s fantastical name ceases to be an ironic counterpoint to the band’s playful fuzz-pop and becomes a guiding principle.

column1: The new record also turns a page on proto-punk completely in favor of weirder turf: industrialized dissonance
column2: sci-fi surf-punk
column3: and tweaked-out guitar frequencies that ring out like a biohazard lab activating the meltdown siren. Lee’s cool
column4: conversational voice melds into the artfully mutated noise swirling around him
column5: as he breaks down his melodies into staccato communiqués.

column1: But as Hooded Fang’s music has grown wilder
column2: their lyrical focus has become more concrete. Venus on Edge is another springtime release from a Toronto act presenting views from the 6
column3: though
column4: as Hooded Fang would tell you
column5: any view view of that city is inevitably obstructed by friggin’ condos. Where Drake invokes Toronto as a visual and thematic backdrop
column6: Hooded Fang treat the city as a target
column7: a place where gentrification
column8: smartphone dependency
column9: and pandering lifestyle marketing have run amok: “Plastic Love” depicts big-business branding as an exercise in Invasion of the Body Snatchers-style mind control
column10: complete with a wonderfully wiggy B-52s-style breakdown; “Glass Shadows” channels the dispiriting feeling of walking among the high-density
column11: high-rise developments that loom ominously over city’s downtown core
column12: with Lee darting around the song’s jabbing riff as if he were trying to avoid the panes of glass that frequently rain down from Toronto’s shoddily built towers.

column1: And while Toronto’s rich multiculturalism is an oft-advertised point of civic pride
column2: Hooded Fang are nonetheless one of the few mixed-race bands in the city’s indie-rock scene
column3: a circumstance that informs Venus on Edge’s most agitated tracks. Where the frantic “Impressions” spins an alien-visitation yarn to highlight the corrosive effects of xenophobia
column4: the pin-pricked
column5: new-waved rave-up “Shallow” sings of unchecked white privilege as a festering disease: “You’re no iconoclast/Blinded all your life by the paleness of your sight/It’s a sickness/You can’t see what’s going on.” The target of the song is unnamed
column6: but it’s not a stretch to assume it’s directed at the band formerly known as Viet Cong
column7: given the instrumental role Aliermo played in mobilizing the protest to get them to change their name.

column1: Over the course of its 10 tracks
column2: Venus on Edge’s warping effects do start to normalize somewhat
column3: like when you stare into a funhouse mirror for an extended period and your eyes get used to the distended shapes. Even as its songs twist into new shapes
column4: the dynamic between the band’s relentless racket and Lee’s casual tone never wavers
column5: to the point where the transformation of the finale “Venus” from deconstructed blues dirge to high-speed sprint feels less dramatic than intended. But
column6: on an album that’s about keeping your cool in the face of mounting frustration
column7: perhaps that resolute stance is just a defense mechanism. With Venus on Edge

column10: inconsiderate
column11: glass-eyed drones. And like all good scary movies
column12:
there’s a plot twist: this one’s actually a documentary.

Remember when Ryan Adams released Heartbreaker and confused diehards wondered what happened to the real Ryan Adams? You know
column2: the lovable fuck-up who made alt-country sound dangerous

column7: bundling it with a bunch of wearable merch (i.e.
column8: ""exclusive 3-inch Heartbreaker patch"") might be more a sly commentary on its supposed “authenticity”—even it still towers over Adams’ solo work

column1: The myth of Heartbreaker as the realest breakup album ever starts to fall apart the minute you press play: it is certainly the saddest record to contain the line
column2: “a mouth full of cookies

column1: More importantly
column2: it’s an argument concerning Morrissey—not Gram Parsons
column3: not Bob Dylan
column4: not Paul Westerberg. The influence of the Smiths would fully manifest on Adams’ Love Is Hell
column5: and the inclusion of a “Hairdresser on Fire Jam” demo in the bonus material here suggests that maybe his maligned bedsit opus has more in common with Heartbreaker than we think. Either way
column6: it’s an important artistic allegiance
column7: linking Adams and Morrissey as the rare artists who can recognize the inherent absurdity in exchanging performative sadness for adoration.

column1: After all
column2: a truly inconsolable song couldn’t possibly be given a title like “To Be Young (Is To Be Sad
column3: Is To Be High).” On it
column4: Adams appears more wise and empathetic than young and sad; note that it’s sung in the past tense. Like so much of Heartbreaker
column5: its focus isn’t misery
column6: but nostalgia—its inclusion during the opening credits of Old School
column7: a comedy suffused with longing for a simple forms of self-destructive behavior
column8: made its flexibility all the more apparent. It’s a song that Adams plays at nearly every one of his shows
column9: not to commiserate with the crowd

column11: ” an open invitation to fondly remember that time when you relied on a fucked-up guy like him to save your life.

column1: The introduction is an outlier
column2: though—would Heartbreaker be held in the same regard if it was just wistful folk-rock like “My Winding Wheel?” Even though “AMY” outright names the supposed inspiration behind Heartbreaker and is the most striking stylistic divergence from Whiskeytown (prior to the experimental Pneumonia)

column6: Heartbreaker is Heartbreaker for the times it allows the listener sees themselves in its own album cover—prostrate
column7: staring at the ceiling
column8: half-hoping that cigarette drops onto their bed so they can feel something different.

column1: Despair alone never accounted for Heartbreaker’s unusual resonance. It isn’t the most dire or confessional account of bad romance; its language is not the most clever. There are all kinds of odd tangents

column4: how to explain the inclusion of the barroom brawl “Shakedown on 9th Street” or the Dylan goof “Damn Sam (I Love a Woman That Rains)?” Even “In My Time of Need” isn’t actually about Ryan Adams’ time of need and certainly inapplicable to a broken relationship between an up-and-coming rock star and a music publicist; it’s pretty much a Whiskeytown-style character study about rural financial distress (“I work these hands to bleed

column1: No
column2: the power of this album
column3: and the reason it reminds its devotees too much of him
column4: or her
column5: or a past version of themselves
column6: can be found in “Come Pick Me Up.” “Come Pick Me Up” is the that ends most of Adams' concerts these days and probably will for the rest of his career. On a basic level
column7: it could slot alongside petulant
column8: scorned-dude screeds like “Song for the Dumped” or Kanye West’s “Heartless;” it is about a woman who seemingly fucked him over. But the most important lyric isn’t the one about this is the kind of person who would steal your records and screw your friends without the slightest remorse. It’s “I wish you would”—the point of “Come Pick Me Up” is not to marvel at this person’s monstrosity and project it outwards. It’s to see yourself in Ryan Adams and remember every single time you’ve allowed yourself to get fucked over and even worse
column9: sought it out.

column1: In every repetition of “I wish you would
column2: ” Adams underlines not just the appeal of <i>Heartbreaker

column4: they make no evolutionary sense: life is hard enough

column6: there’s jokes and asides and times where Heartbreaker rocks

column8: “oh
column9: I just wanna die without you” and it sure as hell sounds like the truth.

column1: Maybe you wanna die. But you didn’t. And that’s OK. Like Morrissey

He recently compared this dissatisfaction with his role in the mainstream with Britney Spears' infamous shaved head incident. If there is a similar meltdown for Skepta it happened in April of 2012

column7: vulnerable

column6: and pirate radio broadcasts. This partly comes from an album roll out and rebranding that has lasted almost two years. Last April

And even earlier than that Drake had cribbed lines from Skepta’s “That’s Not Me” for “Used To” starting a cross-continental musical love affair

column11: even though it's cold.""

column1: ""Only Us"" is a cavernous
column2: Pink Floyd-indebted piano lament for the intimacy the couple once shared

and will endure far longer than mawkish titillation.

There’s a particularly touching moment in a recent FADER profile of the Montreal-based producer Kaytranada. Kay
column2: whose real name is Louis Kevin Celestin
column3: moved from Haiti to Canada with his family when he was an infant
column4: and his father retains a strong sense of national pride. When Kaytranada plays his dad a song from his debut album
column6: the music sparks a rush of patriotic excitement. “Now I understand that he didn’t forget Haiti!” his father exclaims. “You can feel it!”

column1: It’s possible to guess at the characteristics Kay’s father had in mind. Among Haitian music’s distinct features is an insistent focus on complex rhythms
column2: many of them imported from African music and Dominican merengue
column3: as well as a more general willingness to incorporate various countries’ homegrown styles into a cohesive whole. The genre-defying stew of funk
column4: soul
column5: R&B
column6: and beat and dance music that Kaytranada has cooked up on 99.9% nods back at that heritage of percussion-driven synthesis.

column1: Kay first made his name as a Soundcloud standout and dance DJ
column2: but he has the mentality of a musico-archaeologist
column3: digging past yesterday’s obvious pop gems to unearth the overlooked. In its sonic diversity
column4: his album is reminiscent of Madlib’s crate-digging dynamism
column5: but unlike a lot of instrumental hip-hop (or the house artists he’s sometimes grouped with)
column6: Kay’s beats are not at all rigid or predictable. His drums are configured strangely
column7: bending
column8: shifting
column9: doubling back. With those rhythms
column10: and his own custom-made synths
column11: the 23-year-old shows himself to be a strong-willed studio auteur on a mix of instrumental and lyric-based tracks.

column1: Several standout drummers were recruited for the record
column2: including Karriem Riggins and Alexander Sowinski of the Toronto jazz outfit BADBADNOTGOOD
column3: but even the tracks that don’t feature a guest percussionist are studded with polyrhythms. The chillwave synths that kick off the album opener
column4: “Track Uno
column5: ” prop up restless rhythms that morph several times throughout the song. They drive it forward into the Riggins feature “Bus Ride
column6: ” and the momentum never lets up.

column1: Kay’s inventive percussion keeps the album upbeat
column2: but it’s often a dreamy
column3: mellow listen
column4: perhaps a result of the producer’s effort to broaden perceptions of his capabilities. Many of the featured collaborators
column5: including Phonte
column6: Syd
column7: and Anderson .Paak
column8: are hip-hop adjacent artists who have refused to be constrained by the dogmas of the genre
column9: something that seems to have inspired Kay. Syd and Phonte in particular
column10: have helped to define a contemporary
column11: melodic take on funk
column12: combining soul
column13: R&B
column14: and a dash of electronica. Their features
column15: “One Too Many” and “You’re the One
column16: ” on which Kay showcases his love for warmly shimmering synths
column17: are two of the album’s strongest.

column1: Only four of the album’s fifteen tracks do not feature a guest
column2: but even without any company
column3: Kaytranada displays plenty of range. His most impressive solo cut is “Lite Spots
column4: ” a rework of the Brazilian singer Gal Costa’s 1973 track
column5: “Pontos De Luz.” Kay takes advantage of the abrupt shifts in tempo in Costa’s original vocal
column6: assembling a circle of handclaps and other percussive quirks to maximize the song’s potential as a house party special.

column1: Even on his collaborations with more traditional hip-hop and R&B artists
column2: Kaytranada rarely reaches for the radio
column3: avoiding formulaic structures. His track with AlunaGeorge
column4: “Together
column5: ” is almost all hook
column6: with an energized central verse from the D.C. rapper GoldLink. On the Vic Mensa feature
column7: “Drive Me Crazy
column8: ” the outro takes up almost half the track’s running time. It’s long been clear that Kay thinks of vocals as just another musical element
column9: which helps him to make even the most unmemorable guest performances function as dependable instruments. (Also clear: his lack of interest in lyrics
column10: the only generic aspect of <i>99.9%
column11: and the one element that doesn’t bear traces of his close attention.)

column1: There are two other features on 99.9% that should not escape mention. Anderson .Paak’s contribution
column2: “Glowed Up
column3: ” is a two-part suite that make use of the Oxnard artist’s skills as a rapper and a singer respectively
column4: emphasizing just how much Kay can accomplish with a similarly creative collaborator. The other is extra-musical: The album’s cover
column5: painted by the globetrotting Spanish artist Ricardo Cavolo
column6: is warm
column7: colorful and psychedelic
column8: as perfect a match for the record’s sound as any of its tracks. (Cavolo also contributed animated sketches for each track
column9: which can be found on Instagram.)

column1: Kaytranada picked Cavolo out personally
column2: of course
column3: just one more example of his painstaking focus on nearly every detail. Though his credentials are those of an artist who came of age in a digital era
column4: his album is replete with the qualities that we associate with the analogue. It echoes the warm
column5: melodic funk of golden-era Stevie Wonder far more closely than
column6: say
column7: the flatscreen sheen of Drake’s VIEWS
column8: revealing the increasing uselessness of the word “digital” as a descriptor. There’s certainly nothing programmed about Kaytranada’s approach. His record’s name is meant to suggest a certain sense of incompleteness
column9: but it’s one of the most well-edited
column10:
coherent debuts to emerge in recent memory.

When Mark Pritchard first released ""?
column2: that question mark made perfect sense. It was 2009
column3: and the track—six somber minutes of gelatinous
column4: pitch-black drones and a doleful
column5: harpsichord-like synth melody—didn't sound like anything else he had ever done. And that's saying something
column6: because Pritchard has done a lot: Between his time in iconic early-'90s groups like Global Communication
column7: Jedi Knights
column8: and Reload
column9: plus an array of solo aliases including Harmonic 313 and Troubleman
column10: the UK producer made ambient
column11: electro
column12: house
column13: acid
column14: instrumental hip-hop
column15: and broken beat
column16: among other styles and hybrids. Not long after ""?"" appeared as the A-side of a 10"" single (the B-side cut
column17: ""The Hologram
column18: sounded more like a lost Mo Wax instrumental from the mid '90s)
column19: he embarked upon his career's wildly prolific second act
column20: making dancehall
column21: grime
column22: footwork
column25: and throwback rave tunes in the duo Africa Hitech and under his own name. Throughout it all
column26: ""?"" felt like an outlier among outliers; in an oeuvre full of left turns
column27: it was the only one that didn't seemed to have steered him full circle.

column1: Seven years later
column2: that stray puzzle piece falls into place as the opening track on Under the Sun. ""?"" has always had a liminal feel to it—a number of DJs
column3: including the Gaslamp Killer
column4: Manuel Tur
column5: and Oneman
column6: have used it to open mixtapes

column9: Under the Sun is loosely ambient in feel
column10: but it's a world away from the lushly psychedelic chillout-room tropes of Global Communication. Many of its tracks feel like soundtrack cues
column11: and its blippy analog palette often suggests the influence of Delia Derbyshire and the BBC Radiophonic Workshop. There are nods to Boards of Canada
column12: particularly in the vocoded recitation of colors in ""Hi Red
column13: the shortest of a number of sketch-like
column14: interstitial cuts. But the album's most unusual aspect
column15: and its unifying thread
column16: are the thin
column17: quavering synthesizer patches suggestive of flute and clarinet and recorder
column18: which
column19: playing quiet
column20: contrapuntal melodies
column21: imbue the album with an almost medieval air.

column1: Against this atmospheric backdrop
column2: a few key vocal features help give the album its shape and sense of movement. The first
column3: immediately following the ambient intro of ""?
column4: is the Bibio-sung ""Give It Your Choir
column5: which pairs chiming synth parts with richly colored vocal harmonies that whirl like the beads in a kaleidoscope. For much of the warm
column6: woozy ""Beautiful People
column7: Thom Yorke's voice is processed nearly beyond recognition
column8: and even when the effects are stripped away
column9: it sounds like he's singing through clenched teeth
column10: his words reduced to something like pure tone. But the odd phrases that sneak through (""Angels stroke your head
column11: ""I can't go back"") reinforce the song's dream-like logic
column12: forever on the verge of pulling into focus. ""The Blinds Cage"" also bobs on the surface of consciousness
column13: as Anti-Pop Consortium's Beans narrates a stream-of-consciousness report from the border between life and death over a blippy backdrop of electronic abstractions.

column1: In the album's centerpiece
column2: ""You Wash My Soul
column3: the folksinger Linda Perhacs is accompanied by delicately plucked acoustic guitar as she sings mournfully of elemental forces and spiritual connections. At once chilly and pastoral
column4: it's evocative of a strain of gothic folk that stretches back through Jarboe
column5: Current 93
column6: and Nick Drake; it's the polar opposite of ""Infrared
column7: a nervous synth'n'roll number that's reminiscent of Suicide. On paper
column8: the two songs might not seem to have much to do with each other
column9: but part of the beauty of the album is how it pulls such contrasting moods together into a coherent whole.

column1: Deeply atmospheric and richly impressionistic
column2: Under the Sun is an easy album to disappear into. Alternating short sketches with long
column3: immersive tracks like the sumptuously droning ""EMS
column4: and balancing emotional vocal tracks with more abstracted moodpieces
column5: it never feels scattered; instead
column6: each piece leads into the next
column7: like the segments of a maze. I put it on for an hour-long perambulation through the city and found myself cozily cocooned in its folds. I was surprised
column8: when I finally took my headphones off
column9: to be confronted with the lively din of an outdoor café I had been idly watching for 15 minutes; it felt as though I had been zapped back to the heart of the city
column10: transported from a faraway place that was green and warm and ancient. The only question was how music so simple
column11: and almost naïve
column12:
had done such a thorough job of erasing the traces of the modern world around me.

Twin Peaks don’t seem like the sort of guys who would fork out $1
column2: 599 for tickets to the Desert Trip festival. But
column3: given the chance
column4: they’d surely hop the fence. Make all the “Oldchella” cracks you want—there are still a whole lot of young folk who bow before rock ‘n’ roll’s few remaining golden gods
column5: and in three short years
column6: Twin Peaks have proven themselves quick studies in the ways of tradition. In stark defiance of The Who’s “hope I die before I get old” edict
column7: the relaxed
column8: easy-going groove of Down in Heaven suggests this Chicago garage-rock outfit can’t wait to age.

column1: Already
column2: the band seems decades removed from their 2013 debut
column3: Sunken
column4: recorded when they were still teenagers and sounding very much like it—carefree
column5: cocky
column6: and sloppy. The follow-up
column7: 2014’s Wild Onion
column8: tightened up the songcraft
column9: amped up their attack
column10: and spit-shined the production
column11: suggesting aspirations to follow fellow Chi-town miscreants The Orwells down the path of major-label patronage and late-night talk-show appearances. But with Down in Heaven
column12: Twin Peaks have already initiated the rural retreat that most rock bands take only after succumbing to excess
column13: holing themselves up in a friend’s northern Massachusetts studio-house and turning it into a veritable retirement home for early twenty-somethings. The result is a casual
column14: charmingly low-key set of kitchen-table blues
column15: slow-dance serenades
column16: and unplugged power pop. Here
column17: Twin Peaks aren’t so interested in being the life of party as documenting what happens outside of it: the awkward first kisses
column18: the difficult break-up conversations
column19: the sad walks home alone.

column1: It’s a really good look for them. By toning down their sound
column2: Twin Peaks are better able to amplify the sweet/sour tension between honey-voiced vocalists Cadien Lake James and Jack Dolan
column3: and their more acid-tongued compatriot
column4: Clay Frankel. But even as down ‘n’ out diatribes like “Cold Lips” wallow in cruel sentiment (to wit: “you ought to get yourself a shiny gold medal for being the coldest bitch I know”)
column5: Down in Heaven exudes a welcoming
column6: wood-panelled warmth. But Twin Peaks take certain liberties with the past
column7: weaving alternate histories into a sound that’s familiar yet peculiar. Their version of the Stones folds the raw blues of Beggars Banquet into the smooth
column8: falsettoed soul of “Beast of Burden”; their definition of cool is equal parts Lou Reed and Tom Petty. And with the recruitment of keyboardist
column9: Colin Croom
column10: Twin Peaks acquire their own Benmont Tench
column11: swaddling beautifully bruised ballads like “Holding Roses” in soothing Hammond tones or guiding the bouncing-ball rhythm of Dolan’s delightful “Getting Better” with playful piano rolls.

column1: Twin Peaks still flash some swagger between their more sensitive moments
column2: though in these cases
column3: it’s harder to parse their personality from their source material: “Keep It Together” is essentially Big Star’s “Mod Lang” dipped in extra T. Rex glitter
column4: while “Butterfly” loads up on Loaded
column5: copping everything from Lou Reed’s streetwise sneer on “Head Held High” to the “ba ba bas” from “Who Loves the Sun” for good measure. While these songs reinforce a definition of garage-rock steeped in impetuous
column6: middle-fingered attitude
column7: Down in Heaven’s more revelatory slow songs remind us that the genre has always been an outlet for misfit romantics to express feelings they’d be too shy and embarrassed to say in person. In other words
column8: it’s a music for neglected nice guys as much as boisterous bad boys. With Down in Heaven
column9: Twin Peaks come off like a Black Lips that would rather drink apple juice instead of their own piss
column10:
and seem evermore willing to embrace the idea that they’re actually better at kiss-off ballads than kicked-out jams.

The Bacao Rhythm & Steel Band is a pet project of the German instrumental group the Mighty Mocambos
column2: a practiced collective that makes versatile deep funk. Bacao is a vehicle for bandleader and guitarist Björn Wagner's dedicated enchantment with the steelpan drum
column3: which he and three other band members play on a new debut full-length called 55.

column1: Steelpan drums are traditionally hammered out of 55-gallon oil barrels and inextricably linked to Trinidad
column2: where they were invented in the 1930s
column3: borne into the island’s calypso and soca music traditions
column4: and have since been co-opted around the world. The metallic ping a pan makes is entirely unique for an acoustic instrument. With a series of soft strikes
column5: players can conjure a swelling
column6: fluttering effect; with stronger contact a pan rattles. More generally
column7: the sustained notes obscure the player’s attack
column8: as if the sound floated into earshot from a faraway place instead of bursting from an acute mallet strike. Conversely
column9: it’s almost impossible to achieve the sharp briefness of a staccato. It’s a deceptively sensitive piece of metal that is easy to make loud but finicky to get right.

column1: Wagner spent time learning the instrument and commissioning a handmade pan for himself while in Trinidad and Tobago
column2: and Bacao released its first two songs—a pair of Meters covers—in 2007. By the following year
column3: the group had grown more playful with its covers
column4: releasing a stunning instrumental take on 50 Cent’s “P.I.M.P.” that sounds unmistakably like the steelpan riff at the heart of the rapper's original
column5: now with the added appeal of a Caribbean groove and the kind of swampy horn solo expected of a Latin jazz burner.

column1: About half the songs on 55 are covers
column2: all of which are immediately endearing. Since its invention and because of its timbral distinction
column3: the steelpan has long been an instrument used for unexpected covers of popular songs. 55
column4: which places previous singles alongside new tracks
column5: sidesteps pure novelty factor in that the band is an impeccably tight funk outfit to begin with
column6: and the pan is folded in as seasoning. Given that Wagner and his bandmates are recent converts
column7: none of the pan playing on 55 is flashily virtuosic
column8: but they’re deft and restrained use of the instrument—in this case both a single tenor steelpan as well as the lower registered double second pan—is nonetheless the album’s obvious calling card.

column1: “Dog Was a Doughnut
column2: ” a delightful rework of Cat Steven’s shifty electronic original
column3: is one of the album’s most sparsely arranged
column4: the pan walking in awkward step with the rest of the percussion instead of standing out front. Bacao is prone to crisp mid-song breaks that frequently center percussive elements like a cowbell as much as a drum kit
column5: but the group has the impressive coordination to move as one as well. The guitar is sometimes tucked into the groove as a jangling or ticking rhythmic element
column6: but on tracks like “Queen of Cheeba
column7: ” a constant guitar riff becomes the woozy centerpiece of a psychedelic-tinged Latin jam. Originally a 1980s political anthem from John Holt about marijuana in Jamaica
column8: “Police in Helicopter"" digs into heavy psychedelic reggae territory instead. “Scorpio
column9: ” an oft-sampled legendary breakbeat track from Dennis Coffey
column10: gets a true-to-form but sped-up rendition here that trades the famously overdubbed guitar motif for the sound of the featured instrument. As a groove-forward band
column11: Bacao are shape-shifters in the best sense.

column1: As the “P.I.M.P.” rendition suggests
column2: Bacao are also molded by hip-hop. On “Round & Round
column3: ” they flip the smoothness of Hi-Tek’s wondrous original beat into a lazy shuffle
column4: the pan clunkily plucking out the catchy refrain while the guitar creeps alongside. It’s “Love Like This
column5: ” a slinky cover of Faith Evans’ Grammy-nominated Bad Boy-era R&B hit
column6: that takes the cake
column7: accomplishing the rare intersection of unexpected and obvious. Like much of the album
column8: “Love Like This
column9: ” which carries a cleaner bassline than the sampled original
column10: is built by the heavy lifting of the traditional rhythm core; the pan then drives it home. The album’s original compositions are mostly impressive themselves: “Bacao Suave” is a horn-heavy
column11: Latin-tinged jam
column12: while “Port of Spain Hustle” offers up the slick-moving rhythm guitar and stabbing horn runs of a disco classic.

column1: Even though the songs themselves are short
column2: at 16 tracks
column3: 55 runs a touch too long
column4: and some of the band’s early standout singles are sorely missing. Still
column5:
steelpan homages this delightfully listenable and yet devoid of schtick deserve credit. Bacao is a fantastic funk band first and foremost—the pan just adds some well-earned panache.

The experimental band Negativland introduced the concept of “culture jamming” to the world in 1984
column3: defining it as “an awareness of how the media environment we occupy affects and directs our inner life.” They coined the term largely as a cynical reaction to America’s commercial monuments: billboards
column4: logos
column5: fashion trends and the like
column6: but the phrase’s subtext isn’t as nihilistic as it may seem. By defining the phrase
column7: Negativland and their peers legitimized it as a tool to deface and expose the dark side of capitalism
column8: inviting artists to punch back through graffiti
column9: guerrilla radio
column10: fliers
column11: and other media. With the advent of Internet and social media
column12: culture jamming’s grown more ubiquitous than ever. (As a matter of fact
column13: the word “meme” also refers to the imagery that jammers disseminate en masse.) Just like graffiti
column14: Dat Boi
column15: Boaty McBoatface
column16: and Make America Great Again hats disrupt our global communication systems and incite reactions ranging from befuddled amusement to anger
column17: fear
column18: and dejection.

column1: Zach Hill
column2: Andy Morin
column3: and Stefan Burnett (otherwise known as MC Ride) are easily the most talented
column4: impactful culture jammers of the streaming age: a distinction primarily owed to just how seriously the California trio take those ideas. Never mind the Trojan Horse they pulled on Epic

column6: the no-shows—the real subversion’s in Death Grips' music
column7: which continues to draw huge audiences (see: the massive crowd who filled the Gobi tent for their headlining Coachella set) and unsurprisingly
column8: co-signs from fellow pranksters like Tyler
column9: the Creator and Eric André. It’s no surprise that the loudest contingency of their fanbase resides on an infamous image-board; Death Grips speak directly to the dark worldview that accompanies years wasted lurking online
column10: getting high off digital schadenfreude. (Been there.)

column1: On their new album Bottomless Pit
column2: they stitch together one of their most cohesive grotesques ever
column3: renewing their focus on songcraft
column4: rather than chicanery. It's sure to elicit a sigh of relief among fans who’ve grown jaded with the band’s work. Opening track “Giving Bad People Good Ideas"" opens on a feint—an eerie
column5: descending vocal from Cherry Glazerr vocalist Clementine Creevy
column6: the feminine foil to macho
column7: malicious Burnett. The lilting intro gives way to a black-metal sprint
column8: with Tera Melos’ Nick Reinhart churning out jagged tremolo riffs. The follow-up blow carries that momentum further: “Hot Head” starts off inside a cartoon fight cloud spinning off towards oblivion
column9: a blur of percussive jabs
column10: whooshing machines
column11: and screamed gibberish. From there
column12: the song takes an equally disorienting nose-dive into a slack
column13: spacious verse.

column1: Death Grips draw heavily on abrasive styles
column2: but the group are arguably at their most lethal when they're hijacking popular tastes
column3: as they did on 2012’s<i> The Money Store
column4: and as they do here. With their stacked guitar riffs
column5: dissonant samples
column6: and glitchy percussion
column7: “Spikes” and “Three Bedrooms In A Good Neighborhood” invoke an alternate history where hip-hop and metal fusion didn't dead-end into visions of Fred Durst’s punchable mug. The EBM-flavored “80808” supercharges a house-y backbeat with additional crackles and pops; the choruses expand that texture
column8: dialing up the voltage until the synths alight in an arc flash. The most straightforward of these standouts is “Eh
column9: ” a rap song anchored in glimmering
column10: burbling synths that dart in and out of the bass drums’ margins. Unmoved by the giddy surroundings
column11: Burnett deadpans his morbid imagery with unusual calm
column12: as if a tranquilizer dart struck him mid-verse: “Catch me hanging from my noose like ehhhh
column13: ” he yawns
column14: stretching out the final syllable like putty.

column1: MC Ride has long been regarded as Death Grips’ anchor
column2: both onstage and off: a privilege largely owed to a pair of vocal cords which never seem to tire
column3: even as the man screams himself sick. On Bottomless Pit he offers his most athletic performance to date
column4: double-dutching over fallen power on “80808
column5: ” bobbing and weaving over Krautrock shards on “Ring A Bell
column6: ” and howling out in agony as the machines draw and quarter him on “Warping.” It’s not all gloom-and-doom
column7: however; “Bubbles Buried in this Jungle” and “Trash"" showcase a seething monotone delivery that taps into the absurd

column10: a hairstyle?/This asshole be at pussy church

column1: For all its chaos and fury
column2: Bottomless Pit is Death Grips' most accessible record since The Money Store. It has a distractingly uneven mix

column9:
you will probably grin wider than you have through any Death Grips album in years.

Emerging in the mid-'70's
column2: Jean-Michel Jarre was part of wave of musicians that were incorporating synthesizers
column3: tape loops and state-of-the-art effects systems into pop-leaning forms. Unlike his mentor Pierre Schaeffer and his peers in the avant-garde and academic communities
column4: Jarre married sweet
column5: hummable melodies and traditional European harmonies to star-gazing soundscapes
column6: making electronics seem safe and inviting to the masses. To some
column7: this was tantamount to treason; one of electronic music's first manifestos
column8: written by Luigi Russolo in 1913
column9: demanded composers “break at all costs from this restrictive circle of pure sounds and conquer the infinite variety of noise-sounds.” For those not interested in modernist treatises and radical new forms
column10: however
column11: Jarre was the sound of the future.

column1: Without doubt
column2: Jarre was on the right side of history. In addition to album sales well into the millions
column3: in 1979 he broke the world's record for concert attendance
column4: bringing 1
column6: 000 people to Paris' Place de la Concorde (he went on to break that record three more times). Yet in many ways his influence pales in comparison to his sales; his sheen is futuristic but his music looks fondly to the past. Though titled Electronica 2: The Heart of Noise
column7: Jarre's latest album is anything but an exploration of the genre's roots in the radical manipulations of raw sound and analogue circuitry. Rather
column8: it's an overstuffed
column9: overlong string of collaborations that smothers Jarre's nimble melodicism under heaving EDM production and spooks his guests into cliches of themselves
column10: or worse.

column1: And what a series of guests. The Pet Shop Boys
column2: Yello
column3: and Gary Numan are all here
column4: as well as Cyndi Lauper
column5: ambient pioneers the Orb and pop shapeshifters Primal Scream. In their heyday
column6: each of these artists had an unmistakable sound signature (except perhaps Primal Scream
column7: who made a career out of reinvention)
column8: yet on Electronica 2 they are bulldozed by Jarre's production. There are flashes of recognition
column9: such as the gospel choir on Primal Scream collab “As One
column10: ” an obvious nod to “Come Together.” More often though
column11: Jarre appears resolutely in the driver's seat. For the previous installation<i>
column12: Electronica 1:The Time Machine
column13: he said he tailored each song as a demo with the specific collaborator in mind
column14: to be fleshed out or rewritten together in the studio later. If that's true here
column15: it's hard to tell.

column1: <div>
Jarre's decades on stadium stages may have something to do with the broader-than-broad strokes employed throughout the album. His preference is for slow
column2: bombastic tempos and questing
column3: classically-leaning chord progressions
column4: and he runs this formula into the ground. The arrangements
column5: heavily layered and sound-designed
column6: telegraph an up-to-the-minute sheen yet lack a timeless quality. Sadly the effect carries over to the singers' performances; Lauper attempts an Ellie Goulding impression on “Swipe to the Right.” Numan
column7: once both campy and sleek
column8: is a bogged-down wannabe pop messiah on “Here for You.” The Pet Shop Boys fare a little better on “Brick England”—they simply sound like a boring version of themselves. Yello are meanwhile unrecognizable on the aptly titled existential dirge “Why This
column9: Why That and Why.”

column1: Other collaborations promise to push Jarre a bit out of his comfort zone
column2: yet you feel him fussing. The presence of Jeff Mills suggests that Jarre might be game for a descent into a techno wormhole. Though “The Architect” eventually speeds up to a danceable clip and features traces of the claustrophobic minimalism that Mills perfected in his younger years
column3: it also foregrounds string flourishes worthy of a James Bond opening sequence. The structure
column4: too
column5: is a mess
column6: scrolling through breakdowns
column7: sequences and buildups that have little relation to each other.

column1: Intriguingly
column2: the brief presence of NSA whistleblower and non-musician Edward Snowden on “Exit” yields the liveliest results. Jarre described the track as “trying to illustrate the idea of this crazy quest for big data on one side and the manhunt for this one young guy by the CIA
column3: NSA and FBI on the other
column4: ” and “Exit” could certainly soundtrack a frenetic chase scene. Mid-song
column5: the music slows to a halt and Snowden gets on the mic: “Technology can actually increase privacy... Saying that you don't care about the right to privacy because you have nothing to hide is no different than saying you don't care about freedom of speech because you have nothing to say... And if you don't stand up for it
column6: then who will?” Jarre grabs that last phrase and loops it as he builds to a rushing climax. It's grandiose
column7: cheesy and sounds like any generic rave scene in a movie
column8: but coming halfway through Electronica 2's slog
column9: it's a high point.

column1: Closing with a pair of solo expeditions
column2: one strangely credited “with JMJ himself
column3: ” the lasting impression isn't of a journey to the heart of noise
column4: but rather of a blustery loneliness. Jarre recorded his breakthrough 1976 album Oxygene in his kitchen on a rudimentary setup; now he's has assembled a collection of his ""heroes"" and been given access to the finest studios in the world and yet repeatedly fails to engage the imagination. One senses a massively missed opportunity
column5: a chance for exploration blown by Jarre's insatiable need to make everything bigger
column6: more impressive. Perhaps Yello caught a glimpse of this while working on their lyrics: “trying to dig out the man that I could be
column7:
and I was shouting loud to find there's little me. ”

Though he’s been making music since the mid-’90s
column2: Peter Rehberg is still a bit of a cult figure. It’s not too hard to understand why. A pioneer of laptop-based music that was at turns abrasive and sublime
column3: the Austrian producer’s early records could be a bit intimidating
column4: even alongside the work of experimental-minded peers like Jim O’Rourke
column5: Fennesz
column6: and Kevin Drumm. And it also doesn’t help that the last album released under his most prolific alias
column7: Pita
column8: came out more than a decade ago. Yet
column9: it’s hard to think of anybody whose work—both as an artist and a label owner—has remained more deeply embedded in the DNA of contemporary electronic and out-there music.

column1: Founded in the mid-'90s
column2: Rehberg’s label
column3: Mego
column4: released computer music that defied classification
column5: existing outside of terms like “dance” or “ambient.” The label’s most enduring releases – Fennesz’s Endless Summer
column6: O’Rourke’s I’m Happy and I’m Singing
column7: Drumm’s Sheer Hellish Miasma – made digitally mulched sounds register as dense and organic. That label’s Rehberg-run successor
column8: Editions Mego
column9: has proven equally influential
column10: releasing records that helped establish American Kosmiche nobility like Emeralds
column11: Oneohtrix Point Never
column12: and Keith Fullerton Whitman. And that’s not even counting Editions Mego’s multitude of artist-curated sub-labels
column13: which include Spectrum Spools (Emeralds’ John Elliott)
column14: Recollection GRM (curated by François Bonnet and Daniel Teruggi)
column15: Ideologic Organ (Stephen O'Malley)
column16: and Old News (Jim O’Rourke). You can also hear traces of Rehberg’s gritty sound design in releases on edgier contemporary dance labels like Trilogy Tapes and PAN. He even beat Matmos to the household appliance thing by two decades.

column1: Get In is Rehberg’s first release as Pita since 2004’s Get Off and it picks up more or less where its predecessor left off. The sound design is cleaner and richer in detail
column2: but the same rules apply. It is a record defined by not-so-subtle shifts in volume and intensity. Serene drones give way to rubbery atonal squelch. Familiar tones are dissected and decimated. On “S200729” the burble of a TB-303 bassline – the defining sound of acid house – is digitally deconstructed from a warm analog burble into the kind of sound that could bust up asphalt.

column1: Attitude was a key to Pita’s first records: They were loud and rude. The music might lull you into a false sense of security only to turn around and fry your eardrums. However
column2: Get In is more gripping in its meditative moments. On “Line Angel” glimmering keyboard tones are periodically interrupted and skewed out of tune
column3: dive-bombing from soothing to seasick. “Mfbk” is more earnest
column4: ascending in volume to reveal generative melodies and cello-like tones that evoke Brian Eno’s Discreet Music. If you’re a long-time Pita listener
column5: you might keep the volume low
column6: just in case a shocking blast of fuzz is imminent. The punishment never comes
column7: though.

column1: The tools that are used in its creation define so much about electronic music – it’s utility
column2: it’s time and place. Rehberg’s process has always been a bit mysterious
column3: though. It’s the product of a set of programs
column4: rather than a table full of boxes and knobs. In concert
column5: the back of a laptop screen obscures his moves
column6: and it’s harder to date his records as a result. Get In was recorded last year
column7: but it sounds like it could have been made at any time over the intervening decade. There are no melodic clichés to give it away and no organized rhythms. The sounds are proto-human
column8:
primeval and timeless.

Seratones would be just another pretty-good-not-great rock band without frontwoman AJ Haynes' powerful voice leading the charge. Their first LP
column2: <i>Get Gone
column3: brandishes playful guitar hooks that swing in at just the right moments
column4: but Haynes is the band’s best asset
column5: lighting these otherwise-conventional songs on fire.

column1: In their mix of soulful grease and punky grit
column2: Seratones feel like a natural
column3: rollicking complement to The Alabama Shakes
column4: but it’s not quite fair to call them a ripoff. Where the Shakes go for the groovy soul of Muscle Shoals
column5: Seratones instead veer toward swinging Southern garage rock. Get Gone’s guitars crackle with the heat of the band’s native Louisiana. In his earliest days as a Squirrel Nut Zipper
column6: Get Gone producer Jimbo Mathus specialized in fast-and-loose tunes that sounded like they might fly apart at any moment
column7: an energy the Seratones often capture well (though some extra occasional grit wouldn’t hurt
column8: either).

column1: Haynes attributes her vocal prowess to learning to sing in a church choir from a young age
column2: and she shows off her quivering high notes right away on opener “Choking On Your Spit
column3: ” balancing it neatly with a sneer at the song's recipient. When she belts that she’s seen the light “Don’t Need It
column4: ” you believe it. She slinks a little lower on the more blues-inclined title track before cutting in with sharp
column5: cathartic “Ooh-ooh!”s for the song’s chorus.

column1: The band is at is best when it’s playing fast and tight
column2: as with the bright
column3: soaring “Sun.” They lose momentum on the drifting “Tide” early in the record before picking up with the punchier “Chandelier
column4: ” and closing track “Keep Me” is pretty
column5: but it feels like a sleepy
column6: anticlimactic close to a record that otherwise vibrates with energy. “Kingdom Come” begins with an impatient patter before dipping into chugging guitar riffs
column7: combining for a track that oozes anticipation.

column1: Haynes' charisma is palpable through almost every song—even the giggles that bubble up on “Kingdom Come” inject the record with a genuine joy. She ends that song with the line
column2: “I’ll be your best
column3: believe me
column4:
” delivering the last two words like a slow punch to the gut. She does so much work on Get Gone that you wind up hoping she follows through on her promise.

Radiohead
column2: who titled their ninth studio album<i> A Moon Shaped Pool
column3: have a unique grasp on how easily profundity can slip into banality. Their music is obsessed with the point where great truths harden into platitudes
column4: where pure signal meets wretched noise. In the past
column5: Thom Yorke has sharply peppered his lyrics with everyday cliches to suggest a mind consumed by meaningless data
column6: but on the new album
column7: he largely moves beyond cynicism. He is now considering simpler truths in a heretofore-unexplored register: wonder and amazement. “This goes beyond me
column8: beyond you
column9: ” he sings on “Daydreaming.” “We are just happy to serve you.” There is no concealed razor under Yorke’s tongue as he offers this thought
column10: or in the pearly music that surrounds him. It sounds for all the world like the most cloistered and isolated soul in modern rock music opening up and admitting a helplessness far more personal than he’s ever dared. Yorke has flirted with surrender before
column11: and on A Moon Shaped Pool
column12: that submission feels nearly complete.

column1: The album is framed by two older pieces of music that act as gateways to the darker
column2: unfamiliar waters within. Opener “Burn the Witch” has been floating around
column3: in some form or another
column4: since Kid A. “This is a low-flying panic attack
column5: ” Yorke announces
column6: explicitly linking to the bad old days of air crashes
column7: iron lungs
column8: and wolves at doors. (In fact
column9: several of the song’s lyrics—“avoid all eye contact
column10: ” “cheer at the gallows”—first appeared in the album art to 2003’s anti-Bush polemic Hail to the Thief.) Meanwhile
column11: Jonny Greenwood’s brittle modernist string arrangement reinforces the angst
column12: turning the orchestra into a giant pair of gnashing teeth. It’s a vintage splash of Radiohead stomach acid
column13: a cloud of gnats unleashed in your cranial nerves.

column1: It also feels like an exorcism for what follows: a plunge into something scarier than the military industrial complex
column2: or the insidious nature of propaganda
column3: or human nature’s disturbing tendency towards unquestioning obedience. Yorke separated from his partner of 23 years and the mother to his two children last August
column4: and on “Identikit
column5: ” he sings “Broken hearts make it rain” and “When I see you messin’ me around
column6: I don’t want to know.”

column1: That isn’t to say that this is necessarily a “break-up album.” Separations (particularly those involving children) take place in the harsh light of day
column2: with lawyers’ appointments and checklists and logistical arrangements. Radiohead albums are the stuff of dreams and nightmares
column3: and the band retains a healthy resistance to clarity; their music is a maze of signs you can peer into any way you like. Even so
column4: the impact of trauma
column5: a sort of car crash of the soul
column6: is palpable. The music here feels loose and unknotted
column7: broken open in the way you can only be after a tragedy. “There’s a spacecraft blocking out the sky
column8: ” Yorke observes on “Decks Dark
column9: ” as choral voices pass overhead. The scene is straight from 1997’s “Subterranean Homesick Alien
column10: ” but here Yorke doesn’t sound “uptight.” He sounds utterly drained
column11: as if impending invasion doesn’t concern him at all.

column1: A song title like “Glass Eyes” hints at many of the band’s longstanding morbid preoccupations—the semblance of humanity in something cold and dead
column2: or the violation of the biological body by foreign objects—but the song is a bloodflow of strings straight into the heart. “Hey it’s me
column3: I just got off the train
column4: ” Yorke sings
column5: and it’s a strikingly ordinary image: the Paranoid Android himself
column6: picking up the phone and calling someone to tell them he’s just arrived. “I feel this love turn cold
column7: ” he confesses as the ballad draws to a close
column8: the phrasing an echo
column9: subconscious or not
column10: of his Kid A sign-off “I’ll see you in the next life.” A throbbing cello appears like a lump in the throat; the song fades away.

column1: Throughout the album
column2: Yorke’s everyday enlightenment is backed by music of expanse and abandon. The guitars sound like pianos
column3: the pianos sound like guitars
column4: and the mixes breathe with pastoral calm. “The Numbers
column5: ” a song about the impending apocalypse brought on by climate change
column6: meanders along
column7: its groove as wide as an ocean. Even the malevolent synth wave that passes through “Ful Stop” sounds like a visitor
column8: a momentary darkness rather than a caged spirit. As the song builds
column9: the band works up a coursing groove that will feel familiar to longtime fans
column10: with its interlocking guitars and an arterial bustle of rhythms serving to launch Yorke’s wordless moan. It’s a sound that Radiohead has spent the last decade honing
column11: but the payoff here is deeper and more gratifying than it has been in a while.

column1: The added dimension comes from Yorke
column2: who pumps fresh oxygen into these songs
column3: many of which have existed in sketch-like forms for years. On the lonely folk hymn “Desert Island Disk
column4: ” he sings of an epiphanic experience: “The wind rushing ‘round my open heart/An open ravine/In my spirit white.” As a vision of transformation
column5: it feels like the inverse to Amnesiac’s “Pyramid Song
column6: ” where his only companions were the dead; here
column7: he is “totally alive.”

column1: And then there’s “True Love Waits.” It’s an old song
column2: one that has been around in various forms for over two decades
column3: but unlike “Burn the Witch” or the other teased sketches and scraps that Radiohead diehards pick apart on forums
column4: it’s long been a part of their canon. It appeared on the 2001 live album I Might Be Wrong and
column5: dragged into 2016
column6: feels like a relic from a different geological era. “I’ll drown my beliefs
column7: ” Yorke sings
column8: “just don’t leave.” It is the message they leave us with
column9: this very open-hearted song that has always felt like an open wound in their discography
column10: a geyser of feeling erupting out of scorched earth. Its very inclusion is a striking moment of transparency.

column1: The version here is just Yorke and a piano
column2: so reverberant and echo-drenched that it feels like we’ve stuck our heads inside it. Yorke croons tenderly
column3: never opening up into his chest voice. It’s sung to one person this time
column4: not crowds. In its mundane visions of “lollipops and crisps
column5: ” the lyrics purposefully skirt doggerel
column6: an acknowledgment that cliches can be
column7: in fact
column8: where all the action is. “I’m not living/I’m just killing time
column9: ” the 47-year-old admits. You can write a line like that and set it to music; you can perform it for years in front of adoring millions; you can carry the idea around in your heart and mind. But it might take a lifetime for it to strike
column10: as it does here
column11: with a newfound power. The truth
column12: as always
column13: lies in plain sight
column14: right there in the kicking and the squealing
column15:
the panic and the vomit. Some truths just take longer to see than others.

column2: then 21

column1: Unsurprisingly

column3: he’s uninterested in anyone’s approval. That mix could herald disaster

column9: imbued with waves of reverb and gothic flourishes that meet its frontman’s astronomical intensity. ""Lost Under Heaven

column7: and slow
column8: sunrise synths: ""I’m so bored of this reality/Of fearful men trying to limit me
column9: she sings
column10: poised between despondence and third-act redemption. On ""Lament
column11: the update of ""Kerou’s Lament
column12: Hoorn concedes

“What to Keep and What to Throw Away

column6: Sturgill Simpson

column2: raw production is a welcome change of pace for Carpenter

column4: lonely late night drive. Like many long drives
column5: however

column7:
and leaving the rest behind.

It’s not James Blake’s fault that The Colour in Anything came out in the middle of a rainy week. Or it might be; the circumstances seem almost planned. Maybe the team plotting the surprise release of this album was watching storm fronts
column3: waiting for ideal new-James-Blake-album conditions. On first impressions alone
column4: they succeeded wildly: When bed sheets are in disarray
column5: when grey light seeps into wet windows
column6: and the sky is an interminable reminder that there is always a chance of showers

column8: it doesn't matter

column1: In keeping with his last two albums
column2: The Colour in Anything is a hard
column3: frank
column4: and unsparing listen. But if you listen closer
column5: you will notice some tonal shifts in the fog. For one
column6: Blake shed the monomania of his past work
column7: allowing other voices and sounds to creep in. He’s noted in interviews that The Colour in Anything is meant to represent a sea-change
column8: personally
column9: musically
column10: and geographically. The disposition of this record is suppose to reflect its milieus: Southern California
column11: friendship
column12: and new love. Seven of its 17 tracks were co-produced by Rick Rubin. Much of the album was also mixed and mastered at Rubin’s Shangri-La studios in Malibu. Frank Ocean and Justin Vernon appear throughout
column13: lending writing and production help. There’s also Connan Mockasin
column14: who appears
column15: bass in hand
column16: for a song. James has stepped out of his London bedroom and invited collaboration at an unprecedented level. Clocking in at 76 minutes
column17: The Colour in Anything is Blake’s wonderfully messy dive into maximalism.

column1: All that said
column2: in the best way possible
column3: in no way shape or form is The Colour in Anything a rapid departure or reversal of what Blake does well. He still paints in deep blues and greys. His production is still unparalleled
column4: spacious
column5: and impossibly textured. His voice is still chilly and metallic
column6: but maintains all its choir boy charm. His music is still towering and menacingly sad. He sings almost exclusively about lost love (“While you were away
column7: I started loving you”)
column8: miscommunication (“I’m sorry I don’t know how you feel”)
column9: miasma (“I hope my life is no sign of the times”)
column10: and defeat (“I want it to be over”). It can be brutal to hear the microscopic variations of themes hammered over and over again
column11: making the album’s pace something between apocalyptic and glacial. Each listen is draining in its way
column12: and when it's over it feels like decades have passed. It can be so self-indulgent and extravagantly sad that it comes close to ruin porn. But it’s worth it. And there are positive messages to eke out of the experience
column13: vitally important ones; that it's all right to be hurt
column14: or alone
column15: that heartbreak helps fuel the flow of life.

column1: As contemporary electronic music moves towards more caustic
column2: crunchy
column3: and self-referential tropes
column4: Blake's music is almost resolutely old fashioned. It deploys auto-tune
column5: expressive (bordering on Platonic) percussion
column6: minimalist pianos
column7: and throwback sub-bass warble and womps. He distills his influences of R&B
column8: gospel
column9: and the wide patina of British dance music in such strange and ineffable concoctions that it makes it difficult to not rewind certain chunks of drum breakdowns and airy synths continually. The melancholic funk of “I Hope My Life (1-800 Mix)” or the dive bomb synth swoops of “Radio Silence” show Blake’s ability to orchestrate moments that mimic the stark romantic bombast of a Caspar David Friedrich painting.

column1: Yet ironically Blake’s own grasp of lyric writing is still immature. He is never clever
column2: catchy
column3: or subtle. If anything he can even be comically melodramatic (“Where is my beautiful life?”) or annoyingly whiny (“I can’t believe that you don’t want to see me”). It makes it so that you wish he would just hum and slur his words into indistinct hunks of emotion. There are also several missteps in how his voice is treated throughout the record. A high pitched vocal processing in “My Willing Heart” is nearly unlistenable. Guest Bon Iver's “hooooo” at the start of “I Need a Forest Fire” is laughable in its wimpy approximation of bravado.

column1: But these flubs are all forgivable. For the most part his singing can be vertiginous
column2: isolating

column5: Blake approaches the sublime. He may never be able to reproduce the discomfiting beauty of his cover of “A Case of You” but he can still yoke tears from dry eyes in vulnerable songs like “F.O.R.E.V.E.R.” or the album’s title track. In closer ""Meet You in the Maze

column10: and acceptance. After the probing self-consciousness that preceded it
column11: these five minutes of fragility feel healing. “It's me who makes the peace in me...Music can't be everything

column14: its goals are actually quite modest. At the end of the day Blake just wants to prioritize happiness and self-knowledge above all else. It’s a thoroughly unhip statement that makes you believe smiling
column15: even if it hurts
column16:
is the coolest possible thing in the world you can do.

Andrew Broder has held a lot of jobs over the course of his career: turntablist
column2: indie-rock frontman
column3: beatmaker
column4: ambient musician. More recently
column5: he’s been working as a handyman and commercial painter in his native Minneapolis. Following the release of 2007’s Ditherer
column6: Broder stepped away from the Fog moniker for nearly a decade
column7: though he continued to dabble in various side-projects and solo endeavors. With the benefit of distance
column8: Broder is now looking back at his itinerant career

column1: Still
column2: a lot has changed since 2007
column3: not the least of which is Broder himself. On For Good
column4: his vocals are more confident
column5: his darkly impressionistic lyrics sharper
column6: his piano playing playing delicate yet assured. Stepping back from the full-band arrangements of Ditherer

column3: with its clattering percussion

column2: though
column3: Broder is as uncompromising as he’s ever been. The record’s midsection is both bleak and sonically confrontational—here Broder lets his experimental side run wild within the constraints of a pop song. ""Cory"" is a claustrophobic nightmare: all oppressive low-end
column4: machine-gun drums and submerged
column5: chopped-up vocals as percussion. ""Crime was always there for you/Crime was always there for me
column6: Broder sings during one of the song’s few bright spots. ""Jim"" is driven by a breakbeat that whirrs to life like some terrifying machine: it sounds like the sort of thing Amon Tobin and Scott Walker might cook up together in an abandoned factory full of old industrial equipment. ""Trying"" is a sample-based hip-hop instrumental trapped under a heavy cloak of foreboding

column6: closing with the lines ""Father popcorn/Father popcorn/Make the popcorn."" Musically
column7: it’s one of the most skeletal songs of Broder’s career

column11: around the final notes of each bar. Despite its nearly seven minute runtime
column12: the song is consistently engaging throughout

column1: If there’s a surprise to be found on For Good

column8: melancholic indie-pop that slots in nicely next to acts like Sparklehorse

column10: and Radiohead. That’s hardly a bad thing

the point of an experiment is to arrive at an answer. Andrew Broder seems to have finally found some.

column12: the reverb around her voice suggests physical space rather than infinity; it's just one of the ways that Will scans as humble and homespun in comparison to Nepenthe's effortless opulence.

column1: Beyond voice and natural reverb
column2: the most frequently used instruments are reedy
column3: inexpensive-sounding synthesizers and watery piano
column4: the kind you might encounter at a distant relative's beach house—its strings gone faintly out of tune over the long
column5: boarded-up winter. Melodies often feel like they're folding back in upon themselves: Her piano playing ruminates on repeated sequences
column6: lingering on the same few notes and small
column7: simple chords. On ""Wist
column8: heavy reverb pulls at her descending lines
column9: blurring her words and tugging them back into the folds of the earth. You can tell that there are words in many of these songs

column11: windswept vistas: ""Same

column1: Between the piano and the omnipresent hush
column2: the record that Will most resembles is probably Grouper's Ruins (which
column3: coincidentally
column4: was also recorded in Portugal; the effects of saudade upon visiting musicians are apparently very real). But where Grouper's album was isolationist to the extreme
column5: Barwick's never stops letting in the wider world. The swirling synthesizer loop of ""Nebula
column6: almost indistinguishable from a humming voice
column7: recalls the gracefully spinning arpeggios of Meredith Monk's Book of Days; the simplicity of ""Big Hollow"" suggests Low at their most demure; the weightless ecstasy of ""Same"" fires up the same pain-and-pleasure centers as This Mortal Coil's version of ""Song to the Siren."" And something about the melody and atmosphere of ""Wist"" even brings to mind Swans' ethereal ""Blackmail
column8: as though heard resonating through a cistern. It's not that Barwick is imitating these songs
column9: but it's impossible to shake the sense that she is picking up on fragments of a greater melody
column10: a harmonic continuum
column11: a song that belongs to all of us. Will may at first seem small
column12: private
column13: and modestly appointed—just a room with a piano
column14: a synthesizer
column15: and a looping pedal—but once you settle in
column16:
it feels as vast as the universe in there.

When Roberto Lange performs as Helado Negro
column2: there's not a lot to watch. He's an engaging singer and performer
column3: but aside from the occasional knob tweak
column4: his backing tracks stream from his laptop and assorted electronic gizmos with little intervention. Where another electronic musician might overcompensate with garish videos
column5: Lange has come up with a curious
column6: low-key solution that is a perfect fit for his curious
column7: low-key music: He's flanked onstage by three figures who don't do much more than sway back and forth
column8: ever so gently

column11: reflecting the light like disco balls run through a shredder.

column1: Those mute
column2: cryptic figures make an appearance on Island Universe Story: Selected Works: Bits of their tinsel are mixed right into the clear vinyl on which the records are pressed. I like to think of the sparkly strands a little like religious relics

column1: Invisibility has always been of special interest to Lange

column3: in Spanish and English

column9: with a deep-diving vocoder melody that recalls Basic Channel's underwater dub. ""Enfocando"" (""Focusing"")
column10: which follows
column11: is another standout
column12: with an odd collection of sounds—harpsichord-like synth melody
column13: reggae-inspired guitar backbeat
column14: jaunty whistling—that he rolls around like a palmful of jewel-toned baubles. ""Enfocando
column15: he sings
column16: over and over
column17: in his throaty almost-whisper
column18: allowing each contrapuntal strand to zoom briefly into focus.

column1: One of the stumbling blocks on Helado Negro's last two albums has been their relatively uniform palettes
column2: so it's gratifying to hear him trying out so many different sounds and styles and moods here. Richmond
column3: Virginia's Trey Pollard
column4: a collaborator of Matthew E. White and Natalie Prass
column5: lends watery pedal steel to ""Mitad de Tu Mundo
column6: a sort of ambient dub lullaby. ""Stop Living Dead
column7: which features Pollard's arrangements for string octet
column8: has something of the dissonant
column9: plastic feel of Arca's Mutant
column10: as the acoustic source material is stretched into strange
column11: synthetic shapes. ""Enters
column12: the album's most atypical cut

column14: like a fuzzy Drexciyan daydream. And while most of the album is dominated by Lange's cool voice
column15: which lingers over koan-like statements in a drowsy sing-song cadence
column16: one of the album's most affecting tracks
column17: ""Detroit
column18: is a slow-motion electro-funk instrumental where Lange's vocals are limited to background breaths and coos.

column1: Yet Island Universe Story also coheres surprisingly well

column4: Lange wrote of using the tapes to explore ""subconscious whisperings

column4: too flush from the life to take a step back.

column1: Sticking to this trusted methodology
column2: Lauren has struggled to separate himself from the pack. The wheezy-voiced rapper often deploys a steady-paced flow that rumbles into view like a packed SUV
column3: his style landing somewhere between NYC legends Raekwon and Big Pun
column4: without the former’s eye for detail or latter’s technical complexity. When Meyhem overexerts himself
column5: he sounds like the air can’t back into his lungs fast enough; in his best moments
column6: his gruff vocals hit hard and effectively. He’ll rap blood-soaked confessions with the eerie calm of a guy who isn’t kidding

column3: familiar beats and the no-nonsense hooks—like on the sidewalk-smashing ""Deep Cover"" homage ""Badmon Ting"" and shimmering street anthem ""Elevation""—mostly stick. It’s old school gangster rap appropriation for those who can’t get enough of the familiar stuff.

column5: bragging about eating crab meat ""right out the shell"" on the soul sample-swaddled ""Garlic and Oil"" and his 4am steam fish take-out runs on the tough drums of ""Vintage."" In Mey’s world
column6: the quality on your cuisine is the ultimate status barometer.

column1: Though there’s surface-level value to the set

column3: but we never get close enough to the drama. The violent imagery and drug-dealing narratives lack rich specifics
column4: a moralistic center or any sense of a beating heart behind the poker-faced protagonist’s bluster. It’s a widescreen crime flick with a seven-page script.

column3: we get more stock similes: ""Breitling on my wrist since I’m 21/Became a man
column4: bought a watch and a gun
column5: he spits

column9: Bronson does with a bar than most rappers need whole verses to lay out: ""Daddy didn’t believe I was an earner/‘Till I showed up in the Lamb with the safari window

column13:
in just a couple of lines. It’s a reminder that most of Piatto D’oro is all gusto with little underneath.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23155/homepage_large.1e0c24e3.jpg|In Movement|12519.0|Jack DeJohnette|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ECM']|2016-05-09 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:03.599385|"

Jack DeJohnette knows how to turn traditions inside out. He can invest light-touch cymbal playing with the feel of pulsing funk. His freer patterns of blast can sound like some of the most refined avant-percussion you've ever heard. Though while DeJohnette is obviously an original
column2: he's not bent on tearing down all the boundaries between jazz sub-genres. His engagement with various aspects of blues and swing flows from an evident reverence for each specific style. Even when pushing his own creative language to new places
column3: DeJohnette manages to keep the inherited forms in view.

column1: His half-century discography suggests how invaluable (and how rare) that philosophy of performance has been. DeJohnette played on Miles Davis' Bitches Brew
column2: was part of an acoustic trio led by pianist Bill Evans
column3: and also collaborated with experimental visionaries from the Chicago scene
column4: many of whom were active in the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians (or AACM). In decades since
column5: he's worked with Keith Jarrett and Pat Metheny
column6: while recording frequently as a leader for the ECM label.

column1: DeJohnette's 2015 release on the imprint
column2: Made in Chicago
column3: referenced his deep relationships with various AACM musicians while staying mostly focused on recent compositions from that all-star group of players. The drummer's latest album follows a broadly similar path
column4: by affording DeJohnette a chance to create some new pieces alongside two scions of jazz: the saxophonist Ravi Coltrane and the bassist (and electronics whiz) Matthew Garrison. The aura of history is inescapable on a project that includes them both
column5: given that their fathers were members of the “classic” John Coltrane Quartet. And DeJohnette's new trio plunges right into the deepest of jazz-legacy waters by tackling one of the classic Coltrane quartet's most iconic tunes
column6: at the very beginning of In Movement.

column1: “Alabama” was the elder Coltrane's response to the 1963 white-supremacist terror bombing of Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church. The studio take is a piece that can stand with any work of tragic poetry
column2: from any artistic discipline. When the climactic tenor line breaks through
column3: there is an emotional transition—from a state of mourning to one of wrenching
column4: cathartic protest. (Spike Lee used this portion of the song to shattering effect during 4 Little Girls
column5: his documentary on the murders.) It's one of the great compositions and performances of music history. As a consequence
column6: it's a risky thing for anyone else to touch.

column1: Here
column2: after a few seconds of cymbal work from DeJohnette
column3: the trio's performance begins in earnest when Ravi Coltrane plays a closing portion of the song's main theme. This needle-drop
column4: in media res choice conjures up the haunting suggestion of “Alabama” playing on an everlasting loop
column5: as a mandated accompaniment for each and every occurrence of racially motivated violence. This sense of disquiet is also promoted by Garrison's electric bass playing. His clouds of fuzz-tone thicken noticeably when Coltrane moves up to the famous high-register cry. The purgatorial (or else eternally damned) quality of this “Alabama” feels even even grimmer than the original. There's no swinging
column6: breakdown section (as in the originally issued album version). And even DeJohnette's rollicking percussive moments have a pensive air. Still
column7: the liberties taken here feel well thought-out
column8: while also keeping the performance from seeming backward looking.

column1: The mood brightens considerably during the pair of lengthy (and jointly composed) original tunes that follow “Alabama.” “Two Jimmys” is a joint tribute to Garrison's father as well as Jimi Hendrix
column2: and it has a variable-but-intense groove pitched somewhere between Sun Ship and Band of Gypsys. But the real stomper on In Movement is the trio's Earth
column3: Wind and Fire cover
column4: “Serpentine Fire
column5: ” which this trio stretches with abandon. Similarly refashioned is “Blue in Green” from Miles Davis' Kind of Blue
column6: which finds DeJohnette moving from behind his kit to offer some rich support on piano. Along with two lyrical ballads by DeJohnette
column7: this cover also offers a respite after some of the album's noisier material.

column1: The only cut on the 50-minute set that feels a little too beholden to the past is “Rashied
column2: ” a tribute to Coltrane's hookup with drummer Rashied Ali on the duo set Insterstellar Space. It's certainly an energetic performance—and both DeJohnette and Coltrane avoid sounding like they're directly copying the players this piece sets out to honor. But the duo-setup that animates this performance doesn't feel as freshly conceived as the trio's performance of “Alabama” does.

column1: That may sound like a high critical bar
column2: but it's one this group sets for itself. Despite the grand shadows cast by their forbears
column3: In Movement shows how both Ravi and Matthew have emerged as distinct instrumentalists on the contemporary jazz scene. And they have skills that match up with DeJohnette's own. No one in this group has to run from history
column4: or overly fetishize it
column5:
in order to sound like an individual—a shared skill that makes In Movement a frequently spellbinding experience.
