When the German rock renaissance began in earnest in the mid-'90s
column4: it was the result of multiple factors. Can's catalog was reissued on CD; they gained verbally outspoken fans like Sonic Youth
column5: Tortoise
column6: and Stereolab; and Julian Cope’s Krautrocksampler: One Head's Guide to the Great Kosmische Musik provided a crucial roadmap for casual listeners. For the most part
column7: the revival foregrounded the era’s headiest rock bands and no doubt appealed to classic rock fans looking for new thrills: Can
column8: Neu!
column9: Amon Düül I and II
column10: Faust and the like. And while Kraftwerk already enjoyed success in the worlds of early hip-hop
column11: electro and industrial circles at this time
column12: a purely electronic act like Cluster went unnoticed for the most part. But as listeners dug and listened deeper
column13: the charms of the duo of Hans-Joachim Roedelius and Dieter Moebius began to gain their own cult following. Now
column14: their discography is rightfully regarded as one of the era’s finest. Exploratory yet grounded
column15: futuristic yet melodic
column16: alien and charming
column17: the eight studio albums they recorded from 1971-1981 are now compiled in a handy if no-frills box set. With it
column18: Cluster’s heavenly horizon-to-horizon arc—which spans from the dawn of electronic experimentation to the rise of new age and synthesized pop music—can finally be fully gleaned.

column1: As Asmus Tietchens’s liner notes put it
column2: the group arose from a heady blend of post-war artistic intent: Fluxus
column3: Viennese Actionism
column4: the Frankfurt School
column5: as well as the rise of '60s hippie counter-culture. The group began as Kluster
column6: a three-piece featuring Roedelius
column7: Moebius and fellow synth pioneer Conrad Schnitzler. Seeking to breach boundaries
column8: this incarnation utilized the electronic components of academic composition in ways that moved from high art to all-night happenings. And while Schnitzler exited the group the same year
column9: their 1971 self-titled debut (titled here Cluster 71) carries forth that rebellious spirit. Across three long untitled tracks
column10: the unfettered live-wire sound of their early experiments continued on in the studio. While Kraftwerk’s (now-disowned) debut album dates from the year before
column11: it placed electronics alongside organ
column12: flute
column13: drums and violin; Cluster 71 is the buzzing
column14: churning
column15: crackling sound of electricity itself
column16: made audible in all its untamed glory. Its closest peer would be Tangerine Dream’s Electronic Meditation
column17: but even that album feels more restrained in comparison.

column1: The next year
column2: Cluster II would venture even further into the lightning field. Some numbers
column3: like “Für die Katz'
column4: ” have a slow cycling guitar line
column5: but circuits spark and simmer on all sides around it
column6: rising and falling like a cardiograph. One of the box set’s meager bonuses is a live concert from this same year. It’s slightly longer here
column7: a shame since these early Cluster shows were usually all-night affairs that rippled and surged for six hours or more
column8: soundtracking chemically altered altered mental flights much like Terry Riley’s concerts would.

column1: The first two albums fleshed out their obtuse experimental side
column2: and by 1972 the duo moved out of Berlin. They relocated to the rural village of Forst on the river Weser and set up shop in a massive manor that might be regarded as the group's unofficial third member. Bucolic climes altered Cluster's music as much as Brian Eno
column3: producer Conny Plank or Michael Rother would in the ensuing years. But don't think Forst just inspired mellow idylls; when they released 1974’s Zuckerzeit
column4: it was one of the most audacious about-faces any band had attempted. Rather than the unhurried
column5: unstructured
column6: beatless freeform explorations
column7: Zuckerzeit (which I’ve seen translated as both “Sugar Time” and “Sugar Era”) was electronic pop at its most protean and still acts like a sugar overload: giddy
column8: infectious
column9: manic and a little queasy. The ten tracks belie the fact that the album is two solo halves welded into a whole
column10: each person contributing five tracks and each mapping their musical personas. Utilizing an early analog drum machine
column11: Roedelius's ""Hollywood"" is epic
column12: its shuffling
column13: chugging beat paired with sweeping synths that strafe across the song like eagles
column14: each successive synth layer pushing towards a heart-stirring new summit. Whereas early Cluster albums might have taken an entire side to reach such a climax
column15: now they moved to dizzying heights and back down in a pop song's runtime
column16: anywhere from two to six minutes. Moebius' ""Caramel"" is equally infectious
column17: his lines not as dramatic as his partner's but more kinetic
column18: wiggling in and around the pistoning programmed beat. While Kraftwerk no doubt set the electronic paradigm for the decades to come across numerous genres
column19: the dynamic established between Roedelius and Moebius was also influential. Theirs showed what a sound world two individuals could manifest—expansive yet efficient at once—and it's a dynamic that's powered most electronic music groups ever since
column20: from the Chemical Brothers and Orbital to Daft Punk and any B2B DJ set.

column1: Around this time
column2: charmed by both Cluster's output and that of Harmonia (their trio with Neu!'s Rother)
column3: Brian Eno trekked to Forst for two collaborative albums
column4: which no doubt solidified an aesthetic begun with Another Green World that would soon carry over to David Bowie's Berlin trilogy and Eno's ambient series. And while oblique strategies informed Eno's work during this time
column5: there's a casual tone to Cluster & Eno and After the Heat that suggests neither strategy nor willful obliqueness were needed in the forest. The cover of the former hints at the sounds within
column6: a microphone craning towards the evening sky as if to record drifting clouds. And while one might be inclined to chalk these albums as the work of a trio

column8: suggesting a quartet at work. The ten tracks are as formless and minutely shifting as that photo suggests
column9: lovely and intangible daydreams.

column1: Elegant piano and twanging guitar entwine on “Ho Renomo” and then drift apart
column2: while pensive piano chords slide across synth flares on ""Wehrmut."" The ambience suggests peacefulness
column3: but there’s always something a little unsettling in these pieces. “Die Bunge” sounds like frog and bird calls from an alien bog
column4: a concept that Eno would revisit for Ambient 4 (On Land) a few years on. Recorded a few months on
column5: After the Heat kept the open experimentation of the previous encounter intact while edging closer to Eno's sense of song craft. Songs like “Broken Head” and “The Belldog” could have landed on Before and After Science
column6: the lone instances of vocals intruding upon Cluster's otherwise wordless music. There’s more of a pulse to the album
column7: from the brass burbles of “Oil” to Holgar Czukay’s wobbling bass on “Tzima N’Arki
column8: ” and fans of Eno’s mid-70s highs will find yet another green world to be had here.

column1: As the decade drew to an end
column2: the synthesizers and drum machines that had once defined the avant garde had increasingly become part of pop music’s fabric. After years of working with Plank
column3: for Großes Wasser
column4: Cluster recorded with Tangerine Dream’s Peter Baumann
column5: finding a sound both darker (“Avanti”)
column6: sweeter (the charming etude of “Manchmal”) and funkier (the too-short space-disco of “Prothese”). After years spent exploring shorter times
column7: the title track comprises the entire second side
column8: an epic that touches on Cluster’s tropes from the decade prior: sustained piano chords
column9: strange synth trickles
column10: eerie drones and skeletal drums. By the time of 1981’s Curiosum
column11: British new wavers
column12: new-agers
column13: synth-poppers and industrial miscreants alike had fully embraced Cluster’s examples within their own music
column14: so much so that the miniatures of their last full-length album that decade sound more like Cluster emulating these newer artists (be they OMD
column15: Cabaret Voltaire
column16: or Throbbing Gristle) than the other way around. It still speaks for Cluster’s prescience
column17: to render the mechanistic noise of early electronic devices and warm them up in such a manner so as to reveal that no matter the new technology

such components are ultimately human after all.

When the German rock renaissance began in earnest in the mid-'90s
column4: it was the result of multiple factors. Can's catalog was reissued on CD; they gained verbally outspoken fans like Sonic Youth
column5: Tortoise
column6: and Stereolab; and Julian Cope’s Krautrocksampler: One Head's Guide to the Great Kosmische Musik provided a crucial roadmap for casual listeners. For the most part
column7: the revival foregrounded the era’s headiest rock bands and no doubt appealed to classic rock fans looking for new thrills: Can
column8: Neu!
column9: Amon Düül I and II
column10: Faust and the like. And while Kraftwerk already enjoyed success in the worlds of early hip-hop
column11: electro and industrial circles at this time
column12: a purely electronic act like Cluster went unnoticed for the most part. But as listeners dug and listened deeper
column13: the charms of the duo of Hans-Joachim Roedelius and Dieter Moebius began to gain their own cult following. Now
column14: their discography is rightfully regarded as one of the era’s finest. Exploratory yet grounded
column15: futuristic yet melodic
column16: alien and charming
column17: the eight studio albums they recorded from 1971-1981 are now compiled in a handy if no-frills box set. With it
column18: Cluster’s heavenly horizon-to-horizon arc—which spans from the dawn of electronic experimentation to the rise of new age and synthesized pop music—can finally be fully gleaned.

column1: As Asmus Tietchens’s liner notes put it
column2: the group arose from a heady blend of post-war artistic intent: Fluxus
column3: Viennese Actionism
column4: the Frankfurt School
column5: as well as the rise of '60s hippie counter-culture. The group began as Kluster
column6: a three-piece featuring Roedelius
column7: Moebius and fellow synth pioneer Conrad Schnitzler. Seeking to breach boundaries
column8: this incarnation utilized the electronic components of academic composition in ways that moved from high art to all-night happenings. And while Schnitzler exited the group the same year
column9: their 1971 self-titled debut (titled here Cluster 71) carries forth that rebellious spirit. Across three long untitled tracks
column10: the unfettered live-wire sound of their early experiments continued on in the studio. While Kraftwerk’s (now-disowned) debut album dates from the year before
column11: it placed electronics alongside organ
column12: flute
column13: drums and violin; Cluster 71 is the buzzing
column14: churning
column15: crackling sound of electricity itself
column16: made audible in all its untamed glory. Its closest peer would be Tangerine Dream’s Electronic Meditation
column17: but even that album feels more restrained in comparison.

column1: The next year
column2: Cluster II would venture even further into the lightning field. Some numbers
column3: like “Für die Katz'
column4: ” have a slow cycling guitar line
column5: but circuits spark and simmer on all sides around it
column6: rising and falling like a cardiograph. One of the box set’s meager bonuses is a live concert from this same year. It’s slightly longer here
column7: a shame since these early Cluster shows were usually all-night affairs that rippled and surged for six hours or more
column8: soundtracking chemically altered altered mental flights much like Terry Riley’s concerts would.

column1: The first two albums fleshed out their obtuse experimental side
column2: and by 1972 the duo moved out of Berlin. They relocated to the rural village of Forst on the river Weser and set up shop in a massive manor that might be regarded as the group's unofficial third member. Bucolic climes altered Cluster's music as much as Brian Eno
column3: producer Conny Plank or Michael Rother would in the ensuing years. But don't think Forst just inspired mellow idylls; when they released 1974’s Zuckerzeit
column4: it was one of the most audacious about-faces any band had attempted. Rather than the unhurried
column5: unstructured
column6: beatless freeform explorations
column7: Zuckerzeit (which I’ve seen translated as both “Sugar Time” and “Sugar Era”) was electronic pop at its most protean and still acts like a sugar overload: giddy
column8: infectious
column9: manic and a little queasy. The ten tracks belie the fact that the album is two solo halves welded into a whole
column10: each person contributing five tracks and each mapping their musical personas. Utilizing an early analog drum machine
column11: Roedelius's ""Hollywood"" is epic
column12: its shuffling
column13: chugging beat paired with sweeping synths that strafe across the song like eagles
column14: each successive synth layer pushing towards a heart-stirring new summit. Whereas early Cluster albums might have taken an entire side to reach such a climax
column15: now they moved to dizzying heights and back down in a pop song's runtime
column16: anywhere from two to six minutes. Moebius' ""Caramel"" is equally infectious
column17: his lines not as dramatic as his partner's but more kinetic
column18: wiggling in and around the pistoning programmed beat. While Kraftwerk no doubt set the electronic paradigm for the decades to come across numerous genres
column19: the dynamic established between Roedelius and Moebius was also influential. Theirs showed what a sound world two individuals could manifest—expansive yet efficient at once—and it's a dynamic that's powered most electronic music groups ever since
column20: from the Chemical Brothers and Orbital to Daft Punk and any B2B DJ set.

column1: By the time 1976's Sowiesoso appeared
column2: the effects of rural living were audible on tape. While there's a stiff
column3: rigorous Teutonic aspect to many of krautrock's biggest artists
column4: there's a pliancy and playfulness to Moebius and Roedelius in contrast to the other sounds of the era. Kraftwerk was more formal
column5: Can was more kinetic
column6: Faust more Dadaist
column7: Neu! more manic
column8: leaving Cluster as the most Romantic
column9: and no where does that shine through than on their latter albums
column10: beginning here. Melody
column11: ambience
column12: wistfulness and gentleness underpin songs like "" Zum Wohl"" and the title track. But that doesn't keep weird quirks from arising
column13: like the little drum circle that emerges around the campfire-warm ""Umleitung"" or the drunken lilt of closer “In Ewigkeit.”

column1: Around this time
column2: charmed by both Cluster's output and that of Harmonia (their trio with Neu!'s Rother)
column3: Brian Eno trekked to Forst for two collaborative albums
column4: which no doubt solidified an aesthetic begun with Another Green World that would soon carry over to David Bowie's Berlin trilogy and Eno's ambient series. And while oblique strategies informed Eno's work during this time
column5: there's a casual tone to Cluster & Eno and After the Heat that suggests neither strategy nor willful obliqueness were needed in the forest. The cover of the former hints at the sounds within
column6: a microphone craning towards the evening sky as if to record drifting clouds. And while one might be inclined to chalk these albums as the work of a trio
column7: producer Conny Plank’s fingerprints are all over these albums
column8: suggesting a quartet at work. The ten tracks are as formless and minutely shifting as that photo suggests
column9: lovely and intangible daydreams.

column1: Elegant piano and twanging guitar entwine on “Ho Renomo” and then drift apart
column2: while pensive piano chords slide across synth flares on ""Wehrmut."" The ambience suggests peacefulness
column3: but there’s always something a little unsettling in these pieces. “Die Bunge” sounds like frog and bird calls from an alien bog
column4: a concept that Eno would revisit for Ambient 4 (On Land) a few years on. Recorded a few months on
column5: After the Heat kept the open experimentation of the previous encounter intact while edging closer to Eno's sense of song craft. Songs like “Broken Head” and “The Belldog” could have landed on Before and After Science
column6: the lone instances of vocals intruding upon Cluster's otherwise wordless music. There’s more of a pulse to the album
column7: from the brass burbles of “Oil” to Holgar Czukay’s wobbling bass on “Tzima N’Arki
column8: ” and fans of Eno’s mid-70s highs will find yet another green world to be had here.

column1: As the decade drew to an end
column2: the synthesizers and drum machines that had once defined the avant garde had increasingly become part of pop music’s fabric. After years of working with Plank
column3: for Großes Wasser
column4: Cluster recorded with Tangerine Dream’s Peter Baumann
column5: finding a sound both darker (“Avanti”)
column6: sweeter (the charming etude of “Manchmal”) and funkier (the too-short space-disco of “Prothese”). After years spent exploring shorter times
column7: the title track comprises the entire second side
column8: an epic that touches on Cluster’s tropes from the decade prior: sustained piano chords
column9: strange synth trickles
column10: eerie drones and skeletal drums. By the time of 1981’s Curiosum
column11: British new wavers
column12: new-agers
column13: synth-poppers and industrial miscreants alike had fully embraced Cluster’s examples within their own music
column14: so much so that the miniatures of their last full-length album that decade sound more like Cluster emulating these newer artists (be they OMD
column15: Cabaret Voltaire
column16: or Throbbing Gristle) than the other way around. It still speaks for Cluster’s prescience
column17: to render the mechanistic noise of early electronic devices and warm them up in such a manner so as to reveal that no matter the new technology
column18:
such components are ultimately human after all.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23194/homepage_large.d9686f2a.jpg|songs from wonder.land|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Parlophone']|2016-05-07 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:05.052466|"

wonder.land
column2: a musical by playwright Moira Buffini and Blur’s Damon Albarn that just finished its London run
column3: has a plot that’d make a quite serviceable Christmas panto
column4: if perhaps not a fully-formed production. Like most teens
column5: protagonist Aly has a heart that’s outgrown her sense of identity. Really like most teens
column6: she spends all her time online – specifically
column7: on the titular online MMORPG
column8: which doesn’t have all that many discernible MMORPG elements but is at least populated by the usual wacky sorts
column9: only a few of which are obviously inspired by Tim Burton’s versions of themselves in 2010. In the role of Boomer sneering at millennials and their screens we have Aly’s technophobic Miss Hannigan of a headmaster
column10: though she’s not exasperated enough that she can’t steal Aly’s avatar and turn herself into the Red Queen
column11: the resident wonder.land shitposter.

column1: There are
column2: right from the outset
column3: a number of ways this could go wrong. There is no genre or medium in existence in which a version
column4: straight or tweaked
column5: of Alice in Wonderland is not clichéd. (Last down the rabbit hole in the theater world was Jekyll and Hyde director Frank Wildhorn
column6: whose 2011 Alice adaptation flopped mightily.) And a lightly tweaked musical take on fairy tales in general is a Broadway standby—see Sondheim’s Into the Woods
column7: whose high-profile film adaptation would bring it first to mind even if its Broadway revival and canonical status didn’t. Making one’s fairytale world a MMORPG was dated somewhere around the heyday of Second Life
column8: if not the Ultima Online or BBS eras; equating that digital world with Wonderland was dated when The Matrix did it; and titles like “wonder.land” became hilariously dated somewhere around 2000
column9: the year of “www.nevergetoveryou.” And Albarn
column10: though not new to theater scores—2012’s Dr. Dee is pleasantly complex and holds up remarkably well as a standalone work – is a curious choice for this one
column11: being neither a fan of modern musicals (which “lack identity musically”) nor
column12: perhaps digital culture (Everyday Robots in particular betrays some Luddite tendencies). Could the man whose last solo single lamented the rise of “everyday robots on [their] phones” really bring this digital wonderland to life?

column1: As it turns out Albarn’s wonder.land score is perfectly fine
column2: which is the entire problem. Buffini described her vision for the score as a blend of electronic music and music hall
column3: but the electronic elements are minimal (this is no PC Music
column4: nor even Owl City) and the vaudeville elements are unsurprising; a better description might be “a middling Amanda Palmer side project.” The score dutifully shuffles from pop ballads to vaguely creepy variety show numbers without much consistency or identity musically. The individual songs aren’t even consistent about how good they are. “Me” would be a perfectly serviceable loopy-soprano character piece with a few just-off-enough lyrics (“like a toenail all ingrown”) were it not backed by the sort of breezy ukulele soft-rock that’s the bane of anyone's existence who has watched a commercial in the past 10 years.

column1: “I’m Right” is supposed to be the kind of villainous patter song that
column2: with the right performer
column3: steals shows
column4: but both arrangement and lyric are clunky and over-practiced; it’s as if the headmaster who performs it rapped her cane to silence the cast every time she suspected things might be getting fun. (The character songs are particularly weak
column5: which for a work like Alice in Wonderland is death; Tweedledee
column6: Tweedledum
column7: the Dormouse
column8: and the Mock Turtle are shuffled through in one not-particularly-memorable song
column9: which may be intended as a quick-cut take on the megapopulation of online spaces but comes off more as songwriting-by-checklist.) There is fun in the title track
column10: a bit of female-fronted power-pop that’s among the more failure-proof styles out there – that is
column11: unless it loses all its energy from stage to recording and
column12: more damningly
column13: punctuates every other riff with the worst-aging part of the book
column14: namely: DOUBLE-YOU-DOUBLE-YOU-DOUBLE-YOU-DOT-WONDER-DOT-LAND! This is supposed to get silly with repetition. It just maybe wasn’t supposed to sound so silly from go.

column1: The biggest downfall of wonder.land
column2: ultimately
column3: isn’t anything in particular it does
column4: but everything it doesn’t. An early draft of the musical was set in North Korea
column5: which is a horrible idea
column6: but at least an interesting horrible idea. Very little in wonder.land is interesting
column7: and what is comes mostly from the book and the concept. (The theatrical production’s gotten middling reviews
column8: but unlike
column9: say
column10: Hamilton
column11: even the positive reviews rarely praise the score.) Perhaps they wrung some originality out of the material after all; Alice has been done for children
column12: for teens
column13: for adults
column14: squeaky-clean to drugged-out
column15: lighthearted to dark and darker and darkest
column16:
but seldom has it been done so bland.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23196/homepage_large.c7fb290b.jpg|Luck or Magic|6396.0|Britta Phillips|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Double Feature']|2016-05-07 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:05.633325|"

Britta Phillips' first solo album
column2: Luck or Magic
column3: is an attempt  to leave the drowsy
column4: Belle and Sebastian-y sound of Dean & Britta—the band she formed with husband Dean Wareham when Luna originally broke up—behind. Unfortunately
column5: she couldn't shake the couple's penchant for covers. Luck or Magic totals 10 tracks and half are Phillips' interpretations of other people's work. This move winds up feeling like album filler
column6: despite the offbeat quirkiness of her picks. (A cover of Agnetha Fältskog's ""Wrap Your Arms Around Me"" is a highlight. When's the last time you listened to that song and remembered how great it is?) Ultimately
column7: the covers feel more like a security blanket than a homage
column8: as if Phillips couldn't quite trust her own work to make the cut.

column1: Truly
column2: it's her sweet voice that suffers the consequences. She has a honeyed touch that can be as soothing as it is airy and bright
column3: even when the songs are tinged with tragedy—think ""The Sun Is Still Sunny."" Now
column4: her vocals have been run through the same flat
column5: echo effect that Lana Del Rey seems to live inside. Nowhere is this comparison more apparent than on the album's opener ""Daydream."" It becomes quite easy to swap out Phillips for Del Rey in your mind
column6: minus Del Rey's pouty affect. Similar vocal effects are applied to the cover of ""Fallin' In Love
column7: written by Dennis Wilson and originally titled ""Lady."" Phillips plays it safe and willfully changes the song's subject by replacing ""lady"" with ""baby
column8: which comes off as cutesy and trite
column9: negating her ability to take a deep dive into the Beach Boys' catalog and make an offbeat selection.

column1: Sadly
column2: that's not the album's worst transgression when it comes to tapering with originals. She opens her cover of ""Landslide"" with a cheerful
column3: bubbly synth line
column4: dubs in a child's voice right before the line ""Can the child in my heart rise above?
column5: and adds electric guitar solos so out of place they're just downright bizarre. If you're going to tackle Stevie Nicks
column6: it's best not to rob her work of its emotional power by pummeling the song with unnecessary flourishes. Not to mention
column7: the world needs another ""Landslide"" cover like it needs another version of Cohen's ""Hallelujah.""

column1: It's not as if the album is devoid of its bright spots. ""Do It Last"" is pleasant enough to listen to. ""Million Dollar Doll"" is catchy. The cover of ""One Fine Summer Morning"" is perfectly lovely because Phillips sticks close to the original
column2: which is a relief. The slowed-down version of ""Drive"" is also well-suited to the tone of her voice and worth a listen. But all in all
column3: the sparks are overshadowed by poor choices and general lack of direction. Phillips recently told The Wall Street Journal that producer Erik Broucek kept the album from ""sound[ing] like a random playlist
column4: when in fact that's exactly how it ends up sounding.

column1: It would be nice to see her trust herself more and cut down on the plethora of embellishments. Phillips can stand on her own
column2: her talent will support her. (She was Jem for God's sake!) But the ability to make decent music doesn't need to rely on a rabbit's foot
column3: or a stroke of good fortune
column4: or mimicry. It does
column5: however
column6:
tend to require a belief in oneself. A continued search for Luck or Magic probably isn't going to be very fruitful when what you really need is confidence.

"|21856.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21856-luck-or-magic/|5.0|Lindsay Hood

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23242/homepage_large.607e3dc5.jpg|Beloved|33716.0|Mo Troper|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Good Cheer']|2016-05-07 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:06.325125|"

Like drawing a perfect circle
column2: making a good power-pop record is a task that seems easy but becomes nearly impossible when put into practice. So many have aimed for simple and landed on trite; aimed for timeless and landed on toothless; aimed for sweet and landed on creepy. This is precisely why most power-pop albums are not necessarily graded for breaking new ground
column3: but rather
column4: for how competently they fit within the genre’s pre-established formula. Beloved
column5: the debut album from Portland
column6: OR songwriter Mo Troper
column7: indeed recalls some important figures from the past. Over the course of its thirteen tracks
column8: you will find the blushing-schoolboy narratives from the first two Big Star records

column1: In fact
column2: it’s almost impressive how much Troper is able to wring not only out of his genre’s limitations but also his stunted lyrical inspiration. Nearly all his songs are planted firmly within either accusatory pop-punk juvenilia (“You’re just another human being/But you’re the only one who’s cool enough to be a casualty/Of everything”) or starry-eyed high school fantasy (“Do you want to kiss me?/Do you ever say my name out loud?”). The latter lyric—from “After the Movies
column3: ” the album’s obvious highpoint—is a lot more successful territory for Troper
column4: whose voice is significantly more attractive beneath that song’s cozy distortion than amid the awkward open-mic dryness of “Somebody Special.” On an album that
column5: at its best
column6: sounds like an unearthed live bootleg from an obscure Titan Records band
column7: moments like these can’t help but feel like the local openers coming back to play one more song: you can practically hear the audience hightailing it to the bathroom within the first fifteen seconds. Same goes for eight-minute slow burner “The Biggest” and its acoustic coda
column8: “Teeth

column1: As spotty as the album is
column2: Troper’s gifts are undeniable. “Judy Garland” employs a lyrical conceit not unlike Weezer’s “Buddy Holly” before breaking into a similarly infectious “Ooh ooh ooh” refrain
column3: ensuring the song takes a permanent place in your head. On “Star Wars
column4: ” Troper plays up his loner persona (“All my friends want to get drunk again/I just want to stay home and stare at my phone”) before admitting squarely
column5: “All my friends are total fucking bros.” It’s one of the album’s funnier moments
column6: not to mention one that plants his material firmly in the present
column7: as opposed to the unremembered golden age his melodies and production occasionally recall. Plus
column8: it’s nice for once to hear him slightly implicate himself in his trademark
column9: snot-nosed pwnage.

column1: It’s hard to say just how long Troper’s keen melodic sensibility can counterbalance his lyrics’ occasionally mean-spirited adolescent tone; it will be interesting to see whether or not he will be able to pass the ultimate test for power-pop artists—the dreaded sophomore album. Still
column2: in a genre often criticized for its timidity
column3: Troper gets points for confidence. Not to mention
column4: it’s easy to ignore what he’s actually saying in songs like “After the Movies” and “Paint
column5: ” in which nearly every couplet feels effortlessly like a hook. While Troper is not the first person to do what he’s doing
column6: he is the first in a long time who can convince you—for the length of a few perfect moments—that no one’s ever done it better. If he’s half as interested in taking advice as he is in giving it
column7:
he’s well on his way to earning the authority that these songs seem obsessed with obtaining.

column6: were typical of an idealistic new movement rooted in the mod revival. It antagonized both dreary realists

column5: besides this compilation
column6: left few footprints in the British underground—was the first scene since punk to observe the widespread rejection of '60s Britrock
column7: and to reject that rejection. Thanks in part to the ""second Cold War

What has been the price of my protection? This spring at New York's Whitney Museum
column4: the artist Laura Poitras—best known for her 2014 film about the NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden
column5: Citizenfour—offered a harrowing answer. Within her multimedia exhibition Astro Noise was a piece called Bed Down Location. It invited viewers to lay on a platform in the dark
column6: assuming what in yoga is referred to as ""corpse pose."" The installation lulled you with doomy static and dispassionate male voices. The night skies of Somalia
column7: Pakistan
column8: and Yemen were projected at the ceiling like a planetarium. The idea was to stare at them—the celestial expanses of countries in which the U.S. has launched drone warfare—and think. To imagine human lives reduced to coordinates on a grid
column9: as if flesh and blood were part of an exercise in a math textbook. To imagine balls of fire falling onto us. To imagine death. A New Yorker might be struck by just how many stars those skies contained. Struck by how they look like sheets of glitter. By the beauty of an ornamented mustard-yellow building under our big Moon. By how nature could look like an oil painting. By how you want to be there. The emotion of Poitras' work did not just show the cost of our sense of protection—irrevocably
column10: the cost was felt.

column1: I thought of Anohni's HOPELESSNESS there. Both Anohni and Poitras have constructed monumental works this year dealing in the atrocity of post-9/11 America—drone warfare
column2: mass surveillance
column3: violent masculinity. These are the depths into which HOPELESSNESS demands that you swim or drown. HOPELESSNESS is a record where the American dream is a hallucination
column4: where Big Brother lustfully becomes ""daddy/ohhh
column5: where we are all called out. It is the sonic equivalent of a burning Shepard Fairey painting and all its embers.

column3: with co-producers Hudson Mohawke and Oneohtrix Point Never
column4: there are many more layers of rigor to that conversation. Anohni has undergone a musical metamorphosis
column5: crafting another outlet for her vision: the electronic dance anthem as visceral protest song. So much has unfolded in the six years since Anohni's last studio album with the Johnsons—Occupy Wall Street
column6: the Arab Spring
column7: the trial of Chelsea Manning
column8: the Black Lives Matter movement. Anohni—ecofeminist soul warrior
column9: dramatist
column10: a person who Lou Reed called an ""angel""—it would be hard to find a more capable figure to lead us into a woke pop polemic.

column1: Poignant political realities have always grounded Anohni's work
column2: but now they are at the forefront
column3: articulated with an incisiveness that stares you in the eye. You have never heard words like ""chemotherapy
column4: ""child molesters
column5: and ""mass graves"" crooned so gorgeously. HOPELESSNESS places Anohni alongside radical pop provocateurs like M.I.A.
column6: artists who propose difficult questions that mainstream America does not want to ask because it would not know what to do with the answers. But Anohni insists that we raise our stakes. ""A lot of the music scene is just a wanking
column7: self-congratulatory boys club
column8: she said in 2012. ""It's just so fucking boring and not useful. It's such a waste of our time... another reflection of how astray we are as a civilization.""

column1: HOPELESSNESS disrupts that. Anohni
column2: HudMo
column3: and OPN meet on an astral plane and construct a sleek salon there
column4: where we can reflect on the current moment and perhaps be spurred to action. The elegant bombast of these tracks propels the issues forward with a clarity that is exacting and exhilarating. Anohni has worked with both of these electro sophisticates before (in June of 2011 OPN tweeted: ""antony doesn't use the internet anymore"") but HOPELESSNESS represents a new level of collaboration. The subject matter is daunting
column5: but this is some of the most accessible and pristinely infectious music that any of these people have made. With that
column6: HOPELESSNESS simultaneously broadens Anohni's appeal and brings that appeal into focus.

column1: ""Drone Bomb Me"" is sung from the perspective of a seven-year-old girl whose family falls victim to a targeted killing. ""Blow my head off/Explode my crystal guts
column2: Anohni sings
column3: describing toxic reality with a honeyed cadence
column4: and as this body-music gets under your skin
column5: its subject—which in life is too often abstracted—makes an appeal to the heart. In her singing I am reminded of what we mean by ""soul"" music: empathy
column6: pain
column7: sincerity
column8: dignity
column9: the truth of life. I am also reminded that Anohni covered Beyoncé years ago
column10: that her voice crushes you like Adele's. This isn't the first time Anohni has overlapped with dance music—she collaborated with Hercules and Love Affair
column11: and in 2013
column12: the DJ Avicii included an electro house remix of ""Hope There's Someone"" on his album True. (Perhaps Anohni heard its hyper-masculine drops and thought: ummmm…..)

column1: Production-wise
column2: the HOPELESSNESS team did not take the obvious route
column3: which would have been doomy post-Arca metal scraps from Yeezus' industrial wasteland. If HOPELESSNESS recalls any Arca song
column4: it's the xen philosophy of 2014's unsettlingly beatific ""Sisters."" (That Mohawke
column5: a producer on Yeezus
column6: Pablo
column7: and <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/17354-kanye-west-all-day-ft-allan-kingdom-theophilus-london-and-paul-mccartney/"">""All Day
column8: should serve as a connective between Anohni and Kanye—who've both worked to infiltrate and subvert—makes a lot of sense.) The sinister rumble of ""Violent Men"" and the ominous ""Obama"" monologue makes them outliers here
column9: texturing HOPELESSNESS with darker
column10: episodic pieces. The maximalist slam-dunk beats of HudMo's TNGHT project are absent
column11: but the burnt-rubber bounce that opens ""Obama"" hints at it. There's an impulse to place ""Obama"" in the tradition of scathing presidential take-downs—like Stevie Wonder's ""You Haven't Done Nothin'"" or Neil Young's ""Let's Impeach the President""—but the way Anohni turns liberal subterfuge into a literal hex feels more complicated. ""Obama"" recounts how the world cried for joy when the President was elected and how furiously disappointing recent years have been
column12: ""all the hope drained from your face."" These are menacing lyrics you would still more readily expect to be railed by a contemporary punk band like Downtown Boys or Priests (""Barack Obama killed something in me
column13: Katie Greer succinctly put it in 2014
column14: ""And I'm gonna get him for it!"") than any pop star.

column1: ""Violent Men""—an ambient
column2: pitch-shifted meditation on the need to ""never again give birth to violent men""—underscores the essential theme of these songs
column3: which is the violence of patriarchy as the core of all oppression. And this leads to another tenet of HOPELESSNESS: ecofeminism. On the 2012 Johnsons live album Cut the World there was a poetic speech called ""Future Feminism
column4: which situated Anohni unmistakably into this context—the basic idea that feminism must extend its liberationist ethos from gender
column5: race
column6: class
column7: and physical abilities into nature. Ecofeminism defines the stunning ""4 Degrees
column8: alluding to the impending global temperature-increase that will factually topple our ecosystem. ""I want to see this world/I want to see it boil
column9: Anohni sings
column10: belting out a striking catalog of the dogs
column11: lemurs
column12: rhinos
column13: and other creatures who are going to perish because of our selfishness and greed. The mood is heavy
column14: urgent
column15: dire—a fully-issued wake-up call bearing reportorial weight
column16: an ultralight beam parting a cloud.

column1: Anohni's vast environmental songs are like modern rewrites of Kate Bush's ""The Big Sky
column2: where the once-innocent vaults of heaven are more foreboding
column3: sites of hidden remote-control murder
column4: invisible all-watching eyes
column5: gas emissions. And yet underlying these songs is a plea for a kind of love that implicates all life. As Anohni sings of our current apocalypse
column6: her voice and these beats have some semblance of utopia in them. It is music about death and destruction that sounds deep-down infatuated by the forces that keep us alive.

column1: The bracing ""Why Did You Separate Me From the Earth?"" is another ecofeminist epic
column2: the no-future punk tradition born anew: ""I don't want your future/I'll never return/I'll be born into the past."" HOPELESSNESS makes the lethal clashes of capitalism and nature
column3: of the industrial and the organic
column4: impossible to ignore. Crucially
column5: ecofeminism posits that a masculine sense-of-self considers itself separate of the world
column6: whereas a feminine sense-of-self sees itself as fundamentally interconnected
column7: with responsibilities. All violence and ecological crises
column8: then
column9: come from failing to make connections. Anohni poses a most pressing question of late-capitalism: ""Why did you separate me from the Earth?""

column1: ""Watch Me
column2: meanwhile
column3: is possibly the most sensual piece of musical surveillance art ever. Crisp
column4: cavernous beats boom over ambient noise
column5: and our nightmarish culture of intercepted metadata floats into eerie seduction—there's a degree of absurdity to that
column6: befitting the absurdity of our world. In ""Watch Me"" Anohni is being spied on in her hotel room: ""Watch me watching pornography/Watch me talking to my friends and my family
column7: she sings
column8: gliding gracefully
column9: ""I know you love me/‘Cause you're always watching me/Protecting me from evil/Protecting me from terrorism/Protecting me from child molesters."" With bone-chilling intimacy
column10: Anohni reveals so much about how surveillance culture cuts out the potential of choice. ""Watch Me"" is the HOPELESSNESS song that is most likely to lodge itself into your skull with its euphoric melody
column11: but plot-twist: you can't really sing it in public. Astonishingly
column12: then
column13: ""Watch Me"" is song about surveillance that might make you surveil yourself—an act of sousveillance.

column1: One is reminded of Anohni's connection to former Johnsons member William Basinski. HOPELESSNESS should fall alongside his ambient classic The Disintegration Loops in the canon of music that responds to post-9/11 America. The songs constantly underscore Anohni's complicity—from a pained utterance that ""I'm partly to blame"" to how she cries through the ecstatic apology of ""Crisis""—but HOPELESSNESS also comes with an embodied promise of change. The message is encoded into every note: If Anohni's music can manifest into something new
column2: then perhaps we can. There is risk involved with moving from a timeless sound towards one that attempts to capture a moment
column3: but without risk art is worthless.

column1: Earlier this year
column2: news broke that Anohni would not appear at the Oscars. She was the first transgender performer to ever be nominated—on the successes of a song she wrote about ecocide for a movie literally called Racing Extinction—but the honor was diminished when she was not invited to perform at the ceremony. In response
column3: Anohni wrote an essay about the decision that is itself a remarkable document. ""They are going to try to convince us that they have our best interests at heart by waving flags for identity politics and fake moral issues
column4: she wrote. ""But don't forget that many of these celebrities are the trophies of billionaire corporations whose only intention is to manipulate you into giving them your consent and the last of your money. They have been paid to do a little tap dance to occupy you while Rome burns.""

column1: HOPELESSNESS is not afraid to sway within the flames
column2:
to draw you towards the heat. The fact is that Anohni's dramas cannot exist in a world of Hollywood endings. They are too real for a silver lining. HOPELESSNESS communicates the horror of seeing that in so many ways we have been profoundly fooled by the fantasy of the American experiment. By how the stars are not just stars. By how they contain lies. By how the truest protagonist of HOPELESSNESS is us.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23133/homepage_large.0c440312.jpg|White Hot Moon|31637.0|Pity Sex|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Run for Cover']|2016-05-05 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:09.548215|"

For the surprising influence that it wields today
column2: second-wave emo was not without its shortcomings. While the movement’s largely male figureheads were more than happy to detail the emotional harm they suffered in relationships—usually at the hands of women—their avoidance of the topic of sex was near puritanical. Arriving nearly twenty years after the fact
column3: Ann Arbor’s Pity Sex felt like something of a corrective. Despite their typical beginnings—hardcore scene vets start melodic project—Pity Sex were very much unlike their peers
column4: a co-ed emo act willing to venture beyond the bedroom door. What’s more
column5: their first-person vignettes turned emo’s central trope on its head
column6: telling stories of doomed romances from the perspective of the unfeeling aggressor
column7: rather than the wounded victim. “There’s nothing to talk about
column8: ” one such protagonist admits on 2013’s Feast of Love
column9: “When we talk about love.""

column1: Pity Sex don’t sound all that emo these days; since their noisy
column2: shambolic beginnings on 2012’s Dark World
column3: they’ve expanded their sonic palette
column4: borrowing guitar tones from alternative rock’s '90s heyday and brisk
column5: hooky songwriting from that same era's pop-punk. Their latest
column6: White Hot Moon
column7: doesn’t stray far from this path
column8: though it does find the band further cleaning up their sound
column9: with the assistance of producer Will Yip. There’s a satisfying crispness to be found on White Hot Moon
column10: from the crunch of its power chords to the bright pop of each snare hit. Like many of Yip’s projects
column11: White Hot Moon recalls a time when even scruffy bands like Jawbreaker had access to the sort of studio equipment a major label budget affords.

column1: Still
column2: if you’ve been following Pity Sex
column3: most of White Hot Moon’s dynamics will feel familiar: quiet verses
column4: loud choruses
column5: fuzzed-out guitars set atop driving percussion. The beating heart of most Pity Sex songs lies in the interplay between Brennan Greaves' stoic tone and Britty Drake’s earnest delivery
column6: and lead single “Burden You” leverages this formula to great effect. Here
column7: Greaves takes on some of the messier lines (""Follow me home between my sheets and mend the burden in me”) with a cool detachment
column8: while Drake alternates between singing “I wanna burden you” and “I wanna burn in you
column9: ” channeling the dark intimacy of In Utero-era Kurt Cobain. That’s not all they’re borrowing from the monsters of alt-rock: the song closes with a squall of feedback that creeps up steadily through the final verses. Even so
column10: the kicker—Drake’s gutting admission
column11: “I’ll always think of your lips/When I’m moving mine against his”—feels like a signature Pity Sex move
column12: an emotional time-bomb delivered as a casual aside.

column1: Most of White Hot Moon plays out similarly
column2: from the punky sprint of “Orange and Red” to the squealing string bends and knuckle-dragging minor chords of “White Hot Moon.” For evidence of the band venturing outside of their comfort zone
column3: look to the handful of ballads
column4: which extend their range with mixed results. “Dandelion” gets by on prettiness
column5: hiding its payload inside of the kind of bodily metaphors (""Let roots run through me like veins
column6: ventricles
column7: and arteries”) that rank among emo’s most beloved clichés. “September” goes further yet—here
column8: the band attempts to pass as a clean-cut
column9: Midwestern emo act. Its sappiness is maybe a bit too on the nose: after all
column10: the refrain of “You are the earth beneath my feet” is just a few words away from being a Bette Midler lyric.

column1: The album’s most striking number
column2: “Plum
column3: ” manages to put that same earnestness to better use
column4: with Drake detailing the loss of a parent with an artful yet unflinching candor. Her sadness here is deeply felt but never morose
column5: while the band provides just enough muscle to propel the narrative forward. Pity Sex’s primary asset is their willingness to approach emotionally difficult topics head-on
column6: and “Plum” is perhaps the most wrenching demonstration of this skill yet.

column1: Overall
column2: White Hot Moon is likely to please existing fans of Pity Sex—its 12 tracks largely find the band continuing to leverage what worked on Feast of Love. That said
column3: White Hot Moon isn’t quite as catchy as that record—its hooks feel a bit dilute next to an earworm like “Drown Me Out.” The band's relative lack of growth here is also disappointing. Certainly
column4: their central conceit—using the tools of angsty
column5: suburban teens to get at some very adult themes—continues to be compelling. But with an emo revival in full swing
column6: they’re hardly alone in this endeavor. Just look to bands like The World is a Beautiful Place...
column7: The Hotelier
column8: or Touché Amoré
column9: all of whom have found emo to be a more than capable vehicle for mature songwriting. Emo is growing up
column10:
but is Pity Sex?

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23148/homepage_large.7220bb61.jpg|Junjo Presents: Wins the World Cup|31016.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Greensleeves']|2016-05-05 00:00:00|1982|2016-06-11 15:47:10.158210|"

It’s not often that a reissue reframes the narrative around a record. This edition of the 1982 ….Wins the World Cup tells an interesting story and exemplifies a particular moment in Jamaican music history—all the while providing a bit of an object lesson in dub reggae.

The cheekily titled album’s release coincided with the 1982 FIFA World Cup—complete with Tony McDermott’s tell-tale album art depicting a reggae-fied team beating England 6-to-1. Originally titled Scientist Wins the World Cup
column2: the record features the legendary Roots Radics and the studio stylings of Overton H. ""Scientist"" Brown
column3: with producer Henry ""Junjo"" Lawes acting as ""referee."" The tracks are labelled ""Dangerous Match
column4: numbers 1–10
column5: followed by five separate tracks entitled ""Extra Time"" and the final track aptly named ""Golden Goal."" Initially reissued in 2002
column6: the new version seriously ups the ante by providing the whole World Cup-winning game
column7: and then the original versions of the songs. There are also some extra counteraction deejay tunes—vocal versions that provide an alternative perspective. This move places the emphasis on Junjo—and the title therefore shifts to Junjo Presents: Wins the World Cup. Doesn’t have the ring of the original
column8: but it points to the role played by the producer in advance of the dub treatment.

column1: Dub reggae is its own particular thing. A bass-driven
column2: heavy version of reggae
column3: dub breaks down songs into component parts and then sticks them all back together after playing around with all the pieces. Scientist was one of the masters of the form. Born in 1960
column4: he was a teenager as reggae edged into the era of extreme studio experimentation
column5: exemplified by the creative genius of producers such as Lee ""Scratch"" Perry and Osbourne ""King Tubby"" Ruddock. It was Tubby who apparently dubbed him ""Scientist"" after hearing the young Brown talking about his ideas for adjusting and altering studio technology (http://www.niceup.com/interviews/scientist). In the case of …Wins the World Cup
column6: Junjo produced and arranged a series of songs with the Roots Radics and a range of vocalists. These recordings were taken from Channel One on Maxfield Avenue to King Tubby’s Waterhouse Studio in another part of town to be experimented with by Scientist.

column1: The record demonstrates that the general sense some folks have about a shift between the roots- and-culture focus of the 1970s and the degenerative digital dancehall 1980s isn’t really the case. The production prowess of Junjo paired with Scientist’s touch created classic late-70s reggae songs like ""Collie Weed"" by Barrington Levy and Sugar Minnott’s ""Oh Mr D.C.""
column2: but also slack dancehall king Yellowman’s tunes in the early 80s. …Wins the World Cup is the sweet spot right in the middle.

column1: As for the tunes
column2: this collection provides an insight into the dub process by allowing easy side-by-side comparison between vocal originals and dub versions. Listening to Johnny Osbourne’s well-known ""Ice Cream Love"" followed by ""Extra Time One"" draws attention to Scientist’s dropping of the vocal after the first line
column3: echoing in the distance until it is but a trace in the background
column4: just audible under the bass and the added wobble on the guitar. At moments
column5: even the bass drops out
column6: leaving the spare
column7: metallic rhythm
column8: and the reverberation of the drum and that bit of tinny melody. It’s much easier to hear how this provides a near opposite to the ""warmer than chocolate fudge"" original when you can switch back and forth. Little sounds stick out—it’s difficult to not play the game of what’s missing and what’s been added.

column1: The wobbly bits on ""Dangerous Match Three"" the dub version of Hugh Mandell’s ""Jacqueline"" sound like they might be the reason for dubstep being called dubstep. The echo of the drums rings out each measure
column2: being pushed along by the bass
column3: accompanied by the clear jangle of guitar and sparkle of horns. Wayne Jarrett’s vocal on ""Ranny and Lou
column4: a song about two of Jamaica’s most well-loved performers
column5: is virtually eliminated in ""Dangerous Match Ten
column6: drawing attention to piano and organ. The dub treatment tends to play with listener focus
column7: pulling attention from one instrument to the next
column8: seemingly adding extra creaks and beeps just to confound the listener. Regardless
column9:
the weight and depth of these tunes lend them to being played loud and for a long time.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23153/homepage_large.bc3b0088.jpg|Guided Meditation|32717.0|Hurry|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lame-O']|2016-05-05 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:10.742601|"

When Hurry expanded to a trio for 2014’s Everything/Nothing
column2: there were two ways to view Matt Scottoline’s formerly solo project. One: a solid Philadelphia band making fuzzy
column3: mid-fi indie rock. The other was as an offshoot of Everyone Everywhere
column4: who released two of the first truly outstanding albums from emo's fourth wave
column5: albeit ones that predated 2013’s mini-explosion of ""revival"" trendwatching by at least a year. Taken in combination
column6: those two views could work against Scottoline: there are damn near hundreds of solid bands in Philadelphia making fuzzy
column7: mid-fi indie rock and only one Everyone Everywhere
column8: whose near total inactivity since 2012 feels like more of a semi-permanent hiatus than a result of their methodical work ethic.

column1: Hurry's third LP Guided Meditation sounds like a credibility bid for Scottoline's fledgling new band. The cover might be a Brian Eno homage
column2: but there is no magical ""Enoxification"" happening here. Their success is in their ability to be serious about frivolity
column3: which could be an oblique strategy all its own. The difference is entirely present within a rerecorded version of “Shake It Off
column4: which appeared on a stacked 2015 six-way charity split that damn nears as a mini-Singles soundtrack for Philadelphia. Perhaps they figured since it would be associated with Taylor Swift anyways
column5: “Shake It Off"" removes anything that made the original sound bashful—the unnecessary feedback is sheared
column6: the performance is significantly tightened
column7: Scottoline’s vocals aren’t subject to the same fuzz as the guitars. And there you go: Hurry decided they’re really a power-pop band at heart
column8: not indie rock.

column1: Regardless of how much Scottoline’s beloved Yo La Tengo or Guided By Voices influenced the writing of Guided Meditation
column2: this is more in the lineage of the Posies and Matthew Sweet
column3: acts who would’ve been considered pure pop had they existed in a different decade or just simply sold more records. And like them
column4: Scottoline writes from a position of weakness
column5: of being “dumb and in love"" and not always both at the same time: he’s incapable of handling life due to the prospect of a new crush on “Fascination"" (“overthink and overplan imagining you hold my hand"")
column6: uses relationships as a shield from life’s responsibilities (“Under Her Thumb"")
column7: retreats the moment those responsibilities start piling up (“Nothing to Say"") and ends Guided Meditation wishing for a kind of zen existence that requires nothing out of him (“I Wanna Be You"").

column1: They’re adolescent feelings that don’t really ever go away and Scottoline honors them by letting them speak for themselves. Likewise
column2: Hurry doesn’t overcomplicate things musically—they abide by the Weezer Method that states all vocal melodies should sound good as guitar leads and that instant gratification can be replicable gratification. Hurry are capable of expanse and modest grandeur
column3: though like Everyone Everywhere
column4: they find a kind of psychedelia in everyday fatigue—“Love is Elusive"" cruises through six-and-a-half minutes of flanger clouds towards a sunburst of layered harmonies and “Nothing to Say"" feels like companion piece to Everyone Everywhere’s definitive “I Feel Exhausted"" if cubicle-bound anxiety was traded for a three-beer daze at happy hour.

column1: But music this reliant on simple pleasures is also inherently risky. If the melodies don’t connect
column2: there isn’t much to fall back on and occasionally Guided Meditation harkens back to Hurry’s less distinct previous work. Still
column3: the lack of punk or emo or played-out '90s touchstones (i.e.
column4: Pavement or Dinosaur Jr.) in Guided Meditation makes it at least something close to novel in 2016. Fittingly
column5: the most easygoing and instantly ingratiating song here (""When I'm With You"") shares a title with Best Coast. As with Crazy for You
column6: Guided Meditation can be accused of being too simplistic
column7: too sweet and unengaged with the present. But
column8: really: isn't being dumb and in love the most uncomplicated state of being?  So when Scottoline sings
column9: “I don’t even have to try when I’m with you/All the stupid things I say
column10: you know they’re true
column11:
it damn sure sounds like the truth.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23012/homepage_large.00d1aac5.jpg|The Impossible Kid|29.0|Aesop Rock|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rhymesayers']|2016-05-04 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:11.336894|"

Rakim once famously said he thinks of 16-bar verses as a grid and measures out exactly how many syllables can fit neatly within it. If this is true
column2: then Aesop Rock’s grid must look like the cascading sea of glyphs from The Matrix. He has a wickedly extensive vocabulary
column3: once deemed by a study to be the largest in rap
column4: and he uses it to warp time and disrupt balance with phonetic pairings that sprout out unpredictably
column5: an idea best articulated on the Busdriver collaboration ""Ego Death"": ""I am ivy up the goddamn lattice/March to the math rock.""

column1: On ""Rings
column2: the single from his latest album The Impossible Kid and his second on indie rap mainstay Rhymesayers Entertainment
column3: he eulogizes the visual art career he abandoned. ""I left some years
column4: a deer in the light/I left some will to spirit away/I let my fears materialize/I let my skills deteriorate
column5: he raps
column6: splitting all of the syllables on the back end. But he still is a visual artist in his way
column7: coiling carefully articulated sentences into diagrams
column8: each syllable a pixel in the frame of an image. He sketches in vibrant detail on<i> Impossible Kid
column9: balancing heavy verbiage with sharp clarity. This is what it sounds like when rap’s greatest wordsmith only uses the ones that count.

column1: It's also the most specific Aesop Rock has ever been about what he’s thinking or feeling
column2: and it borders at times on confessional. ""Question: If I died in my apartment like a rat in a cage/Would the neighbors smell the corpse before the cat ate my face?/I used to floss the albatross like Daddy Kane with the chain/I’m trying to jettison the ballast with the hazardous waste
column3: he asks on ""Dorks."" That doesn’t mean he’s making it easy; his yarns are still sometimes purposefully written like a puzzle with half the pieces missing. But the album loosely outlines the series of events and strained relationships that led him to abandon San Francisco for the seclusion of a cabin in the woods.

column1: ""Get Out of the Car"" is a poignant reflection on loss and grief that points to the death of close friend and rapper Camu Tao as the starting point for much of his anguish. ""Ah watch the impossible kid
column2: everything that he touch turns promptly to shit/If I zoom on out I can finally admit
column3: it’s all been a blur since ‘Mu got sick
column4: he raps before diving down a rabbit hole of depression
column5: explaining his withdrawal in expertly articulated tidbits and snapshots (""Into the woods go his alien tongue/It was that or a textbook faking of funk
column6: and I can’t""). Then there’s ""Blood Sandwich
column7: which casts his brothers in starring roles in two memorable vignettes: In the first
column8: his younger brother plays in a Little League game interrupted by a wayward gopher
column9: a rodent that suffers a bloody end at the hands of the enraged coach. The second is a remembrance of his older brother's teen angst at being denied the opportunity to go to a Ministry show
column10: resulting in a suicide threat. Later on
column11: he studies the actions of his cat on ""Kirby"" before psychoanalyzing their relationship and society’s larger relationship with the felines as a whole
column12: which have been everything from gods to memes. Each one of these songs constructs little worlds out of simple ideas using dexterous lyricism.

column1: But The Impossible Kid is measured by more than its virtuosity. The soundbeds of dizzying synth abstractions
column2: ominous piano crawls
column3: and slow-strutting garage rock samples
column4: all provided by Aesop Rock himself
column5: are monuments to his growing skills as a producer. He is as detail-oriented with his beats as he is with his raps
column6: providing the right mood at every occasion. Some of them are busy and swarming
column7: while others are pleasantly simple
column8: like ""Lotta Years
column9: giving Aesop the room to set up dialogue. Then there are beats that are simply hard-hitting
column10: like ""Rabies"" and ""Water Tower
column11: with slapping drums that seem traditional until they stagger. These all supplement his writing
column12: which is as crisp and as fluid as it has ever been
column13: bending breakbeats to the whims of his strung-out cadences. Aesop Rock has yet to run out of words. After nearly 20-years in the rap game
column14:
he is still finding new means of self-expression.

column1:

The email address Egyptian Lover lists on his Facebook profile
column2: like Egyptian Lover himself
column3: is a cipher and a time capsule
column4: and not just because it exists on the ancient servers of former dial-up titans AOL. His handle is egyptianlover661
column5: where 661 is a reference to DMSR-661
column6: the catalog number for the first record a young Greg Broussard ever put out on his own Egyptian Empire label back in 1984. ""DMSR"" was a reference to his idol Prince’s 1999 ""D.M.S.R."" (Dance Music Sex Romance). The record was called ""Egypt
column7: Egypt
column8: and it became a hit and a West Coast hip hop/electro staple. In making it
column9: Egyptian Lover drew on both Prince (May He Rest in Peace and Reign in Purple) and Kraftwerk. He combined the melody from Kraftwerk's ""Trans Europe Express"" that Afrika Bambaataa had sampled on ""Planet Rock
column10: flipping it and inserting it into his own electrofunk framework
column11: with the addition of some heavy breathing à la The Purple One.

column1: ""Egypt
column2: Egypt"" along with 21 other tracks have now been compiled
column3: smartly sequenced
column4: and packaged into 1983-1988
column5: a 4-LP Stones Throw anthology that charts the Lover’s reign over West Coast hip hop during that same time. The anthology itself contains the majority of Egyptian Lover’s On the Nile album (including ""Egypt
column6: Egypt"") with a couple of fresh re-edits from Stones Throw’s Peanut Butter Wolf (""Yes
column7: Yes
column8: Yes"" and ""My Beat Goes Boom"")
column9: 12"" singles
column10: never-released material
column11: and others—all taken from the original master tapes. The anthology is mostly chronological
column12: and the accompanying booklet contains a track-by-track breakdown as recounted by the Lover himself. (Full disclosure: Pitchfork contributor Jeff Weiss wrote the liner notes.) There aren’t any big sonic shifts or tracks that speak to particular ""phases"" the Egyptian Lover went through
column13: mainly because for the years between '83-'88 and for the entire 30 years he’s been in the game
column14: he’s primarily only had one phase and overarching sound: old-school electrofunk—that '80s 808-driven
column15: Parliament- and Kraftwerk-inspired
column16: breakbeats-referencing
column17: futuristic-yet-analog pastiche that laid the foundation for everything from g-funk to techno to Miami bass that followed.

column1: Egyptian Lover has remained similarly faithful over the years to his persona as a freak-a-holic pharaoh blasted forth from that bend in the space-time continuum known as his mind. His origin myth begins in high school
column2: by which time he was already making and selling his own pause-button mixtapes to other students under his Egyptian Lover moniker. Broussard says he got his name in part from Rudolph Valentino
column3: the famous white actor who played an ""Arab sheik"" in <i>The Sheik
column4: during that vibrant era of racist 1920s black and white films. The young Greg Broussard was drawn to Valentino’s savoir faire. Additionally
column5: growing up in South Central Los Angeles in the '70s and '80s
column6: he was drawn to King Tut
column7: who represented to him a kind of mystique
column8: power
column9: and escape. Hence ""Egyptian Lover"" was born.

column1: Not long after graduating high school
column2: the young Lover was invited to join the ranks of Uncle Jamm’s Army
column3: the top LA dance party crew at the time. KDAY Radio bumped them constantly
column4: and at their peak
column5: they filled up 10
column6: 000-capacity sports arenas. The Egyptian Lover became Uncle Jamm’s star DJ
column7: spinning
column8: scratching
column9: and wreaking freaky havoc on dancefloors across LA
column10: alongside Unknown DJ
column11: Cli-N-Tel
column12: Chris ""The Glove"" Taylor
column13: and Ice-T
column14: among others. The latter two
column15: along with Egyptian Lover
column16: can be seen working their magic at the infamous Radio Club (later Radiotron) in the landmark West Coast hip hop documentary Breakin’ N’ Enterin’. Not accidentally
column17: Lover had also been hired to score the film
column18: and two of those tracks are featured on the anthology: ""Egyptian Lover Theme"" and ""Spray It Super AJ.""

column1: These LA mobile dance party crews
column2: including World Class Wreckin’ Cru and LA Dream Team
column3: were where a number of prominent West Coast DJs
column4: producers
column5: and MCs got their start. World Class Wreckin’ Cru
column6: which included a young Dr. Dre
column7: along with fellow future NWA member Yella
column8: followed swiftly in Uncle Jamm’s steps in producing electro hits like ""Surgery"" and ""Juice""—but only after Uncle Jamm’s had already changed the game a year earlier by being the first LA crew to press to vinyl
column9: producing hits like ""Dial-A-Freak"" and ""Yes
column10: Yes
column11: Yes
column12: which now find their place on 1983-1988.

column1: Since then
column2: Egyptian Lover’s sound hasn’t changed a whole lot
column3: but in the 30-some years he’s been in the game
column4: he’s been able to manipulate a lot of different sounds out of the machines he uses. Often
column5: this has meant his beloved 808 in various combinations with turntables
column6: a mic
column7: vocoder
column8: and SH-101 bass synth (among others). Clocking in at just under 2 minutes
column9: ""What is a DJ if He Can’t Scratch"" is a quick flex on all the DJs who can’t scratch
column10: MCs who can’t rap
column11: and beats made without live claps. A more minimalistic and rhythm-focused cut from his debut album On the Nile
column12: the track shows off EL’s scratching techniques
column13: including his ability to play a record backwards entirely on-beat. By contrast
column14: ""I Cry (Night After Night)"" from the same album
column15: is the most melodic and Prince-ly pop song of the lot and even incorporates electric guitar. Egyptian Lover whimpers
column16: recounting his nightly walks staring up at the stars
column17: looking himself in the mirror
column18: and bemoaning an unrequited love interest. Over '80s drum smacks
column19: he programs high
column20: breathy
column21: Prince-inspired call-and-response vocals and twinkly bells that ornament his raps
column22: which are equal parts horny and humorous.

column1: Lover also wasn’t afraid to stretch hip-hop into more experimental territory. The track ""Electric Encounter
column2: which was never actually completed until the making of this anthology
column3: is basically a conceptual electronic number set to a hard funk beat. ""Gears (gears)
column4: belts (belts)
column5: recites a chipmunk voice
column6: running through a long list of ""computer"" parts. ""Plugs (plugs)
column7: switches (switches)
column8: nuts (nuts)
column9: and bolts (and bolts)."" Over the course of the song
column10: this computer’s desire for an electric encounter burns through its inner circuitry
column11: and a heavily distorted hardware meltdown ensues
column12: resulting in a gloopy puddle of busted wires and melted transistors.

column1: This tendency to blur the lines between human and machine
column2: reality and fantasy
column3: and present and future is a hallmark of Egyptian Lover’s particular imagination—as well as of electro more broadly. ""Kinky Nation
column4: originally released on One Track Mind (1986)
column5: lays out Lover’s vision of his kingdom come. It’s a sexual paradise guarded by a robot with a talk box for a voice
column6: who greets visitors at the gates with a mechanized
column7: ""Wel-come-to-the-kin-ky-na-tion."" Like many of Broussard’s songs
column8: ""Kinky Nation"" also leans on old popular cultural depictions of Ancient Egypt–which have often relied on exotification
column9: or even cartoonification
column10: and which even today affect popular (mis)understandings of modern Egypt and Egyptians. On ""My House (On the Nile)
column11: as on ""Kinky Nation
column12: EL describes his sex pad on the Nile
column13: complete with camels out back and Egyptian women for whom ""there’s no substitute."" To be sure
column14: Egyptian Lover injects a lot of humor into his music
column15: but sometimes
column16: as in the box set’s recent infomercial or in his songs about bellydancers
column17: the way the exoticism plays out can feel questionable or off-color.

column1: That said
column2: Egyptian Lover’s imagination is still colorful in other ways. On that same ""My House (On the Nile)"" record
column3: he talks about getting freaky on his 50-foot waterbed flanked by solid gold speakers
column4: from which blast the very song he’s singing. ""Dial-A-Freak
column5: an early track from his Uncle Jamm’s days
column6: is all about phone sex
column7: an exercise in pornographic imagination if there ever was one. And on 1983-1988’s final track
column8: ""I Need A Freak
column9: a remake of (unfortunately named) electro group Sexual Harassment’s single of the same name that Egyptian Lover then put on his 1994 Back From The Tomb album
column10: and which now features additional synth work by Dam Funk
column11: he raps
column12: ""In these times of hate and pain
column13: we need a remedy to take us from the rain…I need a freak!"" In the liner notes
column14: Egyptian Lover mentions that when he first heard the song back in the day
column15:
he thought it sounded like Prince. So it seems only right that this is the note this anthology should end on.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23193/homepage_large.f2bb0e44.jpg|Nonagon Infinity|32633.0|King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2016-05-04 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:12.243951|"

 Since the advent of digital music
column2: all media players have been outfitted with the Repeat function—whether it’s a button on a traditional CD player
column3: or those circular lines you click on in your iTunes app. I’m willing to bet no one has ever activated this feature on purpose
column4: yet it always seems to mysteriously switch itself on. The effect is always jarring
column5: the contemplative post-listen pause rudely interrupted by an abrupt jump back to the opening track. It’s the ultimate useless proof-of-concept innovation
column6: something that exists simply because it can. But as it turns out
column7: whichever technicians invented this functionality were onto something—because they were effectively preparing us for the advent of King Gizzard & the Lizard Wizard’s Nonagon Infinity.

column1: Over the course of eight wildly divergent albums
column2: the Melbourne psych-rock septet have fed the past 50 years of rock history through a paper shredder and seamlessly taped the strands back together in intriguing new patterns
column3: even leaving in the parts (bluesy harmonica slobber
column4: flute solos
column5: jazz odysseys) that more cool-conscious retro-rock revivalists would excise. And through experimenting with myriad sounds
column6: they’ve also started experimenting with album formats. Last year’s Quarters! presented four prog-pop suites each clocking at exactly 10 minutes and 10 seconds. But Nonagon Infinity ups the high-concept ante to absurd extremes. While pieced together from discretely recorded
column7: separately titled songs
column8: the record is mixed to feel like a continuous 41-minute live performance
column9: complete with recurring musical and lyrical passages. And it’s the first album in history to give you a legitimate
column10: practical reason to hit that Repeat button—Nonagon Infinity is constructed as an infinite loop
column11: meaning its final notes connect perfectly with the album’s opening.

column1: But independent of that gambit
column2: Nonagon Infinity is the Gizzard’s most ballistic
column3: berserker album to date
column4: a merciless
column5: atomic-bomb erasure of the pastoral terrain traversed by its flower-powered predecessor
column6: Paper Mâché Dream Balloon. In their most hot-wired moments (see 2014’s I’m in Your Mind Fuzz)
column7: King Gizzard have earned copious comparisons to their former label patrons Thee Oh Sees
column8: and here frontman Stu Mackenzie punctuates almost every chord change with an echo-drenched
column9: John Dwyer-esque “wooo” like a dancehall selector pushing the air-horn button. But on Nonagon Infinity
column10: they assume a more mechanistic precision and sinister
column11: metallic force—all the better to reinforce the lyrics’ '70s sci-fi cartoon-show universe of robots
column12: monsters
column13: and hidden dimensions. Ironically
column14: for an album that functions as a shrine to record-collector rock
column15: Nonagon Infinity operates on the same principles as a club DJ set
column16: weaving in and out of different melodic motifs while remaining locked (for the most part) into a propulsive
column17: breakneck rhythm that sounds like Devo riffing on Hawkwind’s “Motorhead.”

column1: When it’s running at peak velocity—which is like
column2: 90 per cent of the time—Nonagon Infinity yields some of the most outrageous
column3: exhilarating rock ‘n’ roll in recent memory
column4: on par with modern psych-punk touchstones like Comets on Fire’s Blue Cathedral
column5: Thee Oh Sees’ Carrion Crawler/The Dream and Ty Segall’s Slaughterhouse. It’s a preview of what our not-too-distant future of hyperloop travel will feel like—this is a record that requires protective seat belts
column6: induces G-force ripples in your cheeks and drives fingernails into armrest upholstery. But the band’s gonzo attack never overpowers Mackenzie’s psych-pop accessibility
column7: as he spits out a stream of fragmented hooks like a combusting jukebox of British Invasion singles going on the fritz. If anything
column8: his melodic change-ups provide crucial orientation markers on this endless Autobahn of a record. The band also possess an innate sense of knowing just the right moment to switch things up
column9: like with the loose Krautrock boogie that introduces “Mr. Beat
column10: or the twinned Allman Brothers leads dropped into the “TV Eye”-style surge of ""Evil Death Roll
column11: or the Yes-worthy contoro-riffs that overtake “Invisible Face”. (That said
column12: the incense-scented Santana jam that breaks out partway through the latter piece constitutes the record’s only forced detour.)

column1: Ultimately
column2: the question of how the band will reconcile the chugging
column3: roadhouse-razing closer “Road Train” with the album’s motorik opening proves moot—in Nonagon Infinity’s final minute
column4: the Gizzard effectively bring the former to a dead stop and then just quickly work themselves back up into the album’s familiar high-octane groove. At first
column5: it feels like a bit of a cheat—a switcheroo the band could’ve conceivably dropped at any point in this piece
column6: rather than a natural climax they’re working toward. But the instant Nonagon Infinity resets back to its blitzkrieged beginning
column7:
the gimmick’s greater purpose is revealed: this is the first album whose intro actually doubles as its crescendo. And Nonagon Infinity is overstuffed with so many stomach-tossing thrills that you’ll actually be jonesing to ride the roller-coaster all over again.
