It's ironic that Dan Boeckner sings so specifically about dreaming on four of the 10 songs that make up Operators' full-length debut. While Blue Wave showcases enough synth-centric production to meet all of the requirements to recreate a genre once widely referred to as dream pop
column2: the songs on this album teem with such agitation that it could be the photo negative of that style: nightmare pop.

column1: Operators is the latest act from a man who has played vital roles in Wolf Parade
column2: Handsome Furs
column3: and Divine Fits. With this project
column4: Boeckner—along with bandmates Sam Brown and Devojka—has discovered the secret ingredient missing from so much of the music meant to reawaken the new wave sound of the 1980s: paranoia
column5: at a peppy tempo. Between fear of Orwellian prophesies coming true in 1984 and the Cold War machine springing to life
column6: there was plenty to be paranoid about in the 1980s
column7: and the current political climate demands that more music be spiked with anxiety.

column1: There's plenty of that to spare with Blue Wave. Throughout the album
column2: Big Brother is watching as a pervasive ""they"": ""They come to correct you"" in ""Control""; ""They wanna see you moving underground"" in ""Cold Light""; and ""While we were sleeping
column3: dreaming in our beds they moved the Earth"" in ""Evil.""  And like the best alarmist music of the Reagan era
column4: this is all delivered with super danceable beats and synth sounds so fat and fizzy that they feel like the original analog instruments
column5: rather than imitations by computer plug-ins. Boeckner's melodies are precise and the choruses show moments of bright clarity cutting through the foggy verses: not unlike fleeing a bleak reality to find asylum in a dream. He hasn't sounded this committed and angry since leading Atlas Strategic a decade and a half ago.

column1: Boeckner captures a mood well
column2: and his approach to the past is one of aggressive repurposing. Operators do à la carte shopping for 1983 tones and lyrical inspiration
column3: boldly loading up at the buffet to get their money's worth. What could be a more fitting tribute to a decade of such excess? The title track borrows the flangey echo guitar of ""I Ran
column4: the chugging rhythm of ""Major Tom (Coming Home)"" and the ba-dada ba-dada sax punches of ""Modern Love
column5: a song from which Boeckner generously paraphrased lyrically on the single ""Ecstasy at My House"" last year. Boeckner has a history of brazenly overindulging on influences: with Handsome Furs' ""All We Want
column6: Baby
column7: Is Everything
column8: he borrowed so heavily that the need to legally clear a song with New Order reportedly delayed the Furs' second album. Speaking of New Order
column9: Peter Hook's bass sound is all over Blue Wave too.

column1: There are times when Boeckner's phrasing feels so stylized that it borders on unnatural: nobody really says ""gown"" in a way that rhymes with ""phone."" But this is what dedication sounds like. Towards the end of the album
column2: Boeckner delivers a telling line in the song
column3: ""Nobody
column4: when he sings
column5: ""I rip my life up and tear it apart/Before I start."" This is his thing
column6: violent reinvention
column7: and he'll likely do it again with the upcoming Wolf Parade reunion. Here's hoping that he comes back to Operators
column8: though if the last line of the album is any indication
column9: it won't be for a while. ""Wake up with me
column10: he sings. And like that
column11:
the dream is over.

Katy B’s songs tend to orbit people and relationships
column4: but they’re just as often about rooms
column5: and the way music sounds inside of those rooms
column6: or the way that environmental combinations of music and desire can distort one’s sense of time. ""Let history repeat / in parallel lines
column7: she sang on Little Red’s ""5 AM
column8: describing not only the small infinities implied by dance music but the recursive structure of desire itself.

column1: On her new album
column2: Honey
column3: Katy B seems to want to sublimate herself even further into the texture of her music
column4: as if to emphasize the distinct rooms she finds herself in; each of the producers and singers she works with on the album receives equal credit with her
column5: and most of them are located deep with the roster of Rinse FM
column6: the radio station/label that’s released each of her records. She isn’t lost so easily. The album’s centerpiece is a collaboration with jackin’ house producer Chris Lorenzo called ""I Wanna Be
column7: the instrumental of the which has been floating around the internet since 2014. Katy B gives the diffuse beat gravity and narrative drama; it ceases to be a tightly-cropped brightness and unfolds and shimmers into a complete emotional landscape. ""I wanna tell you / but anxiety’s a bitch babe
column8: she sings
column9: unlocking inner melodies and tensions from otherwise iridescent
column10: smooth house.

column1: Where Little Red saw Katy throwing herself into the occasional ballad
column2: Honey is reduced to a pure set of dance music; within these aesthetic limits
column3: though
column4: it may be her most varied record stylistically. On ""So Far Away
column5: produced by Wilkinson
column6: drum and bass production gathers and collides together
column7: and Katy weaves through it in deliberate swerves. ""Calm Down
column8: written with Floating Points and Four Tet
column9: features strings that saw crisply through the track and then rematerialize in ribbony masses. Only on ""Lose Your Head
column10: with grime MCs J Hus and D Double E
column11: does Katy B feel like a hook singer on her own song
column12: which causes it feels drawn from an entirely different order of work. Because of the wide range of producers
column13: the songs on Honey can feel unrelated to each other
column14: and often settle together indifferently.

column1: Oddly enough Honey starts to snap into focus on a track originally released last year as a single by KDA
column2: ""Turn the Music Louder (Rumble)
column3: itself a vocal rework of an earlier instrumental; on the album version
column4: Tinie Tempeh is subtracted from the song
column5: and Katy B draws the verses and chorus of the song into a subterranean gravity.  Songs like these show Katy B at her best
column6: caught up in the flow of something so overwhelming she can’t see the beginning or the end of it
column7: time expanding and collapsing with her in its center.

column1: As with Little Red
column2: the ideal way of hearing Honey is in its continuous mix
column3: but where Little Red’s arranged all of its album and bonus tracks into a kind of diagram of a long
column4: frustrating night out
column5: Honey’s continuous mix merely places opaque tempo shifts between each song. Regardless
column6: the album feels more connected and coherent when experienced in this way
column7: when the listener is allowed to enter a portal before the next distinct context asserts itself
column8:
and where Katy herself feels like she’s stretching seamlessly from one dimension into another.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22970/homepage_large.ecfb418b.jpg|Close To the Noise Floor - Formative UK Electronica 1975 - 1984|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cherry Red']|2016-05-03 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:13.849074|"

The evolutionary arc of the synthesizer has a completely different shape from the trajectory of the electric guitar. With a few exceptions
column2: the guitar started out as a crude generator of exciting noise and dance energy—a fundamentally teenage sound. Then it gradually became an ever more subtle expressive implement
column3: with a huge textural range. Synths
column4: in contrast
column5: started out prog: they cost a fortune and were challenging to operate
column6: and this made them the preserve of established performers generally of virtuosic and artistically ambitious bent. Either that
column7: or synthesizers belonged to institutions like universities and were accessible only to composers with equally lofty purposes in mind.

column1: The primitivist phase of the synthesizer came after the sophisticated start. In the late 1970s
column2: cheaper machines like the Wasp became available; they were also compact
column3: portable
column4: and relatively user-friendly compared with their bulky predecessors. This democratization of electronics happened to coincide with rock’s own self-conscious return to juvenile basics in the form of punk. All of a sudden
column5: the synth was competing with the guitar to be the true instrument of do-it-yourself. For many
column6: the synth won that contest handily—you didn’t even need to learn two chords
column7: you could riff out abstract blurts of nasty noise or play one-finger melodies. Furthermore
column8: synths and the rudimentary drum machines that were also newly available encouraged a “non-musical” (at least in rock terms) approach. Rather than jam your way to a song through the intuitive logic of groove and feel
column9: tracks could be built up through addition and subtraction
column10: using a hypnotic but uninflected machine-beat as a grid for the assembly process.

column1: Close To the Noise Floor is a 4xCD survey of the excitingly messy birth of British electronica during the late '70s and early '80s. One of the maps for the set compiler Richard Anderson used is “Wild Planet
column2: ” a celebrated three-part feature written by Dave Henderson for the music weekly Sounds. The 1983 article spawned a regular Sounds column dedicated to the cassette underground of tiny labels like Flowmotion and Third Mind. Henderson contributes a short but vivid memoir-style introduction to this box set and also features in his musical guise as a member of Worldbackwards
column3: a group whose ambition was to sound like “Throbbing Gristle on Tamla Motown.”

column1: “Minimal synth” works as a shorthand tag for Close To the Noise Floor’s remit
column2: although the scope of the trawl is actually wider and more disparate than what that term tends to signify
column3: taking in electro-punk
column4: industrial
column5: synthpop
column6: dark ambient
column7: and more. Rather than use generic focus as an organizing principle
column8: the anthology achieves coherence through sticking with a single country—Britain—when it could have easily have swept across the equally active European scene or harvested the scattered but significant American exponents like John Bender and Nervous Gender.

column1: The national focus makes sense historically
column2: in so far as the UK scene was catalyzed by half-a-dozen native outfits who released debut singles within a few months of each other in mid-1978: the Normal
column3: Human League
column4: Throbbing Gristle
column5: Cabaret Voltaire
column6: Thomas Leer
column7: and Robert Rental. The combined impact of these singles—respectively “T.V.O.D.
column8: ” “Being Boiled
column9: ” “United
column10: ” the Extended Play EP
column11: “Private Plane
column12: ” and “Paralysis”—was as galvanizing as Buzzcocks’s “Spiral Scratch” had been for scrappy DIY guitar-groups a year earlier.

column1: Noise Floor’s first disc concentrates on the children of Throbbing Gristle and “Warm Leatherette” (the more influential B-side to The Normal’s “T.V.O.D.”). No spacey ripples or groovy Moogy sensuality here: the synth is used aggressively and obnoxiously. One gem in this vein is Storm Bugs’ “Little Bob Minor
column2: with its ear-itching drones whose texture resembles a comb-and-paper kazoo. Vocals
column3: when they appear
column4: are usually screams or creepy spoken-word soundbites
column5: as with the cut-up voices from a radio interview with prostitutes that appear on We Be Echo’s “Sexuality.”

column1: The stand-out track on the first disc
column2: though
column3: is a bit of an anomaly: Thomas Leer’s “Tight As a Drum
column4: ” from his fabulous EP 4 Movements. By 1981
column5: Leer had left behind the gratingly foreboding ambiences of The Bridge
column6: his collaborative album with Robert Rental
column7: and absorbed the mutant disco influence of New York’s ZE label. 4 Movements also sounds like he’s letting back in some of the banished musicality of pre-punk rock
column8: figures like Island Records folk-blues minstrel John Martyn. “Tight As a Drum” swings because although the percussion is electronic
column9: Leer played it by hand on pads; the intricate weave of synth-melodies over the top sounds vaguely Middle Eastern in its ornamented filigree. The song seems to reach your ears through the heat-haze coming off a sun-baked road. A snapshot of a moment of tension so exquisitely taut it’s a kind of ecstasy
column10: “Tight As a Drum” features the briefest of spoken-not-sung lyrics: a depiction of a young man stretching himself
column11: silhouetted against the morning light streaming through a window.

column1: Embracing mainstream ideas of melody and musicality doesn’t work so well on the second disc
column2: which mostly features groups who reach towards pop but don’t get even as close as the Human League did on “Being Boiled” (included here). Performance art duo SchleImer K’s “Broken Vein” suggests Soft Cell sans the soaring voice and heart-swelling tunes; Native Europe’s “The Distance from Köln” is a lo-fi cousin to Berlin’s '80s radio staple “The Metro”; lyrically if not so much sonically
column3: Cultural Amnesia’s 1981 anti-Thatcherism ditty “Materialistic Man” comes over like a dry run for Depeche Mode’s “Everything Counts."" The better tunes come from those who actually managed to make it as pop stars. “A New Kind of Man
column4: ” an unreleased solo single by ex-Ultravox singer John Foxx
column5: features a vocal that—typical for the emerging synthpop genre—sounds glacial and torrid at the same time
column6: plus lyrics like scraps from an abandoned and torn-up screenplay: “An underwater kind of silence/Humming of electric pylons/Don’t forget me/Fits of static/Another scene began.” Heard in its superior 1980 album version rather than original incarnation
column7: Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark’s “Almost” sounds like a spindly North-of-England Kraftwerk—graph-paper rhythm
column8: sobbing synth.

column1: Livening up the second disc—otherwise a bit of slog—are specimens from the post-punk mini-genre of parody. The late '70s erupted with cover versions that swapped reverent reinterpretation for willfully goofy travesty—think Flying Lizards’ deadpan take on “Money
column2: “ or the Dickies’s punked-up “Nights in White Satin.” The idea
column3: I think
column4: was to show just how much distance there was now between Old Wave and New Wave—or
column5: if the cover was of a contemporary hit
column6: how far from chart-pop convention you could push the song.

column1: That’s the nature of the game with British Standard Unit’s deconstructive molesting of Rod Stewart’s “D’Ya Think I’m Sexy
column2: ” which became a John Peel radio show fave in 1979 with its grotesquely sped-up voices and anti-disco jerkiness. B.S.U. was just one of numerous guises worn by ex-Mott the Hoople keyboard player Morgan Fisher for a covers album project called Hybrid Kids - A Collection of Classic Mutants. “Gerry and the Holograms
column3: ” by the group of the same name
column4: isn’t a cover but a lampoon of the emergent synthpop genre itself
column5: wrought by two members of the cult band Alberto Y Lost Trios Paranoias (whose output consisted almost entirely of parodies such as their punk-mocking Snuff Rock EP). “Gerry and the Holograms” has been identified as the melodic source for New Order’s “Blue Monday
column6: ” but to these ears sounds more like The Stooges’s “I Wanna Be Your Dog” covered by BBC Radiophonic Workshop. In a word
column7: awesome.

column1: That pair of whimsies could equally have been squeezed onto the last disc of Close To the Noise Floor
column2: which corrals an array of unclassifiable oddities. Although electronic in feel
column3: more often than not the sounds here are achieved via conventional instruments subjected to heavy treatments. Here the forebears
column4: if any exist
column5: are the Residents and Cabaret Voltaire (who in their early days used effects-processed flute and guitar more than synths). Renaldo and the Loaf’s “Dying Inside” sounds ripe for sampling by Kanye West on Pablo II. Unable to afford synths
column6: the duo used effects pedals to render their instruments and voices as inorganic and alien-sounding as possible. Alien Brains’ “Menial Disorders” has a great backstory (the project started in the physics lab at the group’s high school and mainly deployed a “Loopotron
column7: ” a self-cobbled tape-echo machine that used the erase head to alter the sound) which is matched by the sound itself : a cloud of mechanical gnats circling around your head
column8: fizzing zig-zags of hi-hat
column9: corrugated crumples of texture
column10: rhythm like bed springs pinging inside a giant reverberant cistern.

column1: Most of Noise Floor’s contents are shaped by twin prohibitions. First and foremost
column2: the goal was to sound as un-rock’n’roll and un-American as possible (which is why the vocals
column3: when they appear
column4: are usually absurdly English—stiff-backed
column5: groomed-sounding
column6: somehow short-haired). But there was a secondary impulse at work too: to break with the conventions of synth-based music established in the first half of the ’70s by groups like Tangerine Dream and Klaus Schulze
column7: who favored long-form compositions (often taking up an entire album side) and an atmosphere of celestial serenity.

column1: Now you might have noticed that I jumped right past this box’s third disc. That’s because in some ways it’s the most intriguing of the four
column2: precisely because it’s full of post-punk DIY that still took its bearings from the pre-punk electronic cosmonauts. Maximal Synth
column3: you could call this stuff: operators like Sea of Wires
column4: MFH
column5: and Mark Shreeve
column6: who
column7: rather than ape “Warm Leatherette” or Cabaret Voltaire’s “Silent Command
column8: parallel the billowing pulse-scapes being made at that same time by Manuel Gottsching on albums like 1978’s Blackouts. This sound—late period kosmische drifting towards New Age or proto-techno—has in recent years enjoyed a measure of renewed currency thanks to Emeralds and their ilk
column9: but generally it’s been written right out of history.

column1: One of the groups included on Disc 3 are actually a totally pre-punk proposition. Zorch took their battery of EMS Synthi As and light show to free festivals all across England
column2: including the very first Stonehenge Festival in 1974. Hearing their “Adrenalin (Return of the Elohim Pt. 1)” made me wish for a time machine so I could experience its spaceship-landing whooshes panning around the megalithic columns and frazzling the minds of the gathered long-hairs. In a similar amorphous vein
column3: Ron Berry’s “Sea of Tranquility” is an elegiac homage to the Moon Landing. But “Triptych” by EG Oblique Graph (Bryn Jones
column4: later better known as Muslimgauze) is less beatific
column5: recalling the sensory-deprivation aesthetic of Conrad Schnitzler: insidiously hissing percussion and color-leached tones
column6: like a wintry after-dark walk through a Berlin pedestrian underpass.

column1: Despite the omission of obvious classics like “Warm Leatherette” or Fad Gadget’s “Ricky’s Hand” (presumably because the Mute label archive was off-limits to the compiler) Close To the Noise Floor provides a fascinating overview of the formative years of British home-studio electronica: groups who were precursors in spirit
column2: if not direct lineage
column3: to the techno and IDM artists of the ’90s. Still
column4: with the cult for “minimal wave” now a decade old
column5: it almost feels like another task has become urgent: the rediscovery of the groups that did the groundwork for the outfits on Disc 3 of Noise Floor. Time
column6: perhaps
column7: for a box set that does justice to major label synth-rock of the ’70s: figures like Tomita
column8: pre-Chariots of Fire Vangelis
column9: Michael Hoenig
column10: Ralph Lundsten
column11: even Jean Michel-Jarre. Rather than the underground
column12: which enjoys a healthy complement of dedicated curators and salvage operators
column13: it’s the mainstream of that era that is truly lost
column14:
that in a strange way seems even more exotic and remote in time.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['DFA']|2016-05-03 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:14.435142|"

While James Murphy and his cohorts in LCD Soundsystem are busy touring the globe while positioning themselves as voices of a generation that may have partied a little too hard for a little too long
column3: their DFA labelmates Holy Ghost! are engineering a notable return to form with Crime Cutz
column4: their first EP of new material since their 2013 sophomore record
column5: Dynamics. Up until now
column6: Holy Ghost!'s arguable greatest achievement was their debut single
column7: ""Hold On
column8: a track brilliant enough to carry the band from its release in 2007 to their debut album four years later. The four sprawling
column9: joyous dance tracks on Crime Cutz finally follow up ""Hold On"" with something equally substantial. It's a bright
column10: tight
column11: tense mini-epic
column12: solidifying the band as one of the pillars of the mid-'00s disco resurgence.

column1: The EP's titular opener begins with a drudged-out minute of spacey synths before bursting into full-fledged disco: arpeggiated synthesizers
column2: falsettos
column3: super-dry guitar riffs
column4: an angelic choir of diva vocals
column5: and a hands-to-the-heavens chorus of ""You lift me up and up! Up and off the floor!"" Many of these elements could be regarded as pure retro revivalism
column6: but Holy Ghost!'s touch is light enough to make the song transcend its obvious crib notes.

column1: Crime Cutz doesn't draw only from disco
column2: however. There's a distinct '80s-pop aura permeating the record
column3: courtesy of over-the-top pop arrangements and frontman Alex Frankel's earnest blue-eyed R&B vocal style. ""Stereotype"" recalls old-school dancefloor staples from the likes of Colonel Abrams
column4: Rockwell
column5: and even Jermaine Stewart
column6: gems from the post-Thriller R&B boom that produced countless hits. Frankel sings with the uninhibited glee of someone karaoke-ing ""P.Y.T."" at a high school house party circa 1984. ""I know I'm a stereotype
column7: he croons
column8: ""don't be so critical […] Let go."" You'd expect nothing but seriousness from a band that is this on top of their history
column9: but they understand that half of what makes this type of music fun is its abandon.

column1: Another highlight
column2: ""Compass Point
column3: adds another instrumental layer with a welcome and  unexpected surge of horns near the end. If anything
column4: Crime Cutz's weakness lies in its lack of diversity—you spend a lot of the record hoping for something to take them even further over the edge
column5: but they continue to pull back until the very end. ""Footsteps
column6: the record's closer
column7: is the only track that slightly misses the mark
column8: leaning a little too heavily on all the touchstones mentioned above. It barely touches the overall effect of Crime Cutz
column9: though
column10: and if this EP is indeed a precursor to a new full length
column11:
we have reason to be excited.

In the middle of the last decade
column2: Serengeti starting carving out a niche as one of the weirdest and most confounding voices in underground rap
column3: grappling with the tension between art and commerce and the tension between the industrial painter and his smocks. But the Windy City rapper born David Cohn is best known as someone else entirely—Kenny Dennis
column4: the aging rapper he dreamed up
column5: the one who hates Shaq but loves the '85 Chicago Bears
column6: his wife Jueles
column7: O’Douls
column8: brats
column9: beers
column10: and the actor Brian Dennehy.

column1: Kenny isn’t a joke
column2: and he isn’t a one-off; he’s been animated on a handful of full-length records and a masterful EP
column3: and even the fictitious rap group Kenny was supposed to be a member of  during the early '90s got its own
column4: very real album. Kenny has hopes
column5: fears
column6: insecurities
column7: blind spots. In short
column8: Cohn knows how to build worlds.

column1: Testarossa
column2: the second-full length collaboration between Cohn and WHY?’s Yoni Wolf
column3: credits the rapper as Serengeti. While swapping one stage name for another is not necessarily truth-telling
column4: it’s implied that when compared to Kenny Dennis
column5: Serengeti more closely approximates the feelings and experiences of David Cohn. But when Geti lets you into his own psyche
column6: it’s through fractured narratives and half-truths
column7: ill-advised blogging ventures and apocryphal trips to the hardware store. The last Geti/Yoni LP
column8: 2011’s Family & Friends
column9: was intermittently brilliant
column10: but also unremittingly dark. (The standout song from that record
column11: ""The Whip
column12: is a portrait of a retired UFC fighter trying desperately to get back in the octagon.) The sequel has fewer songs that are obvious conceptual departures
column13: but finds Geti just as slippery
column14: just as evasive.

column1: The album follows a narrative of sorts
column2: purportedly based on a script that Geti and Yoni co-wrote about a fledgling musician who leaves his wife and young children at home to head out on tour
column3: only to watch his family dissolve from afar. As always
column4: Cohn finds the emotional weight of the story in the crevices: in the weight he gained one winter with his wife
column5: in the rental cars he uses to assume new identities in new towns. On ""I
column6: Testarossa
column7: his character wrings his hands over the length of his daughter’s bangs and shoves bills into a jukebox to make strangers dance.

column1: The production and Wolf’s vocals are lush and subdued to where the story feels like one long dream sequence. Its best moments come when Geti yanks you violently into a scene
column2: like he does during a conversation with a girl outside a venue on ""Down"": ""I’m waiting for Yoni outside in a coat/ Smelling like coke
column3: sipping on a smoke/ Talking to a young girl
column4: trying to steal hope/ Leaning in like the pope/ ‘Yo
column5: let’s get down.’"" There’s that economy of language
column6: that willingness to sneak vials into the Vatican that make him one of rap’s sharpest writers. Unfortunately
column7: moments like that are too infrequent on the album’s spare front half. But in the suite that ends Testarossa
column8:
Geti waxes romantic about homework folders and Google Plus in a way that feels more intimate than any revelations about his childhood could hope to be.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22488/homepage_large.2032afe8.jpg|Gala|2564.0|Lush|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['4AD']|2016-05-03 00:00:00|1990|2016-06-11 15:47:15.843737|"

If you're hearing Lush for the first time via this five-record retrospective box
column2: bear in mind: the feathery jangle of leadoff track ""Sweetness and Light"" is going to sound somewhat anemic measured against the sensory-bathing production favored by Lush's modern-day successors like Beach House
column3: Painted Zeros
column4: and Dum Dum Girls. The same goes if you're arriving at this set straight from the brand new EP Blind Spot
column5: Lush's first recorded output after a 20-year absence. Conversely
column6: back in 1989-90
column7: when Lush's debut EP Scar first made a splash
column8: it was tempting to dismiss the English quartet's music as a Cocteau Twins knockoff—but only if you focused on skin-deep similarities rather than the character underneath the sound.

column1: The first record in this set is Gala
column2: a re-packaging of Scar and two other EPs released together in 1990 to function as the band's introduction to new audiences. Sequenced in backwards chronological order
column3: Gala allowed the uninitiated to stumble onto the demo-like crudeness of Scar after being won-over by the radiant shimmer of songs like ""Sweetness and Light"" and ""De-Luxe."" Those songs came across as something of a revelation if you were unfamiliar with Lush's influences and were listening through the lens of alternative rock's transition to a hard-driving
column4: heavy guitar-based format. With six songs produced by Cocteau Twins co-founder Robin Guthrie
column5: Gala still has the naive air of a band fumbling for its voice in the shadow of its heroes. Nevertheless
column6: on the first seven songs
column7: the band throws down the gauntlet and asserts all of the traits that have established its sound as timeless.

column1: The second record of the set is Lush's first proper full-length
column2: 1992's Spooky. Here
column3: it becomes quite clear that this band possessed the substance to match its style. As part of the wave of British acts that were first slapped with the shoegaze tag—Ride
column4: Slowdive
column5: and Pale Saints among them—Lush's music was naturally defined by its seemingly endless ripples of delay
column6: reverb
column7: flange
column8: and chorus. But the almost-supernatural power of frontwoman/guitarist Miki Berenyi and lead guitarist/vocalist Emma Anderson's vocal harmonies and intertwining guitar work set Lush apart from the shoegaze pack on a number of levels.

column1: After a brief intro
column2: Spooky launches straight into the stratosphere with ""Nothing Natural
column3: a pinnacle moment not only for Lush but for shoegaze/alternative across the board. Although Guthrie brings his soft-focus production once again
column4: no amount of sonic soft-pedaling can contain the band's assuredness as it aspires to—and mostly reaches—a beauty so sublime that it pumps you up as much as it takes your breath away. Sure
column5: Lush made melancholy
column6: ethereal music
column7: but such was the band's range during this period that none of the songs on Spooky conform strictly to one mood.

column1: By turns dour
column2: impatient
column3: hopeful
column4: and resigned
column5: the album never runs out of shades. Uptempo numbers like ""Laura"" and ""Superblast!"" counterbalance the more reflective moments
column6: which hit hardest on album closer ""Monochrome
column7: a song with a swaying underwater groove. In the chorus
column8: Berenyi sings
column9: ""And sometimes I think if I stand by the phone it may ring/ And sometimes I worry and fear what tomorrow may bring
column10: her voice drenched in reverb so she sounds less like a human than an apparition. It is one of several moments on Spooky where Lush's music verges on mind-altering.

column1: As the band's sole songwriters
column2: Anderson and Berenyi each took unorthodox approaches to melody
column3: chord structure
column4: pacing
column5: lyrics
column6: and even guitar strumming. With Lush
column7: they wove their idiosyncrasies together into a sound whose rough edge belies its delicate outer lacing. The pair was especially fond of inserting odd notes into chords that draped even their most delicate songs in a haze of dissonance. And if you refer to bootleg recordings from the band's heyday
column8: it's evident that Lush packed a punch in concert that none of these records quite capture. Most unfortunately
column9: you can listen to this whole reissue set and never get a sense of the assertive
column10: even forceful playing of late drummer Chris Acland
column11: whose suicide in October of '96 stopped Lush's career in its tracks just as Anderson was contemplating quitting and collective morale had begun wane.

column1: Had Acland not ended his own life
column2: it seems like an implosion was imminent anyway—which is strange considering that Lush's third and final full-length
column3: 1996's Lovelife
column4: triggered a spike in commercial success in the UK. By Lovelife
column5: however
column6: Berenyi and Anderson had abandoned what originally made their music appealing in favor of a more streamlined sound hewing towards Britpop. While a tune like Anderson's ""500 (Shake Baby Shake)"" distills the familiar harmonies into a tight
column7: sugary-sweet package
column8: which only makes the song's underlying sarcasm and faux-vapidity all the more biting
column9: a multi-faceted muse like Anderson's wasn't best served by going down the same path as Pulp and Blur. Frankly
column10: she and Berenyi were more capable than that.

column1: At a crucial midpoint between the beginning and the end
column2: 1994's Split documents the band reaching beyond the shoegaze mold but not yet pandering to pop appeal. By all accounts a difficult process that involved repeated attempts at a final mix
column3: Split benefits from the turmoil. By that point
column4: Anderson and Berenyi's romantic outlooks had darkened considerably
column5: and at times—the languid
column6: seven-and-a-half minute ""Desire Lines
column7: a plea to a person who needs help on ""Undertow""—Split simulates the sensation of being emotionally lost
column8: adrift on a sea of uncertainty and woe. On those songs
column9: the pair's guitars are like waves lapping against the side of a boat going nowhere.

column1: The final disc
column2: a collection of Lovelife-era B-sides originally released (in two versions) in Canada and Japan as Topolino
column3: largely follows in the direction of Lovelife and then veers off course with delightfully varied results. It's a breath of fresh air
column4: for example
column5: when Lush delve into their signature guitar glitter on ""I Have the Moon."" Meanwhile
column6: on ""Plums and Oranges"" (one of a slew of digital bonus tracks
column7: all of which also appear on the recent 5-cd box set Chorus)
column8: the band seamlessly transplants its classic sound onto an electronic framework—a tantalizing hint of what might have been had Lush had more time to experiment. Likewise
column9: ""Matador"" and ""I'd Like to Walk Around in Your Mind"" see the band venturing into a pastoral English folk arena one wishes Berenyi and Anderson would have explored more.

column1: It's frustrating
column2: because the stripped-down simplicity of ""Carmen""—a chipper rock ditty that sounds like it was rescued by the spirit of Juliana Hatfield on its way to becoming a Britpop single—proves that Lush could have sailed right past the trends of the day. In truth
column3: Topolino serves as a postscript
column4: rather than the meat
column5: of a remarkable career
column6: but its charming odds and ends reveal myriad new angles on the band. Even the instrumental cocktail jazz of ""Cul De Sac"" stumbles its way into grace somehow
column7: and the album's haphazard running order caps the listening experience off on a surprisingly carefree note.

column1: Of course
column2: Origami establishes Lush's place in the lineage of guitar rock well before you get to the Topolino record. Anchored by Anderson and Berenyi's songwriting acumen
column3: Lush's music didn't lunge at the jugular quite like the work of more audacious sonic innovators like My Bloody Valentine or the Jesus and Mary Chain. But
column4: in a strange way
column5: time has proven to be on Lush's side. Two-plus decades later
column6: bands have gotten rather adept at reproducing the sound and attitude that this box documents so vividly. Nevertheless
column7: Lush's body of work reminds us that all the guitar pedals in the world amount to little more than window dressing if you don't have the heart and soul to harness them. With Origami
column8: it's perhaps more clear than ever that Lush possessed both in spades.

column1: Correction: Due to a publishing error
column2:
this review was published with incorrect scores; they have been changed.

column9: the pair's guitars are like waves lapping against the side of a boat going nowhere.

column1: The final disc
column2: a collection of Lovelife-era B-sides originally released (in two versions) in Canada and Japan as Topolino
column3: largely follows in the direction of Lovelife and then veers off course with delightfully varied results. It's a breath of fresh air
column4: for example
column5: when Lush delve into their signature guitar glitter on ""I Have the Moon."" Meanwhile
column6: on ""Plums and Oranges"" (one of a slew of digital bonus tracks
column7: all of which also appear on the recent 5-cd box set Chorus)
column8: the band seamlessly transplants its classic sound onto an electronic framework—a tantalizing hint of what might have been had Lush had more time to experiment. Likewise
column9: ""Matador"" and ""I'd Like to Walk Around in Your Mind"" see the band venturing into a pastoral English folk arena one wishes Berenyi and Anderson would have explored more.

column1: It's frustrating
column2: because the stripped-down simplicity of ""Carmen""—a chipper rock ditty that sounds like it was rescued by the spirit of Juliana Hatfield on its way to becoming a Britpop single—proves that Lush could have sailed right past the trends of the day. In truth
column3: Topolino serves as a postscript
column4: rather than the meat
column5: of a remarkable career
column6: but its charming odds and ends reveal myriad new angles on the band. Even the instrumental cocktail jazz of ""Cul De Sac"" stumbles its way into grace somehow
column7: and the album's haphazard running order caps the listening experience off on a surprisingly carefree note.

column1: Of course
column2: Origami establishes Lush's place in the lineage of guitar rock well before you get to the Topolino record. Anchored by Anderson and Berenyi's songwriting acumen
column3: Lush's music didn't lunge at the jugular quite like the work of more audacious sonic innovators like My Bloody Valentine or the Jesus and Mary Chain. But
column4: in a strange way
column5: time has proven to be on Lush's side. Two-plus decades later
column6: bands have gotten rather adept at reproducing the sound and attitude that this box documents so vividly. Nevertheless
column7: Lush's body of work reminds us that all the guitar pedals in the world amount to little more than window dressing if you don't have the heart and soul to harness them. With Origami
column8: it's perhaps more clear than ever that Lush possessed both in spades.

If you're hearing Lush for the first time via this five-record retrospective box
column2: bear in mind: the feathery jangle of leadoff track ""Sweetness and Light"" is going to sound somewhat anemic measured against the sensory-bathing production favored by Lush's modern-day successors like Beach House
column3: Painted Zeros
column4: and Dum Dum Girls. The same goes if you're arriving at this set straight from the brand new EP Blind Spot
column5: Lush's first recorded output after a 20-year absence. Conversely
column6: back in 1989-90
column7: when Lush's debut EP Scar first made a splash
column8: it was tempting to dismiss the English quartet's music as a Cocteau Twins knockoff—but only if you focused on skin-deep similarities rather than the character underneath the sound.

column1: The first record in this set is Gala
column2: a re-packaging of Scar and two other EPs released together in 1990 to function as the band's introduction to new audiences. Sequenced in backwards chronological order
column3: Gala allowed the uninitiated to stumble onto the demo-like crudeness of Scar after being won-over by the radiant shimmer of songs like ""Sweetness and Light"" and ""De-Luxe."" Those songs came across as something of a revelation if you were unfamiliar with Lush's influences and were listening through the lens of alternative rock's transition to a hard-driving
column4: heavy guitar-based format. With six songs produced by Cocteau Twins co-founder Robin Guthrie
column5: Gala still has the naive air of a band fumbling for its voice in the shadow of its heroes. Nevertheless
column6: on the first seven songs
column7: the band throws down the gauntlet and asserts all of the traits that have established its sound as timeless.

column1: The second record of the set is Lush's first proper full-length
column2: 1992's Spooky. Here
column3: it becomes quite clear that this band possessed the substance to match its style. As part of the wave of British acts that were first slapped with the shoegaze tag—Ride
column4: Slowdive
column5: and Pale Saints among them—Lush's music was naturally defined by its seemingly endless ripples of delay
column6: reverb
column7: flange
column8: and chorus. But the almost-supernatural power of frontwoman/guitarist Miki Berenyi and lead guitarist/vocalist Emma Anderson's vocal harmonies and intertwining guitar work set Lush apart from the shoegaze pack on a number of levels.

column1: After a brief intro
column2: Spooky launches straight into the stratosphere with ""Nothing Natural
column3: a pinnacle moment not only for Lush but for shoegaze/alternative across the board. Although Guthrie brings his soft-focus production once again
column4: no amount of sonic soft-pedaling can contain the band's assuredness as it aspires to—and mostly reaches—a beauty so sublime that it pumps you up as much as it takes your breath away. Sure
column5: Lush made melancholy
column6: ethereal music
column7: but such was the band's range during this period that none of the songs on Spooky conform strictly to one mood.

column1: By turns dour
column2: impatient
column3: hopeful
column4: and resigned
column5: the album never runs out of shades. Uptempo numbers like ""Laura"" and ""Superblast!"" counterbalance the more reflective moments
column6: which hit hardest on album closer ""Monochrome
column7: a song with a swaying underwater groove. In the chorus
column8: Berenyi sings
column9: ""And sometimes I think if I stand by the phone it may ring/ And sometimes I worry and fear what tomorrow may bring
column10: her voice drenched in reverb so she sounds less like a human than an apparition. It is one of several moments on Spooky where Lush's music verges on mind-altering.

column1: As the band's sole songwriters
column2: Anderson and Berenyi each took unorthodox approaches to melody
column3: chord structure
column4: pacing
column5: lyrics
column6: and even guitar strumming. With Lush
column7: they wove their idiosyncrasies together into a sound whose rough edge belies its delicate outer lacing. The pair was especially fond of inserting odd notes into chords that draped even their most delicate songs in a haze of dissonance. And if you refer to bootleg recordings from the band's heyday
column8: it's evident that Lush packed a punch in concert that none of these records quite capture. Most unfortunately
column9: you can listen to this whole reissue set and never get a sense of the assertive
column10: even forceful playing of late drummer Chris Acland
column11: whose suicide in October of '96 stopped Lush's career in its tracks just as Anderson was contemplating quitting and collective morale had begun wane.

column5: however

column7: sugary-sweet package
column8: which only makes the song's underlying sarcasm and faux-vapidity all the more biting
column9: a multi-faceted muse like Anderson's wasn't best served by going down the same path as Pulp and Blur. Frankly
column10: she and Berenyi were more capable than that.

column5: and at times—the languid
column6: seven-and-a-half minute ""Desire Lines
column7: a plea to a person who needs help on ""Undertow""—Split simulates the sensation of being emotionally lost
column8: adrift on a sea of uncertainty and woe. On those songs

column2: the theory goes
column3: and you will know all. The world will open up to you. Existence will be made plain. You will be one with the matrix. Yadda yadda yadda. From arenas to memes
column4: Drake has always had a skill for turning his innermost thoughts
column5: feelings
column6: and anxieties into breakthrough group therapy sessions—he articulates what we know to be true and then lets us rap or sing those truths en masse
column7: exalting in common bonds that are as vulnerable as they are revealing. When he confides his fears
column8: we become a little more fearless. When he turns his woes into anthems
column9: we all get lifted. But there is a razor-sharp line between self-awareness and self-absorption: Whereas self-awareness can expand wisdom by reflecting it outward
column10: self-absorption often festers
column11: drawing things in only to let them rot. For the past seven years
column12: Drake has expertly glided along that line. But on his fourth proper album
column13: he edges closer than ever to a mirrored abyss
column14: a suffocating echo chamber of self.

column1: The record is called VIEWS but its perspective is decidedly singular. “This album
column2: I’m very proud to say
column3: is just—I feel like I told everybody how I’m actually feeling
column4: ” Drake told Zane Lowe in a toothless recent interview
column5: differentiating VIEWS from his previous work. This might seem like a ridiculous distinction—there’s never any question that Drake is the star of his own show—but it’s apt
column6: and it hints at why this album feels like more of a claustrophobic mindfuck than a collective catharsis. VIEWS is what happens when venting turns into whining. Spanning an obnoxious 82 minutes
column7: the record goes through several musical and thematic phases
column8: but the overall atmosphere is bitter
column9: petty
column10: worn-down. It confuses loyalty and stagnation
column11: wallowing in a sound that is starting to show its limits.

column1: Until the last minute
column2: the album was to be called Views from the 6
column3: and it still serves as an ode to Drake’s hometown of Toronto. After having other producers handle the lion’s share of beats on his last two mixtapes
column4: Drake's longtime musical consigliere
column5: Noah “40” Shebib
column6: returns to the head of the table here
column7: with production credits on 12 of the album’s 20 tracks. The atmosphere 40 creates with his music is now synonymous with Drake’s Toronto; the harsh chill of winter is brought forth via cold snares and ice-cube synths
column8: with the summer’s relief often rendered through sped-up ‘90s R&B samples that quietly churn in the background. It’s essentially a screwed-down take on Kanye West’s chipmunk soul
column9: and it has provided a perfect backdrop for Drake’s poignant introspection while ushering in an entire stage of hip-hop’s evolution.

column1: But on VIEWS
column2: the style is simply getting tired
column3: its wintry mood now actively blocking any springtime salvation. It’s also bringing out some of Drake’s most self-loathing tendencies
column4: playing into his groaning paranoia on tracks like “9
column5: ” where he laments
column6: “Life is always on
column7: man
column8: I never get a break from it/Doesn’t matter where I go
column9: I can never get away from it.” Songs like these play out like dour self-fulfilling prophecies
column10: puffed-up bad attitudes drunk on their own misery. They also expose the downside of a “no new friends” mindset and how a bunker mentality can snub out curiosity. Marked by frigidness and a furrowed brow
column11: much of VIEWS may be true to Toronto’s darker months
column12: but it also makes the city sound like a pretty inhospitable place.

column1: Fact is
column2: the 6 is one of the most multicultural places on Earth
column3: a sprawling metropolis in which more than 140 different languages and dialects are spoken. And it’s when VIEWS embraces this more inviting and open-minded side of Toronto that it points to a better way forward. Drake’s fascination with the city’s Caribbean enclaves take root in the effervescent rhythms of songs like “With You
column4: ” “One Dance
column5: ” and “Too Good”—all of them featuring welcomed guest vocals that break up the monotony and also allow Drake to get out of his own brain for a second.

column1: Rihanna co-stars on “Too Good
column2: ” finally offering a counterpoint to Drake’s constant disappointment with the opposite sex; when she sings “You take my love for granted
column3: I just don’t understand it
column4: ” she’s giving voice to all of the women Drake has spurned on record over the years. (Perhaps tellingly
column5: she only gets to sing the line alongside her duet partner.) Because while Drake’s relationship dissections were once questioning and openly hurt
column6: they too have hardened—at this point
column7: it’s getting impossible to believe he’s not the one to blame for so many squandered attempts at love.

column1: Even slight tweaks to Drake’s usual sound pay dividends here. “Childs Play” finds 40 putting his spin on New Orleans bounce
column2: bringing out Drake’s more playful side as he raps about a lady friend who gets in a fight with him at The Cheesecake Factory and takes his Bugatti for a spin to pick up some tampons. The song’s angst plays out more like a jokey spat than another existential treatise on the hopelessness of searching for the girl of his dreams. “Feel No Ways” is another sad story
column3: but its beat—which zips up Malcolm McClaren’s 1983 hip-hop experiment “World’s Famous”—harkens back to Drake’s masterpiece
column4: Take Care
column5: adding levity and the sense that these feelings
column6: like all feelings
column7: will not be so heavy in time. “Weston Road Flows” is another throwback
column8: with Drake reminiscing about his salad days over a gorgeous Mary J. Blige sample
column9: another instance of a woman’s voice helping to add humanity to the rapper’s toughened exterior. The song finds Drake looking back on his come-up with fondness and
column10: naturally
column11: some melancholy. But when he lets out a little cackle at the end of the track
column12: it’s not out of spite. He sounds like he’s genuinely enjoying himself on the song. It’s nice to hear.

column1: If last year’s If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late had Drake doing his best all-guns-blazing Tony Montana
column2: shedding his softness for an untouchable-don pose
column3: VIEWS has him on his Tony Soprano
column4: trying to reach deep into his own psyche for revelations but often just falling back on a sour version of what got him this far. Perhaps its shortcomings are in part due to a cloistered view of what being candid really means. “I’m an honest person
column5: I can’t write fiction
column6: ” Drake said last week. “It all directly has to do with me or else I can’t make the music.” While artistic honesty is certainly something to aspire to
column7: it doesn’t have to equate with blinding selfishness or even concrete reality. Drake’s most apparent current rap peers
column8: Kanye and Kendrick Lamar
column9: have both let their minds wander to surreal places in order to add depth and intrigue to their own music
column10:
and nobody would accuse them of dishonesty. Such inventiveness is required for the type of longevity Drake seems to crave. Because knowing thyself is a quest. It never ends.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23175/homepage_large.d1b59ff2.jpg|DJ Koze Presents Pampa Vol. 1|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Pampa']|2016-05-02 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:16.586947|"

In its seven years of existence
column2: Stefan Kozalla and Marcus Fink’s Pampa Records label has been defined by its stance against purism. The techno and house artists featured by the German label
column3: from DJ Koze himself to the underground king Isolée
column4: from the madcap experimentalist Roman Flügel to the fan-favorite Dntel
column5: shun conventional genre wisdom and of-the-moment sounds
column6: instead favoring an approach wrapped in humor
column7: warmth
column8: and the pleasure of small surprises. “All the best things happen from mistakes
column9: ” Koze told Pitchfork three years ago
column10: in a statement representative of the spontaneity that he’s embraced in heading up the imprint.

column1: That’s not to say that the tasting menu represented by the new label compilation Pampa Vol. 1 is incoherent
column2: even with the unexpected appearances of big-name guest stars including Jamie xx and Matthew Herbert. The 19 tracks that make up this confectioner's array sit in neatly ordered rows
column3: most of them sweet
column4: light
column5: and pleasant
column6: with novel ingredients often cropping in the middle or even near the end of tracks. With a running time of nearly two hours
column7: the compilation shouldn’t be ingested in one go—doing so might bring on the overstuffed achiness of gobbling down a box of chocolates. The offerings on hand here are meant to be picked out at random and savored; Pampa Vol. 1 is the album as discovery machine
column8: rather than completist’s task. It’s as good an album as any to justify the existence of the shuffle setting.

column1: Starting at the beginning may run counter to the record’s freewheeling design
column2: but Matthew Herbert’s remix of Lianne La Havas’ “Lost and Found” is irresistible as an album opener. In Herbert’s hands
column3: the pain and beauty of the London singer’s 2012 ballad are transmuted
column4: as staircases of bass elevate the track’s more hopeful qualities. If you feel like taking a side entrance
column5: another possible point of immersion is the Swedish house producer Axel Boman’s offering
column6: “In the Dust of This Planet.” Boman’s 2010 EP Holy Love was one of Pampa’s first big releases
column7: and the new track is characteristic of the exploratory push that Pampa’s artists receive from the label. Its winding back half
column8: considered by Boman to be its proper ending
column9: interrupts what had been a climactic crescendo. That shift changes the song's entire direction
column10: allowing it to evoke a sense of regret
column11: an actualization of the wish to go back in time and start again.

column1: Newcomers to Pampa may skip right to the Jamie xx offering
column2: “Come We Go
column3: ” and thankfully
column4: it’s as good a portal as any into the label’s core values. At first
column5: the track seems as if it’s following the path of In Colour’s dance floor fetish. Then
column6: suddenly
column7: the walls close in and the bass becomes claustrophobic. It’s a left turn typical of DJ Koze’s sense of play
column8: and although it’s not entirely clear
column9: he appears to be Jamie’s collaborator on the track
column10: working under the pseudonym Kosi Kos.

column1: Other standouts include the cotton candy world built by the Swiss house veteran Michel Cleis on his contribution
column2: “Un Prince
column3: ” Acid Pauli’s fractured beauty “Nana
column4: ” which dices its sampled melody into thousands of tiny pieces
column5: and Die Vögel’s bizarrely lovely pastoral
column6: ”Everything
column7: ” which features the American singer Sophia Kennedy
column8: another track to which Koze contributed something essential (in this case
column9: advising that the beat be pulled out altogether.)

column1: Some tracks don’t make as much sense within the mix
column2: including “I Does It
column3: ” a serviceable slab of funk-infused hip-hop from the electronic duo Funkstörung that’s aggressive and low-slung in a way that feels out of sync with its airy companions. The crooning that provides the centerpiece of Josef’s “I Wonder
column4: ” is so shrill that it makes the track hard to stomach; it seems like a joke that was pushed a bit too far.

column1: The record is bookended by two versions of Roman Flügel’s “9 Years
column2: ” the original and Koze’s club remix
column3: which fans may recognize from Flügel’s Essential Mix. Koze’s version is no mere ego trip; if anything he does more justice to the tracks core attributes—its pensiveness
column4: its beauty—than the original. It’s the most obvious example of Koze’s influence on his collaborators
column5: but in the statements included with the press copy of Pampa Vol. 1
column6: several of the artists mention how a suggestion he made helped them finish their tracks. Koze has described the label as a “small family
column7: ” a “gang which makes you feel that you’re not alone.” If that’s the case
column8: the new record suggests that he’s operating as the ideal paterfamilias
column9: daring the artists he works with to go beyond their boundaries
column10: to try something unfamiliar
column11: to surprise themselves
column12: and in doing so
column13:
to give listeners a taste of something new.

Many knew Anna Wise as one-half of the duo Sonnymoon
column2: as the siren who provides the Yin to Dane Orr's Yang. However
column3: her celebrity kicked up a notch once she became Kendrick Lamar's go-to vocalist
column4: lending her ethereal vibes to his projects <i>Good Kid
column5: m.A.A.d. City
column6: To Pimp a Butterfly
column7: and untitled unmastered. If Anna Wise had any perfect moment to step forward to her podium
column8: then that time is certainly now.

column1: She arrives armed with a message that many if not most have trouble effectively communicating. In 2014 a video circulated of a woman walking the streets of New York City amidst a diverse array of male cat calls. The video introduced a dichotomy that manifested itself in every Facebook comment section. Half of the viewers were offended (though many women were also unsurprised) and the other half rolled their eyes. The mixed reaction to that very video is exactly what Wise is speaking to on her EP. The project opens with a snippet of a dissertation on the feminine
column2: and its need to be understood clearly. It pours into the delicate ""Precious Possession
column3: which at first listen channels all the romantic vibes of early Erykah Badu
column4: but placed within the context of the project could arguably be completely sardonic. ""I wanna be your princess
column5: Wise gently coos. ""Will you call me your girlfriend?"" That's not to say women should exist as stoic figures shrugging at the sight of flowers; she's simply displaying the layers of the feminine psyche
column6: which at times can be self-minimizing in the presence of love.

column1: An interlude ""How Would You Call a Dog?"" reflects on the dual catcalling of both types of ""bitches
column2: as Wise snatches the derogations for ""BitchSlut
column3: a laundry list of absurd ways women are called both terms. It's empowering
column4: but this topic has been talked into mastication. Still
column5: when Wise cites reasons for being a ""bitchslut
column6: including ""Cause your hair's long/ Cause you shaved it off
column7: there's a tongue-in-cheek air of brilliance. ""Decrease My Waist
column8: Increase My Wage"" is laid out similarly to a song by a group like the Coup
column9: where the important lyrics are woven so tightly into a basic-sounding song that the stop-and-listen effect solicits an inevitable ""Oh shit.""

column1: Any reference to women on anything is oftentimes an abrasive subject to broach
column2:
especially at a time when many are just learning to embrace the word ""feminist."" What Anna Wise attempts with The Feminine: Act I is to serve this realness with a spoonful of sugar to help the medicine go down. While it's still a jagged little pill to swallow—and the proof is in the EP's parts that traipse into cornier territory—Wise does present a degree of transparency that many attempt but wind up losing half their audience in the process. This isn't simply a project to make women nod and smirk; it's a work to hand over to men who assume every aspect of a woman's life is a gift with no curses.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23138/homepage_large.c7af9edb.jpg|Modernists|244.0|Alarm Will Sound|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cantaloupe']|2016-05-02 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:17.813919|"

America’s classical music scene is one of the last fine-arts zones in which modernism remains controversial. While museums do brisk business with retrospectives of experimental visual artists—and as hardcore cinephiles flock to see Jean-Luc Godard’s exploration of 3D—you can still find attendees of classical gigs storming out of venues when the music of the mid-20th century is presented. The consistency of this response to the new and recent creates some self-inflicted wounds. Among other problems
column2: the modernist-classical freeze out makes cultural absorption of today’s compositions all the more difficult. (It’s hard to process blazingly new music if you’re still covering your ears in response to Arnold Schoenberg.)

column1: The bleeding-edge virtuosos in Alarm Will Sound have a bit of fun with this state of play on the cover for their latest album
column2: Modernism
column3: with an illustration styled in the manner of a poster for a midcentury sci-fi flick. In addition to pointing out that the history of “modernism” is now long enough to feel every bit as vintage as your favorite piece of B-movie ephemera
column4: the comic portrait of screaming human faces also poses a rhetorical question: Do we honestly still need to act scared by this stuff? Over the course of their 40-minute set
column5: the Alarm Will Sound players and conductor Alan Pierson respond to this prompt by delivering pure modern-classical fun. The six pieces they’ve chosen speak different structural languages
column6: though each one shares a desire to bring across a sense of wildness that is exuberant at heart.

column1: The first composition on the bill is a classical transcription of the Beatles’ “Revolution 9”—the legit musique concrete song on the White Album that was famously built from loops and samples of prerecorded sound (including some classical pieces). In interviews
column2: both Paul McCartney and John Lennon were eager to talk up their interest in studio assemblages by European composers such as Karlheinz Stockhausen. And Lennon’s partnership with Yoko Ono was also an influence (given her pathbreaking
column3: early '60s association with experimental composers like John Cage and La Monte Young).

column1: The arrangement on Modernists was devised by the composer and Alarm member Matt Marks
column2: and it’s clear he’s fully sorted out all the sonic layers of the piece. Using nothing but acoustic instruments
column3: the arranger has notated an impressive range of gestures present on the original. And the group’s performance here is stunning—particularly when Alarm’s woodwind and string sections play a few opening licks in a way that successfully calls to mind some of the backward-masking effects of Lennon’s tape loops. Overall
column4: the performance makes a persuasive argument on behalf of “Revolution 9” as a modernist composition
column5: full stop.

column1: From there
column2: Alarm Will Sound present works dedicated to them by a cross-section of contemporary classical heavy hitters. Charles Wuorinen has a fearsome reputation as one of America’s craggiest atonalists
column3: but his “Big Spinoff” has a riff-fueled energy that’s easy to love. Wolfgang Rihm’s “Will Sound” is designed as a test of the group’s collective nimbleness: the length of the phrases for various players seems to be continually expanding and contracting
column4: with each part needing to click into the overall performance just right. (Naturally
column5: the group never sounds tentative when playing this madly morphing music.) Augusta Read Thomas’ “Final Soliloquy of the Internal Paramour” superimposes two texts by Wallace Stevens over some active
column6: songful writing for the ensemble. Group pianist John Orfe’s original work “Journeyman” has some rollicking elements that fit in with the overall program
column7: but it’s not quite on the same level as the other recent pieces.

column1: The final composition on the album is another transcription—this time of a piece that’s easier to categorize as belonging to the modernist classical idiom. Yet taking on Edgard Varèse’s “Poème Électronique” is perhaps an even tougher assignment than transcribing “Revolution 9.” The original is plenty musical
column2: but also frequently delicate. On this recording
column3: when Varese’s opening music is assigned to “traditional” instrumentation
column4: there’s a harmonic richness at play that feels at odds with the composer’s more tinny-sounding design. (As the album’s liner notes accurately tell us
column5: Varèse hoped this piece would reach the audience “unadulterated by ‘interpretation.’”)

column1: Though even a performance like this one has its uses—since a question-raising take can help us define exactly how much contingency and revisionism we’re willing to accept from any re-staging of past experimental glories. As with most modern art museum shows
column2: you can quibble with individual curatorial choices. But overall
column3: Modernists makes for a strong show
column4:
mounted on behalf of a wing of classical music that isn’t always represented at your local chamber music hall.

column3: Prince Rogers Nelson was in transition. He’d disbanded the Revolution
column4: the band that had backed him since Purple Rain. He’d toyed with doing a collaborative album with Revolution members Wendy & Lisa
column5: but also abandoned that. He’d put a lot of time into crafting a record around an alter ego called Camille
column6: whose tracks were recorded with his voice pitched to sound even more womanly than his trademark falsetto. But that too had stalled.

column1: The album he released on March 31
column2: 1987 was a Prince solo record that
column3: like his 1980 artistic breakthrough Dirty Mind and his two earlier albums
column4: was essentially a one-man-band recording which relied heavily on the LinnDrum
column5: various samplers
column6: and his remarkable aptitude on every instrument under the sun. Of the 16 songs on Sign ""O"" the Times
column7: only three have co-writers
column8: and save for one track (“It’s Going to Be a Beautiful Night”)
column9: outside musical accompaniment is slight. In a sense
column10: Prince’s major musical collaborator at this point was his engineer Susan Rogers
column11: who recorded him at different studios in Minneapolis
column12: Los Angeles
column13: and even Paris.

column1: But unlike his earlier solo efforts
column2: Sign ""O"" the Times wasn’t a record by an ambitious kid trying to make impression. At 28
column3: Prince had already made himself into a pop superstar  (and movie star too)
column4: and he easily sold out arenas. In one sense
column5: he had nothing to prove. Yet Sign ""O"" the Times is the most varied
column6: accomplished record of his prime 1980s period
column7: a testament to the range of his gifts and the bold artistic ambition that gave his music shape.

column1: Part of Prince’s drive was that he was keenly aware that hip-hop was rising up and shifting the sound of music. Rap was entering its “golden age
column2: ” and its mix of gritty storytelling and dope beats had to be reckoned with. (Michael Jackson would release Bad
column3: his own answer to hip-hop
column4: six months later.) So the title cut
column5: with Prince’s commentary on the issues of the day (“a big disease with a little name
column6: ” mentions of crack and gang violence) and minimalist Run-DMC-styled production
column7: made clear that Prince had his ear to the street. The song functions as Prince’s version of “The Message
column8: ” and
column9: as crazy as that sounds
column10: it works.

column1: Prince wasn’t just wrestling with fresh energy from the streets on Sign ""O"" the Times
column2: but with the twin pillars of carnality and spirituality that had defined his career and that of black popular music for decades. For this Minneapolis native
column3: it wasn’t so much a battle between sin and salvation
column4: as it was how the warring desires could become one
column5: synthesized through innovative arrangements
column6: seductive yet fraught lyrics
column7: and that remarkable voice.

column1: “Forever in My Life
column2: ” for example
column3: has the sincere melody of early Sly and the Family Stone. It sounds ready made for optimistic sing-a-longs. At first
column4: you think it’s a simple love song
column5: but there’s a devotional quality (“You are my savior/You are my life”) that makes it a chant of piety. At the same time
column6: songs like “Hot Thing” and “It” are aggressively sexual
column7: but in the context of the electronic
column8: oddly-pitched sounds around the words
column9: they seem more like the search for human connection and transcendence rather than a roll in the hay.

column1: The album’s two ballads
column2: “Slow Love” (co-written by singer-songwriter Carol Davis) and “Adore
column3: ” are both showcases for Prince’s vocal prowess. The man was an encyclopedia of vocal styles
column4: able to croon like a 1950s pop star on the nostalgic “Slow Love” and do '60s soul style on “Adore.” Though equally adept at showy vocal riffs and screaming in tune
column5: Prince’s lower
column6: cooler register seems to express his truest self.

column1: Prince’s ability to move between genres made him a unique musical chameleon with Stevie Wonder and Paul McCartney his only peers at the highest levels of pop. While he was often compared to Wonder
column2: especially early in his career
column3: it’s the ex-Beatle who seemed to have the most enduring influence. McCartney’s story-song sketches on The White Album helped define his career. For Prince
column4: they were just one of many tools. His whimsical profiles of an odd elementary school classmate (“Starfish & Coffee”) and a quirky lover with the name of a celebrated New Yorker writer (“The Ballad of Dorothy Parker”) are lovely stories supported by surreal sounds and beats
column5: suggesting you are on psychedelic journey through Prince’s memories.

column1: Sign ""O"" the Times is difficult to grapple with because there’s so much going on in each track. The up-tempo “Play in the Sunshine” drops in jazz fusion riffs and choral voices just when you think its winding down. “The Cross"" starts as a mournful song of devotion to Christ with acoustic guitar and sitar before exploding into a huge rock anthem with military drums and fuzz guitar. “Play in the Sunshine” opens with the sound of kids at play
column2: becomes a rockabilly song
column3: transitions midway into a guitar showcase
column4: and then
column5: with a marimba
column6: a different drum pattern
column7: and cleverly arranged backing voices
column8: it ends a musical world away from where it began.

column1: “Housequake” is
column2: perhaps
column3: the most obvious songs on the album
column4: a funk jam that would have been a hit single if he’d allowed it to be released as such. But the care of the track’s construction belies any shallow analysis. It starts with a cartoony voice (maybe a Camille reference)
column5: a synthesized drum heavy with echo
column6: then adds bass
column7: keyboard stabs
column8: and rhythm guitar. The synth drum and snare drum merge while there’s a double-beat on the kick. Live horns come it and the bass line moves as there’s both a synth bass keyboard and a live bass doing playing different lines. Various backing vocals float in and out with Prince doing his James Brown impersonation as singer/MC. Compared to the simple loops of your average club banger
column9: “Housequake” is a symphony of syncopation. The beat moves even as it grooves.

column1: Because Prince played and recorded the album using now-vintage late '80s technology there are moments when certain sounds
column2: particularly the drums
column3: are clearly of their era. But these sonic distractions don’t last as the scope of the songs
column4: the musicianship
column5: and overall arrangements are just too glorious to nitpick. Sign ""O"" the Times is a double album made with a restlessness that never allows it to settle into complacency or formula. It’s a soundtrack to a highly charged and specific period
column6: for both Prince and his listeners. I remember partying to “Housequake” in the summer of '87
column7: laughing along with “Starfish & Coffee
column8: ” and playing “Adore” for my girlfriend when it was time to get busy. All these years later
column9: it’s still a vibrant thing
column10:
the product of a great artist at the height of his powers.

For all the hot-pink light bathing 30-years-on memories of the '80s
column3: that decade was full of dread—bad guys lurked around corners

It is wrong to say that Purple Rain blazes a new trail. Rather it beams a blinding light signal from a part of the forest that no one will be able to ever find again. You cannot make another album like it. The only way to get to where Purple Rain takes you is to play Purple Rain.
