column1: The most noticeable thing about Around the World in a Day was what it wasn’t: It wasn’t remotely a sequel to Purple Rain. On first listen
column2: it was instantly clear that the album was a dramatic left-turn
column3: with none of the flashy guitar and few of the pop hooks. The sound was bright and sweet
column4: as opposed to low-end raunch. If Prince had streamlined and rocked up his approach for global domination
column5: now he was creating something more intimate
column6: cerebral
column7: and challenging.

column1: Though Around the World was released with no radio single or advance promotion—“This has got to be the easiest album I’ve ever worked on
column2: ” Warner Bros. creative marketing chief Jeff Ayeroff said—the first taste for most listeners wasn’t too shocking. The irresistibly playful “Raspberry Beret” was in fact the most pure pop Prince had ever delivered. (I clearly remember hearing him play the song alone at the piano during the Purple Rain show I attended that spring
column3: and the crowd went nuts
column4: singing along by the second chorus.)

column1: But “Raspberry Beret” was actually a song he had written a few years earlier
column2: and was a bit of an outlier on the album. The real linchpin for the project was a demo that Revolution members Wendy Melvoin and Lisa Coleman brought him
column3: a track that had been recorded by their respective brothers
column4: David Coleman and Jonathan Melvoin. It was a shimmery
column5: winding instrumental with flutes and strings reminiscent of the Beatles circa Magical Mystery Tour. Prince loved its sound and feel
column6: and he began to build the album around the psychedelic sensibility of this song
column7: which would ultimately give the album its title.

column1: The album cover—a painting depicting the Revolution in a trippy
column2: candy-colored landscape—clearly evoked Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band. The first sounds you heard backed up this reference; the record kicked off with a keening Middle Eastern flute
column3: and Prince’s first line is “Open your heart
column4: open your mind.” This vision of a mystical journey for which “laughter is all you pay” was followed by “Paisley Park
column5: ” a depiction of Prince’s dream world (and
column6: for those paying attention
column7: the name of his new label imprint
column8: for which Around the World was the first release) where “admission is easy/ Just say U believe
column9: ” and whose inhabitants feel only “profound inner peace.”

column1: At the time
column2: this utopian hippie bliss was the most obvious element of Around the World in a Day. “Prince goes psychedelic” was the common hot take
column3: with all of the naïve optimism that implied. Several of the songs opened with fairy-tale introductions—“Once upon a time in the land of Sinaplenty” or “There was a girl in Paris.” Over time
column4: though
column5: what emerged was a much darker undertone running through the album. Even “Paisley Park” included a betrayed wife whose husband died “without knowing forgiveness” and a man crying as his house is condemned.

column1: Over a loosely thudding drum sound
column2: “Pop Life” (the album’s other Top 10 hit) was a skeptical meditation on the trappings of success
column3: the lure of drugs and anti-intellectualism. “Everybody can’t be on top
column4: ” Prince sang with a hint of a sneer
column5: “But life it ain’t real funky
column6: unless it’s got that pop.” It was the moment that first articulated the creative tension that would play out over the rest of his career; was Prince more naturally a stadium-filling superstar or was he really the world’s biggest cult artist
column7: with a dedicated following ready to follow him down which musical path he chose?

column1: The album’s most conventional-sounding rock song was in some ways the oddest of all—was “America” a patriotic anthem without irony
column2: an anti-communist manifesto written at the height of Ronald Reagan’s “Morning in America
column3: ” or a savage attack on that mentality? Prince sang about a girl “making minimum wage/ Living in a one-room jungle monkey cage…she may not be in the black/ But she’s happy she ain’t in the red.” Tougher to interpret than “Born in the USA
column4: ” the song also allowed Prince to indulge his fantasies of nuclear apocalypse that went back to “1999” and “Ronnie
column5: Talk to Russia.”

column1: Some of the most striking moments on Around the World were the most compositionally experimental. The jittery
column2: sexually-charged funk of “Tamborine” never fully coheres into a complete song
column3: stretching the tension almost unbearably thin. “Condition of the Heart
column4: ” its jazz chords unfolding over an impossibly slow tempo as Prince maintains an inhuman falsetto
column5: is as delicate as a spider’s web
column6: threatening to fall apart at any moment.

column1: As the album nears its conclusion
column2: things get genuinely mystifying
column3: and we get the clearest sense of the issues Prince was grappling with in the aftermath of Purple Rain. “The Ladder” is a bewildering parable of a king “who didn’t deserve 2 B
column4: ” and who embarks on a spiritual quest. The reward he (and we all) receive for “looking for the ladder
column5: ” Prince sings
column6: building up his testifying vocal screams over slow-swinging
column7: traditional gospel chords
column8: is that “a feeling of self-worth will caress U/ The size of the whole wide world will decrease.”

column1: There’s a remarkable co-writing credit on this curious epic
column2: as well as on the title cut—John L. Nelson
column3: Prince’s father
column4: whose conflict with his son was spun into the fictional emotional center of the Purple Rain movie. A jazz pianist
column5: Nelson even attended Prince’s initial presentation of the album at the Warner Bros. offices
column6: clad in a caftan. What could it possibly mean that this father-son reconciliation and collaboration resulted in such dense
column7: almost coded lyrics
column8: with such a desperate yearning for salvation?

column1: The final track on Around the World took things even farther. At some of the Purple Rain shows
column2: Prince stopped the music to engage in actual on-stage conversations with God. Unlike his R&B sex symbol predecessors like Al Green and Marvin Gaye
column3: Prince had never seemed tortured by the relationship between sex and faith; rather than defining physical love as sin
column4: he had embraced sex as an earthly manifestation of the divine spirit. But clearly there was some new guilt pulling at him
column5: some reaction to his success or his lifestyle
column6: and it is documented on the eight-minute-plus “Temptation.”

column1: Reeling off spiky
column2: fuzzed-out guitar licks
column3: Prince practically drools his expressions of desire; “Working my body with a hot flash of animal lust
column4: ” he squeals
column5: shrieks
column6: leers. Eddie M.’s saxophone gives the song an almost comic burlesque strut as Prince works himself into a sexual frenzy. Until another voice comes down from the heavens: “Oh
column7: silly man
column8: that’s not how it works/ You have 2 want her 4 the right reasons/""I do!""/ U don’t
column9: now die!”

column1: Prince ends the album having learned his lesson—that “love is more important than sex”—and by saying goodbye to his audience. “I have 2 go now
column2: ” he whispers
column3: “I don’t know when I’ll return.” And indeed
column4: just a few weeks before the release of Around the World in a Day
column5: Prince announced his “retirement” from live performance; it may have been sincere at the time
column6: but it was barely a year later when he was back on tour
column7: this time for the Parade album.

column1: With the momentum of Purple Rain behind it—or
column2: more precisely
column3: with the momentum still going full tilt—Around the World sold over two million copies; no Prince record would ever be as commercially successful in his lifetime. But the album didn’t capture the public imagination to anywhere near the degree that Purple Rain had. If anything
column4: its lilting textures and cryptic lyrics served to confuse a large portion of the fans attracted by the girls-and-guitars spirit of the motorcycle riding
column5: Jimi Hendrix-meets-James Brown image the movie had cultivated. Which
column6: of course
column7: seemed to be his intention
column8: his only possible way out of competing with a world-changing
column9: life-changing phenomenon.

column1: But it’s unfair to only consider the album as a defensive maneuver or a strategy to keep his future options open. It was also a brave and deeply personal project
column2: exploring sounds and ideas that were almost shocking coming from a pop icon at his peak. “I sorta had an f-you attitude
column3: ” Prince told legendary Detroit DJ the Electrifying Mojo about his mood while recording Around the World in a Day
column4: “meaning that I was making something for myself and my fans. And the people who supported me through the years—I wanted to give them something
column5: and it was like my mental letter. And those people are the ones who wrote me back
column6:
telling me that they felt what I was feeling.”

Throughout their 40-year existence
column2: Wire have striven to both obliterate and preserve their past. The post-punk pioneers’ discography is one of abrupt but clean breaks
column3: with prolonged periods of inactivity that neatly group their records into distinct phases—which the band and fans cheekily refer to as Marks

column1: Not surprisingly

column4: they’re not ones to let leftovers go to waste—they’re committed to giving aborted material its proper due and consideration

column9: but didn’t make it onto the album.

column1: According to the band

column3: whereas the tracks compiled on and reworked for Nocturnal Koreans encouraged a greater degree of studio manipulation. But the two releases still sound like byproducts of the same moment—Wire was hardly lacking for textural trickery
column4: while Nocturnal Koreans accommodates a couple of rockers. Furthermore
column5: the atypical tools employed here (trumpet
column6: lap-steel guitar) are treated less as feature attractions than soluble materials to be mutated and absorbed into the band’s soundstream. Whereas Wire effectively found this perennially re-inventive band settling into a comfort zone of sorts
column7: forging the melodic middle ground between post-punk whirr and Krautrock swirl

column11: with frontman Colin Newman’s bleary-eyed mental haze (“I dressed in my shower before I awoke”) rendered through an encroaching
column12: droning buzz that gradually blurs the edges of the song’s incessant backbeat.

column1: True to that nighttime scene-setter
column2: Nocturnal Koreans ranks among Wire’s most musically relaxed releases
column3: with Newman mostly singing in calm
column4: sometimes hushed tones. But it’s only relaxed in the sense that a sleepless night in your bedroom is relaxed—the pillows and sheets feel familiar
column5: but your thoughts are riddled with anxieties over the unknown. While the droll
column6: dry “Internal Exile” may deliver its critique of cutthroat capitalism with a smirk (“Hearts of gold/ No pot to piss in/ Join the queue of future has-beens”)
column7: its tense acoustic stalk and prodding chorus apply palpable pressure. The more wiry—and typically Wire-y— “Numbered” packs in a cheeky callback to one of the band’s signature songs (“You think I’m a number/ Still willing to rhumba”)
column8: yet that knowing nod only reinforces the new track’s doomsday messaging. Those apocalyptic intimations are rendered all the more starkly through the dead-of-night stillness of “Forward Motion
column9: ” whose eerie
column10: frosty ambience swells into a mushroom cloud of lingering cold-war paranoia.

column1: It’s easy to see how something like “Forward Position” was deemed too much of an aesthetic outlier to fit in with the Wire tracklist. But there are also a handful of tracks here (“Dead Weight
column2: ” “Still
column3: ” “Pilgrim Trade”) that seem like mere victims of attrition—functional
column4: pro-forma songs that try to boost their mid-tempo pulse by piling on synth and noise textures. So when bassist Graham Lewis steps up to take his lone
column5: lead vocal on the closing “Fishes Bones

column8: are you needing a boost?/ Inside is where my chicken roost”) providing an absurdist counterpoint to Newman’s more contemplative observations. As per Wire’s 21st century M.O.

column10: the strobe-lit
column11: lockstep assault of late-’80s standards like “(A Berlin) Drill.” But it uses nostalgia like a slingshot
column12:
pulling back to the past as a means to shoot forth into the future.

Given hip hop's longevity

column1: Dälek (a play on the word ""dialect"") parlayed atypical hip-hop inspirations—My Bloody Valentine

But no matter how used to this group's agility we've become

column1: Not unlike Gutter Tactics

column4: totalitarianism

column3: the music becomes all the more moving when it directly contrasts Brooks' chilling shards of imagery. The dulcet electronic ripples of ""Masked Laughter

column6: in turn

Rock is just a small piece of the greater amalgamation—a simple-yet-complex affair that welds repetitive riffing in strange time signatures to microtonal harmonies that glint like flecks of mica. It might be tempting to call it math rock
column6: but these aren't problems to be solved—they're patterns that unfold as if of their own accord. Maybe ""biology rock"" would be more apt. It's fluid

column1: The Baltimore band has released two albums up to this point

column3: knotty studio experiments. They've also released three freeform ""mixtapes"" containing sidelong collages of full-throttle rave-ups

column4: bass
column5: and saxophone pile up in teetering heaps. Their scales have an odd
column6: in-between quality

column3: sketch-like pieces. ""Encounter I / Transfinite Flow"" braids taut guitar plucks and staccato sax blasts around one another like the strands of a double helix; ""Intervention I"" is a chiming modular synth miniature that feels like standing in the lobby of a Reno casino; and ""Encounter II / Intervention II

column5: this kind of challenge is core to his identity as a musician. The Ship
column6: Eno’s newest release and his sixth on Warp
column7: somehow manages to feel distinct from all the work he’s done. He describes this divergence as a desire “to make a record of songs that didn’t rely on the normal underpinnings of rhythmic structure and chord progressions but which allowed voices to exist in their own space and time
column8: like events in a landscape.” The Ship is broken into four tracks that more or less flow into one fluid 48-minute suite of music.

column1: On his website Eno describes his inspiration for The Ship as coming from
column2: among other things
column3: a fascination with the sinking of the Titanic and humankind’s balance “between hubris and paranoia.” That Eno should go here now is an interesting way of coming around full circle
column4: because four decades ago he kicked off his non-pop career by issuing The Sinking of the Titanic by his friend and peer Gavin Bryars. That release
column5: which featured not only Bryars but also Michael Nyman and Derek Bailey
column6: was the very first on Eno’s then-new Obscure label in 1975
column7: and served as one more footnote in the annals of Eno’s history in serving as a nexus for the “scenius.” (a term he coined to describe his belief that “it’s not individuals who create things
column8: it’s scenes.”) The Bryars opus is also a double-edged sword as reference points go
column9: because it has claimed ownership on Titanic-related musical storytelling
column10: and it’s also incredibly good.

column1: Thankfully
column2: the comparisons end there. While Bryars’s piece
column3: with its beautiful
column4: looping melody and gentle
column5: nagging insistence
column6: conjures a feeling of an auspicious capital-M Moment whirlpooling slowly downward
column7: Eno’s opening track “The Ship” tells a story not of submerging into sea but of floating listlessly across windless water and forever fog
column8: waves nibbling at the bow and starboard. With a minimalist structure and languid pace
column9: this is not music meant to be experienced or appreciated by those in a hurry
column10: or to be played in the background; it demands your attention in a way that quiet music often doesn’t.

column1: For those willing to stick it out for 21 minutes
column2: “The Ship” unfolds with a kind of majesty that can make one feel like they’re getting their body re-calibrated. Slowly shifting synths establish both gait and mood
column3: before eventually giving way to poem-like vocals by Eno
column4: intoned in a sort of Gregorian chant that only serves to strengthen the feeling that you are being induced into a meditative state. They continue for several minutes before subsiding and the track’s gentle voyage continues
column5: with pitch-shifted voice returning with the refrain “Wave
column6: after wave
column7: after wave.” While not ambient music
column8: the sounds at times resemble moments from Eno’s past
column9: including especially the burbling sounds around 5:50 that recall his work with Bowie on Heroes’ ""Neuköln.""

column1: From here
column2: The Ship gives way to the album’s second longest composition
column3: “Fickle Sun (i)
column4: ” clocking in at 18 minutes. Though the pace is a similar speed to “The Ship
column5: ” the feel is quite different
column6: with a bass somewhere between “bounce” and “plod” and trebly
column7: rising synths that give the track a menacing oomph. A later section seems to call upon the ’00s work of Fennesz
column8: David Sylvian
column9: and Scott Walker
column10: which are good reference points for this record in general. While “The Ship” is remarkable for sustaining a specific tone for 21 minutes
column11: all the while telling a clear story
column12: “Fickle Sun (i)” is just as impressive
column13: going in more directions musically and challenging the listener’s sense of understanding.

column1: After these two behemoths conclude
column2: the storm clears and we are left with two brief cuts that function more as appendices
column3: both of which are technically parts of “(ii)” and “(iii)” of “Fickle Sun” and each of which present issues for different reasons. “(ii)”
column4: subtitled “The Hour Is Thin
column5: ” carries the same emotional tone
column6: but stripped down only to plaintively struck piano notes and with a spoken-word piece by Peter Serafinowicz. While the music itself fits very well here
column7: it would have been preferable to hear Eno’s honeyed baritone instead of Serafinowicz's clinical recitation. And “Fickle Sun (iii)” is a luxurious
column8: jaw-dropping cover of the Velvet Underground’s “I’m Set Free” emerging unexpectedly from the last twinkled notes of “The Hour is Thin.” It’s incongruous to the rest of the record
column9: but is so painfully perfect it can make you nearly let go of everything you’ve just heard to imagine
column10: for a second
column11: that Eno hadn’t stopped making pop music all those years ago.

column1: The Ship is a great
column2: unexpected record. The title track and “Fickle Sun (i)” on their own and as a connected piece of music are marvelous accomplishments
column3: distinctive in Eno’s catalog. And “I’m Set Free” immediately ranks among the most perfect-sounding pop songs Eno has ever had a hand in making. It is a little tough to process the disparity between the minimalist front and the melodic hanging chad of “I’m Set Free” at the end—and the latter is just so damned good that Eno’s pop fans may weep over being denied a full record’s worth of it. But in the end it’s easy to feel grateful that it all exists
column4:
and enthusiastic that Eno is an artist who still sees new techniques to learn and new landscapes to paint.

Collaborations between classical players and composers associated with rock are no longer surprising. By now
column3: most Radiohead fans know that Jonny Greenwood writes orchestra works. Fans of Annie Clark and Sufjan Stevens may have seen those singers’ chamber-music pieces show up on albums by groups such as yMusic. One thing that has remained rare
column4: though
column5: is the indie-meets-classical “merged ensemble.” While someone like Bryce Dessner may play guitar in a classical group
column6: we haven’t seen him include his bandmates from the National in any original items written for the Kronos Quartet.

column1: So it is genuinely notable to find the members of Deerhoof hanging with an elite contemporary classical group like Ensemble Dal Niente. Even more impressive is the fact that the Deerhoof players aren’t here to perform arrangements of their own music. Instead
column2: this collaborative album opens with Dal Niente and Deerhoof tearing through a seven-movement suite by Brazilian-American composer Marcos Balter
column3: titled ""meltDown Upshot."" This 23-minute opus takes full advantage of this mega-ensemble’s chamber chops and rock edge—just like you’d hope—but it doesn’t stop there. When he’s not indulging in minimalist-inspired patterns or proggy progressions
column4: Balter also includes some gestures that sound copped from the world of avant-jazz.

column1: That’s a lot of textures for any one composer to handle well. Though Balter pulls it off. His writing engages with the diverse talents of this group without ever feeling choppy. The contemplative first movement
column2: “Credo
column3: ” places the delicate (but confident) vocals of Deerhoof’s Satomi Matsuzaki over writing for strings and piano that often glides over the minor second interval—a doleful semitone hop that receives tender-lullaby handling
column4: here. The second movement introduces Greg Saunier’s drums and Ed Rodriguez’s electric guitar arpeggios
column5: and it has a lightly propulsive feel.

column1: A hint of manic writing announces the third movement
column2: “Ready
column3: ” which is packed full of short
column4: exciting riffs for the full ensemble
column5: as well as saxophone squall and fast-moving vocal figures. Plucked strings
column6: piano and Saunier’s drums animate the memorable “True/False.” Later on
column7: “Cherubim” builds on the indie-power first introduced during “Ready.” This time
column8: the drums and guitars hit harder—yet they don’t obscure the contributions of the Dal Niente players
column9: either. And while this passage represents the height of freneticism during ""meltDown Upshot
column10: the climax of the piece is delivered by the more optimistic-sounding harmonies of “Rapture
column11: ” the closing movement. Overall
column12: this feels like a major composition from Balter. And it’s also a triumph for the musicians of Dal Niente and Deerhoof. The performance comes from a group that sounds like a group
column13: rather than two bands taking a flier on a cross-genre experiment.

column1: On the record's other long track
column2: Dal Niente play the music of Deerhoof
column3: as newly arranged by Saunier himself. Though
column4: in keeping with the band’s own fragmented aesthetic
column5: these aren’t straight-up transcriptions. The stomping chords from the beginning of “Rainbow Silhouette of the Milky Rain” (originally heard on the album Milk Man) have been pulled apart a bit in the version that appears almost four minutes into ""Deerhoof Chamber Variations."" Now the barnstorming line sounds more akin to the work of John Adams
column6: circa that composer’s madcap Chamber Symphony.

column1: Touches like these keep Saunier’s recasting of various Deerhoof themes from seeming under-thought. But even when the music is smart and attractive
column2: the roving unpredictability of the band’s own performances is not always captured by these arrangements. Nor does the overall shape of this 20-minute work have the same force as Balter’s major piece. Still
column3: Dal Niente’s playing is always vibrant
column4: and it’s interesting to hear Saunier stretching in this way. Deerhoof and Dal Niente are both plenty busy with their more typical efforts
column5:
but their joint-venture debut sounds far too good to be a one-off.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23173/homepage_large.2bf7c445.jpg|Triangle|27272.0|Susanna|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['SusannaSonata']|2016-04-27 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:28.761553|"

Norwegian singer-songwriter Susanna Wallumrød’s career has taken many forms. With her project Susanna and the Magical Orchestra
column2: she made several albums of art-pop composed enough to be interesting yet accessible enough for TV syncs. One might also know her for her deconstructed covers of pop songs akin to those of Stina Nordenstam or Cat Power
column3: or perhaps for her stint of making straightforward alt-rock—on 2011’s underrated Jeg vil hjem til menneskene
column4: which was situated somewhere between jazz and grunge. These days
column5: one’s as likely to know her for her collaborations with Scandinavian artists like Jenny Hval; like many in her circles
column6: Susanna is an accomplished curator of talent
column7: and her first self-produced album
column8: Triangle
column9: features a murderer’s row of jazz and experimental musicians
column10: including Helge Sten of Deathprod and Anja Lauvdal of Skadedyr.

column1: With so many influences to synthesize for a first solo production
column2: it makes sense that Susanna would go big: 22 songs
column3: reprises and interludes and variations on themes
column4: generally on religion and mortality. She’s described Triangle as “soul music for lost souls
column5: ” and the first few seconds neatly sum up her idea of this: “Nothing is holy
column6: nothing is sacred
column7: ” she intones over a synth pitched like a chant section. Triangle is the sort of fully-realized work that can only come from an artist lost in her highest
column8: headiest intellectual space. It’s also near-monastically austere
column9: nearly 70 minutes long
column10: and a commitment
column11: at best
column12: to take in as an album; in even a mildly uncharitable mood
column13: the unending sparseness will be wearying.

column1: Paradoxically
column2: Triangle is best experienced in short
column3: repeated bursts of close listening. “Burning Sea” conjures waves of feedback that evoke its title
column4: if perhaps too obviously. “We Don’t Belong” is an almost religious meditation on impermanence
column5: Ecclesiastes arranged for solo voice and drone; when the piano comes in
column6: it’s like anxious palpitations
column7: scrabbling back and clinging to earth. “Born Again
column8: ” another religion-adjacent track
column9: comes off like a deconstructed gospel song
column10: the piano and brass collapsing where elsewhere they might exult
column11: and Susanna’s words a subtly yet fundamentally tweaked credo: “born again
column12: and again
column13: and again.”

column1: “Death Hanging
column2: ” in its original form
column3: was a trio recording with Susanne Sundfør and Siri Nilsen in the vein of Harris/Parton/Ronstadt or Case/Lang/Veirs—folk that floats above and haunts its listener. The Triangle recording is a more traditional duet with Dutch mezzo Jessica Sligter; from her first note
column4: her more harrowing voice amid Triangle’s spare arrangements and soprano lines is instantly arresting. The arrangement
column5: a maelstrom of cello and low strings
column6: works much the same. Death sounds more imminent here. A little more editing and pacing might have made the whole album like this
column7: but given enough time
column8:
Triangle has moments of clarity to be found.

Oktane and Price of Audio Push got their first taste of the music biz and misnomers back in the MySpace era when their dance-inspired song “Teach Me How To Jerk” blew up on the social networking site. Teenagers at the time
column3: the two kids from Southern California’s Inland Empire region were swept up in a major label feeding frenzy and signed to Interscope in 2009. Articles popped up describing jerkin’—a descendant of clowning and krumping before it—as a “movement” and Audio Push (then known as “The P.U.S.H.”) also became reluctant representatives of the SoCal’s dance scene.

column1: Dancing was a part of their lifestyle but not central to it. Like many other kids from their neighborhood
column2: they jerked but they also skated and gangbanged and prayed and—most importantly—rapped. This multi-faceted
column3: seemingly contradictory existence is the crux of their content. In the years since their debut single they’ve been dropped and re-signed (via Hit-Boy’s HS87 imprint)
column4: and released 11 free mixtapes and EPs that have showcased their versatility. They’ve shown they can do everything from romantic rap to grimy boom bap to turn-up anthems and have collaborated with a who’s-who of artists including Lil Wayne
column5: Travis Scott
column6: Wale
column7: Joey Bada$$
column8: and G-Eazy. What they’ve yet to do
column9: however
column10: is have breakout success. The Stone Junction EP
column11: their very first for-sale project
column12: is a declaration of their intention to change that without compromising their positive “good vibe” message.

column1: Realizing that versatility can be a liability—especially in an industry that prefers its musicians to have easily identifiable sounds—Audio Push has enlisted some of Atlanta’s premier producers to complement their distinctively Californian approach to rhyming. The beats are high energy
column2: juxtaposing the duo’s lyricism with 808s and synths. “They wanna put me in a box/ The industry
column3: the enemies and the cops
column4: ” raps Price on the Slade Da Monsta-produced
column5: “BBQ Spot.” The formula works throughout the EP—the music lending intensity and urgency to their assertions of MC supremacy and descriptions of the everyday struggle.

column1: Beyond beats
column2: they get assists from ATL on the mic too: Kap G joins in for some trap-inflected wordplay on the one the album’s standouts
column3: “Vámonos
column4: ” and Two-9’s Jace helps to slam the door shut at the end of the seven-song EP on “Same.” Still in the midst of adrenaline-pumping songs like these it’s that second half of “Hard” that teases Audio Push’s potential to make even greater
column5: emotive music. At the 2:34 mark
column6: the ominous
column7: unmistakably ATL thump of producer Ducko McFli’s beat gives way to glistening piano chords and swirling strings and things get emotional. What was an aggressive backdrop for bravado becomes a vulnerable
column8: heartfelt verse from Price: “It’s hard to see you not be yourself/ It’s hard to see you with someone else/ Hard to know your heart was broken/ And you find it hard to grow/ Wth me
column9: and it’s hard to cope
column10: ” he confesses to some unnamed ex-lover. A brief glimpse of what’s in store
column11:
tucked away in a brief project. A moment that shows just how tough being tender can be.

column3: Beyoncé Knowles Carter starts rolling mid-scene: She’s just realized that her husband is cheating on her. The surrounding context is familiar to anyone who follows popular culture. Beyoncé and Jay Z are the most famous musical couple on the planet
column4: and Beyoncé in particular is in a great place. With 2013’s Beyoncé
column5: MJ-level talent met pop-perfectionism in a moment that defined album-cycle disruption; moreover
column6: it was a victory lap Bey took as pop feminism's reigning goddess. Jay Z
column7: on the other hand
column8: is a rapper who used to rap brilliantly and sometimes still sounds good when he really tries
column9: but his music has become secondary. Over the course of their eight-year marriage and long courtship before that
column10: Jay Z and Beyoncé’s private relationship seemed to play out in song
column11: in concert
column12: and of course
column13: in the tabloids. But Beyoncé’s “smile pretty and give no interviews” approach to public relations over the last couple of years
column14: combined with “the elevator incident” and subsequent speculation about the state of their marriage
column15: and followed by their public makeup (see: VMAs 2014
column16: On the Run Tour)
column17: has suggested that something has changed
column18: but that Beyoncé would prefer we not know the specifics.

column1: Lemonade shatters this theory. If the album is to be considered a document of some kind of truth
column2: emotional or otherwise
column3: then it seems Beyoncé was saving the juicy details for her own story. Because nothing she does is an accident
column4: let’s assume she understands that any song she puts her name on will be perceived as being about her own very public relationship. So what we think we know about her marriage after listening is the result of Beyoncé wanting us to think that. With its slate of accompanying videos
column5: Lemonade is billed as Beyonce’s second ""visual album."" But here that voyeuristic feeling manifests while listening rather than viewing
column6: given the high visibility of Bey and Jay. The songwriting is littered with scenes that seem positively cinematic
column7: so it helps that you can imagine these characters living them: Beyoncé smelling another woman’s scent on Jay Z
column8: her pacing their penthouse in the middle of the night before leaving a note and disappearing with Blue. Lemonade is a film as well
column9: yet the album itself feels like a movie.

column1: It’s not until the record's second half that you realize Lemonade has a happy ending. At first you might think that Bey is using the album to announce her divorce from Jay’s cheating ass. Because she doesn’t scold
column2: “Don’t you ever do that to me again”—she drags her very famous
column3: seemingly powerful husband publicly
column4: in the process giving the world a modern-day “Respect” in “Don’t Hurt Yourself.” On the “7/11”-style banger “Sorry
column5: ” she turns his side-chicks into memes
column6: which will inevitably become “better call Becky with the good hair” sweatshirts that Beyoncé can sell for $60 a pop. Best revenge is your paper.

column1: If you’ve ever been cheated on by someone who thought you’d be too stupid or naive to notice
column2: you will find the first half of Lemonade incredibly satisfying. If you have ears and love brilliant production and hooks that stick
column3: you'll likely arrive at the same conclusion. The run from “Hold Up” to “6 Inch” contains some of Beyoncé’s strongest work—ever
column4: period—and a bit of that has to do with her clap-back prowess. The increasingly signature cadence
column5: patois
column6: and all-around attitude on Lemonade speaks to her status as the hip-hop pop star—but this being Bey
column7: she doesn’t stop there. Via the album’s highly specific samples and features by artists like Jack White and James Blake
column8: Lemonade proves Beyoncé to also be a new kind of post-genre pop star. (Let us remember a time
column9: not very long ago
column10: when Bey and Jay attending a Grizzly Bear show with Solange made headlines.)

column1: Both of these attributes—a methodical rapper’s flow
column2: an open-eared listener’s frame of reference—meet on the slowed-down stunner “Hold Up
column3: ” where Beyoncé borrows an iconic Karen O turn of phrase via Ezra Koenig
column4: a touch of Jamaican flavor via Diplo (again)
column5: and a plucky Andy Williams sample to fight for her man while chiding him for doing this to her (!)
column6: of all people. From there
column7: Bey’s just like
column8: “fuck it—<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pXdIK1xgfFk"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">big mistake
column9: huge” and gets (Tidal co-owner) Jack White to join her in dueting over a psychedelic soul jam and a Zeppelin sample as she scowls
column10: “Watch my fat ass twist
column11: boy
column12: as I bounce to the next dick
column13: boy.” As she accuses her husband of not being man enough to handle all of her multitudes
column14: fury frays her voice. Even on an album stacked with some of Beyoncé’s best recorded vocal performances to date
column15: “Don’t Hurt Yourself” has her belting to a whole other dimension—specifically
column16: that of Janis Joplin and late-‘60s Tina Turner. This won’t be the last time Bey dips into the classic vinyl on Lemonade
column17: either: see “Freedom
column18: ” which manages to both: a) speak poignantly to Civil Rights as much as personal plight
column19: b) sound like an Adidas commercial; this means it’s the logical choice for next single
column20: assuming Beyoncé is still releasing those.

column1: Bey’s genre-hopping doesn’t always sound quite as transcendent as “Don’t Hurt Yourself
column2: ” however. Though certainly memorable (not least because it finds her name-checking the Second Amendment)
column3: “Daddy Lessons”—where a country guitar-line meets New Orleans brass in service of her Southern roots—is the least interesting chapter sonically
column4: though the parallels it draws between Jay Z and Beyoncé’s own cheating father still make it crucial in the context of Lemonade’s narrative. It’s hard to see how Beyoncé could have done without any of these scenes to tell the story (not even “Formation” in the end-credits)
column5: and though the specific sounds may not be as forward-thinking as those of her 2013 self-titled
column6: there are clear reasons for every musical treatment she has made here. Lemonade is a stunning album
column7: one that sees her exploring sounds she never has before. It also voices a rarely seen concept
column8: that of the album-length ode to infidelity. Even stranger
column9: it doesn’t double as an album-length ode to breaking up.

column1: Yes
column2: after Beyoncé makes nearly half an album’s worth of glorious rage songs directed at an unfaithful partner
column3: she gives it a little time and remembers that she was raised to value hard work and spirituality. And so
column4: she can’t give up on her marriage
column5: the same one she spent her last two albums (mostly) celebrating. Beyoncé even kind of sells it
column6: surmising with a tear-inducing sincerity on relaxed-fit soul jam “All Night” that “nothing real can be threatened.” It’s an easy platitude to make
column7: but it’s also an extremely Beyoncé way of looking at things. For a perfectionist who controls her image meticulously
column8: Beyoncé is obsessed with the notion of realness. That’s the biggest selling point of an album like Lemonade
column9:
but there’s a quality to it that also invites skepticism: That desire to basically art-direct your own sobbing self-portrait to make sure your mascara smears in the most perfectly disheveled way. But who cares what's ""real"" when the music delivers a truth you can use.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23165/homepage_large.827e37b8.jpg|Always Strive and Prosper|30648.0|A$AP Ferg|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['RCA']|2016-04-26 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:30.165363|"

When they first came on the scene
column2: A$AP Ferg and A$AP Rocky offered two very different perspectives on rap’s new Harlem. In Rocky’s case
column3: he brought a strong sense of fashion
column4: with musical branches extending to Houston and Atlanta. Ferg stayed with the conventions of trap music
column5: though his cadence and lyricism diverted from the genre’s formulaic sound. And just like that
column6: the Trap Lord was born. His debut was aptly titled
column7: full of chest-beating cuts that suggested Ferg was artsier than Rocky and slightly more overbearing—the Kanye to his Jay. But what happens when you’ve run out of superlatives for yourself and self-reflection kicks in? Well
column8: you work in reverse
column9: which is exactly where Ferg resides on his follow-up project Always Strive and Prosper. If Ferg secured a strong group of followers off Trap Lord
column10: then his new album will surely lock them down as a cult.

column1: An argument could be made that ASAP is the prequel to Trap Lord
column2: where we’re finally understanding the Bruce Wayne before the Batman. But the underlying self-awareness suggests that Ferg has tasted fame and rejected the poisonous parts. The opener “Rebirth” makes that declaration in no uncertain terms. Over a joint production effort of DJ Khalil and Clams Casino
column3: a chopped-and-screwed Ferg talks to himself: “Now that you’re no longer a lord that’s trapped/ You have graduated to the Hood Pope/ You have made it to represent your people/ Show them another way/ Be the voice of the people who couldn’t make it out the hood.”

column1: This is no longer about A$AP Ferg
column2: but Darold Ferguson
column3: Jr. (Ferg’s given name)
column4: who came back home after being out in the world to report on what he’s seen. Production-value is high
column5: with Ferg enlisting top-tier beatmakers like the aforementioned DJ Khalil but also No I.D.
column6: DJ Mustard
column7: and even Skrillex. But the beats take a backseat to the lyrics. The overall sound remains intact
column8: but he’s even more invested in what he’s saying.

column1: The track “Strive” brings a deep house vibe—compliments of Mustard and Stelios Phili—as Ferg shares the cautionary tale of sitting at a basic job with bigger dreams but refusing to trap like the rest of them. Missy Elliott is the icing on the cake
column2: bringing an evenly ambitious verse
column3: turning what could have been a simple dance track into something so much more. Missy isn’t the only notable collaborator on the project. ASAP boasts an all-star lineup ranging from Chris Brown and Ty Dolla $ign on the breezy “I Love You” to Rick Ross on the violently spacey “Swipe Life” and even Chuck D on “Beautiful People
column4: ” also featuring his Mama Ferg. The family theme runs throughout Always Strive and Prosper. The idea of affording luxuries for his mother remains at the forefront (buying his mama a house on “Swipe Life”)
column5: but so does his family in general. His Uncle “Psycho” gets his own song
column6: as does his “Grandma
column7: ” and there’s a strong desire on Ferg’s part to be a family man.

column1: Stargate makes a smart appearance
column2: producing “Let You Go
column3: ” which has the capacity to own the summer on beat alone
column4: as does “Let It Bang” with ScHoolboy Q
column5: only in an entirely different part of town. The deluxe version caps off Always Strive and Prosper with one vital cut—the quintessential New York joint “Don’t Mine” with French Montana and Fabolous—and one recklessly unnecessary one
column6: the aggressively average “Back Hurt” with Migos. While Ferg is aware of his new station in music
column7: there a few slip-ups where he falls back on style over substance. But not nearly enough to disqualify his epiphany.

column1: There’s an important allegory woven through the fabric of A$AP Ferg’s Always Strive and Prosper: A$AP Ferg likes his fame
column2: but doesn’t need it. He’s making this transition from Trap Lord to Hood Pope
column3: attempting to address his congregation of all the perils that come with celebrity. It’s a vulnerable position in which to be in
column4: following a self-proclaimed lord status. But strip away the features
column5: strip the beats
column6: strip the quirky nicknames
column7: and you’re left with Darold’s wise words
column8:
coming through loud and clear.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23178/homepage_large.1e36b86b.jpg|New Misery|33302.0|Cullen Omori|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2016-04-26 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:30.873851|"

When a band goes through a messy divorce
column2: you often get a clean division of communal artistic property. The ensuing rivalry
column3: whether spoken or unspoken
column4: typically pits the eccentric against the centrist—see Mars Volta vs. Sparta
column5: Lennon vs. McCartney
column6: Wilco vs. Son Volt
column7: or Andre 3000 vs. Big Boi. For those who must choose sides in following the dissolution of Smith Westerns
column8: which saw former guitarist Max Kakacek breaking off from the band to form Whitney
column9: an immediate tonal difference can be identified: Whitney plays breezy AM radio-indie; Lead singer Cullen Omori made a solo record and called it New Misery.

column1: So it’s up to Omori to further the emotional trajectory the Smith Westerns established over their three LPs. While they grew from reckless
column2: glam-punk wunderkinds to the verge of maturity
column3: the best Smith Westerns songs (<a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/12032-the-smith-westerns-weekend/"">“Weekend
column4: “All Die Young”) were the sound of young men seeing their golden days dissolving in front of their eyes in real time. Their success was enviable by just about any standard
column5: but now that the smoke has cleared
column6: Omori is now saddled with the expected problems of someone who skipped college to be in a modestly popular rock band: financial instability and a lack of marketable skills.

column1: There are points here where Omori directly invokes his previous band’s rep as hedonist brats amongst the genteel indie rock acts that defined the early part of the decade
column2: but his malaise is typically drawn broadly enough to not offend the specifics of any quarter-life crisis. “Wrote a letter to my former self/ Saying ‘thanks for knowing when to give up’
column3: ” he smirks on “No Big Deal
column4: ” speaking to the regrets and fear recognizable to anyone who invested their formative years in something that left them unprepared to face the future. Sure
column5: an early highlight of New Misery is a sleepwalk of drowsy harmonies and slide guitar reminiscent of All Things Must Pass. But its sentiment is a far more cynical rendering of the same idea: “And Yet the World Still Turns.”

column1: Omori has never been the most personal songwriter
column2: so the context of New Misery gives an easy entry and a new way to experience a style that has remained mostly intact since Soft Will. Very little of it can be described as “rock
column3: ” none of it as “punk
column4: ” the result of Omori trying to emulate the top 40 music he’d hear in hospitals while working with a medical supply company. New Misery provides sturdy melodies throughout; as with Tame Impala’s Kevin Parker
column5: Omori’s voice ensures that he’ll always approach pop sounding like a classic rock throwback
column6: though he doesn’t have the same taste for adventure or sonic precision.

column1: New Misery’s filler doesn’t lie in the songs themselves
column2: but rather within them
column3: the predictable indulgences of both solo albums and transitions from guitar to synthesizers. The instrumental sections that of “And Yet the World Still Turns” and “Lom” meander rather than mesmerize
column4: overdubs add distance rather than depth
column5: Shane Stonebeck’s production slathers reverb on every instrument
column6: turning even the coke-sniffing Drive-pop of “Cinnamon” into aural taffy.

column1: The razored leads of Kakacek were often the thing that could draw boundaries on Smith Westerns songs as they became increasingly reliant on reverb and Chris Coady’s humidified production. Omori hasn’t quite figured out how to replace them; “Poison Dart” and “Sour Silk” would be gorgeous Smith Western ballads without the time-stamped
column2: sci-fi synths that feel like placeholders. He certainly doesn’t need any implication that Kakacek and Julien Ehrlich’s absence are palpable and sorely missed here; after all
column3: the reception of Whitney’s Light Upon the Lake singles has them well-positioned to play afternoon festival slots for at least the next two years. But that’s where the non-musical context of New Misery comes into play—it’s a transitional album in all senses
column4:
more intent on Omori getting lost inside himself before he tries to move forward.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23177/homepage_large.074d57a0.jpg|Double Ecstasy EP|31017.0|Antwon|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anticon']|2016-04-26 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:31.384734|"

San Jose rapper Antwon is not an easy read. For every vulnerable song there's another that feels insufferably ironic
column2: and all of the above are unwaveringly libidinous
column3: some more mature than others. Returning now with the five-song
column4: 16-minute Double Ecstasy EP
column5: Antwon has refined his vision as well as his aesthetic choices
column6: but the overall message remains consistent. He's still a conflicted hedonist
column7: adept at both indulgence and self-loathing.

column1: Double Ecstasy makes more sense sonically than Antwon's previous work. The diffuse cloud rap of 2014's Heavy Hearted in Doldrums
column2: which made any genuine confessions feel like jokes
column3: has been replaced with pounding club-ready songs. On ""Luv
column4: Antwon openly raps about visiting the strip club to make himself feel happy like his friends (who consume drugs
column5: in their own right
column6: to ease life's pain)
column7: but at the most audible on the hook
column8: he wouldn't dare say he's going to ""the booty club"" to ""fall in love.""

column1: ""Luv"" is an important step forward for Antwon
column2: as it's one of the rare times he sounds at home over an instrumental that's as powerful as his natural vocal delivery. On ""Girl
column3: Flex
column4: however
column5: Antwon falls right back into his musical and behavioral traps
column6: rapping bland and juvenile lines like ""I'm chillin' with my lil bitch at the mall."" Unlike ""Luv
column7: there's no self examination
column8: and he doesn't make sex sound particularly fun.

column1: When artists like Future
column2: Danny Brown
column3: and Young Thug rap about excess
column4: they're so beyond the pale or dejected that trauma is clear. But Antwon never manages that level of complexity. Still
column5: the songs on Double Ecstasy are enjoyable and
column6: at times
column7: captivating. They're uptempo and Antwon's voice is inviting
column8: his delivery incredibly consistent. But the EP also leaves the rapper at a crossroads. He could continue to make solid tracks that occasionally pop when all the circumstances align
column9: or he could further explore his more confessional side
column10: but at this point
column11:
it would make sense for him to commit one way or another.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23172/homepage_large.5a440cc6.jpg|Too Many Voices|22792.0|Andy Stott|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Modern Love']|2016-04-25 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:31.945234|"

When Manchester's Andy Stott dropped the Passed Me By EP in 2011
column2: its sound was such a paradigm shift for the producer that it effectively obliterated all that had come before. A previous full-length and more than a dozen singles were rendered obsolete; this rang out as Stott's ""true"" sound and self. The bruising and bleak dirges were diametrically opposed to the dub techno of his earlier work
column3: its depth of bass aligned more with Sunn O))) and Demdike Stare. Through albums like Luxury Problems and Faith in Strangers
column4: the silty sound palette evoked dour industrial spaces even as Stott let in more and more light
column5: primarily by folding in the voice of his onetime piano teacher Alison Skidmore. Much like one of David Lynch's blondes
column6: she was the one beacon of light in human darkness.

column1: For most of Too Many Voices
column2: it sounds like the end of that cycle
column3: suggesting that the grimy sonic template that defined Stott and earned him fans in noise and experimental circles the past five years ultimately might just be a phase itself rather than a final iteration. If anything
column4: Stott sounds like Blue Velvet’s Jeffrey Beaumont
column5: pulled between those two worlds
column6: still dabbling in dark
column7: abrasive textures while also moving towards something airier. ""Butterflies"" best exemplifies that split. On the hand it keeps the sluggish rhythm that underpinned his previous tracks. But rather than sounding weighted by granite it feels untethered
column8: the beat landing like ping pong balls instead of boulders. A melody shrieks through
column9: but the mood is no longer foreboding and the effect more enervating than haunting. And where Skidmore’s vocals once gave tracks such as this a thrilling contrast
column10: against these thinner backdrops
column11: now they are turned into mere wisps.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: the tracks feel unfinished
column3: such as ""Selfish
column4: wherein Stott takes a preset that sounds like a monkey wrench on cheap plastic. It’s the album’s trickiest beat
column5: bringing to mind early dancehall
column6: early '00s grime and even a bit of Radiohead’s ""Idioteque
column7: but Stott does very little with the beat or with Skidmore's voice
column8: just speeding up and slowing down both elements. "" The distorted beat of ""On My Mind"" and gaseous synths might be the start of something
column9: but Stott seems reluctant to add layers in-between. The inverse applies to the title track
column10: with Skidmore’s voice existing in multiples but with little around them. There’s plenty of low and high end
column11: but none of the gray in-between. It makes for an album that sounds more like backing tracks missing the singer and the song to complete them. If anything
column12: Too Many Voices sounds like it has too few.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23135/homepage_large.bbf6e4ba.jpg|At Last!|23485.0|Etta James|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Jackpot Records']|2016-04-25 00:00:00|1960|2016-06-11 15:47:32.680231|"

Anyone trying to reverse-engineer the particular way contemporary pop ballads are now sung— the careening melisma
column2: the guttural
column3: quasi-unscripted grunts
column4: an apparently boundless capacity for emotion–needs only to consider a handful of tough
column5: pioneering American singers: Bessie Smith
column6: Sister Rosetta Tharpe
column7: Alberta Hunter
column8: Aretha Franklin
column9: and Etta James. This past Record Store Day
column10: Portland's Jackpot Records reissued James's masterwork
column11: At Last!
column12: on limited edition vinyl
column13: including the four bonus tracks which first appeared on a CD reissue in 1999. More than a half-century after its release
column14: At Last! remains one of the greatest records about loneliness ever made: a languid
column15: jazz-inflected paean to (reluctantly) working it out on your own.

column1: James was born in 1938
column2: in the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles
column3: as Jamesetta Hawkins. She never knew her father
column4: and her mother was only fourteen when she gave birth. James was raised by a series of foster parents
column5: and came of age singing in the Echoes of Eden choir at St. Paul's Baptist church. Stories of her childhood— including the ones she recounts herself in Rage to Survive
column6: her tellingly titled autobiography—are grisly. One of her foster parents
column7: a loutish man called Sarge
column8: used to drag her from bed in the middle of the night and force her
column9: via brutal and humiliating beatings
column10: to sing for a cabal of his drunk poker cronies. In the early 1950s
column11: she joined a girl group (the Creolettes; later the Peaches) and met the R&B producer Johnny Otis
column12: who suggested she re-name herself–transmuting ""Jamesetta"" into ""Etta James""–and eventually helped the Peaches book a spot opening for Little Richard on a national tour. James left the group to sign with Chess Records
column13: and began collaborating with Harvey Fuqua
column14: then of the Moonglows and later a crucial
column15: visionary producer for Motown. At Last!
column16: her debut album
column17: was released by Argo
column18: Chess's jazz imprint
column19: in the fall of 1961.

column1: If there's anything anachronistic about At Last!
column2: it's how plainly vulnerable James sounds while performing these songs. Insomuch as it's possible to distill any one theme from the last couple decades of pop music
column3: it's the presentation of—and insistence upon—self-empowerment as an infallible path toward joy. Those sorts of affirmations can induce a wild ecstasy in the moment—I AM THE BEST! NO ONE CAN TOUCH ME! SUCK A DICK
column4: JERKS!—but eventually
column5: one has to worry about whether those same notions are not
column6: in fact
column7: a deeply odious and toxic force in the world. It can't be great for whole generations to come of age hollering self-aggrandizing anthems that never quite acknowledge the most gratifying and dangerous thing a human being can actually do: courageously make room for another person in her heart.

column1: So when James loses her man
column2: and sings a verse like this one
column3: from ""Stormy Weather""—""Life is bare
column4: gloom and mis'ry everywhere / Stormy weather
column5: stormy weather / And I just can't get my poor self together / I'm weary all of the time
column6: the time / So weary all of the time""—it sounds fearless. Most of At Last! concerns itself with unmitigated heartache. James isn't the sort of singer capable of or interested in couching true anguish in anything prettier or more reassuring
column7: and there is a glorious synchronicity between the frankness of her vocal and the heaviness of the lyrics. James was a professional
column8: and a true expert—her control is astounding; she bites off each note like she's taking a chunk out of an apple—but there's no moment on At Last! that feels explicitly or distractingly performative. There's something almost punctured in her breath
column9: like a person who has been struck in the chest
column10: effectively felled by pain.

column1: James opines
column2: repeatedly and without guile
column3: her inability to find and keep the right person for her to love. There are moments where she thinks that she had it
column4: maybe
column5: for a minute (like on ""Anything to Say You're Mine
column6: in which she waits for a letter from her lover
column7: hoping their correspondence might finally reveal his devotion to her)
column8: and then moments in which she is convinced she has already lost
column9: and will continue losing – that the ecstatic
column10: unspooling
column11: true
column12: true love she watches other people share and celebrate will elude her forever.

column1: The latter idea reaches a kind of brutal apotheosis on ""Sunday Kind of Love
column2: in which James sings
column3: over a spare
column4: barely-tinkling piano melody (interrupted
column5: on occasion
column6: by rising swells of strings)
column7: about what she wants but can't ever seem to get: an earnest communion that lasts long past Saturday night
column8: ""for all my life to have and to hold."" James isn't necessarily having a tough time attracting men to her bedroom
column9: but she can't seem to land a caring or truly unafraid partner. Periodically
column10: James lets out a little ""Uh!"" between lines of the verse. Those little vocal punctuations are commonplace now
column11: but when James looses one
column12: even the quickest
column13: most under-thought ""Uh!"" communicates tremendous certainty. She knows what she wants
column14: even (especially) as it remains just out of her reach.

column1: What's maybe most satisfying about At Last! is the record's title track
column2: arguably the single greatest unburdening ever laid to tape. It plays like a person stumbling into a hotel room and simultaneously dropping all of her bags on the floor. In an album of lost and mangled love songs
column3: in which relief and fulfillment begin to seem truly impossible (""I can't love nobody unless I'm loving you
column4: James announces in the bonus track ""If I Can't Have You
column5: a duet she co-wrote with Fuqua)
column6: here is a moment of extraordinary deliverance. Finally
column7: James finds her man: a person who doesn't get spooked
column8: doesn't waver
column9: doesn't leave her crumpled somewhere
column10: alone and pining. ""My lonely days are over
column11: and life is like a song
column12: she sings
column13: her voice buoyant. The irony – that her own songs
column14: in fact
column15: express considerable pain – is deep and heavy.

column1: Beyoncé famously performed ""At Last"" at Barack Obama's first inaugural ball
column2: while he and Michelle shared their first dance. The performance was poignant for obvious reasons—there was
column3: at last
column4: a black president in the White House—but James quickly called bullshit on it (""She ain't mine… I can't stand Beyoncé
column5: is how James expressed her annoyance during a Seattle concert
column6: shortly after the ball aired on television). There is a sense
column7: among singers of a certain era—who came of age as performers in a pre-Civil Rights America—of ferociously protecting what they have made or claimed as their own
column8: usually against staggering odds (Aretha Franklin still insists on being paid up-front and in cash
column9: and keeps her purse firmly wedged under her arm as she strolls onstage). James didn't write ""At Last""; it was written in 1941 by Mack Gordon and Harry Warren
column10: for a musical film called Orchestra Wives—but she animated it
column11: made it feel real. And there isn't a single moment on At Last! that doesn't feel unmistakably her own
column12:
and forever.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23096/homepage_large.e5a3c203.jpg|Bergtatt|4414.0|Ulver|['Metal'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Century Media']|2016-04-25 00:00:00|1995|2016-06-11 15:47:32.791711|"

The Norwegians use the word ""trolsk"" to describe the dark magic that sets in when you're wandering in the forest after sundown and find yourself seized by a desire to surrender to the id
column3: slinking off like a wolf into the forest. In the early '90s
column4: this untranslatable fury fueled the country's burgeoning black metal scene: a radical
column5: violent offshoot of the misanthropic havoc wreaked abroad by Bathory and Venom. Trolsk imbued Per Yngve Ohlin
column6: Euronymous and Varg Vikernes with the fierce energy they needed to achieve worldwide acclaim—and notoriety—with their respective bands
column7: Mayhem and Burzum. In time
column8: the same forces would lead to their downfall—and inspire musicians and fans to stab men and set churches ablaze.

column1: In Oslo 1993
column2: away from the spotlight
column3: 17-year-old Kristoffer Rygg (known to most by his nickname
column4: Garm) quietly formed Ulver with his friends: Sigmund Andreas ""Grellmund"" Løkken (who died the same year)
column5: Robin Malmberg
column6: Hävard Jørgensen
column7: Carl-Michael Eide
column8: and Ali Reza. A lifelong disciple of black metal
column9: Garm was as enamored with the necrocosms as anyone else
column10: with some exceptions: while his peers were indulging LaVeyan power-trips
column11: the teenager espoused rebellious romanticism
column12: recasting black metal as a dissonant
column13: gloomy cousin of Norwegian folk music
column14: rather than a form love-letter to Baphomet. They crystallized this vision on their first three albums
column15: which are also their loudest:'95's Bergtatt – Et Eeventyr I 5 Capitier
column16: '96's Kveldssanger
column17: and '97's Nattens Madrigal-Aatte Hymne Til Ulven I Manden. A trifold rebuttal to black metal formalism
column18: the records presaged the disintegration of heavy music's stylistic boundaries
column19: laying the groundwork for everyone from Windhand and Horseback to Drudkh and Deafheaven.

column1: Ulver's debut album Bergtatt – Et Eeventyr I 5 Capitier (typically shortened to Bargtatt) derives both its title and inspiration from a Norwegian folk tale centered around the aforementioned trolsk. Lost in the wilderness and enticed by the mythical creatures lurking in the twilight
column2: the album's female protagonist clambers into the mountains
column3: never to return. Accordingly
column4: Bergtatt's five chapters see Ulver dragging Norwegian folk into the black-metal void. The nearly seven-minute “Capitel II: Soelen gaaer bag Aase need” opens with a graceful flute solo that flits about
column5: only to get snapped up by the blast-beats after the first minute. Garm’s phantom croon drifts in to fill the vacant space
column6: guiding the melody through the web of misery. Just when it seems like a truce has been reached and all's at ease
column7: the frontman flips back to black-metal mode
column8: unleashing more punishing death growls. Ulver are a crafty bunch
column9: but they’re not afraid to flex their muscles once in a while.

column1: Bergtatt's massive arrangements are majestic on their own
column2: but the album's esteemed reputation is owed to stylistic diversity
column3: rather than pure aggression. Ulver were among the first to integrate folk into the genre's thorny framework
column4: illuminating the pitch-black racket with haunting
column5: clean melodies and acoustic arpeggios. The razed thicket gave outside listeners an access point into a sound that had catered to diehards
column6: breaking open black metal's hostile niche. Simultaneously
column7: the stylistic juggling paved the way for future crossovers by proving that metal bands could expand their stylistic palette without compromising on their abrasive integrity.

column1: A little over a year after Bergtatt made Ulver heroes in their scene
column2: the band torched their laurels on the follow-up Kveldssanger (""Twilight Songs."") The 14-track album does away with the debut's black metal trappings entirely. In other words
column3: it's an entire album of ""Capitel IV""s. Garm's icy tenor has been largely replaced by somber
column4: choral vocals
column5: frequently presented a cappella as if they're sourced from some sacrilegious church service. Unless you're a sucker for medieval chants or Norwegian folkways
column6: you'd be wise to skip over tracks like ""Ord
column7: ""A Capella (Sielens Sang)
column8: and ""Kledt I Nattens Farger"" and stick to the instrumental requiems
column9: which reprise Ulver's mournful
column10: multi-faceted approach to melody. Flutes feature prominently on the hypnotic ""Naturmystikk
column11: twirling atop the spindly chords like landing snowflakes; they deepen this wintry mood on ""Hiertets Vee
column12: situating the woodwinds within a howling blizzard. Devoid of the guitars' molten heft and the drums' thunderous pulse
column13: Kveldssanger can't capture the heft of the previous album; It's an enjoyable folk record
column14: but ultimately underwhelming.

column1: The band completed their Trilogie in 1997 with Nattens Madrigal-Aate Hymne Tip Ulven I Manden (""Madrigal of the Night – Eight Hymns to the Wolf in Man."") The eight-part record reprises the same hyper-focused approach as its predecessor
column2: but its palette's the polar opposite: a riotous return to black metal
column3: stripped clean of all traces of Ulver's folk favoritism. Once again
column4: the group found their muse in the trolsk: more specifically
column5: its animal emissary
column6: the wolf. ""It [the wolf] indisputably holds a strong position as the Devil's herald in Norwegian myths and conceptions
column7: the band revealed in an interview with Slayer. ""[Nattens Madrigal]  glorifies this fiery crossroads and describes both the pain and pleasure by giving in to and recognizing the beast within.""

column1: True to their muse
column2: Ulver frame Nattens Madrigal as a show of musical lycanthropy: not just with regards to its animalistic themes and fanged arrangements
column3: but also its ramshackled
column4: lo-fi production. Fans have come up with some crazy origin stories to explain the record's divergence the from the first two albums' sterling presentation. According to one popular (and sadly
column5: debunked) legend
column6: Ulver recorded the epic in a Norwegian forest on an 8-track recorder after blowing their entire recording budget on drugs
column7: cars and Armani suits. In actuality
column8: the cramped sonics have nothing to due with logistics; rather
column9: the album's compressed presentation is an extension of its return to nature
column10: far from the comforts of a cushy studio.

column1: Inhospitable as their presentation may be
column2: Nattens Madrigal's eight hymns unfold with the same grace as the first two records
column3: provided that you're willing to dig through the din to uncover that wild beauty. Within the monstrous core of ""Hymne V
column4: for example
column5: Jørgensen and Pedersen's guitars weave together subtle harmonies that lend the song's mammoth arrangement some much-needed breathing room. ""Hymne I"" and ""Hymne VII"" are unexpectedly nuanced as well. Even as Garm growls his throat to shreds
column6: barreling down his devolutionary path in time with the blast beats
column7: his bandmates resist the temptation to transgress. Instead
column8: the guitarists' pointed
column9: victorious solos muzzle the feral roar
column10: ensuring that the tug-of-war between man and beast never gets too one-sided.

column1: Ulver left the woods for good following Nattens Madrigal
column2: but their fascination with the arcane has yet to fade in the 19 years since the Trilogie. From industrial reinterpretations of William Blake to sludgy takes on Greek mythology
column3: they've peered into the darkness through every imaginable prism. Listening to January's sophisticated kraut-rock offensive ATGCLVLSSCAP
column4:
it's hard to believe that these three albums came from the same band. Certainly Ulver will go down in history for crafting two of black metal's greatest achievements—but it's that unparalleled polymorphism that marvels so many years later.

column2: the album's female protagonist clambers into the mountains
column3: never to return. Accordingly
column4: Bergtatt's five chapters see Ulver dragging Norwegian folk into the black-metal void. The nearly seven-minute “Capitel II: Soelen gaaer bag Aase need” opens with a graceful flute solo that flits about
column5: only to get snapped up by the blast-beats after the first minute. Garm’s phantom croon drifts in to fill the vacant space
column6: guiding the melody through the web of misery. Just when it seems like a truce has been reached and all's at ease
column7: the frontman flips back to black-metal mode
column8: unleashing more punishing death growls. Ulver are a crafty bunch
column9: but they’re not afraid to flex their muscles once in a while.

column1: Bergtatt's massive arrangements are majestic on their own
column2: but the album's esteemed reputation is owed to stylistic diversity
column3: rather than pure aggression. Ulver were among the first to integrate folk into the genre's thorny framework
column4: illuminating the pitch-black racket with haunting
column5: clean melodies and acoustic arpeggios. The razed thicket gave outside listeners an access point into a sound that had catered to diehards
column6: breaking open black metal's hostile niche. Simultaneously
column7: the stylistic juggling paved the way for future crossovers by proving that metal bands could expand their stylistic palette without compromising on their abrasive integrity.

column1: A little over a year after Bergtatt made Ulver heroes in their scene
column2: the band torched their laurels on the follow-up Kveldssanger (""Twilight Songs."") The 14-track album does away with the debut's black metal trappings entirely. In other words
column3: it's an entire album of ""Capitel IV""s. Garm's icy tenor has been largely replaced by somber
column4: choral vocals
column5: frequently presented a cappella as if they're sourced from some sacrilegious church service. Unless you're a sucker for medieval chants or Norwegian folkways
column6: you'd be wise to skip over tracks like ""Ord
column7: ""A Capella (Sielens Sang)
column8: and ""Kledt I Nattens Farger"" and stick to the instrumental requiems
column9: which reprise Ulver's mournful
column10: multi-faceted approach to melody. Flutes feature prominently on the hypnotic ""Naturmystikk
column11: twirling atop the spindly chords like landing snowflakes; they deepen this wintry mood on ""Hiertets Vee
column12: situating the woodwinds within a howling blizzard. Devoid of the guitars' molten heft and the drums' thunderous pulse
column13: Kveldssanger can't capture the heft of the previous album; It's an enjoyable folk record
column14: but ultimately underwhelming.

column1: The band completed their Trilogie in 1997 with Nattens Madrigal-Aate Hymne Tip Ulven I Manden (""Madrigal of the Night – Eight Hymns to the Wolf in Man."") The eight-part record reprises the same hyper-focused approach as its predecessor
column2: but its palette's the polar opposite: a riotous return to black metal
column3: stripped clean of all traces of Ulver's folk favoritism. Once again
column4: the group found their muse in the trolsk: more specifically
column5: its animal emissary
column6: the wolf. ""It [the wolf] indisputably holds a strong position as the Devil's herald in Norwegian myths and conceptions
column7: the band revealed in an interview with Slayer. ""[Nattens Madrigal]  glorifies this fiery crossroads and describes both the pain and pleasure by giving in to and recognizing the beast within.""

column1: True to their muse
column2: Ulver frame Nattens Madrigal as a show of musical lycanthropy: not just with regards to its animalistic themes and fanged arrangements
column3: but also its ramshackled
column4: lo-fi production. Fans have come up with some crazy origin stories to explain the record's divergence the from the first two albums' sterling presentation. According to one popular (and sadly
column5: debunked) legend
column6: Ulver recorded the epic in a Norwegian forest on an 8-track recorder after blowing their entire recording budget on drugs
column7: cars and Armani suits. In actuality
column8: the cramped sonics have nothing to due with logistics; rather
column9: the album's compressed presentation is an extension of its return to nature
column10: far from the comforts of a cushy studio.

column1: Inhospitable as their presentation may be
column2: Nattens Madrigal's eight hymns unfold with the same grace as the first two records
column3: provided that you're willing to dig through the din to uncover that wild beauty. Within the monstrous core of ""Hymne V
column4: for example
column5: Jørgensen and Pedersen's guitars weave together subtle harmonies that lend the song's mammoth arrangement some much-needed breathing room. ""Hymne I"" and ""Hymne VII"" are unexpectedly nuanced as well. Even as Garm growls his throat to shreds
column6: barreling down his devolutionary path in time with the blast beats
column7: his bandmates resist the temptation to transgress. Instead
column8: the guitarists' pointed
column9: victorious solos muzzle the feral roar
column10: ensuring that the tug-of-war between man and beast never gets too one-sided.

column1: Ulver left the woods for good following Nattens Madrigal
column2: but their fascination with the arcane has yet to fade in the 19 years since the Trilogie. From industrial reinterpretations of William Blake to sludgy takes on Greek mythology

it's hard to believe that these three albums came from the same band. Certainly Ulver will go down in history for crafting two of black metal's greatest achievements—but it's that unparalleled polymorphism that marvels so many years later.
