True to its penchant for lipstick and lingerie
column2: glam rock has proven to be the most promiscuous of musical genres. Its sneering
column3: transgressive attitude and electric-warmongering paved the way for punk
column4: but its theatrical flair also connects it to the caped crusaders of prog. And since its early ’70s heyday
column5: glam rock’s aesthetics have been revamped by everyone from synth-pop androgynes to hair-metal shriekers to 21st-century boys and toys alike. But this looseness has its limits—Elton John’s Honky Château residency notwithstanding
column6: the world is still waiting for its first true glitter-speckled
column7: roots-rock renegade. And though Portland (via Shreveport
column8: Louisiana) maverick Kyle Craft doesn’t really tart himself up beyond the occasional silver-hair dye job
column9: his frisky
column10: fantastical debut album
column11: Dolls of Highland
column12: proves the gig is his for the taking.

column1: Dolls of Highland is reportedly a break-up album
column2: cobbled from the ashes of a flamed-out eight-year relationship and recorded in a makeshift home studio set up in a friend’s laundry room. But you’d never know about that heart-rending inspiration from the stage-crashing gusto on display here. If Dolls of Highland has a basis in autobiography—the title references the Shreveport neighborhood where it was made—Craft spends the album imagining himself as Ziggy Sawdust
column3: a flamboyant fop working the barrelhouse piano in the front room of the seediest bayou bordello. His songs illustrate how the intense religiosity and voodoo-infused mythology of the South make it fertile turf for the sort of colorful characterization and freak-scenery on which glam rock was founded. This is an album populated by burlesque dancers
column4: bloodsuckers
column5: lonely nightclub singers
column6: goth girls
column7: one-night stands
column8: suicide victims
column9: and otherwise innocent folk going crazy from the heat. Craft summons you into their world like a carnival barker wooing unsuspecting customers into a funhouse attraction.

column1: Like all good Southern boys
column2: Craft grew up in the church before discovering the devil’s music
column3: and he’s prone to casting his songs’ female protagonists as temptresses who can corrupt the most pious of choir boys. There’s the undead damsel of “Eye of a Hurricane” who lures oblivious paramours to their demise with a “kiss down in the catacombs
column4: ” and the pole-dancing star of “Berlin” (the stripper’s stage name
column5: not the German city) who renders her most loyal customer a blubbering
column6: blue-balled mess hiding in a rear corner booth. But Craft transcends witchy-woman cliches through both self-deprecating humor and surprisingly sympathetic portrayals—like the vampiric hero of “Jane Beat the Reaper” who wears “medallions on a string
column7: she said they warded off the boredom/ Of life alone and the constant sting of what she was before them.” The further you venture into Dolls of Highland
column8: the more its laundry-room recording locale makes sense: This is an album where dirty souls can go to be cleansed.

column1: Craft is one of those singers who is always on
column2: with a moonstruck howl of a voice that seizes you by the lapels. Its audacity is only amplified by the relatively rustic environs: the beautiful barstool serenade “Balmorhea” could pass for a Bat Out of Hell ballad if Meat Loaf was backed by The Band
column3: while the vivacious countrified romp “Future Midcity Massacre” sounds like a Styx from the sticks. His performances are extravagant
column4: but never excessive
column5: using a folk singer’s sepia-toned palette—acoustic guitars
column6: piano
column7: harmonica—to make radiant
column8: rambunctious rock ‘n’ roll
column9: while subtly bending time and space with electrified guitar slides that hearken back to the heartland psychedelia of early-'90s Flaming Lips.

column1: But Craft’s outsized personality is matched by less flashy
column2: more fundamental skills: vivid
column3: immersive storytelling and sharply focused
column4: fat-free songs that have the lived-in feel of 40-year-old FM-radio favorites. And he can dial down the irreverence and deliver the drama on more sobering turns like “Trinidad Beach (Before I Ride)” (where Craft forges a spiritual kinship with another southern Anglophilic misfit
column5: the late Chris Bell of Big Star)
column6: and the astounding “Lady of the Ark
column7: ” a strummed-out song for a silenced siren that’s launched heavenward atop Spectorized drum crashes and sleigh-bell rattles. “Swing low
column8: sweet heathen/ Swing for the wretch and the rock ‘n’ roll kid
column9: ” Craft belts out in the song’s dying moments. “Roam this earth
column10: repeat it/ All this sin until this wicked world makes sense.” Kyle Craft may no longer go to church
column11: but he nonetheless commands a congregation
column12:
united in ostracization and a fundamental belief in blasphemy.

After losing his Silicon Valley job in the early-'00s dotcom bust
column3: Zach Schwartz debuted his Rogue Wave project in 2002
column4: during the indie-pop boom. Like his Shins-era peers
column5: Schwartz
column6: who goes by Zach Rogue
column7: was a sensitive songwriter who politely aired grievances with wayward friends
column8: reckless parents
column9: and departed partners in a way that shone a warm light on his personal losses. It was the redemptive aspect that attracted TV music scouts
column10: and the scouts who helped break the band. But after syncs in shows like ""The O.C.
column11: the label Sub Pop
column12: who had signed the group after Rogue’s lo-fi solo debut
column13: mysteriously dropped them. A decade later
column14: following increasingly crisp and radio-ready LPs
column15: sixth album Delusions of Grand Fur finds the California band at a crossroads from which every path looks like a cul-de-sac.

column1: Rogue
column2: a self-effacing character
column3: would be the first to concede his modest prospects. He’s recently professed his newfound obsession with hip-hop and electronic music
column4: lamenting that breakout stars like Kendrick Lamar are rare beacons at a time when ""[so] many artists rising to the top are garbage."" Where 2010’s Permalight felt like a rudimentary synthpop dalliance
column5: Delusions of Grand Fur is a chance for Rogue Wave to bust open the indie-pop model
column6: inspect the components
column7: and rebuild from scratch. That chance goes untaken and
column8: seemingly
column9: unobserved. The record is chronically mild—it neither pulls off nor attempts songwriting acrobatics. Highlights like ""Endless Supply"" and ""Take It Slow"" are pastoral and pretty
column10: vast yet cosy
column11: with a vague sense of battles won. But for all the formula tweaks and threads of political intent—""In the vast expanse of governments/ I think you’re gonna burn
column12: Rogue sings
column13: Leonard Cohen-like
column14: on ""Look at Me""—Rogue and Pat Spurgeon have redrafted their gentle-and-epic songwriting orthodoxy
column15: when what it needed was a revolution.

column1: A sign of the record’s impasse is its cover
column2: a defaced
column3: hollow-eyed image by the artist Matthew Craven of Confederate general P. G. T. Beauregard. That a decorated racist seemed fitting art for an otherwise harmless pop record feels instructive: Rogue has thoughtful intentions—his reading concerns white America’s blindness to its past
column4: particularly given the present GOP agenda—but overlooks the possibility that album sleeves simply aren’t the best place to put Confederate generals in 2016. Like the album’s lyrics
column5: it presents a potent idea in a manner just broad and ambiguous enough to ring hollow.

column1: It’s a shame
column2: because Rogue has a gift for making art of his uncertainties. On 2003’s ""Postage Stamp World
column3: he sang
column4: ""You can all get in line/ And lick my behind""—a comically sheepish threat that felt somehow revealing. Now
column5: apprehensive of both world-weariness and quixotic optimism
column6: his songwriting is compromised precisely by its faith in compromise. ""Hey
column7: in the morning/ Can’t get you off my mind
column8: goes a typically airy lyric from ""In the Morning
column9: a nicely crafted anthem about the trials of marriage. But never does the music submit to raw emotion
column10: relay the breathless rush of dreams chased or the complexities that
column11: in a grim political climate
column12: make retreating into the love of one’s family such a terrifying
column13: guilty temptation. As much as the record flirts with reinvention—personal
column14: political
column15:
musical—its modest ambition sounds exactly like complacency.

 The only direct sequel John Carpenter directed in his career was Escape from LA
column2: and the critical reaction to his follow up to anti-hero Snake Plissken's New York adventures in the post apocalyptic millennial hellscape of urban America was a mixed bag. In 1996 for the New York Times Stephen Holden wrote that the movie barely kept afloat amidst its conceit of ""hopelessly choppy adventure spoof."" In his over forty-year film career Carpenter has cultivated a reputation that rests on a take-it-or-leave-it attitude to camp glory. Either it touches your or it doesn't. The oodles of corn syrup blood
column3: saccharine thrills
column4: and canned dialogue to some is secretly self aware and to others confoundingly corny.

column1: His career as a musician is about as long as his film career
column2: having scored almost all of his movies on his own with an admirably spare set up of minimal synths
column3: and he's been widely praised for the sound design of his films. One could make an argument that his ability to foreground scenes with haunting sonics saved otherwise-faltering cinematics. He used repetitive synth notes as dramatic puppet strings
column4: yoking reactions and scary moments for all their worth. He hasn't produced a score that has lived up to this billing since his early- and mid-career work in Halloween
column5: Assault on Precinct 13
column6: or The Thing (when he went toe-to-toe with Ennio Morricone
column7: no less). Lest we forget
column8: he split music duties for one of his last scores with Anthrax. But that doesn't discount the fact that film scoring is irrevocably different because of what Carpenter did
column9: and if anything his easily imitable minimalist style is in vogue again. Disasterpeace's luxuriant soundtrack/Carpenter love letter It Follows
column10: or Mica Levi's spare soundscapes for Under the Skin
column11: are living examples of Carpenter's enduring legacy. And outside of film
column12: you can hear the whispers of Carpenter in the work of an artist like Oneohtrix Point Never.

column1: Emerging from the renewed interest
column2: he's begun a late-career revival as a solo musician
column3: and last year released his debut studio album Lost Themes. It was the first time Carpenter made music not directly tied to any visual accompaniment. He said that the process was freeing
column4: and the album was quite good
column5: extracting the best sides of his scores over the years. All that being said
column6: Carpenter is not a man known for his sequels. And his follow up to Lost Themes
column7: the aptly named
column8: Lost Themes II
column9: goes to show that some ideas
column10: some sounds
column11: and some themes have legible and reasonable expiration dates.

column1: Listening to the opening minutes of the album's introduction ""Distant Dream"" you miss the quieter and more restrained aspects of his music making. Brow-beating synth walls and a breathy chorus open the song at backbreaking pace
column2: and then right in the middle you're treated with a drum solo so bombastic that it sounds copy-and-pasted from a Neil Peart practice sessions. And the album never slows down from this opening salvo. The second track ""White Pulse"" starts on a lighter note
column3: and features a chord progressions that would have sounded fantastic in any of Carpenter's films
column4: but quickly descends into a confusing midsong tempo change
column5: filled with fat drum beats
column6: belching pulses
column7: and more choruses. Tracks like ""Dark Blues"" feature frolicking hair metal-style guitar solos. And others like ""Angel's Asylum"" or ""Hofner Dawn"" made me think of light shows at a local planetarium.

column1: Songs in the album's back half
column2: especially the penultimate track ""Utopian Facade"" make the experience worth it. Listening to it
column3: even on a long
column4: mundane bus ride
column5: can make you feel the hero of your own movie. It's the perfect closing credits for the journey of a normal day. But these moments are few and far between. It pops up again in brief snippets of ""Persia Rising"" and ""Last Sunrise
column6:
but it's not enough to detract from an overwhelmingly cheesy experience. You get the feeling as you listen to the entirety of Lost Themes II that someone let their finger linger far too long on the butter button at the movie theater concession stand.

Casual jazz fans know Bill Evans through his association with Miles Davis. Kind of Blue
column2: the one jazz album you own if you only own one
column3: features Evans on piano on four of the five tracks
column4: and his brief liner notes sketch out the group's approach to improvisation in poetic and accessible terms. When you learn a bit more about Kind of Blue
column5: you learn that Davis actually envisioned the record with Evans in mind. And though for years Davis was listed as the album's sole composer
column6: Evans wrote ""Blue in Green"" (he eventually received credit.)

column1: Another Kind of Blue piece
column2: ""Flamenco Sketches
column3: was partly based on Evans' arrangement of ""Some Other Time
column4: the Leonard Bernstein standard. (Evans had earlier used the slow opening vamp as a building block to his breathtaking solo piano composition ""Peace Piece""). So though he may not be an especially famous jazz musician
column5: Bill Evans played an integral role in shaping the most famous jazz recording of all time
column6: and the arc of his discography is a rewarding one for those branching off from classic Miles. ""Some Other Time"" continued to be a touchstone piece for Evans for the rest of his life
column7: appearing regularly on his albums (notably on his duet record with Tony Bennett). And now it's become the title track to a newly unearthed studio album
column8: one recorded in 1968 in Germany but not released until this month.

column1: Jazz in general overflows with archival material. It's a live medium
column2: and recordings of shows have been common since the early part of the last century. Studio LPs could typically be cut in a couple of days
column3: which generally meant a wealth of unused songs and outtakes. But it's somewhat rare to have a true unreleased album—a collection of songs recorded together at a session with the thought of a specific release that never saw the light of day.

column1: Some Other Time: The Lost Session From the Black Forest is one of these. It was recorded when Evans was on tour in Europe with a trio that included Eddie Gomez on bass and
column2: on drums
column3: a young Jack DeJohnette
column4: who would go on to much greater fame with Miles Davis
column5: Keith Jarrett
column6: and as a leader himself. It was cut between stops on a European tour by German producer Joachim-Ernst Berendt
column7: with the idea that the rights and a release plan would be figured out later. This particular group had only been documented on record just once
column8: on At the Montreux Jazz Festival
column9: recorded five days prior to this date. So the existence of an unheard studio album by the trio is a significant addition to the Evans story.

column1: The piano/bass/drums trio setting is where Evans did his most important and lasting work. He thrived on both the limitations and the possibilities of the set-up
column2: and returned to it constantly over the course of his quarter-century recording career. He generally favored truly collaborative improvising in the setup; the bassist in his trio was expected to contribute melodically and harmonically
column3: in addition to rhythmically
column4: and he could often be heard soloing alongside the pianist. Eddie Gomez
column5: heard on this album
column6: was a steady partner of Evans' for a decade
column7: and the level of empathy between the two players is something to behold. On ""What Kind of Fool Am I?
column8: Gomez's dancing lines darts between Evans' bass notes
column9: almost serving as a third hand on the piano. On the immortal title track
column10: Gomez seems like half a conversation
column11: accenting and commenting on Evans' melodic flourishes. For his part
column12: DeJohnette offers tasteful and low-key accompaniment
column13: heavy on the brushwork and soft textures on cymbals—he was more of a role-player at this point in his career. But the three together feel like a true unit.

column1: The tracklist on Some Other Time is heavy on standards
column2: with a few Evans original sprinkled in. To love the American songbook is to be in love with harmony
column3: and Evans never stopped discovering new possibilities in old and frequently played songs. He had a way of phrasing chord progressions for maximum impact
column4: and he used space as virtually another instrument. Evans recorded ""My Funny Valentine"" many times in a number of different arrangements
column5: often uptempo
column6: but here he drags it out into an achingly poignant ballad that picks up speed as it goes. In his autobiography
column7: Miles Davis famously described Evans' tone as sounding like ""like crystal notes or sparkling water cascading down from some clear waterfall
column8: and the tumble of notes on the faster sections of ""My Funny Valentine"" evince that crystalline loveliness. In addition to the material planned for the original LP
column9: there's a second LP of outtakes and alternate versions that feels very much on par with the first disc.

column1: Evans' art has endured in part because he has a brilliant combination of formal sophistication and accessibility; critics and his fellow musicians heard the genius in his approach to chords
column2: his lightness of touch
column3: and his open-eared support of others in his band
column4: while listeners could put on his records and simply bask in their beauty
column5: how Evans' continual foregrounding of emotion made the sad songs extra wrenching and the happy ones extra buoyant. He was sometimes criticized for an approach that could sound like ""cocktail piano
column6: meaning that it wasn't terribly heavy on dynamics and tended to be lower key and generally pretty
column7: but this turned out to be another strength. If you wanted jazz in the background while engaging in another activity
column8: Evans was your man
column9: and if you wanted to listen closely and hear a standard like ""Some Other Time"" pushed to the limits of expression by his ear for space
column10: he was there for that too.

column1: Evans was one of those jazz artists who changed relatively little over the course of their career. His style developed and his sound had subtle shifts in emphasis over time
column2: but his general approach to music was remarkably consistent
column3: and he remained apart from most of the fashionable trends that wound through the jazz of his era. His first studio date as a leader
column5: was just a year after Charlie Parker's death
column6: with bebop very much still au courant; his last
column8: the year before his death
column9: was the year Chuck Mangione was nominated for a Grammy for the discofied light jazz funk of ""Feels So Good."" In both of those years
column10: Evans recorded small-group acoustic jazz albums featuring his standard trio
column11: playing a mix of standards and a few originals. About midway between those two bookends came this set
column12: recorded in a small studio in Germany and left on the shelf
column13:
and it still sounds fresh and alive almost 50 years later.

DJ Quik and Problem have been sporadic collaborators for years
column6: but news of a shared EP called Rosecrans arrived as a relative surprise. Quik
column7: the '90s G-funk legend who continues making some of the best music of his career well into his 40s
column8: has been quiet since his last album
column9: The Midnight Life
column10: was released in 2014. Over the same time period Problem
column11: a generation younger than Quik but from the same city
column12: has released a handful of mixtapes pining after the commercial peak he reached in 2013 with a single called ""Like Whaaat."" At six songs
column13: the duo's breezes by as a loosely fitting tribute to a shared hometown.

column1: ""Y’all know what Rosecrans is
column2: it’s a long ass avenue that go from the beach to the streets
column3: DJ Quik says coolly on the first song
column4: describing the famous Compton throughway that the EP could soundtrack a drive down on a lazy day. Rosecrans was co-produced by Quik and Problem together but it’s the veteran’s genius that shines through in the music. For decades Quik has injected an anything-can-be-funky sensibility into his catalog and into hip-hop more generally
column5: but his legend rests also on an understated musicality that he provides himself and enlists in session instrumentalists. He makes smart music that’s easy to listen to
column6: both clinical and warm at once.

column1: Problem is a practiced and stylish-enough rapper
column2: and he’s noticeably channelled better in short verses here than you’d find on an aimlessly sprawling mixtape. He also seems to have corralled many of the EP’s seven guests. Wiz Khalifa drops in as a mostly forgettable cameo on ""This Is Your Moment
column3: which trades the EP’s frequent live bass for a bottom end programmed for the club
column4: alongside a young and far happier-to-be-here Compton rapper named Buddy. The first verse on the album belongs to Game
column5: who has made a career of reminding listeners he’s from Compton and that he knows a bunch of rappers. He does both here with a word-cloud-like verse that checks off self-implicating references to Dre
column6: Drake
column7: Bompton
column8: and Chuck Taylor’s. Bad Lucc sneaks in on ""Take It Off One Time
column9: a skippable track that sounds like a contemporary-R&B grab Problem brought to the table and Quik tweaked to his liking.

column1: Rosecrans features a pair of instrumentalists that also appeared on Quik’s last album and are billed here alongside the man himself as a trio called SuperDave. (They’re all named David.) David Forman’s bass is both fat and nimble on the shimmering opening title track
column2: while David ""Preach"" Balfour finesses his keys into a twinkle on top. David Blake is the obvious coordinator
column3: and he talks his shit instead of rapping it here—not that there’s that much difference—introducing himself as ""the abominable DJ Quik."" Quik has always considered himself a producer first
column4: but as a rapper he’s one of hip-hop’s great acquired tastes
column5: and carries the ability to revolt and charm in a single conversational bar.

column1: The EP’s crown jewel comes early with ""A New Nite / Rosecrans Grove
column2: which seems to function as a sort of nostalgic retread on one of Quik’s earliest hits
column3: 1991’s ""Tonite."" Vocalist Shy Carter does a bit of a Nate Dogg impression on the hook
column4: but the beauty is in the laid back and eventually rearranged groove. ""Now this the kinda beat that I might need Dre on
column5: Quik raps truthfully before promising
column6: ""I’mma stay on."" It’s the blippy
column7: chiptune synth that rises above the fray and catches the ear though. The seemingly out-of-place sound—""Is that my fucking pager going off?"" Problem wonders during the intro—becomes the meandering centerpiece of the track
column8: oscillating from choppily plucked out funk to the sounds you might expect from a prancing Mario as he pockets strings of coins in a hidden level. Later
column9: after more dissection and a vocoder has set the mood
column10: the synth somehow shifts into a wailing police siren with a European accent. The groove never breaks
column11: but the synth throws things off-kilter. It’s another Quik trademark: an unexpected sound twisted to surprisingly versatile depths
column12:
the same magic he’s been using to steer his still-winding career.

Plants and Animals singer/guitarist Warren Spicer has recorded and mixed his band's fourth full-length to near perfection. This cannot be overstated. Each instrument on Waltzed in from the Rumbling is so exactly in tune and at the optimum volume and placement in the speakers that it feels like each note is tangible. From the chop of the stereo-panned acoustic guitars to the gentle golf claps on last month's single
column2: ""No Worries Gonna Find Us
column3: to the train-brakes flute on ""So Many Nights
column4: to the string and horn arrangements that bring so much texture to this album
column5: everything is in its right place. If that sounds like I'm referencing a different band
column6: this is because Plants and Animals sound like a different band
column7: namely a combination of turn-of-the-century Radiohead and turn-of-the-century Flaming Lips.

column1: It's another detour in a career made of them. Over the years
column2: Plants and Animals' disinclination to stick with a signature sound has pretty much become their signature. Their first album favored folk rock arrangements and invited comparisons to Blitzen Trapper and Neil Young. Their second offered pared-down rock that ignored the precedent set by their debut. The third album was the proverbial “mature” outing. So now
column3: after a four-year absence
column4: Plants and Animals have made a collection of songs that sound gorgeous and will pop up on your Radiohead Pandora station
column5: even though they likely wouldn't even pop up on your Plants and Animals Pandora station.

column1: If the music falls between a soundtrack to dystopia and a technicolor symphony
column2: Spicer's words also fall somewhere between Thom Yorke's sneering cynicism and Wayne Coyne's wide-eyed wonder. Both lyrical ends of the OK Bulletin spectrum—""love is the place that you're drawn to"" on one end and ""when I am king
column3: you will be first against the wall"" on the other—are highly effective
column4: but the area Spicer chooses to inhabit is often a no man's land.  The first words he sings on the album are ""all my time
column5: my friend
column6: I'll spend with you
column7: which doesn't sound nearly epic enough for the music he's created with guitarist/bassist Nicolas Basque and drummer Woody Matthew Woodley.

column1: The most rewarding surprises of the album occur when the influences aren't as apparent. The trio brought many guests into Montreal's Mixart Studios for the recording sessions
column2: most notably vocalists Adéle Trottier-Rivard and Katie Moore
column3: who add winning romanticism to the mix. They trade call-and-response vocals on lead single ""Stay"" and sing with Spicer on ""Off the Water"" that they won't always have the chance to ""move with you like water when we dance."" Although all of this is expertly orchestrated
column4: it retains a loose feel
column5: one brimming with the excitement of friends getting back together to collaborate on music again. In doing so
column6: Plants and Animals have created something beautiful
column7:
even if it's not wholly original.

Jay Reatard’s reputation was to smash disco balls and get in on-stage fights—the kind of guy who tried to make people laugh by shooting bottle rockets out his ass. As wild and ridiculous as he was
column2: he took his music seriously. He moved away from home when he was 16 and dropped out of high school
column3: meaning most of his considerable free time was spent writing and recording music. He always had several bands going at once; he figured that if he played with each of his bands at least once a month
column4: he’d make enough to get by. He was an excellent guitarist who got really good at recording; his collective discography was massive. It was his living
column5: so the endless touring
column6: huge pile of records
column7: and even the provocations and live show destruction could be seen as business savvy. He played fast
column8: he played loud
column9: and in the early days of YouTube
column10: his every move was documented.

column1: By the time he died in early 2010
column2: Jay Reatard had long usurped the Oblivians’ throne and ruled as the undisputed kingpin of Memphis garage rock. (He knew it
column3: too—he quipped that getting thrown out of Gonerfest was like “kicking Jimi Hendrix out of Woodstock.”) He wasn’t just some local figurehead
column4: either—he was the standard bearer for an entire genre. Obviously there were prolific punks before him
column5: but Jay standardized the practice of putting out tons of music under several names in the internet age. He never seemed to oversaturate the market
column6: either
column7: since his audience kept coming back for more. That torch is carried today by guys like Ty Segall and Sick Thoughts’ Drew Owen. When Jay’s profile raised after he signed with Matador
column8: he pulled artists like Hunx and His Punx and Nobunny into the spotlight with him by bringing them on tour. His absence is jarring
column9: but his influence—both sonically and structurally—is still palpable in garage punk circles. That’s partially due to his work in the Reatards and Lost Sounds
column10: but his best and most powerful full-length work—and the record that made him a standalone rock star—was his first solo album.

column1: Blood Visions came together in the aftermath of the Lost Sounds’ dissolution. After Jay broke up with bandmate Alicja Trout
column2: the band fell apart in short order. Their final tour in 2005 ended badly—there was a physical altercation between Jay and Alicja. He was in a ""really
column3: really bad place"" when he temporarily decamped to Atlanta later that year. While staying in an apartment with Alix Brown and Black Lips’ Jared Swilley
column4: he channeled everything into a murderous revenge album. (When asked if the record was about a particular girl
column5: he revealed
column6: “Yeah
column7: a couple.”) He borrowed Carbonas’ practice space and knocked out most of the songs in one or two takes. Ten years later
column8: the result is still a revelation.

column1: The album is a portrait of a moony-eyed murderer. As a boy
column2: he starts attacking his own family. When he falls in love
column3: he lurks in the shadows and watches her from afar. ""I won't stop until you're dead
column4: / because of voices in my head
column5: he sings on ""Fading All Away."" This is the stuff of horror movies—love that leads to obsession
column6: graduates to stalking
column7: and culminates in murder. It's a narrative framed perfectly by his performance. In ""Death Is Forming
column8: as he attempts to veer away from dark thoughts
column9: the words ""death is forming"" rush in at an anxious rapid-fire. With some simple studio work
column10: Jay makes himself the narrator and all the voices in the narrator's head—the tortured and the torturer. He also offsets some of the stalking menace with power-pop riffs and tambourines
column11: which puts ""Nightmares"" in the same tradition as the Ramones' Nazi love song ""Today Your Love
column12: Tomorrow the World."" Both songs explore the cross-section of good and evil—of love and hate.

column1: To call Blood Visions a classic isn't just to praise its fucked-up storytelling—it's to celebrate an album stuffed with amazing hooks. The palm-muted chug of ""My Shadow
column2: the breakneck backbone of the 56-second highlight ""Greed
column3: Money
column4: Useless Children
column5: the loud-to-quiet blues rock stomp of ""Turning Blue""—the album pivots between several rock'n'roll comfort food modes across its 29 minutes. These hooks are punchy and extremely well done—the sort of stuff that sounded incredible when he'd play them live at practically double the recording's speed. And while of course he was an amazing guitarist
column6: his drumming is also essential here. When the instantly recognizable clacking introduction of the title track plays
column7: it's worth noting that Jay was playing that part cold. Drumming is where he'd start—he'd do the percussion in one take and build out the song from there.

column1: Aside from some blood-red vinyl
column2: the album's 10th anniversary Record Store Day reissue came with a 7"" featuring four demos: the title track
column3: ""Turning Blue
column4: ""It's So Easy
column5: and ""Oh
column6: It's Such a Shame."" The bonus record is far from essential
column7: but it's an interesting glimpse into Jay's process. The percussion is thinner
column8: the tempo slower; the main guitar hook is performed on a keyboard
column9: and the words ""blood vision"" are delivered in a demonic bark. Now that he's gone
column10: the urge to collect every single recording he ever made is strong. In this case
column11: the extras feel definitively extra: you buy Blood Visions to listen to Blood Visions
column12: not the preliminary sketches.

column1: When it came time to turn in Blood Visions
column2: Jay considered going back to his old routine—forming a new band and releasing those songs under that band’s name. The label convinced him that it should be a solo album. ""This was the first record I made as an adult
column3: when I didn't have to answer to another collaborative member of the band
column4: so it was supposed to be like I was a big fat baby
column5: he said of his appearance on the cover. ""Now I finally get to start my life at 24."" It's the perfect illustration to accompany the violent
column6: unsettling birth of a rock'n'roll icon. Even though the guy had already amassed an impressive and sizable discography of wide-eyed rippers
column7: Blood Visions stands as the ideal introduction to Jay Reatard the songwriter
column8: studio perfectionist
column9: character
column10:
and (reluctant) star.

Congotronics
column3: the 2004 album by the Congolese ensemble Konono No. 1
column4: resonated with Western ears in part because it didn't hew cleanly to any one region or genre. Sure
column5: they deployed traditional instrumentation

column1: For all of the music that the Congolese group has released in the past decade
column2: songs were never really Konono’s forte
column3: so much as building up a headful of steam and letting things careen and rumble as they might. Their finest moments remind me of a ferris wheel gone off its moorings
column4: the likembés making a metallic churning that cycles in ever widening patterns; it's an astonishing sound that both mesmerizes and rolls over everything in its path. So the most effective track here is the eleven minutes of ""Nzonzing Família

to always be taking their collaborators for a ride but never getting taken to some new destination.

Primitive Weapons wouldn't sound out of place sharing a stage with just about any heavy band you can think of from the last 25 years. It takes a great deal of dexterity to blend the all-out
column2: histrionic abrasion of Converge and straight-ahead melodics of Warrior Soul

column6: Glassjaw

column1: Perhaps it's this ear to both the local and global pulse that gives The Future of Death a fluidity that's bound to speak to disparate breeds of fans. column6: in another twist
column7: vaporize

Vocalist David Castillo favors a more traditional death metal bark in the other band he fronts

column3: songwriter Cameron Boucher saves the album’s biggest
column4: grungiest riff for an explosive declaration: ""I stopped wishing I was dead!"" The sentiment is played mostly for celebration
column5: and Boucher shouts it with palpable joy. But it’s also a correction
column6: an indictment of emo’s long history of glorifying depressive thinking
column7: and an implied apology for his complicity in that. In interviews
column8: Boucher explained ""Using"" was the first song he’d ever written with a positive takeaway. Despite his struggles with mental illness
column9: he'd decided to make the best of things. ""I started loving again
column10:
he sang.  

How cruel it is
column11: then
column12: that just as Boucher was learning to appreciate his own life
column13: so many of the people close to him were giving up on theirs. Since recording <i>Joy
column14: Departed
column15: Boucher lost some friends to suicide—""a lot of friends
column16: he told American Songwriter. Loss on that scale would upend anybody
column17: but it’s especially derailing for an artist who’s had reason to fear he could meet the same fate. In all likelihood he’ll be working through his grief for albums to come
column18: and that long process begins on the home-recorded It Kindly Stopped For Me EP
column19:
a four-song cycle narrated from the perspectives of both the departed and those left behind.

Boucher doesn’t just sound bereaved; he sounds downright shell-shocked. Singing like all the color has been drained from his face
column20: he recites most of the EP in a sickly
column21: half-inaudible mumble. If there are listeners who haven’t checked in on Sorority Noise since their debut LP Forgettable
column22: released only two years ago
column23: they won’t even recognize the band. Boucher’s purged every trace of pop-punk whimsy from his songs
column24:
trading crunchy riffs and shout-along tantrums for hushed pianos and closed-mic'ed drums tapped so lightly it’s as if they’re being gently blown on.

It Kindly Stopped is as intensely somber as its subject matter demands—maybe even more so
column25: if that’s possible—and Boucher often seems to be processing these tragedies in real time. He captured the EP’s most disquieting track
column27: while he was literally wandering through the wilderness. ""I think it might be okay
column29: Boucher mutters unconvincingly into his recorder while trying to catch his breath. ""Today was an off day; I’ve had a few."" If he wasn’t actually drunk when he recorded it
column30: he’s a mighty convincing actor. And while the rest of the EP is more deliberate than that field recording
column31:
it’s nearly as lonesome.

Sonics aside
column32: what truly distinguishes this recent iteration of Sorority Noise is Boucher's newfound sense of responsibility. In concert
column33: he prefaces ""Using"" with a heartfelt introduction about mental illness and the value of life. He includes a similar plea in It Kindly Stopped For Me’s liner notes. ""If you do have the opportunity to listen to this record please know that suicide is not the answer
column34: he writes. ""Please know how important you are and how much your life matters to your family
column36: and most importantly yourself."" Yet despite his convictions
column37: he never admonishes the dead in these songs. He sympathizes with them too much for that. On ""Either Way
column38: he casts life as a coin toss
column39: drawing a parallel between a friend who saw ""a chance to leave a life you couldn’t lead"" and his own chance ""to rid myself of my toxic ways
column40: a chance he could have just as easily missed. That’s the lone consolation on an otherwise disheartening EP
column41: and it’s not an insignificant one: Many of his friends are gone
column42:
but Boucher is still here and he's still thankful for that.

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rockathon']|2016-04-21 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:39.413157|"

As reunions go
column3: the second coming of Guided by Voices was a remarkably generous affair. Between 2010 and 2014
column4: the band’s beloved ""classic"" lineup from the early '90s—the guys responsible for GBV’s best records (Bee Thousand
column5: Alien Lanes
column6: etc.)—returned to release six records
column7: including three in 2012 alone
column8: and play for thousands of enthralled faithful. The albums were only intermittently successful
column9: but it was still a thrill to see Robert Pollard—the band’s ageless
column10: indefatigable leader
column11: its one constant across decades of lineup changes—scissor-kick his way across the country
column12: a bottle of Jose Cuervo tucked under his arm
column13: while his old buddies wailed away behind him.

column1: Now Guided by Voices are back again—or at least the name is. You see
column2: for Please Be Honest (GBV’s 23rd LP)
column3: Bob Pollard wrote every track and played every instrument himself. There is no Tobin Sprout
column4: Pollard’s songwriting partner from the classic lineup; no Doug Gillard
column5: Pollard’s guitar-shredding sidekick from the TVT and Matador years; not even Todd Tobias
column6: Pollard’s near constant companion on his endless side projects and solo records. This time the Fading Captain rides alone.

column1: And the results are a decidedly mixed bag. With its slapdash
column2: lo-fi production and jarring transitions from ballad to rocker to quirky one-off
column3: Please Be Honest is a close sonic relative of GBV’s post-2010 discography
column4: Let’s Go Eat the Factory in particular. But this new Pollard-only GBV has less of the easygoing melodicism and sense of goofy fun that kept those records fresh
column5: even at their most awkward moments.

column1: Of course
column2: this being Guided by Voices
column3: there are still gems to be found. The stately opener ""My Zodiac Companion"" features one of the more anthemic Pollard choruses in recent memory. The breezy drum-machine jangle of ""Kid on a Ladder"" could fit on Alien Lanes
column4: nestled somewhere between ""Game of Pricks"" and ""My Valuable Hunting Knife."" The title track serves up the record’s finest melody
column5: sung in Pollard’s bittersweet higher register over nerve-damaged electric guitar. Refreshingly
column6: the song touches on a real-world subject (Pollard’s attempt to get someone to level with him) rather than the usual carnival of GBV absurdities—the ""cucumber guns
column7: ""shriveled artichokes
column8: and ""glittering parliaments""—that populate the rest of the album.

column1: Despite its myriad eccentricities
column2: aural and otherwise
column3: GBV is at its core a power-pop band. But great hooks are frustratingly scarce on Please Be Honest
column4: particularly on grinding
column5: midtempo dirges like ""The Grasshopper Eaters
column6: ""The Quickers Arrive
column7: and ""Nightmare Jamboree."" One really misses Sprout’s songwriting—his emotional candor and vivid harmonies would have helped to brighten what is often a dark
column8: brittle record. And while musicianship is never the point with GBV
column9: many of these tunes
column10: like the lurching
column11: proggy ""Hotel X (Big Soap)
column12:
would have benefited from a bit more finesse. Too many of the drum and guitar tracks sound like they’re being played with a hammer.

Ultimately
column13: however
column14: the biggest problem with Please Be Honest is existential: The fact that it’s a Guided by Voices record at all seems entirely arbitrary. It could just as easily have been a Pollard solo album or a new record from Teenage Guitar (Bob’s other solo project) or the debut album from some other dreamed-up band (like
column15: say
column16: Kitchen Winners
column17: Jet Logic
column18: or the Easy Cyclists). Pollard seems simply to have finished a new batch of songs and decided they sounded like a Guided by Voices record—a strikingly anti-climatic backstory for the return of such a legendary act. Without a solid band identity and the sense of mission it provides
column19: this new GBV comes off like little more than a side project
column20: like just another star in the greater constellation of Bob (and not even the brightest one
column21: considering the quality of Pollard’s recent Ricked Wicky records with guitarist Nick Mitchell). Please Be Honest certainly has its charms. But for the first time in Pollard’s career
column22: Guided by Voices isn’t the main event—which
column23: for the band’s legions of fans

During his lifetime
column2: Arthur Russell maintained only a very small cult fan base beyond the direct circles of artists who found his work so moving. Our understanding of the singer
column3: cellist
column4: producer
column5: and composer's artistic identity
column6: then
column7: continues to evolve
column8: as lost or cobbled-together releases trickle out via the Russell archival label Audika Records. Among the different versions of Russell
column9: the eccentric disco obsessive and the confessional singer/songwriter remain his most familiar modes. The aspiring avant-garde classical music composer is less known
column10: with the least recorded music to show for himself.

column1: Yet Russell spent years of his life absorbed in this scene. During his composition studies at the Manhattan School of Music and Dartmouth University
column2: he found inspiration in the work of the previous generation of downtown New York avant-garde composers—studying the early minimalist music of La Monte Young and Terry Riley
column3: and the spare
column4: pacifying orchestral works of Morton Feldman
column5: John Cage
column6: and one of his teachers
column7: Christian Wolff. In works like his 48-hour-long experiment Instrumentals
column8: he blended rock'n'roll influences with modern classical methodology. But the newly rereleased Tower of Meaning recordings capture a set of incidental theater music that bears an even clearer mark of those influences. Eschewing the pulsating
column9: pop-influenced underpinnings of almost all of his other work
column10: Tower of Meaning is the greatest outlier in his Russell's recorded catalogue: the most uncharacteristic one-off project in a career that is full of them.

column1: And like many of Russell's creative ventures
column2: there were other famous figures tangentially involved with this project. The pieces included on Tower of Meaning were written for a production of Euripides' Medea by legendary opera and theater director Robert Wilson in the early '80s. The collaboration was facilitated by Philip Glass
column3: who worked with Wilson on seminal avant-music-theater work Einstein on the Beach in 1976. A fight between Wilson and Russell resulted in the music being axed from the program
column4: and it went unheard until Glass released the tapes on his own Chatham Square label—in a run of 320—some years later. Ironically
column5: outside of his landmark cello-and-vocal release
column6: 1986's World of Echo
column7: Tower of Meaning was the only finished and properly pressed ""Arthur Russell"" album during his lifetime.

column1: Devoid of its dramatic context
column2: and peppered with abrupt track ends that suggest lost tape reels
column3: this music feels more in-process than many of Russell's ""unfinished"" music does—a skeleton to be filled in. Each of the seven tracks consist mostly of long
column4: repeating strings of block chords
column5: voiced by mixed string
column6: wind
column7: and brass ensembles. In later movements
column8: a harp and hand drum
column9: respectively
column10: provide decoration in between the chords
column11: perhaps suggesting the court music of the play's time period. Some of the harmonies have a brittle
column12: dissonant quality; others feel open and cavernous; a few feel a couple of ticks away from pop music. The three types are mixed up thoroughly in these pieces
column13: and it takes a while to become acclimated to this fidgety vocabulary.

column1: But the most notable and challenging thing about the pieces on Tower of Meaning is their lack of arc or climax. Russell's misty but urgent song accompaniments have a similarly static quality
column2: accumulating mass gradually and never drastically. But Tower of Meaning takes a very different approach to achieving a similar effect. The chords move in no consistent meter; there is almost no variation of dynamic across the album
column3: and the chamber orchestra is stark and untreated with effects. Over time—consistent with most of Russell's work—this begins to create a pleasant
column4: soothing effect
column5: despite the sometimes-jarring nature of the harmony.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the approach finds overlap with that of ambient music. A few years prior to writing the Medea score
column3: while at the Manhattan School
column4: Russell told a skeptical composition teacher that he liked writing pieces that the listener could ""plug out [from] and then plug back in[to] again without losing anything essential."" On Tower of Meaning
column5: it's easiest to do this during the culminating piece of the album
column6: ""Fragments From Tower of Meaning
column7: which assembles chordal ideas from earlier tracks into a cyclical chamber orchestra piece
column8: punctuated by a Pavlovian chime
column9: which becomes more warm and enveloping across its 21-minute duration.

column1: It would be tough to claim that Tower of Meaning is one of Russell's greatest efforts. Then again
column2: it was not designed to be: It sounds very much like it was written as a functional component of Wilson's larger picture
column3: not to be disseminated separately. Also
column4: it has more of a clear grounding in a pre-existing musical lineage than anything else that Russell ever released. Yet Tower of Meaning works well within its own self-imposed boundaries. It has definite jolts of Russell's playful
column5: try-anything-once mentality. Like most of his best music
column6: it manages to position itself just slightly outside of convention
column7:
at a jaunty angle.

"|21807.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21807-tower-of-meaning/|7.0|Winston Cook-Wilson

In a bar in L.A.'s Echo Park
column2: Ariel Pink met Allene Norton
column3: a twenty-something Seattle transplant with a good ear for the '80s. She had been hard at work on Cellars
column4: her unabashedly vintage synth pop project since she moved to L.A.
column5: with one LP already under her belt. With her second album
column6: Phases
column7: a Pink-produced project of sparkling electro ballads
column8: it looks like the '80s revival Simon Reynolds foresaw at its end in 2010 keeps on pushing forward. And in the 16th year of our 21st century
column9: a question needs to be asked: Does it matter if the revival ever ends?  Should we just stop calling it revival
column10: and just settle for the plasticity of reinvention?

column1: The first quarter  of 2016 has been kind to someone particularly dedicated to such tropes
column2: with Kristin Kontrol's impressively glacial ""X-Communicate"" and Jessy Lanza’s minimalist pop experiments. But unlike either of those
column3: the music of Phases sounds
column4: even if not intentionally
column5: zapped straight from an anachronistic radio transmission
column6: or the sepia-toned dance floor of a long-forgotten high school prom. Norton
column7: from what we can hear in <i>Phases
column8: has committed herself to digging around in the archive
column9: perfecting a photocopy of not just sounds
column10: but affects and emotions that don't feel of this time.

column1: A lot of this power comes from an intelligent reliance on a form of  schmaltz that is virtually missing from even the most heated and heavy of contemporary pop music. Things aren't as wilfully corny
column2: campy
column3: or self effacingly sentimental anymore. Even the most melodramatic music can feel cool to the touch
column4: over-processed to a fault.  Etymologically one of the roots of schmaltz is the old German word smelzan
column5: a verb that literally signifies to melt. One of its other roots is chicken fat
column6: a high cholesterol substance that makes you feel bad in the long run
column7: yet so good at the moment you consume it. Phases perfectly internalizes these two ways of being
column8: excess and constant evaporation. You feel the overload in the album’s selection of palatial synths
column9: bubbling percussion
column10: sugary bass lines. And the threat of melt is in Norton’s voice and drawn out intonation
column11: which hangs like a diffuse cloud of dry ice around the soupy mixture of sounds.

column1: This effect is best achieved in songs like ""Real Good Day"" and the album’s centerpiece
column2: ""Still in Love."" In ""Real Good Day"" twinkling arpeggios and a cooing chorus carry Norton’s voice down the PCH like a convertible driving towards the sunset.  Even if never stated explicitly
column3: the album as a whole is rather optimistic. It comes from what is at times a goofy erotic sheen
column4: indebted to Giorgio Moroder or YMO.  Phases might be the only the album this year to capture camp in all its classic glory: Even the missed beats have a kernel of fun and whimsy
column5: like a teen movie montage. The sounds they have made and the emotions they've referenced here are always in the back of your mind
column6: on the tip of your tongue
column7: never new or old
column8:
just pure plastic.

Dance music
column2: by definition
column3: is communal—except when it's not. The German electronic musician Lawrence
column4: aka Peter Kersten
column5: makes house music that's as much about getting lost in one's head as being enfolded by the crowd. And while Kersten rarely strays too far from dancefloor-oriented forms
column6: his work has spent the past several years getting steadily dreamier.

column1: Kersten is a key figure in German house and techno
column2: having co-founded Hamburg's Dial label in 2000 and then
column4: the deeper-diving Smallville. Early Dial pursued a streamlined take on house music that
column5: combined with the whittled-down sounds of early-'00s digital production
column6: led to its characterization
column7: not always accurately
column8: as a minimalist enterprise. But the label never relinquished its fondness for the skippy rhythms and soulful undercurrent of Chicago house
column9: and it went in hard for a strain of windswept romanticism that was easily apparent in both the label's sleeves and its titles. (From Lawrence's own catalog
column10: just consider bittersweet songs like ""Happy Sometimes
column11: ""The Night Will Last Forever
column12: and the Smiths-referencing ""Fifteen Minutes With You."") Smallville
column13: meanwhile
column14: has represented a distillation of those tendencies
column15: resulting in a hyper-classicist style of house
column16: heavy on all the analog signatures of pioneers like Larry Heard
column17: that's also wistfully misty-eyed. Throughout
column18: Lawrence's recordings—including his albums for Japan's Mule Musiq label
column19: of which Yoyogi Park is the third—have served as a kind of ur-text for the Smallville aesthetic.

column1: His ambient inclinations peaked with 2014's A Day in the Life
column2: a collection of songs that took all his typical hallmarks—the shimmer
column3: the swirl
column4: the open-ended tones—and muted all the drums. The result
column5: delicate and ephemeral
column6: was something like the logical conclusion of his most sensitive tendencies: music for Sunday-morning snuggling
column7: walks in the garden
column8: and gentle comedowns
column9: with the merest memory of the dancefloor traced in the shadow of a pulse. Yoyogi Park starts where A Day in the Life left off. It's suffused in hazy synthesizers
column10: sparkling arpeggios
column11: and melodic lines that twist like green tendrils. But in places Yoyogi Park also marks Lawrence's wholehearted return to the dancefloor. Nowhere is that more apparent than on the three songs that have been reprised—upcycled
column12: really—from the previous album
column13: doubled in length and given a whole new rhythmic underpinning. Where the original version of ""Nowhere Is a Place"" drifted like a kelp forest
column14: the new one leaps purposefully into motion
column15: driven by tightly wound hi-hats and a walking bassline that's unusually fleet of foot. Flickering chords lend additional color and movement
column16: and the result sounds a little like an updated version of Ricardo Villalobos' great ""808 the Bassqueen
column17: but even more full-bodied
column18: if you can believe it. This is not an album for sitting still: ""Marble Star"" fleshes out its ultra-low lows and ultra-dreamy highs with rugged
column19: rolling breakbeats
column20: and ""Blue Mountain"" rides white-capped waves of synths and drums that bob like flotsam borne aloft on the tide.

column1: One of Kersten's favorite tricks is to juggle soft and hard textures until you're not sure which is which. ""Tensui"" starts off with knife-edged hi-hats and tough wooden thumps
column2: but it's soon suffused in drowsy pads and bucolic flutes. It would be easy to imagine the same elements remade for A Day in the Life's beatless reveries; the fact that he manages to marry such diffuse sounds to a rhythm track so overwhelmingly physical—this isn't bass you simply feel; you savor it
column3: with your whole body—only makes the track more remarkable. Nothing on Yoyogi Park is original
column4: exactly; Lawrence has been making music like this for most of his career
column5: and his peers on Dial and Smallville have spun the same material in similar ways. Still
column6: no one else is making this music quite so well. And as far as Lawrence's catalog goes
column7: this is his fullest realization yet of interior and exterior—of thought and movement
column8: of daydream and dance. The line separating Saturday night and Sunday morning is no thicker than a second hand; Yoyogi Park invites you to clear out a space inside that sliver of time
column9:
and to luxuriate in it.

"|21695.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21695-yoyogi-park/|7.9|Philip Sherburne

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23042/homepage_large.caba3b70.jpg|The Diary|2248.0|J Dilla|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mass Appeal'
column3: it's difficult to talk about James Dewitt Yancey—the accomplished producer and aspiring rapper known as Jay Dee
column4: and more commonly J Dilla
column5: or just Dilla
column6: who passed away in 2006—without dipping into hagiography. His legacy means many different things to hip-hop fans; he brought Pharcyde (and much of hip-hop) into adulthood on Pharcyde's 1995 album LabCabinCalifornia
column7: placing warm and sunny beats under the L.A. quartet's disillusioned musings on identity
column8: purpose
column9: and struggles against commerce. He supported De La Soul as they directly campaigned against rap's material excess on Stakes Is High. He collaborated with Q-Tip on A Tribe Called Quest's Beats
column10: Rhymes & Life at the exact moment that the group's personal expansion and internal tension began to forecast their end.

column1: These are the formative years
column2: a pivotal part of  the origin story that places him in the pantheon. But the tale behind The Diary twists the narrative. It goes back to at least 2002
column3: years after Dilla had contributed to the then-flowering neo-soul movement by bringing a softened low end and melodic
column4: hazy middles to Erykah Badu's Mama's Gun and D'Angelo's Voodoo. Along with his continued work with Tribe
column5: his efforts on Q-Tip's Amplified
column6: as well Common's Like Water for Chocolate and Electric Circus
column7: Dilla provided a safe space for forward thinking hip-hop and smart R&B to meet on their own terms and grow beyond the sum of their parts.  At a time when hip-hop and and R&B pairings were still being done as mash-ups that simply dropped a dollop of peanut butter into a chocolate cup
column8: Dilla was experimenting with new flavors and cutting-edge swirls of tastes. It was all prescient and revolutionary and it's exactly why MCA
column9: his then-record label shelved his solo debut Pay Jay
column10: the album that has been dusted off and presented to us almost a decade and a half later as The Diary.

column1: Dilla's most noted collaborators had been progressive
column2: socially conscious writers who waxed about the big ideas about their immediate society in grand terms. But precious little of that sentiment was to be found in his own raps. As a producer
column3: he was thoughtful and intimate; as a rapper he was brash
column4: confrontational
column5: and unrepentantly materialistic and misogynist. Nary a song on this project goes by without either a mention of wealth
column6: an intimation of violence
column7: or a dismissal of women. And sometimes he manages all three with neck-breaking economy. ""The Shining
column8: Pt. 2 (Ice)"" is barely over one minute long but still manages to house uncomfortable lyrics like
column9: ""Jay been nice with his since Dre said he was a n-gga for life/ And bitches ain't shit but hoes and tricks—that's what I'm thinking when I'm dickin' your wife/ Yup/ Big truck jewels in the truck with tools/ You don't want to pop shit tonight."" On ""The Creep (The O)"" Dilla paints himself as a serial womanizer and incorrigible cuckolder. ""You could stay out with Craig and them
column10: he raps to the listener
column11: personified as a man whose woman he's cheating with. ""Mo' time for me to bang out/ Shit
column12: I love when you hang out/ It's nothing else to do but send her home to you/ I'm through
column13: 'til the next time we screw."" The latter couplets are repurposed from the Notorious B.I.G.
column14: but the sentiment is all Dilla. As far as hip-hop trespasses go
column15: it's quotidian by early-'00s standards
column16: and tame by current ones. But it's obviously not what label execs expected or wanted from the guy who produced songs like Common's ""Between Me
column17: You & Liberation"" and Erykah's ""Kiss Me on My Neck (Hesi).""

column1: Despite being intended as Dilla's first true solo album
column2: The Diary is not what people who are seeking an entry point should gravitate to. For that
column3: listeners are better directed towards the upcoming collection
column4: The Fantastic Box: A Jay Dee Production in order to get a concise overview of his themes and sounds; or directly to his magnum opus Donuts
column5: the last album released in his lifetime
column6: which shows him at the height of his production mastery. In many senses
column7: it's hard to understand who this record is directed towards. The Diary was released in conjunction with Record Store Day
column8: an obvious move at collectors and archivists. But a quarter of these songs have already been released in some form; and Pay Jay has already widely circulated in bootleg form. The Diary comes off as a play for completists that was prefaced with a listening party at a trendy hotel and a gastronomic orgy in New York—events for the committed and connected
column9: not the everyman. It’s an over-reaching approach that attempts to make a blockbuster out of what should be an arthouse film.

column1: The bookends of the album—the cinematic intro
column2: the proclamations
column3: the heavy-handed ad-libs on the closing track—are conceits that try hard to position The Diary as an important record
column4: but they're unnecessary. The tracks—namely Supa Dave West's ""So Far
column5: Hi-Tek's ""The Creep (The O)
column6: and Karriem Riggins' ""Drive Me Wild""—are playfully bouncy enough to get  heads bopping
column7: shoulders bouncing
column8: and hips grooving while still smart enough to be cerebrally rewarding to beat nerds. They're all incredibly short
column9: as well. Like most numbers here
column10: they clock in at under three minutes
column11: all but begging for expanded editions masterminded by Dilla collaborators and devotees like
column12: Madlib
column13: Kanye West
column14: and Flying Lotus. (Seriously and please.)

column1: There are still moments
column2: like the touchingly personal title track
column3: where we are reminded Dilla was a beast of an MC when he wanted to be. On ""The Shining
column4: Pt. 1 (Diamonds)
column5: Dilla lights up like a late-90's Jay Z. An obvious take on Jay's ""Girl's Best Friend
column6: it's a song-long metaphor as love song to bling and plays like Dilla's radio concession. But Dilla may as well have been prophesying his legacy:  ""You so special
column7: you multifaceted/ You can cut glass with it/ It's so brilliant /Go spend a little dough
column8: look like you sold millions/ Plus you everlastin'/ And drastically important when sportin' your ghetto fashion."" That was Dilla—multifaceted and brilliant—and The Diary is notable for presenting an official release to his intended debut. And
column9: just like any diamond unearthed after many years
column10: The Diary is flawed
column11:
but still precious.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23113/homepage_large.307b600a.jpg|Flutes
column2: Echoes
column3:
It's All Happening!|33625.0|Carlos Niño & Friends|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Leaving']|2016-04-20 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:41.973873|"

Like most interesting places
column4: Los Angeles lives in contradiction of itself. The things that make it seem superficial also make it seem happy and industrious
column5: a place where people are always freewheeling from one rad thing to the next. Los Angeles challenges you to take it seriously and wonders—in wounded earnestness—why you can't. It is one of the least believable places I've ever been and a place I consequently never want to leave.

column1: Flutes
column2: Echoes
column3: It's All Happening!
column4: by Carlos Niño & Friends
column5: is a very Los Angeles album. Niño is a hub of the city's musical subculture
column6: one of those people whose primary contribution seems to be his ability to connect other people. Over the past 20 years
column7: he has hosted three radio shows and worked on over 50 albums
column8: charting an invisible continent where hippy jazz meets new age music and underground hip-hop meets airy
column9: Laurel Canyon-style folk. (Lately his shows have been focused on the perennially great Dublab.) Along with the vocalist Dwight Trible
column10: he leads a big band called Build an Ark
column11: whose loose
column12: ever-shifting roster of players—inspired by groups like the Sun Ra Arkestra—turns the model of the 1930s jazz orchestra into a metaphor for equality and collectivity. He has helped arrange the music of J Dilla for chamber orchestra and participated in an album-length tribute to tea. Though many of the projects he's worked on credit him as an artist
column13: I'm still not sure what he plays. At the time of writing
column14: he is 39.

column1: Flutes is the fourth of Niño's ""and friends"" series. Pieced together using fragments and sketches Niño had worked on over the past few years
column2: it's a loose
column3: comfortable and often deliberately comforting experience
column4: the kind of music that makes room for the listener rather than reaching out to be heard. As with Niño's other archive-related releases
column5: the range is wide but the journey is easy. “Metamaravilla
column6: with its bird sounds and untamed cascades of violin
column7: follows a line from the impressionism of Debussy and Ravel through to the postwar exotica of Les Baxter
column8: music designed to transform familiar rooms into wilds of which the listener had only dreamed. ""Alice's Chord"" is presumably a reference to the pianist
column9: harpist and composer Alice Coltrane
column10: whose loose rhapsodies turned jazz into a metaphor for inner space. (Her husband
column11: John
column12: hovers over the Kamasi Washington–featuring “Joyous Gratitude
column13: as does his collaborator Pharoah Sanders). You can see why guys like Madlib belong here
column14: and where Niño's interest in hip-hop stems from in general: Not as a party-ready extension of funk and disco
column15: but as music that uses groove and repetition as a way to leverage meditative states.

column1: Like any good curator
column2: Niño is proposing an alternative history
column3: one where the sound of a style isn't as important as the spirit behind it
column4: where black and white have more in common than they might otherwise realize
column5: where you can hear the new-age pioneer Iasos digress about the benefits of hanging out near waterfalls alongside a little free jazz. (Negative ions. It's negative ions.) In that sense
column6: the diversity of Flutes often ends up being more interesting than the material itself. I like it best when I listen to it less as music than as a blueprint to how music might be made
column7: a map of Niño's place in the universe. “I don't feel like I'm a citizen of the United States
column8:
he told the L.A. Weekly in 2009. “But I do relate to California."" California seems to relate back.
