column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23040/homepage_large.67bbf556.jpg|Music of Morocco: Recorded by Paul Bowles
column3: the stories of Sheltering Sky author Paul Bowles and other Beat-generation figures traveling to Morocco in the late '50s/early '60s aren't exactly lacking in mystique. In his introduction to the liner notes for this 4-disc box
column4: former Sonic Youth guitarist Lee Ranaldo references a widely circulated group photo of Bowles along with William Burroughs
column5: Allen Ginsberg
column6: and others taken on the patio of the Villa Muniria hotel in Tangier. Of course
column7: the North African desert would become almost synonymous with Bowles' storied career. But for him
column8: Morocco was also the place he would call home for the rest of his life.

column1: Long considered a 20th-century literary giant
column2: Bowles actually pursued a career in composition prior to (and even after) the success of The Sheltering Sky
column3: which was his first novel. Bowles
column4: in fact
column5: visited Morocco for the first time in 1931 on a trip with Aaron Copland
column6: under whom he was studying composition at the time. And though he changed lanes professionally
column7: Bowles continued to nurture a profound interest in music
column8: which is made abundantly clear by this set. Of course
column9: the author occupies a central role here
column10: having recorded all four discs himself over a six-month period in 1959 during which he criss-crossed Morocco
column11: but thankfully he keeps his focus trained strictly on the music and the cultural currents from which it emerged.

column1: ""For years
column2: I composed music
column3: Bowles can be heard saying at the beginning of the 1993 documentary Un Américain à Tanger. ""Then
column4: suddenly
column5: I decided to write books instead... There’s nothing to say about either the music or the books. I hate talking about myself. I’ve got nothing to say."" In another documentary
column6: 1998’s Let It Come Down: The Life of Paul Bowles
column7: the author says
column8: ""There was no violence in my life ever—maybe that’s why I gave up writing music.""

column1: Maybe so
column2: but on Music of Morocco he has plenty to say. True to his word
column3: though
column4: he says almost nothing about himself. Though his voluminous notes
column5: reprinted here from his own journal
column6: do at times provide first-person accounts of his travels
column7: they do so only to serve a better understanding of what you’re hearing. In fact
column8: ""understanding"" might be an understatement. The thoroughness of Bowles’ ethnomusicological narration (not to mention the way project producer Philip D. Schuyler organizes and adds to that narration) more or less gives listeners a crash course in the social
column9: historical
column10: and musical basis for four-and-a-half-hours’ worth of music.

column1: Originally released in 1972 as a (now long-out-of-print) 2-record set
column2: this new presentation more than doubles the total runtime
column3: restoring each individual performance to its original length—a crucial difference considering that several of these pieces stretch to 10-15 minutes or more. Bowles separated the music into two major categories: the music of North Africa’s Berber people on one LP and Arab- and Sub-Saharan-influenced music on another. Schuyler
column4: an ethnomusicologist on faculty at the University of Washington
column5: explains that Bowles regarded Berber music and culture as reflective of the ""real"" Morocco and thought of the Arabic influence as an invasive ""contagion.""

column1: Schuyler’s new track sequence remains faithful to Bowles’ delineation between those two musical strains
column2: but he does point out that the Arab influence had been steeping in Morocco for a thousand years by the time Bowles arrived. (Schuyler got to consult with Bowles on the project before the author’s death in 1999.) And while it’s certainly not necessary to approach the liner notes as a textbook in order to enjoy the music
column3: the uninitiated will undoubtedly have trouble distinguishing between sounds that Bowles had learned to tell apart. On the other hand
column4: the running order at first comes across as disparate and somewhat disconnected—as if playback had been a secondary consideration.

column1: But the musical variety proves to be an asset in the long run. You may not initially be able place the various rhythmic and harmonic modes that bob and weave in what at first seems like one giant pool of music. But the more you listen
column2: the more you can discern how the various motifs inter-relate and complement one another. After a while
column3: as you get acclimated and your hearing comes into better focus
column4: the entire 4xCD swath starts to play less like a haphazard gumbo of sounds and more like a series of carefully laid-out fabrics.

column1: Regardless
column2: it requires zero background info to be struck right away by three key aspects: repetition
column3: cadence
column4: and the fluidity of North African melodic scales. Bowles and Schuyler expound at great length on all the above
column5: but suffice it to say that much of this music induces a powerful hypnotic effect. In the 1970 documentary Paul Bowles in Morocco
column6: the author recalls how he once saw a man walk into a Moroccan café where a group of musicians were playing. As the man grew more entranced by the music
column7: he started to slash his own arms and legs with a knife—in rhythm as the musicians kept playing. While that’s certainly on the extreme end
column8: it’s a good illustration of how transportive this music can be—not unlike the way American gospel or Haitian ceremonial music can move people into altered states.

column1: Of course
column2: Music of Morocco offers a deeply satisfying experience even if you don’t get that carried away. For some perspective: Led Zeppelin and Jimi Hendrix significantly enriched their work when they trained their sights on North Africa
column3: but their exposure was limited. When Bowles put his Alan Lomax hat on and made these tapes
column4: he had lived in the country for well over a decade. Unfamiliar listeners will no doubt find the flow of this music alien
column5: its meter unfolding in seemingly lopsided patterns the way separate sets of wooden chimes clatter randomly as the wind strikes them. But the form in that clatter becomes evident over time. Moreover
column6: Bowles’ attention to detail shows that he didn’t just regard this stuff as brightly-colored wallpaper or background scenery
column7: but as the living
column8: breathing pulse of the place he chose to call home.  When approaching this box
column9: it pays to ditch your notions of how glamorous it was for emotionally desiccated
column10: self-destructive figures like William Burroughs and late Rolling Stones guitarist Brian Jones to feed their habits in an ""exotic"" locale
column11: the allure of the North African desert a mere backdrop in the arc of their crash-and-burn stories. Unlike his peers
column12: Paul Bowles wasn’t content to just disappear into a cloud of hash smoke.

column1: And so it makes sense that Music of Morocco is such an eye-opening
column2: immersive document
column3: the kind we’d expect from someone who’s spent time in a country getting to know its way of life but who could still make observations (or simply observe) as a guest. And if you’re a fan of Bowles’ novels
column4: don’t expect the indulgent prose that’s all too typical of writers who can’t help but phrase everything as if they were reading aloud in front of an audience. Thankfully
column5: as Schuyler explains
column6: Bowles—a college dropout—didn’t identify as an academic
column7: so he doesn’t come off as pedantic either. (One of the CD sleeves describes his writing as ""spare
column8: precise
column9: and carefully assembled."") Because he didn’t lay it on thick in his journal
column10: and because Schuyler refrains from fawning
column11: the faux-leather
column12: 120-page book that comes with this box actually works as standalone reading material that you'd want to keep at your bedside table or pack in your travel bag.

column1: For a record label that’s built its reputation in large part on top-notch presentation standards
column2: Dust-To-Digital
column3: along with Rounder Records’ Bill Nowlin
column4: have outdone themselves this time with a breathtaking package and sleek art direction courtesy of Barbara Bersche. If either you’ve lost sight of or continue to lament the disappearance of the physical object in recorded music
column5: you couldn’t dream of a better reminder than this set. Words just don’t do justice to how it feels holding Music of Morocco in your hands
column6: or to its stately elegance sitting on your shelf. And if you’re looking for an entry point into the soul of a people via its music
column7:
you simply can’t do better than Music of Morocco. Consider it essential regardless of your musical tastes or background.

"|21708.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21708-music-of-morocco-recorded-by-paul-bowles-1959/|8.9|Saby Reyes-Kulkarni

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23147/homepage_large.cb598729.jpg|BIS: 001-020|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Beats in Space']|2016-04-20 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:42.694488|"

Even at its most inclusive and open-minded
column2: the underground dance community still aspires to a certain cool factor—man or woman
column3: gay or straight
column4: just
column5: please
column6: don't be a dork. This is one of the reasons Beats in Space's Tim Sweeney is a comforting presence: In addition to being one of New York's best DJs and longest-tenured tastemakers
column7: he comes off on his weekly WNYU radio show—broadcast every Tuesday night at 10:30pm since he walked in as a student in 1999
column8: and meticulously archived on his website—like
column9: well
column10: a bit of a dork. His casual demeanor and idiosyncratic interview style
column11: in addition to his musical curiosity
column12: lends his show an irrepressible friendliness that is unusual in dance music culture.

column1: It's a vibe that has carried over to his record label of the same name
column2: under which he's released 20 records—mostly 12""s but also a couple of albums—since 2011. Sweeney's tastes run wide and deep
column3: and he's been in on the ground floor of every important trend in underground dance music during the last 15 years (he notably interned for DFA and has regularly DJ'ed with James Murphy). He's kept his label stylistically diverse but with a few common threads: groovy
column4: lightly psychedelic tracks that might sound best at a deck party
column5: or the beach. Balearic would be a good catchall
column6: though Sweeney's choices represent a very New York iteration—basically disco and its stepchildren—that includes various shades of electro
column7: italo
column8: house
column9: and punky funk.

column1: BIS: 001 - 020 collects a track from each of the label's releases offering an easy
column2: if slightly daunting (there's nearly 150 minutes of music here) overview of the label. The collection doesn't offer any household names; certainly given his connections and status Sweeney could've recruited higher profile producers. What's on offer here is really Sweeney's vision
column3: the humid urban tropics his selections conjure.

column1: In practice this is everything from the bratty guitar stomp of the Hidden Fees' ""So What""—as fine a replica of mid-2000s DFA clamor on offer in 2016—to the sprawling acid bass of Secret Circuit's ""Afterlife."" BIS: 001 - 020 doesn't offer a discernible flow or progression; it's a great record to jump in and out of
column2: or to set to random and cook dinner to. Many of the tracks contain the kind of charming off-key vocals that helped differentiate
column3: say
column4: Ze Records disco tracks from gaudier major label productions. The compilation's more traditional dance tracks—Matt Karmil's Four Tet-ish ""So You Say"" and Crystal & S. Koshi's roiling ""Break the Dawn""—offer chopped vocals
column5: never straying far from an easy tunefulness.

column1: BIS: 001 - 020 is never less than good
column2: but it also falls somewhat short of essential. Labels like International Feel and Permanent Vacation have offered similar thrills for years. It's possible to parse out the peculiarities of Sweeney's taste but there's a certain irony in appreciating Sweeney on a granular level. What has made his radio show so special is that there is no one easy summation of it; its value increases as you return week after week (or archived stream after archived stream)
column3: listening to an ever widening variety of DJs and styles. Beats in Space the radio show remains an essential resource for fans of dance music; Beats in Space the label is a fun
column4:
friendly capsule of Sweeney's favored style.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23092/homepage_large.9dd278d7.jpg|A Sailor's Guide to Earth|32293.0|Sturgill Simpson|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic']|2016-04-19 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:43.277019|"

Sturgill Simpson's 2014 sophomore release
column2: Metamodern Sounds in Country Music
column3: dragged ""outlaw country"" into modern times with acid-tongued clarity and a world-weary sense of humor. Its perspective was so refreshing that other like-minded albums came to be: Chris Stapleton enlisted Metamodern producer Dave Cobb to craft his own revivalist release Traveller
column4: which won the 2016 Grammy for Best Country Album. While Metamodern Sounds of Country Music is certainly a record that invited imitation
column5: it's darker and deeper than Stapleton's award winner or even Jason Isbell's most lauded recent solo albums (also produced by Cobb)
column6: a sometimes-nihilistic opus that proclaims things like “Ain't no point of getting out of bed if you ain't livin' the dream"" and declares hallucinogens like DMT as lenses with which to see the truths of existence. The combination of the vintage music and the album's contemporary subject matter made for one of the most memorable releases of the last five years.

column1: While Simpson could have easily milked a few records out of that glum sound and guaranteed industry adulations for decades
column2: A Sailor's Guide to Earth represents a startling change in tone and presents a wealth of rewards for every creative risk. Instead of counting turtles and finding a voice in classic country—Simpson himself smirks at the notion that he is a modern Waylon Jennings
column3: because he doesn't listen to Waylon Jennings' music
column4: though the connection is by no means inaccurate—Simpson is doing something far more difficult. Embarking on song cycle that draw upon sounds and songwriting styles that aren't found on his first two records at all
column5: Simpson draws from his time in the Navy
column6: where he was stationed in Japan
column7: and the record is framed as a sailor's letter home to his wife and newborn son. (It's loosely based on a letter his grandfather wrote his grandmother).  It's a deeply personal album that
column8: while establishing Simpson as the defining songwriter of his class
column9: displays an artistic growth that defies any sort of easy label.

column1: The premise—a concept album addressed to his own son and wife—might sound corny
column2: but the result is a beautiful and earnest record that flips the defeatist subtext of Metamodern on its head. The moods on A Sailor's Guide to Earth are brighter than on Metamodern
column3: and the instrumentation on songs like “Keep It Between the Lines""—much of it provided by <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/2240-sharon-jones-and-the-dap-kings/"">Sharon Jones' backing band
column4: the Dap-Kings—is denser
column5: bolder
column6: and more rhythmic than anything Simpson has steered previously. (Simpson produced the record himself
column7: deciding to spend his Atlantic Records budget chasing his instincts to their logical extreme). At the climax of side A
column8: Simpson tosses in a countrypolitan Nirvana cover; one of the LP's more jarring moments occurs when Simpson sings “Sell the kids for food"" on an album addressed to his son. To watch Simpson stretch (and succeed) is thrilling.

column1: The back half of the album is less audacious
column2: making room for more contemplative moments like the tender ballad ""Oh Sarah."" Simpson holds onto the sneaky cleverness that distinguished Metamodern—""Get high
column3: play a little GoldenEye/ That old 64!"" Simpson shouts on ""Sea Stories
column4: like he's fondly remembering an old Cadillac—while taking a completely different journey.  If Metamodern was Waylon Jennings eating tabs of acid on a Tennessee back porch
column5: A Sailor’s Guide is something like the musical combination of Moby Dick and Elvis.

column1: A Sailor's Guide to Earth plants Simpson at the forefront of the current crop of artists living beneath the always-contentious ""alt-country""  banner. But what's most striking is how it completely redefines Simpson's own career
column2: and sets him on his own unique path. Metamodern became the subject of trendpieces
column3: where critics and fans alike willingly read into the drugs-and-darkness subtext that Simpson has himself been reluctant to endorse. But A Sailor's Guide to Earth is such a rearrangement of Simpson's sonic universe that any previous categorization now seems out of date. His earlier records communicate a weariness
column4: dedicated to the journey to whatever's at the end of that long white line
column5:
even if it's sorrow. A Sailor's Guide to Earth takes a trip somewhere entirely different and life-affirming.

"|21758.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21758-a-sailors-guide-to-earth/|8.0|Corban Goble

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23130/homepage_large.9dc3ed40.jpg|Blind Spot EP|2564.0|Lush|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Edamame']|2016-04-19 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:44.620243|"

In his review of Still in a Dream: A Story of Shoegaze 1988-1995—the recently released 5xCD box set that strives to illuminate/explain the so-called “Scene That Celebrates Itself”—Simon Reynolds describes the experience of hearing Lush’s 1991 single “De-Luxe” as something akin to “being buffeted by flower petals in a wind-tunnel.” It’s an apt description for a band that
column2: over the course of four full-length albums
column3: managed to strike a delicate balance between shimmery guitar squalls and jangly pop hooks. Though they were often unfairly regarded as sonic lightweights in regards to their peers—perhaps due to their airy vocal harmonies—Lush were always a formidable live act
column4: capable of delivering sweetness and noise in equal measure. And while so many of their shoegazing brethren wrote lyrics that were as amorphous as their guitar effects (and then buried them deep in the mix)
column5: Lush traded in emotional intelligence
column6: crafting songs that were as lyrically sharp as they were sonically adventurous.

column1: Given the recent spate of shoegaze-era reunions—My Bloody Valentine
column2: Ride
column3: Slowdive—it’s something of a no-brainer that Lush would finally be making a comeback. Rather than simply embark on a cash-grabbing nostalgia tour
column4: the band recorded Blind Spot—a sparkling 4-song EP that marks their first new output in two decades. Hewing closely to the ephemeral vibe of 1990’s Gala and the more plaintive tracks sprinkled across 1994’s Split
column5: these new Lush songs are instantly unmistakable—the pairing of co-frontwomen Miki Berenyi and Emma Anderson’s voices and chiming guitar tones sounding every bit as diaphanous as they did over 20 years ago.

column1: “Out of Control”—the EP’s first single—offers the kind of romantic yearning that made old songs like “Last Night” and “Desire Lines” such compelling listens. “I can’t understand why you won’t take my hand
column2: ” sings Berenyi throughout the track
column3: “Out of control but I love you so much.” Elsewhere
column4: “Burnham Beeches” bubbles with the same kind of lovelorn effervescence of Spooky’s “Untogether” (“I’m so shy
column5: I never speak a word till we’re on our own
column6: ” admits Berenyi. “That’s just fine
column7: as long as everybody leaves us alone.”) Closing track “Rosebud” is an oddly beguiling take on a Grimm ""Sleeping Beauty"" narrative in which the threat of eternal slumber is both ominous and strangely tantalizing: “Goodnight my baby girl and dream of Paradise/ My thorns will cradle you with love.” It would sound more sinister if the song itself wasn’t so lovely—all gently strummed rhythm guitar
column8: gently shaken tambourine
column9: and quietly employed strings.

column1: It’s important to note that while many of the Lush’s dreampoppy peers and 4AD labelmates either dramatically crashed and burned or simply fizzled into obscurity
column2: Lush ended their first career run on a tragically bittersweet note. The band’s last full-length
column3: 1996’s <i>Lovelife
column4: was a commercial and critical high—a razor sharp feminist kiss off and hook-filled antidote to the laddish mentality of late '90s Britpop. At a moment when they might have parlayed the success of songs like “Single Girl” and “Ladykillers” into even bigger mainstream success
column5: drummer and founding member Chris Acland took his own life. It proved to be a loss so profound that it appeared as though it would essentially silence the band forever. It’s hard not to think of Acland when listening to “Lost Boy
column6: ” the EP’s simplest and most haunting track. “I should have never let you out of my sight
column7: ” sings Berenyi. “Desperate to be beside you
column8: I didn’t know I’d never see you again.” Whether or not the song is an oblique reference to Acland’s passing
column9: it hints at the kind of abject heartbreak that is often impossible to overcome
column10: making the band’s poised return all the more remarkable.

column1: If there’s a weakness with Blind Spot it might simply be its brevity
column2: or perhaps the marked absence of the kind of swaggering sonic guitar bombast the band unleashed in old songs like “Sweetness and Light” or “Superblast!.” Regardless
column3: Blind Spot feels like an assured—albeit somewhat tentative—way for the band to dip their toes back in the water. It would be great if  the EP served as something more than just a primer for the band’s forthcoming reunion tour. Hopefully it will provide the kind of emotional throat-clearing they need in order to set about recording another full-length record. Clearly
column4:
they still have plenty to say.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23024/homepage_large.075a0735.jpg|Become Alive |33560.0|Dave Harrington Group|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Other People']|2016-04-19 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:45.325113|"

Before he became Nicolas Jaar’s foil in the electro-noir duo Darkside
column2: guitarist Dave Harrington was immersed in the jazz world
column3: hitting shows at the old Knitting Factory and Tonic in the late 1990s and early '00s. The New York improv scene was at the time especially vital
column4: but like any other young
column5: hungry player
column6: Harrington began to dabble outside of jazz so as to have enough working gigs
column7: doing time in metal
column8: synth-pop
column9: and indie bands. With Darkside now on indefinite hiatus and Harrington’s profile significantly raised
column10: it makes sense that he would form his own band and circle back to his improvised music roots.

column1: Following the downtempo Before This There Was One Heart But a Thousand Thoughts EP is Become Alive
column2: Harrington’s debut album as a leader
column3: which features instrumental configurations ranging from duos to 11-piece ensembles. Opener “White Heat” is made by a five-piece
column4: and finds Harrington’s group creating a dark
column5: foreboding mood
column6: as he coaxes flares of feedback that suggest a fire at the horizon. But even as it builds across its seven minutes
column7: there’s little actual movement. Volumes swell and recede
column8: cymbals sizzle and settle back in
column9: but rather than resolving tension
column10: “Heat” just dissipates.

column1: That dynamic holds true the rest of Become Alive
column2: which accentuates texture and mood over structure and melody to a fault. The unsettling atmosphere draws you in
column3: but there’s a sameness to the eight tracks that makes distinguishing individual parts difficult
column4: in part because every instrument finds itself in the service of ambience rather than melody or meter. “Slides
column5: ” arranged for Harrington and John Stanesco’s bass clarinet
column6: suggests disused industrial space
column7: the electronics churning far in the background like discarded machinery. Its function is mainly interstitial
column8: leading into “The Prophet
column9: ” wherein the drums and percussion clatter in an increasing pace without ever settling on an actual rhythm.

column1: The highlight is the title track
column2: a nearly 10-minute epic that features 11 players and some new timbres: vibes
column3: flute and soprano sax. The group works right up to a boil
column4: the woodwinds swerving around the other instruments. Harrington’s guitar has plenty to engage with here
column5: be it the high register of the saxophone or the rumbling percussion
column6: suggesting Santana at his earliest and most incandescent. The piece continues to build and build
column7: reaching a massive
column8: full-blown climax that justifies its lengthy runtime.

column1: The album ends on a stronger note. “Spectrum” mixes vibraphone
column2: theremin
column3: Fender Rhodes and Harrington’s pedal steel
column4: a curious array of instruments that come together to suggest a weightless
column5: sparkling space that slides ever so slowly towards dissonance. The new age ambience of “All I Can Do” leads into Become Alive’s most driving and most lyrical number. Harrington’s solo shows that while he’s adept at embracing bleak
column6: desolate atmospheres with his fretwork
column7: he’s just as capable of moving towards the lighter side. If the first half of the album has a lethargic sense that record never quite shakes
column8:
the last two tracks suggest there may be more for the group to explore in the future.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23170/homepage_large.595a7cba.jpg|印象III : なんとなく、パブロ (Imagining “The Life of Pablo”)|33675.0|Toyomu|['Experimental'
column3: the leaks
column4: the surprise releases
column5: and the streaming service arms race
column6: today’s recording industry is closer to the Wild West than a longstanding global market. For years now
column7: sheriffs at Apple Music and Tidal have struggled to convince customers in the Americas
column8: Europe
column9: Australia
column10: and elsewhere to pay for their damn music already. And yet
column11: across the sea in Japan
column12: folks continue to play by the rules—and what’s more
column13: they’re on track to surpass the United States as the world’s most lucrative music market. Unlike most of the world
column14: Japan didn’t experience the Napster revolution; in fact
column15: the supposedly obsolete CD continues to account for about 85 percent of sales. Moreover
column16: the major streaming services (and their exclusive releases) have yet to become available in the country. In other words
column17: while we’ve been blasting three different incarnations of Kanye West’s latest album The Life of Pablo for two months
column18: over 127 million people have been sitting in the dark; until the album’s broader global re-release earlier this month
column19: 2016’s most-hyped album was little more than a Dark Tidal Fantasy. What was a Kanye stan to do?

column1: The solution couldn’t be more obvious for Toyomu
column2: a Kyoto-based producer and ’Ye diehard: if he couldn’t listen to The Life of Pablo
column3: he’d have to make his own version. ""I thought it might be a good idea to make the whole album without listening to it
column4: he told Pigeons and Planes. Ironically
column5: the same digital forces that kept him from hearing the album proved key to his reinterpretation. Thanks to WhoSampled and Genius
column6: the producer was able to assemble a complete listing of every last obscure sample and punchline featured on the record
column7: providing Toyomu with the material for his own ""Album of the Life:"" 印象III : なんとなく、パブロ
column8: or (Imagining ""The Life of Pablo""). The project isn’t so much a recreation as it is an uncanny
column9: absurd outlier among the scores of fanservice-y ’Ye mash-ups populating the internet.

column1: The Life of Pablo—and obviously
column2: Toyomu’s project—wouldn’t exist if it weren’t for the internet. West has vowed never to release the project across physical formats
column3: instead relying on streaming to drive its success. (The record recently became the first to top the Billboard charts primarily from streaming.) This has created headaches and opportunities alike: Liberated from the finality of a CD pressing
column4: the album—like its creator
column5: and the internet at large—remains in perpetual flux
column6: its trappings mutable. As Toyomu put it in a Genius interview
column7: it's ""an eternity of creativity."" Accordingly
column8: the record feels more like a snapshot than like a tacit statement.

column1: If you thought Yeezus was esoteric
column2: just try to make it through印象III : なんとなく、パブロ—It makes West’s opus sound like a Rockabye Baby! installment
column3: primarily because it sounds so inhuman. All of the lyrics are fed through Apple's text-to-voice function
column4: giving us a record performed entirely by Microsoft Sam (known to most listeners as the stiff-sounding android that ""sings"" Radiohead’s ""Fitter
column5: Happier."") Obviously
column6: the robot sucks at rapping
column7: stripping the songs all nuance in syllable stress and meter
column8: particularly on the standout cuts. Lead single ""有名税"" (""Famous)] collapses under the weight of all its lyrical moving parts
column9: transmitting the braggadocio into paranoid-sounding pep talk. ""I made that bitch famous/God damn/I made that bitch famous/Talk that talk
column10: man"" deadpans simultaneous MC/hypeman Sam
column11: unable to distinguish between West’s rhymes and Swizz Beat’s ab libs. (A similar phenomenon lends hilarity to ""ゆらゆらボックス 0"" (""Waves"")
column12: with Chris Brown’s smooth tenor taking the form of a high-pitched
column13: drunken warble.) Even ""Low Lights
column14: —a song centered around Sandy Rivera's passionate inspirational speech—feels mechanical
column15: her every syllable stuck to a hollow
column16: randomly-pitched keyboard plunk in a manner that channels Wesley Willis.

column1: The technology detracts from the latent menace in West’s raps as well
column2: even as the established samples on ""Freestyle 4"" and ""FML"" drive the darkness home. In Toyomu’s world
column3: the agitated
column4: carnal queries on the former track (""What if we fucked right now?/What if we fucked right in the middle of the goddamn dinner table?"") may very well have come from a curious eight-year-old. The chuckle-inducing moments are frequent (not to mention steadily grating)
column5: but there’s ample darkness lurking in the margins: On ""Real Friends"" and ""Highlights
column6: Toyomu digs up the angst buried within West's gospel-infused opus. Meanwhile
column7: ""I Love Kanye"" is entirely devoid of its a cappella cheer
column8: replaced by a nightmarish duet delivered atop mournful keyboards: following an eerie
column9: monotone Japanese recitation of the track's lyrics
column10: a choir of English-speaking androids come in to proclaim their love for West.

column1: In terms of creepiness
column2: however
column3: nothing compares to ""nikeezy
column4: Toyomu’s take on ""FACTS."" The less-than-two-minute track transports me back to a traumatizing video from my high school physics class that simulated death by black hole. In this case
column5: it’s Kanye who’s being sucked up by the end of it all
column6: his repeated chants of ""Yeezy
column7: yeezy
column8: yeezy"" stretching and spinning as the rapper floats along the event horizon. The syllables collide with increasing force and velocity
column9: until the song's ""Street Fighter"" sample resets the sickening cycle with a Sonic Boom. It’s impossible to listen to the track without cracking up
column10: and yet it haunts me more than any Prurient song—not just because it’s terrifying
column11: but because it illustrates the artist's absurdity more than any interview or album ever could. Kanye’s hubris drives our obsession with his art and persona—as well as his own destruction. The celebrity
column12: the memes
column13: the outbursts
column14: the KTT stans—they’re all window dressing to distract from the void that threatens to consume him
column15: and us.

column1: 印象III : なんとなく、パブロ may sound like a bit like an Oneohtrix Point Never album at moments
column2: but it’s unlikely to break out of the fan-content niche any soon. Microsoft Sam’s goofy rhymes get old quick
column3: the half-baked
column4: discombobulated arrangements lack the nuance to compel repeat listens
column5: and save for awesome
column6: video-game influenced reworkings of ""Fade"" and ""Siiiiiiiiilver Surffffeeeeer Intermission"" (the latter incorporates music from the notorious
column7: well-soundtracked ""Silver Surfer"" NES game)
column8: most won’t be reaching for Toyomu’s takes over West’s. That said
column9: such surface-level aesthetic arguments distract from the album’s sterling achievements. This strange little record has certainly refigured how we view streaming’s ubiquity in the today's industry—not to mention how we perceive the ""global album""—but it’s also opened the doors for transcending such barriers through creative drive and compositional savvy. If we can’t have #Tidalforall
column10:
at least we can take the power into our own hands.

"|21831.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21831-iii-imagining-the-life-of-pablo/|6.0|Zoe Camp

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23161/homepage_large.0d44e20c.jpg|Sleep Cycle|29084.0|Deakin|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['My Animal Home']|2016-04-18 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:46.366903|"

Josh “Deakin” Dibb is the Ringo of Animal Collective—the member of a revered psychedelic-pop quartet that gets the least amount of love. Though in Dibb’s case
column3: that’s mostly a function of spotty attendance. He’s the only Animal Collective member still taking advantage of the group’s formative open-door policy
column4: having appeared on just five of their 10 official albums
column5: and his perceived expendability is further underscored by the fact the band’s most successful record to date—2009’s Merriweather Post Pavilion—was recorded without him.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: his status as Animal Collective’s resident black sheep was further entrenched by the well-intentioned but ill-conceived Kickstater campaign he used to announce this debut solo album way back in 2009. After crowd-sourcing over $25
column3: 000 to fund a festival trip-cum-recording mission to Mali—with promises of an accompanying picture-book to complement the resultant album—Dibb provided scant updates about the project’s status for the better part of seven years
column4: causing many donating AnCo fans to lose their chill. But this would-be scandal failed to address a more prosaic problem: as Dibb recently relayed to Pitchfork
column5: the extended delay was mostly the product of chronic
column6: near-paralyzing self-doubt about the quality of his material and vocal performances.

column1: Now
column2: having long ago donated the majority of the Kickstarter proceeds to a Malian NGO
column3: Dibb has finally emerged with a mostly self-financed
column4: small-scale album that was quietly released this month in a special cassette/book edition for donors (and on Bandcamp for everyone else). But despite all the Kickstarter confusion and communication breakdowns
column5: none of Dibb’s out-of-pocket supporters should feel short-changed. Because whatever anxiety Dibb felt about not following through on his Kickstarter campaign has been channeled into a wonderful little album about overcoming the anxiety of not following through on your Kickstarter campaign. Okay
column6: so Sleep Cycle doesn’t include any lyrics that specifically reference inflated funding targets and comment-section outrage
column7: but this exercise in self-help psychedelia provides a poignant portrait of an artist regaining their confidence one song at a time. It’s a short album—six songs
column8: 33 minutes—but a substantial one
column9: a deeply personal work that takes us inside the mind of Animal Collective’s most mysterious member
column10: while restoring some of the patience and mystique that’s been sucked out of that band’s recent
column11: more spasmodic work.

column1: To date
column2: Deakin's biggest solo vocal was on the swirling Centipede Hz centerpiece “Wide Eyed.” But even if Sleep Cycle’s opener
column3: “Golden Chords
column4: ” finds him crooning in a heretofore-unheard higher register
column5: it’s instantly identifiable as an Animal Collective product
column6: its field-recording ambience and hypnotic acoustic oscillations conjuring allusions to Sung Tongs (ironically
column7: another AC album that Dibb sat out). But Dibb’s lyrics are far more lucid and plaintive than anything Avey Tare and Panda Bear were attempting back in 2004: “Stop believing your being’s been shattered and distorted/ because
column8: brother
column9: you’re so full of love
column10: ” he sings atop a beautifully aching melody
column11: and though the lyrics are delivered in second person
column12: you get the strong sense Dibb is singing them into a mirror.

column1: As a vocalist
column2: Dibb is positioned about halfway between Panda and Avey—not gifted with the natural angelic grace of the former
column3: yet more plainspoken and less prone to hysterics than the latter. But he knows how to get the most out of it
column4: immersing his voice in his aqueous mixes without obscuring its emotional intent. Amid the phantasmagoric dub-pop of “Just Am
column5: ” he sings
column6: “I’ve lost my voice
column7: I need direction
column8: ” so he relies on the song’s repeated juju guitar lick
column9: steam-piped beat and drifting piano chords to show him the way. And if unadorned opening verse of “Footy” initially puts some Jeff Mangum-like strain on his cords
column10: they prove resilient enough to withstand the incoming onslaught of percussive shocks. True to its title
column11: “Footy” essentially sounds like Dibb kicking a drum set down a never-ending flight of collapsing stairs
column12: pausing at each wobbly landing before working up the strength for another punt. But just as the song seems like it’s going to completely combust
column13: an encroaching tsunami of analog synths washes the destruction away
column14: representing the victory of inner peace over external pressure.

column1: Sleep Cycle’s weightier tracks are threaded together through brief interstitials featuring street recordings of Malians that Dibb encountered on his African excursion
column2: but they’re more than mere vacation souvenirs—on “Shadow Mine
column3: ” he mutters his own affirming words overtop a Malian chant
column4: and the effect is like eavesdropping on the private prayer of someone working up the courage to face the outside world. “Seed Song”
column5: meanwhile
column6: answers the cacophonous chaos of the aforementioned “Footy” with a rippling
column7: pulse-regulating soundscape that provides another vivid reminder of Animal Collective’s mid-2000s masterworks. But the closing
column8: stargazing ballad “Good House” is less about Feels than the #feels. Atop a churchly
column9: Spiritualized-style sway
column10: Dibb dispenses reassuring mantras (“Breathe in without/ Breathe out you’re alright/ Breathe in with all/ Spit out all that rage/ You’re safe now/ Don’t fight”) much as he did back on “Golden Chords.” But here it sounds less like a personal therapeutic exercise than the sage advice of someone who’s survived a crisis of confidence and is now trying to help you cope with your own. And surely
column11:
that’s a reward more valuable than anything promised on his Kickstarter page.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23136/homepage_large.5fff5e3e.jpg|Love Letter for Fire|33638.0|Sam Beam & Jesca Hoop|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2016-04-18 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:47.020245|"

For almost as long as humans have had fire
column2: they've been writing songs about it. Billy Joel didn't start it
column3: Hendrix wanted to stand next to it
column4: and Jerry Lee Lewis had great balls of it. For Johnny Cash
column5: it burned
column6: burned
column7: burned in an unholy ring. You might expect
column8: then
column9: that a record titled Love Letter for Fire would pay direct homage to the power of those crackling flames.  But instead
column10: Sam Beam and Jesca Hoop deliver a gently rolling record that recalls healing summer storms more than destructive blazes.

column1: You'll know Sam Beam as the bearded fellow behind Iron & Wine
column2: while Hoop is an American singer-songwriter who now calls Manchester
column3: England home. The two co-wrote the thirteen duets that comprise the record
column4: and they're all seamless amalgamations of each writer's poetic songwriting style.

column1: Some of these tunes are a little dark at times
column2: like the lonely and hopeful ""Soft Place to Land
column3: ” but these songs never feel beholden to any particular sadness—or for that matter
column4: joy. Even with its moment-to-moment ups and downs
column5: the album keeps an even keel that refrains from ebullient delight or languishing sorrow. It's a surprisingly fertile middle ground that's only effective thanks to the pair's beguiling lyrics.

column1: Love Letter for Fire sounds lush and gorgeous from its outset
column2: with arrangements that do the songs justice without being overwrought. They're rich and earthy
column3: with Glenn Kotche's gentle percussion grounding airy string parts. Beam's voice sounds far more at home among low-end strings and piano than it did on Ghost On Ghost
column4: his jazz-inclined Iron & Wine LP from 2013. And though the instrumentation is more or less the same across the record
column5: subtle shifts in tempo keep it from becoming a gray lump of indistinguishable
column6: uninteresting songs. ""One Way to Pray” sways like an old porch swing
column7: while ""Bright Lights and Goodbyes” steps lightly as it ambles along.

column1: The duo's exquisite vocal harmonies are the crown jewel of Love Letter for Fire
column2: with the centerpiece and single ""Every Songbird Says” maximizing each singer's strengths. Her voice is high and taut against his lower
column3: billowing warmth. They circle each other from line to line and soar upward together gracefully on the song's high notes. The tune is a patient ode to a partner
column4: finding satisfaction in the small stuff: ""We know when it's enough to be walking with you
column5: ” they sing. Their voices fit together so uncannily that it's like each was made to sing with the other.

column1: Only one of Love Letter for Fire's songs stumbles: the plunking
column2: pointed ""Chalk It Up to Chi.” Compared to the elegance of its counterparts
column3: ""Chalk It Up to Chi” feels clunky and cartoonish
column4: especially with Hoop's exaggerated English affectation. The rest of the record is so pretty that it teeters on the edge of precious
column5: but fortunately
column6: this is the only one of thirteen tracks that falls over the edge. Instead of a love letter to consuming blazes
column7: Hoop's and Beam's collection appeals to our individual internal pilot lights: those softly smoldering flames that illuminate moments of beauty in ourselves
column8: in each other
column9:
and beyond.

"|21800.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21800-love-letter-for-fire/|7.5|Allison Hussey

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23065/homepage_large.30dea3b4.jpg|Welcome the Worms |29757.0|Bleached|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2016-04-18 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:47.585762|"

Over the past decade
column2: California rock has fully embraced the stoner beach party mood
column3: mixing the '60s girl-group sound with a fuzzy
column4: hotboxed playfulness. L.A.-based quartet Bleached have always been able to cruise in this lane fairly easily–their scrappy and infectious breakout single “Think of You” was exactly the type of ear worm that works best lazily blasted out of a drop top while riding down a palm-lined avenue. But even in the summer of 2011
column5: there was an ever-so-slight whiff of “too little
column6: too late” in the air surrounding the band
column7: especially since singer/guitarist Jennifer Clavin and her sister
column8: guitarist/bassist Jessica
column9: were both members of cult art-punk band Mika Miko
column10: one of those locally-beloved outfits who burned out way before they reached their full potential. It's always hard to not judge a new band by the successes of their past incarnations
column11: and by the time Bleached released their flawed-but-solid 2013 debut album
column12: Ride Your Heart
column13: they had fit themselves in snugly with the multitudes of other Shangri-Las idolaters from their home state
column14: but hadn't seemed to carve out a true identity for themselves
column15: which was a shame.

column1: Luckily
column2: with Welcome the Worms
column3: that identity has begun to take form
column4: and surprisingly
column5: it's not rooted in '60s revivalism at all
column6: but fast-forwards a decade into the future with a precisely jagged '70s rock edge. What's immediately striking about the album is its simplicity—its melodies are stark
column7: clean
column8: and in direct contrast to the lo-fi
column9: purposefully muddled sound that has defined Bleached and bands like them up until this point. Instead of scratchy and whimsical
column10: Jennifer's voice comes through sultry and clear. The overall feel evokes Suzi Quatro or Joan Jett—women who slashed their way through a traditionally male genre using sexism's own weapons against it. On “Trying To Lose Myself Again
column11: ” in which Jennifer asserts “I know what I want/ And I know what I like/ Keep on feeling good/ Just like I always should
column12: ” you can practically feel the dirty heat rising from the Sunset Strip pavement.

column1: There's an anecdote in the Runaways documentary Edgeplay where the band's bassist
column2: Jackie Fox
column3: describes finishing a night by vomiting banana daiquiris onto a telephone in a hotel room
column4: only to be awakened hours later by Lita Ford trying to strangle her with the phone's cord. That's basically what “Keep on Keepin' on
column5: ” sounds like: a thundering
column6: sudden
column7: rude awakening that swiftly establishes Welcome the Worms as new territory for Bleached. It calls on rock showboating just a hair
column8: even using a clever fake-out ending three-quarters of the way through
column9: but doesn't come off as tongue-in-cheek in the slightest. You could easily classify this record next to the likes of say
column10: Sahara Hotnights or the Donnas (a compliment or a curse
column11: depending on how old you were in 1999)
column12: with the exception that it deftly avoids gimmickry where more purely rockist acts may bask in it.

column1: However
column2: simplicity is a fickle beast
column3: and one that's difficult to maintain. Although Welcome the Worms starts off with a bang
column4: it gradually loses that momentum as it goes on—and at only ten short tracks
column5: it's a problem it never has time to overcome. “Chemical Air” makes perfect use of Bleached's airtight three-part harmonies
column6: but by the time to get to tracks like “Desolate Town” and the downtempo “I'm All Over the Place (Mystic Mama)
column7: ” that electricity has all but dissipated. While not a record of cast-iron slam dunks
column8: Welcome the Worms possesses enough raw power to cast Bleached in a completely different light
column9:
and one that is considerably more sustainable than their debut.

"|21733.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21733-welcome-the-worms/|6.9|Cameron Cook

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23062/homepage_large.a2c5bca2.jpg|Don't Look Down|2850.0|Mr. Lif|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mello Music Group']|2016-04-18 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:48.063217|"

Mr. Lif was a corner piece of the Definitive Jux puzzle
column2: as important to its cause as co-founder El-P
column3: Cannibal Ox
column4: or Aesop Rock. The Bostonian nonconformist took an analytical approach to writing that attempted to drill home on-the-nose messages. His debut album
column5: I Phantom
column6: remains one of Def Jux’s seminal achievements and it is still his best work to date
column7: a concept album on how black people are disenfranchised by the American system. He has always been equal parts revolutionary and educator
column8: finding his way through carefully-articulated syllabic mazes in search of hard truths. He doubled-down on this in his last two albums
column9: the surging class evaluation Mo’ Mega and its heavy-handed followup I Heard It Today. After a seven-year absence from rap
column10: he has returned with Don’t Look Down
column11: his first album on Mello Music Group
column12: a sharp technical marvel and a meditation on all that’s brought him here. This is a record of the weary lecturer
column13: one who has long been fighting the good fight with little to show for it. But Mr. Lif doesn’t ever wonder if it was all really worth it; he merely acknowledges the cost.

column1: Unlike past sanctimonious lyrical displays
column2: which read like condensed civics seminars
column3: these raps are riddled with mentions of missed opportunities and internal self-doubt
column4: and they’re delivered with a dryness that only enhances the candor. The what-ifs  here are personal
column5: not historical or conspiratorial. “Well I’m sitting at my table now
column6: hands crossed
column7: blast off/ Thinking ‘bout some opportunities that I had passed on/ Hindsight is 20/20
column8: thinking isn’t helping any/ Drinking will just serve to end me/ Progress
column9: am I making any?” he raps on “Everyday We Pray.” It's a peek into the exhaustion of the lifelong renegade: When your life’s work is beating your head against the walls of the political establishment
column10: it’s natural to wonder if it has actually done any good.

column1: Lif has sought to use his career to explain complex ideas to strangers
column2: yet he’s spent just as much time making basic ideas complicated. “The goal is to search deeper and go smarter and think harder
column3: ” he raps on “Let Go
column4: ” but overthinking has always been one of his weaknesses. Don’t Look Down keeps things relatively simple
column5: opting for narratives and wordplay that are far more approachable. What ties the whole experience together is his cautious optimism
column6: along with his still-firm belief that struggle builds character. Don’t Look Down openly acknowledges doubt but never succumbs to it
column7: instead using it as a balance for self-righteousness. There aren’t any regrets
column8: only lessons learned. The emotional (and literal) centerpiece for the album is “A Better Day
column9: ” which opens with a snippet of Dr. Martin Luther King
column10: Jr.’s speech “I’ve Been to the Mountaintop.” In it
column11: Mr. Lif  uses the full arsenal—his lyrical dexterity
column12: his reflexive flow
column13: and his observant eye—to paint a vibrant picture in broad strokes.

column1: And yet the best moments on the album are the free-wheelers
column2: records that aren’t anchored by any weighty concepts
column3: allowing him to just be the proficient rapper that he is. On “World Renowned
column4: ” the fun-loving energy of Del the Funky Homosapien rubs off
column5: and over a skipping loop it sounds like both tag-team partners are having a good time. Lif snuggles into the undulating wave on the Edan-produced “Whizdom
column6: ” which billows around him. The best of these is “Mission Accomplished
column7: ” which reunites the Perceptionists and finds the two emcees finishing each other’s syllabic yarns in call-and-response. It’s in the moments when he isn’t tethered to any belief system that Mr. Lif sounds most liberated.

Tunji Ige is a very current sounding rapper. ""Sometimes I’m like… Oh my god
column3: this sounds too much like [Kid] Cudi
column4: the then-sophomore in college jokingly worried in an interview with Fader around the time he released his first project in 2014. A couple years later
column5: on Ige’s new EP
column6: Missed Calls
column7: the comparison holds
column8: and he more obviously channels Kanye West and Drake throughout
column9: trying on their flows and crafting quiet homages out of beats. On one song he brags: ""This is post-backpack
column10: post-swag rap
column11: the end of trap
column12: and it’s not wack."" It’s kind of a corny line
column13: and Ige is actually at his best melding these hip-hop sub-movements he’s hoping to push past
column14: but it’s also an emotionally honest survey of the land for an in-between generation.

column1: Missed Calls is the product of a collaboration between Ige
column2: a 20-year-old Philadelphian son of Nigerian parents
column3: and Noah Breakfast
column4: an increasingly important behind-the-scenes force in the same city. Breakfast previously made up the production half of the college hip-hop duo Chiddy Bang under the name Xaphoon Jones and has more recently clocked work for acts like Jeremih
column5: Rome Fortune
column6: and Baauer. Ige is an inventive
column7: minimalist producer on his own
column8: and Breakfast’s touch articulates his ideas
column9: sculpting rough drafts into finely-tuned productions. The result is a noticeably well-mixed record
column10: and while Ige has an undeniable imitative propensity
column11: Missed Calls also sounds contained and consistent
column12: like it belongs entirely to him alone.

column1: Generally
column2: the EP leans warmly electronic with sounds that swell instead of crackle. Album opener ""Change That"" splays ambient synths on top of snappy drums while Ige waxes about his come-up. Ige isn’t a flashy lyricist and some of his raps are overly predictable
column3: but his restraint and smart approach to song structure are his best skills
column4: assets that make him more valuable as a hopeful hitmaker than as a cypher cameo. More importantly
column5: he’s got an ear for catchiness and is a capable enough singer to carry his own hooks.

column1: On ""War
column2: the only song produced solely by Breakfast
column3: Ige delivers a mumbling and monotonous sing-song
column4: but it works for the sparse
column5: subdued vibe. On ""22
column6: a dramatic
column7: self-serious reflection on being an ascendant 20 year-old rapper
column8: Ige is at his most intimate
column9: but remains a vague and low-stakes writer. ""The only road I see is by your side / And know I really could be that guy
column10: he sings affectionately. The song sandwiches a 32-bar verse between strategic bridges and a chanting hook. Like the rest of <i>Missed Calls
column11: you might not double back on a single verse or particular turn of phrase
column12: but Ige’s talent is in pushing a song forward and fleshing it out completely.

column1: The best songs on the album are in the middle and in succession. ""On My Grind
column2: the EP’s spacey trap lead single
column3: is rightfully Ige’s biggest hit to date and packages his most accomplished burst of rapping into a pair of verses
column4: the first of which bundles a succession of oddball but obvious similes (""She Bollywood dance like Punjabi / Slum Dog nigga eating Mahi
column5: he raps). The minimalist production interlocks entirely
column6: leaving no open space until a breaking point liberates the hook. ""Bring Yo Friends"" is an earworm with a simple
column7: bassy foundation and ad-libs—a persistent ""Yeah!"" tacked onto the end of each line—that nod affectionately to Juvenile’s late-’90s bounce smash ""Back That Azz Up."" ""You should bring your friends yeah
column8: bring your friends yeah!"" Ige chants. It’s carefree and simple
column9: inspirational and party-worthy. There’s no narrative ambitions to bog things down
column10: it’s just an obvious hit about having fun. It’s Ige at his best
column11:
accomplishing a lot with a little.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23005/homepage_large.8ded819b.jpg|Singing Saw|31668.0|Kevin Morby|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2016-04-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:48.805387|"

Kevin Morby speaks the language of records. His spare acoustic sound pulls from the late ’60s and early ’70s
column2: particularly Bob Dylan in baroque country mode
column3: Songs of Leonard Cohen
column4: and Lee Hazlewood. But where the well-read novelist Cohen was comparing mythologies and Hazelwood held forth like a wizened industry cynic
column5: Morby’s earlier work refracted meaning through the lens of his record collection. His debut album
column6: Harlem River
column7: featured one song about a slow train
column8: another about walking on the wild side
column9: and a third with a line about going down to the station with a ticket in your hand
column10: as if were still possible to buy paper tickets ahead of time. But connecting directly to the real world isn’t exactly Morby’s point. His music comes from another place
column11: one where you try and piece together meaning by tapping into a kind of collective unconscious
column12: using whatever tools you have at your disposal. And his references add up to something more than their parts and when paired with his unerring feel for arrangement and style.

column1: Morby’s own albums keep getting better
column2: and some of this we can chalk up to experience. Though he’s not yet 30
column3: he’s been involved with a lot of records—two in his band the Babies with Cassie Ramone from Vivian Girls
column4: four as a bass player in Woods (Morby is to Woods what Kurt Vile is to War on Drugs: a kindred spirit musically whose quirky vision needed more room than a band could provide)
column5: and now three as a solo artist. Singing Saw is his strongest album because it shows a process of refinement
column6: and because Morby’s songwriting has become less referential and more grounded. The basic ingredients haven’t changed
column7: but Morby is figuring out how to retain and amplify his strongest points—his weary and wise voice
column8: his understanding of how the musical pieces fit together—and leave everything else behind.

column1: On his debut
column2: Morby’s voice cracked in places
column3: suggesting effort that transcended ability
column4: but Singing Saw finds him cool and controlled at every turn
column5: fully aware of his limitations but confident in what he can accomplish within them. His singing is simultaneously intimate and distant
column6: part conversation and part stylized monologue. He’s got a nasally diction with a tendency to stretch vowels that didn’t exist in the world until Dylan first gazed at the Nashville skyline and a fondness for short
column7: direct statements that could have been written a century ago. The most contemporary piece of technology mentioned on the album is a Ferris wheel; the songs feature gardens and earth and shadows and fire and tears whose prevailing downward trajectory
column8: yes
column9: brings to mind rain. Single lines don’t really stand out
column10: but Morby’s commitment to such elemental concerns has a cumulative effect
column11: and the album’s lack of specificity becomes a strength.

column1: That confidence extends to musical choices
column2: including Morby’s tendency to let the small details of the sound do the work—he would never play five notes if four could get the meaning across. And while the core elements of his aesthetic—his deep voice with just the right halo of reverb
column3: gently plucked acoustic guitar— are a constant
column4: subtle instrumental variety abounds
column5: which Morby sometimes takes great joy in pointing out. On ""Dorothy
column6: he sings ""I could hear that piano play
column7: it'd go like…"" and the buzzing uptempo arrangement falls away leaving a beautiful tumble of keyboard notes
column8: and he follows it a bar later with a paean to a trumpet player that a horn player answers. ""Singing Saw"" seems to say something about how a single tool can be used either creatively or destructively
column9: and features the titular instrument prominently (and very beautifully).

column1: For Morby
column2: any day-to-day situation or mundane observation could spark something for his next album
column3: and sometimes being that tuned-in can be a curse. ""Got a song book in my head
column4: he sings on the album’s title track
column5: and he climbs a hill past the houses to find somewhere quiet where he can leave them behind. He claims in press notes that he wrote the song about his neighborhood in Los Angeles
column6: and his first album
column7: <i>Harlem River
column8: was in part about his stint living in New York. But while many people in L.A. notice the traffic and the food and the sunlight and the celebrity culture
column9:
Morby hears the coyotes and sees the moon.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23003/homepage_large.5e1390f7.jpg|Sorrow - A Reimagining of Gorecki's 3rd Symphony|29454.0|Colin Stetson|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['52Hz']|2016-04-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:49.756384|"

The story of Gorecki’s Symphony No. 3 (often called ""Symphony of Sorrowful Songs"") is one of a runaway success nobody
column2: even its composer
column3: understood. Why did a 1992 recording of a work written 16 years earlier by a previously unknown Polish composer suddenly sell a million copies? Other modern Polish composers’ works weren’t exactly leaping off shelves. No one knew why
column4: but critics
column5: who by and large weren’t fans
column6: offered theories; the piece was the lucky beneficiary of the early compact-disc boom
column7: for instance. It was bathetic music
column8: pandering to the worst and easiest film-score ideas that the general populace had about orchestral music. It sounded good at dinner parties. It was
column9: in other words
column10: a fluke
column11: a misfire in the central nervous system of the collective unconscious.

column1: As the years have accumulated
column2: and the piece has maintained its grip on the public imagination
column3: generating tributes and new recordings and finding use in multiple films
column4: a simpler explanation gently suggests itself: this piece pierced something in us
column5: gave us something we decided we needed badly. The timing of it will always be mysterious
column6: but the basic fact seems plain: Music listeners have decided we need Gorecki’s piece
column7: and we have made a permanent place for it in our lives. It has also
column8: famously
column9: saved some lives—in an NPR interview from 1995
column10: Gorecki read aloud a letter from a 14-year-old girl
column11: a burn victim
column12: who told Gorecki that the music was the only thing keeping her alive.

column1: It’s a simple piece
column2: at least in a harmonic sense. Works in this vein
column3: in which songful lines move slowly against each other (Barber's Adagio for Strings comes to mind)
column4: tend to require a brisk interpretive hand—all the pathos the music needs is in the notes
column5: and to wring any extra juice from them is to watch the whole thing curdle. What is most surprising about avant-garde saxophonist Colin Stetson’s Sorrow - A Reimagining of Gorecki's 3rd Symphony is how fully it embraces the music’s inherent sweep. Stetson’s often known for bracing music
column6: and his fans might have expected him to cut this big souffle with quinine. But from the first movement’s opening canon
column7: with Stetson blowing long
column8: low notes mimicking the orchestra’s double basses
column9: it’s pretty obvious: Whatever this piece has meant to decades of listeners
column10: it has meant something similar to Stetson. He clearly loves it
column11: and his recreation is nothing it not a personal act of love.

column1: He’s assembled a small force of about twelve musicians here
column2: including violinist Sarah Neufeld
column3: with whom he recorded last year’s Never Were the Way She Was. Stetson arranged and produced the recording himself
column4: playing multiple instruments
column5: and the soprano lament is sung by his sister
column6: Megan. Greg Fox
column7: the virtuoso drummer behind Liturgy and Guardian Alien
column8: fills the background with splashes of cymbal color and produces a steady thrum of double kicks. Two guitarists play high
column9: insistent tremolos
column10: and as the first movement reaches its peak
column11: I was startled to realize how similar this version sounded to something by a post-rock band like Explosions or Godspeed You! Black Emperor.

column1: Gorecki’s symphony
column2: with its deliberately simple and clear framework and soaring themes
column3: has a lot of the same emotional appeal as those bands. But Stetson’s arrangements give that correlation a meaningful nudge
column4: and suddenly Gorecki’s work feel less like a distant cousin to post-rock and more like a direct blueprint. This is instrumental music that embraces its undying capacity for uplift
column5: that shakes off distinctions between bathos and pathos
column6: between mawkish and grave
column7: as it blasts upward. The best moments in Godspeed and Explosions songs go for the emotional jugular without caring if you squawk in protest
column8: and so it is with Gorecki's Third Symphony.

column1: Gorecki was no sentimentalist by nature. His earlier works were mostly in the serial and twelve tone-based tradition
column2: and they haven't exactly been embraced by a fanatical general populace. But in the folk-song laments that inspired his Third Symphony
column3: he found something that touched his heart
column4: and he trusted it. In his work
column5: Stetson and his collaborators have found something similar
column6: and they trust him
column7:
too. 

"|21680.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21680-sorrow-a-reimagining-of-goreckis-3rd-symphony/|7.8|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23168/homepage_large.7ca9c045.jpg|Layers|28303.0|"Royce 5'9"""|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bad Half Entertainment']|2016-04-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:50.474363|"

Royce 5’9” (formerly Royce da 5’9”) has done a lot of his most visible rapping as a plus-one. His first appearance for many was on Eminem’s The Slim Shady LP as one half of Bad Meets Evil on a song of the same name. He caught his second wind years later as one of the senior members of the major label castoff Voltron that is Slaughterhouse (with Joe Budden
column2: Crooked I
column3: and Joell Ortiz). Most recently
column4: he’s functioned as DJ Premier’s rapping partner in PRhyme. Royce is an excellent supporting character
column5: but things never came together for any of his solo records
column6: which tend to drag.

column1: His sixth studio album
column2: Layers
column3: isn’t much different
column4: albeit not for lack of trying. Royce checks all the boxes on paper here
column5: fully loading it with big-time producers
column6: skits
column7: and tons of careful introspection
column8: the typical keys to a success for any traditionalist rap album. But this lyrical marathon falls short by any conceivable benchmark
column9: unable to really get going or sustain momentum until the very end. There’s also plenty of rapping about how good at rapping he is
column10: which is almost always boring.

column1: The main difference between Layers and past Royce records is supposed to be the newfound commitment to full-fledged storytelling
column2: and it’s easy to hear those gears turning on songs like ""Startercoat"" and ""Misses."" On the former
column3: he defends 2Pac's place in history
column4: in response to the omission on Billboard's Greatest Rappers of All-Time list from last year (“If Pac ain’t on your list then you ain’t fucking logical”)
column5: using a UNLV Starter jacket as a symbol for the influence Pac had on him. On ""Misses
column6: he writes about his relationship with his wife
column7: implying it’s difficult being a married rapper. While these are functional stories with interesting plot points
column8: they also prove he has a knack for overthinking (and oversharing)
column9: which torpedoes some of the strongest technical rapping on Layers. On “Tabernacle
column10: ” he tells the heartbreaking story of losing his grandmother and meeting his newborn son within hours at the same hospital. But he is incapable of building suspense or changing his tone
column11: and what should be an epic tale is reduced to the songwriting equivalent of turn-by-turn navigation—taking readable steps toward a predetermined destination. He’s prone to rapping in bulk
column12: and thus wants to narrate every detail of a story in a linear timetable
column13: telegraphing outcomes; sometimes it’s like a nonfiction book on tape.

column1: When he isn’t attempting to retell his story in extreme detail
column2: Layers is still packed wall-to-wall with Royce's filler-filled rap style
column3: relying heavily on knotty
column4: tightly-packed cadences. This can be dazzling
column5: like on “Off” (“Look in the sky there's a fly sorcerer/ Eyeballing me from a flying saucer/ And my mind is like a full clip/ And my competitions' magazines are running low like the Source and Vibe offices”)
column6: and it can also be cringe-worthy
column7: like on “Wait” (“My son got on them 350 boosts Kanye West is dressed in Bape/ Askin' me questions 'bout gettin' to second base/ Wifey textin' SMH”). Then there are outliers like ""Shine
column8: where he takes a swing at singsong raps and misses
column9: and ""Hard
column10: a song that doesn't even know what story it's trying to tell.

column1: That doesn’t mean that Layers is a complete misfire
column2: though
column3: or that Royce doesn’t have outings where he rattles off some truly impressive performances. The verses on “Gottaknow” are clinical. The Rick Ross and Pusha T-featuring “Layers” and the somber “America” are clear standouts. The album ends strong
column4: from ""America"" to closer ""Off
column5: but much like most of Royce’s solo catalog
column6:
there aren't many songs on Layers that really reward replaying or close listening.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22952/homepage_large.d47011d8.jpg|Crab Day|9328.0|Cate Le Bon|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2016-04-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:51.170530|"

Cate Le Bon's young niece did not take kindly to the idea of April Fool's Day. Instead
column2: she declared
column3: she would be celebrating Crab Day
column4: and inaugurated an annual tradition of drawing crustaceans. And why the heck not? The budding surrealist realized early on that nonsense is often the best response to nonsense
column5: that the constructs we use to prop up our lives are often totally arbitrary.

column1: Named for her niece's flash of genius
column2: Le Bon's fourth album features a song where the Welsh songwriter adopts an eerie falsetto and sings that she was born on the wrong day. A few years ago
column3: her mum unearthed her birth certificate
column4: and admitted to her daughter that they'd had her birthday a day off for nearly three decades. That sense of misaligned reality is the guiding force on Crab Day
column5: where Le Bon establishes a strange
column6: almost Dadaist lyrical scheme to make sense—or make more nonsense—of some unnamed life rupture that's left her grasping. Her perception is muddled
column7: but in her solemn voice
column8: everything appears clear: ""I'm gonna cry in your mouth
column9: she sings
column10: like that's a perfectly sensible thing to do.

column1: Last year
column2: Le Bon released Hermits on Holiday
column3: a collaborative album with White Fence's Tim Presley under the name Drinks. It pushed her usual pastoral post-punk into hairy
column4: deep-fried territory; the only rule of its creation was that there were no rules. Le Bon has said that it revived her creativity going into Crab Day
column5: which she recorded with her regular Welsh comrades Huw Evans (aka H. Hawkline) and Stephen Black (Sweet Baboo)
column6: and Warpaint drummer Stella Mozgawa. Things aren't as freeform here
column7: but in the absence of her lovely
column8: weathered old melodies
column9: nothing feels quite as it should be; the sound is as precisely off-kilter as touch-typing while gazing out of the window
column10: then looking at the screen to find you've been one key to the left all along. From neatly squawking guitar
column11: curiously skittish marimba
column12: and wry saxophone parps
column13: LeBon forges a chaotic cubist cabaret.

column1: It's unsettling
column2: but Le Bon's sensitivity to shifts in tone and pace
column3: and the strange interplay between her players
column4: make Crab Day feel welcoming
column5: like an old house whose creepy anachronisms become a strange comfort. A good half of its songs wed burbling guitar parts to stark
column6: straight-shooting rhythms
column7: and verses landslide into choruses where her vocals cascade like sycamore leaves
column8: but they establish and normalize Le Bon's uncanny universe
column9: and aren't without their individual touches: the feral cat guitar mewl of ""What's Not Mine;"" what could be a maniac bashing on a metal trap door in the midst of ""I Was Born on the Wrong Day.""

column1: Crab Day's primitivism hasn't totally sacrificed her lovely
column2: lilting melodies
column3: which are filled with remorse on ""Love is Not Love
column4: and sad acceptance on ""What's Not Mine."" And she's transmuted the overly literal aggression of ""Wild
column5: from 2013's Mug Museum
column6: into songs that pulse with weird rushes of adrenaline. With its racing verses and ambient chorus
column7: ""Wonderful"" perfectly captures both the mania and distraction of being thrown for a loop
column8: and ""We Might Revolve"" makes a horror film out of needling marimba and Le Bon's observation that ""all the towns are miniature
column9: which she delivers with the stern paranoia of a stoner certain they've seen something sinister in their domestic surroundings.

column1: As much as Le Bon's expression on Crab Day feels abstract and alienating
column2: it also speaks to a deep intimacy—perhaps one that's been lost and provoked all this discombobulation in the first place. Mug Museum made an emotional archive out of the dirty cups she collected in her room. Here
column3: she ascribes impenetrable significance to inanimate objects—she feels like geometry
column4: a dirty attic
column5: and a humid satellite in the face of a lover—but struggles to rationalize the basics of human connection: She and the subject of her address routinely look through each other
column6: the effect like a love story pieced together through split screen. ""How would I know you really swim in me?"" she asks on ""How Do You Know?"" ""How would I know to stay?""

column1: Crab Day is a voyage into doubt led by a queasy compass
column2: and a ringleader who's prepared to stake out uncertain territory. Le Bon always keeps you guessing
column3: making the old traditions of guitar-oriented rock feel arbitrary
column4: too. Her nervy assessments of the world are filled with equal parts suspense and heart
column5: and beautifully zany riffs
column6:
where the feeling of being frayed by uncertainty comes together into a strangely comforting patchwork.
