column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22951/homepage_large.90ee7bd9.jpg|YYY EP|33532.0|Tyler Friedman|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Arjunamusic']|2016-04-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:52.587498|"

YYY is essentially a 12-inch single that functions more like a 2-track EP
column2: with each side lasting in the neighborhood of 12 minutes. It super-imposes Tyler Friedman's minimalist-techno framework over the organic
column3: improvisation-heavy approach of Swiss-born jazz drummer Samuel Rohrer (Laurie Anderson
column4: Skúli Sverrisson
column5: Charles Gayle) and then flips the script somewhat when you flip the record. But
column6: though both pieces are titled ""YYY
column7: the two different versions— the ""Original Mix"" and ""Drum & Vocal Dub""—they don't draw from any of the same source material and aren't the same besides a shared core basis in overlapping rhythms.

column1: Rohrer doesn't even appear on the original version of the piece
column2: but the sensitivity to timbre that he shows on the alternate version undoubtedly influenced Friedman's structure and choice of sounds
column3: most notably a synthesized percussion pattern that by the pair's own description resembles a digitized cross between a vibraphone and a kalimba. Friedman created all the sounds on the original ""YYY"" using a modular synth setup
column4: and the kalimba-vibes hybrid tone is also drenched in pitch modulation so that the various hits sound like different-sized drops of water dunking into reverberant pools. When Rohrer does enter the picture on side 2
column5: he supplies a vaguely tribal meshwork of hand- and stick-tapped beats
column6: one of which gives the impression of a drum head whose tension is always changing so that the pitch bends up and down in a circular pattern.

column1: On hearing them together
column2: it's easy to see how the second version started out as a remix/re-imagining of Friedman's original but then evolved into its own separate piece. Both versions start out as a set of skeletal components and then swell as more and more layers of sound stream into the stereo field until
column3: at their peak
column4: each piece becomes quite busy. Both also make optimal use of the stereo field. But for all the thought that went into the juxtapositions here—synthetic vs. organic
column5: improvised vs. composed—Friedman arguably covers more ground and creates a more fertile set of contrasts on his own. Rohrer would likely have matched him had he added his own
column6: third version consisting entirely of acoustic-based sounds
column7: or had he been left to his own devices on side 2.

column1: On side 1
column2: it's easy to get lost in the endless shifting between the kalimba-like pattern and the steady-hissing techno beat. On much of side 2
column3: however
column4: the robotic and human sounds cause more friction as they collide. Perhaps this was intentional
column5: but since side 1 derives much of its energy from Friedman's interpretation of Rohrer's style
column6: the drum-vocal dub leaves the listener wondering what could have happened had Rohrer returned the favor in isolation. The duo shares a rehearsal space
column7: so the temptation to team up makes sense. And to mimic the effect of haunting sine-wave swells on the original mix
column8: Friedman and Rohrer brought in Norwegian singer Tora Augestad
column9: whose voice they manipulate at times so that it sounds like
column10: say
column11: a screeching saxophone reed or a swarm-like cloud of distortion.

column1: Clearly
column2: Rohrer and Friedman have been mindful of ambience and space in their separate careers up to this point—Friedman with his installations and works for film
column3: and Rohrer doing the rounds in a number groups in the experimental jazz and ECM records orbits. Interestingly
column4: they've chosen to give YYY a flat
column5: almost space-less quality—the musical equivalent of a green screen. That decision serves as one of this EPs defining characteristics
column6: but if there's one knock on this music
column7: it's that it's quite literally out of place without a spacial
column8: visual
column9: or extra-musical dimension to go with it.

column1: In spite of its steady pulse and proximity to dance music
column2: YYY is ultimately coming from a ponderous rather than sweaty place. While there are spots
column3: particularly on side 2
column4: that speak to something innate in the hips that wants to move
column5: it's hard to see this music ever making an appearance in a club. On the other hand
column6:
Friedman and Rohrer favor a kind repetition that's ultimately too active to encourage trance-like zoning out. Dance fans might find it too stiff and jazz fans might find it too electronic. But alienating genre loyalists is usually a good sign that an artist is onto something. Let's hope that he and Friedman expand on this initial dalliance and come up with more.

"|21703.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21703-yyy-ep/|6.0|Saby Reyes-Kulkarni

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/23023/homepage_large.163b6904.jpg|The Hope Six Demolition Project|1896.0|PJ Harvey|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Island']|2016-04-14 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:47:52.761562|"

In 1992
column2: an NME writer asked PJ Harvey about the political resonance of her work. ""I feel uncomfortable with myself at the moment because I feel I’m neglecting that side
column3: she replied. ""I’m not concerned enough about things."" She worried that the critical attention she had received for her debut album
column4: that year’s Dry
column5: was making her introspective. ""It could get really dangerous if I don’t do something about it soon
column6: she said. ""I could develop a huge ego or something."" Instead
column7: Harvey
column8: then 22
column9: suffered a breakdown
column10: the result of moving to London from rural Dorset
column11: her first big breakup
column12: and the pressure of being the scrutinized center of a rapidly popular band (as the PJ Harvey Trio were then). From then on
column13: her interviews became opaque. She refused to explain her lyrics or discuss much of her personal life. It frustrated journalists
column14: but her records spoke for themselves
column15: centering sexual and biblical apocalypse in the body of a middle-class white woman with a filthy sense of humor and a preternatural gift for the blues.

column1: But 14 months ago
column2: Harvey pulled off an unprecedented reveal for the making of her ninth album. She and her band recorded behind one-way glass in the basement of London’s Somerset House
column3: as paying spectators looked on. Last October
column4: she showcased the finished songs live
column5: along with poems (available as a book
column6: The Hollow of the Hand)
column7: and Seamus Murphy’s photographs from their research trips to Afghanistan
column8: Kosovo
column9: and Washington D.C.
column10: which formed the record. Her creative process has never been more transparent
column11: yet somehow
column12: her intentions remain totally inscrutable—she’s given zero interviews since announcing the project
column13: and considering the noncommittal dispatches she offers from these places
column14: it's hard to know what point she's trying to make.

column1: On 2011’s groundbreaking Let England Shake
column2: all roads led back to England and its role in various 20th century international conflicts. If there’s a unifying thread between the desolate global vignettes of <i>The Hope Six Demolition Project
column3: it’s that Washington has a tendency to leave its business unfinished. The U.S. wades into communities at home and abroad in the name of improving conditions
column4: whether through toppling dictators or tearing down unsafe housing projects
column5: but ultimately disenfranchises them
column6: amputating the infected limb and driving off with the crutches. This is her Let America Shake
column7: if you will.

column1: However
column2: she can be strangely thoughtless here
column3: in ways that aren't easy to parse. She’s already run into trouble for the album’s opening track
column4: ""The Community of Hope
column5: which offered a dispiriting portrait of the D.C. neighborhood Anacostia. Local activists denounced her characterizations of the local school as ""a shithole
column6: and the addicted
column7: homeless populace as ""zombies."" ""Or at least
column8: that’s what I’m told
column9: she sings
column10: making clear that those were her tour guide’s words. Perhaps she’s pointing out the subjectivity of perception
column11: but there’s a frustrating reluctance on her part to assign any value or judgment to the things she sees
column12: other than a few trite comparisons between haves and have-nots—not least a terrible faux-deep portrait of a homeless
column13: disabled indigenous woman drinking in a Redskins cap.

column1: Whatever her geopolitical intentions
column2: The Hope Six Demolition Project is her most exhilarating rock album in years
column3: yoking the siren-like catchiness of her last great America-influenced album
column4: Stories From the City… to the swamp-tarnished filth of her classic first three records
column5: Dry
column6: Rid of Me
column7: and To Bring You My Love. It’s leering
column8: brash
column9: and dissonant

 Xiu Xiu are an archetypally ""difficult"" band. Hard to measure and
column3: at times

column5: they are experimental in the most literal meaning—not musicians exploring ""experimental genres"" of music

column7: leading to music whose ideas travel the map so broadly as to be deemed unclassifiable when put together. This approach has led the band to develop passionate followers but also put themselves in a position where these constant new approaches not only alienate the mainstream but past fans as well.

column1: Given this perspective
column2: the band’s latest release
column3: <i>Plays the Music of Twin Peaks
column4: makes a lot of sense. It’s easy to see parallels between Xiu Xiu and David Lynch—both are challenging

column6: for much of his career Lynch was seen less as a genius and more as a fascinating but flawed artist obsessed with the '50s and the death of the American Dream.

column1: Perhaps nowhere is this mix of ""Wow!"" and ""Ungh :-/"" on display more in Lynch’s work than in 1990’s groundbreaking show ""Twin Peaks."" ""Twin Peaks"" was a watershed moment—the first time anyone had attempted to port sinister art-house cinema vision to Big Three television
column2: that mainest of mainstreams—but despite What It Did and What It Meant
column3: ""Twin Peaks"" was still a messy failure that devolved into a soap opera slop—James’s search for meaning
column4: Dick Tremayne
column5: BILLY ZANE!!!—difficult for even diehard fans to stick by. But if you ""got it"" anyway
column6: it just didn’t matter. You just put on headphones
column7: kept watching and felt ok knowing it made you feel ok.

column1: One of the reasons why Lynch’s work always hit hard was his way with music and sound
column2: particularly his partnership with Angelo Badalamenti. The score to ""Twin Peaks"" is arguably Badalamenti's crown jewel
column3: and Xiu Xiu do it justice. Their success here is twofold: Not only do they capture the haunted spirit of the show
column4: they also provide Xiu Xiu fans with one of their strongest releases in awhile.

column1: The simple
column2: live-in-the-studio recorded feel helps keep the band grounded and the sound uniform
column3: giving it the sense of a live performance. They skip the obvious choice of ""Falling"" as opener--the vocal version of the famous theme

column5: which begins not with the famous Moby-sampled synth but instead a very portentous tom drum thud followed by sustain-pedaled piano notes.  The choice here indicates upfront that they intend to evoke something deeper and more resonant than simple nostalgia.

column1: ""Laura Palmer’s Theme"" is followed by ""Into the Night
column2: the album’s best track
column3: and one of three with vocals. The original
column4: featuring Julee Cruise
column5: is hard to top
column6: but this version is bold and ominous
column7: propulsive and mysterious. In a way
column8: Stewart's manic delivery suits this material better than it sometimes does on his own. On the last vocal number
column9: ""Sycamore Tree
column10: they take a tune originally sung by jazz legend Little Jimmy Scott and bring it closer to ""a Xiu Xiu song"" (if such a thing exists
column11: I guess)
column12: than anything else on Plays. Stewart channels the dead Scott with a caricatured capital-P Performance  that succeeds without feeling fake or contrived. On “Falling
column13: ” Stewart relies on the soaring
column14: heart-tweaking power of the song without overselling it. While Stewart’s singing in Xiu Xiu often feels like it's been appended on top of or along side of the music it accompanies
column15: on these three it feels threaded into its fabric. I even found myself yearning for a Xiu Xiu version of ""Just You
column16: "" the corny and inexplicable '50s ballad sung by Laura Palmer’s boyfriend James.

column1: The instrumentals are nearly as strong
column2: including ""Packard’s Vibration
column3: which begins as a vibraphone-led jazz number before the distorted guitar and shimmering synths help it achieve lift-off. The only real misstep is the closer
column4: ""Josie’s Past

column6: spoken in stilted
column7: accented English
column8: only call attention to the terrible cheesiness of the writing—and
column9: god
column10: at nearly eight minutes
column11: it nearly dares you to stop listening before the end. Stewart gives a perfectly ridiculous thirty second reading of the '40s song ""Mairzy Doats"" (sung by Laura’s dad Leland Palmer on the show) five minutes in and the whole track would have worked better as a 60 second bit with just that.

column1: These are minor gripes
column2: though. Appreciators of the uncanny

Listening to Year of the Rabbit is like stumbling across a cache of hidden journals that Gabrielle Smith wrote five years ago
column2: hid in a box

column5: ""Are you home?""

column1: She’s always been one to thread anxiety through her work

column3: beautiful moments to satisfy. By far

""See you at Myrtle Broadway/ I’m shy and keep walking/ Your eyes as sad as tree stumps/ A nose just like a ski jump/ I don’t just wanna fuck/ I wanna show you love
column5: "" she sings. It’s a powerful snapshot of desire and lust

column3: Told Slant
column4: and Bellows .(The EP was recorded with fellow Epoch collective members Emily Sprague of Florist and returning drummer Felix Walworth—who also plays in Florist and is the frontperson for Told Slant.) Smith’s descriptions of long-distance relationships and lengthy separations
column5: of shaky stops and starts
column6: of ""trying to be open to whatever

column8: Year of the Rabbit can be viewed as a retrospective
column9:
an artist piecing together bits of her past to gain further clarity and insight into whatever comes next.

It's easy to forget how crucial guitars were to the music of Everything But the Girl. They were not merely embellishment of production
column3: but rather an anchor to the style that gave credence to both Tracey Thorn and her husband Ben Watt at the start of their respective careers. While she got her start in such post-punk outfits as Stern Bops and Marine Girls
column4: it was her hushed 1982 solo debut
column5: A Distant Shore
column6: that helped the NME set recognize Thorn. Watt’s trajectory
column7: meanwhile
column8: saw him being taken under the wings of such prominent English rock icons as Kevin Coyne
column9: who produced his first single ""Cant"" upon signing to Cherry Red in 1981
column10: and Robert Wyatt
column11: prominently featured on his 1982 debut EP <i>Summer Into Winter
column12: before forging his own unique fusion of British folk and bossa nova on 1983’s North Marine Drive.

column1: It was once thought that a full-on return to those organic roots was a bridge too far for Watt
column2: who continued to travel further and further into London’s deep house and techno culture as the curator of both the influential late '90s/early '00s Sunday club Lazy Dog and the independent record label Buzzin’ Fly

column4: the Marylebone native surprised both fans and critics alike in 2014 with Hendra
column5: a leftfield return to the intimate songcraft he explored on North Marine Drive 31 years prior as if the whole time burning up dancefloors in Miami
column6:
Berlin and Ibiza was all just something of a fever dream.

And so goes the name of his third proper solo full-length
column7: an album that continues to find Watt moving his DJ rig further into the storage unit of his creative mind in order to continue to explore his reignited love for live instrumentation. He recorded at the renowned RAK Studios in London
column8: with the intention of melding the fineness of Pentangle to the fury of Crazy Horse. And in its way
column9: Fever Dream picks up where Hendra left off
column10: as songs like ""Women’s Company"" and ""Never Goes Away"" retain the delicacy of its predecessor's finest moments. But the cranked-amp grit of the record's more combustible cuts
column11: like ""Winter's Eve"" and ""Bricks and Wood
column12: sets the scene.

column1: This is the very first time we are really hearing Ben Watt in full guitar rock mode. You can certainly hear the influence of solo David Gilmour
column2: whose appearance on ""The Levels"" was one of the highlights of Hendra. Yet by largely keeping the electric currents of Fever Dream so well mannered
column3: however
column4: songs like ""Gradually"" and ""Between Two Fires"" fail to muster up much excitement. The strongest material
column5: in fact
column6: constitutes some of Ben Watt's finest work in years. The closest he does come to integrating his Buzzin' Fly past happens on ""Running With the Front Runners""
column7: when that whistling Moog you might have heard on some of your favorite Everything But the Girl tunes turns up. Elsewhere
column8: an appearance by MC Taylor of Hiss Golden Messenger shines on the title cut. By the closing number
column9: the pastoral ""New Year of Grace""
column10: Watt lets his British folk roots show
column11:
with Marissa Nadler playing Jacqui McShee to his Bert Jansch.

From his four decades in music to his valiant coping with the rare inflammatory disease Churg-Strauss Syndrome (chronicled in his excellent 1996 book Patient)

column17: however
column18:
had he decided to really get his hands dirty in feedback and digital fuzz.

You might not recognize Peder Mannerfelt by name

He and his frequent collaborator Henrik von Sivers co-produced much of Fever Ray's debut album; they also produced Blonde Redhead's Penny Sparkle and some of Glasser's debut. Mannerfelt used to make stark

column11: ""filth

the human point of reference that brings his gothic panorama thrillingly to life.

column3: some albums change the course of music so profoundly that it's hard to imagine what the world was like before their arrival. Metallica's 1983 debut Kill 'Em All more or less singlehandedly launched thrash metal and established the template for every other speed- or extremity-oriented metal band on earth that's been active since. You can split hairs about the key role played by fellow ground-floor pioneers Slayer and Exodus
column4: and point out that Anthrax and Voivod had also already formed by the time Kill 'Em All was released. You could even argue that other bands were bound to reach the same threshold of tempo and attack because the early-'80s metal underground was collectively headed in the same direction anyway—i.e: getting faster and heavier and building on the work of Motörhead
column5: Venom
column6: Mercyful Fate
column7: and others.

column1: But the fact is
column2: several key participants in thrash metal's first wave freely admit that Kill 'Em All gave them a framework for the sound they had all been searching for. In other words
column3: once Metallica stepped up the pace
column4: everyone else followed suit. Listening back through modern ears
column5: it's almost like revisiting those first three Ramones records—you know this music shaped the world you live in
column6: but since so many artists have added extra levels of intensity since then
column7: there's no way to re-create the sensation of how revolutionary the music was during its time. Today
column8: the sequencing sounds a little more abrupt
column9: and a surprising share of the riffs fall closer to traditional Maiden/Priest-level heavy than outright thrash. But of course
column10: there are moments—the crunching chugga-chugga riffs that propel songs like ""Whiplash
column11: ""Metal Militia
column12: for instance—where Metallica's sense of purpose crystallized
column13: and it's easy to see why the band became known as such a genre-defining force right out of the gate.

column1: That said
column2: the question here is whether there's any justification for re-releasing a title that
column3: for metalheads
column4: is as much a ""required listening"" staple as Led Zeppelin's first album is for fans of classic rock. It's not like the original pressing of Kill 'Em All suffered from a muddy mix or anything—dated
column5: maybe
column6: but not anything that could be significantly improved upon via remastering. So if you already own this music
column7: don't expect an improvement in sound quality. And if you don't own it
column8: you may be asking yourself: do I need to pay top dollar to get the album plus several hours' worth of previously unreleased extras? For neophytes and—unfortunately
column9: even for dedicated fans—the answer is: probably not. At first
column10: all the extras look tempting—several complete live shows
column11: demos and rough mixes
column12: the ""Jump in the Fire"" and ""Whiplash"" singles (both of which come with the same two live b-sides
column13: which was unnecessary)
column14: and an hour-plus long interview with drummer and lead mouthpiece Lars Ulrich. If the infamous band biopic Some Kind of Monster makes you cringe at the thought of spending upwards of an hour with Ulrich talking in your ear
column15: his Q&A actually sheds a good deal of light on the early days of the band.

column1: And
column2: though the rough mixes vary in quality
column3: the more fully-developed songs provide a startling new perspective on the material. Classics like ""Motorbreath"" and ""Hit the Lights"" actually sound fuller
column4: meatier
column5: and more vital. In this more organic form
column6: the music breathes more. Apparently
column7: the conventional wisdom of the time dictated that this sound was too crude for public consumption. But today
column8: bands put a lot of effort into getting this kind of loose
column9: raw sound on purpose. Now
column10: we finally get to see that perhaps the final Kill 'Em All mix that the public got was too constricted
column11: which makes sense given this music demanded a new approach to production values that hadn't been invented yet. But the new mastering job doesn't serve the main mix especially well. If anything
column12: it only exposes the clenched and unnatural quality of the reverb that's applied to pretty much every instrument. Any time a vocal or snare hit rings out (like when frontman James Hetfield screams ""PESTILENCE"" on ""The Four Horsemen"")
column13: the echo tail abruptly closes shut. If you were used to listening to this album on a shitty cassette or in a car or a noisy work environment
column14: you probably never noticed. Here
column15: the clunky gated reverb becomes the music's most noticeable feature.

column1: As for the live material
column2: it would be charitable to call it ""bootleg quality."" Not to mention that multiple rounds of pretty much the same songs get old pretty quick. The one thing that fans might hone in on is the historical value of early performances of material from the band's next album

column3: some albums change the course of music so profoundly that it's hard to imagine what the world was like before their arrival. Metallica's 1983 debut Kill 'Em All more or less singlehandedly launched thrash metal and established the template for every other speed- or extremity-oriented metal band on earth that's been active since. You can split hairs about the key role played by fellow ground-floor pioneers Slayer and Exodus
column4: and point out that Anthrax and Voivod had also already formed by the time Kill 'Em All was released. You could even argue that other bands were bound to reach the same threshold of tempo and attack because the early-'80s metal underground was collectively headed in the same direction anyway—i.e: getting faster and heavier and building on the work of Motörhead
column5: Venom
column6: Mercyful Fate
column7: and others.

column1: But the fact is
column2: several key participants in thrash metal's first wave freely admit that Kill 'Em All gave them a framework for the sound they had all been searching for. In other words
column3: once Metallica stepped up the pace
column4: everyone else followed suit. Listening back through modern ears
column5: it's almost like revisiting those first three Ramones records—you know this music shaped the world you live in
column6: but since so many artists have added extra levels of intensity since then
column7: there's no way to re-create the sensation of how revolutionary the music was during its time. Today
column8: the sequencing sounds a little more abrupt
column9: and a surprising share of the riffs fall closer to traditional Maiden/Priest-level heavy than outright thrash. But of course
column10: there are moments—the crunching chugga-chugga riffs that propel songs like ""Whiplash
column11: ""Metal Militia
column12: for instance—where Metallica's sense of purpose crystallized
column13: and it's easy to see why the band became known as such a genre-defining force right out of the gate.

column1: That said
column2: the question here is whether there's any justification for re-releasing a title that
column3: for metalheads
column4: is as much a ""required listening"" staple as Led Zeppelin's first album is for fans of classic rock. It's not like the original pressing of Kill 'Em All suffered from a muddy mix or anything—dated
column5: maybe
column6: but not anything that could be significantly improved upon via remastering. So if you already own this music
column7: don't expect an improvement in sound quality. And if you don't own it
column8: you may be asking yourself: do I need to pay top dollar to get the album plus several hours' worth of previously unreleased extras? For neophytes and—unfortunately
column9: even for dedicated fans—the answer is: probably not. At first
column10: all the extras look tempting—several complete live shows
column11: demos and rough mixes
column12: the ""Jump in the Fire"" and ""Whiplash"" singles (both of which come with the same two live b-sides
column13: which was unnecessary)
column14: and an hour-plus long interview with drummer and lead mouthpiece Lars Ulrich. If the infamous band biopic Some Kind of Monster makes you cringe at the thought of spending upwards of an hour with Ulrich talking in your ear

column1: And
column2: though the rough mixes vary in quality
column3: the more fully-developed songs provide a startling new perspective on the material. Classics like ""Motorbreath"" and ""Hit the Lights"" actually sound fuller
column4: meatier
column5: and more vital. In this more organic form
column6: the music breathes more. Apparently
column7: the conventional wisdom of the time dictated that this sound was too crude for public consumption. But today
column8: bands put a lot of effort into getting this kind of loose
column9: raw sound on purpose. Now
column10: we finally get to see that perhaps the final Kill 'Em All mix that the public got was too constricted
column11: which makes sense given this music demanded a new approach to production values that hadn't been invented yet. But the new mastering job doesn't serve the main mix especially well. If anything
column12: it only exposes the clenched and unnatural quality of the reverb that's applied to pretty much every instrument. Any time a vocal or snare hit rings out (like when frontman James Hetfield screams ""PESTILENCE"" on ""The Four Horsemen"")
column13: the echo tail abruptly closes shut. If you were used to listening to this album on a shitty cassette or in a car or a noisy work environment

Niki and the Dove's Malin Dahlström has one of the most fantastic voices in pop. The Gothenburg native has that slightly wry

Since 2014
column2: Kweku Collins has been releasing small
column3: intimate
column4: and subdued hip-hop-informed bohemian rhapsodies on self-worth and the meaning of life. His perspective wobbles hazily between navel-gazing and philosophical musings
column5: in a way that can only be conveyed by a late '90s-born suburban kid living just outside one of the most violent inner cities in the US. His output has been all bedroom music (literally: he produced
column6: recorded and mixed everything himself; in his Evanston
column7: Il bedroom) and he seems willing to save the world
column8: but only if he can get past his own self-doubt and willing alienation. ""My momma told me I am a king/ And I believe her/ Why I used to think that I wasn't shit"" he sang on ""Kings"" from last year's rewarding <i>Say It Here
column9: While It's Safe EP. On the song he also said ""R.I.P [to] my demons"" and confessed that ""today we feel like Kings/ I ain't never been this happy.""

column1: But euphoria is not Collins' constant companion; melancholy and second-guessing introspection are. And on his new LP
column2: Nat Love—the name references the former slave
column3: cowboy
column4: Black folk hero
column5: and author also known as Deadwood Dick—his tendency to turn inward and re-emerge with poetic reveries are strengths that serve him well. Thematically
column6: Collins is more about observations than declarations
column7: inquiry over polemic. As a former slam poet
column8: he tends to write in circles of wordplay or elongated strands of thought that seek meaning through journal-like streams of discovery. On ""Nat's Intro"" he confesses that
column9: ""Well
column10: I listen to Future and lay up/ Playin' like I am a student / I know no future is proven/ But I know some people that prove it
column11: before repeatedly asking
column12: both confident and unsure: ""Is this what you wanted?"" (His answer: ""There is no answer/ “Til you answer."")

column1: None of the music sounds as dreary or as downtrodden as the lyrics would suggest: the tracks are light and bouncy

On ""Death a Salesman""—the lone track on the project which Collins didn't have a hand in producing; instead passing off duties to his Closed Sessions labelmate oddCouple—there's an inspired and melodic take on the sentiments expressed by Ice Cube's ""I Wanna Kill Sam"": ""See
column5: I have this Uncle Sam/ And I hate his ass so much/With a finger in my face/ As if I should give a fuck/ He said he'll give me a gun/ And he think I should shoot for him/I say
column6: 'Sam
column7: I think you right'/ Then I turned the gun on him

column2: folk
column3: and neo-soul coming together to form a new micro-genre of hip-hop that's part part Chance the Rapper
column4: part Wyclef
column5: part Future
column6: part Chief Keef. The sounds here are immersed in the dance of lingua franca and colloquialisms and tastes and cultures defined by a generation raised on playlists and the ability to stream the history of music on their phones for less than the price of a single CD. When Collins sings

column8: his vocals sound like rambling rocks in a river of thoughts

column1: ""If I'm a rapper then she's a bad bitch
column2: says Collins on ""Stupid Roses
column3:
a song about marijuana that doubles as a meditation on a love half-remembered but still felt. It's not the full-on ode that D'Angelo's ""Brown Sugar"" was—Collins seems conflicted about his ""love for cannabis""—and the double narrative and sense of self-hate and addiction feel like they're talking about his  greater conflicts with love and self-acceptance. On ""The Outsider"" he posits that ""love is a battlefield/ Pat Benatar shit"" and declares ""I'ma be a legend/ I'ma be a Johnny to your Dolly."" Those aren't the kind of references typical to a hip-hop song; they're the observations of an insider walking the line between finding and defining himself.

column3: Toronto has played host to Death to T.O.
column4: a marathon two-level party where 20-odd local bands dress up as some iconic group and cover a bunch of their songs in rotating 20-minute mini-sets. Last October
column5: noise-punk quartet Greys performed as Smashing Pumpkins

column7: the Pumpkins are Greys' polar opposites. Where Billy Corgan channels themes of alienation into unabashedly earnest
column8: immaculately rendered grunge-prog

column10: stage-leveling ethos. After all
column11: Greys are the sort of band that write songs in honour of Fugazi's Guy Picciotto

column1: But listen to Greys' second full-length
column2: Outer Heaven

column4: Greys came off like a less brawny

column6: but he had to blow out his vocal cords to be heard amid the band's Jehu-schooled
column7: post-hardcore pummel. And the feelings of inadequacy he was trying to express were filtered through cheeky song titles (see: ""Use Your Delusion"") and tongue-in-cheek complaints (""Wish I was born in New York
column8: wish I was born in L.A.
column9: wish I was born in the royal family""). But with the tranquil
column10: starlit jangle of the opening ""Cruelty
column11: Outer Heaven marks a clean
column12: abrupt break from that past—not just by opening up greater spatial possibilities in the band's sound world
column13: but by foregrounding a nakedly emotional tenor that permeates even the more typically ferocious tracks that follow.

column1: Like many ’90s kids
column2: Greys got swept up in the alt-rock revolution
column3: before burrowing deeper underground to discover the self-sustaining network of bands and labels that laid the groundwork for it. (That evolution can be traced from the fact the aforementioned song about Picciotto swipes its opening line from the Foo Fighters: ""There goes my hero!/ He lives right down the street!"") Now that ""indie"" has become a satellite-radio format for well-heeled commuters
column4: it's hard to remember a time when such a discovery could be so empowering that it could alter the course of one's life. But guitar-driven indie rock's deliberately modest scale and often introverted
column5: sometimes ironic sensibility can make it ill-equipped to address the more complex socio-political conversations that dominate our thoughts today; at a time when the top pop stars of our age are tackling big issues head on
column6: the insular nature of indie rock can seem antiquated at best and tone-deaf at worst. For those raised to believe in indie-rock's insurrectionary spirit
column7: it's easy to feel like you were sold a false bill of goods—a music that once seemed absolutely revolutionary now reeks of complacency and privilege.

column1: Jiwani is a unique position to reconcile this divide. He's of South Asian descent
column2: which makes him a minority amid a scene that's predominantly white even in a city as famously multicultural as Toronto. So you could say his relationship with indie rock is complicated
column3: and that tension comes to a head on Outer Heaven's delirious mid-album highlight
column4: ""Complaint Rock."" Jiwani gamely assumes the role of a slack motherfucker (""gimme gimme my gold star/ for not trying so hard"")
column5: before summing up his chosen vocation with a two-faced cry of ""I hate it!/ I want it!/ I need it! /I love it!"" That conflict is as much musical as lyrical: partway through
column6: the song's glass-smashing abandon gives way to a gentle waves of rippling
column7: psychedelic guitars—as if Jiwani suddenly slipped into a spa isolation-tank treatment mid-song—before it's violently thrust back into attack mode for a final blitz. And that push-pull structure presents a perfect microcosm of Greys' larger mission—as easy as it is to complain about the state of indie rock and check out of the conversation
column8: they feel compelled to stay in the game to get the job done right.

column1: On Outer Heaven

column4: he declared back on ""Use Your Delusion"")
column5: but Outer Heaven's searing
column6: slow-boiling salvo ""No Star"" sees him tackling matters of race in more explicit terms: ""Don't shoot/ I'm not the enemy
column7: he sings

column10: but often documented

column3: and with Fulber's touch

column6: and even so

column10: ” which has a groovier tempo—its fanciness makes for quite the contrast with Taylor ripping her soul apart. Commitment makes huge strides in its production
column11: but it's Taylor who really pushes it ahead of their past works.

column1: Metal and hardcore have been more spiritual influences on them than sonic. With “Shift of Dismay
column2: ” featuring guitar from Nails' Todd Jones

column4:
it's hard not to think of the cover of Ministry's 1990 live record In Case You Didn't Feel Like Showing Up. Will Commitment cross over to metalheads and hardcore kids who may normally be averse to electronics? It should.

column1: More justifiable causes for concern were Moreno’s claims that Deftones were making studio-intensive “heady

column1: Moreno perhaps sensed they’d exhausted their decades-tested “five guys in a room” format and Deftones entered the studio with no written material and no real timetable. Rather than sapping them of their immediacy or energy

column6: a layering of black-

column6: nasty

In 1980

column3: Indian music

On Fourth World they took their interests in texture and unusual structures and created music that was hard to pigeonhole. You could draw lines from certain genres to individual elements

column4: acoustic instruments sound like electronic ones

column7: the album features woodwinds and flute from Bitchin Bajas member Rob Frye along with Smith’s singing—are turned inside out and re-defined

column6: <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15881-hurry-up-were-dreaming/"" target=""_blank"">Hurry Up
column7: We’re Dreaming
column8: fell into the latter camp and—bolstered by its ubiquitous single “Midnight City”—transformed Anthony Gonzalez’s curious 15-year-old project into a soundtrack for Victoria’s Secret commercials and Tom Cruise sci-fi flicks. Surely this shift explains something about the new M83 album
column9: the fascinating and somewhat flummoxing Junk.

column1: Based on Junk’s downright goofy first single
column2: “Do It Try It
column3: ” there was some indication that Gonzalez might be pulling the classic move in which a musician takes a hard left in reacting against the thing that made them famous. Since Hurry Up
column4: We’re Dreaming was essentially the widescreen distillation of Gonzalez’s '80s neon dreams
column5: it would make sense if a defiant about-face toward all things synthed and saxophoned might be in store. But Junk is not that. Instead
column6: it’s as if Gonzalez is doggedly determined to mine those same nostalgic influences all over again
column7: just in much more arcane ways. As a result
column8: Junk is arguably the weirdest record he’s ever made
column9: but it’s far from the best.

column1: Those familiar with M83’s back catalog will hear familiar touchstones on Junk—lush synthscapes
column2: collaged narratives
column3: insouciantly spoken French—but anyone looking for another “Kim and Jessie” or “Teen Angst” will be at a loss. The big pop moments here are centered around massive synth lines that could have been lifted off a Pointer Sisters record (“Laser Gun
column4: ” “Road Blaster”)
column5: or in the case of “Go!
column6: ” a gloriously wanky guitar solo courtesy of '80s axe god Steve Vai. Drafting Vai for a song that sounds like a tribute to songs that Vai actually played on gives the record a meta quality not unlike when Lady Gaga enlisted Clarence Clemons for a sax solo on her Springsteen-worshipping “The Edge of Glory.” So although it’s an undeniable fist-pump of an anthem in a similar lane as “Midnight City
column7: ” “Go!” treads so close to total irony that it becomes difficult to swallow
column8: in the process revealing one of Junk’s most consistent flaws.

column1: This kind of pure homage to slick '70s and'’80s FM ephemera is so exacting in places
column2: it almost makes you wonder: What is the point of remaking this into something new? That small voice grows louder when you hear the album’s instrumental tracks (“Moon Crystal
column3: ” “Tension
column4: ” “The Wizard”)
column5: where Gonzalez proves he can perfectly replicate the kind of incidental muzak that played in JCPenney dressing rooms circa 1983
column6: or as the opening score of a “Too Close For Comfort” episode.

column1: That is not to say that Junk is without its charms. “Road Blaster” is a pristine '80s mega-single that never was—a slick hybrid of synthesized horns and Chic guitars that sounds as if it were made specifically to soundtrack a late-night joy ride around Hollywood in an old sports car. “For The Kids” is a saxophone-soaked ballad featuring Norwegian singer Susanne Sundfør
column2: and it’s thoroughly gorgeous—until a voice-over from what sounds to be a ghost-child kicks in.

column1: Gonzalez largely farms out vocal duties on Junk—like to Beck on “Time Wind
column2: ” a gently funky highlight from an imagined movie soundtrack—but the album’s best tracks feature his own voice. “Atlantique Sud” is a duet with Mai Lan Chapiron in which she and Gonzalez purr at each other in French
column3: while “Solitude” features Gonzalez singing against a backdrop of strings that swell dramatically before eventually overpowering the song completely. The album closes with “Sunday Night 1987”—a song that serves as a tribute to the late Julia Brightly
column4: a sound engineer with whom M83 had a long and devoted working relationship. Building on a somber piano melody reminiscent of Harold Budd and Cocteau Twin’s The Moon and the Melodies
column5: “Sunday Night 1987” is Junk’s most stunning song
column6: and the one that most resembles early M83 albums. It’s also the only track on Junk that doesn’t sound like a showy exercise in a defunct style
column7: though ending with a Stevie Wonder-esque harmonica solo would come close if it didn’t provide an appropriately mournful final note.

column1: It seems impossible that
column2: seven albums in
column3: Gonzalez doesn’t appreciate the possibly divisive nature of this album. You don’t call a record Junk and grace its cover with a couple of googly-eyed 21st-century Fry Kids without having some inkling that you are taking the piss. In the album’s press materials
column4: Gonzalez is quoted as saying
column5: “I wanted to make what I call an ‘organized mess’—a collection of songs that aren’t made to live with each other
column6: yet somehow work together.” It’s a commendable idea and one that almost works—collecting these various bits of cultural detritus and refashioning them into something that is at once compelling and potentially disposable. In the end
column7: though
column8: it’s that feeling of disposability that makes the album’s title resonate more pointedly in the wrong way.

column1: CORRECTION: An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated that Hurry Up
column2:
We're Dreaming was released in 2014. It came out in 2011.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23015/homepage_large.89e47443.jpg|Afterlife|31089.0|DJ Rashad|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Teklife']|2016-04-11 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:48:02.694106|"

Posthumous art is always going to be a tad controversial. At its worst it feels like a tabloid-style ransacking of an archive. At its best it's a thoughtful and prodding collecting of memories—the ultimate memorial to a life in art. Most of the time it falls somewhere in the middle. We turn to the rough drafts of greats because they might offer hints of the magnum opus always on the horizon. And without the presence and guiding hand of the art’s creator
column2: quality rests solely in the skill of curation and editing.

column1: The 26th of this month will mark the two-year anniversary of Rashad Harden’s (DJ Rashad) passing
column2: and in the 730 days since
column3: the pulse of his legacy remains strong. Fifteen of Rashad’s previously unreleased collaborations have been compiled as Afterlife. The editors of the collection intelligently admit a fallibility in the face of the materials
column4: and even offer a tantalizing hint of things still lurking in the vault
column5: saying ""it would be impossible to present a definitive collection of DJ Rashad's music"" and that ""many many classics will remain unreleased for ever."" And like all posthumous art
column6: Afterlife raises a very hard question: Does the trove of tracks significantly affect the ways we evaluate and interpret Rashad’s legacy?

column1: In short
column2: the answer is no
column3: and the fifteen songs in Afterlife all feel incomplete in some way or another. They match the mood and fervor you want from a Rashad track quite often
column4: but it is hard to ignore their skeletal and fragmentary nature. Many of the songs feel like sonic bridges between tracks in a DJ set; they can ferry one moment to the next
column5: but seem to lack the legs to stand on their own. And as befits an album cobbled together from unfinished stuff
column6: you can see the stitching exposed. It doesn't have the same complete narrative push of Double Cup
column7: the concision of the Rollin’ EP. In composition it is closer to Rashad’s Just a Taste
column8: Vol. One
column9: a survey of work rather than an album perhaps.

column1: Not to say that there aren’t highlights throughout. The opener
column2: ""Roll Up that Loud"" is classic Rashad
column3: ebullient from start to finish. It has the inimitable quality of a Rube Goldberg machine
column4: with all the moving parts of the track whizzing back and forth. It's hard to know where artistic intentions and listener interpretations begin with posthumous work
column5: but large chunks of this project reflect a surprising melancholy. This same feeling in Rashad’s work was most present in the Rollin’ EP
column6: where high-speed funkiness was blended with a languorous mood. ""Oh God
column7: one of the most simple songs here
column8: is composed of a lone synth arpeggio and gentle drum patterning
column9: and its tone is as plaintive as 160 BPM music can get. Rashad’s collaboration with DJ Paypal
column10: ""Do U Wanna B Mine
column11: meanwhile
column12: counts as one of the odder songs Rashad had worked on. The melding of their two musical personalities leads into something that surprisingly sounds like earnest chiptune.

column1: What Afterlife succeeds in above all is capturing the spirit of familial connection and experimentation integral to the Teklife crew. Teklife has always been a family affair. Not a single release from the collective has existed without collaboration. What made them so vital on stage and across blistering tracks was the ethic of teamwork. In all the times I’ve seen Rashad and the extended Teklife crew
column2: I was witness to the exuberance of familial genius. The mixer was their hearth and they all took turns stoking the fire
column3: whispering into each other’s ears
column4:
grinning because they all knew what five minutes into the future looked like: a mass of writhing bodies losing their shit in the face of something nearly ineffable. It was something I endlessly appreciated as a seventeen-year-old who had never even heard the whisper of a synth or the bump of a drum machine. To discover Teklife and Rashad then felt like walking across a mile of hot coals—throttled by the sheer force of realization at the other end.

Forming in 2003
column2: Frightened Rabbit established their reputation with ramshackle anthems of heartbreak and hangovers that presented frontman Scott Hutchison as self-loathing
column3: self-destructive
column4: but ultimately sympathetic. By 2010
column5: success and expanding ambition started to strain against their underdog appeal. That tension was projected onto the anxious
column6: thickly overdubbed The Winter of Mixed Drinks. Pedestrian Verse arrived three years later
column7: an album that isn’t widely considered their best
column8: but it's definitive in its own way. It's the one that said “this is who we are going forward”: a major-label band that plays 2000-3000 cap rooms. Shortly thereafter
column9: Hutchison moved to Los Angeles with his girlfriend. Sub in High Violet and Trouble Will Find Me for their respective years
column10: and this is basically the same exact career trajectory as the National
column11: so it’s only natural that the two bands go from sharing tour bills and a producer (Peter Katis) to sharing a studio—and so with Aaron Dessner behind the boards
column12: Painting of a Panic Attack is more a sensible repositioning than a reinvention.

column1: “Death Dream” immediately extinguishes any hope that Frightened Rabbit might return to the scrappy charms of Sing the Greys or The Midnight Organ Fight. He often plays the religious skeptic in his lyrics
column2: but Hutchison sure thinks piano sounds heavenly in a church; it’s hard not to think of “Fake Empire” just from the mere tone of the reverberant chord that opens “Death Dream.” By the time the progression begins to settle
column3: it’s pretty much impossible to not hum “stay out...super late…tonight
column4: ” as the “Fake Empire” melody fits almost exactly. While it boasts Hutchison’s most vivid and morbid poetry yet
column5: “Death Dreams” doesn’t lift off
column6: floating more towards the rafters like a errant balloon. So it makes for a curious opener
column7: though it’s an accurate preview of yet another instance where Dessner’s charges end up sounding like his main band.

column1: This can work for a newer act that’s trying to hit a similar emotional tenor to the National. On their respective sophomore LPs
column2: Local Natives and Sharon Van Etten followed raw debuts by contrasting Dessner’s sumptuous
column3: solemn orchestration with simmering angst
column4: the sound of people trying their best not to crack up in public. A band less willing to exert their own personality ends up with something like Wilder Mind. Painting is somewhere in between; Dessner helps add a silvery stylization to Frightened Rabbit’s jittery indie-folk on “Break
column5: ” while late-album ballads “400 Bones” and “Die Like a Rich Boy” cover Hutchison’s barstool laments with Rag & Bone sympathy. The choral burst of “Get Out” is jarring in a strictly musical sense
column6: more so if you once viewed Frightened Rabbit as an alternative to post-Britpop Patsavas-core like Snow Patrol and Travis. But ""Grey’s Anatomy"" is still chugging along and thus will need stadium-ready surges from a bearded man with a burly voice expressing an all-purpose longing about a flawed girl that won’t get out of his heart.

column1: They’re both effective
column2: as formula should be
column3: reliant on devices that become cliches only within their established parameters. After The Midnight Organ Fight
column4: Hutchison joked that he couldn’t make another break-up record because he hadn’t had one that year. But it seems like he’s recognized that fans rely on Frightened Rabbit for a specific kind of Scottish miserablism
column5: which Painting of a Panic Attack delivers with consistency if not conviction. They don’t strike me as cynical
column6: so I’d hate to use the word “pandering” for the way uber-Frightened Rabbit laments “Blood Under the Bridge
column7: ” “An Otherwise Disappointing Life
column8: ” and “Woke Up Hurting” play towards expectations. But it’s really difficult to do otherwise after Hutchison’s expected recriminations of god
column9: booze
column10: and breakups tell you nothing the titles didn’t already
column11: and the heavy-handed rhyming of “I Wish I Was Sober” only enhances the suspicion that it’s concept-driven exercise rather than an expression of actual emotion.

column1: Yet
column2: the best Frightened Rabbit songs aren’t entirely defined by their despondance or desperation. What’s missing from Panic is some kind of levity or the cutting humor that once personalized Hutchison’s self-loathing. It’s admittedly impossible to gauge the legitimacy of Hutchison’s emotions; like the National
column3: maybe Frightened Rabbit have just gotten too good at their formula for it to not seem self-aware. And too often
column4:
the title of Painting of a Panic Attack serves as an unintentional reminder of the way Hutchison comes across: like a television version of a person with a broken heart.

K. Michelle always entertains through the surprising experimentations in her music

column7: sing-song pop
column8: rap
column9: and further out sounds
column10: Michelle makes the best argument for herself as artist

column12: ” are
column13: interestingly

column10: cinematic strings and chewable
column11: universal lyrics
column12: the track should (and hopefully) does translate to audiences who might not have heard of K. Michelle outside of ""Love & Hip Hop: Atlanta"" and ""Love & Hip Hop: New York
column13: or even at all. It is that good.

column1: Like on “If It Ain’t it Love

column3: the track is a too-short and perfect groove (it clocks in under two minutes) featuring the vocalist flexing her rap skills. “Who the fuck told y’all hoes to open up … I’m coming straight from the gut

Michelle shines. She no longer asks that you take her seriously. Instead she demands it and rightfully so. It's now a matter as to whether or not audiences will come onboard. Hopefully they will.

While interviewing Dirty Projectors for a profile in 2009—on the cusp of the release of Bitte Orca and their Malian guitar-meets-Mariah hit “Stillness Is the Move”—band leader Dave Longstreth enthused over a Saharan guitarist on the Sublime Frequencies label who went by the name Bombino. In the last six years
column2: the Tuareg artist has continued to make inroads in the West
column3: touring and recording Stateside
column4: and his 2013 album Nomad found him in the studio with the Black Keys’ Dan Auerbach. And now
column5: Longstreth’s early admiration has come full circle
column6: as he was tapped to record Bombino’s latest
column7: Azel
column8: in upstate New York. The resulting record presents the guitarist in a lucid
column9: unadorned light.

column1: There’s no need to add too much to Bombino’s desert blues—his unassuming and astonishing playing speaks volumes on its own. Seeing him live
column2: his left hand is deceptively fast
column3: flicking off the strings and lighting upon extra notes that other players can’t quite hit. Much like fellow Tichumaren players Tinariwen
column4: Bombino’s acumen blends techniques derived from ngoni (a traditional lute)
column5: the imzad (a one-stringed bow instrument)
column6: and the amplified guitar of Hendrix and Santana.

column1: Azel isn’t so different from his unofficial first album for Sublime Frequencies
column2: 2009’s Guitars From Agadez Vol. 2
column3: which was recorded in his home country of Niger and intimate enough to capture the sounds of camels on one side and ragged stomping on the other. His gentleness comes through on “Igmayagh Dum (My Lover)
column4: ” built from handclaps
column5: thumped guitar body
column6: and a nimble melody
column7: with Bombino’s lines of love—sung in Tamasheq—delivered in a gentle purr. Meanwhile
column8: his electric guitar prickles and the drums careen on “Timidiwa (Friendship).” There is one new wrinkle
column9: though: a kind of fusion with reggae. That might sound corny on paper
column10: but Bombino and his group keep it all low-key
column11: and the sounds soon assimilate. Album centerpiece “Iyat Ninhay / Jaguar (A Great Desert I Saw)” is driven by a lilting bassline that leads into an incandescent solo from Bombino as trilling zaghrouta voices punctuate the ecstasy of the moment.

column1: But for all the guitar pyrotechnics
column2: Western production
column3: and reggae infusions
column4: Azel never sounds like anything other than a sublime iteration of desert blues. Bombino has not pivoted towards Western music
column5: as he still sings about the issues of his homeland in his native tongue. Hushed closer “Naqqim Dagh Timshar (We Are Left in This Abandoned Place)” tells of the plight of his people with a lines that translate to: “We sit in an abandoned place/ Everyone has left us/ The world has evolved/ And we’ve been abandoned.” Even with Bombino increasingly gaining exposure in America
column6:
lyrics like those remind us that his music continually speaks for those that would otherwise be unheard back home.

When Parquet Courts debuted in 2011 with the supremely bratty American Specialties cassette—its Dada-esque cover art a repurposed Chinese takeout menu—Andrew Savage
column2: who is also a visual artist
column3: presented the facts unsentimentally. ""Facebook pages/ Boring boring!/ Rock'n'roll has got me snoring
column4: he gasped over a skeleton of atonal guitar-noise
column5: ultimately landing upon the most sacred of conclusions: ""Music! Matters! More than ever! Free your brain and conform never!"" Lucky for us
column6: Parquet Courts have spent the past five years heeding their own call.

column1: With Human Performance
column2: their third proper album and first for London's legendary Rough Trade Records
column3: Parquet Courts offer a fine testament to rock's continued power and relevance. They might mine the past for feedback and eccentricities
column4: but their astute lyrics tackle the present head-on—co-songwriters Savage and Austin Brown write as if their songs might have real-world consequences. Parquet Courts emerged at a good time
column5: when we yearn for something slightly more intellectual and aware and less about vibe—a longing that has spread into all areas of music culture. While not explicitly political
column6: Parquet Courts are definitely a thinking band
column7: and a critical one
column8: which is equally important when the world is falling apart. Perhaps some of this sharpness comes from their roots in the DIY punk and hardcore underground with their previous bands
column9: including Wiccans and the criminally overlooked Teenage Cool Kids.

column1: At its best
column2: Human Performance is Parquet Courts in a mellower
column3: heart-stopping Velvet Underground mode
column4: but it is also at turns upbeat and funny
column5: sensitive and odd. Compositionally
column6: these are the most dynamic Parquet Courts songs yet. You could no longer brush these guys off as mere Modern Lovers rip-offs
column7: as you might have around 2012's clangoring
column8: whip-smart Light Up Gold. Human Performance presents a more earnest
column9: emotional side of the band. The record's bare
column10: stunning closer ""It's Gonna Happen
column11: penned by bassist Sean Yeaton and sung by Savage
column12: recalls the heart-wrenching minimalism of Lou Reed's starry 2000 ballad ""Turning Time Around."" And it's kind of touching to hear Brown—author of such genius dispatches as ""Socrates died in the fucking gutter!""—sing a simple
column13: open love song like the wistful road ballad ""Steady On My Mind.""

column1: As ever
column2: the fever-pitch of New York life is alive and fast-walking within these songs—zig-zagging the concrete to blaze past all the downward-gazing multitaskers too busy texting to get on where they're going. Human Performance captures the humor and horror of New York in 2016
column3: alive with post-Cagean street noise
column4: with a faster-louder Ramonic ideal
column5: with the erratic rhythm of train delays
column6: a bus that never shows up
column7: or the ""skull-shaking cadence of the J train rolls."" Something about Parquet Courts' intense-yet-witty existential energy reminds me of the legendary NYC tour-guide-cum-philosopher Speed Levitch (immortalized in '90s doc The Cruise)
column8: who has long approached New York as if the city itself were an epic poem.

column1: The sour rattle of Human Performance's absurd and charmingly cartoonish opener ""Dust"" juxtaposes so many elements—jaunty piano riffs
column2: discordant car honks
column3: sweet organs—that you could imagine it soundtracking the opening sequence to a demented musical. ""Dust is everywhere/ Sweep
column4: Brown taunts on loop
column5: and it is not a stretch to hear the decrepitude as a metaphor for the finely-ground wreckage of Western civilization that we have all inherited. There is dread implied
column6: but ""Dust"" mostly makes you laugh. Parquet Courts' take on New York life grows legitimately and rightfully severe on ""Two Dead Cops
column7: a sobering and compact punk song that is literally about two cops who were murdered in Savage's Bed-Stuy neighborhood.

column1: There are songs on Human Performance that defy logic; they should not work and yet somehow
column2: they do. <span class=""s1"">On the trudging
column3: visceral centerpiece ""Captive of the Sun
column4: the Beaumont
column5: Tx.-bred Brown's rhythmic delivery is basically rapping. (He has written at length about his intense personal connection to the ""outsider art"" that is Houston rap.) Earlier
column6: Sean Yeaton voices some city-fueled discontent with the stream-of-conscious curiosity ""I Was Just Here."" It takes on a classic New York dilemma—a jarring elegy for a Chinese restaurant that has recently closed much to his surprise and chagrin. ""You look so nice/ Chinese fried rice/ Wouldn't you know/ That place just closed
column7: the band laments with an alien Devo affect
column8: in turn evoking the beloved underground punk-band-of-the-moment
column9: Indiana's Coneheads.

column1: The latent weirdness of ""I Was Just Here"" reminds me of the time Savage wearily shouted-out the true freaks of Zappa's backing band
column2: the Mothers of Invention
column3: in a cheeky Teenage Cool Kids song called ""Beg to Differ."" In fact
column4: there are several moments on Human Performance that recall Teenage Cool Kids' 2011 cult hit Denton After Sunset (in which Savage romanticized Texas in a way to rival John Darnielle). In some of Human Performance's best songs—like ""Berlin Got Blurry
column5: with its winding Spaghetti Western riff and wandering spirit—there's a bright directness he hasn't shown since back then. Denton After Sunset was a love letter of sorts to the place Savage came from; it showed his adept understanding of the evocative power of geography
column6: something he's carried into his New York songbook.

column1: Alongside the likes of Courtney Barnett and Sadie Dupuis
column2: Savage remains one of the best rock lyricists of his generation. In the past
column3: he has written philosophical punk songs about cats
column4: candy
column5: and existence; about Stalinist art and opera. Here
column6: he cuts inward
column7: clawing further into his own soul. It's in the arresting one-two punch of ""Human Performance"" and ""Outside"" that Savage's writing shines most elegantly. These are break-up songs
column8: for sure
column9: but sometimes it's hard to tell if Savage is breaking up with a lover or with himself. At the core of the soulful ""Human Performance"" is a difficult
column10: messy question: <i>Am I good person
column11: or am I fooling everyone
column12: including myself? Savage's tender ruminations on love and loneliness are deeply self-critical: ""I told you I loved you/ Did I even deserve it? When you returned it
column13: he croons
column14: sounding like Dylan circa Nashville Skyline. The layered feel of the track's chorus reminds me of the ""multi-latch gating"" technique that Tony Visconti used to produce ""Heroes""—each time Savage screams
column15: the echoes sound further away
column16: more unhinged and desperate
column17: tempered by lovely organ lines and jazzy drum patterns.

column1: The sub-two-minute ""Outside"" follows
column2: and it is the sunniest
column3: snappiest Parquet Courts tune ever—a song about admission
column4: about accepting your flaws and finding peace. For such a short song it is impossibly beautiful. ""Dear everything I've harmed/ My fault lies on my tongue/ And I take it holy as a last rite
column5: Savage sings
column6: his voice shining with palpable abandon and relief
column7: a kind you only get from telling the truth. ""Outside"" is ultimately about turning honesty and imperfection into virtues
column8: and that purity is doubled by its indelible melody. Little details
column9: like a lopsided beat and an endearing note sung flat
column10: only serve to deepen it.

column1: Human Performance is a bracing snapshot of a band on a roll. As punk turns 40 on both sides of the Atlantic this year
column2: it's fitting that this record is out on Rough Trade—that era's arty
column3: leftist wing of outsiders-among-outsiders. You'd be hard pressed to find a contemporary rock band honoring the classic Rough Trade legacy as well as Parquet Courts
column4: in both sound and spirit
column5: while doing something audacious and new. In a sense
column6: they even revive Rough Trade's O.G. connection to eccentric Texas psych-rock
column7: from back when conceptual artist Mayo Thompson of the Red Krayola was the label's heady spokesperson
column8: producing crucial records by the Raincoats and the Fall
column9: and collaborating with members of Pere Ubu and Swell Maps. Parquet Courts deserve to be discussed within this lineage. Intelligence is addictive
column10: and there is accordingly a quiet mania to Parquet Courts fandom that matches that of their forebears. On Human Performance
column11: Parquet Courts send a generation-skewing message that avails not
column12:
time nor place: it is cool to really think.

"|21597.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21597-human-performance/|8.4|Jenn Pelly

Mogwai's latest full-length is technically a soundtrack: It comprises reworked material from their musical contributions to last year’s BBC 4 documentary Storyville - Atomic: Living in Dread and Promise
column3: a chronological history of nuclear disaster (and innovation) from Hiroshima onward. However
column4: unlike the previous works the Scottish post-rock innovators have scored (Zidane: A 21st Century Portrait
column5: The Fountain
column6: and ""Les Revenants"") the source material doesn’t have a clear-cut narrative. With no outside narration or interviews to provide context to the film's archival cortège (save a series of statistics at the conclusion)
column7: director Mark Cousins takes a bold risk and assumes the audience's familiarity with everything mentioned in ""We Didn't Start the Fire."" It's more an obtuse high-art music video than it is a traditional documentary. Atomic
column8: on the other hand
column9: is anything but esoteric. Despite its minimalistic approach
column10: the album poignantly illustrates the binary oppositions that cropped up in Hiroshima’s wake: life and death
column11: hope and fear
column12: war and peace
column13: atomic and organic.

column1: Mogwai have always thrived on textural contrast: the fission of twangy strings against somber snare hits
column2: the disintegration of brittle synthesizers beneath a tide of feedback
column3: a violin crying out in silence. In keeping with the film’s themes
column4: several tracks on Atomic sound corrupted. Beneath the uplifting fanfare of opening track ""Ether
column5: for instance
column6: one can hear a faint
column7: dull drone
column8: as though the band recorded the track on nuked recording equipment. The unsettling murmur continues throughout the entire record
column9: and even in moments of rare purity—such as the tender duet of guitars and violin on ""Are You A Dancer?""—the mechanical roar is never far behind.

column1: The majority of the album distances itself from rock and sticks to a doom-ridden breed of new-wave. ""SCRAM"" sees the group sequencing a stream of staggered synth lines into hypnotic orbit
column2: like a Cold War Calder mobile
column3: while ""Weak Force"" resembles a piano ballad performed by a forlorn android. The record’s final track
column4: ""Fat Man
column5: is the most methodical and magnificent by far. The band take a lone
column6: unassuming piano riff and bombard it with sharp guitar tones
column7: the corruption further catalyzed with steadily-increasing doses of the aforementioned aural radioactivity; there’s a cinematic swell
column8: and then... silence.

column1: Considering the conditions of Atomic's conception
column2: the album’s departure from the band’s preceding full-length
column3: 2014’s Rave Tapes
column4: shouldn’t come as a surprise. Sure
column5: fans expecting a Stuart Braithwaite shred-fest may find the LP a disappointment. But like all good concept albums (and soundtracks)
column6: Atomic’s sole allegiance is to its subject. And when you’re dealing with the pinnacle of human innovation and the symbol of death
column7:
that subject deserves to take center stage.

You know the story by now: Kendrick Lamar paired up with a few jazz musicians and created some game-changing rap music. The results were To Pimp a Butterfly and untitled and unmastered.
column3: both expansive and intricate
column4: scanning the vast spectrum of Black art. Multi-instrumentalist Terrace Martin was a binding agent for both albums: He co-produced what might be untitled’s best track—“untitled 05”—playing saxophone and keys
column5: and his name appeared several times in Butterfly’s liner notes
column6: credited for producing “For Free? (Interlude)” and adding elements to many other album tracks. (He produced “Real” on Lamar’s <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17253-good-kid-maad-city/"">good kid
column7: m.A.A.d. city as well.) Along with Sounwave
column8: bassist Thundercat
column9: keyboardist Robert Glasper and saxophonist Kamasi Washington
column10: Martin played a big role in shaping Butterfly’s atmospheric approach
column11: the way it spread out in different directions without losing focus. Though it addressed societal despair and Lamar’s own angst
column12: Butterfly was also a love letter to Compton and the West Coast in general
column13: its wide-open funk and soul a direct reflection of Cali’s pastoral grooves.

column1: Martin takes a similar path on Velvet Portraits
column2: which pulls in R&B and G-funk while paying homage to his native Los Angeles. The multifaceted ethos has become useful for the composer
column3: whose music never stays in the same place for too long
column4: while maintaining its breezy spirit. Martin has crafted instrumentals for Snoop
column5: Kurupt and Murs over the years
column6: and his debut studio album
column7: 2013’s 3ChordFold
column8: mixed live instruments and studio beats with refreshing results. In an interview with The Fader
column9: Martin said Velvet Portraits was headed a different way until a mix of family emergencies encouraged him to take another tack. “We went through all these things and it made me want to pull closer with myself
column10: and it really made me want to pull closer with God
column11: ” he said at the time. That’s why Velvet feels remarkably scenic
column12: moving methodically and conjuring pastoral scenes. Technically
column13: this is jazz
column14: but the tag is almost a disservice here: Sure it has some of the genre’s traditional aspects—the improvised nature of “Curly Martin” and the Sérgio Mendes aesthetic of “Bromali” are examples—but the album registers as something deeper without a clear definition. This is jazz the way Glasper is jazz
column15: the way Bitches Brew is a jazz record: Martin mixes pieces of the genre with others
column16: setting a vibe that’s uniquely his.

column1: Velvet Portraits is full of subtle shifts that make the album tough to pin down
column2: even if the individual tracks are easily deciphered at first glance. Songs like “Push” and “Patiently Waiting” have pronounced gospel influences—the former an upbeat revival tune; the latter reminiscent of the church-soul hybrids Ray Charles used to make. Velvet Portraits is decidedly nostalgic in that regard
column3: and as it plays
column4: you sense Martin’s allegiance to old-school music and the way it made him feel. It’s in the trunk-rattling bounce of  “Turkey Taco” and the Quiet Storm ambience of “Never Enough.” On “Think of You
column5: ” especially
column6: singer Rose Gold salutes soul icons Curtis Mayfield and Marvin Gaye while Kamasi’s sax simmers in the background.

column1: In many ways
column2: Velvet Portraits is Butterfly’s companion piece
column3: harboring the same voluminous reach while conveying uplifting messages of love and inclusiveness
column4: resting in the heart of southern California. Where Martin’s previous work was more energetic
column5: Velvet seems far more relaxed
column6: as if he’s found a creative lane and is fully comfortable in it. The album doesn’t hit as hard as the producer’s other offerings
column7: but on purpose
column8: Velvet Portraits is a soft touch that slowly unfolds over time
column9: best heard under bright skies
column10: on spring and summer evenings with the car windows down. It all culminates on ""Mortal Man
column11: the album's epic closer
column12: which takes from Butterfly's closer of the same name. Sprawling almost 12 minutes
column13: Martin's version is theatrical
column14: full of synthesized vocals and sporadic horns. Light keys bubble to the surface
column15:
bringing the LP to a radiant conclusion. It doesn’t get more L.A. than that.

The third album by Tacocat starts with a clean garage-rock tribute to discerning ""X-Files"" lead ""Dana Katherine Scully."" It's typical for the Seattle four-piece
column2: who mix songs about their love of pop culture—they just did the theme to the ""Powerpuff Girls"" reboot—with tirades about periods
column3: pervs
column4: and the patriarchy. Released in 2014
column5: Tacocat's NVM riffed on IM slang for ""never mind
column6: a reference to the city's most famous sons
column7: and essentially mocked how far we'd veered from Kurt Cobain's future-female ideals. Its vibrant spirit ran on the kind of energy you'd only otherwise get from chugging a giant sports drink before egging someone's house.

column1: Lost Time (another ""X-Files"" reference) delves into some of the same subject matter. ""FDP"" is an SOS from the first day of lead singer Emily Nokes' period
column2: ""Plan A
column3: Plan B"" mocks the wrongheaded GOP idea that women use the morning-after pill as contraceptive
column4: and ""Talk"" sounds a little like fellow Pacific Northwester Laura Veirs reincarnated as a frustrated millennial
column5: wishing she and her friends would ditch their iPhones for living room dance parties. ""Men Explain Things to Me"" takes its name from the Rebecca Solnit essay that popularized the term ""mansplaining."" ""Though I know all about the words you're spitting out
column6: the floor is yours without a doubt
column7: Nokes sings
column8: her typically sharp tongue cutting some blowhard down to size.

column1: They also widen the net
column2: in terms of inspiration. ""I Love Seattle"" references ""The Really Big One
column3: a New Yorker article about the earthquake that will destroy much of the coastal Northwest. There's nowhere else they'd rather be
column4: but admit
column5: ""at least no-one's pretending like that would even be bad."" The highlight of Lost Time is ""I Hate the Weekend
column6: which explains their ambivalence about Seattle falling into the Pacific. In a melody Jenny Lewis wouldn't be ashamed to stick on her recent records
column7: Nokes paints an incisive portrait of how tech bros haven't just whitewashed the city's thriving culture (""paint the rainbow shades of beige"")
column8: but terrorize the streets when they ""cut loose"" at weekends. ""Got a hall pass from your job just to act like a fucking slob
column9: they sing
column10: filled with catchy disdain.

column1: And that kind of fire is what Lost Time sorely needs more of. There's no question that many of Lost Time's lyrics are funny
column2: but the attitude that fueled NVM feels crushed. In both the vocal delivery and the driving guitars
column3: the vibe is damper
column4: the color somewhat drained. Sometimes the fruit hangs a little low: ""The Internet"" is a straight-strummer about trolls. With that in mind
column5: it's unsurprising that the peppier songs here are the ones about the things you do for pleasure and pleasure alone. Lost Time's most inventive song
column6: ""Horse Grrls
column7: is a fully enthused stop-start shredder about equestrian obsessives: ""They know the different breeds of all their favorite steeds!"" And ""Night Swimming
column8: too
column9: is lovely—a splashy
column10: beatific jam about breaking into a lake at night
column11: where the only rule is
column12: ""You can bring a boombox
column13: but you can't play R.E.M."" The final song
column14: ""Leisure Bees
column15: is ambitious and engaging
column16: shifting between Beach Boys-indebted harmonies
column17: girl-group coos
column18: and shaggy nostalgic jams.

column1: It makes sense that the record starts with an ode to Scully
column2: whose artful eye-rolls have become the internet's go-to meme in the face of the men who plague your @-replies. Tacocat have always approached feminism from a point of fun rather than anger
column3: but inevitably
column4: when bros keep bro-ing and your city's falling apart
column5: and nothing ever seems to change
column6: it's gonna get hard to see the funny side. It feels like perpetuating all that bullshit to even call them on it: Ugh
column7:
I can't believe you can no longer laugh at these things for my entertainment. They sound as weary as anyone would.
