The music of ’70s Swedish group Träd
column3: Gräs och Stenar (Trees
column4: Grass
column5: and Stones) emerged from a chemical reaction between two basic elements: rock'n'roll and Terry Riley. The latter influence came first: when Riley visited Stockholm in the mid 60’s to perform his groundbreaking In C
column6: it blew the mind of an art-school student named Bo Anders Persson. Inspired by Riley’s repetitive
column7: long-form minimalism
column8: Persson experimented with drones and tape manipulations
column9: eventually bringing those ideas to a group he formed with fellow classmates called Pärson Sound.

column1: It turned out Persson and his comrades were as interested in rock and roll as they were in the avant-garde. As they evolved through lineups and band names
column2: that interest escalated. Morphing into Träd
column3: Gräs och Stenar  in 1969
column4: they became a full-fledged rock band
column5: with most of the artier experimentation stripped away in favor of lengthy
column6: guitar-heavy jams. But the group’s extended
column7: open-ended playing still carried the spirit of Riley’s “all-night flights.” Their songs might not have sounded like In C
column8: but they could be just as expansive
column9: indeterminant
column10: and mind-blowing.

column1: That expansiveness is essential to Träd
column2: Gräs och Stenar’s magic. Though their sky-seeking grooves also work in small doses
column3: they usually need lots of time and space to fully explore and develop their ideas. In that sense
column4: this new set of reissues is the best way so far to experience their work. Two live releases from the early 70’s have been expanded into double albums
column5: while a third double album comprises previously-unreleased live material rescued from the attic of band member Jakob Sjöholm. In its biggest version—a six LP box set plus digital download— Anthology’s series offers nearly five hours of music in total
column6: with 12 of the 27 tracks lasting over 10 minutes.

column1: Those numbers may seem like a formula for tedium
column2: but Träd
column3: Gräs och Stenar’s music is never a slog. It’s usually easy to enter
column4: and often downright breezy and relaxed. The band was confident enough not to force epiphanies
column5: trusting that euphoria could grow from steady
column6: upbeat swing. This has led some to call them Sweden’s Grateful Dead
column7: but Träd
column8: Gräs och Stenar were more free-form
column9: and more interested in sonic chaos. In that way
column10: along with their status as communal outsiders
column11: they were more like Father Yod’s primitive psych-rock pioneers YaHoWha 13. The latter’s delirious 3am trips share an aura with the Träd
column12: Gräs och Stenar songs that feature raw
column13: seemingly-possessed singing and chanting.

column1: One crucial difference between Träd
column2: Gräs och Stenar and other communal collectives of the time (YaHoWha 13
column3: Captain Beefheart and the Magic Band
column4: the Sun Ra Arkestra) was their leaderless nature. With no particular member in charge
column5: their music has a refreshing lack of ego; it feels like the only thing steering the ship is the momentum created by playing together. Though some guitar parts resemble solos
column6: they rarely dominate. All the riffs merge into a mutli-colored swirl
column7: and the band digs into each repetition like coal miners chipping away in unison. Over 40 years later
column8: this all-for-one approach still resonates in the far-flung forays of collectives such as No-Neck Blues Band
column9: Bardo Pond
column10: Acid Mothers Temple
column11: and Eternal Tapestry.

column1: Since such emergent music is all about the moment
column2: Träd
column3: Gräs och Stenar’s best work came in live performance. Though they debuted with a self-titled 1970 studio album
column4: their subsequent two live records cemented their legend. The music on 1971’s Djungelns Lag (The Law of the Jungle) and 1972’s Mors Mors (Hi
column5: How Are You?) was captured in locales as diverse as an airfield
column6: an autonomous Denmark commune
column7: and a meadow next to the Vindeln river. Some tunes have studio-level clarity
column8: revealing acoustic strums
column9: rhythmic handclaps
column10: and vocal chatter
column11: while others are as murky as bootlegs. Both of those styles fit the band’s vibe
column12: which could be simultaneously precise and unruly
column13: bold and mysterious. That vibe is strongest on Djungelns Lag
column14: which feels as open and diverse as the universe
column15: and as big too (see the consistently-compelling
column16: 34-minute “Amithaba In Kommer Gösta”). But Mors Mors is nearly as good
column17: rhyming shorter
column18: poppier gems with masterful extended journeys.

column1: The unreleased material Anthology has collected on Kom Tillsammans (Come Together) comes from the same 1972 recordings as Mors Mors
column2: and works in similar ways. As a whole it’s not as compelling as either preceding album
column3: but it does show how deftly Träd
column4: Gräs och Stenar could continually reinvent themselves. Take their covers of the Rolling Stones’ “The Last Time”: on Mors Mors
column5: they build a relaxed riff into something monumental over nine minutes. On Kom Tillsammans
column6: they completely rethink their attack
column7: grafting in a riff from the Stones’ “Jumpin’ Jack Flash” and doubling the length to 17 minutes without losing a second of interest.

column1: It’s hard to think of many bands who could imagine such interpretations
column2: and this eternal openness might be Träd
column3: Gräs och Stenar’s most enduring legacy. There’s a political aspect to it too; as band member Torbjörn Abelli put it in liner notes
column4: “our music was a sort of ritualistic battle cry
column5: a call for people to be free
column6: follow their own rhythm
column7: their own harmony.” Yet that cry would be unconvincing if the results weren’t inspiring. Träd
column8: Gräs och Stenar delivered on the promise of freedom
column9:
finding moments that couldn’t be achieved by any other means.

column1: Those numbers may seem like a formula for tedium
column2: but Träd
column3: Gräs och Stenar’s music is never a slog. It’s usually easy to enter
column4: and often downright breezy and relaxed. The band was confident enough not to force epiphanies
column5: trusting that euphoria could grow from steady
column6: upbeat swing. This has led some to call them Sweden’s Grateful Dead
column7: but Träd
column8: Gräs och Stenar were more free-form
column9: and more interested in sonic chaos. In that way
column10: along with their status as communal outsiders
column11: they were more like Father Yod’s primitive psych-rock pioneers YaHoWha 13. The latter’s delirious 3am trips share an aura with the Träd
column12: Gräs och Stenar songs that feature raw
column13: seemingly-possessed singing and chanting.

column1: One crucial difference between Träd
column2: Gräs och Stenar and other communal collectives of the time (YaHoWha 13
column3: Captain Beefheart and the Magic Band
column4: the Sun Ra Arkestra) was their leaderless nature. With no particular member in charge
column5: their music has a refreshing lack of ego; it feels like the only thing steering the ship is the momentum created by playing together. Though some guitar parts resemble solos
column6: they rarely dominate. All the riffs merge into a mutli-colored swirl
column7: and the band digs into each repetition like coal miners chipping away in unison. Over 40 years later
column8: this all-for-one approach still resonates in the far-flung forays of collectives such as No-Neck Blues Band
column9: Bardo Pond
column10: Acid Mothers Temple
column11: and Eternal Tapestry.

column1: Since such emergent music is all about the moment
column2: Träd
column3: Gräs och Stenar’s best work came in live performance. Though they debuted with a self-titled 1970 studio album
column4: their subsequent two live records cemented their legend. The music on 1971’s Djungelns Lag (The Law of the Jungle) and 1972’s Mors Mors (Hi
column5: How Are You?) was captured in locales as diverse as an airfield
column6: an autonomous Denmark commune
column7: and a meadow next to the Vindeln river. Some tunes have studio-level clarity
column8: revealing acoustic strums
column9: rhythmic handclaps
column10: and vocal chatter
column11: while others are as murky as bootlegs. Both of those styles fit the band’s vibe
column12: which could be simultaneously precise and unruly
column13: bold and mysterious. That vibe is strongest on Djungelns Lag
column14: which feels as open and diverse as the universe
column15: and as big too (see the consistently-compelling
column16: 34-minute “Amithaba In Kommer Gösta”). But Mors Mors is nearly as good
column17: rhyming shorter
column18: poppier gems with masterful extended journeys.

column1: The unreleased material Anthology has collected on Kom Tillsammans (Come Together) comes from the same 1972 recordings as Mors Mors
column2: and works in similar ways. As a whole it’s not as compelling as either preceding album
column3: but it does show how deftly Träd
column4: Gräs och Stenar could continually reinvent themselves. Take their covers of the Rolling Stones’ “The Last Time”: on Mors Mors
column5: they build a relaxed riff into something monumental over nine minutes. On Kom Tillsammans
column6: they completely rethink their attack
column7: grafting in a riff from the Stones’ “Jumpin’ Jack Flash” and doubling the length to 17 minutes without losing a second of interest.

column1: It’s hard to think of many bands who could imagine such interpretations
column2: and this eternal openness might be Träd
column3: Gräs och Stenar’s most enduring legacy. There’s a political aspect to it too; as band member Torbjörn Abelli put it in liner notes
column4: “our music was a sort of ritualistic battle cry
column5: a call for people to be free
column6: follow their own rhythm
column7: their own harmony.” Yet that cry would be unconvincing if the results weren’t inspiring. Träd
column8: Gräs och Stenar delivered on the promise of freedom
column9:
finding moments that couldn’t be achieved by any other means.

column3: in Krakow
column4: I had the unusual experience of standing in an indoor fog bank. The visibility ended just a few feet in front of your nose; the shapes of other people drifted past while the haze pulsed in deep shades of red and blue and lavender. The music was a soup of drones
column5: and the sound
column6: the visuals
column7: and the space itself blended together in such a way that you felt a little like you were floating in space.

column1: The event in question was Ephemera
column2: a site-specific collaboration between the Canadian electronic musician Tim Hecker
column3: German visual artist Marcel Weber
column4: a.k.a. MFO
column5: and Geza Schoen. While the audiovisual experience at most concerts rarely rises above the level of a laser light show
column6: what made this performance-slash-installation so successful was not only its immersive
column7: experiential quality; to longtime fans of Hecker's work
column8: it was an act of transmutation
column9: drawing out qualities that were latent in Hecker's music and bringing them to life around you
column10: in four dimensions.

column1: Over 15 years and multiple solo albums
column2: Hecker has built up a formidable vocabulary of scrape and shimmer and crackle and throb. Using guitar
column3: piano
column4: organ
column5: and
column6: primarily
column7: scads of digital processing
column8: he treats sound as a plastic object
column9: something physical to be molded and stretched. His work is sculptural in feel and widescreen in scope
column10: and it is extraordinarily attentive to texture. Foremost among his concerns has been the idea of diffuseness
column11: of dissolution. There are few hard edges
column12: few identifiable motifs; musical events
column13: like a shift in tone or the introduction of a new timbre
column14: often take place under the cover of static. He prefers distant shapes with vague outlines.

column1: Some of that fog burns off on Love Streams
column2: an album that marks a subtle shift in Hecker's habitual style
column3: a pivot away from his hazy trademark. ""What do you do when you're known for making a certain type of work?"" he recently asked
column4: rhetorically
column5: in an interview with The Fader. Feeling like he was beginning to repeat himself
column6: he said
column7: he decided that the solution ""was not stacking things louder and heavier but working in a different way."" That meant working with voices
column8: for one thing—a complicated-sounding process of using software to translate medieval choral music to digital synthesis and then
column9: working with Icelandic composer Jóhann Jóhannsson
column10: to write and record complementary new choral parts.

column1: He treats his voices in the same way he has typically treated instruments like piano and organ—that is to say
column2: attacking them as if with steel wool—but they're still recognizable as voices. On ""Violet Monumental I
column3: a chattering soprano sings an abstracted lamentation that feels almost liturgical
column4: and on ""Music of the Air
column5: disconnected bursts of voice are staggered in time and spread across the stereo field
column6: lending the impression of wandering through a choir pit while the singers warm up. 4AD turns out to be the perfect home for Hecker's new album
column7: given the way it faintly echoes the choral fixations of '80s 4AD staples like Dead Can Dance
column8: Cocteau Twins
column9: and Le Mystère Des Voix Bulgares.

column1: Hecker's palette has evolved in other ways
column2: too. ""Obsidian Counterpoint"" opens the album with a blippy stream of arpeggios
column3: an explicitly electronic sound that is unusual for his work. Throughout
column4: his sounds seem tugged in two directions at once
column5: as though caught between the digital and the physical. In ""Music of the Air
column6: a buzzing
column7: droning synthesizer patch bobs in unpredictable motions like a handful of jewel-colored flies. Toward the end of ""Bijie Dream
column8: a harpsichord-like sound mutates into something resembling a steel pan
column9: a far cry from Hecker's typically Arctic-inspired palette.

column1: These bold
column2: declarative sounds—which also include the bleating bass clarinet of ""Violet Monumental II"" and the guitar-like riffing of ""Voice Crack""—cut strong shapes through the murk
column3: but Hecker's compositional sensibilities remain opaque: He traffics not so much in melodies or song forms as in unsteady tone clusters. There's not a lot of forward motion here; motifs and timbres repeat across the record
column4: and while many tracks flow seamlessly from one to the next
column5: his open-ended constructions give the album a rewardingly meandering feel. Not a lot happens
column6: except when it does: In the final minute of ""Collapse Sonata
column7: there might be more dynamic action
column8: as tolling bells are gradually absorbed into a queasy slick of steel drum
column9: digital distortion
column10: and dissonant organ tones
column11: than there is on the rest of the album put together.

column1: It's a setup for ""Black Phase
column2: a dramatic conclusion that pairs somber choral harmonies with the gravelly guitars of Ben Frost or Sunn O))). It's as diffuse as the rest of the record
column3: yet it feels somehow cathartic. Like Virgins
column4: Love Streams tackles a lot of abstract concepts
column5: like ""live"" sound
column6: and synthetic sound
column7: and rooms and space
column8: and technology's ability to complicate all those things. But it's also about the ability to disappear into sound
column9: to get lost in the contours of a slippery timbre
column10: or to be made whole by a consonant harmony. At its close
column11: those staccato vocal parts and that smoldering low end deliver a real emotional punch
column12: the release to subtle tensions that have been building up throughout the course of the record's hazy
column13: unpredictable run. It's a suggestion that
column14: if you stumble around in the fog long enough
column15:
you might just find what you're looking for.

Death Grips aren’t above ditching highly-anticipated festival appearances. They didn’t lose sleep after sabotaging their own record deal
column3: and they sure didn’t mind selling thousands of tickets for concerts they never intended on playing in the first place. By any reasonable standard
column4: this band doesn’t give a shit. So it’s been surprising that
column5: in recent months
column6: Death Grips have actually shown generosity to their fans
column7: punctuating the interim between proper albums with low-stakes instrumental work.

column1: In the opening weeks of 2015
column2: the band preceded Jenny Death with a full-length “soundtrack“ titled Fashion Week. At roughly 48 minutes (the second-longest runtime in Death Grips’ catalog after Exmilitary)
column3: it certainly had the bulk of a typical album
column4: but the absence of frontman MC Ride
column5: their furious heart and anguished soul
column6: ultimately rendered Fashion Week unnecessary. And now
column7: just prior to the release of their next album
column8: Bottomless Pit
column9: comes another unusual instrumental release: “Interview 2016
column10: ” a 32-minute clip that depicts the band playing for actor/TV host Matthew Hoffman in a darkened room before sitting down for a conversation. Had the band not legitimized the soundtrack by uploading it to SoundCloud (and later
column11: other streaming sites)
column12: the release would probably be written off as a curio
column13: rather than an entry in the Death Grips canon. Now that it’s isolated
column14: we can see Interview 2016 for what really is: an instrumental EP that abandons Fashion Week’s uneventful expanses for a cramped space that shows Death Grips in confrontational mode.

column1: As with the last soundtrack
column2: MC Ride’s absence diminishes Interview’s intensity
column3: but its brevity gives them space to compensate
column4: narrowing the focus for a sharper sound. Other than the ambient interlude “Interview E
column5: ” the EP mainly sees Zach Hill and Andy Morin doubling down on Jenny Death’s unhinged hardcore with a proliferation of over-driven drums and basslines that seem as if they’re fired from from a Gatling gun. And even though there’s not a clear human voice in the mix (save from a quick “Hi Everybody!” in “Interview F”)
column6: the instruments do plenty of talking. Listen closely to the slippery percussive sample smattered across “Interview C
column7: ” or the barking undercurrent of “Interview F:” the effects themselves are undeniably alien
column8: but they still manage to communicate.

column1: The dynamic and varied arrangements keep the EP from slipping into a formlessness; “Interview B
column2: ” the standout of the set
column3: periodically diverts to an eerie
column4: faintly Eastern chorus that pops open suddenly like a trap-door into the void. And lest the din grow dull on punishing cuts like “Interview A” and “Interview D
column5: “ Hill and Morin temper the racket ever-so-slightly through silvery
column6: distant-sounding refrains that comfort even as they contort
column7: like possessed library music. They even transmogrify Hill’s drum fills into an arpeggiating melody on “Interview C.”

column1: While MC Ride might be perceived as the alpha and omega of Death Grips
column2: Interview 2016 underscores that Hill and Morin are quite formidable on their own. This release is far more interesting than Fashion Week
column3: a full-length twice its size
column4:
and it suggests that Death Grips' strength as an instrumental entity shouldn’t be underestimated.

After eight albums of solid
column2: if ever-more-predictable
column3: psych-folk in about as many years
column4: do Woods have anything new to offer? The band answers that question before anybody can ask it on City Sun Eater in the River of Light
column5: which opens with the most surprising departure of their entire discography: “Sun City Creeps
column6: ” a detour into reggae and African jazz
column7: complete with island horns
column8: trebly guitars and the loose
column9: first-take feel of an early Studio One session. It’s a knockout song
column10: even before the pace quickens during its jammy payoff stretch
column11:
yet the group adopts these tropical sounds so naturally that it never feels like they’re showing off. You can count on one hand the number of American rock bands that could tastefully pull off this sort of stylistic gambit—Calexico; maybe My Morning Jacket. Turns out Woods is one of them.

An opener like that stirs real excitement
column12: and the assurance that the band hasn’t grown complacent is particularly well-timed
column13: coming as it does after 2014’s With Light and With Love
column14: a characteristically enjoyable but familiar-on-arrival LP that left even many Woods loyalists longing for a shakeup. To be sure
column15: City Sun Eater isn’t a complete reinvention
column16: either—it’s largely rooted in the same '60s pop and druggy Americana that’s defined all the band's records—but periodic shadings of reggae give the record a character of its own. Dubby organs lead “Can’t See At All
column17: ” which breathes like a classic Lee Perry track. Some moaning backing vocals are tracked so closely they sound like a wailing electronic gizmo
column18: exactly the kind of lo-fi studio trickery that dub producers played with on their early efforts. Stately horns add gravity to the bongo-guided “The Take
column19:
” another number that patiently builds to a tweaked-out climax.

All of those tracks work because they’re never played as straight genre experiments; they all sound first and foremost like Woods songs
column20: even when they draw from a different vocabulary than any that came before. And like all of Woods’ recent albums
column21: City Sun Eater is generously packed with pop songs
column22: too. With its delirious wah-wah guitars
column23: closer “Hollow Home” imagines what a George Harrison cover of “Just Like Heaven” might have sounded like (utterly joyous
column24: as expected). The song most guaranteed to make audiences twirl in the mud at their live shows
column25:
“Politics of Free” pairs the album’s pluckiest guitars and cheeriest tempo with a parade of uplifting aphorisms: “Find the time to separate your work life from relief/ Constellations in the summer sky/ In a world of shit/ Let’s tune out.”

For most acts
column27: but Woods have never been much of a singles band. They don’t have much to gain from them
column28: since singer Jeremy Earl’s thin voice still makes them a hard sell for wider audiences. On the group's scrappy early efforts it was easy to write off that untrained voice as part of the group’s rumpled charm
column29: but as their albums have grown more deliberate
column30: his anemic falsetto has become more of a nuisance—it’s the only one-note instrument in an act that otherwise wrings so much nuance out of all the other ones. Nine albums in
column31: Woods are still turning out great tunes while tapping new muses
column32:
and that’s worth celebrating. But how great would it be if they had a singer who could really do them justice?

column2: Aiko said
column3: ""It's a '70s aesthetic

column9: setup
column10: punchline

column1: As a pair
column2: Aiko and Sean complement each other well; the former once called Drake her ""musical soulmate
column3: but that distinction is probably better suited here. The L.A. singer-songwriter has a mewing voice that nestles just into the casing of her rap counterpart's cadences. They pen verses in a similar fashion
column4: too
column5: curt and to the point

column11: which writhes in carnal anticipation. Her warm harmonies melt into the backdrop of the thrusting ""Push It."" On ""2 Minute Warning

column15:
but manage to survive on their chemistry.

column3: Bristol's Flying Saucer Attack were as '90s as Nirvana and the Beastie Boys. They emerged early in the decade in an independent music world that was expanding its reach; information
column4: then as now
column5: was zipping around the world
column6: but when FSA debuted
column7: it was mostly traveling on paper. Indeed
column8: the band
column9: consisting at first of Dave Pearce and Rachel Brook (the latter also was a key member of the excellent Movietone)
column10: and later of Pearce alone
column11: owed a great deal to the zine world that had blossomed in the '80s and was in this pre-internet moment in full flower.

column1: One influential zine in particular
column2: Ptolemaic Terrascope
column3: founded and based in the rural west of England
column4: championed FSA early
column5: positioning them in a dark
column6: drone-y
column7: goth-derived scene that included Windy & Carl and Roy Montgomery along with Bristol acts like the Third Eye Foundation and Amp. During this period
column8: you could be an impossibly murky and impenetrable lo-fi psychedelic band obscure enough that even devoted indie music fans had never heard of you
column9: but still play a Peel Session
column10: release singles and EPs on 7-inch vinyl (this when turntables were considered by most a hopelessly passé marker of the clunky analog era)
column11: and find yourself with a modest and devoted international cult. These two records
column12: now reissued on vinyl by Drag City
column13: find Flying Saucer Attack at the moment in the mid-'90s when their sound hit its stride.

column1: Flying Saucer Attack were less about invention and more about combining disparate ingredients in a new way. Their most distinctive feature on first listen is the thick blanket of feedback and distortion that overwhelms almost everything else. The roots of this technique were clearly in the Jesus and Mary Chain's Psychocandy
column2: but where JAMC fetishized bubblegum pop
column3: FSA applied hyper-distortion to British folk and the drifting throb of krautrock. So where the noise of JAMC and later shoegaze bands amplified the catchiness of their simple melodies
column4: FSA blew up the abstraction
column5: and where the best shoegaze noise generally hinted at an enveloping ocean of sensuality
column6: FSA used similar techniques to wallow in feelings of extreme isolation and distance. This was music you used as insulation
column7: raw material to thicken the space between you and the world
column8: and these qualities were reinforced by the proudly D.I.Y. nature of the records; “home taping is reinventing music
column9: ” read a line on the spine of Further.

column1: Further from 1994 is arguably the quintessential Flying Saucer Attack album
column2: with a little bit of everything—evocative instrumental miniatures
column3: folky near-songs
column4: extended spatial explorations—that made them good. There's plenty of fingerpicked acoustic guitar amid the white-noise din
column5: and the bassy pulse of analog noisemakers floats in and out
column6: evoking the spaciness of early '70s synth music. Pearce's voice
column7: a husky tenor indeterminate pitch
column8: is as buried as a voice can possibly be
column9: but despite his extreme limitations as a vocalist
column10: he manages to communicate melancholy
column11: alienation
column12: and loneliness. “Still Point” features lead vocals by Brook
column13: her slightly warmer tone breaking the illusion that Pearce is the last person in the world. The ballad “Come and Close My Eyes” is structured enough that you could almost see someone covering it
column14: while “To the Shore” is a gnarly instrumental that moves from a cymbal tap to churning sonic violence and back to delicate acoustic guitar over the course of 12 minutes.

column1: Chorus from 1995 is a collection of singles
column2: B-sides
column3: and a Peel Session
column4: but Flying Saucer Attack's general approach was so narrow it feels like a proper album. The two main differences are a uniformity of song length
column5: befitting the 7-inch format
column6: and
column7: at places
column8: a growing technological sophistication
column9: as if Pearce was learning how to squeeze more out of his 4-track. The precise layering of the rumbling distortion and simple melody on “Popol Vuh III” demonstrate considerable craft
column10: and “Beach Red Lullaby
column11: ” another Brook lead and a gorgeous acoustic folk song
column12: sounds like a genuine product of another time
column13: an accompaniment to a grainy art film that Pink Floyd might have soundtracked several decades earlier. There's a track called “Feedback Song
column14: ” demonstrating just how much Pearce embraced his defining aesthetic
column15: and later in the collection
column16: as if that wasn't enough
column17: we get “Feedback Song Demo.” But despite the repetition and the feeling of deja vu
column18:
Chorus hangs together and makes for a richly rewarding 40-minute listen; Flying Saucer Attack are living proof that you only need a couple of ideas as long as they're good ones.

column7: at places

column1: Halfaxa is Grimes at her most mystical. Boucher has referred to it as her ""medieval album"" in terms of intent and subject matter. She once explained that the record is meant to be an electronic interpretation of Middle Age Christian reverence

column5: Hildegard von Bingen
column6: a 12th-century German saint without musical training whose music was inspired by divine visions she received starting at the age of three. As explained in von Bingen's theological text Liber Vitae Meritorum

column1: Accordingly
column2: Halfaxa is not direct in the same manner as Visions or Art Angels
column3: which are less enigmatic and perhaps more easily digestible. Lyrics are abstracted to the point of becoming unintelligible

column7: Boucher’s voice stretches towards heavenly octaves before layering itself beneath soprano sighs. The most mysterious songs on Halfaxa rely solely on tone
column8: elongation

column1: Offering a deeper sense of Grimes' world

column3: a jittering incantation of a dance track
column4: takes its name from an archaic legal value placed on all beings and pieces of property

column1: Somewhere along the line

column1:
Correction: An earlier version of this review incorrectly stated that Boucher receives no payment for sales of this reissue.

If you couldn't tell from the title or its 26 tracks or 69-minute length
column2: <i>It's the Big Joyous Celebration

column1: Ray's ascent as an indie/DIY auteur has been propelled by his prolificity and his equally active desire to circumvent any barrier between him and his listeners. column5: like a tear-stained take on the Range's recent emotronica. ""My Little World"" touches on Aphex Twin's early ambient work

column3: Yeasayer's Chris Keating surprised fans by abandoning the comfortably pastoral landscape of All Hour Cymbals to guest on Simian Mobile Disco’s farcical electro-house banger “Audacity of Huge.” At the time

column6: but the move added to the already-nagging suspicion that Keating and Co. were calculated trend hoppers rather than truly idiosyncratic personalities.

column1: That narrative further congealed when Odd Blood positioned Yeasayer as a glossier version of MGMT (or stonier version of Empire of the Sun)

column6: minimalistic sound. (Their lyrics

If ever there was a case to be made for the late career hot streak
column2: Bob Mould is making it. After spending much of the 2000s lost in a fog of self-examination that didn’t always make for compelling music

column1: On Patch the Sky Mould seems to be at peace

column7: he's finally embracing them. “I’m a really good rhythm guitar player

column1: Joined by drummer Jon Wurster and bassist Jason Narducy

Leon Vynehall's music is an artful blend of punchy and plush. Since the British producer started putting out records
column3: his music has blended the tough
column4: percussive energy of contemporary UK house music
column5: with its muscled low end
column6: with the rich harmonies of sample-centric producers in a continuum that stretches through Pal Joey
column7: Moodymann
column8: Pépé Bradock
column9: and Four Tet. Stylistically
column10: he hasn't changed much since his first singles. But while there's no shortage of electronic musicians who approach dance music as a form of collage
column11: Vynehall has developed into a master craftsman. He's got a keen sense for tone color
column12: and the way he mixes textures—blocky piano chords
column13: silken disco strings
column14: rounded horns—lends to an unusually tactile sensibility
column15: like brushstrokes built up into thick waves and oily crusts.

column1: Rojus continues in the vein of 2014's mini-LP Music for the Uninvited
column2: but it boasts a bigger sound in almost every way
column3: with more layers
column4: bolder basslines
column5: and harder-edged drums. With the exception of beatless opener ""Beyond This
column6: whose arpeggiated synth and sampled birdsong make for a breezy ambient aperitif
column7: the record aims its sights squarely at the dancefloor
column8: with bass and percussion pushed up in the mix and tempos locked between 118 and 124 BPM. Like Music for the Uninvited
column9: which was inspired by the cassettes he listened to in his mother's car
column10: Rojus is a loose sort of concept album
column11: one that purports to compare the mating rituals of birds of paradise with the behavior of clubbers. (The title means ""paradise"" in Lithuanian; it comes from a book cover he serendipitously stumbled across around the same time as his epiphany regarding dancers and jungle fowl.)

column1: The theme doesn't extend much further than the sampled caws and trills woven into a few tracks. Still
column2: like his avian inspirations
column3: who sometimes use tools to prep the patch of ground where they'll dance for potential mates
column4: Vynehall proves a remarkably resourceful producer: Instead of limiting himself to a single drum machine
column5: he avails himself of scads of percussion sounds sampled from a variety of sources—a choice that yields a vastly expanded palette of timbres and timing. ""Paradisea
column6: one of the record's standouts
column7: boasts at least three different sampled snares and a panoply of differently treated hi-hats; its syncopated accents are typical of the record's highly elastic sense of swing. The effect is a dizzying array of textures and frequencies
column8: about as easy to parse as a rainstorm.

column1: Vynehall only stumbles when it comes to the uniformity of his songs. They all avail themselves of similar types of sounds
column2: and they all develop in exactly the same way—by beginning with a particularly resonant set of loops and then progressively adding more layers. To create tension
column3: he'll mute a handful of sounds throughout the breakdown and then bring them back for a reprise. But there are no choruses
column4: no bridges
column5: no unexpected left turns. And his sounds sit so well in the mix
column6: there are really no surprises
column7: either. A little dissonance would go a long way.

column1: Despite sonic attributes meant to suggest roughness
column2: rawness
column3: and even risk—the distortion
column4: the swing
column5: the grit—the music remains fundamentally agreeable
column6: polite
column7: even a little safe. Even the wordless cry that goes soaring over the top of ""Blush
column8: meant to evoke a moment of total abandon
column9: fits so well with all the other moving pieces that it provokes admiration for its craft more than it stirs
column10: much less disturbs
column11: the soul. It points you in the right direction
column12: but it doesn't quite tip you over the edge.

column1: In addition to its ornithological conceit
column2: Rojus is supposed to represent the arc of a night out. But it doesn't quite manage: The music's intensity remains more or less constant from the second track on. A good nightclub should have nooks and crannies
column3: hidden rooms
column4: mysterious passageways; its layout should encourage all kinds of mystery and mischief. But as wonderfully appointed as Rojus is
column5: it really offers just one vista: Once you're through its welcoming foyer
column6: you know exactly where you're going to be and what you're going to hear until the doors close. As a set of tracks for DJs to pick from
column7: Rojus offers plenty of potential. As a front-to-back listening experience
column8:
it's almost paradise—but not quite the album that it wants to be.

column11: like ""You Only Tell Me You Love Me When You’re Drunk

column5: it feels so good."" The Boys trusted Price enough to leave several tracks nearly instrumental

column3: Morrissey ghosting for Bashar Assad. ""Will someone please say the unsayable?"" Tennant pleads. ""Will someone please tell me I’m wrong? I live every day like a sad beast of prey
column4: for I have to appear to be strong."" As he frets over secret prison facilities

column1: A Pet Shop Boys narrator is so often the bereft observer: Like Carly Rae Jepsen's characters

Tombs are restless—or at least vocalist and guitarist Mike Hill is. Hill's changed the lineup around him a handful of times since founding the band in 2007
column3: and the sound's shifted just as often. They've had a couple different drummers
column4: a few different guitarists and bassists. They've also moved from an act that brought to mind Helmet collaborating with Immortal to something that can bring to mind Sisters of Mercy stuck in a blackened downpour.

column1: Hill has done all this while maintaining an eerie consistency—the group hasn't released a bad record
column2: and their last two collections
column3: 2011's Path of Totality and 2014's Savage Gold
column4: were among the best the years they came out. The music has always been precise and muscular
column5: tough but elegant
column6: even as they started working more elements into their sound: They are capable of making you think of Unsane
column7: Darkthrone
column8: and Bauhaus in the same song. The band name itself
column9: Tombs
column10: is flexible—broad
column11: everyday
column12: non-specific—but it's always related to death.

column1: Their new EP

column3: features their biggest stylistic shift to date. Much of this is due to the addition of synth/electronics player and co-vocalist Fade Kainer
column4: an avowed Andy Stott fan who used to front the crusty doom group
column5: Batillus
column6: and currently plays in the power-electronics project
column7: Theologian
column8: among other industrial-leaning acts. (The EP also welcomes new drummer Charlie Schmid of Vaura and guitarist Evan Void of Sadgiqacea.)

column1: There's more space here than on past offerings. The songs are still coiled and intense
column2: but Tombs allow themselves room to drift into dark chasms of rough
column3: bleak ambience. You have to think this is partially a result of the flexibility Kainer affords them. He also adds Wax Trax howls alongside Hill's brutal barks. Hill continues to grow as a singer; When not shouting or screaming
column4: he's crooning clean tones that can bring to mind Peter Murphy or Ian Curtis. In the past I've likened Hill to a drill sergeant because of his muscles and shaved head. In person
column5: though
column6: he strikes me as especially calm
column7: even zen. You do get the idea
column8: however
column9: that he's pushing the people around him to make the most disciplined music of their careers—and that they're happily following his lead.

column1: All Empires Fall is brief. There are five songs across 24 minutes
column2: and it feels more like a palate cleanser than a complete offering. But because of its precision
column3: and Sanford Parker's dense production
column4: it's also powerful. Short instrumental ""The World is Made of Fire"" sounds like a post-metal anthem reminiscent of fellow Brooklynites Sannhet until the entrance of melancholic
column5: gothic-metal synths. It's followed by ""Obsidian
column6: ” which as its name suggests
column7: offers swarming black metal. On the song
column8: Hill growls""We are the fallen/ Manifest in shadows""; much of the record explores the apocalypse on a personal
column9: individual level.

column1: Like all of what Tombs does
column2: the lyrics and music feel thoughtful— there are no tossed-off details in the maelstrom. The more mid-tempo ""Last Days of Sunlight” drips with haunted
column3: clanging atmospherics; Hill chants lyrics that feel personal (""It is hard to forgive me/ 100 tears have fallen"") with a dead-eyed intonation. The shredding
column4: bass-heavy
column5: death rock-paced""Deceiver"" features dual vocals from Hill and Kainer
column6: along with contributions from Sera Timms of Black Mare and Ides of Gemini. It's kind of like industrial Watain.

column1: But it's the last song
column2: V”
column3: that has me most excited for what they do next. Opening with a minute and a half of what sounds like a distant wind tunnel lined with ice
column4: the six and a half minute track becomes an anthem that moves between black metal
column5: post-punk
column6: and death rock. Hill and Kainer repeatedly shout""Fall into the great divide/ Fall into the netherworld
column7: while elegant synths and layers of guitars and drums fight it out behind them. It's maybe the catchiest song Tombs have ever written. It reminded me of the dark punk anthems that would sometimes show up on MTV's 120 Minutes when I was a kid

column10:
and then sprint.

As Com Truise
column3: Los Angeles-transplanted producer Seth Haley uses a narrow palette
column4: but it works on a remarkable variety of canvases. Early EPs such as 2010's Cyanide Sisters and 2011's Fairlight introduced a project devoted to spacey slow-funk synth excursions with a whiff of ’80s nostalgia— an approach Haley continued on Com Truise's 2011 fine debut LP
column5: Galactic Melt
column6: and 2013's rarities grab bag In Decay. Over the years
column7: though
column8: this ""Com Truise sound"" has seemed equally suited to remixes for pop stars like Charli XCX or Maroon 5 as well as for Ghostly International labelmate Tycho. PARTYNEXTDOOR even sampled Galactic Melt's ""Hyperlips"" for the highlight of the Drake protégé's self-titled 2013 debut.

column1: Working with other artists gives Haley a vocal presence that can go in front of his cleanly designed backdrops. Plenty of instrumental or nearly instrumental music can dominate the foreground
column2: of course
column3: but listening to Com Truise often feels like listening to a movie or videogame score. Which makes sense: Haley has described these releases as ""like a film score... from the mind"" for a storyline involving the interplanetary journey of ""the world's first synthetic/robotic astronaut."" On Galactic Melt
column4: samples of dating advice (""Brokendate"") or orgasmic moans (""VHS Sex"") served as additional entrypoints
column5: and the standout on 2014's Wave 1 EP was a guest vocal turn that had Ford & Lopatin's Joel Ford sounding like a cyborg Scritti Politti (""Declination""). Follow-up EP Silicon Tare sounds once again like vintage Com Truise
column6: but it would have benefited from having more of a focal point.

column1: The five tracks here differ from their predecessors only by degrees
column2: so if you liked the previous records there's little here to find too upsetting
column3: but as an EP it feels like a stopgap ahead of the next Com Truise album. Most enticing
column4: unsurprisingly
column5: are the two tracks shared in advance: the drifting
column6: jittery flicker of ""Diffraction"" and the languid sweeps of the title track. But opener ""Sunspot
column7: with its busy drum programming
column8: and the subsequent ""Forgive
column9: punctuated by squeals of synth
column10: are of a piece. The closest the EP comes to an outright failure is the draggy finale
column11: ""Du Zirconia
column12: which at six minutes takes too long to shift from its high opening bleeps to its eventual midtempo groove. What's a shame is that these tracks do little to expand on their initial ideas
column13: let alone do more than set a vague
column14: unblinking mood for their ostensible subject
column15: the robot astronaut on its voyage through space.

column1: Artists whose work shifts only subtly between releases have some welcome precedents
column2: this year alone including the likes of Julianna Barwick or the Field. What raises bigger questions about Com Truise is the durability of this particular sound. From the soul and funk records that became ""disco"" to the varied post-punk sounds later boiled down into ""alternative
column3: genres often have more to offer before they've become codified; the homebaked synth-funk of Neon Indian or Washed Out didn't really have a name in 2009's deadbeat summer
column4: but popular opinion coalesced around the name ""chillwave"" by the time Com Truise came to embody many of that YouTube-retro style's basic points. With Neon Indian — Com Truise's former tourmate — recently resurgent
column5: Lindstrøm mastering similar sounds from more of a disco angle

how much room is there for ’80s-harking synthscapes?

Most of the time

column5: bordering on perfectly arranged. As I listened

column7: <span> staple the pages together
column8: and read along

column11: one where she will eventually deserve mention alongside poets like <span>Lydia Davis

column1: The sound on her sophomore album is mature
column2: fully-fleshed
column3: but never loses the unique immediacy of her Bandcamp work. Like those albums

column8: grinning contentedly at her untied shoes."" In Next Thing
column9: she's looked up from her laces
column10: meeting your eyes and delivering observations <span>that are by turns strange
column11: self-possessed

column1: On these songs
column2: those observational powers are at their height. Her greatest talent remains her ability to transform minute-long songs into experiences that resemble hours of intimate and impressionistic conversation. In the first minute of album opener ""Floated In
column3: Kline sings: ""Now it would be bedtime if/I could close off my mind/It just flops onto you/Wet and soppy glue...You know I'd love to/Rummage through your silky pink space cap."" It's an uncanny description of two drowsy minds splattering thoughts on each other
column4: hoping something sticks
column5: but the words gently pass by before you've even internalized how weird and salient they are. Even when she paints scenes that ostensibly are filled with private meaning
column6: something universal resonates. In ""Fool"" for example
column7: when she sings ""Your name is a triangle
column8: your heart is a square
column9: the funky cubist formulation gets closer to the uncomfortable feeling of naming the one you love than straight description ever would.

column1: As a singer
column2: she's perfected an inimitable vocal delivery that is willfully off-center
column3: out-of-focus
column4: and matter-of-fact. She uses enjambment in her writing and in the long pauses of her singing so well that it reminds me of an idea from Maggie Nelson
column5: that some people who tend bonsai trees plant them askew or aslant to leave space for God. The gaps in Sappho's poetry have been called ""a free space of imaginal adventure
column6: and it is an apt description for Kline's music: In the momentary disjunctions of Kline's singing
column7: the hiccup between words

column9: she savors the nanoseconds that come between words
column10: asking ordinary-seeming questions (""I haven't written this part yet/will you help me write it?"") that invite radical participation from a listener. Even though the song may end after two and a half minutes

column1: Her work has a continuity to it that invites deep diving
column2: as if she is formulating and reformulating the same few thoughts
column3: waiting for their perfect expressions. Many of the songs (""Embody
column4: ""On the Lips

column6: and they make the leap seamlessly. Each are marvelously well-wrought trains of thought
column7: cramming existential questions into the banality of everyday moments and finding something beatific even in the plainest of things. ""Embody"" finds Kline singing about a day where friendship is everything holy in the world
column8: ""It's Sunday night/and my friends are friends with my friends/it shows me they embody all the grace and lightness."" It's a feeling that helps her move past her self-perceived inability to access this feeling herself (""someday in bravery/I'll embody all the grace and lightness). In Catholicism
column9: past the fog of guilt
column10: there's an incredible idea that light
column11: love
column12: and all that's holy can be transferable from one person to the next. It usually happens in ritual
column13: the eating of a wafer of bread and a sip of wine. In Greta Kline's pocket universe
column14:
all you need to get closer to heaven is a night with friends.

Eric Bachmann and his longtime label Merge Records would have us believe that the Archers of Loaf frontman's first new album in five years is a radical reinvention. The truth is far less dramatic. The forty-something singer-songwriter can't really escape himself or the raw
column2: unaffected sound
column3: gruffly melodic vocals
column4: and pointed lyrical approach that he adopted in the early ’00s when he started recording as Crooked Fingers. Instead
column5: this short
column6: engaging collection of tunes feels more like Bachmann getting a tighter grip on who is as an human and as an artist
column7: and more deeply appreciating his past and the influences that got him to this point.

column1: That idea is laid bare in the album's eponymous title and the cover art
column2: which features a picture of Bachmann as a gangly
column3: bright eyed Little Leaguer. And within the music itself
column4: he introduces a broader array of sonic inspiration: the fizzy highs of ’60s pop
column5: the glossy production style of ’70s country
column6: and a hint of British post-punk fervor for good measure. Some songwriters who drink from those wells let their creations become busy and dense
column7: but Bachmann leaves plenty of empty space
column8: using small signifiers—the “Be My Baby” drum hits that kick off “Mercy
column9: ” the piano line of “Dreaming” that feels drawn from slow dance mainstay “Color My World”—to do big work. The only indulgence he allows himself here is the inclusion of gospel-esque backing vocalists
column10: but even they only come when a certain lyrical phase needs to be driven home.

column1: The decision to release the album under his own name is also connected with the more personal nature of these songs. It's a move he has made once before
column3: with To The Races
column4: a plaintive collection that centered on his voice and acoustic guitar and lyrics that spoke to his wanderlust and his fraught romantic life. Both of those concerns have been
column5: for the most part
column6: quelled: Bachmann is married to his frequent collaborator and touring partner Liz Durrett
column7: and the long-time North Carolinian seems to be comfortably settled in Athens
column8: Georgia. That opens him up to take on some broader issues.

column1: Primary among them is Bachmann's political frustrations. He uses the true stories of murder and ill-fated justice to opine
column2: over a ska-like drum beat and a bouncing piano melody
column3: that “what should be an old relic by now should never have been/the South is a ghost
column4: a ghost is a lie.” Elsewhere
column5: in the stormy “Mercy
column6: ” he relishes the irony of using a church-like choir to back him as he sings about his disbelief in a higher power and marveling that “I've got friends and I've got family/from Alaska to Miami/you won't believe the crazy shit they sometimes say.” These songs were likely recorded months ago
column7: but they reflect current fractious political conditions
column8: ones that have allowed his home state's legislature to pass a bill that overturns LGBT protections.

column1: As frustrated as those songs are
column2: there's also a ruminative quality to their lyrics that carries throughout the album. It feels like the product of a man finally settling down after years of travel and activity
column3: and not liking what he sees. That goes for himself as well. For as much appreciation as Bachmann exudes with regards to life and love
column4: the emphasis is really on regret. He reopens former emotional wounds on the noir-ish album closer “The Old Temptation
column5: ” and sounds surprised at his own panic in “Separation Anxiety.” And the album is peppered with references to the dead and dying. Bachmann
column6: who knows more than ever that his time on earth is finite
column7: is going to say his piece before he goes. Again
column8: none of this signals a huge shift for Bachmann. But after spending a long stretch of time playing with his former band and as a member of Neko Case's backing band
column9: it's good to see that he can return to the mold of singer-songwriter with a little extra fire in his belly.

column1:
Correction: The original version of this review stated that Georgia passed a ""religious liberty"" bill into law. It's been corrected to reflect that the governor vetoed it before it became a law.

column3: proceeds directly from their last two. Its opening track

column6: through the magic of dub

By now

column6: poignant and infectious debut album. Released outside of the typical label structure
column7: BWET was a triumph

column2: she continues to double down on her love of ’90s NY house. ""The Big Big Beat

column1: That is the thing about Azealia Banks: she still puts out consistent work
column2: and each release feels like a well-timed reminder of how good she can be. For all of her questionable tweets or political affiliations
column3: her music still touches on feelings that other artists rarely touch: Consider the sly vulnerability of Broke with Expensive Taste's ""Soda
column4: a song that became something of an anthem for misunderstood
column5: creative
column6: emotionally unfulfilled young black women navigating a world that continues to disregard our deepest desires and emotions.

column1: And it is the sort of thing that makes people willing to give her artistic chances. There were very few gut punches as memorable as listening to Broke with Expensive Taste for the first time. And on Slay-Z
column2: there are hints of that power. They don’t shine nearly as bright as her almost flawless debut record
column3:
but they keep us watching and listening.

It’s easy to root for Charles Bradley
column3: the 67-year-old soul singer who has spent the last few years enjoying a breakout career on Daptone Records. Bradley’s underdog narrative has remained as genuinely endearing as it has perpetually marketable
column4: and Changes
column5: his third album

column8: Bradley now seems to command ownership of his songs like never before. It’s an accomplished skill in the world of retro-soul
column9: and Bradley sounds vital instead of nostalgic because of it.

column1: Changes’ lyrics are immediately and sometimes overly familiar
column2: but Bradley’s unmistakable voice is the obvious draw throughout. For a guy who has often been affectionately pigeonholed—Bradley has earned a tagline as the “The Screaming Eagle of Soul”—the new album instead finds him at his most versatile and complete. The record opens with a soulful gospel rendition of “God Bless America” in which the singer delivers an organ-laced testimony; the same keys pop up in funkier form on follow-up “Good to Be Back at Home.” After spending much of his seventh decade as a first-time international headliner
column3: Bradley sings about the mixture of relief and disappointment in his return trip. Like other songs on the album
column4: the song is vaguely and upliftingly political: On “Changed For the World” Bradley tells us ""Heaven is crying
column5: the world is shaking."" Half singing
column6: half preaching
column7: he warns “God is unhappy
column8: the moon is breaking / Blood is spilling
column9: God is coming.”

column1: Musically

column3: but the session players—primarily from Menahan Street Band but also Bradley’s touring group The Extraordinaries—are more restrained here to make room for Bradley's big presence and even bigger voice. But the album is nonetheless inflected with the referential post-funk and hip-hop drum sounds of  label guitarist Thomas Brenneck and company. Near the end of “Nobody But You” a horn line quotes the unmistakable saxophone from Seals and Crofts 1972 hit “Summer Breeze

column5: ” now perhaps better known to all as the sample chop Biz Markie finagled into “Just a Friend.”

column1: Much of the album is about love: searching for it
column2: being wronged by it
column3: basking in it. Of the spare forty-minute tracklist
column4: “Things We Do For Love” might be the most satisfyingly retro offering
column5: complete with a dose of doo-wop accompaniment and a nimble
column6: romantic groove. The album’s greatest accomplishment is in its most unexpectedly personal moment though
column7: in which Bradley wrestles an out-of-character Black Sabbath ballad about a breakup into an agonizing paean to his late mother. After spending a lifetime estranged
column8: Bradley patched up his relationship with his mother in time to serve as her caretaker before she passed
column9: and also early enough that she got to see his career finally take off. In her absence and in the midst of post-success family quarrels
column10: Bradley sounds heartbreakingly alone when he wails “I’ve lost the best friend I’ve ever had.” “Changes
column11: ” and its accompanying video

column1: A few years ago
column2: Bradley’s success seemed more romantic in its improbability. “We found an authentic soul man that liked our music
column3: ” Brenneck glowed of his band’s initial collaboration with the singer in 2012. Changes somehow feels more natural

column6: the singer remains a precious commodity: the real thing. He’s not reenacting or revisiting
column7:
he’s on his first run through. And it's still inspiring to watch him live it out at last.

column2: by this point

But
column2: occasionally

column11: and for that matter

column1: On Everything Will Be All Right in the End

""Wind in Our Sail"" and ""(Girl We Got A) Good Thing"" derive their momentum from peppy keyboard plunks

column10: frequently-unadressed fears of abandonment and inferiority that accompany modern notions of masculinity and femininity. How disappointing

column1: <div class=""message_content ""><span class=""message_body"">No
column2: we listen to Weezer in 2016 largely for nostalgic dog whistles. We listen because Blue retreads like ""Endless Summer"" and ""Summer Elaine and Drunk Dori"" offer Proustian pleasures in spite of their obviously-recycled frameworks

column10: low-key tape tricks color straightforward musicianship

It takes roughly three days to travel on the Amtrak from Portland
column3: Ore.

column1: Whether or not Living Life Golden will actually work as a breakout for Elliphant remains to be seen; it's not a home run. With the absolute best aspects of her pop musicianship present

column1: As a document of his metamorphosis

The album is so certain of what kind of adulthood it wants to convey that it often ends up expressing an amplified parody of it. The lyrics are hyper-focused on types of haze (drunk or drugged) and heterosexual sex; blustery lead single ""PILLOWTALK"" seems reverse-engineered from Zayn singing the word ""fucking

column7: like the majority of sexual encounters on the record

column1: <div><span style=""color: #000000; font-family: Georgia
column2: serif;"">The bonus tracks expand the dimensions of the album. ""BLUE"" would seem Zayn’s attempt at a Coldplay-esque ballad if it approached any sort of resolution or climax; instead it just hovers nervously at half-altitude. These uncertain moments are the most compelling ones

column6: his debut
column7: serif;""> is oddly inflexible and over-calculated.
column8: serif;""><span> Great solo pop careers are usually born when the performer figures out what space they want to claim and leave enough room for the listener to join them

column3: exactly

column1: It's actually not hard to believe that Moderat initially clashed; it was never the most natural fit. They were three musicians at the forefront of a developing minimal techno and performance scene
column2: jamming together by linking their laptops with software they wrote
column3: as it wasn't readily commercially available yet. Gernot Bronsert and Sebastian Szary strung up heavy metals at high bpms as Modeselektor
column4: muddling jungle
column5: breakbeat
column6: and glitch-hop. Sascha Ring
column7: meanwhile
column8: made fluttering
column9: sculpted ambient pop as Apparat. Their merger could feel tentative or slanted on the first two parts of the Moderat trilogy
column10: which were prone to instrumental tangents and guest vocalists. But it's apparent from III’s air of ease and consistency of style that they've finally gelled around one vision.

column1: The album absorbs a dark spectrum of postminimal electronic music—the rococo bass and deep contrasts of James Blake
column2: the windy knock and moan of Burial
column3: the sultry lightness of The xx
column4: the granular whir of Four Tet—and reflects it back. It reminds me most of Jamie Woon's underrated Mirrorwriting
column5: from the committed vocal performances down to the new age incense wafting through the spare
column6: softly thundering arrangements.  Though it's Moderat's strongest record
column7: III isn't quite all killer. The very Field-like ""Finder"" bounces its vocal loop into the pocket
column8: but it doesn't show off the songcraft found on songs like ""Reminder
column9: which might have sprung from a solo album by Thom Yorke. The three best songs allow the vocal performances to lengthen
column10: open up
column11: and gather weight. The best of them is ""Eating Hooks
column12: where low wobbles and glittering trills are strung together in a hypnotic equilibrium. It's closely followed by ""Intruder
column13: a sincere big-whoa anthem
column14: and ""Ghostmother"" that could pass for The Antlers if they were ex-ravers.

column1: The last couple of tracks are instrumentals that seem superfluous—on closer ""Ethereal
column2: III has run out of songs as well as titles. But the highlights make it a must-hear for sensitive electronic-soul lovers waiting in vain for Rhye to return. It's also a resounding realization of what Moderat is and can be: a band you can relate to
column3:
not just a beat you can bob to. Here’s to their health.

column1: Venis displays all the poise of a nerdy kid brother learning how not to speak to women one spectacular embarrassment at a time
column2: but just as exasperating as the lyrics
column3: which are somehow even more bantamweight than ""Sweeterman
column4: is Ram's shaky grasp on melody. On the low end
column5: he employs a soothing Drake-ish croon
column6: the same one being run into obsolescence by scores of adopters around Toronto and beyond. It's Venis' saving grace on highlights ""Left
column7: Right"" and ""Bodmon
column8: cuts where the singer leans back as his producers carry him to the hooks. But these peaks are too often offset by the shrill bleat at the other end of his register
column9: a grating wobbly tone processed within an inch of humanity by pitch-correcting software
column10: one assumes
column11: because Ram can't quite nail the actual notes. When he sails up an octave in the second verse of the single ""Hey Mr. RamRod"" to ask a girl to let him in the ""kitty kat
column12: it sounds like he's trying to strangle one instead.

column1: Ramriddlz doesn't bring much to Venis that any number of other singers couldn't

column3: then

column7: and 1Mind. Together

column9: it is because of the ultralight sonics underfoot
column10: not the unsure fake patois over top. 1Mind's soaring ""Baeby"" airlifts Ram by way of a pulsating groove not even a string of bad puns and fake Jadakiss ad libs can quell. ""Venis"" pulls a dizzying hard left into downcast house in its last minute as the singer prattles on
column11: Auto Tune so thick he may as well be another synth in the mix. Really
column12: this is a producer's project.

column1: How much this music successfully entertains is directly rooted in how easily the center attraction can be tuned out
column2: because on Venis

column5: the more adroitly sexual end of the dancehall spectrum
column6: but by and large
column7: this stuff isn't sexy
column8: unless Ram's promise of semen that tastes like Chick-fil-A Polynesian sauce sounds like a good time. If Ramriddlz is going to last beyond the quick
column9: bright heat of a choice Drake cosign

column11:
when what was really needed was refinement.

Halfway through Little Big League's ""Year of the Sunhouse
column2: some dope asks Michelle Zauner whether she's still ""playing basement shows with the band—doing the music thing?"" She roars back
column3: ""Well yes I fuckin' a-a-am!"" Her pride was justified. The underrated Philadelphia four-piece were among the best of their kind
column4: playing knotty
column5: effervescent indie rock that confronted darker themes like sexual violence and infidelity. Shortly before that single's release in late 2014
column6: Zauner's mother was diagnosed with cancer. The frontwoman/guitarist stopped playing basement shows with the band
column7: and moved back to small-town Oregon to be with her mom
column8: and later comfort her widowed father. Psychopomp came together that year in rural Eugene
column9: where Zauner revamped songs from her previous lo-fi releases under the name Japanese Breakfast. In collaboration with musician Ned Eisenberg
column10: she pushed them beyond their original scrappy basement confines into shimmering gems.

column1: If Zauner's palette has largely softened
column2: her subject matter hasn't
column3: even though only two songs here deal specifically with the death of her mother. ""In Heaven"" welds the billowing
column4: shoegazy coo of peak Asobi Seksu to distinct songwriting fit for the Sundays. The heartbreaking lyrics measure the distance between a mother's love and the effect of its loss
column5: but Zauner sings in a forceful celebration of life. When she belts
column6: ""Oh
column7: do you believe in heaven like you believed in me?/ Oh
column8: it could be such heaven if you believed it was real
column9: her heart sounds like it might burst.

column1: It sets the tone for a record that loosely explores issues of dependency. The disco-tinged ""The Woman That Loves You"" and intimate closer ""Triple 7"" find Zauner playing ""the other woman"" involved with a married man. The latter is one of her characteristically blunt depictions of sex. ""I love a man in uniform
column2: she admits
column3: before wrinkling the cliche: ""'Cause he loves me like a slot machine from the valley of loose women in the cruel light of morning."" Similarly
column4: ""Everybody Wants to Love You
column5: a driving duet with Radiator Hospital's Sam Cook-Parrott
column6: leaps swiftly from a one-night stand to marriage through varying emotional and physical demands—most notably
column7: ""When we wake up in the morning
column8: will you give me lots of head?"" These songs are never as clear-cut as dominance versus submission
column9: and Zauner doesn't apologize or rationalize her desires
column10: which is refreshing.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: Psychopomp bites harder when Zauner lets you feel the weight of her pain. She turns the lens on herself on ""Jane Cum
column3: the record's most hopeless
column4: cathartic moment
column5: where the starry shimmer slips away
column6: and heavy
column7: staticky storms envelop her yearning voice. ""Heft"" is the other song about her mother's death
column8: updated from its original appearance on 2014's Where is My Great Big Feeling to sound like the kind of eerie
column9: creeping indie rock that the teens in ""Twin Peaks"" would have listened to if the show had its own Bronze or Bait Shop. Staring down the barrel of her mother's impending diagnosis
column10: Zauner panics about whether ""it's the same dark coming
column11: a reprisal of the cancer that also took her aunt. ""Oh fuck it all
column12: she sings
column13: wringing out the last word.

column1: It's as good a response as any other. Playing shows in basement bands may not offer adult security
column2: just as writing songs about one of life's worst losses doesn't necessarily offer any resolutions
column3: but survival is its own reward. And Psychopomp offers much more than that: at once cosmically huge and acutely personal
column4:
Zauner captures grief for the perversely intimate yet overwhelming pain it is. Long may she keep at this music thing.

Synthesizer music was hardly a new phenomenon in 1984
column2: the year of The Terminator’s release
column3: but the movie theater proved a remarkably successful means of injecting experimental electronic sounds direct into the mainstream consciousness. Not that anyone out there expected The Terminator to find such a broad audience. Made for a lean $6.4 million by James Cameron
column4: then a rookie screenwriter and special effects designer with just one directorial credit—1981’s best-forgotten Piranha II: The Spawning—to his name
column5: even the film’s star
column6: Arnold Schwarzenegger was initially cool to it. “Some shit movie I’m doing
column7: take a couple of weeks
column8: ” he explained while on the set of Conan The Barbarian. But The Terminator made Schwarzenegger a star and set the tenor for the next decade of sci-fi cinema
column9: its vision of humanity crushed by a malign artificial intelligence backed up by a score that not just dramatized but echoed the sense of a machine army in the ascendant.

column1: This freshly remastered reissue of Brad Fiedel’s Terminator score comes as part of the Milan Records’ Nicolas Winding Refn Presents series
column2: and is lavishly presented
column3: its 69 minutes of music spread across two slabs of 180g red-and-blue spattered vinyl and housed in reflective UV wrap. Such quality production values mean that it’s easy to forget scores like this were often ad hoc
column4: the result of budgetary expediency and on-the-fly invention. Neither a celebrated soundtrack maestro or analogue synthesizer guru
column5: Fiedel’s CV was about as square as it gets: he began his career signed to Paul Simon’s music publishing company and spent six months playing live keyboards for the soft rock duo Hall and Oates before making the leap into TV scoring. The Terminator was his first feature film
column6: and after an intermittent film career that culminated with Cameron’s 1994 blockbuster True Lies
column7: he retreated from Hollywood to pursue his real love
column8: musicals. In an interview recorded for Japanese TV
column9: now available to view on YouTube
column10: you get a glimpse of Fiedel’s sensibility: sat at an electric piano
column11: he tinkles away at The Terminator’s main theme as if auditioning for some Broadway revue.

column1: Still
column2: if the soundtrack still feels special
column3: perhaps it’s because of this unlikely collision: an intermingling of theatric sensibility and emergent technology. The tools Fiedel used were cutting-edge for the period—a Prophet 10
column4: an Oberheim
column5: a drum machine and a sequencer—but still primitive in their workings. This was
column6: just
column7: a pre-MIDI age
column8: so he would synch up his instruments by hand
column9: and you can hear the occasional sense of slip and slide. The film’s majestically dark “Main Title” is a perfect mix of haunting melody and remorseless
column10: mechanical rhythm
column11: the latter in part the result of human error. While looping his Prophet 10
column12: Fiedel missed the complete measure by a split second
column13: but liking the result
column14: kept it. Seth Stevenson’s 2014 article for Slate pins it to the unusual time signature of 13/16
column15: which lends the track an eerie
column16: unheimlich quality: the heartbeat of a machine.

column1: The Terminator was a pulp film with depth
column2: one that critics have gone lengths to decode. In 1995’s Projecting The Shadow: The Cyborg Hero In American Film
column3: Janice H Rushing and Thomas S Frentz read it as a sort of Christian parable
column4: writing that “John Conner
column5: a modern day J.C. born of an ‘ordinary’ mother
column6: is the warrior-king who is prophesied to reconstitute the world
column7: to avert the apocalypse through a fight with a cyborgian devil.” Whether Fiedel recognized it or not
column8: his music echoes something of this eschatological struggle: the implacable rhythms and cold choral swells of “Terminator Arrival – Reese Chased – Sarah on Motorbike” gesture to both the ruthless march of an automated future and the cold solemnity of the Catholic mass.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Fiedel weaves around to capture the film’s sense of cat-and-mouse pursuit
column3: shifting beats between simmering tension
column4: lurching pursuit
column5: and brief but precious glimpses of redemption. There are moments when the limited sound palette dates it—see the gurgling
column6: acidic arpeggios of “Matt & Ginger Killed – Sarah Calls Detectives” and “Tunnel Chase.” Elsewhere
column7: though
column8: it feels eerily timeless: the dark ambient investigations of “Arm & Eye Surgery”; or “Reese Dreams Of Future War
column9: ” which with its racing synth progressions
column10: harsh stabs and rumbling martial percussion might have slotted seamlessly onto Prurient’s Frozen Niagra Falls.

column1: Perhaps the root of Fiedel’s success here
column2: though
column3: is the way his score holds close to the main theme’s central melodic and rhythmic motifs
column4: remaking and remolding them to keep a sense of narrative continuity even as he shifts around sound and tone. From the metallic march of “‘I’ll Be Back' – Police Station & Escape” to the yearning piano of “Love Scene
column5: ” a firm backbone runs throughout
column6: and when the end credits ushers in a cold dawn
column7:
Fiedel holds back on fireworks or tidy emotional resolution. As Sarah Connor loads up the Land Rover and disappears into the desert here is no salvation here; just a cold dread for what is to come.

Explosions in the Sky are the kind of band that you think about in terms of scale. There is the sheer size of their songs

column1: Like Cold Dead Place

column6: that horribly unreal and frozen moment when you first hear a friend has died
column7: walks alone at dusk
column8: laying on your back and watching the constellations with the person you want to grow old with
column9: the calm of seeing a loved one sleep. These songs feel personal. They tug at important moments. It's a quietly masterful
column10: emotionally rich work. Of all their records
column11: it's ultimately the one that sounds the most like the image their band name evokes. But you're watching from a distance
column12:
and paying more attention to the person next to you than those colors smearing against the clouds overhead.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23095/homepage_large.a2b74c77.jpg|Dame Fortune|3581.0|RJD2|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|"[""RJ's Electrical Connections""]"|2016-03-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:48:34.249023|"

There’s a good chance you know producer RJD2’s work
column2: even if you didn’t know he was at the helm. He composed the Mad Men intro
column3: a layered blend of strings and cascading drums depicting the main character’s descent. Then there’s the beat in this Miller Lite TV spot—a brassy number with blaring horns
column4: soaked in New Orleans-style soul. In these instances and others
column5: the composer skillfully blends genres
column6: creating rap/funk hybrids that seem influenced by his living in Philadelphia
column7: a city known for its rich musical history. For the new album
column8: he says
column9: Philly provided a context for all the soul music he's liked over the years.

column1: RJD2’s art is full of unique twists and tough to pin down. His albums play like film scores
column2: launching in one place and landing somewhere totally different. On 2002’s Deadringer—widely considered the producer’s magnum opus—his mix of jazz
column3: New York rap and R&B went in all sorts of directions
column4: but it made complete sense for El-P’s vaunted Def Jux label. Eleven years later
column5: on More Is Than Isn’t
column6: the results were decidedly electronic
column7: pulling from the L.A. beat scene while streamlining his vast experiments over the years. Above all
column8: RJD2 is a chameleon—able to navigate multiple scenes
column9: eluding creative boxes along the way.

column1: RJD2 doesn’t deviate from that approach on Dame Fortune
column2: his sixth album
column3: which resembles parts of his previous work while keeping with current sounds. “A New Theory” in particular
column4: with its menacing rap knock
column5: is a worthy compliment to any Cannibal Ox or Mr. Lif release. “A Portal Inward” is perhaps RJD2’s best Pink Floyd impression: Collecting light and dark synths
column6: it’s a long—perhaps too long—album intro ala “Shine On You Crazy Diamond.” For RJD2
column7: it doesn’t quite set a tone for the music that follows
column8: which moves quickly toward festive breakbeats and progressive rock. Much like the producer’s former offerings
column9: Dame Fortune tries to be everything all at once
column10: making for a good listen with occasional lapses. Parts of it feel a little too on the nose—like “The Roaming Hoard
column11: ” a kinetic funk track that loses a touch of steam when the vocals kick in
column12: and “Band of Matron Saints
column13: ” an edgy rock track somewhat out of place compared with Dame Fortune’s more versatile songs. The producer’s style is commendable
column14: but the album is inconsistent
column15: and the noteworthy moments run the risk of getting lost. “The Sheboygan Left
column16: ” a shape-shifting instrumental near Dame’s beginning
column17: thrives from a gospel-esque collection of crashing drum cymbals and choral moans. On the celebratory ""We Come Alive
column18: long-time collaborator Son Little is given ample room to shine.

column1: As the album plays
column2: you get a strong sense that RJD2 is traveling towards something. There's a road ahead that he's yet to endure
column3: a path toward a destination he knows nothing about. Of course this isn't new for the producer. After all these years
column4: it seems RJD2 is still searching for some sort of shade amongst the chaos
column5: a place away from the pack. Dame Fortune is about the journey to some sort of eutopia—which for RJD2
column6: is likely full of bright
column7:
panoramic views.
