column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/23072/homepage_large.6006f56e.jpg|Genesis|29181.0|Domo Genesis|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Odd Future']|2016-03-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:48:34.808686|"

It was always difficult to figure out where exactly Domo Genesis fit in with Odd Future. Earl Sweatshirt was its teen prodigy
column2: Frank Ocean its silent genius
column3: and <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/29179-tyler-the-creator/"">Tyler
column4: the Creator its radical leader. In the beginning
column5: Domo seemed like merely another warm body to justify the ""collective"" tag; his lethargic
column6: professional weed carrier raps never really complementing the anarchist shouts of his teen rebel cohorts. But eventually he carved out space for himself on sheer tenacity
column7: becoming more technically proficient and simply rapping harder. As the collective dissolved around him
column8: he continued to be its steadiest member.

column1: His Odd Future Records debut
column2: Genesis
column3: is the culmination of his years of consistency
column4: the result of existing on the fringes of his friends’ fame and trying to earn his keep. ""If you don’t like this song they gon’ turn my lights off
column5: Domo Genesis painfully reminds listeners on ""All Night
column6: and throughout Genesis he raps like it
column7: spitting coiling phrases densely populated with slant rhymes. He spends much of its time searching for answers
column8: trying to piece together a sensible reason to keep rapping. Over the course of the album’s running time
column9: he finds one: he’s logged way too many hours to just quit now.

column1: It’d be easy to discount Domo Genesis strictly as a stoner rapper
column2: especially since his second single
column3: ""Go (Gas)
column4: featuring smokers of note Wiz Khalifa and Juicy J
column5: is packed with references to the drug (many from vocal straightedge rapper Tyler
column6: in the vein of his appearance on ""Rolling Papers""). But that’d be reductive. Domo Genesis can be a thoughtful writer. His paranoia starts to get the better of him on ""Questions
column7: which is a rabbit hole of internal doubt
column8: and he communicates much of the internal conflict with his voice alone
column9: which is cutting and combative. The flute-driven ""One Below
column10: a song prefaced by words from his mother
column11: delves into how industry politics have reframed his outlook
column12: rapping jarring lines like ""I’ma take all of mine if they’ve got nothing to give/ The lack of inspiration had me chasing broken ideas"" and ""my life story gotta be worth somebody’s time."" If anything
column13: Domo seems to be sobering up.

column1: The subtle
column2: soulful production
column3: from Christian Rich
column4: Sha Money XL
column5: Sap
column6: and Cam O’bi
column7: gives him mellow headspace from which to unspool his musings. When he raps over the elegant vocal chop on ""Coming Back
column8: with one of his most tightly wound verses
column9: his bars snap into the pockets left by the sweet
column10: retreating voice. But there are kinks: Sometimes the hooks on Genesis get wonky
column11: there are portions of the record that feel unfinished (like the second half of ""Wanderer"")
column12: and every now and then Domo will sneak in a groaner. But for the most part
column13: Genesis is a revelation. ""I got knowledge for every dollar made
column14: so look at me now/ I'm scared of none of my flaws
column15: they got 'em shook of me now/ So if you ever had a doubt about it
column16: it shouldn’t be now
column17: he raps on ""Awkward Groove."" Now that the Odd Future bubble has burst
column18:
Domo Genesis is finally figuring out his worth.

column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Firehouse 12']|2016-03-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:48:35.475842|"

Anthony Braxton contains multitudes—perhaps to a greater extent than any other composer alive today. The saxophonist hasn’t demonstrated this merely by playing with a diverse range of icons that includes Dave Brubeck
column3: Max Roach
column4: and Cecil Taylor. Nor has he done so solely by serving as a teacher and mentor to younger talents like Mary Halvorson and Steve Lehman. Instead
column5: Braxton’s hybrid-sound identity is due to the staggering variety of projects he has undertaken as a bandleader.

column1: In the 1970s
column2: while recording for the major label-funded Arista imprint
column3: Braxton signaled an intention to play in multiple creative arenas
column4: sequencing his madly accelerated bebop compositions alongside electronic-music explorations. He composed music for multiple piano virtuosos. He produced one of the great post-Ellington big band albums
column5: with Creative Orchestra Music 1976. Toward the end of his Arista contract
column6: Braxton submitted a triple-LP recording of a modern classical piece ""for four orchestras."" (His major label deal was not renewed.)

column1: When Braxton lost corporate support
column2: he reacted by expanding his ambition. He began composing a twelve-opera cycle
column3: titled Trillium. Though each one sounds like nothing else in the classical catalog
column4: works in this series do bear traces of European modernists like Iannis Xenakis and Karlheinz Stockhausen. At other points
column5: Braxton has interpreted early-jazz standards (sometimes furrowing the brows of period specialists). And he’s fielded a succession of smaller ensembles focused on his original music and growing catalog of ""systems""—which often bear mystic monikers like ""Ghost Trance Music"" or ""Diamond Curtain Wall Music."" Some of his most recent concepts require collaborators to handle the intercession of electronics
column6: or to navigate scores that look like paintings.

column1: For those who are interested
column2: this all begs the question: Where to start? Picking up the box set that collects all the famous Arista projects remains a solid bet. Those looking for a less-expensive opening gambit can opt to sample the winning run of albums Braxton recorded for the Black Saint label
column3: in the 1980s. The Complete Braxton 1971 is another comparatively bite-sized
column4: double-album look at the madcap idea factory. Though there is also now a new contender on the scene for the curious-but-uninitiated. (Or
column5: as Braxton prefers to call such listeners
column6: ""friendly experiencers."") And this record hails from a much more recent concept.

column1: 3 Compositions (EEMHM) 2011 is a triple-CD/download release that includes the first studio realization of Braxton’s ""Echo Echo Mirror House Music."" Here
column2: Braxton and six bandmates play their usual instruments
column3: while also ""wielding"" iPods that contain the bulk of Braxton’s discography. Each musician uses their hardware to pipe selections of old recordings into the live-performance mix. Over time
column4: the resulting blend of improvisation
column5: score-reading and fragmentary drops from past albums has a compelling
column6: hypnotic effect. Prior live-concert recordings of the ""Echo Echo"" concept have sounded comparatively tinny. But the studio where this was recorded
column7: which also doubles as an intimate venue
column8: affords Braxton a well-separated stereo mix that rewards listener exploration. (There’s also a ""pure audio"" Blu-ray version of the album available.)

column1: The hour-long performances on each disc often suggest installation art soundscapes more than they recall past composed-and-improvised landmarks like the Free Jazz LP led by Ornette Coleman—a saxophone mentor who gave Braxton housing
column2: early on
column3: in New York. And unlike the environment-heavy sound works you’ll find in some contemporary museum exhibits
column4: Braxton’s miasma is built from a rich variety of source materials that can make misty experimentalism feel fully active and alive. Chalk it up as a side benefit of 50 years spent in the avant-trenches
column5: working to discover new sounds.

column1: On an initial listen to the first disc—aka ""Composition No. 372""— I started out by trying to keep track of all the old-school inserts. I noticed a piquant ensemble march that sounded like recent ""Ghost Trance Music
column2: as well as the more clearly identifiable
column3: hard-riffing lines of ""Composition No. 40M"" (as played on the album Five Pieces 1975).This endeavor soon started to seem like a point-missing exercise
column4: and after letting go of the effort to distinguish past from present
column5: the overall wash of the experience quickly seemed like the best possible way to experience this setting.

column1: Braxton suggests as much in the section of his liner notes that bears the heading ""How To Listen to This Music
column2: where he writes: ""Don’t worry about it - have a fun listening experience in a music that more and more is like life itself. Suddenly something will emerge that was composed 40 years ago
column3: and that something will be placed next to something composed last year. It’s OK
column4: just let it happen. This is a ‘dream state’ sonic environment that is constantly changing. I find myself thinking of the movie Prometheus where the cyber hero has discovered an image projection hologram that he can walk inside of and manipulate
column5: or play with."" (Braxton’s liner notes
column6: like his music
column7: can turn sharply from academic phraseology to colloquial joking and vernacular references.) So
column8: with the composer’s blessing
column9: you’re invited to tune in and out at will. Put on 10 minutes from a set while getting ready to leave the house. Let a different section score a subway ride. Or clear an evening and sink into the aggregate experience.

column1: Throughout
column2: tricky chorus-writing from Braxton operas like Trillium E dances with classic solo-saxophone explorations as well as live-guitar work by Braxton bandmates like Mary Halvorson. Sometimes you get a group of vintage Braxtons
column3: wailing on different saxophones at once
column4: that is interrupted by the in-studio vibraphone playing of Aaron Siegel. By braiding together the artist’s music dramas
column5: large-ensemble jazz opuses
column6: and freer group-improvisations
column7: 3 Compositions (EEMHM) 2011 ultimately achieves something that no ""Braxton Sampler"" album has ever quite managed to pull off. By giving us an aerial survey of a large and varied sonic landscape
column8: it cuts down on the cognitive stress that can result from trying to ""process"" such a defiantly diverse career. It’s such an elegant solution to the contemporary anxiety about information overload that it might have made John Cage crack a Zen smile.

column1: And if you find yourself wanting more
column2: you can definitely get more. With some artists
column3: 16 CDs and two Blu-ray discs would be sufficient for capturing a career—though that’s merely the physical-media tally required to hold Braxton’s early-2016 releases. Two other box sets
column4: released simultaneously with (EEMHM) 2011
column5: appear on the composer’s own New Braxton House label. The more noteworthy effort is Trillium J
column6: the composer’s most recently performed four-act music drama. The librettos of Braxton’s operas blend his philosophical analysis of culture-at-large with absurdist comedic setups that often refuse to resolve. That postmodern dramaturgy fits with the orchestral language
column7: which can lean heavily on thick
column8: atonal cadences
column9: before sliding into a square dance without warning. (Seriously
column10: that happens in Act I.)

column1: Braxton’s ability to independently field an orchestra that can produce compelling performances of complex
column2: multi-hour works for the stage is a testament to his impresario’s pluck. Fittingly
column3: Braxton cites a range of dramatic influences that includes Wagner
column4: Stockhausen and Walt Disney. (So Kanye West has company
column5: on that last one.) This recording of Trillium J benefits from a Blu-ray supplement that presents a full live-performance version from the Brooklyn venue Roulette
column6: as well. In general
column7: the CDs in the box offer crisper performances—with the orchestra in particular savoring details in the studio that were missed in the live moment. But since opera is also a visual medium
column8: and because it has so occupied this composer for decades
column9: the Blu-ray version offers a rare chance to fully appreciate the seriously oddball aesthetic of his ongoing Trillium project.

column1: Switching lanes again
column2: it’s the legacy of swing—specifically
column3: the music composed by midcentury pianist Lennie Tristano and his associates—that anchors another 7xCD box
column4: titled Quintet (Tristano) 2014. This is the release that is most explicitly for the Braxton-diehards who have kept track of his prior ""jazz standards"" projects. Though for those listeners
column5: there is idiosyncratic value here
column6: too. In contrast with an earlier investigation of this composer’s work (the much easier-to-digest Eight (+3) Tristano Compositions 1989)
column7: here Braxton plays not a lick of saxophone
column8: instead holding down the piano chair in the group. In conversation
column9: he’s straightforward about his limitations on the instrument. (“I don’t kid myself!"" he recently told The New York Times. ""I’m a self-taught piano player who tries to continue learning more."") But he is capable of bringing a blocky
column10: Sun Ra-derived touch to Tristano compositions like ""Lennie’s Pennies.""

column1: If you’re wondering whether Braxton still reserves any time for shredding on his main axe—the answer is yes. It’s just that he’s not currently using his own distribution channels to feature an aspect of his art that’s already been documented on the hundreds of recordings that fill his Echo Echo Mirror House Music iPods. So it’s up to a small Brazilian label
column2: Selo SESC
column3: to bring us a notable recent live performance from São Paulo.

column1: Generically titled Ao Vivo Jazz Na Fábrica (Google Translate renders this ""Live Jazz at Work"") the album features Braxton on multiple saxophones—alto
column2: soprano
column3: and sopranino—as well as his regular guitarist Halvorson
column4: trumpeter Taylor Ho Bynum
column5: and another saxophonist
column6: Ingrid Laubrock (who often focuses on tenor playing). This group navigates the painting-scores and electronics of Braxton’s ""Diamond Curtain Wall"" music with the assurance of seasoned collaborators. (A consistent highlight of the first set is Braxton’s interaction with Halvorson’s rock-ish guitar progressions.) While his solos can careen with rapid groupings of notes and harsh rhythmic patterns
column7: the tone of Braxton’s playing sometimes feels feather-soft. The disparity between the aggression of the melodic line and the lilt of its execution makes for a frequently thrilling experience.

column1: Even more impressive than this protean output is the way these aesthetically diverged aspects of Braxton’s art all seem to converge on a central
column2: spiritual impulse—one that he outlined in the liner notes of his 1968 debut
column3: 3 Compositions of New Jazz: ""You are your music. … If you try to vibrate toward the good
column4: that’s where your music will come from."" It's a simple sounding idea. Though because the world is more complex than inspirational koans commonly allow
column5: realizing the objective can require multiple modes of effort. Contemplative sound-installations
column6: humorously experimental operas
column7: reinterpretations of classic swing
column8: and<span class=""s1""> serene
column9: small-group free-jazz with electronics: the common thread here is Braxton’s curious and warm-hearted openness
column10: perceptible even when his music verges on extreme cacophony. It’s a charming
column11: insightful approach for an avant-garde sound artist to pursue. And it can prove addictive for ""friendly experiencers
column12:
too.

This group navigates the painting-scores and electronics of Braxton’s ""Diamond Curtain Wall"" music with the assurance of seasoned collaborators. (A consistent highlight of the first set is Braxton’s interaction with Halvorson’s rock-ish guitar progressions.) While his solos can careen with rapid groupings of notes and harsh rhythmic patterns
column7: the tone of Braxton’s playing sometimes feels feather-soft. The disparity between the aggression of the melodic line and the lilt of its execution makes for a frequently thrilling experience.

column1: 2|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23124/homepage_large.6cfe8a08.jpg|Quintet (Tristano) 2014|11316.0|Anthony Braxton|['Jazz'

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New Braxton House']|2016-03-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:48:35.475842|"

Anthony Braxton contains multitudes—perhaps to a greater extent than any other composer alive today. The saxophonist hasn’t demonstrated this merely by playing with a diverse range of icons that includes Dave Brubeck
column3: Max Roach
column4: and Cecil Taylor. Nor has he done so solely by serving as a teacher and mentor to younger talents like Mary Halvorson and Steve Lehman. Instead
column5: Braxton’s hybrid-sound identity is due to the staggering variety of projects he has undertaken as a bandleader.

column1: In the 1970s
column2: while recording for the major label-funded Arista imprint
column3: Braxton signaled an intention to play in multiple creative arenas
column4: sequencing his madly accelerated bebop compositions alongside electronic-music explorations. He composed music for multiple piano virtuosos. He produced one of the great post-Ellington big band albums
column5: with Creative Orchestra Music 1976. Toward the end of his Arista contract
column6: Braxton submitted a triple-LP recording of a modern classical piece ""for four orchestras."" (His major label deal was not renewed.)

column1: When Braxton lost corporate support
column2: he reacted by expanding his ambition. He began composing a twelve-opera cycle
column3: titled Trillium. Though each one sounds like nothing else in the classical catalog
column4: works in this series do bear traces of European modernists like Iannis Xenakis and Karlheinz Stockhausen. At other points
column5: Braxton has interpreted early-jazz standards (sometimes furrowing the brows of period specialists). And he’s fielded a succession of smaller ensembles focused on his original music and growing catalog of ""systems""—which often bear mystic monikers like ""Ghost Trance Music"" or ""Diamond Curtain Wall Music."" Some of his most recent concepts require collaborators to handle the intercession of electronics
column6: or to navigate scores that look like paintings.

column1: For those who are interested
column2: this all begs the question: Where to start? Picking up the box set that collects all the famous Arista projects remains a solid bet. Those looking for a less-expensive opening gambit can opt to sample the winning run of albums Braxton recorded for the Black Saint label
column3: in the 1980s. The Complete Braxton 1971 is another comparatively bite-sized
column4: double-album look at the madcap idea factory. Though there is also now a new contender on the scene for the curious-but-uninitiated. (Or
column5: as Braxton prefers to call such listeners
column6: ""friendly experiencers."") And this record hails from a much more recent concept.

column1: 3 Compositions (EEMHM) 2011 is a triple-CD/download release that includes the first studio realization of Braxton’s ""Echo Echo Mirror House Music."" Here
column2: Braxton and six bandmates play their usual instruments
column3: while also ""wielding"" iPods that contain the bulk of Braxton’s discography. Each musician uses their hardware to pipe selections of old recordings into the live-performance mix. Over time
column4: the resulting blend of improvisation
column5: score-reading and fragmentary drops from past albums has a compelling
column6: hypnotic effect. Prior live-concert recordings of the ""Echo Echo"" concept have sounded comparatively tinny. But the studio where this was recorded
column7: which also doubles as an intimate venue
column8: affords Braxton a well-separated stereo mix that rewards listener exploration. (There’s also a ""pure audio"" Blu-ray version of the album available.)

column1: The hour-long performances on each disc often suggest installation art soundscapes more than they recall past composed-and-improvised landmarks like the Free Jazz LP led by Ornette Coleman—a saxophone mentor who gave Braxton housing
column2: early on
column3: in New York. And unlike the environment-heavy sound works you’ll find in some contemporary museum exhibits
column4: Braxton’s miasma is built from a rich variety of source materials that can make misty experimentalism feel fully active and alive. Chalk it up as a side benefit of 50 years spent in the avant-trenches
column5: working to discover new sounds.

column1: On an initial listen to the first disc—aka ""Composition No. 372""— I started out by trying to keep track of all the old-school inserts. I noticed a piquant ensemble march that sounded like recent ""Ghost Trance Music
column2: as well as the more clearly identifiable
column3: hard-riffing lines of ""Composition No. 40M"" (as played on the album Five Pieces 1975).This endeavor soon started to seem like a point-missing exercise
column4: and after letting go of the effort to distinguish past from present
column5: the overall wash of the experience quickly seemed like the best possible way to experience this setting.

column1: Braxton suggests as much in the section of his liner notes that bears the heading ""How To Listen to This Music
column2: where he writes: ""Don’t worry about it - have a fun listening experience in a music that more and more is like life itself. Suddenly something will emerge that was composed 40 years ago
column3: and that something will be placed next to something composed last year. It’s OK
column4: just let it happen. This is a ‘dream state’ sonic environment that is constantly changing. I find myself thinking of the movie Prometheus where the cyber hero has discovered an image projection hologram that he can walk inside of and manipulate
column5: or play with."" (Braxton’s liner notes
column6: like his music
column7: can turn sharply from academic phraseology to colloquial joking and vernacular references.) So
column8: with the composer’s blessing
column9: you’re invited to tune in and out at will. Put on 10 minutes from a set while getting ready to leave the house. Let a different section score a subway ride. Or clear an evening and sink into the aggregate experience.

column1: Throughout
column2: tricky chorus-writing from Braxton operas like Trillium E dances with classic solo-saxophone explorations as well as live-guitar work by Braxton bandmates like Mary Halvorson. Sometimes you get a group of vintage Braxtons
column3: wailing on different saxophones at once
column4: that is interrupted by the in-studio vibraphone playing of Aaron Siegel. By braiding together the artist’s music dramas
column5: large-ensemble jazz opuses
column6: and freer group-improvisations
column7: 3 Compositions (EEMHM) 2011 ultimately achieves something that no ""Braxton Sampler"" album has ever quite managed to pull off. By giving us an aerial survey of a large and varied sonic landscape
column8: it cuts down on the cognitive stress that can result from trying to ""process"" such a defiantly diverse career. It’s such an elegant solution to the contemporary anxiety about information overload that it might have made John Cage crack a Zen smile.

column1: And if you find yourself wanting more
column2: you can definitely get more. With some artists
column3: 16 CDs and two Blu-ray discs would be sufficient for capturing a career—though that’s merely the physical-media tally required to hold Braxton’s early-2016 releases. Two other box sets
column4: released simultaneously with (EEMHM) 2011
column5: appear on the composer’s own New Braxton House label. The more noteworthy effort is Trillium J
column6: the composer’s most recently performed four-act music drama. The librettos of Braxton’s operas blend his philosophical analysis of culture-at-large with absurdist comedic setups that often refuse to resolve. That postmodern dramaturgy fits with the orchestral language
column7: which can lean heavily on thick
column8: atonal cadences
column9: before sliding into a square dance without warning. (Seriously
column10: that happens in Act I.)

column1: Braxton’s ability to independently field an orchestra that can produce compelling performances of complex
column2: multi-hour works for the stage is a testament to his impresario’s pluck. Fittingly
column3: Braxton cites a range of dramatic influences that includes Wagner
column4: Stockhausen and Walt Disney. (So Kanye West has company
column5: on that last one.) This recording of Trillium J benefits from a Blu-ray supplement that presents a full live-performance version from the Brooklyn venue Roulette
column6: as well. In general
column7: the CDs in the box offer crisper performances—with the orchestra in particular savoring details in the studio that were missed in the live moment. But since opera is also a visual medium
column8: and because it has so occupied this composer for decades
column9: the Blu-ray version offers a rare chance to fully appreciate the seriously oddball aesthetic of his ongoing Trillium project.

column1: Switching lanes again
column2: it’s the legacy of swing—specifically
column3: the music composed by midcentury pianist Lennie Tristano and his associates—that anchors another 7xCD box
column4: titled Quintet (Tristano) 2014. This is the release that is most explicitly for the Braxton-diehards who have kept track of his prior ""jazz standards"" projects. Though for those listeners
column5: there is idiosyncratic value here
column6: too. In contrast with an earlier investigation of this composer’s work (the much easier-to-digest Eight (+3) Tristano Compositions 1989)
column7: here Braxton plays not a lick of saxophone
column8: instead holding down the piano chair in the group. In conversation
column9: he’s straightforward about his limitations on the instrument. (“I don’t kid myself!"" he recently told The New York Times. ""I’m a self-taught piano player who tries to continue learning more."") But he is capable of bringing a blocky
column10: Sun Ra-derived touch to Tristano compositions like ""Lennie’s Pennies.""

column1: If you’re wondering whether Braxton still reserves any time for shredding on his main axe—the answer is yes. It’s just that he’s not currently using his own distribution channels to feature an aspect of his art that’s already been documented on the hundreds of recordings that fill his Echo Echo Mirror House Music iPods. So it’s up to a small Brazilian label
column2: Selo SESC
column3: to bring us a notable recent live performance from São Paulo.

column1: Generically titled Ao Vivo Jazz Na Fábrica (Google Translate renders this ""Live Jazz at Work"") the album features Braxton on multiple saxophones—alto
column2: soprano
column3: and sopranino—as well as his regular guitarist Halvorson
column4: trumpeter Taylor Ho Bynum
column5: and another saxophonist
column6: Ingrid Laubrock (who often focuses on tenor playing). This group navigates the painting-scores and electronics of Braxton’s ""Diamond Curtain Wall"" music with the assurance of seasoned collaborators. (A consistent highlight of the first set is Braxton’s interaction with Halvorson’s rock-ish guitar progressions.) While his solos can careen with rapid groupings of notes and harsh rhythmic patterns
column7: the tone of Braxton’s playing sometimes feels feather-soft. The disparity between the aggression of the melodic line and the lilt of its execution makes for a frequently thrilling experience.

column1: Even more impressive than this protean output is the way these aesthetically diverged aspects of Braxton’s art all seem to converge on a central

column4: that’s where your music will come from."" It's a simple sounding idea. Though because the world is more complex than inspirational koans commonly allow
column5: realizing the objective can require multiple modes of effort. Contemplative sound-installations
column6: humorously experimental operas

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23078/homepage_large.cd5eb576.jpg|Wuthering Drum|33591.0|Public Memory|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Felte']|2016-03-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:48:36.013699|"

Public Memory is the solo nom de plume of Robert Toher
column2: a Brooklyn-based musician who formerly served time as a member of Eraas and Apse. While those projects blurred the edges of rambling space rock and synthy post-punk
column3: Public Memory dives headlong down the electronic darkwave rabbit hole
column4: exploring a Korg-constructed sonic palette that weaves together a variety of primitive beats
column5: delicately employed samples (bells
column6: chimes
column7: the weeping of ghosts)
column8: and woozy electronics that sound as if they might have been recorded at the bottom of a lake. Created over the course of a year while Toher was temporarily decamped in Los Angeles
column9: Wuthering Drum is a work of restrained gloom—a remarkably textured electronic record whose minimalist tendencies keep it from collapsing under the weight of its own moribund aesthetic.

column1: One of the problems with making dark electronic music has to do with the fact that so much of it already exists. Music that is already so immediately in thrall to its influences often comes off as pale imitation
column2: a weird facsimile of something we’ve heard again and again and again. It’s to Toher’s credit that Wuthering Drum largely avoids goth pastiche. The ten tracks offered here rarely stray too far past the three-minute mark
column3: which means there isn’t much time for the songs to meander or overstay their welcome. While it’s easy to play spot the influences with the songs on Wuthering Drum—there are nods to krautrock
column4: as well as songs that conjure the ghosts of Fad Gadget
column5: Suspiria-era Goblin and early Cabaret Voltaire—Toher largely succeeds in creating an electronic landscape that is wholly his own.

column1: Rather than provide a series of peaks and valleys
column2: Wuthering Drum is mostly one sustained valley in which the predominant vibe is dirge. “Mirror” moves with all the percussive relentlessness of a chain gang—a chugging beat offset by the sound of shakers
column3: tambourine and celestial bells. Elsewhere
column4: “Ringleader” and “As You Wish” unspool in largely the same manner—somber
column5: elegantly plodding
column6: chorus-free–with Toher’s disembodied vocals floating throughout. It’s only in the album's second half that the inertia finally breaks. “Zig Zag” is the record’s closest flirtation with a pop moment (via a finger-snap of a drum beat and a spooky synth hook) while “Earwig” breaks the sustained tension by introducing just a hint of what sounds like sampled steel drums and the faintest crack of what could be the lazer beam sound effect from an old Atari game. It’s hard to know
column7: actually
column8: since these sounds flitter into and out of the songs so quickly and quietly that they sometimes barely register; it’s only after repeated listens that subtle layering in these compositions start to make sense.

column1: If there’s a problem with Wuthering Drum it might just be a lack of dynamics. All the songs are definitely of a piece and the album provides no shortage of sustained atmosphere
column2: but there is a stifling sameness to these songs that makes them hard to differentiate. Adding to that are Toher’s vocals—a kind of warbly falsetto that brings to mind the warped new wave of an old Blank Dogs record
column3: or something like the sound of a very tremulous apparition anxiously singing to you from another room. As a result
column4: the vocals hover at the edges of these songs with a kind of hopeless disaffection that eventually becomes numbing
column5: you keep wishing for a howl or a yelp or a scream that might punctuate the airless
column6: suffocating universe in which these songs seem to exist. That is not to say that the record is not often quite beautiful—in fact
column7: the record sounds amazing—but you can’t help but wish that Toher might let his hair down a little more. Too often these songs pull back just when you want them to crack open—rather than build to some sort of satisfying conclusion
column8: they simply end.

column1: While lots of ostensibly “dark” music suffers lyrically from the cliché of sounding like tortured teenage poetry
column2: the songs on Wuthering Drum eschew hackneyed doom-and-gloom in favor of near incomprehensibility. When Toher sings about “an alleged near disaster / long toothed man that runs” on album-opener “Heir” it’s all but impossible to know what/who he’s talking about
column3: but ultimately that’s also part of the record’s charm. The evocative
column4: fractured nature of Toher’s lyrics—paired with the austere sonic landscapes and willful ambiguity of these songs—is what sets Public Memory apart from so many other like-minded electronic acts mining similar territory. When the elements all come together in the right way—as they do on the record’s centerpiece
column5: “Cul de Sac”–the results can be stunning. Over a funereal beat and a lilting piano melody that could serve as a long lost sonic cousin to Joy Division’s ""The Eternal
column6: Toher articulates the profound isolation at the album’s core: “I live in small room with all my things in place
column7: ” he sings
column8: “I see no reason to pretend / lock the front door / shut the curtains / it’s a matter of dissent.” Wuthering Drum is a work seemingly unconcerned about giving you what you want
column9:
but what it does provide is almost enough.

It's the norm now
column2: but at the birth of modern dance music in the 1970s
column3: DJs
column4: producers and remixers were rarely the same person. As influential as his Loft parties were
column5: you'd be hard-pressed to find a record bearing the credit of ""a David Mancuso production."" And while Tom Moulton invented the remix (as well as the 12"" single)
column6: outside of the Sandpiper tapes
column7: his legacy wasn't made behind the decks. So while Lawrence Philpot was well on his way to becoming Larry Levan
column8: the greatest DJ of all time (at the helm of the most revered club of all time
column9: the Paradise Garage)
column10: as Tim Lawrence put it in Love Saves the Day
column11: ""even at the early stage of his remixing career the Garage DJ had created such an important canon that even when he wasn't spinning it was more than likely that somewhere else he was being spun.""

column1: That spinning/ spun dichotomy is part of what defines Levan and his lasting legacy as well as what makes boiling down his genius difficult. Try to put Levan into a handy package and it becomes tricky. Do you capture his DJ sets in situ? Do you focus entirely on the work rendered for a single disco label
column2: like Salsoul or West End? Or do you draw from a back catalog big enough to contain Levan's remixes as well as what he himself would have spun? The strength of Universal's two-disc Genius of Time lies in the latter option
column3: now having the biggest catalog to choose from
column4: be it Island
column5: Motown A&M and more.

column1: The prolific Levan had over 250 remix credits to his name
column2: so Genius of Time has its work cut out cherrypicking them and forming a coherent set. And in drawing on Universal's holdings
column3: it still means not licensing some stone Levan-touched classics: Instant Funk's ""I Got My Mind Made Up
column4: Skyy's ""First Time Around
column5: Taana Gardener's ""Work That Body"" and Inner Life's ""Ain't No Mountain High Enough
column6: to name just a few. The disco sound of the late '70s is eschewed to instead focus on the sinewy
column7: synth-laced pop of the early '80s. Nevertheless
column8: its twenty-two tracks capture the slippery
column9: pliant
column10: ecstatic sound that defined Levan as a producer
column11: DJ and high priest for a club night deemed ""Saturday Mass"" by its attendees.

column1: The opener ""Life is Something Special
column2: credited to NYC Peech Boys
column3: shows Levan's mastery behind the boards. The set is bookended by this track as well as the most seductive song about growing impatient ever set to tape (""Don't Make Me Wait""). ""Special"" extends for a slow-rolling nine minutes
column4: and it's so expansive one could parallel park in its stereo field. The song is little more than a stately piano line
column5: a synth that spumes like a squeezed juicebox
column6: a rock guitar solo
column7: handclaps so echo-y they seem to come down from heaven and the group harmonizing the title. With so few moving parts
column8: one might imagine it grows tedious
column9: but Levan manipulates everything so that each sound strides towards you and then veers away
column10: cruising you yet remaining ever elusive. As it continues to unfold
column11: the song sublimates so as to be a mantra of uplift. In hindsight of the AIDS epidemic that would soon ravage the Garage's audience and owner (not to mention Keith Haring
column12: who designed the Peech Boys's album cover)
column13: decades later it sounds more and more like a song of resistance and resilience in the face of impending death.

column1: As a gay African-American making his dancefloors writhe as one
column2: Levan's sets often highlighted R&B divas
column3: so it makes sense that his production skills were at their finest when he partnered with female singers. Esther Williams's ""I'll Be Your Pleasure"" is the most classic disco of the set and Levan adds a lavish swirl of strings and percussion to her husky voice. With a rollicking piano
column4: rattling tambourine and tricky-metered hiccup right at the song's chorus
column5: he teases out the gospel
column6: R&B
column7: soul and jazz roots of Dee Dee Bridgewater's voice on ""Bad For Me."" For Syreeta
column8: the onetime wife of Stevie Wonder
column9: ""Can't Shake Your Love"" shows Levan at his spry best
column10: adding bass squelches
column11: sax squeals
column12: rolling piano and synth lines that fidget like five year-olds on a church pew.

column1: Levan's greatest muse
column2: though
column3: was Gwen Guthrie
column4: and the mini-LP Padlock epitomized the sound of the Garage. Smooth
column5: subtle
column6: never one to over-sentimentalize her lines
column7: Guthrie found the perfect foil in Levan
column8: who remixed the tapes of Guthrie at Compass Point (already boasting a formidable band in Sly & Robbie
column9: Wally Badarou and Steve Stanley) to sublime effect. The four tracks presented here are bright and shadowy
column10: psychedelic yet body-moving
column11: seductive and ebullient
column12: cool and sultry. You'll never regard a PB&J sandwich the same way after hearing Gwen Guthrie purr: ""Spread yourself over me like peanut butter."" It's one of the finest amalgams of singer and producer of that decade
column13: equivocal to Jellybean with Madonna or Janet with Jam & Lewis.

column1: It was short-lived however
column2: and as the decade wore on
column3: the closing of the Paradise Garage and the high human cost of AIDS began to take a toll on Levan's psyche and work (along with his ravenous heroin habit). But as Genius of Time shows a new generation of dance fans
column4: Levan was a singular talent. As Moulton put it: ""He had the feel. He would always sacrifice the technical if it meant that he could have the feel
column5:
and that's the most important thing in music."" You can feel that in every track here.

When do you last remember a respected band replacing a lead singer and actually getting better? This is the central anomaly of the brilliant and brave Slow Forever
column2: the first album in seven years from the reborn metal duo Cobalt. For a decade
column3: Cobalt made mad
column4: warped dashes through black metal
column5: summoning the spirit and language of hero Ernest Hemingway alongside the imagery and intensity of singer Phil McSorley’s stints in the U.S. Army. But without McSorley
column6: Cobalt has opened its sound
column7: fully embracing the blues
column8: country
column9: hardcore
column10: and hard rock strains that have long been latent in its music. Slow Forever is as accessible as it is aggressive
column11: with magnetic hooks
column12: shout-along mantras
column13: and sparkling riffs all anchoring this eighty-minute maelstrom. It is an electrifying
column14: enthralling opus.

column1: Two years ago
column2: it seemed Cobalt would never make another record. Half a decade had passed since the pair’s landmark Gin
column3: when
column4: in March 2014
column5: McSorley announced he was out; a month later
column6: he was back in
column7: set to work on new material with childhood friend and Cobalt co-founder Erik Wunder. But in December of that year
column8: McSorley took a series of brutally misogynistic
column9: homophobic online shots at other bands. Wunder cut him loose. In retrospect
column10: it seems like serendipity
column11: as Lord Mantis
column12: Charlie Fell’s manic sludge band from Chicago
column13: <a href=""http://www.metalsucks.net/2015/03/12/exclusive-lord-mantis-ex-frontman-charlie-fell-band-blow/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">was publicly splitting at the seams
column14: too. Wunder asked Fell—""the only guy that came to mind when I thought about somebody who could replace Phil
column15: he has said—to enlist. They spent the third quarter of 2015 reinventing Cobalt in a Colorado recording studio.

column1: Those fraught beginnings ripple through Slow Forever
column2: where the songs stem from abject depravity
column3: or from a mindset where nothing goes right and hope is only a useless four-letter word. Images of drug abuse
column4: sexual frustration
column5: emotional exhaustion
column6: self-mutilation
column7: wanton violence
column8: and outright dejection flash by one by one
column9: suggesting a Charles Bukowski biopic produced by David Cronenberg. ""I am not a man/I am just a dog
column10: Fell shrieks and repeats above clattering drums and bullying guitars within the first six minutes. ""Condone the act of self-destruction
column11: he roars much later
column12: with militant drums and a clarion riff buttressing his pronouncement. ""A ritual/And bury it
column13: bury it in the veins of lovers."" Fell paints a sort of cosmic portrait with these very human flaws and faults. These failures—the ""pinnacle of the archetype
column14: as he puts it at one point—are the natural order
column15: the way it will always be. ""The past in a pile of ash
column16: forgotten in the cycle
column17: he offers by way of summary.

column1: Even during instrumental interludes and extended introductions
column2: Cobalt seems to be preparing for conflict
column3: for coming face-to face with the demons inside Fell’s words. ""Beast Whip
column4: a song about perpetual dissatisfaction
column5: batters its subject with a series of blast beats and D-beats; Fell seems to be screaming at his own thoughts
column6: demanding more from himself. When ""Elephant Graveyard"" takes up the cycle of addiction
column7: the music illustrates the mania by inciting a circle pit before fading into a long
column8: slow comedown.

column1: Fell is more versatile and nuanced than McSorley
column2: his predecessor. His work here even suggests a range and finesse that his time in Lord Mantis didn’t
column3: firmly establishing him as one of metal’s great new vocalists. During ""Cold Breaker
column4: he launches from a hardcore yammer to a doom-metal roar
column5: alternately summoning the Dead Kennedys and Eyehategod as the music shifts around him. When he emits pained

Like a lot of things related to White Material

column5: suggests a hodgepodge; it also suggests that the material inside is old news (and there's nothing worse in electronic music

column1: But Scenes 2012-2015
column2: which the two RISD grads recorded over three years in a handful of home studios around New York
column3: is no hodgepodge. It's a proper album—the kind that conventional wisdom says that dance music is no good at producing. It's got a beginning

column10: and even a flickering
column11: 144-BPM study in juke's full-throttle skip
column12: they're also unusually cohesive. They make do with a pared-down set of sounds that give the impression of coming from a modest set of gear
column13: and they avoid samples
column14: advanced digital sound design
column15: and intricate computer trickery in favor of long
column16: linear synthesizer and drum machine patterns
column17: loosely and elegantly woven together. The palette is muted but not self-consciously lo-fi
column18: and the mood oscillates between dreamy and melancholy
column19: though not without a playful undercurrent.

column1: Unlike Lustwerk's music
column2: all nine tracks are instrumental
column3: aside from the occasional garbled hint of ring-modulated speech buried deep in the mix
column4: like an intercepted transmission from across the cosmos. The two musicians' respective styles surface in shifting proportions: ""Above the Waves
column5: with its squelchy funk bass and almost jazzy Rhodes keys
column6: recalls Lustwerk's solo productions; ""ITCZ
column7: a fuzzed-out daydream for wispy chords and a clunky vintage CR-78 drum machine

column9: from last year's City EP. What predominates is their shared appreciation for ’90s electronic music: Much of the album brings to mind the sound of R&S Records and its Apollo sub-label from the mid ’90s
column10: when artists like Ken Ishii and Biosphere were fusing ambient and techno in exciting ways. ""Session"" has the crisp
column11: sparkling quality of artists like Morgan Geist and Titonton Duvanté; the stunning ""Whitesands
column12: which closes the album with a moody swirl of plangent fifths and crunchy percussion
column13: might be a lost Aphex Twin or Autechre demo circa 1994.

column1: The centerpieces of the album are ""ITCZ"" and ""Unnatural City
column2: which spin mechanical clatter
column3: shimmering chords
column4: and deep-diving bass frequencies—in the latter
column5: there's no bassline to speak of
column6: just an 808 kick plunging unfathomably low—into sedate
column7: hypnotic configurations. ""ITCZ
column8: rolling out ceaseless son clave rhythms
column9: is plodding and steady
column10: while ""Unnatural City"" moves at a fleet
column11: rolling clip
column12: but what they share in common is an unusual balance between stasis and dynamism. No single element dominates; every sound has equal weight
column13: from quicksilver pings to chalky snares. They're not so much songs as spatial fields: You enter and walk around
column14: admiring the ingenious architecture

they've come up with one of the year's most generously proportioned techno long-players—one far more sumptuous than its modest profile would ever suggest.

Dean Blunt is the kind of musician who inspires even the headiest of critics to admit in think pieces that their take was ""doomed from the start."" He is the kind of musician that has been dissected
column2: questioned
column3: and subject to the wildest interpretations
column4: theorizing
column5: and speculation. Even as he invites all this
column6: Blunt remains nearly impervious to any kind neat conclusion. And on April Fools day of this year
column7: like only Dean Blunt would do
column8: he is releasing a new album called BBF: Hosted by DJ Escrow
column9: under the banner of a possibly fictitious group called Babyfather. It is over 50 minutes long and stretches to an impossible 23 tracks. It brandishes a jaw dropping pièce de résistance of a cover depicting a Union Jack-decaled hoverboard overlooking a hazy London skyline.

column1: From the title
column2: it seems that Blunt is playing an obscure joke of some kind
column3: maybe flicking his nose at the mixtape culture found on Datpiff and Livemixtapes. In BBF
column4: Blunt (I think) alternates between a high-pitched Quasimoto-esque flow and his low baritone drawl. The squealing rap voice that haunts most of this album delivers some of the most important moments
column5: specifically a refrain that occurs three times (""Stealth
column6: ""Stealth Intro
column7: and ""Stealth Outro"") in the album: ""This makes me proud to be British."" This line is repeated over and over and over  again
column8: surrounded by a wash of saccharine strings
column9: and it verges on numbing. This refrain opens up the album
column10: and it stretches on painfully for several minutes
column11: a point at which most sane people would just stop listening.

column1: The rest of album splits itself between two attitudes
column2: a stream-of-consciousness confessional and a potpourri of ironic tropes directed at American hip-hop. It boasts some very snazzy features
column3: namely appearances from Arca and Micachu. But these tracks are red herrings; they prick the interest of someone scanning the tracklist
column4: but for the most part are extremely forgettable. In ""Killuminati"" he repeats ""another one
column5: an obvious joking nod to DJ Khaled. He hints at ""exclusives"" in ""Prolific Demons"" and tries on a mask of bravado in ""Meditations"" [ft. Arca]:  ""20 bands everyone can see/20 bands don't stand for me/20 bands got me up in the sky...Get these white girls out of my home."" This for the most part does not work for Blunt
column6: and the theme takes up more than half of the album. It might be the album’s narrative thrust and conceptual core
column7: but like a lot of Blunt’s concepts
column8: it’s overstated and hangs very loosely.

column1: When Blunt does make himself available and emotive it’s hard to ignore. These are the spots where the album starts to work. On ""Escrow 3"" he admits ""trust is a luxury I cannot afford"" and he doubts the veracity of his friendships: ""I couldn't tell who was real and who wasn't.""  His voice almost cracks as he asks ""If I die/would you cry?"" It's cathartic and feels vaguely shameful to be witnessing. The moment underscores that beneath the irony
column2: this is as vulnerable Blunt has ever been. It is a painfully raw
column3: emotionally generous
column4: politically charged
column5: intensely intelligent
column6: sometimes unlistenable album.The project is
column7: most of all
column8: a fascinating peek into the psyche of man who we are still miles away from understanding
column9:
and when I listen to I can only see a man in the distance getting farther and farther as I try to get closer.

Four years ago
column2: Sasha Frere-Jones wrote an article in The New Yorker called “Merzbiebs” where he conflated the music and process of Japanese noise icon Masami Akita (aka Merzbow) with the then-nascent tabloid pop machine of Justin Bieber. Frere-Jones made a very compelling case that the two
column3: while incommensurably disparate musically speaking
column4: were enviably talented and more similar than we’d like to realize
column5: ultimately deciding that they were “both worth hearing.” But that same argument could not be made in 2016. At this point
column6: Bieber is shifting rapidly
column7: releasing vibrant pop songs carved from strange and infectious sounds
column8: while Akita is mired in some very old tropes.

column1: Akita’s latest record
column2: Kouen Kyoudai
column3: is a collaboration with Eiko Ishibashi
column4: a Japanese singer and multi-instrumentalist who has released two Jim O’Rourke-produced albums of languorous J-pop over the last few years. According to the artists
column5: the two tracks that compose this album
column6: “Slide” and “Junglegym
column7: ” can be read as “contemporary takes on the avant-garde”—an increasingly meaningless marker often used by artists who want to paint themselves as utterly tasteful outsiders. They also stress that the tension of the music comes from “the human use of the tool” which is “made explicit as these works unfold in a storm of ecstatic human/instrument/interaction.” These pretentious statements create an air of importance
column8: suggesting the album only gains weight from its textural presentation. As for the music itself
column9: it fails to live up to the way it’s offered.

column1: Kouen Kyoudai’s two tracks both run more than 18 minutes
column2: and there is very little that distinguishes them other than the main analog instrument accompanying the field of noise. For “Slide” it's a drum set; for “Junglegym” a piano. But both are generally diminished by Akita’s noodling drone sounds
column3: which hog up too much space
column4: making it seem like Eiko’s contributions were little more than an afterthought. In this case
column5: the forceful drone is like the sonic equivalent of manspreading between subway seats. As the album wears on unchanged through almost 40 minutes
column6: it sounds more like an amorphous chunk of noises than an exploration of contemporary avant-garde.

column1: It’s a shame too. For decades
column2: Akita’s music has been chipping away at an allusive and important thesis: That music created with his array of noise-making tools can be life-affirming and express sublimity from such raw and uncontrollable forces. But a lofty presentation can create lofty expectations from a consumer of art. As such
column3:
the entire apparatus revolving around Kouen Kyoudai did it in. The album expects to be taken seriously. It demands to be evaluated under a different aesthetic criteria by pure virtue of its gravity. These demands could be met and accepted if the music here was more than a tired retread of endless philosophical dead-ends alongside a smattering of flashy noises.

Kamaiyah’s debut mixtape Good Night in the Ghetto initially comes across carefree and effortless
column2: which might seduce you into thinking it was easy to make. The songs are simple
column3: unfussy
column4: and full of space
column5: with a low-key mood meant less for a raucous house party and more for a casual basement hangout. Kamaiyah’s calling-card song
column6: ""How Does It Feel
column7: is here

column1: Good Night in the Ghetto's production is the aural equivalent of watching Too $hort and TLC videos half-asleep through one of Hype Williams’ custom ’90s fish-eye lenses—a blur of reference points from across hip-hop's glitziest decade. Kamaiyah is 20
column2: which means her earliest impressions of that decade’s music would have come around the time the industry was locked into a death spiral and rap was vanishing from the charts. Seen through this filter

column1: Besides
column2: Bay Area rap has been celebrating the power of silky Anita Baker and Sade keyboard patches for years. These sounds have been recreated so lovingly for so long that they've become a thread snaking through a wide range of music. Kamaiyah is part of a tradition that extends back to early-‘90s hits like Conscious Daughters’ ""Something to Ride to (Fonky Expedition)"" (she told Pitchfork that Conscious Daughter’s Karryl ""Special One"" Smith gave her the mixtape title) and continues today: the Trackademicks-produced ""Come Back"" could easily have been given to fellow East Bay artist J. Stalin
column3: whose music often has the same plush retro-funk feel.

column1: Kamaiyah stands out from her peers
column2: though
column3: with her appealingly natural presence. Her voice sounds as unaffected and assured singing as it does rapping
column4: and she writes big hooks: The chorus to ""Swing My Way"" is full-bodied enough to picture a shirtless male guest star belting it
column5: but she handles it herself
column6: her small voice giving off its own heat. The little interjection ""woopty woopty woo"" on ""Out the Bottle"" is fearsomely catchy
column7: ""I hope I don’t yelp this involuntarily in a roomful of strangers"" catchy. But it’s a detail
column8: a grace note on an album that never oversells anything. Restraint is a slippery virtue to enthusiastically trumpet
column9: but it usually marks the separation between an artist who can hold down a single and one who can comfortably occupy an album.

column1: This poise is what makes Kamaiyah someone worth spending time with. There's a great song on here in the Too $hort tradition (""Niggas"") about loving sex
column2: and severe disinterest in being obligated to have it with one person. But it’s not a sexual tall-tale meant to make Kamaiyah sound superhuman: ""Hit the back room come back
column3: my dress undid/ He gon’ zip it back before they notice we be fucking
column4: she sings playfully. On ""Freaky Freaks

column6: and b) something an affable-everyman like Devin the Dude has probably done in real life. Approachability is a cornerstone of Kamaiyah’s style.

column1: And then
column2: of course
column3: there’s her good-life ode ""How Does It Feel."" Despite some stiff competition
column4: it remains her best song
column5: something she implicitly acknowledges by reprising it for the introductory track ""I’m On."" It sounds even better on Good Night without eclipsing anything around it. The emotions on the tape—joy
column6: yearning—are never better expressed than in the two questions she poses in the chorus: ""How does it feel to be rich"" and ""How does it  feel to just live?"" The underlying subtext—that these might be two versions of the same question—is present

column9:
a cocked eyebrow and a meaningful pause from someone who’s confident enough to put it all out there in her own way and allow you a minute to catch up.

As is usually the case

not cacophonous forays into existential dread.

Most people don't come to Thermals albums for that stuff. They come for the shout-alongs and fist pumps

Margo Price has been gigging hard in Nashville for nearly a decade
column2: earning a reputation as a fierce live act but getting barely any attention from labels or radio programmers. In the last few months

column1: On Midwest Farmer's Daughter—whose title is clearly meant to echo Loretta Lynn's famous origin story—Price emerges as a woman struggling to reclaim her story from the Nashville machine and reset it in old-school honky-tonk tunes that split the difference between so many ampersands: country & western
column2: rock & roll
column3: rhythm & blues. It's an ambitious piece of music-making and storytelling
column4: featuring a road-hardened backing band called the Price Tags and a singer whose flinty voice conveys both a guarded vulnerability and a reckless scrappiness. She fiddles while Nashville burns on ""This Town Gets Around
column5: three minutes of inside baseball that details all the unscrupulous managers and sexist promoters who populate the industry like fleas on a hound. ""I guess it's me who gets the joke
column6: she sings. ""Maybe I'd be smarter if I played dumb.""

column1: On most of Daughter
column2: however
column3: Price is tough in conventional ways
column4: on songs that fit a bit more squarely with country traditions. She threatens a bar patron on the honky-tonk fight song ""About to Find Out
column5: drowns the devil on her shoulder with whisky and tequila on ""Since You Put Me Down
column6: welcomes a wayward lover on ""How the Mighty Have Fallen."" They're sturdy tunes
column7: strong examples of the country songwriting
column8: but they don't hit with the same force as the more obviously personal songs here. Daughter is best when it's specifically first-person
column9: when Price bends country to fit her own story rather than bend herself to fit the form. You root hard for Price to win these battles
column10:
even as you may find yourself wishing Midwest Farmer's Daughter could transcend the hype.

The ""mysterious European producer"" gambit is a standard and well-rehearsed gimmick by now
column3: with varying degrees of success: For every Burial you have 100 snide SOPHIEs. Berlin twosome Amnesia Scanner arrive in front of us with a terse press release
column4: full of mystery. They are self-described ""Xperienz Designers
column5: but they refuse to give any ""xplanations"" for what that means. Instead
column6: they provide the curious schmuck who’s opened their PR email with six unnamed hyperlinks. As you click along
column7: a pitch of absurdity slowly builds
column8: moving from reviews of their work in multiple languages (English
column9: Japanese
column10: German)
column11: to a suspicious zip file hosted on Mediafire
column12: and finally the homepage for the Protein Data Bank
column13: an archive for three-dimensional models of biological molecules (proteins
column14: nucleic acids
column15: and the like).

column1: Amnesia Scanner's website
column2: too
column3: is a cacophonous visual medley. Their Twitter and Facebook pages don’t offer much. We know they are affiliated with Berlin’s Janus collective (Lotic
column4: M.E.S.H.
column5: Kablam). They contributed to ""An Exit"" from Holly Herndon’s Platform
column6: and they produced a very interesting Mykki Blanco track two years ago. So there it is
column7: a skeleton of biography. Was the journey worth it? The music would have to be surpassingly vivid to stand out from its surrounding rhetoric. Luckly
column8: the gumshoe Google chase matches the music
column9: which feels like a puzzle that might kill you once you’ve solved it.

column1: By the numbers
column2: AS is misleadingly brief. The six tracks total to a slim 21 minutes
column3: but as a whole the album feels much longer that that. Each of the songs is prefaced by ""AS"" (""AS Wood Gas
column4: for example)
column5: which either signifies a contraction of the band’s name or one half of an unfinished metaphor. Titles like ""AS Atlas"" or ""AS Chingy"" just add another level of interpretative chaos. They beg the question of whether or not the song is supposed to embody the object it references. More likely than not
column6: it’s another trap door. Is it possible that they sample late '90s pop-rap superstar Chingy in ""AS Chingy""? That might have to be a mystery for another day.

column1: Describing the music of AS is similarly difficult. ""Electronic"" only suffices if you paint with the widest brush. Sure
column2: the music here was most likely made on a computer
column3: but at its core it is deeply organic. You may never hear a pre-made synth on AS. You are more likely to hear your gurgling stomach or something tumbling down a flight of stairs. These tracks are overflowing
column4: sloshing full of content
column5: and impossibly dense. They can suddenly and brutally evaporate the comforts of time’s steady flow by queering what you think three or four minutes is supposed to feel like.

column1: If there is a steady descriptor for AS
column2: it's ""unmooring."" There's no way to know where they sourced a particular beat
column3: chord
column4: or vocal. This leaves a lot to imagination. The sounds of AS are primordial and alienatingly futuristic
column5: recalling all the worst parts of the uncanny valley. If we can begin to imagine what a cyborg’s chaotic inner id might be like
column6: you have to to listen to AS.

column1: Intense as AS may be
column2: it never becomes a slog or overly complex. The EP has an acute grasp on the rhythms and mood that make people dance. Even at its most mordant
column3: AS somehow remains accessible and exciting
column4: and prompts discovery by tricking you into dancing along to the strangest sonic triggers. It is a testament to the skill and inventiveness of these producers that they can make tracks like ""AS Chingy"" and ""AS Crust"" into implausible bangers. Both are nauseating
column5: vertigo-inducing tracks
column6: stitched together from pleading processed vocals
column7: defiantly herky-jerky percussions
column8: and cold greasy synths. It makes Amnesia Scanner utterly confounding. Even with biographical information in hand
column9: several music videos
column10: and art projects
column11:
you can't put your finger on Amnesia Scanner for one second. Music this uncomfortable is rarely so euphoric.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22827/homepage_large.07bbdbe9.jpg|A Cosmic Rhythm With Each Stroke|33626.0|Vijay Iyer / Wadada Leo Smith|['Jazz']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['ECM']|2016-03-23 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:48:42.306627|"

After John Coltrane’s death in 1967
column2: the improvisational avant-garde found itself asking: Now what? Wadada Leo Smith’s discography stretches back to this critical moment in American experimentalism. As an early member of a Chicago collective
column3: the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians (or AACM)
column4: the trumpeter worked in a trio that included saxophonist Anthony Braxton and violinist Leroy Jenkins—a group documented on the landmark 1968 release 3 Compositions of New Jazz.

column1: On that album and other recordings from the period
column2: Smith’s performance aesthetic signaled the arrival of a confident and original voice. He could craft mournful melodic lines that suggested the folk music of his Mississippi Delta youth
column3: before quickly steering into rough-sounding yet controlled smears of notes. Then
column4: in the midst of an improvisation
column5: he would allow stretches of silence to enter his phrasing. In contrast to New York’s consistently in-the-red style of free-jazz
column6: Smith and other AACM figures also experimented with world music instrumentation and modernist chamber composition in between passages of fiery blast.

column1: In this scene
column2: there was nothing strange about being a blues musician
column3: a composer of classical music
column4: and a free-improviser with a recognizable attack. And this example has proved a durable influence on younger jazz innovators like Vijay Iyer
column5: a pianist who spent time in Smith’s early-21st century quartet (before his own career as a bandleader took off). In interviews
column6: Iyer is often eager to credit the AACM as an inspiration behind his own mobility as a composer and soloist.

column1: Since signing to ECM
column2: the storied jazz-and-classical label
column3: Iyer has continued to vary his creative practice. The album Mutations found him composing for a string quartet
column4: while Break Stuff—the most recent set from Iyer’s celebrated jazz trio—included an acoustic tribute to Detroit techno innovator Robert Hood. On A Cosmic Rhythm With Each Stroke
column5: Iyer reconnects with Smith in a studio for the first time since appearing as a sideman on the trumpeter’s 2009 album Spiritual Dimensions. Their meeting here results in a frequently gorgeous
column6: sometimes roiling set that stands out in each artist’s catalog.

column1: The opener
column2: “Passage
column3: ” was composed by Iyer
column4: and works well as a platform for Smith’s range of instrumental techniques—with wisps of balladry leading to harsh and piercing moments. Some of Smith’s more surprising exclamations may initially seem like unmusical provocations
column5: just before he wrings a demonstration of magic from his trumpet—as when he keeps a seemingly unstable drone alive for seconds
column6: or when he creates a winning melody from an unlikely opening intonation. Iyer’s performance on piano lends dramatic shape to the track
column7: though he’s just getting started.

column1: The set’s centerpiece is a seven-part suite that also provides the album’s title. Inspired by the Indian artist Nasreen Mohamedi—her drawing graces the cover—this nearly hour-long stretch of music often finds Iyer switching seamlessly between acoustic piano and an electronic setup. “All Becomes Alive” begins with simmering traces of digital sound behind Smith’s high-register
column2: incantatory playing. Near the track’s conclusion
column3: Smith contributes tart
column4: pointillistic figures as Iyer uses a laptop to produce a bass-heavy pulse (while keeping both hands on his piano). In the middle section
column5: Smith responds to Iyer’s flowing
column6: legato progressions with a mellow soulfulness.

column1: The players occasionally push each other into less familiar zones. The first three minutes of “A Cold Fire” reveals Iyer playing more “out” than on his past ECM recordings
column2: while on “Labyrinths
column3: ” his joint interest in Indian classical composition and American minimalism guides Smith into fixed-tempo riffing of a kind that is unusual in the trumpeter’s catalog. And when Iyer switches to Fender Rhodes for “Notes on Water
column4: ” the musicians mine the mood of Bitches Brew-era Miles Davis
column5: while still sounding like themselves.

column1: In conceiving such far-ranging explorations of texture
column2: the risk for musicians is that the end result might wind up seeming like a catalog of possible approaches—a look-book to be skipped through by sound designers searching for film-music cues. But the rapport between Iyer and Smith ensures that this music always feels compositionally sure-footed
column3: even when parts of the suite are being discovered as they play.  No matter its track-to-track variance
column4: Cosmic always sounds harmonious as an album-length statement. In doing this
column5: it also recalls Smith’s early-career desire to integrate “all forms of music
column6: ” as stated in a 1969 interview with the French magazine Jazz Hot.

column1: Appropriately
column2: the closing track here is a Smith composition titled “Marian Anderson”—a dedication to the African-American contralto who broke the color barrier at the Metropolitan Opera in 1955. After the meditative theme
column3: Smith’s conjuring of a historic opera singer’s legacy seemingly gives him license to reveal some of his most songful
column4: pure-tone playing. “Everything and anything is valuable
column5: ” Smith told the European magazine in 1969
column6: as the first wave of AACM players was capturing the imagination of audiences on both sides of the Atlantic. More than four decades later
column7:
Smith is still demonstrating the wisdom of this approach—reaching back into American art-music history for inspiration while keeping himself open to the new sounds being proposed by the next generation.

Charli XCX hasn’t quite enjoyed the mainstream crossover she’s obviously capable of

column1: The lyrics to Vroom Vroom deal with being young

The path is so well charted that it's practically a ritual. Young artist creates track; track becomes hit; hit becomes phenomenon
column2: artist becomes famous. The track is undeniable and thus
column3: ubiquitous. Your parents are aware of it. Fans start to hate it
column4: though nowhere close to as much as the artist does. And then
column5: when the artist goes ahead and decides to make new music
column6: everything he does
column7: from the promotion to the concerts
column8: looks like a Sisyphean attempt to escape its shadow.

column1: The Brooklyn producer Baauer is observing the rites. He has called his Billboard-topping
column2: YouTube-dominating 2013 craze ""Harlem Shake"" ""corny and annoying as fuck"" and his new album Aa represents his ""defiant"" new beginning. For Baauer
column3: the problem is exacerbated by the fact that he had less to do with his own song's rise than strangers on the Internet. They were the ones who performed the alchemy that changed it from a jam
column4: to an Essential Mix standout to a viral soundtrack. ""I birthed it
column5: it was raised by others
column6: and now it's like my weird
column7: fucked-up adopted teenage kid coming back to me
column8: he said at the time.

column1: Sometimes
column2: talented career artists become one-hit wonders (Carly Rae Jepsen) and sometimes
column3: clowns who have stumbled upon
column4: or stolen
column5: something infectious do the same (Vanilla Ice.) The experience can be particularly difficult for an artist like Baauer
column6: a raw
column7: young musician with interesting ideas who has yet to fully develop. Following ""Harlem Shake
column8: Aa might feel to some like an undercooked
column9: scattershot album
column10: experimental to its own detriment. But if Baauer were an unknown musician —which
column11: artistically speaking
column12: he still essentially is — it'd be a rimshot of a debut
column13: crackling with energy and humor
column14: well-paced
column15: with no dud tracks and more than a few infectious ones.

column1: Aa is devoted to the block-party spirit of hip-hop
column2: in keeping with most of Baauer's work
column3: and at a time when various genres of electronic music are downplaying the black sources of their sound
column4: it's refreshingly willing to share both its influences and the limelight. Many of the tracks in its adrenaline-spiked back half are dominated by other artists
column5: as Baauer took advantage of the connections afforded him by ""Harlem Shake"" to collaborate with M.I.A.
column6: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/news/63722-baauer-future-and-pusha-t-team-for-kung-fu/"">Pusha T
column7: Future and Rustie. Their appearances aren't wasted. Features function like power-ups on Aa
column8: allowing the album to ascend in excitement
column9: leveling up to an almighty peak. (Baauer's clear love of collaboration and respect for the sounds he incorporates might also serve as a balm to those who were irritated by the way that the mainstream ""Harlem Shake"" dance craze completely ignored<a href=""http://www.theroot.com/articles/culture/2013/02/the_harlem_shake_viral_video_craze_what_about_the_original.html?wpisrc=root_more_news"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""> the original
column10: Cam'ron-approved dance.)

column1: The album's melting pot feel is consistent with that of Baauer's less-famous releases
column2: the EPs Dum Dum (2012) and ß (2014). His methodology is consistent: He excavates the undergirdings of genres like hip-hop
column3: R&B and dancehall
column4: and swaps in a new foundation
column5: often composed of wobbling
column6: thundering bass. After a couple of exploratory warning shots at the outset of Aa — the Rustie-inspired opener
column7: ""Church
column8: the drum n' bass n' trap banger ""GoGo!"" — the album settles into a groove on the explosive R&B of ""Body
column9: its first inescapable track
column10: which splits the difference between the producer's past work with AlunaGeorge and the soiled romanticism of electronic artists like Giraffage.

column1: From there
column2: it's a steady climb with stops along the way in Discovery-era Daft Punk soundalike (""Pinku"") and peace councils between back-alley grime and Bonecrusher-style mob music. (""Day Ones."") On songs like these
column3: Baauer demonstrates his ability to identify and recontextualize bite-size melodic candy
column4: and ""Harlem Shake's"" rise starts to look less like an Internet accident and more like inevitability. Check out the way he plays the Tetris theme song into the back end of ""Sow."" It's a goofy
column5: addictive gimmick that loses none of its melodic power for being so.

column1: In the tradition of many of the best electronic releases of the decade

column3: Baauer and the other artists meet the heavyweight expectations head-on. ""Temple
column4: the M.I.A. feature here
column5: is vintage Mathangi: She sounds as fresh and London-cocky as she did on Arular. And ""Kung Fu"" doesn't dare to waste Pusha T or Future. Pusha and Future have two of the most iconic voices in contemporary hip-hop
column6: and Baauer clearly understands the appeal of placing them as foils on the same track
column7: the brick-hard snarl and the ecstatic lament.

column1: If you want a file to show up at the top of an alphabetically-organized folder
column2: you can throw a bunch of A's at the front of its name
column3: and ensure that it will be there. But as much as Baauer may want Aa to define a new beginning

column5: there's no easy way for him to erase ""Harlem Shake."" He's doomed to be evaluated in the context of what will likely represent the peak of a certain kind of career success. The best he can do is what he's done here: rectify the wrongs of the craze that the track spawned while building on what it did right. Take advantage of the opportunities it's granted

throw an album-length party and encourage the dancers to come correct.

Twenty-three year old Bryndon Cook isn't a child of the '70s or '80s
column2: but you'd never guess that by listening to his work as Starchild & The New Romantic. He carries himself with the air of someone who's studiously thumbed through his parents' record collection. He cites Prince and Sade as primary influences
column3: and his stage name references P-Funk mythology. That said
column4: Cook also has a foot planted firmly in the current moment. His resumé as a touring guitarist reads like a who's who of forward-thinking R&B and electro-pop: Solange
column5: Dev Hynes
column6: Chairlift
column7: Kindness. He's equal parts laptop producer and pop classicist

column1: On his debut EP
column2: Crucial
column3: Cook (a former Pitchfork intern) traffics in woozy R&B numbers built atop dense
column4: keyboard-driven instrumentals. Take ""Relax
column5: which opens with the surface noise of a dusty record that gives way to squelchy synths

column1: Speaking of Prince

column3: given that Crucial borrows its title from a bootleg of studio outtakes that's been apocryphally credited to Prince and Miles Davis. ""New Romantic"" is built around a funk-indebted

column1: Crucial is remarkably dense for a self-recorded album

Fame on the Internet

column8: that
column9: while slight

column1: This is a standard dilemma for an artist like Makonnen at this crossroads
column2: but he exacerbates the problem by frequently flipping between wildly different personalities—brash trap-rapper
column3: which feels a little hollow; emotional rap singer

column6: after all

column1: He refined the balance of all of these elements on Drink More Water 5

column3: somewhat) and an official album (because it is for sale on iTunes). Like everything else he's done since 2014
column4: it feels inherently insecure

column6: but they are a little thinner
column7: and more grating.

column1: Constant experimentation doesn’t mean an artist is getting better

column1: The mild psych touches on the ballad ""Turn Off the Lies"" (geez that title) punch up the track

but it's starting to feel one-dimensional.
