column2: ""C'Mon Lets Drift""
column3: 'Maplemusic'
column4: 'Membran'
column6: the Joy Formidable have captured the trajectory of '90s alternative rock in just three albums. The Welsh trio's bravura 2011 full-length debut The Big Roar recreated the moment when underground rock crashed the mainstream with a sonic boom. It contains the band's only significant radio hit
column7: ""Whirring
column8: and it probably could have spawned two of three more of them if it hadn't arrived at a time when the public's appetite for herculean guitar rock was at an all-time low. 2013's Wolf's Law was the group's sprawling ""let's put our major label budget to use"" record
column9: the work of a band spreading their wings Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness-style
column10: attempting even bigger
column11: proggier sounds and hiring a string section just because they could. It was spottier than their debut
column12: but no less exciting
column13:
if only because it teased the new directions that might come next.

Unfortunately
column14: that makes their third album the disappointing realization that nothing new comes next. Hitch isn't just a retread of the band's previous work; it's a summation of all the ways the Alternative Nation has under-delivered since the new millennium. It's Billy Corgan throwing everything he has into a new album and coming up with the merely good-enough Oceania. It's the gradual realization that Dave Grohl had always been more into classic rock than he was punk. It's the Toadies securing a prime spot at Lollapalooza because they were the only reunited act of their era playing that year.

column1: It might not be a shock to see Joy Formidable eventually fall into the same pattern of diminishing returns as their predecessors
column2: but it still stings
column3: because they've been one of the genre's brightest young exports. Their magnificently loud yet melodically supple vision of big-tent rock has filled a void
column4: and on their earlier albums their blustery sound paired fabulously with singer/guitarist Ritzy Bryan's relatable songwriting. Her gargantuan riffs could make lyrics about routine personal experiences—miscommunications
column5: slights
column6: and romantic letdowns—sound like they were of enormous cosmic importance. And although it's never defined their image
column7: the group also has a righteous feminist streak. Many of Bryan's songs capture the frustration of being talked over; their sheer volume served as a kind of pushback to every man who presumed to know what she's trying to say without having the consideration to actually listen to what she was saying. Alternative could use more bands like this.

column1: But Hitch finds them in a holding pattern. ""Radio Of Lips"" is a virtual rewrite of the Wolf's Law lead single ""This Ladder Is Ours
column2: right down to its propulsive tempo and fluttery
column3: caffeinated-Cure guitar riff. It could be a knock-out song
column4: if it didn't linger for a full six and a half minutes. ""The Last Thing On My Mind"" dabbles in Zeppelin-y blues
column5: but similarly outstays its welcome. Bryan's guitars have always been the band's selling point
column6: but in such prolonged exposures they become downright numbing. The band self-recorded the album over 12 months in a self-built studio in their remote hometown Mold. They clearly spent a lot of time cooped up with these songs
column7: and it's as if they want they listener to feel cooped up with them
column8:
too.

Wolf's Law had the proggy ambitions to justify its bloat
column9: but Hitch's songs take much longer to do far less. Unsurprisingly
column10: then
column11: one of its highlights is one of its shortest. The song that most directly addresses Bryan's break-up from bassist Rhydian Dafydd—a break-up that could have easily ended a different band—""Fog (Black Windows)"" has the tight focus and light bounce of one of Bossanova's torch songs. ""These sheets are haunted / Not by you
column12: but by a moment that's long gone
column13: Bryan sings. And though she worries that ""a love like you will never come again
column14: she grasps at a silver lining: ""Maybe we're not alone after all."" It's a sweet moment
column15: a woman grieving a cherished relationship
column16:
while the very ex she's singing about coos supportively in the background. Everything that comes after it feels mechanical by comparison.

It's hard hearing a band with this much raw talent pour so much into an album that rarely gets off the ground. At times it almost sounds as if they know they've taken their current sound as far as it can go and seem palpably frustrated they can't figure out their next move. Near the end of the record—well into its 67-minute runtime—there's a song called ""Blowing Fire"" where Bryan vents about ""blowing fire for too long and getting nothing
column17: and the line sums up the band's newfound stagnancy so aptly it's as if they're daring critics not to throw it back at them. Fire still comes easy to the Joy Formidable
column18:
but Hitch is the first time they've seemed at a loss for how to use it.

The Brooklyn band Lucius has been a stylish presence on the tour and festival circuit for the past few years. Though the group released one album before Good Grief—2013’s Wildewoman—this sophomore collection feels like one of those debuts that arrive preternaturally fully-formed
column2: with songs as polished as the quintet's outfits. Singer-songwriters Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig
column3: who met while studying at the Berklee College of Music
column4: provide prominent

column1: It’s hard to talk about this sort of music without mentioning Haim

column3: mainstream pop has been setting acoustic toplines to synths for the better part of this decade. And after the notably crunchier Wildewoman

column5: ” with only minor adjustments for an acoustic setting

column8: ” befitting its title

column11: ” ‘50s rock and hyper-compression. A breathless sprint much like Chairlift’s “Romeo
column12: ” it’s an easy standout. Bonus track ""Let's Dance"" plays a neat trick of reproducing in acoustic form the stuttered and sampled textures that are near-ubiquitous in pop. Elsewhere
column13: on “Gone Insane

column4: German experimental record

column6: as far as referencing Taylor Swift

column14:
the issue’s settling upon one.

column1: It's a lot

For a generation of quirky girls
column2: No Doubt’s Gwen Stefani was the Grimes of 1995. She had the kind of look that parents hate (her hair was pink
column3: or blue
column4: or no-way-that’s-natural blonde
column5: her midriff was perpetually exposed) and a punk-ish sneer
column6: and she was at her finest when she was all riled up. She was also
column7: crucially
column8: a product of the post-grunge alternative landscape
column9: in which an Orange County ska band could edge up their sound and land a song on the Top 10 for 15 weeks. As popular music tastes shifted
column10: so did Stefani—and shrewdly
column11: for a time. She first tested the solo waters in 2000
column12: duetting with Moby on the deadpan banger “South Side” before moving on to an even more unlikely partner in crime
column13: Eve
column14: with “Let Me Blow Ya Mind” (i.e. the “Fancy” of 2001). Around this same time
column15: No Doubt’s new wave sheen turned towards Jamaican dancehall
column16: which made Stefani’s own pivot towards hip-hop feel more natural. In hindsight
column17: that hip-hop lean—like Stefani’s other acts of cultural appropriation—was questionable taste-wise
column18: not least because it encouraged Fergie. But like much of her career up to that point
column19: Gwen had enough attitude to pull it off.

column1: Stefani’s first solo album
column2: 2004’s Love. Angel. Music. Baby.
column3: had a few legitimately great singles
column4: the kind of radio hits that take a surprisingly long time to wear out. She also drew inspiration from unexpected places; one of those songs reinterpreted Fiddler on the Roof for the Juicy Couture crowd

column6: The Sweet Escape
column7: was essentially a dashed-off photocopy of its predecessor without the hits; given that weak showing
column8: and then the eventual No Doubt reunion
column9: it started to feel like Gwen solo was no longer a priority
column10: at least until she joined the cast of ""The Voice."" No one joins ""The Voice"" if they’re just trying to hawk their (mostly tasteful) clothing line. By the time a concrete announcement heralding Stefani’s solo return arrived
column11: she had repositioned herself towards the current mainstream once again.

column1: So who is Gwen Stefani in the year 2016? You might say she’s an ageless pop star dealing with her personal drama not just in the tabloids
column2: but on record. While this is a familiar and effective strategy for selling albums
column3: it’s also a jaded way to perceive This Is What the Truth Feels Like
column4: in part because Stefani—who co-wrote every song—seems to be genuinely torn over her own identity here. Long forgotten is the novelty that initially came with watching Gwen go full “TRL” and bring her inspiring weirdness to the masses. Here
column5: she plays a different kind of role model: the quintessential divorcee
column6: fresh off her messy split from Gavin Rossdale. Stefani forces herself to look forward as she navigates the thrill and insecurity of dating for the first time this millennium (ostensibly hand-in-hand with he who shall not be named)
column7: but sometimes
column8: she just can’t help looking back in anger and regret.

column1: As she did on her first two solo albums
column2: Stefani spends a bit of time trend-hopping through current Top 40
column3: from the spacious trap-lite of “You’re My Favorite” to the Bieber-hits-the-islands vibe of sext ode “Send Me a Picture” to “Asking 4 It
column4: ” where Fetty Wap slur-raps the album’s sole feature atop an unconvincing beat. These are decent tracks that affirm her ability to keep up with big pop of the moment (or rather
column5: of a year ago)
column6: but musically
column7: they are unremarkable
column8: and fail to match the unique specificity of her early solo hits. There’s only one “Gwen Gets Back On the Horse” song that really works—second single “Make Me Like You
column9: ” a disco confection that captures the deliciously complicated feeling of falling hard when you least expected.

column1: Stefani’s focus on the good times alternates with songs where she expresses cartoonish anger by awkwardly rapping and shouting non-sequiturs (“Naughty
column2: ” “Red Flag”)
column3: and neither mode plays to her strengths as a songwriter and signature vocalist. Her best songs are the ones in which she is audibly upset—sometimes pissed off
column4: sometimes sad
column5: but best-case scenario
column6: both. No Doubt’s “Don’t Speak” was a heartbreak anthem with a twinge of anger
column7: but with Truth lead single “Used to Love You
column8: ” Stefani—now 20 years wiser—flips it. “You can keep all the memories

column1: “Used to Love You” might be the greatest song Stefani has been involved in since “Don’t Speak

but it’s the fleeting moments like this—where she reminds us why we used to love her—that redeem This Is What the Truth Feels Like.

column5: of course

column7: the latter a masterpiece called Sonic Command. At times here
column8: they seem to go at one another's throat
column9: Merzbow's spirals of clipped-and-mangled signals lashing out against Boris' honeyed drone.

column1: Each time you run this gauntlet
column2: you will undoubtedly notice new cooperative nuances between the two acts
column3: particularly moments when Merzbow seems to be working to fit inside Boris' world and to augment it. When the band lurches into ""Sometimes
column4: for instance
column5: with sweeping guitar chords moving like tectonic plates beneath airy vocals
column6: he locks into a sustained signal and guilds it with quick
column7: near-manic cuts. It's as though he's adding a bass line and his version of a blast beat to the low
column8: slow rumble. He's almost playful during ""Akuma No Uta
column9: countering the band's grand
column10: ascendant riff with a crosstalk of dissonant bits and shards. Such moments
column11: though
column12: are either so few and far between or so constant (it's hard to determine which
column13: really) on Gensho that the entire experience becomes more arduous than enjoyable. Both Merzbow and Boris have built enormous legacies by being monolithic in sound and singular in style
column14: but those assets become liabilities here.

column1: Listening to these sets separately is actually the more interesting experience. The two-part ""Goloka"" suite
column2: which takes the middle 40 minutes of Merzbow's contribution
column3: finds the master in all his versatile glory. He slides seamlessly between electroacoustic radiance and concussive punishment
column4: between drones that are nearly pleasant and scrambles that suggest all the world's servers stalling at once. And the nine preexisting songs that Boris chose for this set—the tidal ""Farewell
column5: the snarling ""Vomitself
column6: the floating ""Rainbow""—are among the landmarks in an enormous catalog. Re-created here without drums
column7: they're newly fascinating
column8: with forgotten elements pulled suddenly into the spotlight. Boris' side of Gensho is the band's most assured and purely pleasurable album in years. As if knowing they'll be overshadowed by Merzbow's volume
column9: anyway
column10: the trio seems to be enjoying itself here
column11: delighting its way through the classics of its own canon. Perhaps it's best to think of Gensho
column12: then
column13: as a split box set.

column1: Still
column2: particularly for this era of instant
column3: easy access to almost everything
column4: Gensho is an intriguing
column5: subversive concept. It makes the listener work to hear the music as it's intended
column6: and that process allows the listener input as to how
column7: exactly
column8: the music should be heard. Which side should be louder? Who gets the right channel? Should the stereos used be the same? Gensho feels delightfully out of step with our present notions of convenience
column9: our belief that music should practically come to us if it wants to be heard. It's not quite so extreme as the infamous Merzcar
column10: in which Merzbow's Noisembryo was locked crypt-style into the CD player of a decrepit Mercedez-Benz
column11: but it's certainly more involved than Adele circumventing Spotify.

column1: Alas
column2: that challenge is the most lasting aspect of the least rewarding partnership between Boris and Merzbow to date. By the fourth or fifth trip through Gensho
column3: the idea begins to slip into pure gimmickry
column4: as though this were a notion that sounded fun for old friends to try but isn't so fun to hear. What's more
column5: Boris' decision to plunder its back catalog for such an album dovetails with the recent feeling that this band
column6: no matter how hard it tries
column7: is simply running out of ground and energy. They couldn't even be bothered to write new songs for this old
column8:
borrowed concept. At least it's good to revisit the ghosts of a force that seems to be fading.

Talk Tight
column2: the debut by the Melbourne quintet Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever
column3: is presented as a “mini-LP”: seven rip-roaring tracks that move by their own logic
column4: any one of which could be a single and all of which leave you wanting more in the best way possible. The group’s revolving team of singers and songwriters (everybody but the drummer takes a turn on the mic) chronicle knotty relationships and winding road trips
column5: but taken together
column6: these songs are after something more public than personal. Asked by the blog Triple J Unearthed what inspires the band
column7: singer-guitarist Fran Keaney hinted at their music’s true subject: “It’s going to sound all at once lame
column8: wanky and vague but: Australia? As in the concept of Australia. What it was
column9: What it is…”

column1: There are too many qualifiers in that response to believe he’s taking the piss on a question that’s impossible to answer. And on Talk Tight
column2: the band evokes certain aspects of Australia in the sunbaked surf-pop guitar licks and taut punk momentum
column3: both carefree and a little cautious and therefore perfect for a country that’s home to this fucking thing. Listening to these seven tunes
column4: you can easily trace a national lineage: the relentlessness of Radio Birdman
column5: the pop literacy of the Go-Betweens
column6: the rambunctious energy of the Easybeats
column7: and the belief—shared with Courtney Barnett—that guitars are not just crucial to the message but might very well be the message themselves.

column1: Even in Melbourne
column2: which seems to produce more great guitar bands per capita than any other city in the world
column3: Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever stand out for the precision of their melodies
column4: the streamlined sophistication of their arrangements
column5: and the undercurrent of melancholy that motivates every note. This is a band that thrives on contradiction and duality
column6: pitting opposing urges against each other. To describe their own sound
column7: the members coined the term “tough pop/soft punk
column8: ” which is apt as a label as well as a refusal to pare themselves down to any one particular thing.

column1: As that awkward name suggests
column2: Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever often sound like they’re in fact two different bands. There’s the group behind midtempo opener “Wither With You
column3: ” which falls squarely in the “tough pop” category. In this mode
column4: each instrument contributes to a swirl of melody and the guitars chime and ramble as Tom Russo chronicles the strained dissolution of a relationship: “Oh your pretty face is curling up in anger
column5: ” he sings
column6: in a tone that might deepen rather than defuse her fury. “Just keep in mind
column7: my darling
column8: I did it all for you.” Keeping it from sounding bitter is the nimble rhythm section
column9: the genial snap of Marcel Tussie’s drums and Joe Russo’s loping bassline. Here and on “Tender Is the Neck
column10: ” the group foreground mood over momentum
column11: establishing an autumnal ambience that underscores the bittersweet reminiscence of the lyrics.

column1: The band’s other mode is to play at the punk end of the Aussie spectrum
column2: closer to Royal Headache or Eddy Current Suppression Ring. The tempos quicken noticeably
column3: with half-shouted vocals and guitars that fight not for the lead but for the rhythm parts. Tussie and Russo chug along diligently
column4: as though timekeeping were the true rock star’s responsibility. You hear it in songs like “Wide Eyes
column5: ” a fierce travelogue that explodes with tightly coiled jangle and angsty wanderlust. They might be too soft to trash a club
column6: but the Blackouts ably wring the last bit of tension from the skeletal “Clean Slate
column7: ” with its intricate curlicue riffs and fidgety call-and-response.

column1: The great trick of Talk Tight is how Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever find the overlap between those conflicting pop and punk impulses. Even at their fiercest they’re happy romantics (“You run the bath
column2: and I’ll warm the pasta
column3: girl”) as well as sensualists (“Your hair stands up when I kiss the back of your neck”)
column4: qualities that seem rare in any band. Rarer still is their precarious balance of idealism and realism
column5: which defines the closer
column6: “Career
column7: ” about a friend who traded his rebellion and defiance for “a silk tie and an ’09 Ford.” It might sound dismissive and taunting if Russo and Keaney didn’t sound half-tempted themselves. They’re wise to the compromises that accrue with the years
column8: but they’d rather stay on the road
column9:
rumbling through Australia and beyond like a tidal wave obliterating every coast.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22927/homepage_large.4c9ae413.jpg|Trekkie Trax the Best 2012 - 2015|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Trekkie Trax']|2016-03-21 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 15:48:50.407851|"

Between social media streams delivering seemingly endless awful news and the creeping sense that we’ve entered content singularity
column2: it’s pretty easy to feel cynical about the state of the Internet in 2016. That same sense of digital constriction extends to music
column3: a place filled with lukewarm takes and fast food restaurants toddling towards relevance. It’s overwhelming
column4: but not hopeless. Plenty of artists have carved out space online where they can create new communities and explore new sounds. They exist far from the regular churn of the Web
column5: just waiting for like-minded people to find them.

column1: Japan’s “netlabel” scene has offered this escape for nearly 15 years. Online imprints such as Maltine Records and Bunkai-Kei Records gave space for young producers with little way of entering the country’s mainstream music industry to experiment—not to mention provide an alternative to a club culture hampered by laws straight out of Footloose. One of the bigger names to emerge in the Japanese netlabel world recently is Trekkie Trax
column2: a collective launched by a few 20-somethings in 2012 that has put out around 50 releases from a global roster of talent and developed a reputation for energetic in-real-life shows across Tokyo. Trekkie Trax the Best 2012-2015 compiles some of the label’s finest cuts
column3: and serves as a great introduction to one of Japan’s best outfits bubbling up from the Internet.

column1: Trekkie Trax’s emergence parallels the Japanese commercial boom in EDM
column2: and many moments on this compilation feature elements of the genre. It’s natural for the young artists here to be attracted to hard-hitting sounds aimed at listeners their age
column3: but the results end up mixed when they cling too closely to the style. The Best lags when simply trying to replicate a buzzy Skrillex drop or Middle-Eastern-tinged Diplo hook
column4: but shines when a producer finds a new angle to the familiar. Masayashi Iimori’s “Break It” draws from the aggressive stylings of trap all the way down to the air horn samples
column5: but offsets the hyped-up centers with longer passages that ramp up the drama significantly. AMUNOA's “Cinderella Song (VIP)” uses similarly clanging beats and vocal samples to get things going
column6: but dusts them with wispy synthesizer that adds an emotional longing to the track.

column1: Youthfulness ultimately helps the Trekkie Trax crew stand out
column2: the artists appearing on The Best capturing the energy of early adulthood when anything seems possible. They are digital natives
column3: producers who grew up with the Web and are eager to throw as many ideas as possible into their dance tracks. Snail’s House embraces elements evoking Japan’s “kawaii” culture—helium-injected vocals
column4: big colorful keyboard notes—on “Kirara
column5: ” while matra magic plunks snippets of Lil Wayne between gloopy synth drips. Kyoto's In the Blue Shirt combines split-second vocal slices with breezy ocarina on “Free Will
column6: ” but he engineers this potentially twee patchwork into a bouncy blast of sunshine. These moments come off like personal details woven into high-BPM numbers
column7: a chance to add character to numbers that function best as uptempo club cuts.

column1: For all the wonkiness
column2: the label is at their best when barreling forward. Tokyo’s Carpainter gives UK garage a spin on “Journey to the West
column3: ” delivering a woozy number propelled by tribal percussion and opting to slowly reveal new details over a consistently driving tempo rather than build up to a huge moment of release. Even better is duo Lolica Tonica’s “Make Me Feel
column4: ” a jittery electro-rush somewhere between breakcore and Jersey Club. On a collection full of songs featuring vocal samples tripping over themselves
column5: “Make Me Feel” is a highlight thanks to pure exuberance
column6: nailing the nervous excitement of just letting loose.

column1: Trekkie Trax didn’t reinvent anything over the last three years—artists in the Maltine Records universe laid down this path years ago
column2: and those in Trekkie Trax point to Maltine as a massive influence on them. Rather
column3: they are shepherding the netlabel spirit to the next generation of Japanese listeners
column4: while also making a greater push internationally by using the net as an amplifier to spread electronic music from artists hailing from places rarely getting the same attention as their Western equals. The Best offers a concise gateway into their world
column5: highlighting the sonic diversity of their crew and their intensity. They found room online to share their energy
column6:
and are using the Internet to bring it to anyone looking for an alternative.

Mike Eagle doesn’t rap; he talks to you in rhythmic form
column2: calmly unpacking his narrative as the world around him spirals out of control. Emcees like Eagle
column3: Action Bronson
column4: Aesop Rock
column5: and Homeboy Sandman have this uncanny way of drawing you into what they say
column6: despite unusual references that don’t always connect. Theirs is a conversational cadence full of random observations; and with Eagle
column7: he can discuss wrestler Rick Martel’s cologne and the struggles of being a black man with the same verve
column8: even if those topics are completely dissimilar. Eagle comes off like the everyman with whom you can talk about anything
column9: an alternative to trap-rap
column10: although he’s dexterous enough to drift in all sorts of directions.

column1: Take last year’s “Raps for When It’s Just You and the Abyss” as an example: Beneath a slow churning instrumental
column2: you can see Eagle methodically pacing back and forth
column3: pulling disparate factoids from his brain: “Was pretty geeked about my L.A. Weekly feature/ I showed it to my dad
column4: my barber and my piano teacher.” On “A History of Modern Dance
column5: ” the Jeremiah Jae-produced standout of Eagle’s Dark Comedy LP
column6: he connects equally scattered thoughts using melodic flows: “People walk into circles … every audience listens … they taking turns judging … everybody got issues.” It doesn’t matter how Eagle conveys his messages
column7: the songs end up feeling direct and honest
column8: as if he’s looking you squarely in the face to make sure you get the point.

column1: There’s no shortage of peculiar insight on Hella Personal Film Festival
column2: Eagle’s collaborative album with British producer Paul White. On “Drunk Dreaming
column3: ” he envisions President Obama in a small drone and sees Dr. Martin Luther King
column4: Jr. on a moving bus. He flubs rhymes on “I Went Outside Today” and trails off slightly on “Dive Bar Support Group.” The mistakes probably wouldn’t work for most rappers
column5: but in Eagle’s case
column6: it makes him even more relatable. For roughly 46 minutes
column7: he observes life with the same gusto he always has
column8: except these songs play like short movies set in a different era. The track titles are quirky—“Dang is Invincible
column9: ” “A Short About a Guy That Dies Every Night
column10: ” “Admitting the Endorphin Addiction”—and the content is largely esoteric
column11: yet Eagle tempers it just enough for broader consumption.

column1: On “Check to Check
column2: ” for instance
column3: he riffs on society’s obsession with smartphones
column4: the fact that we can’t function without looking at our devices every few minutes. White creates a frenetic cosmic funk beat that exemplifies life’s rapid pace
column5: and Eagle darts through it with a nervous energy that complements the track: “Battery getting low
column6: but it’s not quite out yet/ So check
column7: I’m in ya house now checkin’ for outlets/ I need to use maps ‘cause I don’t know the route yet/ I need to see an email
column8: I don’t know when the soundcheck.” The song
column9: which sits near the album’s beginning
column10: is the best example of Eagle and White’s synergy. The beat shifts with each verse
column11: growing more infectious as the rapper grows more restless.

column1: Festival feels steeped in ’70s soul—from the guitar lick on “Admitting the Endorphin Addiction” to the Curtis Mayfield-style harp on “I Went Outside Today.” White’s music fades further back as the album plays; songs like “Protectors of the Heat” and “Insecurity Part II” are made up of simple mouth clicks
column2: light drums
column3: and scant keys. Overall
column4: the album begins quickly before it slows to a moderate pace
column5: on which Eagle fills the second half with self-assessing thoughts on race (“Smiling”) and societal despair (“Reprieve”).

column1: It makes sense that Eagle and White would come together for a project like this. Separately
column2: they hit similar creative marks and speak to the same alt-rap demographic
column3: despite taking divergent paths to get there. Festival is refreshingly cohesive
column4: exploring varied themes without drifting off-course. Then again
column5: that’s not saying much for Eagle and White
column6: who’ve long established their own unique lanes. These songs foreshadow a much larger story
column7:
one that only these two can tell.
